Post ID:114
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-16 13:51:40
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Working Class/ Middle Class
Message:

Chris,

I too work, and hard!--when I'm not bogged down with being a student as of 
late ;]--however, I do not consider myself to be "working class" per se.  I 
am the sole proprietor of a small carpentry business.  I own my own work 
vehicle and my own tools.  If I don't want to go to work in the morning, I 
don't because nobody can fire me.  I would say that my relationship to 
production is "petty bourgeois" in nature, albeit at the smallest scale 
possible & democratically inclined.

"Middle Class" is propaganda terminology, effectively enforcing the Labor 
Aristocracy which the Bourgeoisie (Capitalist ruling class) use to keep the 
majority of the working class in check. It's used much in the same way as 
"American Dream" is used.  These terms usually conjur up the myth of what 
America promises to those who go along with things (ala Forrest Gump)  Most 
working class people that I know consider themselves middle-class, and have 
the ideas and aspirations of the ruling class, i.e. their boss, Rush 
Limbaugh, Hollywood, etc.  As such, this consciousness is imbued with 
character traits of the ruling class: individualism, me-ism, consumerism, 
etc.

Like I said, I can opt to not go to work in the morning, or to seek a 
lucrative renovation contract that will make organizing less economically 
appealing.  Most students/intellectuals can go home to their parents, or ask 
them to send money.  Professionals tend to become quite comfortable in this 
"booming" ecomony.  Artists tend to become consumed by themselves (I'm 
speaking from experience!)  All of these "Classes" have characteristics that 
make them unreliable AS A CLASS.  Why?  It's not because they are all bad or 
mean spirited.  It's because their class interests tending towards 
individualism, etc. as stated, making them vulnerable to being divided, 
prone to react in SELF interest & expose them to the character traits of the 
ruling class pumped out by their multi-faceted media for mass consumption.

My understanding of "working class" are folks who have a boss & don't own 
the means of production, not to mention the goods they produce.  They are 
generally payed a small fraction of the wealth they produce. They can be 
fired, downsized, de-unionized, & un-benifited, etc. As such, they have 
common interests and a common struggle.  Ideally, unions themselves are an 
expression of this.  (Again, this is thwarted with the Labor Aristocracy, 
Sell Out Union Bosses, etc.)

As far as this concerns the NB Peoples Campaign:  I stated that I agree with 
X that we need to be less concerned with isolating the so-called "Middle 
Class" and more concerned allying with the working class.  New Brunswick is 
still a working class town.  The minute you step off the college campuses, 
this is makes itself apparent.  I don't have figures to back this up, but my 
5-6 years of living in NB confirm that most people are working Joes & Janes 
who, when it comes right down to it, have similar concerns, similar 
grievances against the machine, and simliarly have very little clout with 
the Machine to get their demands realized--aka: Political Power.  
Furthuremore, their economic status makes them the most willing to fight in 
a consistant way.  They have the family ties, the social networks, children 
in schools, the knowledge of how things work and how to organize their lives 
to survive.

So the workers TOGETHER with the the artists, the intellectuals and the 
professionals, etc. who support the democratic struggle & join the united 
front will make this happen.  We are all under assault by this system.  
Ideas cannot proliferate, the environment is being devestated, mediocrity in 
music, the arts and architecture has become the norm, science is 
prostituted, history washed away.  This is why we say that since 10% of the 
people control 90% of the wealth, then the other %90 of the people have some 
reason to unite and, (dare I say...) SEIZE POLITICAL POWER!

Matthew Smith





>From: CHRIS KOZLOWSKI <CKOZLOWSKI@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: "'nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com'" <nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com>
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Logo
>Date: Thu, 16 Mar 2000 01:39:35 -0500
>
>Matt, I would like you to clarify what the distinction is between "middle
>class" and "working class" in your perception.  Or do you identify the
>middle class with capitalists?  If the working class does not include the
>middle class, then we certainly are not talking about "the majority"
>anymore.
>
>Just a thought -- seems relevant to me.  I work, and I am middle class.
>
>Chris
>
>
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Matthew Smith
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Sent: 3/15/00 11:09 PM
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Logo
>
>Paul- Not to get too semantical
>--Upon FURTHER further consideration, I ammend my position to that of
>support for "seizure" of power.  Xavier's recent piece provided needed
>clarity (Again, I am at the unfortunate disadvantage of not being
>directly
>involved in the process of campaign development) But essentially, I
>agree
>with X that we need to be clear and honest about who and what we are up
>against.  The Machine is not going to hand over the reigns of power so
>easily.  They have blood on their hands, and they have everything to
>loose
>while the people have everything to gain.  Seizing Power is what it is.
>
>They will put up a fight and we will have to be more cunning to wrestle
>it
>away.  Knowing this, we can conclude that we really must "Seize the
>Day!"...BY WHATEVER MEANS NECESSARY (Today the ballot box, tomorrow...)
>I
>also concur with X that we must be less concerned with isolating the
>so-called middle-class and more concerned with allying ourselves with
>the
>working class who are ultimately going to be the driving force behind
>this
>campaign if its going to be successful.  As for the Logo, the current
>one
>needs work graphically if it's going to be used for a banner, but that
>can
>be arranged...See y'all Thursday at the Court Tavern 7pm or Paulie's
>Fri/Sat.  Matthew

Post ID:115
Sender:"paul mcgee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-16 16:18:08
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Outreach Minutes
Message:

At long last, here are the Outreach Minutes for all of our meetings. Paul

New Brunswick People's Campaign Outreach Committee

Minutes of Outreach Meeting of 2/4 (Unapproved)

1.   Next meeting @ Nicole's house @ 3pm Sun. 2/13.
2. Agreed to have voter reg. Workshop to ensure precision and verification.
3. Tasks of Survey discussed.
4. Canvassing to be Saturdays and Sundays. Will meet @ 1pm and 12noon 
respectively, at NB Library.
5. Agreed to have point person for each day of canvass, responsible for 
coordinating canvassers, mat'ls, etc.
6. Debrief session to follow canvass.
7. Paul agreed to develop tick sheet and copy for 2/5, 2/6 canvass.

Minutes of Outreach Meeting of 2/13 (Unapproved)

1. Cliff volunteered to try to bring Spanish speaking canvassers.
2. Julie and Sam to plan canvass for weekend of 2/19.
3. Julie and Sam to obtain maps of New Brunswick.
4. Paul to obtain new materials issued by media committee-Spanish flyers, 
etc.
5. Paul to copy all materials needed for canvass.
6. Zofia to provide Paul with updated survey incl. new questions.
7. Sam to coordinate surveys and tick sheets from canvass.
8. Committee agreed to hold press event to highlight canvass on 2/19.
9. Julie and Nikki to write press release and contact press for 2/19 press 
event.
10. Sam to call all involved in campaign re canvassing.
11. Xavier and Zofia to prepare fact sheet with talking points for 
canvassers.
12. Committee decided to divide up phone numbers and names obtained in 
canvass and to call about Feb. 26 meeting and to ask individuals to 
distribute flyers to neighbors.
13. Nicole to obtain space in George St. Co-op for next meeting.
14. Next meeting 2/20 @ 4p.m.


Minutes of 2/20 Outreach Meeting (unapproved)

1. Paul ran down minutes of last meeting, updates on progress.
2. Paul to draw up proposal for caravan to take place in one month, approx.
3. Xavier to arrange for Spanish flyers for next canvass date.
4. Paul to submit minutes, expense report to 2/26 general meeting.
5. Nicole spent $50 deposit with George St. Coop to hold weekly meeting 
space.
6. Question of committee authority to be brought to 2/26 general meeting.
7. Sam to call all in coalition for next canvass, and to call Outreach 
committee with names collected from canvass.
8. Sam and Julie to plan canvass strategy against voting results of 1998 
election.
9. Meetings scheduled for 4p.m., Sundays @ George St. Coop.
10. Tara to create database with master list of names from community 
collected on canvass.
11. Paul to ready fliers, survey material for Sunday 2/27 canvass.


Minutes of 2/27 Outreach Meeting (unapproved)

1. Canvass is proceeding smoothly with over 150 surveys taken.
2. Xavier to forward new campaign flyer to Paul.
3. Paul to copy flyers, surveys, tick sheets.
Motorcade for April 1.
4. Paul to organize banner/placard production.
5. Paul to write press release, forward to Media.
6. Xavier to provide sound equip. and a band.
7. Joe Smith to rent a flatbed truck.
8. Paul to secure a generator.
9. Paul and Sam to recruit legal observers for the day.


Outreach Meeting of 3/5

1. Committee decided to request Steering recruit more canvassers. Xavier to 
deliver message.
2. Progress on preparations for motorcade discussed.
3. Progress of canvass discussed.

Outreach Minutes 3/12

1.     Joe to copy, distribute motorcade flyer.
4. Motorcade route confirmed.
5. Paul to database list of interested residents.
6. Paul to organize banner and sign making for 3/17 @ 7pm @ his house.
7. X to confirm flatbed.
8. Julie to get walking lists for 1998 poll results.
9. Joe to confirm performers for motorcade.
10. Idea to survey students in class, churchgoers in at services proposed.
11. Goal of 1000 completed surveys set for convention.


______________________________________________________

Post ID:116
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-16 17:56:58
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Right to Know
Message:

Zophia- I have couple of Right to Know items to lay on you as well. Pat 
Whalen--Attornius Stupendus--had sent me a recent article about the 
conviction of one Attornius Corruptus, Ms. Linda Anderson (no relation) 
whose case we've been following for awhile (She's tied to the city  machine 
up to her neck & is likely a weak link for them.)  You might consider 
calling Paul to ask if he's contacted Curtis.  According to Paulie, Curtis 
has alot of the Coalition Documents in storage (RE: Research on Right to 
Know info, &ct.) We may want to sit down with Paul, Curtis, Janice, Sam, 
Linda & discuss how to 1.)Tie the coalition's efforts in with the Peoples 
Campaign, & 2) Get some of these things roling again.  For instance the 
Coalition was/is a phone call away from advancing their Right to Know 
lawsuit (w/ NJFO) into the courts.  This according to Renee Steinhagen of 
the NJ Public Interest Law Center who wrote up our RTK Request origninally.  
Anyhow, Paul has the necessary contacts.  I'll be at Paul's Friday night, 
Saturday all day.  Matthew Smith

Post ID:117
Sender:CHRIS KOZLOWSKI <CKOZLOWSKI@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-17 11:08:51
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] FW: media minutes for 3/15/00
Message:

                          Media Committee Minutes
                         Wednesday, March 8, 2000

Attended:  DJL, Keith, Chris, Jim, Nikki

    HOW CAN WE STEP IT UP?
         Use the press more systematically
         LTE every week
         Big press conference b/f April convention  (possibly about an
issue rather than the general            campaign)
        DISCUSSION:  have we had enough media hits about the actual
issues that we are basing our platform off of???
         Have press releases every other week
         Feed off of other's people's press (e.g. if there's alreadya
press conf set up be there handing            out our own releases to
press)
         We need someone to be the archivist for all of the press hits
we've had thus far to keep               track of consistency of message
         Must come up with a comprehensive plan for our media strategy
    WHERE WE SHOULD BE
         Jim presents list of events from last city council meeting
(NEXT
EVENT:  Peace March on        the 22nd at 5pm on College Ave (hosted by
church on Suydam)
         Get our research stuff on the internet and in the newsletter
         Next press-worthy events:  M&C police hearings, March 25th
Meeting, April 1st Caravan
    10:30pm-Midnight:  political ranting at Keith's (beer and
chain-smoking included)
    FOR NEXT MEETING
         Analyze minutes from meetings past; where do we go from here?
         Come up with solid media plan on paper
         Come up with our day of canvassing with Outreach Comm.
         Put together comprehensive media contact database

Post ID:124
Sender:JimmyFishHead@...
Post Date/Time:2000-03-18 13:13:49
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Upcoming Events
Message:

I concur.  My experience with this event has been that any issues detracting 
focus of it's core message may be frowned upon by it's participants and 
organizers.  It may however be worth a contact to organizers of the event to 
gauge their interest in the mission of NB Peoples Campaign and have them 
suggest ways, if any, for us to work together.  This could be an additional 
opportunity to bridge the gap between the NB and University women's community.
Jim.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:126
Sender:Chris Kozlowski <CKOZLOWSKI@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-20 00:56:38
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Web site hacked.
Message:

Less than a few hours after the last post, between 10:30 and 11:30 tonight,
the campaign site was hacked, and several key directories were removed.

We have some backups, but not all -- we figured that we would suffer attack,
but there was not enough there to warrant an effort at this point... damn.

Just a heads-up to those who are wondering why the site is not operational.
The next one will have seriously beefed-up security, which I am already
planning for.  We need to keep in mind what we are up against here...

My brain is rattled, and I'm going to bed.  I'll keep you abreast of any
further developments.

Chris





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:129
Sender:FBright123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-03-20 22:50:55
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] RTK Minutes
Message:

Right to Know Committee
Minutes 3/18/00

Agenda

1. Review last weeks minutes of meeting
2. Review Council meeting and planning board
3. Integration of work that coalition against police brutality
4. Getting on egroups
5.  Voter reg update
6.  Discuss approach to work
7.  Redevelopment update
8.  Brian's info on tax policy

1.  Review of last weeks minutes.  New law - increased absorb beyond 55% of 
all new capital construction to be covered by the state of NJ.

3.  Coalition Against Police Brutality has extensive files, around Sissy 
Adams and RTK lawsuit.  They would like to brung this to us, work together 
and start plowing through some of it.  They have all the depositions of the 
Consalvo and Marshall and Chinchilla case.  The coalition wrote a request w/ 
Renee Steinhagen, Director of the NJ Public Interest Law Center - she just 
represented the 14 black state cops.  There is a 10 pt request demanding 
information - from very general history of police complaints, plus the 
personnel files of Kenneth Milroy �Crater Face� - includes points on many 
people.  The requests for informaiton were denied, and after a series of 
requests the next step is to bring a court case against the City of New 
Brunswick, the NB Prolice Department, and the Middlesex County Prosecutors 
office.  At this time, there is a new case  that surfaced - a lawyer Linda 
Anderson - was stealing money - she was Officer Zane Gray�s lawyer, then 
Potts family advocate, and did not support the Potts family vis a vis the 
justice system at all.  There is an investigation by Robert Regan on Zane 
Gray.  In the summertime, everything was ready to move forward.  Renee 
emailed the Coalition about this legal action recently - we need to call her 
and move forward.  RTK call members of Coalition, get on board, sit down with 
their information, archive it to move foreward with this request.  This can 
work in conjunction with the current right to know demands at the state 
level.  X said that legal work will probably be moved to the RTK committee, 
although he is currently coordinating the legal efforts.  F has a concern 
regarding legal coordination.   Beyond this, Paul has a tentative plan of 
action formulated for a couple months down the road.  Matt will call Renee.  
Frank will be the liaison to gather all the information from Curtis.  Q:  
What do we want to produce?  When the news came out in the paper regarding 
the release of Marshall and Chinchilla, we as a group did not have enough 
information to respond appropriately - so we all need to be up to speed.  
Paul will find out the exact status of the Coalition Against Police 
Brutality.  Q of whether Peoples Campaign should join with Coalition Against 
Police Brutality.  Matt will ask Renee for process of NJFO.  Frank will call 
Matt on history of Coalition Against Police Brutality.  We need to develop a 
broader police platform.  

Can we view peoples names on the egroups and what msgs people sent?

We discussed the concern of posting our minutes on the egroups.  This info is 
public.  Anyone can go to the group and download the archives of messages - 
it could give the other side the heads up on our actions, could come out on 
the front page of the Home News, and it is possible that someone could be 
sued as a result of the discussions.  Also, some people are not entering 
discussion on the egroup to protect themselves, and this limits the 
discussion.  One suggestion was to create a separate more restricted egroup 
only for members - so noone could look at the posted or the list of names on 
the egroup, and a moderator would ensure it is only for members.  This would 
be for minutes, polemics, strategy.  The egroups would be just for 
announcements. Lets wait to post minutes until we talk to the steering 
committee.

A second question was raised - how can we make sure that those not on email 
get the minutes.  It should be the job of the committee leaders to print out 
minutes from each group and pass them out to their members who do not have 
access.

Updates:  City council, voter reg, planning board

City Council
Frank Bright and Jim Luceno present.  Bill Hamilton, City Attorney, has been 
hearing about us around town through uninvolved third parties.  There is a 
lot of public forums we need to be prepared for as a research group - July 
4th, Boyd Park, 7:30 pm - 10:00 pm.  Peace march Suydam Street reformed 
Church, Wed, March 22nd, 5-8 pm.College Ave-Somerset, Easton, Albany, Joyce 
Kilmer Ave, Suydam, Drift.  Time:  5-8pm.  Zofia will go and ask what is 
going on. Take Back the Night, April 13 - starts at 7, 9-11 march down 
College Ave.  Holocaust Commemoration, Monday the April 17th, 7pm-10pm.  June 
10th, NB Annual Food and Music Festival 5 am 10pm.  Hungarian Fest June 3rd, 
Somerset St.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:130
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-21 00:15:17
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: RTK Minutes/Libel
Message:

Frank--Regarding concern of Libel issues/rumors relating to information 
posted on egroup from RTK minutes:

Perhaps it is enough just to say that "this and that were discussed; more 
pending...".  We can then come foward when information is concrete.  We 
should avoid getting our signals crossed right now.

(For instance, it's unlikely that the Coalition has ALL depositions from 
Consalvo/ Marchal/ Chinchilla cases.  What we do have we were given in 
confidence, on account of peculiar nature of "source" relationship to case, 
etc.  Let us look at what exists, make an assessment on how to proceed and 
come out strong.)

*Zophia did check with me about what to include in the minutes post, and I 
told her that getting info out widely is key to our security.  I still think 
this is true, but realize that we must be tight, not give reason for city to 
discredit us or our information.  --Matthew


______________________________________________________

Post ID:131
Sender:"Barbara Horne" <aunatural@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-21 05:08:18
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] 8PM WEDNESDAY
Message:

Feel free to come b4 8PM or when the show is over and distribute flyers and 
if you like, we can set it up so that one of the hosts can make a few 
announcements for the campaign.

Barb
______________________________________________________________________
8PM THIS WEDNESDAY MARCH 22ND, THE RUTGERS COLLEGE
PROGRAMMING COUNCIL BRINGS YOU POETRY PALOOZA

FEATUING...

HBO'S OZ MUM'S THE SCHEMER
Nile River Gods...Talaam and Faraji
Ladayne
Twin Poets
2 dogs and a Cat
         ...Helena Lewis...Flow Mentalz...Kirk Nungent
Guy LeCharles Gonzales
Jen Stanton
Jamal St. John
                        HOSTED BY
Demetrius tha Poet and Lyric author of "Release"

     LIVE JAZZ AND FUNK...FEATUING MELVIN MCKNIGHT...
                          Food
                  ALL FREE OF CHARGE

MULTIPURPOSE ROOM
BUSCH CAMPUS CENTER

DIRECTIONS
http://www.rutgers.edu/kiosk/directions/BCC.html

By train: take NJ tranisit to New Brunswick and a cab
to the Busch Campus Center



From New Jersey Turnpike (North or South)
Turn off at Exit 9. After toll booths bear to the
right; follow signs for "Route 18 North - New
Brunswick." Continue along Route 18 North past the
exits for "Route 27" and "Rutgers University" and
proceed over the Raritan River on the John Lynch
Memorial Bridge. (Approx. 3.7 miles) On the other side
of river proceed straight at the traffic light onto
Metlars Lane. Continue on Metlars Lane to Bevier Road,
the third left-hand turn. Follow Bevier Road to the
intersection of Bevier and Bartholomew Roads. Bear
right onto Bartholomew Road. The BCC is on the left.

From Garden State Parkway (North or South)
Southbound - Coming from northern New Jersey
�	Turn off at Exit 129 for the New Jersey Turnpike and
head south.
�	Follow directions to campus from Route 18 North,
below.
Northbound - Coming from southern New Jersey
�	Turn off at Exit 105 and follow signs for Route 18
North.
�	After approximately 24 miles you will pass the
entrance for the New Jersey Turnpike and continue on
Route 18 North.
Proceed along Route 18 North past the exits for "Route
27" and "Rutgers University" and proceed over the
Raritan River on the John Lynch Memorial Bridge.
(Approx. 3.7 miles) On the other side of river proceed
straight at the traffic light onto Metlars Lane.
Continue on Metlars Lane to Bevier Road, the third
left-hand turn. Follow Bevier Road to the intersection
of Bevier and Bartholomew Roads. Bear right onto
Bartholomew Road. The BCC is on the left.

From Route 1 (North or South)
Turn off at exit marked "Route 18 North-New
Brunswick". Proceed along Route 18 North past the
exits for "Route 27" and "Rutgers University" and
proceed over the Raritan River on the John Lynch
Memorial Bridge. (Approx. 3.7 miles) On the other side
of river proceed straight at the traffic light onto
Metlars Lane. Continue on Metlars Lane to Bevier Road,
the third left-hand turn. Follow Bevier Road to the
intersection of Bevier and Bartholomew Roads. Bear
right onto Bartholomew Road. The BCC is on the left.

From Route 287 (North or South)
Turn off at Exit 9 (Formerly Exit 5) "River Road,
Bound Brook, Highland Park". Proceed east on River
Road toward Highland Park until you reach the fifth
traffic light (approximately 3.4 miles) at the
intersection of River Road, Metlars Lane and Route 18.
Turn left onto Metlars Lane.Continue on Metlars Lane
to Bevier Road, the third left-hand turn. Follow
Bevier Road to the intersection of Bevier and
Bartholomew Roads. Bear right onto Bartholomew Road.
The BCC is on the left.

Via Campus Bus
�	From Busch Campus - Routes A, B, G, H (inbound only)

�	From Cook/Douglass Campus - G
�	From College Avenue Campus - Routes A, H
�	From Livingston Campus - B

Post ID:135
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-22 15:07:34
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Suydam Street Reformed Church
Message:

Sorry for the late notice on this one - I called several tims with no response.

The Suydam Street Reformed Church is conducting a peace march today on behalf of the people of Vieques in Puerto Rico - many know the story of the US military base that has destroyed this beautiful area and self-sustaning community, ruined the fisheries, prayed on the people via test bombing.  I think the bombing was halted temporarily due to massive demonstrations - people actually camped directly on the site with continual vigils to the point of setting up new community facilities; and that the bombing is set to resume soon.  Anyway, the Peoples Campaign is welcome to join, it starts at Brower Commons at 5pm and ends at the church at 630 at 74 Drift St for an ecumenical service.  This is an opportunity to support an important cause in the fight against imperialism.

Zofia



Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:137
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-03-22 16:55:45
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] AGENDA FOR MEETING OF 3/25
Message:

Message from the Steering Committee:

Here is the agenda we drafted for the upcoming General 
Meeting of the New Brunswick People�s Campaign. As a 
last reminder, the meeting will be held at the New 
Brunswick Public Library (Livingston Avenue) this coming 
Saturday from 2PM to 5PM. Remind everyone you know who 
might be interested. We are aiming for a large and 
upbeat meeting to move the campaign into high gear for 
the coming six weeks leading to the People�s Convention 
on Saturday May 13.

In unity, 

Xavier.
 
PROPOSED AGENDA FOR THE GENERAL MEETING OF 3/25/2000

1)  Welcome - Curtis Warren 
2)  Approval of the Chair - Keith Joseph 
3)  About the People�s Campaign: Who we are, what we 
want, what we have done
4)  Review of the Agenda: What we want to accomplish at 
this meeting
5)  Introductions
6)  Campaign Discipline - Proposal for basic rules:
While on campaign time or at campaign events: No illegal 
substances, no underage drinking, no abusive behavior 
towards others in the campaign or towards the people.
7)  Reports from the committees (brief - five minutes 
each)
A)  Fundraising
B)  Outreach
C)  Media
D)  Right To Know
8)  First Step in Preparation of the People�s Campaign 
Program to be voted on at the May Convention - Focusing 
at first on 5 issues most important to residents 
according to surveys - Approval of main policy to expand 
people�s democracy in each area:  
A)  Community Control Over the Police: Elected Civilian 
Police Review Board 
B)  Community Control Over Education: Elected School 
Board
C)  Community Control  Redevelopment: Elected DevCo, 
Elected Planning Board
D)  Jobs: goal of all residents employed, residency 
requirements for city contracts, recruitment of 
companies and hiring halls with tax credits only for 
hiring New Brunswick residents and providing 
apprenticeships.
E)  Child Care: goal of child care services for all New 
Brunswick children, statewide struggle to get New 
Brunswick� s state funds mandated in Court decision 
Abbot v. Burke, cooperation between existing child care 
facilities, churches, schools and Rutgers University to 
provide child care for all working parents.       
9)  Decision on campaign logo
10)   Decision on campaign slogan(s)

Post ID:141
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-24 02:16:59
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Argument for Rent Cap/Low-Income Housing Subsidies
Message:

Here's some interesting data to support a platform point on a rent 
cap/increased gov't subsidies for low-income public housing*:

For Middlesex County:

Fair Market Rent for 2 Bedroom  Apartment:            $   960
Annual Income Needed to Afford:                       $38,400
Hourly Wage Needed to Afford:                         $    18.46
       (Tied with Somerset Co. for highest in state!)
Percent of Population UNABLE to Afford:                    41%
WORK HOURS/WEEK Necessary to Afford @ $5.15/HR:           143

[*Most Gov't Housing Subsidies go to the Rich in the form of tax breaks for 
home owners! I need to dig up supporting stats--Matthew]

Source: National Low Income Housing Coalition, Out of Reach Report, 
September 15, 1999;  Affordable Housing Network of NJ, PO Box 1746, Trenton 
NJ 08607  (609) 393-3752


______________________________________________________

4. Goal of 25 canvassers for March 26.
5. Xavier to checkup on progress with calls to community.
6. Sam to get new phone numbers to committee members.
7. Spanish-speaking meeting with community contacts tentatively April    16 
from 2 to 4 pm at NB Public Library.
8. Sam talking to Frank about buttons, pens needed for motorcade.
9. Joe confirming cars for motorcade.
10. Banner and signs/posters for motorcade under way.
11. Paul to make copies, distribute to committee.
12. Paul created database for community contacts. As of 3/12, we have     
over 189 contacts.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:143
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-28 09:25:30
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Monument Square Block
Message:

Note from a fellow researcher on the Monument Square Block development:

I spoke with a NB planning department official the other day.  He informed 
me that the Monument Square redevelopment project is owned and will be 
developed by DEVCO and that it will not require any zoning variances.  (He 
said that even if it did -- and it sounds like it may require a FAR variance 
--  the redevelopment agency can override the city's planning board approval 
process, something that sounds quite strange to me!)

I asked him about tax abatements and he told me that the project would pay 
some city taxes but no county tax.  I left a message on Glenn Paterson's 
voice mail (Glenn Paterson is the head of NB's planning department) but so 
far he hasn't returned my call.

The person I spoke with also seemed unsure of when, exactly, the project 
would be up for approval.  He said it would on the schedule for either April 
12 or April 26.  You may want to phone up the week before the 12th to find 
out.

It seems to me that -- provided what the NB planning official told me is 
accurate and that I understood him correctly -- you will find answers to 
most of your questions in the legislation/regulations connected to the New 
Brunswick redevelopment agency (or whatever they call it).  If projects 
submitted by that agency do indeed supersede the city's own planning board 
approval process, then it really doesn't matter what the planning board and 
its members do or think.  To the degree that the redevelopment agency is 
unelected (which I believe it is) and has veto power over the planning 
board, the whole arrangement appears vaguely unconstitutional, don't you 
think?

Of course, I'm not sure if what I was told by the planning board official is 
accurate or if I understood it correctly.  But if I were you, I would check 
it all out and maybe go see a lawyer.  I'll keep you apprised of any new 
information that comes my way.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Just a note to say that the DOT hearing on road widening is today, March 28th  4-8  at the ground floor of the County Administration building.  This is an opportunity to tell folks to solve the traffic problems with improved public transit, not 4 lanes each way on Rt 18.

Zofia

Post ID:145
Sender:JimmyFishHead@...
Post Date/Time:2000-03-28 13:52:48
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: road widening
Message:

Hey all,
    Just a few thought on Route.  I was under the impression that the DOT 
spent a bunch of money just a few years ago on a traffic flow improvement 
project.  Essentially, the DOT computerized all of the traffic lights from 
New Brunswick through Spotswood by the Seville Diner.  This was done by 
sensors in the road to monitor traffic flow increases, breakdowns, accidents, 
and adjust the duration of traffic lights to handle traffic accordingly.  
This was done in an effort to avoid expanding the highway to 4 lanes each 
direction.
    Where exactly are they looking to expand this?  Let me know, I have 
pretty extensive contacts into the engineering community in Middlesex County. 
  Information regarding DOT shouldn't be too difficult for me to dig up.  
Keep me in the loop and let me know your questions and thought.  I should be 
able to handle some of the research on this from Boston.  Later,
Jim.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:146
Sender:JimmyFishHead@...
Post Date/Time:2000-03-28 14:00:26
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: road widening
Message:

Just found out the traffic light project cost roughly 2 to 4 million for the 
upgrade.  I would suggest someone bring up this point at the meeting and 
request some data regarding this project.  If the DOT spent this sort of 
money on an upgrade, they should be forced to address the issue of this 
failure.
Jim.

Post ID:147
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 10:24:37
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Question of DevCo overriding NB City Planning Agency
Message:

On the Question of DevCo overriding NB City Planning Agency for Monument 
Square development, here's a response from Prof. Tony Schuman of NJIT who 
specializes in public housing:


>On the development question:
>The only instance I know where a development company can override local
>zoning is an agency like the New York State Urban Development Corp. (now
>the Epire Develop. Corp.) which is a quasi-=public agency set up by the
>state with extraordinary powers in order to expedite development.  A
>private company must go through zoning review.
>

______________________________________________________





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:148
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 10:57:45
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] MSB
Message:

I think that DevCo is just such a quasi public private org that has these rights.

My concern overall is the lack of community uses in the building esp one calling itself a traiing center (although we need to see if perhaps they will be servicng the community, the luxury apartments, the decline in retail space. i spoke with a businessman next door and he agreed that soon the sm businesses will be priced out of the market on George St.  He had the idea for a business cluster or village as he called it where there was alot of business space, people could sell their wares formally and informally, rent space, and where the prices would be controlled and local people would be preferred.  We should assemble a business roundtable with this guy in it.  He was contacted by the city b/c he lies within 200 ft of the development - they are arranging to spraywash his building b/c of the dust, replace his facade if it gets messed up from the demolition, and halp with parking.  His business will benefit alot from the increased business.  Another business in the acutal block said they are receiving $10K + another $10K in relocation costs plus moving costs.  the First 10K is standard, state relocation costs for busiensses - even up to $15K I think.  The city may be supplementing.  They have been told there will be space but they are not certain where they will move.  The relocator has been working very close to them and they are on a first name basis.

From David:

I spoke with the NB planning director this afternoon.  He told me that:

1) The proposed Monument Square redevelopment project will meet most
requirements of the Downtown Redevelopment Plan and will therefore not
require much in the way of variances, although it may possibly require
some minor set-back variances;
2) The Downtown Redevelopment Plan is a part of NB's master plan (and
thus it was probably approved at some point by the city -- DG);
3) The developer of the project is DEVCO;
4) The project will generate between $900,000 and $1,000,000 per year in
tax revenue, even with the abatements.  According to the planning
director, it will generate more revenue with the abatements than without
them since Middlesex County, and not NB, is foregoing tax revenue and
kicking back part of its share to the city (thus, the County and not the
City is apparently granting the partial tax abatement);
5) The properties currently on the site generate less than $200,000 per
year in city tax revenue;
6) People living on the proposed site will be relocated elsewhere -- I
assume by NB or by DEVCO (I didn't ask where);
7) The Monument Square redevelopment project will receive the same type
of tax abatements as have other Downtown Redevelopment projects.
8) The Planning Board will most-likely vote on the project in May and
not in April.

Given all of this -- and I think it would be wise to review the NB
Master Plan and the Downtown Redevelopment Plan, as well as any indirect
subsidies that the city may be granting to DEVCO, where the site's
current residents will be relocated to, what potential traffic problems
the proposed development may create (I forgot to ask him about the
traffic impact), etc. & etc. -- what, exactly, would be your objections
to the project?  I think you should think it through very carefully,
especially if you want to oppose it.  Is a Subway sandwich shop and a
bankrupt hotel a better use for the site than the proposed use?  Are
there any alternative uses that may be better?  (Sure there are, but are
they feasible -- that's the important question to answer.)


Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:149

Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Question of DevCo overriding NB City Planning Agency

Back in the day when they built the Hyatt, etc., Devco was public-private 
body charged with buying land and holding it for the projects. They made all 
the deals with HUD, developers, city, J&J, etc. It all happened behind 
closed doors. They may have to go through the planning board, etc., they may 
not--my question is how do we control them?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:150
Sender:"paul mcgee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 12:49:19
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: MSB
Message:

We're not in a position to stop big projects like this. We have to hang on 
like dingleberries and squeeze concessions from them. We may not be able to 
help small business in the immediate area, but we should move to help small 
bus. elsewhere in town. We can push for increased subsidies for essential 
programs and new institutions to run them, tax abatements for small business 
too, lower sales tax, etc. This should be emphasized both within and without 
the big developments, with training and jobs downtown and money for new 
institutions to democratically revitalize other areas of town. We should say 
"You develop here, you fund our development over there"--Paul


______________________________________________________





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:151
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 13:55:55
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Forcing Concessions & Picking up the Bucket...
Message:

Paul's right-   Up here in the Bricks, inevitable construction of the Nets 
Arena is looming like a Zeplin.  Right now we don't have control of the 
rudder, but we can force a seat at the bargaining table...with enough 
pressure.
   This is what is driving the Lincoln Park/Coast Cultural District project 
right now.  When we had our recent Dance/Gala at Symphony Hall to promote 
the concept, Amiri made sure that we put EVERYBODY's name that was remotely 
associated with the effort on the flyer (this included community developers, 
Prudential employees, architects, cultural & political activists, etc.)  It 
wasn't a cosmetic thing, because once people's names were attached to it, it 
forced many talkers into doing.  (This is not to detract from the many 
people who really poured their energies into the effort.)
   Because of this we've been able build enough momentum to get us to the 
point at which we find ourselves now:  the Mayor of Newark has pledged $2500 
start up fee for our Newark-NJ-Store kiosk(our Cultural Ambassodor & 
Economic Generator)& to allow us to install the kiosk in City Hall lobby, 
with an additional pledge to help put together a $25,000 block grant for the 
same.  And we will be negotiating with the Nets/Yankees about installing the 
Nwk-NJ-Store in the new stadium; same with Rick Cerrone, owner of Newark 
Bears, in new stadium.

Figure out what concessions NB residents need (Cultural Institution, 
INDEPENDANT Teen Center, Women's Center, Mid-Night basket ball, whatever)  
use the united front to promote issues/build momentum. NAG THE SHIT out of 
the city to get behind it.  Make them the "Outsider".  Isolate them.  The 
development of Monument Square will go through.  Like Paul says, see what we 
can squeeze out of it for the People of NB.  (You might even consider 
following the model of the Newark-NJ-Store: Cultural Ambassodor of the 
People & Independant Economic Generator for the Movement)

*******************************************************************
See y'all Friday.  If folks aren't too busy Friday night, remember Karen's 
30th Birthday party.  I can give rides.  Later MAtthew


______________________________________________________

Post ID:153
Sender:"paul mcgee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 16:55:13
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Forcing Concessions & Picking up the Bucket...
Message:

Let's not rule out contacts within the firms that are doing the 
construction, etc., We have the beginnings of some good relationships with 
sympathetic ears in the business ($$$$$, I don't mean they own a Krauszer's) 
community and they want to talk when the time is right. But we need to get 
our act together. Timing is everything, as developers and Devco, etc., are 
moving very quickly.

Let's keep that in mind and focus on professionalism and uniting with as 
many different parties as possible. Let's not get bogged down in too much 
left wing discussion, as many said Saturday. We need everyone we can unite 
with. Paul

>From: "Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Forcing Concessions & Picking up the Bucket...
>Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2000 10:55:55 PST
>
>Paul's right-   Up here in the Bricks, inevitable construction of the Nets
>Arena is looming like a Zeplin.  Right now we don't have control of the
>rudder, but we can force a seat at the bargaining table...with enough
>pressure.
>   This is what is driving the Lincoln Park/Coast Cultural District project
>right now.  When we had our recent Dance/Gala at Symphony Hall to promote
>the concept, Amiri made sure that we put EVERYBODY's name that was remotely
>associated with the effort on the flyer (this included community 
>developers,
>Prudential employees, architects, cultural & political activists, etc.)  It
>wasn't a cosmetic thing, because once people's names were attached to it, 
>it
>forced many talkers into doing.  (This is not to detract from the many
>people who really poured their energies into the effort.)
>   Because of this we've been able build enough momentum to get us to the
>point at which we find ourselves now:  the Mayor of Newark has pledged 
>$2500
>start up fee for our Newark-NJ-Store kiosk(our Cultural Ambassodor &
>Economic Generator)& to allow us to install the kiosk in City Hall lobby,
>with an additional pledge to help put together a $25,000 block grant for 
>the
>same.  And we will be negotiating with the Nets/Yankees about installing 
>the
>Nwk-NJ-Store in the new stadium; same with Rick Cerrone, owner of Newark
>Bears, in new stadium.
>
>Figure out what concessions NB residents need (Cultural Institution,
>INDEPENDANT Teen Center, Women's Center, Mid-Night basket ball, whatever)
>use the united front to promote issues/build momentum. NAG THE SHIT out of
>the city to get behind it.  Make them the "Outsider".  Isolate them.  The
>development of Monument Square will go through.  Like Paul says, see what 
>we
>can squeeze out of it for the People of NB.  (You might even consider
>following the model of the Newark-NJ-Store: Cultural Ambassodor of the
>People & Independant Economic Generator for the Movement)
>
>*******************************************************************
>See y'all Friday.  If folks aren't too busy Friday night, remember Karen's
>30th Birthday party.  I can give rides.  Later MAtthew
>
>
>______________________________________________________
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@...
>To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: 
>nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@...
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:154
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 13:48:59
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Media Minutes 3-22-00
Message:

Media Committee Minutes
Wednesday, 22 March 2000

In attendance: Jim, Nikki, Chris, Keith, Jessie, Erric

IMMEDIATE NEEDS
	* Press for this Saturday:  Chris will fax advisory, Nikki/someone
  		press follow-up, Keith writing press release for Saturday
	* Press for motorcade:  Paul wrote press release, Nikki will split up
  		press calls and faxing between all members of the committee

WEBSITE
	* Chris gives update on hacking incident and how the site has been
		secured
	* WE NEED INPUT FROM COMMITTEES -- In order to get the website up to
		par we need:  committee statements/missions, articles,
  		quotes/personal stories, flyers/printed materials, arthouse pics,
  		survey, upcoming events, should get people to use discussion
		board, this is a good way for people to join in the politicization
  		process

MEDIA TIMELINE
	* Went through the coming months until November elections and wrote out
  		our objectives and strategies for each month
	* Prevalent themes to work towards: need to have exposure every month
  		(preferably in a few different ways), start using new media (ex.
		WBAI), start getting media attention around issues like police
  		brutality and education

PREPARE STATEMENT FOR SATURDAY PLANNING MEETING
	* What we have done:  website, listserve, canvassing press, flyers,
  		student and community letters, comprehensive media list (almost
		done), logo, strategy and timeline for committee, newsletter
	* For the future:  more newsletters, billboard, lawn signs, t-shirts,
  		issue press conference, posters and banners for convention, etc
	* Will present timeline for committee





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:155
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 13:49:33
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Media Minutes 3-29-00
Message:

Media Committee Minutes
Wednesday, 29 March 2000

In attendance: Nikki, Keith, Jim, Chris, Erric, Jessie, Mike and Matt

IMMEDIATE NEEDS
	* Press for Motorcade this Saturday:  Nikki and Chris have faxed
  		advisory, Nikki is doing press follow-up, press packet will
  		include cover letter (by Jessie), a press release and a copy of
  		The People Campaign Newspaper, Keith will address the press on
		Saturday

MEETING AGENDA
	* We had a brief discussion about last Saturday's meeting, we felt Jim
		got our message out and did a wonderful job.
	* We didn't get to talk about out timeline, so we will put it out in an
  		e-mail or talk about it at the convention.
	* We discussed a video production for the convention.  We need to
  		contact Jim Hamilton to get copies of whatever video he has
  		already shot.  We will be meeting Tuesday at Jim's house to view
		the footage and plan editing.

ARCHIVING
	* We need to bring in any articles directly related to the Campaign to
  		the meetings  (i.e. Articles about City Council, Planning Board,
  		DevCo, editorials, etc.)
	* Bring press Contacts to meetings as well for addition to "The
  		Comprehensive Media Contact Spreadsheet"

IN THE WORKS
	* T-shirts, T-shirts! - Jessie will have prices and places by the end of
  		next week so we can start printing them
	* Nikki is looking into campaign buttons
	* Keith, Jessie and Mike are planning a large, multi-colored, eye-
		catching poster on Friday about the Convention
	* Chris is writing a letter in response to the "State of The City
  		Address" pamphlet that was mailed to the residents of New
  		Brunswick
	* Media Committee Canvassing Day is on Saturday, April 8th!
	* Mike is fixing the logo so that we can use it for our official
  		letterhead

NEXT MEETING -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 5th, 2000





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:156
Sender:"kristina bas" <krisbas@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 14:42:30
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
Message:

I need clarity as to what the actions/roles of each committee should be. For 
example, we in Fundraising have already discussed and are pursuing producing 
campaign T-Shirts and Buttons. I don't think too much work has been 
replicated, however we are heading in that direction. Perhaps our respective 
committee heads could meet and formerly decide what is the "turf" of each 
committee? in the interest of efficience, of course....

Thanks, kristina

Post ID:157
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 15:42:09
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
Message:

Kristina, this is something I have been saying since the very beginning: 
That the chairs of each committee should be part of the steering committee 
or BE the Steering Committee.  This, I feel, would make things much more 
streamlined and there would be a real central point of communication -- not 
just at these monthly meetings.  Then overlap wouldn't occur because 
veryone would know what each committee has in mind.

Erric

At 11:42 AM 3/30/00 -0800, you wrote:

Post ID:158
Sender:Jess <jswant@...>

Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
Message:

This seems to be an issue that I raised a while ago.  I'm still doing
research on t-shirts and we also had plans for buttons...we need to decide
who is doing what or if this should be a collaborative effort.  

Maybe fundraising should find out pricing and then see what we can do as
far as our budget can handle...and media will do design?

Just a suggetion, 

Jessie

My sense is that overlap is minimal. Committees should have contact people 
to act as go-betweens. I think we could handle these things pretty easily. 
My worry is that we create structures we don't need. Paul

Post ID:160
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 16:37:14
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
Message:

Structure we don't need?  How much overlap do we actually know about?  We 
only found out about this because the minutes were posted.  What if they 
weren't?  We'd have lots of different t-shirt and buttons and spent twice 
as much money.  I don't think that it is overkill or too much to ask to 
have people who decided to become the chairs of their committees to be the 
"go-betweens."

Erric


At 08:46 PM 3/30/00 +0000, you wrote:
>My sense is that overlap is minimal. Committees should have contact people 
>to act as go-betweens. I think we could handle these things pretty easily. 
>My worry is that we create structures we don't need. Paul
>
>>From: "Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>

>>veryone would know what each committee has in mind.

>>>"turf" of each committee? in the interest of efficience, of course....
>>>
>>>Thanks, kristina
>>>
>>>>From: "Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
>>>>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>>>>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>>>>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Media Minutes 3-29-00
>>>>Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2000 13:49:33 -0500
>>>>
>>>>Media Committee Minutes
>>>>Wednesday, 29 March 2000
>>>>
>>>>In attendance: Nikki, Keith, Jim, Chris, Erric, Jessie, Mike and Matt
>>>>
>>>>IMMEDIATE NEEDS
>>>>         * Press for Motorcade this Saturday:  Nikki and Chris have faxed
>>>>                 advisory, Nikki is doing press follow-up, press packet 
>>>> will
>>>>                 include cover letter (by Jessie), a press release and a
>>>>copy of
>>>>                 The People Campaign Newspaper, Keith will address the
>>>>press on
>>>>                 Saturday
>>>>
>>>>MEETING AGENDA
>>>>         * We had a brief discussion about last Saturday's meeting, we
>>>>felt Jim
>>>>                 got our message out and did a wonderful job.
>>>>         * We didn't get to talk about out timeline, so we will put it
>>>>out in an
>>>>                 e-mail or talk about it at the convention.
>>>>         * We discussed a video production for the convention.  We need to
>>>>                 contact Jim Hamilton to get copies of whatever video 
>>>> he has
>>>>                 already shot.  We will be meeting Tuesday at Jim's house
>>>>to view
>>>>                 the footage and plan editing.
>>>>
>>>>ARCHIVING
>>>>         * We need to bring in any articles directly related to the
>>>>Campaign to
>>>>                 the meetings  (i.e. Articles about City Council,
>>>>Planning Board,
>>>>                 DevCo, editorials, etc.)
>>>>         * Bring press Contacts to meetings as well for addition to "The
>>>>                 Comprehensive Media Contact Spreadsheet"
>>>>
>>>>IN THE WORKS
>>>>         * T-shirts, T-shirts! - Jessie will have prices and places by
>>>>the end of
>>>>                 next week so we can start printing them
>>>>         * Nikki is looking into campaign buttons
>>>>         * Keith, Jessie and Mike are planning a large, multi-colored, eye-
>>>>                 catching poster on Friday about the Convention
>>>>         * Chris is writing a letter in response to the "State of The City
>>>>                 Address" pamphlet that was mailed to the residents of New
>>>>                 Brunswick
>>>>         * Media Committee Canvassing Day is on Saturday, April 8th!
>>>>         * Mike is fixing the logo so that we can use it for our official
>>>>                 letterhead
>>>>
>>>>NEXT MEETING -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 5th, 2000
>>>>

Post ID:161
Sender:"Nicole Adler" <nicoleadler@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-30 23:21:26
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] Clearing committee matters up
Message:

Why don't we save ourselves some banter and every committee chair write a 
fairly detailed description of the committee duties. I really think we're 
making this way more complicated than it needs to be...  yes, there may be 
some overlap, but that's why we communicate frequently.  Let's try to have 
descriptions up on the webpage by early next week.  (email them to chris) 
There's already a media description up, but I'll add to it.  Basically it's 
the job of the media committee to create visibility around the campaign.  
This would lead me to believe that the media committee will design the 
t-shirt and the fundraising committee will tell us how much money there is 
to work with.  Let's get those descriptions up!

Nikki

>From: "Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
>Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2000 16:37:14 -0500
>
>
>Structure we don't need?  How much overlap do we actually know about?  We
>only found out about this because the minutes were posted.  What if they
>weren't?  We'd have lots of different t-shirt and buttons and spent twice
>as much money.  I don't think that it is overkill or too much to ask to
>have people who decided to become the chairs of their committees to be the
>"go-betweens."
>
>Erric
>
>
>At 08:46 PM 3/30/00 +0000, you wrote:
>>My sense is that overlap is minimal. Committees should have contact people
>>to act as go-betweens. I think we could handle these things pretty easily.
>>My worry is that we create structures we don't need. Paul
>>
>>>From: "Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
>>>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>>>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>>>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Media Minutes 3-29-00
>>>Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2000 15:42:09 -0500
>>>
>>>Kristina, this is something I have been saying since the very beginning:
>>>That the chairs of each committee should be part of the steering 
>>>committee
>>>or BE the Steering Committee.  This, I feel, would make things much more
>>>streamlined and there would be a real central point of communication -- 
>>>not
>>>just at these monthly meetings.  Then overlap wouldn't occur because
>>>veryone would know what each committee has in mind.
>>>
>>>Erric
>>>
>>>At 11:42 AM 3/30/00 -0800, you wrote:
>>>>I need clarity as to what the actions/roles of each committee should be.
>>>>For example, we in Fundraising have already discussed and are pursuing
>>>>producing campaign T-Shirts and Buttons. I don't think too much work has
>>>>been replicated, however we are heading in that direction. Perhaps our

Post ID:163
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-31 13:05:18
Subject:[nbpeoplescampaign] MOTORCADE TOMORROW
Message:

Folks,

Tomorrow is our famed Motorcade - starting from NB Free Public Libary at 11 AM, (10 am to set up).  to go around town for several hours, stopping at key areas with live music and commentary from the public.  PLEASE DO COME - it will be alot of fun - we have tons of signs - a great voter reg opportunity, chance to get out the newspaper and other info, even complete surveys with residents.

WE NEED YOUR BODY HERE - THE SUCCESS OF THIS EVENT IS CRITICAL TO THIS CAMPAIGN.  YOU WONT REGRET IT.  THE WEATHER IS SUPPOSED TO BE BEAUTIFUL.

We also NEED INCREASED SURVEY TURNOUT on SUNDAY AT 12PM at the Library.  We have not been getting enough people - really the same old stalwarts - this is a key time to build relationships and find out more about NB - I got an amazing quote from a guy who said he grew up with a bunch of the police guys and they had asked him directly to sell drugs. This info is priceless, and provides great fodder to communicate to others why they should support us.  

SEE YOU THIS WEEKEND!

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Santos A. Perez





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:165
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-03 05:03:30
Subject:Fwd: [Fwd: A Letter of Apology to Elian Gonzales from Michael Moore]
Message:

From: TVNatFans@...
Reply-To: "Michael Moore's newsletter" <MICHAELMOORE@...>
To: MICHAELMOORE@...
Subject: A Letter of Apology to Elian Gonzales from Michael Moore
Date: Fri, 31 Mar 2000 19:15:37 EST

March 31, 2000

Dear Elian,

Please forgive me for writing to you in English.
Three semesters of Spanish, and I can't
remember a thing!

Also, please forgive us Americans for standing
back and allowing the child abuse you are now
experiencing. Normally, in this country, we arrest
adults who put children through trauma and
exploitation. Normally, we arrest adults like the
Mayor of Miami who call for violence and incite a
riot. Normally, in this country, we arrest terrorists
and either jail or deport them.

Unfortunately for you, we are doing none of this.
I apologize. I can only imagine what you are
going through. You do not deserve this
treatment.

You are being told that your mother died trying
to bring you to freedom. I am so sorry to have
to tell you, that's not true. The Cuban court
granted your father custody of you, and your
mother decided to kidnap you. She placed your
life in horrible jeopardy by putting you in a
leaky, overcrowded raft that eventually sank,
killing everyone but you. History is filled with
many people who risked their lives escaping to
another country because, had they stayed, they
would have been imprisoned or killed.

That's not what happened in the case of your
mother. Her life was not in jeopardy. Her son --
you -- was in no danger. The worst that could be
said is that, in Cuba, you were in jeopardy of
receiving free health care whenever you needed
it, an excellent education in one of the few
countries that has 100% literacy, and a better
chance of your baby sister being born and
making it to her first birthday than if she had
been born in Washington, DC.

The truth is your mother and her boyfriend
snatched you and put you on that death boat
because they simply wanted to make more
money. I can understand why they wanted a
better life. Cuba is a poor country. America,
from 90 miles away, looks like a rich country.
The majority of people who have sailed to this
country in the past have come for the same
reason. Often, they have come because they
did not like living in a country, such as Cuba,
where you cannot freely elect your president and
your basic rights are limited. I can understand
that.

But your mother placed you in a situation where
you were certain to die on the open seas (as the
rest did) and that is unconscionable. It was the
ultimate form of child abuse, and I see now why
the Cuban judge did not give your mother
custody.

Now you are with "relatives" in Miami. Normally,
in this country, when we say, "I'm going to stay
with the relatives," we mean brothers, sisters,
aunts, uncles, cousins, grandparents.

You are with a "great-uncle" and a "second
cousin." It's not that they aren't blood-related,
but, let's face it, in our country they and the
third cousins-once removed are usually not
sitting at the Thanksgiving table and are only
rarely heard from usually when they need bail
money or part of the inheritance. But in our
country, no "relative" replaces the parent. A
brother, cousin or "great-uncle" who holds a
child against the will of the parent is committing
a major crime.

You must really miss your daddy! I hear he's
coming soon. Those "relatives" are trying to
prevent him from being with you. I know, that
doesn't feel like love, does it? Please don't take
it personally. They do love you. They love
having you to toss around in front of the TV
cameras so they can further their own political
agenda.

You are only six, so I know you can't
understand what all of the politics are about.
That's okay. Some day, you will. In time, you'll
read how these former Cubans, who are abusing
you, instead of staying in Cuba and fighting for
freedom like our ancestors did for this country in
1776, they turned tail and ran to Miami. Once
here, they began demanding that we Americans
fight their fight for them.

What did we do?

Something stupid! We fought their fight for
them! We based our entire foreign policy in this
hemisphere on one thing -- eliminating Castro.
We tried to assassinate him. We sent "troops"
to invade at the Bay of Pigs. We prevented
medicine and food from being shipped to Cuba.
When I was nearly your age, we almost blew up
the world over Cuba and Castro. Can you
believe that? We had become as insane as
those ex-Cubans in Miami!

And we've stayed that way for forty years. We're
still wacked-out over Cuba. Last year, we fined
an American citizen $10,000 because he went
down to Cuba to tune pianos! It's illegal in this
"free" country to travel there. Loopy, huh?
We've been driven crazy 'cause that we still can't
get rid of Fidel Castro. He's out-lived nine of our
presidents!

We have allowed these ex-Cubans with the
yellow stripe down their backs to operate
numerous terrorist missions from South Florida.
These same ex-Cubans were the ones who
broke into a place called Watergate (that
eventually brought down a president), ran drugs
for arms operations (that brought down a
popularly-elected government in Nicaragua),
and, according to some Americans, were behind
the assassination of our president, John
Kennedy (that puts us on a slippery slope we're
still sliding down).

Now, these very ex-Cubans who were afraid to
stand and fight Castro have suddenly found the
courage to fight...us! That's right, they have
made it clear that they will fight, with violence,
any federal officers or troops who are sent in to
enforce our laws (those outrageous ones which
say a son should be with his father).

And you are caught in the middle of all this. I
am so sorry. I wish there was something I could
personally do. I will write to our Attorney General
(web@...) and tell her to stop this child
abuse. I will encourage others to do the same. I
wish I could convince our vice-president (who's
running for president) to help, but he too has
decided to abuse you by using you for his own
political gain. The governor of the state you're
in, Jeb Bush, is the brother of a man running for
president. He wants to use/abuse you, too. I
just want you to know that 80% of the country
doesn't like either of these men.

I guess that's the silver lining in your little
cloud. The majority of Americans are sickened
by the way you are being treated. Please
understand that bad things are often done in
our name and with our money. Often, there is
little we can do as the choices on our ballots are
nearly as slim as the choices your father has on
his.

It's not easy being six -- anywhere in the world.
I know this all too well. My country, the one your
mother thought you should be living in, allows
its six-year olds access to guns, and a little
six-year old girl in my hometown was killed last
month by another six-year old. This is the world
we adults have created for you. This is the world
I promise to do my best, in my own small way,
to change.

I pray you'll be playing catch soon with your
wonderful, loving daddy on a Cuban baseball
diamond. By the time you're 18, long after
Castro and the Bushes and all this nonsense is
gone, maybe you can come back to America on
your own free will.

The Tigers, I can assure you, will still be in
desperate need of some good pitching.

Yours,
Michael Moore
MMFlint@...
http://www.michaelmoore.com



______________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free Email at http://www.hotmail.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:167
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-07 11:50:06
Subject:Rhodia and Mile Run
Message:

From: 	"barnaby" <barnaby@...>
To:	NYC7.GWIA("criticalmassnb@egroups.com","barnaby@th...
Date: 	4/7/00 3:02AM
Subject: 	[criticalmassnb] Mile Run Contamination 

Dear All:
   The Edison Wetlands Association (EWA) recently tested the soil and water of the Mile Run, a brook that serves as a border between New Brunswick and Franklin Twp., and came up with some disturbing results.  Lead, mercury, chamfer,volatile and semi-volatile chemicals were found in the samples taken where the brook intersects Hamilton St.  The likely culprit of this contamination is the Rhodia chemical facility on Jersey Ave. in New Brunswick.  Rhodia has been under a consent order to clean up its site since 1987, but has moved at what EWA considers a glacial pace. EWA has filed suit against Rhodia for its foot dragging.  Testing at the site has revealed the above contaminants plus arsenic and two types of PCBs.  (Actually, I'll be meeting with EWA next week where I'll get the complete list of contaminants at the site and down stream)
   The Mile Run winds its way through working class neighborhoods through New Brunswick and Franklin and emptys out into the Raritan River near the Landing Lane Bridge.  In the past, and possibly now, children have played in it and along its banks.  Clearly, the contamination poses a threat to the river ecology and residents of both communities.
  EWA, the Work Environment Council, and the Raritan Valley Greens have agreed to form a coalition to restore and protect the Mile Run Brook.  We invite all concerned residents to join us in this fight.  It is not necessary to become a member of these groups , we just ask you to work with us.  Please contact me if you're interested.  

Sincerely:
Mark Grieco 


Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:171
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-07 15:48:15
Subject:reminder--Choice Rocks! Tonight at 7 PM (fwd)
Message:


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 7 Apr 2000 15:39:33 -0400 (EDT)
From: Charlotte L. Kates <ckates@...>
To: ru_ignite@egroups.com, starc-rutgers@egroups.com, njfo@egroups.com
Cc: w_d_c@egroups.com, sarutgers@egroups.com, nbpeoplescampaign@...
Subject: reminder--Choice Rocks! Tonight at 7 PM

Just a reminder that *tonight* at 7 PM at the Demarest Hall Lounge on the
College Avenue Campus at Rutgers...is the CHOICE ROCKS! concert. 

Featuring: AUS ROTTEN from Pittsburgh, PA and THE HAGGARD of Portland, OR

with

DIVERSITY, SLOW CHILDREN, CATHERINE MOON, PAM NOVICK, JANHAVI PAKRASHI and
MERE OURS! 

There will be tabling, and speaking--if you want to represent your
organization, let us know! 

All proceeds will go to clinic defense (the South Jersey Clinic Defense
Coalition)! 

Suggested donation is $5....get there early, or you might miss something! 

THEN...

Tomorrow, Saturday, April 8, protest NJ Right to Life at the Doubletree
Hotel in Somerset! 

NJRtL was expelled from National Right to Life for *refusing* to sign a
non-violence pledge. They have featured prominent right-wingers in the
past, including this year's guest, Joseph Sobran, who wants to ban
marriage between people of different races and who calls himself
"anti-semitic". Fight for choice! 

See you tonight at 7, tomorrow at 8! 

Charlotte

CHOICE ROCKS! concert sponsored by LABIA and BiGLARU

concerned. Does anyone know anything about this coalition and what kind of 
activities/efforts they have planned? I 'm really getting into the idea of 
'community clean-up' activities. perhaps this is something the Campaign can 
keep in mind in terms of a future platform, e.g. increased city funding for 
cleaning up urban and natural areas, an anti-litter campaign,... or 
something along those lines...

>Check it Out!  Make your plans!  Build the Movement! Spread the Word!  . .
>. come to:
>
>JOHN BROWN 2000
>a two-hundredth anniversary birthday party for the radical abolitionist
>
>The past, present and future of white solidarity with people of color-
>a national organizing conference on anti-racist, anti-imperialist action
>
>for full information on schedule, registration, logistics, and political
>education, check out our website at: * www.johnbrown2000.org *
>
>**********************************
>
>Friday, May 12, 2000 * opening event * A Celebration of Resistance
>
>with poetry and prose performances from
>Terry Bisson, Hugo & Nebula award-winning science fiction author
>
>Dennis Brutus, South Africa's national poet
>
>Chrystos, Native American poet; author of Not Vanishing
>
>music featuring
>Bev Grant, Director, Brooklyn Women's Chorus
>
>Fred Ho, master jazz saxophonist;
>co-editor of the just-released Legacy to Liberation:
>Politics & Culture of Revolutionary Asian Pacific America
>
>and special surprise guests!!
>
>plus presentation of the second annual John Brown award, for continued
>spirit and struggle, to
>Laura Whitehorn
>anti-imperialist former political prisoner
>
>Friday, May 12, 2000, 6:30 pm
>Hunter College's Brookdale Center Auditorium
>425 East 25th Street, Manhattan, (#6 train to 23rd Street)
>$10.00-$15.00
>sliding scale suggested contribution, free with conference registration, no
>one turned away
>
>*************************************
>
>Sat.-Sun., May 13-14, 2000 * Organizing Conference
>
>Confirmed schedule:
>
>* Saturday, May 13, 9 am-10 am: brief Introductory Plenary, with
>	* DR. LUIS NIEVES FALCON, Puerto Rican Human Rights Committee
>
>* Saturday, May 13, 10 am-Noon: Workshops and Working Sessions I
>info. sessions, planning meetings, and caucuses, including updates from
>Mumia Coalition work,
>anti-WTO/IMF mobilizations, the Jericho Movement, the National Committee to
>Free Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, the League of Indigenous Sovereign
>Nations, Women for Justice and anti-police brutality efforts, Anti-Racist
>Action Network, Greensboro Defense Committee, Midnight Notes,
>anti-Nazi/Skinhead and anti-fascist work, Race Traitor/New Abolitionists,
>including workshop leaders Ashanti Alston, Kai Lumumba Barrow, Dave
>Dellinger, Soffiyah Ellijah, Silvia Federici, Herman Ferguson, Connie
>Hogarth, Mawina Kouyate, Matthew Lyons, Ed Mead, more!
>
>* Saturday, May 13, Noon-1:15 pm: Lunch, Caucus time
>* Saturday, May 13, 1:15 pm-3:15 pm: Workshops and Working Sessions II (see
>above)
>* Saturday, May 13, 3:30 pm-5:30 pm: Workshops and Working Sessions III
>(see above)
>* Saturday, May 13, 5:30-7 pm: Dinner, Caucus time
>
>* Saturday, May 13, 7 pm-9:30 pm: Town Hall "State of the Movements"
>Meeting, with
>	* BO BROWN, Out of Control Lesbian Committee to Support Political
>Prisoners
>	* JOSE LOPEZ, Puerto Rican Cultural Center, Chicago
>	* BARBARA SMITH,activist-author-publisher;editor of recently
>re-published classic Homegirls
>	* CHIEF BILLY TAYAC, League of Indigenous Sovereign Nations
>	* DHORUBA BIN WAHAD, Black Panther Party former political prisoner
>
>* Sunday, May 14, 10 am-Noon: Small Discussion Groups (with sets of 
>questions)
>* Sunday, May 14, 12 pm-1 pm: Conference Closing (including brief report
>backs), with
>	Safiya Bukhari, National Coordinator, Jericho Movement
>
>May 13-14, 2000, NYC
>Hunter College, 68th St. & Lexington Ave.
>$30.00 sliding scale suggested fee (includes Friday celebration), no one
>turned away
>
>All events sponsored by Resistance in Brooklyn (RnB) and the Student
>Liberation Action Movement (SLAM)
>in conjunction with a coalition of organizations, including Out of Control
>(San Francisco), People Against Racist Terror (Los Angeles),  Fireworx
>(S.F.), Prairie Fire Organizing Committee (Chicago), Western Mass
>Resistance Coalition (MA), Peter Maurin Center (Washington D.C.),  Modern
>Times (Long Island), European Dissent/People's Institute for Survival (New
>Orleans),
>and a host of other local groups and individuals from the U.S. & Canada
>
>* for more info., call 212-989-8222; www.johnbrown2000.org; E-mail:
>mmmsrnb@... *
>
>"I cannot remember a night so dark as to have hindered the coming day nor a
>storm so furious or dreadful as to prevent the return of warm sunshine and
>a cloudless sky." -John Brown, 1857
>

Post ID:178
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-11 15:06:49
Subject:Activist Internships in New Brunswick!
Message:

(Please forward to all interested parties)

ATTENTION RUTGERS AND MCC STUDENTS:
ACTIVIST INTERNSHIPS IN NEW BRUNSWICK!
3, 6, and 9 credits - Undergraduate and Graduate Level

Are you interesting in taking part in the growing movement for people's 
democracy in the city of New Brunswick??  Are you ready to put your talents 
and skills to good use in return for a fruitful and enriching experience??

The New Jersey Freedom Organization (NJFO) is now offering three, six, and 
nine credit internships for the Fall 2000 semester. We offer many different 
types of internships through our Student Volunteer Service Program. Some of 
our campaigns and projects include:

The People's Campaign for New Brunswick City Council - (check out 
www.newbruns.org)
The Coalition Against Police Brutality
Malcolm X Youth League
The newspaper Unity and Struggle

We are looking for people to intern as organizers, writers, artists, 
photographers, bookkeepers, editors, researchers, events/program 
coordinators, etc. NJFO is committed to working around your schedule. Along 
with your professor, we will construct an internship program that is 
tailored to your interests and skills.

Register for an NJFO internship for the upcoming fall semester!

For more information, please contact:

Kristina Bas
732-249-9664
krisbas@...

or

Tom DeGloma
732-729-0873
tdegloma@...

Coordinators of the Student Volunteer Service Program
for NJFO.

"the Question of Revolution is the Seizure of Power"
The New Jersey Freedom Organization
P.O. Box 131
New Brunswick, New Jersey 08901
732-545-5756

______________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free Email at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:179
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-11 17:01:55
Subject:Fwd: "Beat the Bushes for Education"
Message:


>From: Kubran, Judith <JKubran@...>
>Subject:  "Beat the Bushes for Education"
>Date: Tue, 11 Apr 2000 14:00:33 -0400
>
>  "Beat the Bushes for Education"
>
>The State of Texas, under the leadership of Governor George W. Bush is
>ranked:
>     • 50th in spending for teachers
>     • 49th in spending on the environment
>     • 48th in per-capita funding for public health
>     • 47th in delivery of social services
>     • 42nd in child support collections
>     • 41st in per-capita spending on public education
>     • 5th in percentage of population living in poverty
>     • 1st in percentage of children without health insurance
>     • 1st in air and water pollution
>     • 1st in percentage of poor working parents without insurance
>     • 1st in executions(avg.1 every 2 weeks for Bush's 5 years)
>
>  Just think what he could do for the country if he were the president.
>

______________________________________________________
