Post ID:183
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-13 13:00:25
Subject:Activist Legal listserve
Message:

---  "SRC-A.L.Adv." <src_st@...> wrote:
> Date:         Tue, 11 Apr 2000 13:57:38 +0500
> Reply-to: Environmental Communication List
> <COCE-L@...>
> From: "SRC-A.L.Adv." <src_st@...>
> Subject:      Fwd: LawJuC Email List of Lawyers,
> Litigants, Researchers,
>               HR Activists & Teachers
> To: COCE-L@...
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: LawJuC Moderator <LawJuC-owner@egroups.com>
> Date: Sunday, April 09, 2000 2:12 PM
> 
> Lawjuc Email List of Lawyers, Litigants,
> Researchers, Law Students &
> Activists.
> 
> Lawjuc is an academic and  research oriented list
> for people interested and
> involved in matters/activities related to Law,
> Justice and Criminology. This
> historical initiative for discussion, debate,
> research, awareness and
> advocacy is open to lawyers, former judges, human
> rights activists,
> litigants, police officials, former prisoners,
> paralegals, law students and
> teachers. The LawJuC list is designed to encourage 
> discussion of different
> aspects of the Criminal Justice System,
> legislations, important rulings and
> it would also raise critical issues and would
> provide communication links
> and a space for the exchange of information among
> researchers, scholars,
> activists, writers, lawyers, academicians,
> journalists and professionals
> interested in all forms of Law, Justice, Criminology
> and Human Rights.
> Lawjuc list would also serve as a network for
> lawyers and researchers in
> discussing data sources, books, events, conferences,
> opportunities, legal
> complications and web-based information resources.
> For subscription send
> blank message to : LawJuC-subscribe@egroups.com   
> LawJuC-owner@egroups.com

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:184
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-15 18:33:58
Subject:PEOPLE'S CONVENTION
Message:

A message from the Steering Committee:

Sisters & brothers,

The historic first New Brunswick People's Convention on 
May 13 (10AM to 6PM at Paul Robeson School) is rapidly 
approaching. We have less than a month left to mobilize 
the community to take an active part in the decisive 
event that will lead the people's democratic 
reconstruction of the city. We have worked hard to reach 
out to the people (thousands of flyers posted, over five 
thousand newspapers distributed and over five hundred 
surveys completed so far). It is now essential that we 
CONSOLIDATE our effort and do all that we can to turn 
out the more conscious workers, students and middle-
class residents at the Convention. Everyone in the 
campaign should draw up a LIST OF TEN RESIDENTS THAT YOU 
KNOW who you will CALL, MEET WITH AND PICK UP (if 
necessary) ON THE DAY OF THE CONVENTION. This is the 
best way to guarantee that we pack the house and truly 
represent the will of the various communities that must 
unite if the people are to win in November. We must 
especially focus on turning out the people we met during 
the canvass who are enthusiastic about the campaign. (If 
you haven't been out to canvass yet, come meet us at the 
Library on Saturday (12:45PM) or Sunday (11:45AM) and 
get down to the grass roots!) Everyone in the campaign 
should bring their list of ten names with them for the 
General Meeting on April 29th. If you can't come up with 
ten names off the top of your head, don't worry. The 
Outreach Committee has gathered many, many names of 
residents who want to seize power in New Brunswick. 
Let's all mobilize for this most important turn out.

In unity, 

X.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:186
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-17 16:40:17
Subject:A Message from A Research Committee Member...
Message:

Esteemed Readers--

As of last night, the Research/Right to Know Committee has instructed
me to perform the following work act in time for the School Board
elections of April 18th (Tuesday). (All but New Brunswick of
course.) Please review this proposed and **personal** media message
and have commentary "e-marked" by 10am, April 18th. Thanks, and
comment or ask any questions you may have.

Solidarity,

Brian Villa



***PROPOSED MESSAGE***

Dear Editor: 

  In towns throughout New Jersey this past Tuesday, people's
democracy was expressed through electoral action in the form
of school board elections. Yet in the City of New Brunswick,
an example of our colonial democracy, the people have no vote.

  Why should the people have no vote on the education and future
of our community's children? Why, in New Brunswick should the
people have "taxation without representation" in a school government
which has a spending budget larger than City hall, and one-third
of the Middlesex County government tax base?

  Even when the public asks questions that seek the affirmation
of democratic accountability, we are met with the authoritarian
arrogance of public officeholders who scold those who ask questions
of public interest.

  This was the recent case with city council member Robert Recine
and citizen activist Frank Bright, when this public representative
asked why elected councilman Recine voted against the school
budget as a member of the Board of School estimate but then switched
votes as a council member which increased the property tax rate.

  More galling is that the councilman wanted to conduct this
public business in hushed private conversation. Could it be that
Recine does not want this embarassing issue to be reseen when
he attempts reelection in November?

  In addition to the city council's school and property tax increase,
we need to seriously look at our unelected school board. Three
of seven members have significant conflict-of-interest concerns.
Two, Martin Arocho and Edwin Gutierrez, have court charges pending
against them for voting for a $415,583 contract to an organization
to which they have historical ties. The third school board member,
Ed Spencer, like Gutierres, works for the City of New Brunswick
--and of course the mayor which appointed him.

  Yet despite all this and the fact that better spending and
budget actions worth several million dollars could be begun in
the school system but are not, the people who comprise the public
do not have an elected say in the children, do not have an elected
say in their schools, and do not have a say in their school property
taxes.

  In too many ways, the electoral system in New Brunswick resembles
that of  colonial democracy where in order to have a true political
voice one has to be White and own a certain level of real property.
In short, this is democracy for the few.

  New Brunswick must have a demorcracy which is current with
the New Millenium and popular democratic expressions throughout
the world --most notably the washington D.C. protests against
World Bank and International Monetary Fund policies. 

  The people --the many-- must act upon their democratic rights
and seize the power that rightfully belongs to then as citizens
in the land of the free and the home of the brave. When the people
lead, the leaders will be made to  follow.

Brian Villa
New Brunswick, NJ


-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!

Post ID:189
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-18 17:46:52
Subject:NJ Dem Congressional Primary Races to the Left
Message:

Anybody catch the Monday Star Ledger Article about Dem Congressional 
candidate Jon Corzine, who's opposing FlimFlamFlorio in June 
primaries...Quote: "It is my view that a time of unprecedented prosperity os 
not an excuse for complaceny, but a time to seize the moment, to take up the 
great unfinished business of social and economic justice."  Stuart 
Rothenberg compaired him to Lenora Fulani, formerly of the New Alliance 
Party (M-L, according to the SL).  His current platform supports abortion 
rights, extending marraige rights to gays, opposes welfare reform, supports 
affirmative action, opposes the death penalty, ties trade policy to labor 
and environmental issues, decries US foreign policy as Eurocentric, and 
claims the US should have intervened in Rawanda.  Also advocates universal 
health care and universal access to college as well as expansion of urban 
development.  He was just endorsed by 20 NJ black ministers, including
Rev. Reginald Jackson.

Granted, he's a multi-millionaire former CEO of Goldman Sachs with a 
questionable history, but it's certainly interesting that candidates are 
running to the left to become electable.  Perhaps the NB Peoples' Campaign 
should drop his campaign a note, and squeeze an endorsement. (We should also 
be considering getting endorsements from other statewide figures, such as 
Rev. Jackson, to broaden focus on the campaign.)

Matthew Smith
______________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free Email at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:190
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-18 18:04:56
Subject:Corzine
Message:

Re: Corzine:

Won't his interests ultimately conflict with those of the working class?

What does his running mean for democracy?

What will his endorsement mean in terms of support from the poor working and middle classes in New Brunswick.? I know Kathy Cupano is supportive of Florio because of the democracy issue - as to whether she is an appropriate litmus test, at least she certainly was a real challenger to the city machine, although I am ignorant of much of the history in local politics.

Zofia

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018

Fax:212.730.1405

establish some ties with other "left" candidates. I have been thinking about 
Maureen Connolly for example, mayor of Fanwood, who is currently running for 
Senate on a feminist, pro-working family platform (she has received NJ NOW's 
endorsement; spoke recently at TBTN, and has a series student following).

What do people think? i know that there's a lot of work as it is, but 
perhaps we shall soon see the need for a "legislative action committee"...

any comments?
Kristina

Post ID:195
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-20 13:53:37
Subject:RE: survey data entry and scientific soundness
Message:

I understand there is a large enough data pool to correlate some
public issues. However, I caution that the survey pool must represent
a large and diversified spatial dimension of New Brunswick. If
not, no pronouncements should be made about what the city's people
desire. This is the only way to insure that the survey is sound.

--BV

------------------------------------------------------------------------
Your high school sweetheart-where is he now?  With 4.4 million
alumni
already registered at Classmates.com, there's a good chance you'll
find her here. Visit your online high school class reunion at:
http://click.egroups.com/1/3139/0/_/357188/_/956250461/
------------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:196
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-20 14:11:15
Subject:RE: Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Corzine
Message:

Corzine will not endorse our effort. He is the puppet of county
democratic organizations. While ideationally progressive, we
will have a tough time seeing that translated in a conservative
U.S. Senate run by Mississppi Rebel Trent Lott. Even moreso given
the floor-level seniority he will have a a first-term member
of the Senate, if elected.

In terms of democracy and impact, I think it's pretty clear that
there are two classes of voters: those that vote, and those that
donate. Corzine comes from the latter. It's up to us to balance
the scales of power. Our impactful say is too limited too often.

--BV
--- Original Message ---
"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...> Wrote on 
Wed, 19 Apr 2000 07:50:29 PDT
 ------------------ 
though i don't think Corzine's endorsement will mean too much
in a real 
sense in terms of gaining the support of working people, it will
serve to 
further legitimize the Campaign and strengthen its position in
the 
mainstream eye. Though Corzine, by virtue of his former CEO status,
may not 
be a "champion" of the working class, it is unmistakable that
his 
progressive politics, for the time being, serve the interests
of the WC...

Kristina

Post ID:197
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-20 14:19:49
Subject:Endorsements
Message:

Now is the time to get our official endorsements and support for the convention. We have a lot of good press clips,  literature, and surveys completed to use for our advantage

The outreach committee will be going to churches and businesses next week to obtain their endorsements.  Media has put together a number of folders including 2 surveys, spanish flyer, newspaper and 2 press clips (HNT grassroots clip and Targum clip). Let us know if there should be something additional. Hopefully we can have letters, english and spanish for businesses and a general  letter ready by early next week signed by the steering committee and listing additional endorsers - so if you know of endorsing orgs, send all my way, even if you think they are obvious.  It would be great if we could get more endorsements before  the letters get made ie before Sun nite- If you want to go to someone to get an endorsement, let steering committee and Sam or me know, and we can get you a packet today, tomorrow, Sat.  If you have time next Thu we are going out to businesses in the evening.

Zofia


******************************
Alice Meaker
Project Director
Good Jobs New York
232 West 40th Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY 10018

Post ID:199
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-20 15:19:50
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] RE: survey data entry and scientific soundness
Message:

Good point.

Unfortunately, although Zofia and I orginally laid out the surveys to 
include: ward, district, nationality, race, age etc of people filling them 
out. Others took it upon themselves to change it, and now we are left with 
just a general overview of issues based on the canvass, which has been 
fairly expansive throughout new brunswick. At any rate, when made public, we 
will be clear in saying it is representative of the sample of the population 
that we surveyed.

Louise


>From: Villa@...
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] RE: survey data entry and scientific soundness
>Date: Thu, 20 Apr 2000 10:53:37 -0700
>
>
>I understand there is a large enough data pool to correlate some
>public issues. However, I caution that the survey pool must represent
>a large and diversified spatial dimension of New Brunswick. If
>not, no pronouncements should be made about what the city's people
>desire. This is the only way to insure that the survey is sound.
>
>--BV

> >We don't know if you had the opportunity to see the press conference that
> >Juan Miguel Gonz�lez gave this afternoon, in front of the house in 
>Bethesda
> >where he's staying while he waits for Eli�n's release.
> >
> >At about 3:00pm on Thursday, April 20, Juan Miguel came out of the house
> >and greeted the reporters; he waited a few minutes and then -- speaking
> >very directly and without notes -- he made this heartfelt appeal: He said
> >that he and his family have been terribly sad as they've spent nearly 
>five
> >months watching his son being abused. He said "I always thought that the
> >United States was a country that abided by "the law." He said "My son
> >belongs with me. He should be with me."
> >
> >He said he wanted to ask the people of the United States -- those who 
>have
> >supported him, and anyone who has the feelings that a parent feels -- to
> >help him, to send a message, to write to the US President and the 
>Attorney
> >General: "to ask them immediately to reunite my son with me, and to not 
>let
> >them continue to abuse him any longer."
> >
> >He said "I love my son; I need him; it hurts me to see what they're doing
> >to him.... He's only six years old. He's like any other six-year-old, 
>like
> >any child of any US citizen." He appealed to all of us -- to anyone who
> >knows what it means for a father to love his child -- to help him send 
>this
> >message.
> >
> >Then he thanked the press and went back in the house.The reporters were
> >visibly moved. They said "Juan Miguel is asking everyone to write to the
> >President and the Attorney General." The only thing they didn't do is 
>give
> >out the addresses and fax numbers -- so we're giving them to you now.
> >

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:205
Sender:Keith Joseph <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-22 17:42:21
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Corzine
Message:

It is probably true that Corzine won't publicly endorse us. It is also true that he is
a rich bourgeois politician whose allegiance to the working class and democartic
middle class should not be trsted.  However, he is appealing to basicly the same
constituency as us.  But he has much more influence, primarily due to his wealth and
acess to media.  The point of working with his camapign would be to gain access to our
people in many ways that we are currently unable to do. We should ride on his back not
the other way around.
I don't think that it is appropriate for the campaign to endorse Corzine at this time,
though I think that discussing it is worthwhile.  Our unity is based on our common
enemy in New Brunswick, this unity may or may not be compatible with Corzine.

Post ID:208
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-25 11:37:05
Subject:Fwd: Sunday, April 30th - Vietnam anniversary
Message:

> > > PLEASE SHARE THIS ANNOUNCEMENT AS WIDELY AS POSSIBLE.
> > > --------------------------------------------------------------------
> > > On April 30th we will celebrate 25 years since the end of the U.S. war
> > > and the victory of peace in Vietnam. Many of us participated in the
> > > anti-war movement and shared in the waging of peace 25 years ago. We 
>now
> > > invite you to join in celebrating this anniversary, reflecting on our
> > > history and re-committing ourselves to the global struggle for peace 
>and
> > > justice.
> > >
> > > At the beginning of this century, much has changed in the world since
> > > that last helicopter pulled away from the roof of the U.S. embassy in
> > > Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City). As we examine our history we must
> > > confront the changes in U.S. foreign policy in the past 25 years and 
>the
> > > challenges facing us today. We must move from learning from our 
>history
> > > to strengthening the movements for peace and justice worldwide.
> > >
> > > April 30, 2000:  25th ANNIVERSARY OF THE VICTORY OF PEACE IN VIETNAM:
> > > A CELEBRATION AND REDEDICATION
> > >
> > > Stephen Wise Free Synagogue
> > > 30 West 68th Street (near Central Park West)
> > > New York, New York
> > >
> > > TEACH-IN: 12:30 to 5:30 pm
> > > Panel I:    The Vietnam War and the Movement Against It
> > > Panel II:   Lessons and Legacies: 25 Years Later, What's Different and
> > > What Remains the Same?
> > > Panel III:  Building Today's Struggles for Peace and Justice
> > >
> > > Panelists include:
> > > Noam Chomsky, Amy Goodman, Ngo Vinh Long, Humberto Brown, Phyllis
> > > Bennis, Ben Chitty, Amy Swerdlow, Don Luce, JJ Johnson, Dick Moser,
> > > Gloria Quinones, Tod Ensign, Norma Becker, Sandra Barros and others
> > >
> > > EVENING CELEBRATION- 6:30 to 8:30 pm
> > > $5 donation at the door
> > >
> > > With:
> > > Nguyen Thanh Chau, Vietnamese Ambassador to the UN
> > > Dr. Theo-Ben Gurirab, President of the UN General Assembly
> > > Jack O'Dell
> > > Grace Paley
> > > performing artist Patti Smith
> > > Yellow Peril (Asian American hip-hop)
> > > Ray Korona Band
> > > slam poet Stacey Ann Chim
> > > Vinie Burrows
> > > and others
> > >
> > > Join us in launching a campaign to demand that the U.S. government 
>honor
> > > its obligations to fund research and treatment in Vietnam to benefit
> > > victims of Agent Orange in both our countries.
> > >
> > > Visit our web site at www.vietnam25.org.
> > > Call 212-604-4256 for more information.
> > >
> > >
> > > _______________ Return coupon ____________________
> > >
> > > Name _____________________________________________
> > >
> > > Address __________________________________________
> > >
> > > City ______________ State ______ Zip _____________
> > >

> > >

> > >

> > >

> > > (Checks should be made out to: The Brecht Forum, earmarked for VN 25

>the end of next week? Check out the bundle below. It includes
>everything you need to get everyone up and running quickly.
>http://www.listbot.com/links/cdw5

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:210
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-27 08:52:46
Subject:FW:A Victory Holiday Inn Workers & "Ficus for Congress"
Message:


--- Original Message ---
        TVNatFans@... Wrote on 
        Wed, 26 Apr 2000 12:50:09 EDT
 ------------------ 
A Victory for the Holiday Inn Workers, Thanks to You
(Now Let's Run a Ficus for Congress!)

April 26, 2000

Dear Friends,

We won!

Not only has Elian Gonzales been reunited with his
father (my only criticism of the raid and that photo
on Saturday is that the gun wasn't big enough), but
our Mexican friends in Minneapolis who were being
deported for starting a union have won their fight to
stay in the United States!

At the INS hearing yesterday, after being deluged
with thousands of your letters, plus the hard work
of a lot of good people in the Twin Cities, the
immigration judge ruled in favor of the 8 Mexican
housekeepers, declaring that they should be made
"legal."

You have no idea how stunning this decision is.
Last week, after interviewing the people at the INS
in Minneapolis, it was clear that these immigrants
(who were being punished because they
successfully formed a union at the Holiday Inn
where they worked) were going to lose. That is why
I wrote to ask you to flood the INS and the Justice
Department with e-mail. But within 24 hours of my
letter to you, those two federal agencies became
quite busy with the nuttiness in Miami. I figured that
our letters to them would get lost in all the
distraction.

But they didn't. By yesterday, the INS had received
tens of thousands of e-mails, eloquent pleas from
those of you who asked that these 8 Mexican
workers be given the same chance most of our
ancestors got when they came to America.

Well, it worked. I can't thank you enough for taking a
few minutes to lend a hand. I continue to be
amazed at the power of the Internet. A few years
ago, we never would have been able to respond so
quickly to a problem, let alone even hear about it.
We must try to keep the Internet in the hands of the
people and free of government and corporate
control. This is a powerful tool.

The Mexicans have received what is called
"deferred status," meaning they can stay and work
legally until such time they can be upgraded to
perhaps a green card or even citizenship. This is a
huge victory. Thanks again to all of you plus the
lawyers and church people in Minneapolis who
gave their time.

You can see the whole story -- plus how we
punished Holiday Inn in our own "special way" -- on
an upcoming episode of "The Awful Truth" (which
premieres in three weeks on Wednesday, May 17,
10pm ET/PT on Bravo).

And, speaking of "The Awful Truth," we are holding
a press conference in an hour to formally
announce a "candidate" we are running for
Congress -- a Ficus plant. That's right. We are
running a potted plant for the U.S. House of
Representatives. Since word leaked out about us
trying to get a Ficus on the ballot, over 20 other
people around the country have also announced
campaigns to get Ficuses elected in their districts.

If you would like to get on board the potted plant
bandwagon and run a write-in campaign in your
district, please read the press release below. We
are shooting all this for "The Awful Truth," and it is
our hope to see Ficuses and other houseplants
giving incumbent Congressmen who face little or
no opposition a run for their money. 95% of all
incumbents get re-elected and many of them run
unopposed. We believe the country would be better
off with a Ficus tree sitting in Congress than some
of these clowns. So, check out our website
(http://www.Ficus2000.com) and send us a photo
or video of the houseplant you are running for
Congress and we'll put it on our show.

Thanks again for your help!

Yours,

Michael Moore
http://www.michaelmoore.com
mmflint@...



FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 26, 2000

FICUS PLANT ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR
CONGRESS

NEW JERSEY'S 11TH DISTRICT IS TARGETED

PUBLIC ENCOURAGED TO WRITE-IN "FICUS" ON
BALLOTS

OVER TWENTY CONGRESSIONAL SEATS IN U.S.
CHALLENGED BY HOUSEPLANTS

Claiming that the American people "deserve
better," a potted plant, commonly known as "Ficus,"
formally announced its campaign this morning to
seek the Congressional seat in New Jersey's 11th
District as a write-in candidate on both the
Democrat and Republican Party ballots in the June
6 primary.

"The United States Congress is full of babbling
idiots and bumbling morons," said Ficus
campaign strategist and filmmaker Michael Moore.
"Most run unopposed in their primaries and 95%
are re-elected every time in the general election.
What we get from these Congressmen-for-life is a
lot of hot air, a bunch of promises that are never
kept, problems like health care and education that
are never addressed, more taxes for a bigger
military when there are no wars, and a bigger
paycheck for Congress when they don't deserve it."

Moore, in presenting the Ficus at a press
conference in the historic town square of
Morristown, New Jersey (site of George
Washington's military headquarters), also
announced that Ficuses in more than twenty other
Congressional districts around the country (see
list), where the incumbent faces little or no
opposition, are also entering the race.

"Ficus Fever is sweeping the nation," said Moore.
"In a country where the majority no longer vote,
writing in Ficus will give the disenfranchised voter a
chance to cast a vote for "None of the Above!"

Ficus will run as both a Democrat and a
Republican because, according to Moore, "There is
little difference between the two so-called parties."

"Both the Democrat and Republican nominees for
President are for NAFTA, for the death penalty, for
increased military spending, against immediate
universal health care, against stringent gun control
that would ban handguns, and both looked like
pandering idiots regarding their exploitation of that
six-year old Cuban boy."

"But, more important, both parties are beholden to
those who pay for their campaigns. Why should the
wealthy have two parties doing their bidding, and
the other 90% of Americans have no real
representation?"

The Ficus will accept no campaign contributions.
All it needs is air, sunlight, and water.

"And a little fertilizer," which Moore said the Ficus
"should find plenty of in Washington."

Moore said that "all Ficuses running for Congress
across the country meet the Constitutional
qualifications: each Ficus is at least twenty-five
years old, each has been in the U.S. for at least
seven years, and each is a resident of the district
where it seeks election."

A search of the official Ficus website -
www.Ficus2000.com - confirms that at least
twenty-one potted plants are running as write-in
candidates in states such as California, Illinois,
Pennsylvania, and Alabama.

The Congressional seat in New Jersey's 11th
District, which covers Morris County and part of
Essex County - and is inhabited by the state's
highest income earners - is currently held by Rep.
Rodney Frelinghuysen, a three-term Republican,
and the thirteenth wealthiest member of Congress.
Frelinghuysen's father once held the same seat
and, since 1793, New Jersey has sent six
Frelinghuysens to Congress -- four to the U.S.
Senate and two to the House of Representatives.

"We think it's time to point out to the Frelinghuysen
Family that we live in a democracy, not a dynasty. If
no credible human out of the district's 500,000
voters was willing to step forward and challenge
Mr. Frelinghuysen, at least the voters now have a
houseplant to give them a real choice on June 6."

Moore said the Ficus will run under the slogans:
"FICUS: Because We Deserve Better"
and
"Put a Houseplant in the House - Vote Ficus."

Anyone around the country who would like to
challenge their incumbent Congressman with a
potted plant is encouraged to contact Moore on the
www.Ficus2000.com web site.

"The choice is simple - hot air or oxygen? I've seen
a lot of politicians lie, cheat, steal, and use
improper syntax. I have never met one who can
perform photosynthesis."

Ficus Congressional Districts

Alabama
6th District
1st District
3rd District

Arkansas
3rd District

North Carolina
5th District
6th District

South Carolina
4th District

Virginia
7th District
5th District
6th District
10th District

California
43rd District
14th District

Illinois
13th District

Pennsylvania
5th District
9th District

Texas
6th District
8th District
19th District

Ohio
16th District

New Jersey
11th District

Post ID:211
Sender:"paul mcgee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-27 13:45:10
Subject:Outreach Minutes for 4/23
Message:

Outreach Minutes 4/23/00

In Attendance: Cliff, Nikki, Samantha, Xavier, Joe, Paul, Little Orange Cat, 
Evil Chair

1. Over 800 surveys complete. Will reach goal of 1000 before convention!!

2. French Street: Samantha and Cliff convinced every shop to put convention 
flyer in window!! Next day they were still there.

3. Xavier getting Spanish Convention Flyer.

4. Plans to contact small businesses this week.

5. Added Tuesday at 6pm for canvassing. Meet at library.

6. Next Sunday, 4/30, canvass Livingston Manor just past Sanford St. Meet at 
11:45 at library.

7. Cliff to copy more surveys and gather all remaining Spanish lit.

8. Paul to input new names and phone nos. Will split list so everyone in 
campaign gets names. Names will correspond with team each person assigned 
to. Teams correspond with territories to be covered by triple motorcade on 
5/6.

9. Motorcade arrangements: X to get sound. 3 vans confirmed. Will confirm 
other vehicles (9) and walking participants at 4/29 meeting. Motorcade to 
convene at library at 11. Leave at 12. To outlying territories. And back to 
Joyce Kilmer Park (all teams) at 3pm. From there, motorcade to circle 
central area of NB.

10. Press conference suggested for May Day. Location? Time? To be confirmed 
with Media Committee.

11. Discussed posters, stickers, handbills. Handbills to be ready for 4/29 
weekend.

12. Next meeting 4/30 @ Joe's @ 6pm.

Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-28 01:40:02
Subject:Fwd: Vieques' Statement by Dr. Doug Rokke
Message:



>From: "Vieques Libre" <viequeslibre@...>
>To: List Member <vivaohio@...>
>Subject: Vieques' Statement by Dr. Doug Rokke
>Date: 25 Apr 2000 09:56:36 -0000
>
>Vieques Libre - http://www.viequeslibre.org
>
>To all recipients: Please broadcast, distribute, publish, and send out to
>every web server list that will accept the following comments for the
>citizens of the world.
>
>Thanks,  dr. doug rokke
>
>----------
>
>If, as indicated in the following press report that DOD officials are
>ready to use force against the residents of Vieques, then the citizens of
>the world must ban together to help the residents of Vieques.
>
>This started because U.S. Marine Corps pilots willfully fired depleted
>uranium in violation of laws and regulations, as admitted by U.S. Navy
>officials, into Vieques and then a Navy pilot dropped a bomb that killed
>one and injured others.  The claim has been that the bomb went off course.
>Funny thing about physics and Newtonian mechanics, bombs only go where you
>place them.  Therefore the claim that the bomb was errant is pure rubbish.
>The pilot killed that guard and injured the others because he was wrong
>and was not careful with the bomb release.  That is pure negligence!!!!!
>
>This is also an issue of environmental justice where U.S. Department of
>Defense representatives refuse to provide medical care for all exposed
>individuals and also complete environmental remediation.  U.S. Forces have
>contaminated the island of Vieques for too long causing health and
>environmental damage.  It must stop now. In a direct quote from:
>
>031-503-1017 Respond to Depleted Uranium/Low level Radioactive Materials
>(DULLRAM) Hazards (new)  U.S. Army  Manual of Common Tasks the Department
>of Defense authors state that:
>"NOTE: Contamination will make food and water unsafe for consumption."
>
>Seems that Navy officials know that the use of DU causes willful harm
>because it is in the required DU training that all DOD personnel must
>complete by order and law. Thus disregard of this information probably
>violates RCRA (42 CFR 901) and is a crime against humanity.
>
>Next:  The U.S. Navy cites that Vieques is needed for training our forces,
>yet, the Navy has advertised to any nation for a fee that Vieques can be
>used for as quoted "Mission: consistently provide professional customer
>services, conduct real world anti-submarine warfare training for
>aircrafts, ships, and submarines of U.S. and foreign navies...Live-fire
>capability for most non-conventional weapons inventory...to provide
>airspace, surface, and subsurface water space for developmental and
>operational testing of new and existing weapons systems."
>
>In case anyone has missed the most important part of this advertisement it
>is that  "non-conventional" as cited has historically referred to nuclear,
>biological, and chemical weapons.  If that has occurred over the years,
>that is why the residents of Vieques are sick. Conventional weapons
>residues will also cause health and environmental problems.
>
>It is time for everyone to support the residents of Vieques and demand
>that the U.S. Navy withdraw and cease all actions on that island.  Just
>remember if the Navy willingly fired DU to prepare for battle in Kosovo
>then the next preparation with "non-conventional weapons"  as advertised
>may be for use against you!
>
>
>"NOT ONE MORE BOMB"
>For additional information see:  http://www.viequeslibre.org/
>
>
>As always:  For GOD and the Citizens of the World.
>
>Dr. Doug Rokke
>
>NOTE: Dr Rokke IS THE FORMER HEAD OF PENTAGON'S DEPLETED URANIUM PROJECT
>AND ONE OF THE AUTHORS OF PENTAGON'S PROGRAM FOR ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION
>OF FORMERLY USED DEFENSE SITES
>
>Dr. ROKKE CONDEMNS ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION OF VIEQUES
>http://www.micronetix.net/virus/rokke.htm
>
>
>
> >
> > Feds May Remove Vieques Protesters
> >
> > WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal authorities are finalizing a plan to remove, 
>by
> > force if necessary, dozens of Puerto Rican protesters at a U.S. Navy
>bombing
> > range on the island of Vieques, government officials said today. The
>removal
> > operation could begin as early as next week, the officials said,
>speaking on
> > condition of anonymity. The presence of the protesters stands in the way
>of
> > fully implementing an agreement reached Jan. 31 by President Clinton and
> > Puerto Rican Gov. Pedro Rossello to permit the Navy to resume limited
>training
> > exercises on Vieques in exchange for a popular referendum to decide
> > whether to eventually close the range.

Post ID:217
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-04-27 15:53:01
Subject:Fwd: Policy Groups Invited
Message:



>From: RBender65@...
>To: NatBender@...
>Subject: Policy Groups Invited
>Date: Wed, 26 Apr 2000 16:57:38 EDT
>
>Policy Groups Invited
>
>Groups with positions on military and nuclear weapons policies are invited 
>to
>provide their literature at the forthcoming 7th Congressional District
>Candidates Forum on Saturday, May 13 in Plainfield.
>
>"The time is overdue for a public dialogue on issues of weapons and
>international relations," said Forum organizer Bob Bender of the Ethical
>Culture Society of Essex County. "More than half of the  nation's
>discretionary budget, over $300 billion proposed, about the average of the
>level of cold war spending adjusted for inflation,  is directed toward the
>military,  with little public attention. Major powers retain reliance on
>nuclear weapons capability, while Middle Powers take initiatives toward
>multilateral agreements to abolish them, following international agreements
>controlling chemical and biological weapons.  And conditions for  U.S.
>involvement around the world, including in  response to human rights
>violations, remain controversial. We look forward to having all 
>Congressional
>candidates make their views known on these issues so that  voters can take
>them into consideration in the June 6 Primary".
>
>Bender heads Debating American Military Policy, (www.damp.org)  which is
>hosting the Forum.  "Our group takes no position on these issues", Bender
>explained. "We deplore the lack of attention paid to them and want
>organizations with positions to make their views available by distributing
>their literature.  Those interested  in having table space reserved should
>call Dr. David Frost, forum host, at 908-755-3286. Candidates of course 
>will
>also have their material available".
>
>The Forum Moderator is from the League of Women Voters.
>
>The event is at the First Unitarian Society of Plainfield, 724 Park Avenue,
>Plainfield , May 13 at 2 p.m. The 7th Congressional District includes parts
>of Union, Somerset, Essex and Middlesex Counties, and is the only New 
>Jersey
>District with no incumbent seeking re-election.
>
>30

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:218
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-28 14:40:18
Subject:AGENDA for 4/29 General Meeting
Message:

From the Steering Committee:

Saturday 4/29 (2PM, new Brunswick Library) is the date 
of the last General Meeting of the People's Campaign 
before the historic May 13 People's Convention. We have 
a sizable Agenda for this meeting since we are 
undertaking an unprecedented people's democratic 
campaign with an all-volunteer team. It is essential 
that we focus on UNITY at this meeting so we can move 
forward with a united will to bring as many New 
Brunswick residents as possible to an inspiring, 
democratic and rock-solid Convention. As we always say: 
This is not an intellectual exercise, we're in it to win 
it.

In unity,

X.

*********************************************************

NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLE�S CAMPAIGN

PROPOSED AGENDA FOR THE GENERAL MEETING OF 4/29/2000

1)  INTRODUCTIONS
 
2)  REPORT FROM THE COMMITTEES

	Steering Committee
	Research Committee
	Outreach Committee		May 6th 
Motorcade - all campaign workers should join one of 
three 
teams to reach out to the outer-bounds areas of New 
Brunswick recently canvassed. 1) Reed St./Robeson 
Village  2) Huntington/Hamilton St. 
3) Raritan Gardens/Route 1   

	Media Committee
	Fundraising Committee

3)  PROPOSAL FOR CAMPAIGN ORGANIZATION 

GENERAL ASSEMBLY
All power to the people - any resident or non-resident 
campaign worker can vote.
General meetings once a month through September. October 
General Meeting to prepare for election day.   

|
|
|

STRATEGIC - STEERING COMMITTEE - POLITICAL DIRECTION OF 
CAMPAIGN
7 members:	3 candidates + 1 campaign manager + 3 at-
large-members

|
|
|

TACTICAL - CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE - ORGANIZATION OF CAMPAIGN
8 members: Campaign Manager + 4 Committee Chairs + 3 
Ward Leaders
(Will eventually have 11 members when campaign grows 
with 6 ward leaders)

|
|
|

COMMITTEES & WARD ORGANIZATIONS
Research, Media, Fundraising, Outreach. Outreach 
Committee expands into 3 Ward areas with a Ward Leader 
each (Wards 3 & 6 + Douglass, Wards 1 & 2, Wards 4 & 5), 
all under the leadership of the Outreach Chair (by 
September, grows into 6 areas & 6 Ward Leaders).

4)  ORGANIZATION OF THE CONVENTION	

	Each committee will take up one main task:

Registration 	 	Prepare Registration log, 
stickers for all participants to identify Name, Ward & 
District (or Freedom Riders from other towns), 
computerized ready-to-print numbered ballots to be 
issued at election time. Distribute, collect and count 
ballots. make posters with Ward Number and organize 
seating in Paul Robeson School auditorium by Ward.
	
Food			Prepare and serve food and 
beverages for all (large sub sandwiches
recommended). Organize of clean-up.
	
Security 		Develop procedure and 
organization to enable a democratic and efficient 
Convention.  
	
Materials		Produce and distribute of all 
Convention literature: Agenda, Program, 
posters, flyers, handbills, etc. Compile and print out 
results of citywide survey.
	
	Steering		Schedule and write 
Convention literature: draft of Program, 
Agenda, rules of debate, etc. Run Convention. 

	Child Care		Louise Ammentorp has 
volunteered to organize a team. 
Child Care workers will vote with absentee ballots.

5)  PROPOSED OVERALL SCHEDULE FOR THE CONVENTION

Registration 
Introduction
Reading of first paragraph of Declaration of 
Independence 
Singing of "We Shall Overcome" (Upbeat)
Presentation, Debate & Adoption of Campaign Program
Nominations of candidates	

LUNCH

Candidate speeches and discussion.
Election of candidates

BREAK

Election of campaign manager
Election of 3 at-large members of Steering Committee
				
	BREAK

Election of 3 Ward Leaders				
Mobilization of all participants into campaign 
organization

6)  OPENING OF NOMINATIONS FOR CITY COUNCIL CANDIDATES, 
CAMPAIGN MANAGER & STEERING COMMITTEE MEMBERS AT LARGE

7)  MOBILIZATION FOR CONVENTION

Noon time press conference on May Day + flyering	
							
Press release week of May 13
Phone canvass
Letters to Home News from all Campaign workers
Calls to WCTC radio
List of campaign endorsers

8)  DRAFT PROPOSAL  FOR CONVENTION RULES

Items not on Draft Agenda go to end of the Agenda.
All proposals taken from the floor must relate to Agenda 
item at hand and be seconded.
Chair may call a motion to vote on a proposal.
Chair can be replaced by majority vote.
Council candidates to be elected by residents only.
All other positions to be elected by residents and non-
resident campaign workers.
Any candidate wins with 51% or more of the votes cast.
Candidates with less than 50% of the vote go into a run-
off election. 
Candidates win with 51% of the vote. Run-off between 
remaining candidates if necessary.

Post ID:219
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-04-29 12:14:31
Subject:Food Not Bombs and City Machine Clash!
Message:

At 11:40 am this morning, Food Not Bombs was shut down by the
forces of the City Machine. Allies arrived as a matter of routine
patrol and press was contacted. Statements and contact information
were created. For further information, contact Frank Bright.

-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:221
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-20 13:00:42
Subject:Fwd: PNN STRIKE
Message:


>From: "Carol Spooner" <wildrose@...>
>To: <Undisclosed-Recipient:;>
>Subject: PNN STRIKE
>Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2000 07:47:10 -0800
>
>The following Press Release was issued on January 31st.  We are now half 
>way
>through the strike  -- but many people still don't know about it!  Please
>visit the strikers webpage at www.savepacifica.net/strike
>If you are not hearing much about the strike on your local station
>(particularly WBAI and KPFA, which supposedly don't enforce the Pacifica
>"gag rule") then please call the station manager and the news department 
>and
>ask for more on-air information.  The strikers need our support.  Help
>spread the word!
>
>(Also, for print monthly in-depth news and opinion on the Pacifica-wide
>crisis subscribe to the FOLIO http://www.ncal.verio.com/~gde/v1n4.htm)
>
>Carol Spooner
>Committee to Remove the Pacifica Board
>wildrose@...
>http://home.pon.net/wildrose/remove.htm
>
>
>Journalists strike to battle censorship at Pacifica Radio
>
>On January 31, 2000, Pacifica Radio's top free-lance reporters and
>contributors, backed by several nationally-recognized, free-speech
>organizations, struck Pacifica's national-news program to protest on-going
>censorship at the 50-year-old community-radio network.
>
>"We believe Pacifica management seeks to intimidate and censor those who 
>try
>to report on matters that management prefers to keep quiet," said PNN
>contributor Aaron Glantz from his base in Berkeley. "Management has not 
>only
>failed to stop censoring the news, management has not even bothered to
>contact us to respond to our concerns. So we have no choice but to strike,"
>Glantz added.
>
>Dozens of journalists from across the Americas, Europe and Asia, many of
>whom have won the industry's top awards, will strike for the next three
>months unless Mary Frances Berry, who chairs both the U.S. Civil Rights
>Commission and the Pacifica Foundation, publicly renounces censorship
>throughout the network, and reasserts the editorial independence of
>Pacifica's local and national-news divisions. The striking journalists
>comprise a majority of active contributors and reporters to Pacifica 
>Network
>News, PNN, a daily, half-hour news program that airs on some 70 radio
>stations nationally. In a recent two-month period, nearly 70% of Pacifica's
>stories came from its stringers.
>
>The striking reporters delivered a signed letter one week ago outlining
>their demands to Pacifica's entire national board, including chair Mary
>Frances Berry, via certified mail, fax and e-mail. To date, there has been
>no official response from Pacifica. Several attempts by the reporters to
>reach Pacifica management--which has not released its phone number to the
>public--have been unsuccessful.
>
>Since the letter was delivered to management last Monday, additional
>stringers have joined the action, and several affiliates are considering a
>boycott of Pacifica Network News as an act of solidarity with the striking
>reporters.
>The strike is supported by the media watchdog group Fairness and Accuracy 
>in
>Reporting, Project Censored and the National Association for Freedom of
>Expression. "The survival of PNN as a reliable source of information is 
>very
>much in doubt," said syndicated media critic Norman Solomon, "this strike
>may be the last chance to make PNN something trustworthy."
>
>Pacifica has long been a bastion of free speech--from broadcasting Allen
>Ginsberg's "Howl," to defying the HUAC witch hunts, to airing the
>commentaries of death-row journalist Mumia Abu Jamal. Since the crisis last
>spring, when armed guards were called in to lock out staff at KPFA, 
>Pacifica
>reporters say management has subjected journalists, contributors and
>independent producers to repeated acts of alteration, suppression and
>censorship of news stories and public-affairs programming, which they say
>are of vital interest to the listeners of Pacifica and the broader
>communities it serves. Reporters also note that management has repeatedly
>silenced programs in mid-broadcast, and ousted signature voices such as 
>Polk
>award-winner Larry Bensky.
>
>In November, Pacifica Network News director Dan Coughlin was "removed" 
>after
>airing a story on a boycott by sixteen Pacifica affiliates over the issue 
>of
>censorship. Most recently, veteran news anchor Verna Avery-Brown, the only
>African-American national-news anchor in public broadcasting, resigned
>amidst the crisis at PNN. Brown cited, among other concerns, censorship and
>a disturbing trend away from progressive coverage in Pacifica's national
>news. The strikers are also demanding that Coughlin be reinstated.
>
>The type of direct censorship of news personnel and programming which
>Pacifica management has been engaging in throughout the network's recent
>crisis would be reprehensible at any U.S. media outlet, not just one which
>claims to present an alternative viewpoint," added former Pacifica Network
>News director and former National Public Radio producer JoAnn Kawell.
>
>Kawell, who is on the steering committee of the National Writers Union, San
>Francisco Bay Area local, appeared at a press conference for the striking
>journalists today in Berkeley. Other speakers include Peter Phillips,
>director of Project Censored; Aileen Alfandary, co-director of the KPFA 
>News
>and member of CWA Local 9415; and Matthew Lasar, author of Pacifica Radio:
>the Rise of an Alternative Network. RealAudio of the press conference |
>Aileen Alfandary's comments in text format
>
>How can you support the strike?  Go to the strikers webpage
>www.savepacifica.net/strike to find out -- spread the word!
>

______________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free Email at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:222
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 11:41:03
Subject:Fwd: big demo in NJ
Message:


>From: Jeanne Locicero <locicero@...>
>To: Tracey Luszcz <traceyx@...>, Matt Smith <VivaOhio@...>, 
>        kristina bas <krisbas@...>,        Shana Stein 
><punky@...>, Karen Asson <renren59@...>
>Subject: big demo in NJ
>Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2000 11:27:32 -0500
>
>Florham Pk. braces for World Bank protest
>
>From: eastcoastnet@...
>
>Hundreds of police will descend on Florham Park
>on Thursday for the start of the World Bank and
>International Monetary Fund meeting, in hopes
>of averting the kind of mayhem that erupted in
>Seattle last December.
>
>Demonstrators from national unions to local civic
>groups have said they will stage an around-the-clock
>protest through the meeting's conclusion on Saturday.
>
>Agents from the Secret Service and FBI have held
>tactical sessions with officials from the Morris County
>sheriff's and prosecutor's offices, as well as the New Jersey
>State Police and borough police. At least one more
>meeting is scheduled for today, officials said.
>
>"We're hoping people do not come to protest," Florham
>Park Mayor Barbara B. Doyle said yesterday. "We're
>encouraging people not to, but we recognize their
>right to free speech, so we will be prepared."
>
>Morris County officials did not know why Florham
>Park was chosen as the site of the meeting.
>
>The rally at the Hamilton Park Conference Center,
>advertised on several groups' Internet sites and
>through mass e-mailings, is intended to highlight
>what activists contend are poor economic
>policies imposed by the World Bank on developing
>countries.
>
>The protest is a prelude to a larger demonstration
>known as the "Festival of Resistance" set for April 16 and
>17 in Washington, D.C., organizers said.
>
>"One of the main things we want to see is debt
>cancellations for all the poor, third-world countries," said
>Carol Gay, chairwoman of New Jersey Jobs with Justice
>and a Communications Workers of America union member.
>
>The protest in Morris County comes about four months
>after tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on
>Seattle for the World Trade Organization's ministers
>meeting, which saw vandalism and violent clashes
>between police and pickets.
>
>Authorities here have not made such detailed preparations
>since last June, when a 12-hour "rave" concert was
>scheduled - and highly publicized on the Internet - at
>the Mennen Sports Arena in Morris Township. The result
>was the arrest of 80 young people and a police overtime
>bill of about $46,000 still not recovered from the promoter.
>
>Sheriff Edward V. Rochford yesterday said all 225 employees
>in his department will be on duty for the protest.
>
>Also, all 39 Morris municipalities have been told they may
>be needed to respond in case of an emergency. It is the
>first time the Morris County Regional Emergency
>Deployment System (MCREDS) has been initiated.
>
>"We're hoping for the best but preparing for the worst,"
>Rochford said. "Our policy is for restraint. We're going to
>let the protesters do whatever they want that is legal."
>
>Protest organizers - which also include the New Jersey
>Industrial Union Council, AFL-CIO and the Bergen Action
>Network - said they are planning a nonviolent display that
>will include a teach-in and large rally.
>
>"One of the legacies of Seattle is it kind of woke people up
>to their concerns of economic globalization," said
>Jim Burchell, director of Morristown-based Peace Works.
>"But one of the downsides was the violence, which was
>only a small part of what went on."
>
>The World Bank's invitation-only meeting will include speeches
>by its president, James Wolfenson, and IMF Acting Managing
>Director Stanley Fisher.
>
>"We have problems in that they're not open to the public
>and that they're not open to democracy," said Bennet D.
>Zurofsky, a Newark attorney representing the rally
>coalition free of charge.
>
>"I am quite certain there are a number of people willing
>to be arrested because of civil disobedience," he said. "I
>could see someone, for example, going up to the
>conference door and asking to present a position."
>
>Officials are ready to make arrests, if necessary. The old
>county jail is overcrowded, so authorities are prepared to
>prematurely open the new jail in Morris Township, which
>is still officially under construction.
>
>"If there is an unusual number of arrests, we'll have a
>number of Superior Court judges on call, and we'll make
>sure people get a prompt hearing wherever they are,"
>Superior Court Assignment Judge Reginald Stanton
>said yesterday.
>
>Planning continues this week for the rally, but Burchell
>said appearances by several speakers, a rap poet, the Peace
>Punk Band and the Solidarity Singers, who perform
>old union songs, are confirmed.
>
>"The unknown is what will be the turnout," said Morris County
>Prosecutor John B. Dangler.
>
>"There might be 50 people or 5,000, so we'll just be prepared
>for either case. These are not terrorists, just people with different
>opinions."
>
>Zurofsky said the demonstrators he has spoken with vowed
>to adhere to four rules at the protest: no use of alcohol or
>drugs, no weapons, no destruction of property and no use
>of physical or verbal force.
>
>"We don't believe we are trying to do anything but engage
>in peaceful and lawful demonstration," he said.
>
>Zurofsky alerted Florham Park police, Hamilton Park officials
>and the provost at Fairleigh Dickinson University, which abuts
>the conference center, in a March 13 letter.
>
>It stated: "The demonstrators want to make arrangements
>to conduct their activities . . These arrangements would
>include some sort of stage or speakers platform, sound
>equipment, electricity, (portable toilets) and probably some tents
>or other temporary shelters."
>
>Burchell said organizers would supply that equipment,
>but needed the approval of Hamilton Park officials before
>setting up.
>
>"We will make sure they have a place to park and a place
>to gather near Hamilton Park," Doyle said. "We're going
>to need to have everybody on alert and we're going to incur
>a great deal of expense because of this."
>
>
>
>Article from today's Daily Record by James A. Duffy
>

______________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free Email at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:223
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 20:23:00
Subject:road widening
Message:

I went to the DOT road widening meeting.  They are going to make Rt 18 a 2 lane express and 2 lane local service each way from Rte 1 to the Albany Street bridge, with the express and local lanes clearly separated from eachother, to address the accidents that have occurred, and they also have taken into account projected growth in car traffic.  This was inot coordinated with the NJ transit people - the NJ Transit basically did a service study and determined that there was not enough demand to increase service.  Of course, they didnt estimate that based on what demand would be like if the service treated people like human beigns instead of leaving them stranded at night along the highway next to a measly metal post.  

Anyway as to changeable details - looks like there will be very little noise buffering.  Also the bike paths - to be on both sides of the road, although in many places the southbound paths curve around corners at crosstreets for a block only to serpentine back again onto the main road.  The guy I talked to recognized that people will take shortcuts and just walk across the crosstreet and I said you have to build it according to the shortcuts people will take to make it safer. 

Anyway if anyone wants a copy of the plan and the comment sheet to send in let me know.

Zofia

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

> > >Beginning at 10:00 A.M. on Saturday April 1, The New Brunswick People's
> > >Campaign will convene a motorcade in front of the New Brunswick Free
> >Public
> > >Library on Livingston Ave. The motorcade will present the campaign to
> > >different neighborhoods in New Brunswick and will highlight the issues
> > >residents seek to place on the city council's agenda.
> > >
> > >The motorcade will include a rolling platform with music, speeches and
> > >lyricists from the New Brunswick community.  Speakers will address the
> >need
> > >for all-inclusive democratic transformation of New Brunswick politics.
> > >People will follow in cars and on foot. The procession will leave the
> > >library at 11 a.m. and will stop at various landmarks in the city. 
>Among
> > >these stops will be New Brunswick Homes and The Schwartz-Robeson 
>housing
> > >complex. The motorcade will end at Feaster Park on Commercial Avenue at
> > >approximately 4:00 P.M.
> > >
> > >The New Brunswick People's Campaign is a collective effort by workers,
> > >small businesspeople and students from diverse backgrounds to elect
>three
> > >new people to the New Brunswick City Council. The campaign is based on 
>a
> > >common opposition to the democratic machine which has run the city for
> > >years. The campaign has been surveying residents on the issues for 
>eight
> > >weeks. Community control over redevelopment, police, education and
> >housing
> > >are among the most important issues for residents so far. The campaign
> >will
> > >use these results to propose a platform for a city council campaign. 
>All
> > >New Brunswick residents will be eligible to vote for their candidates
>and
> > >platform at a citywide convention on May 13th and 14th.
> > >
> > >Directions to New Brunswick Library: Take Route 18 to New Street exit
>and
> > >make a left onto Livingston Ave. The library is one block down on the
> >left.

Subject:  VIEQUES EMERGENCY ALERT!!
Date:  Mon, 01 May 2000 10:49:05 PDT
PLEASE SEND THIS MESSAGE TO EVERY LISTSERVE OR NEWSGROUP YOU CAN, THE MORE
WE GET IT OUT THE BETTER FOR THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES!!


STAND UP WITH THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES!!

JOIN US IN AN EMERGENCY PROTEST WHEN THE ARRESTS OF THE PEOPLE PARTICIPATING
IN THE CIVIL DISOBEDINECE CAMPS OCCUR!!

RALLY AT TIMES SQUARE (43RD AND BROADWAY) THE DAY AFTER THE ARRESTS AT 5PM
IF A WEEKDAY, 12 NOON SATURDAY OR SUNDAY!!

THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES HAVE BEEN ENGAGED IN AN INTENSIFYING STRUGGLE TO GET
THE NAVY OUT OF THE ISLAND MUNICIPALITY OF VIEQUES FOR THE PAST YEAR!!
RECENT REPORTS ARE SAYING THAT THE ARRESTS COULD OCCUR AS SOON AS TUEDAY
MORNING OF THIS WEEK!!  JOIN US AT TIMES SQUARE AND DEMAND THE NAVY LEAVE
VIEQUES AND SHOW YOUR SOLIDARITY WITH THE PEOPLE OF VIEQUES, PUERTO RICO!!

FOR MORE INFO. CONTACT
BEN RAMOS AT 718-601-4751
CARLOS ROVIRA AT 212-677-0619

US NAVY OUT OF VIEQUES!!
US NAVY OUT OF PUERTO RICO!!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:229
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 12:21:25
Subject:McAfee Anti-Virus Home Use mailing list.
Message:

This is for anyone who has a computer: this is the latest version of the 
foremost anti-virus software out there. McAfee is used by every major 
corporation to protect their systems. And remember, don't open any emails 
with the subject saying 'I Love You', it's a nasty virus that's crashed much 
corporate email. And don't register this software, either, or I may be 
exposed to much legal liability. Cheers, Paul

>
>The list owner has included the following welcome message:
>===========================================================
>As a Merrill Lynch employee, you are licensed to run McAfee Anti-Virus
>software on your home computer.  Distributing this software to other users
>is in violation of the licensing agreement.
>
>Use the following links to download your anti-virus software for home use.
>(If you need files to put on diskette, use the links at the bottom of this
>message.)
>
>Windows 9x
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98i403l.zip
>
>Service Pack for VirusScan for Windows9x
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/svc_pack/v98sp1.zip
>
>Windows NT (Intel)
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/winnt/intel/vnti403l.zip
>
>Windows 3.x -
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win31/mcafee/corporate/wsci402l.zip
>
>Macintosh v6.0 -
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/mac/virex6.hqx
>
>OS/2 -
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/os2/osci403l.zip
>
>Use these links to download files that are small enough to put on
>diskette.  Unzip the disks into a single directory and install the
>software from that directory.
>
>Win95 -
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l1.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l2.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l3.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l4.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l5.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l6.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/win9x/corporate/v98403l7.zip
>
>WinNT -
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/winnt/intel/vnt403l1.zip
>http://download.mcafee.com/products/licensed/virusscan/english/winnt/intel/vnt403l2.zip

Post ID:232
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 14:41:11
Subject:ILOVEYOU Virus Fix I put together
Message:

Here's what you can do to fix your PC:

LOVE VIRUS FIX

1.      A. In Windows 95/98, hit CTRL+ALT+DEL and see if you have a WSCRIPT 
file running in memory.  If so, highlight it and click END TASK.
B.      If NT Server/Workstation, hit CTRL+ALT+DEL and select Task 
List.  From the Processes Tab, if you find Wscript.exe, click it and click 
End task.
C.      NOTE: If this file is not resident in memory then you can stop 
searching on this machine only, the network or other PC's may be affected.
2.      Open Internet Explorer, Click Tools, click Internet Options and 
edit the Home Page Box to your normal Home Page (i.e. www.altavista.com) on 
the General Tab
3.      Next, click START, then RUN and type regedit in the Run Box and hit 
ENTER.  This will bring up the registry editor.
4.      Once in, double-click HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
5.      Double-click SOFTWARE
6.      Double-click MICROSOFT
7.      Double-click WINDOWS
8.      Double-click CURRENT VERSION
9.      Click RUN, find MSKernel32, right-click and select Delete
10.     Click RUNSERVICES, find Win32DLL, right-click and select Delete
11.     Now, you need to do a search on each PC and the network 
drive(s).  Login to your machine as Administrator or Admin 
equivalent.  Click START, click FIND then click FILES (OR FOLDERS).
12.     In the Named box, enter .vbs and click FIND NOW.
13.     It will search out files that end with .VBS.  You can delete any 
VBS file that is 11K in size with today's date.  If it was a .JPG file, 
then the file is completely overwritten with the virus.  If it was a .MP3 
or .MP2 file, then it made the original file a hidden file and called the 
new copy ".MP3.VBS."  The .VBS file can be deleted and the original should 
be made NOT HIDDEN by right clicking on the file, selecting Properties and 
uncheck the "Hidden" box.
14.     It also affects vbe, js, jse, css, wsh, sct, hta and jpeg in a 
similar fashion.  Again, if a .VBS file is 11K with today's date, YOU MUST 
DELETE IT BUT MAKE SURE YOU NOTE THE FILE NAME SO YOU CAN RECOVER IT FROM 
YESTERDAY'S BACKUP.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:233
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 15:24:36
Subject:Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk to be displayed at UniverSoul Circus
Message:

Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk to be displayed at UniverSoul Circus in Newark, May 
10-14

The Outreach Committee of the Lincoln Park-Coast Cultural District, Inc.,
presents the Newark-NJ-Stores Kiosk as a first step towards The Newark 
Endowment for the Arts


A component part of the overall renewal effort for the Lincoln Park-Coast 
Cultural District, the Newark-NJ-Store kiosk will be displayed at the 
UniverSoul Circus--the only Afro-American owned and operated circus in the 
world--during its visit to Newark from May 10-14.

The Newark-NJ-Store kiosk is a concept project whose goal is to amass and 
duplicate all products of Newark's (and NJ &c) native achievers.   For 
example, Books, Records, Memorabilia, Photos, Testimonials, will be 
commercially replicated and reproduced as stock for the store. So that a 
Newark-NJ-Store would be a Newark historical-cultural archive and 
tourist/institutional/scholarly resource, able to sell these products 
directly or by mail order to the many thousands of potential customers who 
would be interested.

Just to list a few of the potential contributors to this huge resource: 
Willie "The Lion" Smith, Sarah Vaughan, Jerry Lewis, Ed Koch, Allen 
Ginsberg, Sistah Soul Jah, Philip Roth, Stephen Crane, Whitney Houston. 
Melba Moore, Wayne Shorter, Eva Marie Saint, Joe Pesci, Savion Glover, 
Nathan Beard, Claude Brown, James Moody, &c &c.


A NEWARK ENDOWMENT FOR ART, CULTURE, HUMANITIES

The most profound aspect of the Newark-NJ-Store is that by getting 
agreements from the kind of contributors mentioned above, we can also get 
these important people to contribute the same kinds of materials and revenue 
and projections, of regular appearances for benefits, &c to become 
contributors to an OVERALL ARCHIVE which will be the Value Base for the 
establishment of an Endowment, which can not only serve as a basic revenue 
engine for the development of the Lincoln Park Coast Cultural District, but 
as the material foundation for the completely innovative creation of a 
municipal endowment for the Arts, Culture, Humanities in the city of Newark, 
independent of outside philanthropy, but at the same time Enhancing and 
giving prestigious embellishment for Grant Proposals that LPCCD or any arts, 
culture, humanities project generated throughout the city.

The Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk was initially unveiled to a limited audience at 
the Newark Symphony Hall for the LPCCD Gala and Dance February 25, 2000.  
Here the concept received enthusiastic support from many in Newark's 
cultural, political, and business communities.  It has since been on display 
at the NJ School of Architecture at NJIT for a conference recently held 
there by LPCCD.  The installation at the UniverSoul Circus will be the first 
time the Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk will be opened up to a wider public audience 
in Newark.

Contact Matthew Smith
(973) 372-7130
vivaohio@...



________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:235
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 23:13:16
Subject:Fwd: Letters from Puerto Rican Leaders and Jesse Jackson to Clinton
Message:



>From: "Vieques Libre" <viequeslibre@...>
>To: List Member <vivaohio@...>
>Subject: Letters from Puerto Rican Leaders and Jesse Jackson to Clinton
>Date: 4 May 2000 19:23:58 -0000
>
>Vieques Libre - http://www.viequeslibre.org
>
>April 27, 2000
>
>
>President William J. Clinton
>The White House
>Washington, D.C. 20500
>
>Dear President Clinton:
>
>We are writing to convey our deep concern over reports that the Federal
>government is working on a plan to remove the protesters - by force if
>necessary - from their site on the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico. Use of
>force in this situation, with its potential for loss of life and the
>ensuing disruption to the fabric of civil society in Puerto Rico, would
>work to prevent a just resolution of this crisis.
>
>Thousands of people throughout Puerto Rico and the United States have
>already pledged to support the protesters should they be arrested and/or
>forcibly removed. Notwithstanding the sudden decision of the Governor of
>Puerto Rico to allow continued bombing of Vieques, there is no popular
>support for Navy presence in Vieques, and widespread actions of civil
>disobedience would seem inevitable.
>
>Vieques residents - United States citizens - have suffered fifty years of
>naval bombardment and amphibious assault drills by the Atlantic Fleet
>Weapon Training Force (A.F.W.T.F.). Enormous damage has been done to the
>island and its residents in consequence, and Puerto Ricans and their
>supporters in the United States are justly outraged at the notion of
>continued Naval presence. Coral reefs have been pulverized, the aquifer
>has been contaminated with chemicals, hundred of acres of tropical
>hardwood forests have been deforested, and endangered species have been
>destroyed. The islands' population has also been contaminated with
>excessive levels of dangerous chemicals associated with the military
>operations including lead, cadmium, arsenic and uranium: The island has
>the highest mortality rate in Puerto Rico, and the highest rates of cancer
>An innocent civilian was recently killed outright as a result of Naval
>presence on the island.
>
>The Puerto Rican people have made it clear that they will no longer accept
>use of uranium weaponry by the Navy, which is illegal and which violates
>the Navy's licensing agreement with the government of Puerto Rico.
>Similarly, the Navy's practice of renting the Island of Vieques to foreign
>governments cannot be justified as a national security necessity.
>
>This situation clearly requires delicacy and tact. Surely the national
>security of the United States should not come at the expense of a
>colonized people. We join with the people of Puerto Rico in the justice of
>their cause, and call on this administration to work harder to find a fair
>resolution to what will otherwise become an even more difficult conflict.
>We recognize that this is an extraordinary circumstance and urgently
>propose a joint meeting to discuss this matter further. Please contact
>Juan A_ Figueroa, President of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and
>Education Fund at (212) 219-3360, ext. 230 to make arrangements for this
>essential meeting.
>
>Sincerely,
>
>
>Luis V. Gutierrez
>Member of Congress
>
>Jos� Serrano
>Member of Congress
>
>Nydia Velasquez
>Member of Congress
>
>Fernando Ferrer
>Bronx Borough President
>
>Roberto Ramirez
>Assembly Member New York State
>
>Angel L. Ortiz
>Council Member At-Large Philadelphia
>
>Jos� Rivera
>Council Member New York City
>
>Margarita L�pez
>Council Member New York City
>
>Reverend Jesse Jackson
>
>Dennis Rivera
>President, 1199 SEIU
>
>Juan A. Figueroa
>President, Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund
>
>
>
>=================================================
>
>May 1, 2000
>
>President William J. Clinton
>The White House
>Washington, D.C. 20500
>
>Dear President Clinton:
>
>We are writing this as a follow-up to our telegram of April 27, which
>expressed concern over reports that the Federal government is planning to
>remove the protesters from their campsite on the island of Vieques, Puerto
>Rico. Although we addressed letters to you, Janet Reno and Vice President
>Gore, the only response from the administration thus far has been an
>invitation to attend a meeting with Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder
>tomorrow at 4:00 p.m. in Washington, D.C.
>
>We feel strongly that the situation is sufficiently urgent to require your
>attendance, as Commander-in-Chief, at any such meeting. Reports have
>identified Wednesday as the day chosen for the Federal government's
>possibly forceful action against the protesters. These arrests, with their
>potential for deep civil unrest, must not take place in such a manner.
>
>Again, we urge that you meet with us to discuss ways of diffusing the
>situation in Puerto Rico, which also has attendant repercussions in the
>larger Puerto Rican and Latino community in the United States. Please
>contact Juan A. Figueroa, President of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and
>Education Fund at (212) 219-3360, ext. 230 to arrange this essential
>meeting.
>
>Sincerely,
>
>
>Reverend Jesse Jackson
>
>Dennis Rivera
>President, 1199 SEIU
>
>Juan A. Figueroa
>President, Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund
>
>
>on behalf of all the signatories to the April 37 letter.
>
>
>______________________________________________________________________
>To unsubscribe, write to viequeslibre-unsubscribe@...
>Start Your Own FREE Email List at http://www.listbot.com/links/joinlb
>
