> > > > So..Amiri Baraka does not agree with you about China and North Korea.
> I
> > > > certainly view China (especially before the capitalist-restoration
> > period)
> > > > as a socialist nation, and I view N. Korea as such as well. I view
> them
> > as
> > > > open to criticism too, but worthy of admiration. I sincerely doubt the
> > > > nature of either of these nations will be at issue at the convention.
> > The
> > > > talk was an NJFO meeting, aimed more or less at revolutionaries or
> > people
> > > > interested in the revolutionary perspective--not intended to embrace
> the
> > > > "minimum-program" perspective of the united front itself. And I must
> > say,
> > > > I don't see why agreement on China and North Korea should determine
> this
> > > > issue. For example, I think the CPUSA is an example of a Khruschevian
> > > > revisionist party. Would I oppose, say, Judith Le Blanc speaking at
> the
> > > > convention if she supported the program because I disagree with her
> > about
> > > > Stalin and the nature of revisionism? No. That is sectarianism at its
> > > > worst.
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > > 
> > > > > I also found Xavier's titling of him as the "Leader of the modern
> > > People's
> > > > > Campaign movement" as confusing.  Perhaps Xavier sees Amiri Baraka
> as
> > > his
> > > > > commander.  But I bow to no such gods.  This is the People's
> Campaign,
> > > not
> > > > > Baraka's campaign.  The title attributed to him in that convention
> > > > schedule
> > > > > makes this unclear. 
> > > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > X was, I believe, referring to the fact that Baraka's led this sort of
> > > > campaign before, and that there is to an extent a model from which we
> > are
> > > > learning and working. NJFO put out the call to this Convention and we
> > did
> > > > not cut the plans for it out of whole cloth; rather, we relied on the
> > > > experience of people like Baraka in leading this specific type of
> > campaign
> > > > organization. It's not an official title, maybe "a leader" rather than
> > > > "the" would be more appropriate.
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > > I tend to suspect that the steering committee purposely left out the
> > > > Baraka
> > > > > question, knowing that it would bring about controversy.  I
> certainly
> > > > don't
> > > > > consider NJFO and Block on Lock to be representative of a diverse
> > group
> > > of
> > > > > views, even (or especially) on the left.  
> > > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > Don't you think it would have been mentioned as a certainty at NJFO
> > > > meetings if it *was* a certainty? It wasn't, because it *wasn't*.
> > > > "Hopefully Baraka can speak," people said--you can't vote on that,
> > > > unfortunately. Baraka could speak, the steering committee, charged
> with
> > > > campaign organization (and *not* with an NJFO majority) voted that
> they
> > > > wanted Baraka to speak. It happened after the general meeting. That's
> > > > unfortunate, but I seriously doubt the vote at the general meeting
> would
> > > > have been any different. 
> > > > 
> > > > NJFO and Block and Lock represent 2 specific groups in the campaign
> who
> > > > have done a *lot* of work. Other people and other groups have as well.
> > > > They are representative of 2 of the largest "caucuses" or "factions"
> of
> > > > campaign activists--not the only ones, of course, but 2 of them. I
> don't
> > > > think everyone not affiliated with these groups would oppose
> > > > Baraka--especially since quite a few unaffiliated people came to the
> > NJFO
> > > > speech. 
> > > > 
> > > > As to "representative of the Left"-in this campaign, they *are*. Guess
> > > > what? I don't see the DSA working on this campaign, I don't see the
> > CPUSA
> > > > working on this campaign, I don't see the PLP, I don't see Workers
> > World,
> > > > I don't see the SWP, I don't see the Sparts--if they're not part of
> the
> > > > campaign, they don't get to choose the campaign's convention speaker.
> If
> > > > they show up at the convention and want to get involved, more power to
> > > > them...but they still wouldn't have been at that general meeting, and
> > > > we're not voting on a keynote speaker from the floor the day of the
> > > > convention. 
> > > > 
> > > > IIRC, Cliff mentioned Baraka at the general meeting and his ideas as a
> > > > reason one should support the elected school board position (I think
> it
> > > > was that vote). Whatever vote it was, in all the ensuing discussion,
> > there
> > > > wasn't one bit of debate about this supposed immensely controversial
> > > > quote.
> > > > 
> > > > > I have yet to read anything particularly insightful from Herr
> Baraka.
> > > > Most
> > > > > of what he puts out are simplified regurgitations of conventional
> > > > left-wing
> > > > > notions combined with unfounded off-the-wall statements designed to
> > get
> > > a
> > > > > reaction from the crowd, such as the assertion that "The CIA created
> > > AIDS
> > > > to
> > > > > destroy the Black race."  He's a Black nationalist shock jock who
> has
> > > > > adopted Marxism-Leninism as his religion of choice.  
> > > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > Well, Baraka criticizes cultural nationalism and any sectarian
> > > > nationalism. Certainly he upholds the concept of self-determination,
> as
> > > > does aNJFO, and as is the "traditional" US Marxist-Leninist position
> (as
> > > > in the CPUSA pre-1956). Self-determination for oppressed peoples is
> > > > integral to any ideology of freedom or liberation; and to understand
> > > > self-determination in the context of the struggle for liberation for
> > > > Blacks in America it is necessary to understand the national question.
> > > > This doesn't make Baraka a narrow nationalist any more than the idea
> of
> > > > self-determination for women makes Sisterhood and Struggle bourgeois
> > > > feminists. 
> > > > 
> > > > What's the citation for that AIDS quote? That's not something I
> > > > believe--because it hasn't been proven. However, knowing what we do
> > about
> > > > biological warfare, etc, to be perfectly honest, it wouldn't
> > particularly
> > > > surprise me. It's quite revealing as to the distrust of the CIA, etc,
> in
> > > > African American communities that such concepts *are* frequently
> > rumored.
> > > > In any case, an area of disagreement is just that.
> > > > 
> > > > Except...now Baraka's too conventional, when he's not too
> off-the-wall.
> > > > The speech at NJFO was basic, was introductory, covered concepts in a
> > > > concise, clear manner. Actually, the Left could use a lot more of
> that. 
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > > These are some of the arguments that I would have made if this was
> > > > actually
> > > > > brought up for any sort of discussion.  I find it highly curious
> that
> > we
> > > > had
> > > > > time to discuss the heck out of what to read at the opening, but
> > somehow
> > > > > missed the issue of the keynote speaker.  Given all the talk I have
> > > heard
> > > > at
> > > > > NJFO meetings of how NJFO is going to remain in control of the
> > campaign,
> > > I
> > > > > have reason to be suspicious.  "Undue" influence is indeed a
> > subjective
> > > > > judgement, Charlotte.  What is undue to me might be perfectly in
> line
> > > with
> > > > > the "Role of Revolutionaries in the United Front" <sic> to you.
> > > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > If the steering committee had known, I'm sure it would havee been
> > included
> > > > on the convention agenda list of items. The opening reading discussion
> > > > continued a discussion from the previous steering committee meeting,
> and
> > > > *people had opinions.* It wasn't some kind of eeevil NJFO plot. Gee,
> > what
> > > > I've heard at NJFO meetings has more to do with forwarding the
> > > > revolutionary line within the campaign while preserving unity,
> > encouraging
> > > > the development of leaders from the community, etc. Sure, we take
> > > > positions as NJFO. I don't think I've ever heard it expressed as
> "taking
> > > > control of the campaign;" rather, I've heard and participated in
> > > > discussions about our responsibility as campaign initiators and as a
> > > > leading force in the campaign. Sure, NJFO represents a faction--as
> does
> > > > *every other* grouping. Except we have open public meetings. Thursdays
> > at
> > > > 7:30. You come, anyone can come, they don't have to agree, they're
> > > > welcome, and there aren't any secret agreeements, meetings or
> > discussions.
> > > > The disagreements and criticisms as well as the development of line
> are
> > > > all OPEN TO THE PUBLIC. 
> > > > 
> > > > Chris, you are implying that NJFO engineered an underhanded campaign
> > coup.
> > > > That's simply not true and completely at odds with the reality of
> > > > everything NJFO's done during this campaign. And yeah, I do believe in
> > > > practicing as a revolutionary and strengthening unity--that's what a
> > > > people's-democratic united front is all about. I fail to see anything
> > > > undue or underhanded about that. 
> > > > 
> > > > > Chris
> > > > > 
> > > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > > From: Charlotte L. Kates
> > > > > To: Komuves, Flavio
> > > > > Cc: 'Zofia Nowakowski'; 'nadler@...';

> > > > > Subject: Amiri Baraka's Speech
> > > > > 
> > > > > Just to comment--this speech will obviously be very short, nothing
> > like
> > > > > the usual lengths of "keynote speeches," since the half-hour
> allotted
> > to
> > > > > the speech also will include a speaker from the Latino Committee and
> > > > > Frank's presentation of the rules and agenda of the
> > > > > convention--certainly
> > > > > something that will take time. 
> > > > > 
> > > > > As I see it, the steering committee was able to ascertain--after the
> > > > > general meeting (at which the convention schedule was voted upon
> very
> > > > > hurriedly, due to lack of time)--that Amiri Baraka could speak.

> > > > > he's
> > > > > been deeply involved and a leader in similar independent political
> > > > > struggles in Newark (struggle for an African American mayor, Ras
> > Baraka
> > > > > campaigns, etc), as well as being a person who many people in the
> > > > > campaign--not just NJFO members--respect and welcome advice from,
> the
> > > > > committee--which was charged with such responsibilities of ordering
> > the
> > > > > convention--voted that he should speak in that half-hour period. In
> > > > > addition, when he came to New Brunswick to speak at an NJFO meeting
> > > > > about
> > > > > the united front, many campaign activists who are not in NJFO,
> > including
> > > > > many representatives of Block and Lock Productions and other
> > > > > unaffiliated
> > > > > campaign members, attended the event with great interest. Therefore,
> > > > > IMO,
> > > > > the steering committee was and is quite justified in determining
> that
> > > > > there is interest in hearing a (quite short) speech from Amiri
> Baraka
> > > > > that
> > > > > is relevant to the issue of independent peoples' candidates. 
> > > > > 
> > > > > I raise the point of "not just NJFO," because I assume we are the
> > fringe
> > > > > group to whom Chris refers. I do not see NJFO as a "fringe group" at
> > > > > all,
> > > > > which is reflected in NJFO's *practice*--which has stressed campaign
> > > > > unity
> > > > > and democracy, based on the principles of a united front. NJFO
> members
> > > > > have been leaders in the Campaign, initiators, and activists, yet
> NJFO
> > > > > has
> > > > > never engaged in behind-the-scenes or underhanded tactics of

> > > > > admired and respected by many campaign activists, and although I'm
> not
> > > > > on

> > > > > discussion,

> > speaker

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:258
Sender:Chris Kozlowski <ckozlowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 09:17:34
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amir i Baraka's speech
Message:







On Wed, 10 May 2000, Charlotte L. Kates wrote:

>The program appeals to the middle class of New Brunswick. There are
>different class interests represented within the campaign; the working
>class has been nearly entirely excluded from the political process in this
>city, and the campaign is working to change that. We've met members of the
>middle class, members of the working class, who don't yet recognize that
>their class interests lie in unity. It is the goal of the campaign to
>show, through our unity and our *action* on our program, that unity around
>this program will benefit all of their respective class interests. 

That's lovely in theory, Charlotte.  What has been done in practice to
mobilize the middle class and reach out to them to actively promote the
campaign in their eyes?  The actions on the program will never get a chance
to run their course if the election is not won.  And it seriously undermines
our chances to do so if we focus so extensively on the middle class.

The attitude I speak if is evident from your paragraph above, where you
imply a distinction between "middle class" and "working class".  This is
pseudo-Marxist nonsense.  The interests of working people are, of course,
not disparate between lower classes and middle classes.   But you make it
pretty clear in the above paragraph that the middle class is not the working
class to you -- that they are another creature altogether.  That is not only
a tactical mistake, it is an insult to middle class people who are just as
dependent on a paycheck for their daily lives.  This political faux pas
results from the antiquated view of class relations that has yet to be
adapted to life in New Brunswick in the 21st century.  It further
underscores the need for stronger non-Communist leadership in the People's
Campaign.

>What is this lack of understanding you speak of? What, you think we're
>canvassing *any* neighborhoods by saying, "Join the socialist revolution,
>vote for the People's Campaign"? I don't *think* so, Chris--instead we've
>been surveying, Tom's done crosstabs and statistics on the surveys to see
>what different groups' main concerns are, etc. When we wrote the
>invitations to join the Campaign, we addressed letters to various commuity
>leaders, community groups, small businesses, students, etc--addressing the
>different class interests and concerns that are jointly served by unity.
>That was before the Campaign took off, so it was a solely NJFO project at
>the time. NJFO has *always* attempted to unite a broad class basis in this
>united front. 

Don't say it -- do it.  I remember when about a year ago, NJFO managed to
convince a few businessmen and better-off middle class folk to come to a
fundraising meeting for the organization, where beautiful packets were
devised which, on the very first page, had pictures of Lenin and such
illustrious slogans as "Win the Advanced to Communism!"  Needless to say,
there were not many funds raised.  This is the type of nearsightedness and
impractical clinging to outmoded rhetoric that leaves me concerned as to the
fate of the campaign if the campaign is left in NJFO's hands, without
appropriate checks and balances.  This is the type of nonsense I expect from
Amiri Baraka as well -- the "keynote speaker" of our "united front" who also
writes about how we must "throw Republicans in the trash".  United whaaa?

>Certainly the city machine will do everything it can to stop the campaign.
>Someone I was speaking with tonight compared the NB city machine to an old
>early 20th-century Democratic machine--complete with the danger of
>beatings and the inevitability of corruption. The city machine *will*
>attack us. The city machine *will* attack NJFO. Tney've done it before.
>The task before us, however, is not to become callous opportunists who
>abandon our honest political agendas because "someone might not like it."
>What we must do is publicize the program of the Campaign, organize, draw
>in new people, and lead the vast majority of classes in the City to
>recognize that their common interests are best expressed by joining with
>the Campaign to put our program in office.

Again, examples, plans, how are we going to do this?  By saying that we are?
The same way that we are allegedly a "united front?"  As far as Communism is
concerned, not only does "someone" not like it, the vast majority of
Americans are utterly alienated from it.  Is your ideology more important
than making people's lives better?  You certainly give me that impression.

>I've not seen NJFO organizers make the claim you say we do. Quote or
>citation please? On the other hand, I've seen NJFO organizers commend
>Frank for doing such a great job working with his contacts, I've seen NJFO
>organizers consistently insist on the importance of student involvement in
>the Campaign at all levels, I've seen NJFO organizers discuss the various
>ways of getting middle class people involved in this campaign, from
>approaching small business owners about the problems they face due to
>redevelopment interests to advertising in Hungarian-language publications. 

What claim are you referring to?  Bring small business owners into a meeting
where X talks about the ballot or the bullet, and how we are going to try
the bullet next if the ballot does not suffice.  See how quickly they leave
and tell their friends that we are a bunch of lunatics.

>> Furthermore, while Frank is on the campaign, and his valiant efforts to
>> conscript Republicans onto the People's Campaign are commendable, they
have
>> been unwittingly thwarted by failing to account for the necessary
>> concessions of a united front.  The entire concept of a united front is
to
>> organize around a common agenda that can be sold to all those you wish to
>> participate.  Thinly veiled -- or even explicit -- affronts against
>> political moderates are not uncommon on the Campaign mailing list, and
the
>> idiotic discussion between Cliff and Xavier two meetings ago on the
>> viability of "seizing power without a revolution", among other examples
of
>> childish role-playing of "revolutionary" roles served to alienate a good
>> portion of people who could have offered a significant contribution to
the
>> campaign.  NJFO would do well to stop playing self-important faux
guerillas
>> and acknowledge the fact that you are not revolutionaries or Red Army
>> officers, but activists.  While I'm sure some of you would love to see a
red
>> flag flying over New Brunswick and secret police dutifully seeking out
those
>> failing to adhere to 'the correct ideas', revolution is not going to
happen
>> in New Brunswick.  The possibility for real social change is there, but
you
>> have to let go of your pipe dreams and be a little more practical.  

>Frank's work is great. I'm very glad he's doing it. After all, approaching
>landlords about rent control is difficult, and he's doing it. Good for
>him---he's doing what he's good at doing--and raising plenty of funds! The
>"necessary concessions" of a united front don't include abandoning one's
>right to independent organization, ideology, and activity. To do such
>would be pure opportunism, and not reflective of a united front at all.
>Instead, we are *open and above-board*. NJFO is not in hiding, and should
>not be.

No one said anything about hiding.  You mentioned a few messages back the
necessity of allowing people and groups to put forth their "maximum
program", and you cited the example of the unapproved "Revolutionary
Democratic Workers Party" flyers.  I disagreed with you.  There should not
be flyers that do not stress the campaign platform and the common agenda.
The essential issue with the campaign today is that there is no campaign
discipline.  People continue to practice their personal politics.  What
other organization would tolerate something like this -- especially if we
are indeed "in it to win it", and not to vindicate and promote our personal
ideologies?  

>If you *remember* that meeting so well, you'll remember that NJFO voted to
>*oppose* narrow slogans and to support broad slogans. Xavier said that
>"seize power" doesn't mean you have to be a revolutionary. How exactly is
>this exclusionary? Cliff's argument was indeed one I consider
>left-sectarianism, but he's well-entitled to express it, and it was not
>upheld by the majority of people at the campaign meeting. NJFO was a voice
>*against* sectarianism and for the united front around the question of
>campaign slogans.

Why are you putting words in my mouth?  Did I say "exclusionary"?  No, I
said "idiotic".  *I'm* on the left, Charlotte, and I damn near cringed when
I heard the convoluted explanation of why we are not initiating a revolution
to seize power but instead are going for the ballot -- first.  None of the
new outsiders at that meeting showed up again.  I wonder why.

>The rest of the paragraph is silly anti-communism that should be
>recognized as such. This Campaign has *never* been a home for internal
>red-bating, and I would like to see it remain that way.

What does that mean?  What part of my paragraph is "silly anti-communism?"

>> You can scream "united front" until you turn purple, but until you start
>> acting like you want to unite people around a common platform, and STOP
>> pushing the "maximum program", at least for the next six months, the
>> establishment is going to use that as a very potent weapon to get people
out
>> to vote AGAINST the campaign.  To use Brian's example, what do you think
the
>> old Hungarian woman is going to do when the phone banks are in full
>> operation on election day, telling her to go out there and vote for the
>> Democrats because "Communists are trying to take over New Brunswick"?


>Um...we "scream" "united front," because this *is* a united front. It
>doesn't mean I stop being a Communist, and it doesn't mean Frank stops
>being a Republican because the majority of campaign members aren't either.
>*Neither* of us gives up the right to independent advocacy. When we
>represent the People's Campaign, we represent the *democratically-selected
>program*. When I represent myself as a Communist, or a member of NJFO,
>however, I represent not *just* that program, but also a socialist
>revolutionary program. To pretend otherwise would be politically
>reprehensible, dishonest and opportunist. 

I guess that is why Communists don't win elections.  Their religious fervor
is such that they cannot make practical ammendments to their rhetoric.  The
rhetoric seems to take priority to the goals.

>The united front does *not* entail *anyone* relinquishing their political
>freedom and democratic rights. This is a Communist-to-Republican
>coalition, Chris, and the Communists among us aren't any more likely to
>stop being so, or pretend to do so, than the Republicans are. When the
>city machine attacks us, we'll prove ourselves by our action and by our
>program, Chris--the campaign and *all* of its activists, including those
>from NJFO. And you know what? We'll sue them for push polling and illegal
>campaign tactics if they try those stunts. We're a *real* campaign
>organization, and determined to win. The City Machine DOES NOT have the
>right to decide what members of the People's Campaign will think, believe
>and say. Do you wish to give them that right, Chris?

Again, this seems rather half-baked.  We will not prove ourselves by our
action and our program if we are not in office after November.  Suing the
city seems like a great PR move, but hardly wins us the election.  Maybe the
reality of the courtroom is something that has not occurred to you yet.  

We really do want to be a real campaign organization, and it is damn well
time to start acting like it.  

>And seriously, Chris, again, what specifically are your criticisms of how
>NJFO has apparently created some kind of campaign disunity? I don't
>remember you raising any of this at the general meeting--at which everyone
>had *plenty* of time to speak. You think important issues should be raised
>there (even though you now are aware that the Baraka confirmation came
>*after* that meeting). Why didn't you raise yours in that open, democratic
>forum? 

This is an issue that becomes clearer to me with each day, and each effort
to import more elements of NJFO's agenda into the People's Campaign -- case
in point, Amiri Baraka.  Good idea, though -- I will begin working on a
statement for the next general meeting.

Chris





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:259
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 12:00:30
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amir i Baraka's speech
Message:


On Thu, 11 May 2000, Chris Kozlowski wrote:

> 
> 
> On Wed, 10 May 2000, Charlotte L. Kates wrote:
> 
> >The program appeals to the middle class of New Brunswick. There are
> >different class interests represented within the campaign; the working
> >class has been nearly entirely excluded from the political process in this
> >city, and the campaign is working to change that. We've met members of the
> >middle class, members of the working class, who don't yet recognize that
> >their class interests lie in unity. It is the goal of the campaign to
> >show, through our unity and our *action* on our program, that unity around
> >this program will benefit all of their respective class interests. 
> 
> That's lovely in theory, Charlotte.  What has been done in practice to
> mobilize the middle class and reach out to them to actively promote the
> campaign in their eyes?  The actions on the program will never get a chance
> to run their course if the election is not won.  And it seriously undermines
> our chances to do so if we focus so extensively on the middle class.
> 

Canvassing in "middle-class" neighborhoods. Going around to small
businesses to talk to business owners about the Campaign. Sending letters
to small businesspeople. Talking to personal contacts. You know, the
*same* thing that's going on with every other New Brunswick community. I
take it you do not mean to say that "And it seriously undermines
 our chances to do so if we focus so extensively on the middle class."
But, quite frankly, if we follow your plan...all I can see is us *only*
organizing the "middle class." Putting the "middle class" first among the
people, so to speak. Well, this campaign is about putting the *people*
first--that's all the people. Small businessmen, lawyers, doctors, factory
workers, renters, landlords, homeowners, public housing residents,
mothers, children, women, men, Latinos, Blacks, whites, immigrants, the
unemployed, senior citizens--*everyone* who does not benefit from the city
machine's corruption and greed and big business running rampant. It's not
just one of those groups. And it's not NJFO making the mistake--it's you.
You'd have us concentrate on the "middle class" with more extensive
tactics than any other group in the city, apparently. Well--you're on the
campaign--GO DO IT! Take the intiative, Chris! Frank's doing so, and doing
a damn good job of it. If you want the campaign to organize middle class
people and you have concrete ideas on how we can do it better--why don't
you either suggest them or actually put them into practice rather than
saying NJFO isn't coming up with enough ideas for your taste?

> The attitude I speak if is evident from your paragraph above, where you
> imply a distinction between "middle class" and "working class".  This is
> pseudo-Marxist nonsense.  The interests of working people are, of course,
> not disparate between lower classes and middle classes.   But you make it
> pretty clear in the above paragraph that the middle class is not the working
> class to you -- that they are another creature altogether.  That is not only
> a tactical mistake, it is an insult to middle class people who are just as
> dependent on a paycheck for their daily lives.  This political faux pas
> results from the antiquated view of class relations that has yet to be
> adapted to life in New Brunswick in the 21st century.  It further
> underscores the need for stronger non-Communist leadership in the People's
> Campaign.


Um, small business owners, doctors, and lawyers---the "middle class" I
refer to, are *not* part of the working class. Maybe landlords.. You're
the one with the terminology of "middle class", Chris--I assumed this is
the group of people about whom you speak. But I really do not see that
this is the time or place for another long discussion about varying
conceptions of class and economic strata in the United States today,

That's not an insult to small business owners, doctors, or lawyers. I'm
not saying they don't work. Quite frankly, I *seriously* doubt most of the
above have *any* class concept of themselves as "working class." Even most
of the American working class doesn't have that consciousness, Chris. So I
don't think I'll worry about that, because the small business owners,
doctors and lawyers who think they are middle class--are right! 

(And who are the middle class you refer to if they are the working class?
Do you mean upper strata of the working class? You introduced the term to
this debate.)

If you think "we need stronger non-Communist leadership," than be a
non-Communist leader, Chris. Do something. Put something into practice,
organize the middle class--and if you *do work in the campaign* the
campaign will recognize you democratically for your work. It's sort of
like Frank. He's recognized because he does a lot for the campaign. Xavier
is recognized because he does a lot for the campaign. Samantha is
recognized because she does a lot for the campaign. If you think "we need
non-Communist leadership," don't just sit there engaging in red-baiting.
*Be* a non-communist leader.


 > 
> >What is this lack of understanding you speak of? What, you think we're
> >canvassing *any* neighborhoods by saying, "Join the socialist revolution,
> >vote for the People's Campaign"? I don't *think* so, Chris--instead we've
> >been surveying, Tom's done crosstabs and statistics on the surveys to see
> >what different groups' main concerns are, etc. When we wrote the
> >invitations to join the Campaign, we addressed letters to various commuity
> >leaders, community groups, small businesses, students, etc--addressing the
> >different class interests and concerns that are jointly served by unity.
> >That was before the Campaign took off, so it was a solely NJFO project at
> >the time. NJFO has *always* attempted to unite a broad class basis in this
> >united front. 
> 
> Don't say it -- do it.  I remember when about a year ago, NJFO managed to
> convince a few businessmen and better-off middle class folk to come to a
> fundraising meeting for the organization, where beautiful packets were
> devised which, on the very first page, had pictures of Lenin and such
> illustrious slogans as "Win the Advanced to Communism!"  Needless to say,
> there were not many funds raised.  This is the type of nearsightedness and
> impractical clinging to outmoded rhetoric that leaves me concerned as to the
> fate of the campaign if the campaign is left in NJFO's hands, without
> appropriate checks and balances.  This is the type of nonsense I expect from
> Amiri Baraka as well -- the "keynote speaker" of our "united front" who also
> writes about how we must "throw Republicans in the trash".  United whaaa?
> 

Hahahaha! Chris--NJFO members are in campaign leadership because they are
doing a lot of campaign work, including work with the above categories of
people. We're presenting a broad platform, canvassing everywhere, talking
to everyone. United front doesn't mean giving up political independence,
Chris, and I don't think you understand that. NJFO isn't an opportunist
organization. NJFO studies Marx and Lenin; NJFO sits on the editorial
board of and writes a lot of the articles for _Unity & Struggle_ with the
line "Win the advanced to Communism!" And yeah, a bunch of us are Commies.
Despite all that arduous baggage, NJFO's won respect in the community,
among campaign activists, New Brunswick residents and students for the
*work that is done*. 

Sorry we're not the kind of callow opportunists who change and hide our
politics to please some businessmen and get their money, Chris. If we were
that dishonest, we'd be better off with the city machine--so you should be
happy that NJFO is forthright, open and above-board with our politics and
our struggles. Once again, NJFO isn't even a majority on the steering
committee. NJFO's endorsements will not be all-NJFO by any stretch of the
imagination. Haven't you got it? We're saying what we are, what we believe
and putting that into practice. We aren't looking to "take over the
campaign," we're looking to foster democracy in NB--that's why when NJFO
*proposed* the campaign in the first place, we *did* so with clauses for
recall, political freedom, and open democratic discussion and majority
rule.



> >Certainly the city machine will do everything it can to stop the campaign.
> >Someone I was speaking with tonight compared the NB city machine to an old
> >early 20th-century Democratic machine--complete with the danger of
> >beatings and the inevitability of corruption. The city machine *will*
> >attack us. The city machine *will* attack NJFO. Tney've done it before.
> >The task before us, however, is not to become callous opportunists who
> >abandon our honest political agendas because "someone might not like it."
> >What we must do is publicize the program of the Campaign, organize, draw
> >in new people, and lead the vast majority of classes in the City to
> >recognize that their common interests are best expressed by joining with
> >the Campaign to put our program in office.
> 
> Again, examples, plans, how are we going to do this?  By saying that we are?
> The same way that we are allegedly a "united front?"  As far as Communism is
> concerned, not only does "someone" not like it, the vast majority of
> Americans are utterly alienated from it.  Is your ideology more important
> than making people's lives better?  You certainly give me that impression.
> 

By holding events, canvassing, speaking to contacts, organizing meetings
and events, holding motorcades and talking to people--all the stuff we're
doing now, all the stuff that NJFO members are actively involved in, all
the stuff reported at the general meeting and in the committees. That's
how. And bigger and better later. What are your proposals, Chris, for
organizing? Would you like to start putting them in *action*?

Um, we are a united front. And the more our united front expands, the
better. But we represent multiple class interests, organizations and
sectors of the NB population united around a common cause. That *is* a
united front. 

You are basically saying we should become callow opportunists who run and
hide at the faintest hint of red-bating. Chris--sorry, but we actually
believe in being open and above-board. NJFO isn't gonna stop putting out
_U&S_, we're not going to stop developing and publicizing our line.
Period. We believe in educating people about Communism and showing them
what we are *through our democratic practice*. I am appalled that you seem
to think that abridging Communists of their political rights is an
appropriate part of a democratically-run campaign.


> >I've not seen NJFO organizers make the claim you say we do. Quote or
> >citation please? On the other hand, I've seen NJFO organizers commend
> >Frank for doing such a great job working with his contacts, I've seen NJFO
> >organizers consistently insist on the importance of student involvement in
> >the Campaign at all levels, I've seen NJFO organizers discuss the various
> >ways of getting middle class people involved in this campaign, from
> >approaching small business owners about the problems they face due to
> >redevelopment interests to advertising in Hungarian-language publications. 
> 
> What claim are you referring to?  Bring small business owners into a meeting
> where X talks about the ballot or the bullet, and how we are going to try
> the bullet next if the ballot does not suffice.  See how quickly they leave
> and tell their friends that we are a bunch of lunatics.

See, the thing about the Campaign is--people can *disagree* with that
line, just as people can advocate it. If Campaign members disagree with
that line, they will *say so*, and the business owners will see debate in
action. Small business owners have got to deal with the fact that they are
one part of the coalition, just like Communists and students and tenants
and landlords and Republicans and factory workers. Else we're *not* having
a united front at all, but some sort of strange pandering front that
doesn't lead small business owners to recognize the value of unity at all.



> 
> >> Furthermore, while Frank is on the campaign, and his valiant efforts to
> >> conscript Republicans onto the People's Campaign are commendable, they
> have
> >> been unwittingly thwarted by failing to account for the necessary
> >> concessions of a united front.  The entire concept of a united front is
> to
> >> organize around a common agenda that can be sold to all those you wish to

> of

> the
> >> campaign.  NJFO would do well to stop playing self-important faux
> guerillas
> >> and acknowledge the fact that you are not revolutionaries or Red Army

> red
> >> flag flying over New Brunswick and secret police dutifully seeking out
> those
> >> failing to adhere to 'the correct ideas', revolution is not going to
> happen
> >> in New Brunswick.  The possibility for real social change is there, but
> you
> >> have to let go of your pipe dreams and be a little more practical.  
> 
> >Frank's work is great. I'm very glad he's doing it. After all, approaching
> >landlords about rent control is difficult, and he's doing it. Good for
> >him---he's doing what he's good at doing--and raising plenty of funds! The
> >"necessary concessions" of a united front don't include abandoning one's
> >right to independent organization, ideology, and activity. To do such
> >would be pure opportunism, and not reflective of a united front at all.
> >Instead, we are *open and above-board*. NJFO is not in hiding, and should
> >not be.
> 
> No one said anything about hiding.  You mentioned a few messages back the
> necessity of allowing people and groups to put forth their "maximum
> program", and you cited the example of the unapproved "Revolutionary
> Democratic Workers Party" flyers.  I disagreed with you.  There should not
> be flyers that do not stress the campaign platform and the common agenda.
> The essential issue with the campaign today is that there is no campaign
> discipline.  People continue to practice their personal politics.  What
> other organization would tolerate something like this -- especially if we
> are indeed "in it to win it", and not to vindicate and promote our personal
> ideologies?  
> 

Any group has the right to put out whatever it wishes. It can't say it's
put out by the Campaign if it's not. That's the only limitation. "Campaign
discipline" doesn't mean relinquishing political independence. It means
putting effort into practice. It means making sure we go canvass, it means
making sure we motorcade, it means bringing people to the convention.
*That's* the kind of "discipline" that matters. Or are you
advocating...<gasp> democratic centralism? It's discipline in *practice*
that means we're in it to win it. NJFO members are showing that. 


> >If you *remember* that meeting so well, you'll remember that NJFO voted to
> >*oppose* narrow slogans and to support broad slogans. Xavier said that
> >"seize power" doesn't mean you have to be a revolutionary. How exactly is
> >this exclusionary? Cliff's argument was indeed one I consider
> >left-sectarianism, but he's well-entitled to express it, and it was not
> >upheld by the majority of people at the campaign meeting. NJFO was a voice
> >*against* sectarianism and for the united front around the question of
> >campaign slogans.
> 
> Why are you putting words in my mouth?  Did I say "exclusionary"?  No, I
> said "idiotic".  *I'm* on the left, Charlotte, and I damn near cringed when
> I heard the convoluted explanation of why we are not initiating a revolution
> to seize power but instead are going for the ballot -- first.  None of the
> new outsiders at that meeting showed up again.  I wonder why.
> 

I won't choose to speculate unless I actually speak to them, or *someone*
does. Did you? Otherwise, you're attributing motive without proof. The
discussion was too *long*, perhaps, but we're not in the censorship
business at the Campaign in order to theoretically appease the
sensibilities of one group in a broad united front.


> >The rest of the paragraph is silly anti-communism that should be
> >recognized as such. This Campaign has *never* been a home for internal
> >red-bating, and I would like to see it remain that way.
> 
> What does that mean?  What part of my paragraph is "silly anti-communism?"
> 
This part, the red baiting bit: 
  NJFO would do well to stop playing self-important faux guerillas
> and acknowledge the fact that you are not revolutionaries or Red Army
> officers, but activists.  While I'm sure some of you would love to see a
red
> flag flying over New Brunswick and secret police dutifully seeking out
those
> failing to adhere to 'the correct ideas',

> >> You can scream "united front" until you turn purple, but until you start
> >> acting like you want to unite people around a common platform, and STOP

> >> establishment is going to use that as a very potent weapon to get people
> out

> >> old Hungarian woman is going to do when the phone banks are in full
> >> operation on election day, telling her to go out there and vote for the
> >> Democrats because "Communists are trying to take over New Brunswick"?
> 
> 
> >Um...we "scream" "united front," because this *is* a united front. It
> >doesn't mean I stop being a Communist, and it doesn't mean Frank stops
> >being a Republican because the majority of campaign members aren't either.
> >*Neither* of us gives up the right to independent advocacy. When we
> >represent the People's Campaign, we represent the *democratically-selected
> >program*. When I represent myself as a Communist, or a member of NJFO,
> >however, I represent not *just* that program, but also a socialist
> >revolutionary program. To pretend otherwise would be politically
> >reprehensible, dishonest and opportunist. 
> 
> I guess that is why Communists don't win elections.  Their religious fervor
> is such that they cannot make practical ammendments to their rhetoric.  The
> rhetoric seems to take priority to the goals.

So we should run "stealth commies" for office? Forget open and
above-board, let's play let's pretend and be opportunists without
principle. That's the way to go to make a change! We don't advocate
revolution in the name of the Campaign, and we've argued and voted against
those tactics.

> 
> >The united front does *not* entail *anyone* relinquishing their political
> >freedom and democratic rights. This is a Communist-to-Republican
> >coalition, Chris, and the Communists among us aren't any more likely to
> >stop being so, or pretend to do so, than the Republicans are. When the
> >city machine attacks us, we'll prove ourselves by our action and by our
> >program, Chris--the campaign and *all* of its activists, including those
> >from NJFO. And you know what? We'll sue them for push polling and illegal
> >campaign tactics if they try those stunts. We're a *real* campaign
> >organization, and determined to win. The City Machine DOES NOT have the
> >right to decide what members of the People's Campaign will think, believe
> >and say. Do you wish to give them that right, Chris?
> 
> Again, this seems rather half-baked.  We will not prove ourselves by our
> action and our program if we are not in office after November.  Suing the
> city seems like a great PR move, but hardly wins us the election.  Maybe the
> reality of the courtroom is something that has not occurred to you yet.  
> 
> We really do want to be a real campaign organization, and it is damn well
> time to start acting like it.  
> 

Exposing city machine illegal tactics would be a PR coup, but it's not
something I'm eagerly anticipating or something. We are a real campaign
organization. We show that in our practice. NJFO members are doing that,
at least, with a lot of other excellent activists, non-Communists. Who,
incidentally, don't seem prone to this type of red-baiting, perhaps
because they understand that united front doesn't mean silencing everyone
who doesn't agree with them?



> >And seriously, Chris, again, what specifically are your criticisms of how
> >NJFO has apparently created some kind of campaign disunity? I don't
> >remember you raising any of this at the general meeting--at which everyone
> >had *plenty* of time to speak. You think important issues should be raised
> >there (even though you now are aware that the Baraka confirmation came
> >*after* that meeting). Why didn't you raise yours in that open, democratic
> >forum? 
> 
> This is an issue that becomes clearer to me with each day, and each effort
> to import more elements of NJFO's agenda into the People's Campaign -- case
> in point, Amiri Baraka.  Good idea, though -- I will begin working on a
> statement for the next general meeting.
> 
What are your criticisms? What are your suggestions for improving our
practice? (You know, ones that don't violate the democratic campaign
rules. That involve actual outreach.) I bet Sam would like to hear them.
You say the issue becomes clearer--what are the clear criticisms? When
you're making these sort of allegations, one must be specific, or one is
guilty of engaging in empty red-baiting with absolutely no solutions or
suggestions for practical *work*. 

--charlotte



> Chris
>

> home appliances, and electronics AND win up to $500 
> towards your purchase!

Subject:New E-mail Virus May Hurt Worse Than 'Love'

>http://www.thestandard.com/article/display/0,1151,14993,00.html?mail
>
>By Elinor Abreu
>The bug doesn't even require a user to open the attachment for it to spread.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:261
Sender:"Nicole Adler" <nicoleadler@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 13:31:40
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amir i Baraka's speech
Message:

A few things...
(but first know, charlotte, that as i write this chris is helping me 
conact about 50 different press, this is not an easy task and it 
helps tremendously in reaching out to a lot of different people - 
middle class included)

1.  work and work alone does not a leader make.  one of the major 
failings that i see from njfo is that (i don't even know at this 
point if i should say you or we) njfo does a whole hell of a lot of 
work, but oftentimes forgets to actually ORGANIZE.  by this i mean, 
that if you all were so concerned with getting work done, you would 
have realized a long time ago that absolutely everyone can contribute 
something to this campaign. BUT--if the skilled organizers in a group 
fail to put people to work, then those people who are novice 
organizers are going to fall to the wayside.  this is such a horrible 
failing.  and i really wish it were addressed more.  

2.  frankly, you have alienated me from njfo by what you are saying.  
i am not a communist.  and yes, njfo is constantly spewing off at the 
mouth about how it's open to new ideas, but when it's own members 
criticize some of the political lines all hell breaks lose, and 
nothing of value comes out of the ensuing debate.  i have criticized 
njfo, and feel that the discussion afterwards did nothing to 
alleviate my confusion as to what e.g. the aim of u & s is, or even 
how to begin to write for it, even though i would like to write 
another article.

3.  let's be honest.  every group in this campaign is guilty of 
opportunism.  it is truly disingenuous to say otherwise.  you're 
making njfo out to be some sort of altruistic martyr in the face of 
adversity.  get real.  njfo's motives are just as weird and 
unpractical as block and locks.  

4.  you can't even see that the mere fact that amiri was INVITED w/o 
discussion is WRONG, a MISTAKE!  who the hell cares is he accepted 
without discussion?!  

5. i think you too quickly ignored the idea that we need to keep 
advertising the basic platform.  we need to keep pushing the basics.  
keep it simple!  the city is screwed up, it is making decisions for 
the few at the expense of the many.  is this right? hell no!  lots of 
people can get with that.  

-nikki





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:262
Sender:"Chris Kozlowski" <razer@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 13:49:16
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amir i Baraka's speech
Message:

You're absolutely right, Nikki.  Point 1 speaks precisely to my own
disillusionment -- no one has come to me with any work, aside from computer
issues.  The failure of organizing the skills that we have, as well as
incorporating new talent into the campaign by pushing the simple,
progressive platform that we decided on, is the reason why everyone is so
busy and not much new active blood is flowing through the campaign.  When I
brought up the possibility of mobilizing the middle class, I was essentially
told that this is not our primary focus.  Fine, but then what of those who
feel more comfortable speaking to the issues that unite us all?

My alienation is not due to personal beef.  My personal beef is due to
alienation.  It does not have to be this way.  The fact that others I have
talked with feel similarly is the reason why I have not simply bailed.

I will try to keep the list activity to a minimum, since my discussion with
Charlotte is essentially not bringing any further light to the issues.

I hope some other people get involved and voice their opinions.

Chris

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:263
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 16:37:00
Subject:Love Virus Viriant List
Message:

      As of Tuesday, May 9, anti-virus company Symantec had identified 29 
variations of the virus, transmitted through e-mails with different subject 
lines and contents. All had one thing in common: the e-mails came with 
attachments with a .VBS extension and a snake- or scroll-like icon. If you 
don't click on the attachments, you're safe.
      The following is a list of the major variants and their major 
effects. (Minor variants have the same subject lines and effects as those 
listed below, but slightly different internal code.) The variants also 
delete more obscure files than listed below and set Internet Explorer's 
start page to a range of different pages. For full details of what each 
variant does, go to Symantec's Web site.

Link to List on ABCNews.com:

http://abcnews.go.com/sections/tech/DailyNews/virus_list000510.html


http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/vbs.loveletter.a.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:264
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 16:59:34
Subject:RE: Leadership Sucks!
Message:

Yeah, I'm with Chris.  Why in the world would we want to Amiri Baraka
to speak at this convention?  I mean, after all, just because we followed 
the lead of the 1970 Peoples' Convention in Newark lead by Baraka, where 
they actually got the first black mayor of a major industrial city elected 
to office...what's all that got to do with us?  And now that we're talking 
about it, I find it awefully suspicious that we're readint the Emancipation 
Proclamation AND the Equal Rights Ammendment!  Next thing you know, the 
Steering Committee will be having us stand on our heads reciting the 
International!  Who is this "Steering Committee" anyway?  What do they mean 
"Steer"?  I didn't vote for that!  I wanted a "Navigating Committee".  Or, 
or, or a a a ahhhhhh "Semiphore Committee", so we can actually SEE what 
they're doing!  STEERING is sooo fringe...underhanded & undemocratic.  Hmph.

>I am curious as to why during the voting on the convention schedule at the
>last general meeting, there was no vote called on the presence of Amiri
>Baraka -- certainly no note of his being the "keynote speaker".  Since 
>Amiri
>Baraka is in Newark and represents a fringe movement, I suspect that the
>general body would at least be interested in an open discussion of what his
>role should be at the convention.  How did this get slipped in there?  
>Seems
>like an important oversight to me.  Apparently, the steering committee took
>its share of liberties with the topics presented to the general assembly.

>From: xavier.hansen@...
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Sent: 5/9/00 3:18 PM
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] CONVENTION SCHEDULE
>
>From the Steering Committee:
>
>Here is the schedule for the historic first New
>Brunswick People's Convention this Saturday May 13, from
>10AM to 6PM at Paul Robeson School. The final draft of
>the Campaign Platform and the Election rules will be
>posted in the next 24 hours.
>
>Let's all make an energetic drive to bring as many
>people as we can and remember that unity and principled
>struggle are the key to our success.
>
>In unity,
>
>X.
>
>**************************************************
>
>SCHEDULE FOR THE NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLE'S CONVENTION
>
>Saturday May 13, 2000 at Paul Robeson School
>
>10:00 AM - 	Registration begins
>
>10:30 AM - 	Introduction by Curtis Warren, Sr. -
>reading of the Emancipation
>Proclamation and Equal Rights Amendment
>
>Singing of "We Shall Overcome"
>
>Speaker from the Latino Committee (to be announced)
>
>Keynote Speech by Amiri Baraka, leader of the modern
>People's Convention Movement begun in Newark in 1968.
>
>Presentation of the Agenda and rules of debate by Frank
>Bright
>
>11:00 AM - 	Opening of the Convention by Chair,
>Xavier Hansen
>
>Introduction of the People's Campaign Platform
>
>11:10 AM - 	Amendments and debate on the People's
>Campaign Platform
>(One minute time limit to present or speak in favor of
>or against a proposed  amendment)
>
>12:10 PM - 	Vote on the People's Campaign Platform
>		(Entire platform will be voted on as a
>whole)
>
>12:20 PM - 	Final nominations for People's Campaign
>candidates for City Council
>
>12:30 PM - 	Lunch
>
>1:00 PM - 	Reconvening of People's Convention
>
>1:15 PM - 	Debate of People's Campaign candidates
>for City Council:
>
>		Speeches by prospective candidates (3
>minutes each)
>
>Endorsements of prospective candidates from the floor (3
>endorsements per candidate, 30 seconds each)
>
>2:15 PM - 	Vote on People's Campaign candidates for
>City Council
>		(New Brunswick residents only can  vote)
>
>2:40PM - 	Acceptance speeches by the three winning
>candidates (one minute each)
>
>2:45 PM - 	BREAK
>
>3:00 PM - 	Nominations and election of Campaign
>Manager
>		(Residents and non-resident campaign
>workers can vote)
>
>3:30 PM - 	Nominations and election of Coordinator
>for Elected Board Of Education
>Referendum
>		(Residents and non-resident campaign
>workers can vote)
>
>4:00 PM -	Nominations and election of 3 At-Large
>members of the Steering
>Committee
>		(Residents and non-resident campaign
>workers can vote)
>
>4:30PM -	Nominations and election of  3 Ward
>Leaders for Ward 3-6, Ward 1-2 and
>Ward 4-5
>(residents only vote for leader(s) of the Ward they live
>in)
>
>5:30PM - 	Closing Speech and Clean Up
>
>
>

Post ID:265
Sender:mikelong@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 18:14:07
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] RE: Leadership Sucks! -- What is thy bidding, my Master?
Message:

Matt,

	"Put Republicans in the garbage can"

	Is this an Amiri Baraka quote?  If I recall correctly, 
it is.  How does one expect to win the Republican vote
with this model of acceptance and cross class "unity" ?

With all due respect, I've been trying to stay out of 
this conversation since I feel I have little of 
substance to add.  When it comes to sarcasm, however,
I too could find a response to damn near every post on this
board.  Fortunately sarcasm and other assorted attempts 
at humour have already been deemed as unacceptable forms
of expression on this list (re: Jim's rather clever parody a few
messages back).  

Given the "rules of engagement" as implied by certain members of
this list, your post borders on vicious and slanderous attack.

Perhaps we can have a vote on what forms of expression are 
permitted?

- Michael

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:266
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 19:36:07
Subject:DevCo and more
Message:

I called DevCo today for the first time on this campaign, which says something  - my info has been coming from friends who have called them or gone to the planning office - I sense a tendency in myself to stay away from the people directly in power to stay out of their radar screen but I think this is wrong - they have the info, must provide, and we have to get used to dealing with reality.  I think it is important for us to infterface directly with the people we are criticizing, whatever reasons we may come up with to ourselves for not.  

The project is still as described, although I got more details:

1.  200 luxury apartments at 1200 - 1500 a piece.  They are calling these luxury apartments to market them.  In fact this is what DevCo calls a "going market rate" which is what it will take to recoup their borrowing costs.  Flavio asked the question if they could cut up these into smaller apartments or make them less fancy to be able to market them at a cheaper price.  We may be fooled by them saying market rate - they justify the cost of the apartments.  Im not a developer so I dont know what is possible here in terms of getting cheaper housing.
2. hotel and conference center
3.  7500 sq ft retail space
4.  private health club and pool
5. restarurant and hootel lobby on entrance level
6.  300 parking spots
7.  Heldrich policy center

Financing:

1. $1.3 M a year for training center, $8.5M total, provided by state
2. Advance Group is borrowing money to do the apartments.  I think they did the mall.
3. DevCo as a nonprofit is borrowing money at a cheaper rate for the hotel and conference center
4.  As of now the apartments and hotel/conference center are separately financed - one is not subsidizing the other
5. The conference center is the kind that serves smaller groups so there are rooms for 30-60 participants.  On the weekends they will convert some of the space to a larger "ballroom"
6.  Taxes on the property will be to the tune of $1M versus the 90K they are getting now.

This is their logic - look, its largely private investment, we are offering market rate apartments, it will pay off big in terms of revenues.

They are trying to create this sheek thing that is marketed a certain way.  They must feel that going upscale is the only way to develop and have ths be a success. In terms of financing a large project such as theirs they may be right.  A conference center in NB may not be a financial success if it is not a sheek self enclosed thing.

I have heard comments from storeowners that they feel that it will not be able to sustain itself monetarily.  From DevCos perspective, historically alot of the development activity in the downtown has come from government buildings and the hospitals.  Their perspective must be that unless they create something extra special it wont sustain itself financially. They will be anxious as to whether this takes or not as a private project.  They are not taking Charlottes point into account as to how hard it is to invest downtown for small business due to govt red tape.  Frank also makes the point that zoning often restricts investment in the town by smaller capital.

Given all this,  I still want to write up a petition to get signed on the convention day.  What should we say?  I think - more retail space, allow displaced businesses first picks, public access to pool and conference hall, redesign apartments so they will be cheaper.  They will likely respond that other than the retail the other changes will make the building something that will not be able to finance itself, that this is an unrealistic demand.  One very charitable local business that is getting displaced from the area - and is helping us out with the convention urged me not to try to stop the whole plan, but to advocate at least for more retail space.  This business owner said to me that actually alot of the businesses on the street are very self-centered and dont pay their workers very well, dont care about the community.  Again, local business is not always great for workers.  He was glad they were wiping out the whole block of businesses and starting fresh.

So anyway I think that we need to really interface with the community more but as we do we will find out that things arent as easily characterized as they once seemed.  This is the challenge of the campaign - to really take in conflicting viewpoints from the community as new information and to work with it, rather than blowing the person off by pinning them as one way or another, because these are the people that have been active and struggling.  I say struggling because I have been talking to some people at the Suydam St Reformed Church, many PRAB people go there, and the contact I am supposed to meet with spoke with me briefly.  She took offense to my critique of the youth center, said, they had "struggled "to get it and made the comment that she feels she has to work with reality.  To us that may seem like a word for "give in"  - I got very discouraged and felt here is someone with whom I dont know how to go further because shes telling me she is accepting the status quo, and she knows more of the status quo than I do so  I have to respect that.  This is the point where I have to say - OK , right now she is telling me she doesnt see the point of the campaign, so I have to hang in there with her anyway, and not give up.  I think there is such a tendency to see people as either onthe right side or the wrong side and that is detrimental to our organizing.  If we dont grapple with the status quo-appearing people, who we often can criticize as not having the working class in their true interest, unfortunately we will relegate ourselves to idea land which is another criticism people have had of our meetings - too much talk about what should be not enough about concrete nuts and bolts of city functioning.

Which brings me to another point.  I have heard from two key representatives of the African American and Latino community that they strongly support the campaign but do not want to see a campaign that is strongly negative and attacking to use words that they used.  I think we need to really listen here these are representatives of the communities we are trying to organize and if this is one of their comments on our campaign we have to take it seriously.  Unlike people who have learned how to lobby for their opinions in this campaign (which I am learning I have to do) these are people who will state their opinion once and if it isnt taken seriously they will not repeat it.  The campaign leaders need to think about how to create spaces for such opinions to be expressed and then how to act on them.  If key reps are saying this, then if we shift something for themin terms of the way we run the campaing it will make their organizing that much easier and we can take care of areas that they are not covering.

On to I think the last main point of this damn thing.  It has to do with campaign organization.  Early on in the campaign I learnt a lesson - say I think something would make the campaign more successful, but generally expressed opinion is against that or the committee leader isnt planning that right now, or the steering committee doesnt think its important.  What do I do?  I decided that rather than complaining I should keep my mouth shut and try to do it on my own.  But then I started applying this to alot of areas where I thought something should be different - and lo and behold I am a fucking chicken without a head planning 3 different types of meetings for outreach, trying to do research for RTK, writing letters and flyers for media, reaching out to businesses and residents and churches, and promising things I cant do.  The other way, as I am learning, would have been to be focused and more successful doing one or two things and lobby for the other stuff to be done by someone else.  But I didnt have faith that those things would get done if I wasnt on them.    I think what we need is for there to be a clear way for opinions on how things could go better to be 1. encouraged 2. expressed 3. taken seriously by leadership.  Then leadership can say - OK this person has a perspective that is important - its different from mine but they are talking to people who are telling them about a different perspective, and there must be a kernel of truth in what they are saying.  How can we make the campaign receptive to this perspective?  And how can we deploy our resources as a campaign to address this?  I welcome leadership to tell me Zofia do this one thing and do it well, as long as I can trust that the other things I was concerned were getting left out of the mix - in this case the Spanish community, general outreach, the churches and business community will get listened to and taken care of.  Also I think committee leaders should be seen as coordinators who can request people on their committees to do most of the work - the more time the leaders spend busting their butt, the less coordinated and thought out will be the work of their committees.

Related to this is the middle class thing.  I definitely feel we need to reach out more to the leaders in NB community, and alot of them are middle class.  Im glad we focused on the working class so much because otherwise they would never have come in, and I think we learned loads about the community.  But to give our campaign legitimacy, knowledge, and power we need to welcome everyone and use outreach techniques so that noone in this town can say they havent heard of us - right now that is not the case.  Once we attract people lets figure out how we can keep them with us.  People really do get turned off at our general meetings. Im not saying we shouldnt be ourselves but lets try to figure out things we can add to our approach that make people feel more welcomed, invited to be a part of the campaign, and listened to when they do open their mouths to give their opinion.  Not everyone realizes that if they go in with several people, prepare their talking points ahead of time and then lobby well for it in the meeting they may have a chance at influencing the assembly.  We need to change the way opinions get heard AND we need to actively educate those joining us for the very first time  as to how to make the campaign something they can work with and how power in the campaign functions - and Im afraid alot of people  dont have the time or energy it takes to really lobby people to get something changed.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:267
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-11 23:55:53
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amir i Baraka's speech
Message:


On Thu, 11 May 2000, Nicole Adler wrote:

> A few things...
> (but first know, charlotte, that as i write this chris is helping me 
> conact about 50 different press, this is not an easy task and it 
> helps tremendously in reaching out to a lot of different people - 
> middle class included)

Nikki, that's great! Press is incredibly important, and thanks to you and
Chris for arranging it. 

> 
> 1.  work and work alone does not a leader make.  one of the major 
> failings that i see from njfo is that (i don't even know at this 
> point if i should say you or we) njfo does a whole hell of a lot of 
> work, but oftentimes forgets to actually ORGANIZE.  by this i mean, 
> that if you all were so concerned with getting work done, you would 
> have realized a long time ago that absolutely everyone can contribute 
> something to this campaign. BUT--if the skilled organizers in a group 
> fail to put people to work, then those people who are novice 
> organizers are going to fall to the wayside.  this is such a horrible 
> failing.  and i really wish it were addressed more.  
> 

This is a very valid criticism, Nikki, and I'd like to see it fully
discussed and addressed.


> 2.  frankly, you have alienated me from njfo by what you are saying.  
> i am not a communist.  and yes, njfo is constantly spewing off at the 
> mouth about how it's open to new ideas, but when it's own members 
> criticize some of the political lines all hell breaks lose, and 
> nothing of value comes out of the ensuing debate.  i have criticized 
> njfo, and feel that the discussion afterwards did nothing to 
> alleviate my confusion as to what e.g. the aim of u & s is, or even 
> how to begin to write for it, even though i would like to write 
> another article.

I had no such intention--I speak as a Communist who is a member of NJFO,
as it was those particular members Chris seemed to be addressing. I
certainly have no intention of implying that every member of NJFO is a
Communist or that NJFO is a Communist organization. If that's the case,
then we need to work on our approaches to criticism, discussion and line
struggle, and develop something beneficial to the group and its members. A
detailed discussion of _U&S_ would be a good topic for a meeting
discussion, and I hope you'll feel your questions, criticisms and ideas
are welcome in that discussion.

> 
> 3.  let's be honest.  every group in this campaign is guilty of 
> opportunism.  it is truly disingenuous to say otherwise.  you're 
> making njfo out to be some sort of altruistic martyr in the face of 
> adversity.  get real.  njfo's motives are just as weird and 
> unpractical as block and locks.  
> 

Well, I don't think our motives are weird, or especially impractical. No
political group is exempt from opportunism-but pretending to not believe
in something one believes in , or to downplay it to currry favor with a
particular class group isn't in line with being open and above-board, and
it isn't in line with the united front. It isn't an issue of martyrdom,
it's an issue of the principles of the united front being undermined.

> 4.  you can't even see that the mere fact that amiri was INVITED w/o 
> discussion is WRONG, a MISTAKE!  who the hell cares is he accepted 
> without discussion?!  

I would certainly say that ideally, such a vote should have been held. It
should have been. However, to attribute this to a sort of underhandedness,
scheming or undue influence is unsupported. The Steering Committee who
voted to put Amiri on the schedule when he became available was not a
majority-NJFO steering committee. It was not the result of NJFO control or
machinations but a vote that Amiri Baraka, since he was now available,
would be a positive speaker for the convention.

> 
> 5. i think you too quickly ignored the idea that we need to keep 
> advertising the basic platform.  we need to keep pushing the basics.  
> keep it simple!  the city is screwed up, it is making decisions for 
> the few at the expense of the many.  is this right? hell no!  lots of 
> people can get with that.  

The People's Campaign absolutely should be pushing the platform--something
I repeatedly advocated as the way to attract broad forces to the campaign.
Groups within the campaign should absolutely do so as well, something I
see NJFO doing. However, this doesn't nullify the right to political
independence within the united front. We all need to push the program, and
push our lines on why the program is important. They will vary, they will
be at odds-there are variant interests involved in this campaign, and all
of those interests and organizations should be on equal footing in a
democratic forum.

Chris, I agree with having no particular desire to continue to clog this
list with this discussion. As a matter of fact, I was discussing this just
last night, and decided to 'respond unless it continues forever.' We can
continue the discussion in a more appropriate and less disruptive arena,
if you so choose. However, I still think the list would benefit, as would
the Campaign, from your proposals on practical ways to reach out to the
middle class--the middle class should be brought into the campaign, and
you're obviously interested in seeing that it happens. Apart from this
debate, what do you suggest the campaign take on? Those could be
enormously productive ideas for the campaign as a whole. 


-charlotte

> 
> -nikki
> 
> 
>

> http://click.egroups.com/1/4054/0/_/357188/_/958066303/

Childcare is a major part of our proposed program, and a major part of 
saturday. I need help from people to make it run as smoothly and 
professionally as possible. This is what is needed:

1. PEOPLE- wE  WILL Work in 2 hour shifts. I am asking non-residents first, 
and then if desperate, residents. But there seems to be a decent number of 
non-residents in the campaign so please let me know when in the day you 
would like to volunteer.

2. Paper, poster board, white sheets, markers, crayons
if anyone has access to any of these things let me know asap.

3. A cassette player and children's music if you got it.
