Post ID:270
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-12 11:42:51
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] DevCo and more
Message:

Zofia- I think such a petition should demand "mixed income"  housing--that 
is, there should be some % of low-middle income, which would imply a certain 
% that is subsidized (They HATE that term, but every tax cut for the 
sowntown businesses is a SUBSIDY!)  They should also be encouraged to 
include social amenities, such as a computer/job training facility, day-care 
center, etc, w/in the development as a way of getting tax-credits to support 
the low-income subsidized units.  By no means should we allow this to be 
only LUXURY apartments down town.  It'll be the worst of SOHO & Hoboken 
combined, without the arts and historic preservation!  Matthew
PS- I'll read the rest of your message when I get time...


>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] DevCo and more
>Date: Thu, 11 May 2000 19:36:07 -0400
>
>
>I called DevCo today for the first time on this campaign, which says 
>something  - my info has been coming from friends who have called them or 
>gone to the planning office - I sense a tendency in myself to stay away 
>from the people directly in power to stay out of their radar screen but I 
>think this is wrong - they have the info, must provide, and we have to get 
>used to dealing with reality.  I think it is important for us to infterface 
>directly with the people we are criticizing, whatever reasons we may come 
>up with to ourselves for not.
>
>The project is still as described, although I got more details:
>
>1.  200 luxury apartments at 1200 - 1500 a piece.  They are calling these 
>luxury apartments to market them.  In fact this is what DevCo calls a 
>"going market rate" which is what it will take to recoup their borrowing 
>costs.  Flavio asked the question if they could cut up these into smaller 
>apartments or make them less fancy to be able to market them at a cheaper 
>price.  We may be fooled by them saying market rate - they justify the cost 
>of the apartments.  Im not a developer so I dont know what is possible here 
>in terms of getting cheaper housing.
>2. hotel and conference center
>3.  7500 sq ft retail space
>4.  private health club and pool
>5. restarurant and hootel lobby on entrance level
>6.  300 parking spots
>7.  Heldrich policy center
>
>Financing:
>
>1. $1.3 M a year for training center, $8.5M total, provided by state
>2. Advance Group is borrowing money to do the apartments.  I think they did 
>the mall.
>3. DevCo as a nonprofit is borrowing money at a cheaper rate for the hotel 
>and conference center
>4.  As of now the apartments and hotel/conference center are separately 
>financed - one is not subsidizing the other
>5. The conference center is the kind that serves smaller groups so there 
>are rooms for 30-60 participants.  On the weekends they will convert some 
>of the space to a larger "ballroom"
>6.  Taxes on the property will be to the tune of $1M versus the 90K they 
>are getting now.
>
>This is their logic - look, its largely private investment, we are offering 
>market rate apartments, it will pay off big in terms of revenues.
>
>They are trying to create this sheek thing that is marketed a certain way.  
>They must feel that going upscale is the only way to develop and have ths 
>be a success. In terms of financing a large project such as theirs they may 
>be right.  A conference center in NB may not be a financial success if it 
>is not a sheek self enclosed thing.
>
>I have heard comments from storeowners that they feel that it will not be 
>able to sustain itself monetarily.  From DevCos perspective, historically 
>alot of the development activity in the downtown has come from government 
>buildings and the hospitals.  Their perspective must be that unless they 
>create something extra special it wont sustain itself financially. They 
>will be anxious as to whether this takes or not as a private project.  They 
>are not taking Charlottes point into account as to how hard it is to invest 
>downtown for small business due to govt red tape.  Frank also makes the 
>point that zoning often restricts investment in the town by smaller 
>capital.
>
>Given all this,  I still want to write up a petition to get signed on the 
>convention day.  What should we say?  I think - more retail space, allow 
>displaced businesses first picks, public access to pool and conference 
>hall, redesign apartments so they will be cheaper.  They will likely 
>respond that other than the retail the other changes will make the building 
>something that will not be able to finance itself, that this is an 
>unrealistic demand.  One very charitable local business that is getting 
>displaced from the area - and is helping us out with the convention urged 
>me not to try to stop the whole plan, but to advocate at least for more 
>retail space.  This business owner said to me that actually alot of the 
>businesses on the street are very self-centered and dont pay their workers 
>very well, dont care about the community.  Again, local business is not 
>always great for workers.  He was glad they were wiping out the whole block 
>of businesses and starting fresh.
>
>So anyway I think that we need to really interface with the community more 
>but as we do we will find out that things arent as easily characterized as 
>they once seemed.  This is the challenge of the campaign - to really take 
>in conflicting viewpoints from the community as new information and to work 
>with it, rather than blowing the person off by pinning them as one way or 
>another, because these are the people that have been active and struggling. 
>  I say struggling because I have been talking to some people at the Suydam 
>St Reformed Church, many PRAB people go there, and the contact I am 
>supposed to meet with spoke with me briefly.  She took offense to my 
>critique of the youth center, said, they had "struggled "to get it and made 
>the comment that she feels she has to work with reality.  To us that may 
>seem like a word for "give in"  - I got very discouraged and felt here is 
>someone with whom I dont know how to go further because shes telling me she 
>is accepting the status quo, and she knows more of the status quo than I do 
>so  I have to respect that.  This is the point where I have to say - OK , 
>right now she is telling me she doesnt see the point of the campaign, so I 
>have to hang in there with her anyway, and not give up.  I think there is 
>such a tendency to see people as either onthe right side or the wrong side 
>and that is detrimental to our organizing.  If we dont grapple with the 
>status quo-appearing people, who we often can criticize as not having the 
>working class in their true interest, unfortunately we will relegate 
>ourselves to idea land which is another criticism people have had of our 
>meetings - too much talk about what should be not enough about concrete 
>nuts and bolts of city functioning.
>
>Which brings me to another point.  I have heard from two key 
>representatives of the African American and Latino community that they 
>strongly support the campaign but do not want to see a campaign that is 
>strongly negative and attacking to use words that they used.  I think we 
>need to really listen here these are representatives of the communities we 
>are trying to organize and if this is one of their comments on our campaign 
>we have to take it seriously.  Unlike people who have learned how to lobby 
>for their opinions in this campaign (which I am learning I have to do) 
>these are people who will state their opinion once and if it isnt taken 
>seriously they will not repeat it.  The campaign leaders need to think 
>about how to create spaces for such opinions to be expressed and then how 
>to act on them.  If key reps are saying this, then if we shift something 
>for themin terms of the way we run the campaing it will make their 
>organizing that much easier and we can take care of areas that they are not 
>covering.
>
>On to I think the last main point of this damn thing.  It has to do with 
>campaign organization.  Early on in the campaign I learnt a lesson - say I 
>think something would make the campaign more successful, but generally 
>expressed opinion is against that or the committee leader isnt planning 
>that right now, or the steering committee doesnt think its important.  What 
>do I do?  I decided that rather than complaining I should keep my mouth 
>shut and try to do it on my own.  But then I started applying this to alot 
>of areas where I thought something should be different - and lo and behold 
>I am a fucking chicken without a head planning 3 different types of 
>meetings for outreach, trying to do research for RTK, writing letters and 
>flyers for media, reaching out to businesses and residents and churches, 
>and promising things I cant do.  The other way, as I am learning, would 
>have been to be focused and more successful doing one or two things and 
>lobby for the other stuff to be done by someone else.  But I didnt have 
>faith that those things would get done if I wasnt on them.    I think what 
>we need is for there to be a clear way for opinions on how things could go 
>better to be 1. encouraged 2. expressed 3. taken seriously by leadership.  
>Then leadership can say - OK this person has a perspective that is 
>important - its different from mine but they are talking to people who are 
>telling them about a different perspective, and there must be a kernel of 
>truth in what they are saying.  How can we make the campaign receptive to 
>this perspective?  And how can we deploy our resources as a campaign to 
>address this?  I welcome leadership to tell me Zofia do this one thing and 
>do it well, as long as I can trust that the other things I was concerned 
>were getting left out of the mix - in this case the Spanish community, 
>general outreach, the churches and business community will get listened to 
>and taken care of.  Also I think committee leaders should be seen as 
>coordinators who can request people on their committees to do most of the 
>work - the more time the leaders spend busting their butt, the less 
>coordinated and thought out will be the work of their committees.
>
>Related to this is the middle class thing.  I definitely feel we need to 
>reach out more to the leaders in NB community, and alot of them are middle 
>class.  Im glad we focused on the working class so much because otherwise 
>they would never have come in, and I think we learned loads about the 
>community.  But to give our campaign legitimacy, knowledge, and power we 
>need to welcome everyone and use outreach techniques so that noone in this 
>town can say they havent heard of us - right now that is not the case.  
>Once we attract people lets figure out how we can keep them with us.  
>People really do get turned off at our general meetings. Im not saying we 
>shouldnt be ourselves but lets try to figure out things we can add to our 
>approach that make people feel more welcomed, invited to be a part of the 
>campaign, and listened to when they do open their mouths to give their 
>opinion.  Not everyone realizes that if they go in with several people, 
>prepare their talking points ahead of time and then lobby well for it in 
>the meeting they may have a chance at influencing the assembly.  We need to 
>change the way opinions get heard AND we need to actively educate those 
>joining us for the very first time  as to how to make the campaign 
>something they can work with and how power in the campaign functions - and 
>Im afraid alot of people  dont have the time or energy it takes to really 
>lobby people to get something changed.
>
>Zofia Nowakowski
>Fiscal Policy Institute
>218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
>New York, NY 10018
>Tel: 212.278.0878
>Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:271
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-15 00:32:43
Subject:Fwd: PROTESTERS RE-ENTER VIEQUES BOMBING ZONE
Message:



>From: "Vieques Libre" <viequeslibre@...>
>To: List Member <vivaohio@...>
>Subject: PROTESTERS RE-ENTER VIEQUES BOMBING ZONE
>Date: 15 May 2000 00:09:56 -0000
>
>Vieques Libre - http://www.viequeslibre.org
>
>http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/ap/20000514/wl/puerto_rico_navy_bombing_1.html
>
>Yahoo World Headlines
>Sunday May 14 4:34 PM ET
>
>Puerto Ricans Enter Navy Grounds
>
>SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) - Dozens of Puerto Ricans cut through a fence
>to sneak onto a Navy training ground on Vieques Island, renewing a
>yearlong battle against a U.S. military presence.
>
>The Navy said Sunday that guards had detained 55 protesters, including
>former light heavyweight boxing champion Jose Torres, soon after the
>protesters breached the fence Saturday night. Demonstrators said another
>11 were caught Sunday, but Navy spokesman Robert Nelson said he was
>unaware of any other detentions.
>
>The protesters were trying to break back into the area, after U.S.
>Marshals on May 4 cleared 216 protesters from camps out on the Navy's
>Vieques training ground. Activists have been trying to force the Navy to
>leave Vieques, and have vowed to continue entering Navy land.
>
>Nelson said the latest group of protesters was stopped at about 9 p.m. two
>miles north of the training ground's main gate. The protesters surrendered
>peacefully to military police, he said.
>
>Torres was charged with trespassing and released Sunday morning. Nelson
>said the others detained Saturday were being held at the nearby Roosevelt
>Roads Navy base because they had refused to identify themselves. They were
>awaiting a hearing before a federal magistrate.
>
>Demonstrators said the former president of the Puerto Rican Bar
>Association, Graciany Miranda Marchand, was among the detainees.
>
>Since the May 4 raid, patrol vessels have turned away 72 boats trying to
>enter the waters around the training ground. Last week inside the training
>ground's fence, guards arrested Ruben Berrios, leader of the Puerto Rican
>Independence Party and a gubernatorial candidate in November's elections.
>He was charged with trespassing and released.
>
>Dozens of people held a protest vigil Saturday night in front of the
>training ground's gates, with Puerto Rican riot police standing guard.
>
>The Navy controls two-thirds of Vieques and uses it for weapons storage
>and military exercises. Resentment over the Navy's presence flared in
>April 1999, when a Marine Corps jet dropped two 500-pound bombs off
>target, killing a civilian security guard working in the bombing range.
>
>After months of negotiations with Gov. Pedro Rossello, President Clinton
>agreed to order the Navy out by May 2003 if the island's 9,400 residents
>voted in a referendum to expel it. Clinton gave the Navy permission to
>continue training until then without explosives.
>
>
>====================================
>http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/nm/20000514/ts/puertorico_vieques_1.html
>
>Yahoo Top Stories Headlines
>Sunday May 14 1:31 PM ET
>
>U.S. Military Arrests 51 Protesters on Vieques
>By John Marino
>
>SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (Reuters) - Authorities arrested 51 people for
>attempting to occupy a disputed military firing range on the Puerto Rican
>island of Vieques, the largest number detained since federal agents
>cleared 200 protesters from the site on May 4, U.S. Navy officials said on
>Sunday.
>
>Marine Corps and Navy security personnel made the arrests late on Saturday
>after 54 people breached a fence guarding the Navy's Camp Garcia on the
>eastern third of Vieques, an island off of Puerto Rico's east coast, Navy
>spokesman Robert Nelson said.
>
>One man and two minors were released and the remaining 51 people were
>taken by boat and helicopter to the Roosevelt Roads Naval Station on
>Puerto Rico's east coast for processing.
>
>``They are going to be cited for trespassing on federal property,'' Nelson
>said.
>
>Firing-range protests have been staged for more than a year on Vieques
>since a stray bomb killed resident David Sanes Rodriguez, a civilian
>security guard employed by the Navy, on April 19, 1999.
>
>His death unleashed pent-up resentment in the Spanish-speaking U.S.
>commonwealth, prompting the Navy to suspend live-fire bomb training and
>sparking a drive to oust the Navy from Vieques.
>
>Since then, a deal has been reached between the White House and the
>administration of Gov. Pedro Rossello, under which the Navy can train
>using dummy bombs for three years. In return, Vieques would receive
>economic incentives and the Navy would transfer the western end of the
>island to commonwealth hands.
>
>The deal also called for a referendum among Vieques residents, who would
>choose whether the Navy should leave in three years or stay indefinitely
>for an extra $50 million in economic aid.
>
>Trespassers Face Misdemeanor Charge
>
>The group on Saturday was the largest arrested on Vieques since a May 4
>federal raid removed more than 200 protesters who were camped out on the
>Navy bombing range within Camp Garcia.
>
>Nelson said the latest trespassers, who were peaceful and cooperated with
>authorities, would face only misdemeanor charges. Misdemeanor trespassing
>carries a maximum penalty of six months in jail, versus 10 years for
>felony trespassing.
>
>During the earlier raid on May 4, federal authorities opted not to file
>charges, but warned protesters they could face 10-year prison terms and
>fines of $250,000 for trespassing on the range a second time. The stiff
>penalties corresponded to an order signed by President Clinton on Dec. 1,
>1999, making it a felony to trespass on the bombing range.
>
>Nelson said, however, that the tougher felony penalties were part of a
>``temporary security zone'' that was created to coincide with the
>resumption of target practice using inert ordnance. The security zone was
>later lifted.
>
>Puerto Rican Independence Party President Ruben Berrios, who spent nearly
>a year camped out on the range, was arrested on May 10 when he and another
>party member made it back onto Navy land. While he could have faced a
>felony under Clinton's order, he too was charged with a misdemeanor.
>
>U.S. District Court Judge Carmen Consuelo Vargas de Cerezo, who was
>assigned to hear the Berrios case, recused herself on Friday, arguing that
>the Vieques cause is a petition for peace before the ``holy sacrament.''
>
>
>______________________________________________________________________
>To unsubscribe, write to viequeslibre-unsubscribe@...
>______________________________________________________________________
>Advertisement:
>15% off Ashford Collection jewelry for Mother's Day! Mom will love
>these gorgeous pieces handpicked by our expert jewelry buyers - now
>15% off and shipped FedEx overnight FREE! Spoiled as a child? Return
>the favor - get her gift at Ashford.com.
>http://on.linkexchange.com/?ATID=27&AID=1231
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:272
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-15 00:56:12
Subject:RDWP & News Story
Message:


I hope everyone is doing well.

In a spirit of unity, I must for the first time speak of an issue on the 
discussion group.

Please note the person in charge of the elected BOE question is quoted by the 
Home News Tribune as stating the issue is personally being pushed to further 
a Revolutionary Democratic Worker's Party. 

I have received a number of phone messages over the last few months. The main 
thrust is that the Campaign is not worth joining due to the comments made 
concerning, for an example, a Revolutionary Democratic Worker's Party. This 
is the second time around that scores of established leaders and activists 
have mentioned how they WILL NOT join the campaign because of their 
perception of sectarianism and hard heartedness of a small few that are in 
positions of leadership. The campaign should have doubled after the second 
meeting but has stayed ominiously level. Why? We have been losing the 
"moderates" who are more intent on getting an elected Board of Education in 
order to help children, for an example, rather than help a Revolutionary 
Democratic Worker's Party. 

Now we have another opportunity with residents because we now have 
candidates. As an example, are we to turn residents off with rhetoric such as 
a Revolutionary Democratic Worker's Party again?

I speak sincerely as I personally see the average of fifteen new votes we 
lose every week. Maintaining my constituency is consuming valuable time 
whereas my constituents should be donating money, office space, outreach, 
voter/election work, research and covering City Council meetings ... and many 
other responsibilities.

I am sincerely sorry I have to write this as I sincerely view everyone in 
this campaign as a brother or sister. I want to say none of the above is an 
attack on anyone. However, the situation above is a recurring one. I am sorry 
if this sounds corny but I look to you all as a family to help us sort out 
this kind of situation.

Once again I hope everyone is doing well.

Frank Bright
249-7201




Newly formed slate cites New Brunswick's drug problem 




Published in the Home News Tribune 5/14/00 

By KEN SERRANO
STAFF WRITER



Three independents running as a slate from a group calling itself a 
grass-roots, cross-cultural and multiethnic movement say they will vie for 
three City Council seats in November against incumbent Democrats.

At a convention yesterday at the Paul Robeson Community School, the New 
Brunswick People's Campaign nominated Curtis Warren Sr., Danny Rosado and 
Keith Joseph to run for the four-year council terms in November.

The convention drew about 100 people, most of them city residents who cast 83 
ballots in the nomination of council candidates.

The three candidates have until June 6 to file petitions to run as 
independents, said Flavio Komuves, a Somerset attorney and a member of the 
People's Campaign, who oversaw the balloting yesterday.

The People's Campaign, a coalition of veteran activists, socialists, 
feminists, landlords, business owners, students and disgruntled Republicans 
and Democrats, say they are waging a battle against an entrenched Democratic 
political machine in New Brunswick.

"It's a huge fight," said Warren, 46, who works security at First Baptist 
Church of Lincoln Gardens in Franklin. "We're fighting against old-boy 
politics, against huge money and old ideas. But we're not here to tear down 
the political machine, we're just here to do better."

Warren stressed what has been a talking point for many of the people 
associated with the People's Campaign: "How can we be a health-care city and 
let this drug problem here go on like it is?''

He said he would work to promote joint efforts with health-care companies in 
New Brunswick to deal with that and other problems. 

Warren has been involved with the New Brunswick Coalition Against Police 
Brutality.

Rosado, 42, who worked as an airplane mechanic in the Dominican Republic 
before immigrating to the United States, said through a translator that she 
would work against domestic violence in the city and for more recreational 
facilities for young people.

Joseph, 29, who has been associated with the New Jersey Freedom Organization, 
a group of what he called revolutionary democrats, said, "We want to make New 
Brunswick a city for people, not the corporations that are exploiting it."

He said the People's Campaign canvassed 1,000 residents from around the city 
and has established its platform based on the information it received.

The group's 17-point platform, also voted on yesterday, includes working 
toward placing a question on the November ballot on whether the city board of 
education should be an elected body.

Joseph Smith, who said he has worked on a door-to-door campaign for the past 
five years on putting that question to voters, will continue doing so for the 
People's Campaign as a member of the steering committee. Smith said his 
efforts to register voters and push for the referendum is part of a broader 
effort to establish a Revolutionary Democratic Workers' Party.

The People's Campaign platform includes establishing a civilian police review 
board with subpoena power to investigate police misconduct, building bike 
paths and providing publicly subsidized child care for every child in the 
city.

The three Democrats who are seeking re-election to the council are Robert 
Recine, Joseph Schrum and Jimmie Cook.





from the Home News Tribune 

Published: May 14, 2000





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:273
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-15 01:05:15
Subject:Urban renewal
Message:

Zofia- Take a look at this summary of methods of subsidizing low-income
housing etc from Prof Schuman at NJIT




    >
    >1,  Urban Renewal.  This is the process whereby government takes over
    >land (which could be centrally located, like Lincoln Center in NYC 
which
    was
    >urban renewal project)) and then resells it at a lower price to
    developers.
    >the land could be sold for $1.00 with the provision that it be used for
    50%
    >low- and moderate-income housing.  Of course, the government would have
    to
    >absorb the entire initial expense of buying the land.
    >
    >2. Low-income housing tax credit:  This is where givernment subsidizes
    >housing without direct outlays through a tax credit for investors.  
Very
    >effective program, but also very costly in terms of how much government
    >gives away (indirectly) versus how ,uch the ivestors put into projects.
    >
    >3. 80/20 Housing:  A New York State program where investors can borrow
    >money at low iterest rates through a state bond program and can also 
get
    >reduced local real estate taxes if they provide 20% of their units to
    low-
    >and moderate-income families. An effective program.
    >
    >4. Internal cross-subsidy:  This idea is always available to
    >developers, but few would use it without additional incentive,.  After
    all,
    >if I can get ghigher rents, why should I use [at of them to subsidize a
    >tenant instead of pocketing the difference??  Works only when developer
    is
    >obliged to provide internal subsidy because he/she is benefitting from
    some
    >other government program.
    >
    >The moral, of course, is that the government MUST be involved in 
housing
    for
    >low- and moderate income households.  The question is HOW they should 
be
    >involved.  The answer may be measured in terms of cost efficiency, 
degree
    of
    >protection against corruption, political viability, etc,. etc.
    >

__________________
________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:274
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-15 01:13:55
Subject:Home News Tribune
Message:

Hi! 

Just wanted to cite the HNT article, which quotes all of our *wonderful*
candidates (Congratulations, Curtis, Danny and Keith! We couldn't ask for
a better slate of representatives!) and puts our issues out there as a
campaign--including health care, women's issues, the city machine,
alternative transportation, community control over police and education,
etc. 

Speaking of yesterday, it was an exhilarating, overwhelming experience of
people's democracy in action. We took part in the real rebirth of New
Brunswick yesterday. I don't want to misquote Curtis, but his slogan was
excellent: "Vote for three to set us free!" That's what this Campaign is
all about--democracy for all in New Brunswick, where the people run the
City Council, not the other way around. When all seven candidates signed
the pledge to abide by the leadership of the people, it was a powerful
moment, indelibly declaring that this Campaign belongs to the people, that
this candidates are the highest expressions of democracy-- OF, BY and FOR
the people. 

The next months will be difficult and joyous and stressful and incredible,
full of unity and full of struggle. After yesterday, more than ever, I am
confident that the Campaign and its candidates will come through in
November unified and strong, having organized the people of this city to
recognize what is rightfully ours. Our candidates--and our whole
Campaign--are true freedom fighters. 
--charlotte
And now, the HNT article:
 
Newly formed slate cites New Brunswick's drug problem 


Published in the Home News Tribune 5/14/00 
By KEN SERRANO
STAFF WRITER

Three independents running as a slate from a group calling itself a
grass-roots, cross-cultural and multiethnic movement say they will vie for
three City Council seats in November against incumbent Democrats.

At a convention yesterday at the Paul Robeson Community School, the New
Brunswick People's Campaign nominated Curtis Warren Sr., Danny Rosado and
Keith Joseph to run for the four-year council terms in November.

The convention drew about 100 people, most of them city residents who cast
83 ballots in the nomination of council candidates.

The three candidates have until June 6 to file petitions to run as
independents, said Flavio Komuves, a Somerset attorney and a member of the
People's Campaign, who oversaw the balloting yesterday.

The People's Campaign, a coalition of veteran activists, socialists,
feminists, landlords, business owners, students and disgruntled
Republicans and Democrats, say they are waging a battle against an
entrenched Democratic political machine in New Brunswick.

"It's a huge fight," said Warren, 46, who works security at First Baptist
Church of Lincoln Gardens in Franklin. "We're fighting against old-boy
politics, against huge money and old ideas. But we're not here to tear
down the political machine, we're just here to do better."

Warren stressed what has been a talking point for many of the people
associated with the People's Campaign: "How can we be a health-care city
and let this drug problem here go on like it is?''

He said he would work to promote joint efforts with health-care companies
in New Brunswick to deal with that and other problems. 

Warren has been involved with the New Brunswick Coalition Against Police
Brutality.

Rosado, 42, who worked as an airplane mechanic in the Dominican Republic
before immigrating to the United States, said through a translator that
she would work against domestic violence in the city and for more
recreational facilities for young people.

Joseph, 29, who has been associated with the New Jersey Freedom
Organization, a group of what he called revolutionary democrats, said, "We
want to make New Brunswick a city for people, not the corporations that
are exploiting it."

He said the People's Campaign canvassed 1,000 residents from around the
city and has established its platform based on the information it
received.

The group's 17-point platform, also voted on yesterday, includes working
toward placing a question on the November ballot on whether the city board
of education should be an elected body.

Joseph Smith, who said he has worked on a door-to-door campaign for the
past five years on putting that question to voters, will continue doing so
for the People's Campaign as a member of the steering committee. Smith
said his efforts to register voters and push for the referendum is part of
a broader effort to establish a Revolutionary Democratic Workers' Party.

The People's Campaign platform includes establishing a civilian police
review board with subpoena power to investigate police misconduct,
building bike paths and providing publicly subsidized child care for every
child in the city.

The three Democrats who are seeking re-election to the council are Robert
Recine, Joseph Schrum and Jimmie Cook.

Post ID:275
Sender:"Jml " <jml@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-15 14:59:03
Subject:Canvas Conduct and Protocol
Message:

The following is a three-point proposal I will introduce for 
vote at the next General Meeting of the New Brunswick People's 
Campaign.

	Yours,
	James Luceno


1) When canvassing at the designated Campaign canvass times as
part of the Campaign Canvass, canvassers are required to introduce 
themselves as canvassers of the New Brunswick People's Campaign.
 
2) When canvassing at the designated Campaign canvass times as
part of the Campaign Canvass, canvassers are required to distribute, 
as a minimum, the official Campaign literature approved by the 
Campaign for distribution at the canvass.  

3) Those who refuse to abide by these rules are not
allowed to canvass with the official Campaign Canvass.

After our wonderfully successful convention we find ourselves in need
of new flyers.  This new flyer, which promotes the platform and the candidates,
should certainly do the trick.

This couldn't have been done without Jim who helped out greatly with the content.  
I think we've done our best and (in my opinion) it looks great despite the time crunch.

It's available on the web site for review at:

http://www.newbruns.org/~mike/campaign_flyer_after_convention.doc

I should also mention that I've placed all of the media work I've 
submitted to the campaign on the website, available at:

http://www.newbruns.org/~mike/

Thanks
- Michael





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:278
Sender:"Jml " <jml@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-16 02:09:52
Subject:Canvassing Experience / "From the masses, to the masses"
Message:

An experience I had canvassing today:

Knocking on a door on Townsend Street, I was greeting by a 
man in his 50s.  I told him I was with the New Brunswick People's
Campaign, and we were collecting signatures for petitions for
an elected school board.  He immediately ushered me in.

I was not even across the doorway before he was probing me
with questions: "What is your name?" "Who are you with?" 
"Where is your office?"  

I met his wife in the kitchen.  Both were more than happy to
put their signatures toward an elected school board.  But I
was not in the house more than 15 seconds when the man turned
to me, looked me right in the face, and said "Your flyers are
completely overboard and ridiculous.  What are you doing?"

I asked him which flyers he had in mind.  He told me he meant
the yellow ones.  "The ones with the name Block on Lock," he said,
explicitly remembering the name of the organization written on
those flyers.  "That's not how you go about running a campaign.
I've lived in this town for 40 years.  This is *not* the kind of
message that appeals to people."

I assured the man that, as a representative of the People's
Campaign, I stood as just that -- a representative of the 
People, their platform, and the candidates they chose to run
for City Council.  

He and his wife both seemed pleased with my attitude as they both 
enthusiastically signed the petition,
emphasizing the need for democratic and progressive change
in the city.

We shook hands, the gentleman wishing me and the Campaign
much luck this year.  I assured him I would do everything in
my power to properly represent the will of the people in my
work.

Food for thought.

James Luceno

Post ID:284
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-17 23:48:11
Subject:Hoffman Ain't Fair
Message:

MIDDLESEX COUNTY: Judge bars cop's testimony at trial 




Published in the Home News Tribune 5/17/00 

Defense says statements separate from brothel case

By MICHELLE SAHN
STAFF WRITER

Prosecutors will not be allowed to use New Brunswick police detective James 
Marshall's statements about his alleged drug-related activity at a trial on 
charges he and Sgt. Marco Chinchilla ran a house of prostitution in the city, 
a judge ruled yesterday.

Judge Barnett E. Hoffman listened to arguments yesterday morning about other 
statements made by Marshall to investigators in connection with 121 Jersey 
Ave. in the city -- the site of an alleged brothel the two cops are accused 
of running. Hoffman told the attorneys he will rule on the other statements 
after considering their arguments.

The two officers, along with three co-defendants, face a joint trial in 
September in connection with the Jersey Avenue site. Marshall is facing 
other, separate trials in connection with two other alleged brothels, 
allegations of bribery and narcotics-related charges.

Lawyers for both officers said the two men, both 16-year veterans of the 
force, are innocent. Both Marshall and Chinchilla were suspended without pay 
from their jobs in December 1998.

Yesterday's arguments in state Superior Court, New Brunswick, centered on 
whether Marshall's July 28, 1998, statement to investigator Virgil Angellini 
of the Middlesex County Prosecutor's Office and detective Joseph Celli of the 
state police can be admitted in the September joint trial.

The question was whether the other defendants - Chinchilla, Luis Posadas, 
Michelle Thibeault and Joyce Kathy Sweeney -- will receive a fair trial if 
Marshall's statements are admitted.

Hoffman said it would be a stretch to find how Marshall's statements about 
narcotics are related to the September trial, which will not involve the 
drug-related charges lodged against the detective.

Assistant Middlesex County Prosecutor Lawrence Welle had argued that part of 
the statement -- in which Marshall said he provided a drug dealer with the 
work schedule of narcotics cops, and seized drugs from informants, then 
returned them -- should be admitted because it shows a pattern of misconduct.

But Hoffman said those statements would be prejudicial and cannot be admitted 
at the September trial.

Hoffman heard arguments from Welle and defense attorneys about Marshall's 
statements in connection with 121 Jersey Ave.

Welle contended the statements should be admissible. He said when 
investigators questioned Marshall, he admitted various kinds of official 
misconduct. For example, the detective said he knew a house of prostitution 
was operating at 121 Jersey Ave. and did nothing to stop it, said Welle.

During the interview, Marshall initially denied any knowledge of a brothel at 
121 Jersey Ave., then gradually admitted knowing more and more about it, 
Welle said.

Welle said he also plans to use other evidence, such as witnesses' testimony 
and advertisements placed in magazines for the establishment, to show that 
site was a house of prostitution.

He said references to codefendants can be deleted from the statement before 
it's presented to the jury and said the panel can be told not to use the 
statement against the codefendants.

But Chinchilla's attorney, Barry Albin, said the statement is hearsay and 
should not be admitted, because during the joint trial he won't have the 
opportunity to cross-examine the person who made the statements -- Marshall.

Albin said he will argue 121 Jersey Ave. was not a brothel, and said during 
cross-examination he can question the credibility of the two witnesses who 
are expected to testify it was a house of prostitution.

"(Chinchilla) has the right to contest every element (of the indictment)," 
said Albin. "If witnesses can't be cross-examined, then you're denying him a 
fundamental right."

He questioned whether there was a feasible way to craft instructions to the 
jury to ensure that the panel only consider Marshall's statement in the case 
against Marshall, not in the cases against the other codefendants.

Subject:Media Committee Minutes 5/17/00

In Attendence: Nikki, Jim, Jessie, Mike, Trotsky, Keith and Matt

Organizational Part of Mtg:
-we will begin to bring our weekly literature that we produce to 
Tactical Committee meetings so that each committee head can give 
feedback
-Read minutes from last Sunday's Tactical Comm mtg.
-Jim L. will replace Nikki at the next Tactical mtg and run the next 
media mtg as Nikki will be away from 5/20-5/29
-Daryle will be working on the press conference for turning in the 
signatures
-matt and jeremy will potentially work on at least the first issue 
pamphlet when we get the info from RTK

-Nikki: possible newspaper layouts
-Jim: intro article for newspaper (help from Keith)
-Jessie:  improve design of website

Post ID:286
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-18 12:20:20
Subject:Another canvassing experience. Thank you Cliff.
Message:

I had a canvassing experience on Wednesday. It was different from 
Jim's on Monday. 

Audrey and I were walking down Suydam St. and four guys and a kid
were 
up on a porch. We stopped and I asked them if I could pitch them
about 
the campaign. 

Guys: "You guys hooked up with Cliff?"

Paul: "Yeah."

Guys: "Alright."

Paul: "Cool, we're trying to change how this city's run. First we're 
gonna fire Craterface, then we're gonna send the good cops down to 
fire the housing authority in NB Homes."

Guys: "Yea, these cops are outta hand. Things are all messed up in 
this joint. We're gotta do something about this. Where do I sign? I'm 
gonna vote this year. How do I register?"

Paul: "Yea, we can hook up all of that. Hey, what do you guys think 
about Chinchilla and Marshall? That judge is looking to let them off 
for sure."

Guys: "Yea, I saw the paper. Marshall busted EVERYBODY. He jumped 
outta trees, hid in garbage cans. Everything ... That guy's a
murderer 
[Marshall] ... those two [cops] are kingpins ... they should go to 
trial like a black drug dealer ... they should go to jail just like 
everybody else!"

45 minutes later we bailed, everybody was wound up over our 
discussion. I had four pages of quotes from two guys. They said "Put 
all of that in your paper!"  These guys never voted before and now 
they're talking about seizing power.

I just want to thank Cliff. DOWN WITH ALL FORMS OF SECTARIANISM! 
   In Unity and for the sake of the of the United Front--Paul



--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Jml " <jml@d...> wrote:
> An experience I had canvassing today:
> 
> Knocking on a door on Townsend Street, I was greeting by a 
> man in his 50s.  I told him I was with the New Brunswick People's
> Campaign, and we were collecting signatures for petitions for
> an elected school board.  He immediately ushered me in.
> 
> I was not even across the doorway before he was probing me
> with questions: "What is your name?" "Who are you with?" 
> "Where is your office?"  
> 
> I met his wife in the kitchen.  Both were more than happy to
> put their signatures toward an elected school board.  But I
> was not in the house more than 15 seconds when the man turned
> to me, looked me right in the face, and said "Your flyers are
> completely overboard and ridiculous.  What are you doing?"
> 
> I asked him which flyers he had in mind.  He told me he meant
> the yellow ones.  "The ones with the name Block on Lock," he said,
> explicitly remembering the name of the organization written on
> those flyers.  "That's not how you go about running a campaign.
> I've lived in this town for 40 years.  This is *not* the kind of
> message that appeals to people."
> 
> I assured the man that, as a representative of the People's
> Campaign, I stood as just that -- a representative of the 
> People, their platform, and the candidates they chose to run
> for City Council.  
> 
> He and his wife both seemed pleased with my attitude as they both 
> enthusiastically signed the petition,
> emphasizing the need for democratic and progressive change
> in the city.
> 
> We shook hands, the gentleman wishing me and the Campaign
> much luck this year.  I assured him I would do everything in
> my power to properly represent the will of the people in my
> work.
> 
> Food for thought.
> 
> James Luceno

Post ID:288
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 00:05:26
Subject:Fwd: Springfield, Massachusetts City Council unanimously approves pro-Vieques Resolution
Message:



>From: "Vieques Libre" <viequeslibre@...>
>To: List Member <vivaohio@...>
>Subject: Springfield, Massachusetts City Council unanimously approves 
>pro-Vieques Resolution
>Date: 18 May 2000 21:32:25 -0000
>
>Vieques Libre - http://www.viequeslibre.org
>
>(English version below)
>
>La Asamblea Municipal de la Ciudad de Springfield, Massachusetts, como
>otras ciudades en Estados Unidos, aprob� por unanimidad una Resoluci�n en
>apoyo de la meta Viequense de que la Marina de Guerra se vaya de Vieques
>sin tirar un tiro m�s ni una bomba m�s. El texto de la Resoluci�n aparece
>abajo.
>
>The Springfield, Massachusetts City Council, as have other cities in the
>U.S., unanimously approved a Resolution in support of the goal of the
>Viequenses of having the U.S. Navy leave Vieques without dropping one more
>bomb or firing one more bullet.  The text of the Resolution appears below.
>
>RESOLUTION BY THE CITY COUNCIL, SPRINGFIELD, MASSACHUSETTS ON THE ISSUE OF
>VIEQUES, PUERTO RICO
>
>WHEREAS, City of Springfield residents are concerned about the
>environmental injustice and human rights violations of the U.S. Navy in
>Vieques, Puerto Rico; and
>
>WHEREAS, the City of Springfield houses a large population of Hispanics
>and Puerto Ricans in Massachusetts, and many of them are concerned about
>the ecological damage and human harm resulting from military operations in
>Vieques; and
>
>WHEREAS, City of Springfield businesses have established commercial
>relations with Puerto Rico for over 100 years, and many businesses are
>interested in the economic conversion of military to civilian uses; and
>
>WHEREAS, the City of Springfield has many Puerto Rican and Hispanic
>organizations and they are concerned about the well being of Puerto Ricans
>in Springfield and Puerto Rico; and
>
>WHEREAS, the City of Springfield has many descendants from the island of
>Vieques and they are concerned about the lives of their relatives in
>Vieques, Puerto Rico; and
>
>WHEREAS, since 1941, the United States Navy has operated a training
>facility on two-thirds of the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico; and
>
>WHEREAS, the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico is populated by more than
>9,000 Puerto Ricans, US citizens, who are submitted to the disgrace of
>seeing its territory bombarded by land, air and sea; and
>
>WHEREAS, the US Navy's presence and activities violate the natural right
>of the people of Vieques to enjoy their natural resources; and
>
>WHEREAS, for more than half a century, the US Navy has thwarted the
>healthy development of Vieques' economy forcing the people of Vieques to
>emigrate in search of work and well being, resulting in family
>disintegration; and
>
>WHEREAS, the US Navy has used depleted uranium, napalm bombs, and other
>chemical and toxic weapons that have an adverse impact on the public
>health and the environment; and
>
>WHEREAS, the US Navy's war practices has contributed significantly to the
>pollution of air, water and land and has contributed to high cancer levels
>in Vieques; and
>
>WHEREAS, the US Navy's presence in Vieques has contributed to the
>psychological damage of the children on the island; and
>
>WHEREAS, in 1993, a Navy FA-18 fighter jet missed its target by
>approximately 10 miles, dropped five 500 pound live bombs one mile from
>civilians living in the town of Isabel Segunda; and
>
>WHEREAS, in 1998, Navy and National Guard exercises accidentally fired
>live bullets to municipal vehicles, including school buses and public
>works vehicles, forcing civilian employees to run for their safety; and
>
>WHEREAS, on April 19, 1999, a resident of Vieques and citizen of the
>United States, was killed and four persons injured as a result of a
>routine war exercise conducted by the US Navy; and
>
>WHEREAS, on May 11, 1999, the Governor of Puerto Rico issued an Executive
>Order appointing a Special Commission on Vieques to Study the Existing
>Situation on the island Municipality of Vieques with Regard to the
>Activities of the United States Navy; and
>
>WHEREAS, on June 25, 1999, the Special Commission issued its report which
>included in its recommendations a demand that the United States Navy
>immediately and permanently cease all military operations on Vieques and
>transfer all property controlled by the Navy on Vieques to its people; and
>
>WHEREAS, the people of Vieques have unanimously demanded that the US Navy
>cease its bombings and leave the island; and
>
>WHEREAS, Puerto Rico�s civil society unanimously support the immediate
>withdrawal of the Navy from Vieques; and
>
>WHEREAS, the Government of Puerto Rico adopted as public policy the
>recommendations of the Special Commission of Vieques and the will of the
>residents of Puerto Rico;
>
>NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the Mayor and the City Council of the
>City of Springfield, Massachusetts calls upon the United States Navy to
>relocate from the island of Vieques and return the land to the
>Municipality of Vieques for civilian uses; and, be it further:
>
>RESOLVED, That copies of this Resolution be sent to President William J.
>Clinton, Vice-President Albert Gore, Attorney General Janet Reno, Defense
>Secretary William S. Cohen, Navy Secretary Richard Danzig, Senators Edward
>F. Kennedy and John F. Kerry, Congressional Representative for the City of
>Springfield Richard Neil, and Congressional Hispanic Caucus
>Representatives Carlos Romero Barcelo, Jose Serrano, Nydia Velazquez, and
>Luis Gutierrez, and Puerto Rican Governor Pedro Rossello.
>
>
>(signed)
>____________________________
>MAYOR MICHAEL J. ALBANO
>
>
>______________________________________________________________________
>To unsubscribe, write to viequeslibre-unsubscribe@...
>______________________________________________________________________
>Advertisement:
>15% off Ashford Collection jewelry for Mother's Day! Mom will love
>these gorgeous pieces handpicked by our expert jewelry buyers - now
>15% off and shipped FedEx overnight FREE! Spoiled as a child? Return
>the favor - get her gift at Ashford.com.
>http://on.linkexchange.com/?ATID=27&AID=1231
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:289
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 01:11:38
Subject:Put Republicans in the garbage can
Message:



mikelong@... wrote:

>
>Matt,
>	"Put Republicans in the garbage can"
>
>	Is this an Amiri Baraka quote?  If I recall correctly,
>it is.  How does one expect to win the Republican vote
>with this model of acceptance and cross class "unity" ?


This is indeed an Amiri Baraka quote.  Placed back in the context of it 
being one line out of a broader call to action, which to some up is: "The 
question of revolution is the seizure of power", then we can understand that 
Baraka is refering to the Republicans who hold Political Power, and who 
represent the insidious interests of imperialism with this political power, 
who make the lives of the great majority of life on earth as hellacious as 
they can.  Not to be confused with the blue-collar Republicans who hold down 
full-time jobs, drink beer and watch the Mets on the weekends, and have been 
fooled by some misquided sense of Patriotism that Bush Lite isn't going to 
put him or her into the frying pan next.  But I agree that it is these folks 
with whom we must build unity.  There are those who haven't yet committed 
fully one way or another, and we will continue to struggle with them while 
we can.  I hope they cast their lot with the people, ultimately.


Mike wrote:
>With all due respect, I've been trying to stay out of
>this conversation since I feel I have little of
>substance to add.

Hey, man...give yourself some credit. Remember that sketch you made for the 
campaign logo?  It started an entire wave of creative thought and energy 
resulting in the banner that we now have.  Mao said, "A single spark starts 
a prairy fire."



But then Mike wrote:
>When it comes to sarcasm, however,
>I too could find a response to damn near every post on this
>board.  Fortunately sarcasm and other assorted attempts
>at humour have already been deemed as unacceptable forms
>of expression on this list (re: Jim's rather clever parody a few
>messages back).
>Given the "rules of engagement" as implied by certain members of
>this list, your post borders on vicious and slanderous attack.
>Perhaps we can have a vote on what forms of expression are
>permitted?
>
>- Michael
>

First of all, I would avoid trying to become the Language Police.  It's bad 
form.  I happened to find Jim's "clever parody" particularly amusing.  I 
also disagreed with most of it.  And not to get too trite, but if you really 
are interested in calling out "vicious and slanderous attacks", then I 
suggest you take a closer look at what your buddy Chris spewed about Amiri 
Baraka before you jump to his defense.  You don't have to agree with 
everything Baraka says.  But for chriminy sakes, at least take the time to 
investigate who he is, what he's accomplished, what he represents, what he's 
written, and what opportunities he's opened to us by struggling with over 
the thorny issues of ideological struggle put to practice in the city of his 
birth--Newark--because he refused to sell out, putting his own life on the 
line for decades to make this world a better place, to where he can pack an 
auditorium in Italy, South Africa or South Carolina because he is respected 
all over the world for his teachings and writings that have him listed nest 
to WEB DuBois and Langston Hughes as among the most important Afro American 
writers ever, and then he STILL remains humble enough to open up his home to 
the public ever month for revolutionary culture because the city fathers 
don't think it's important enough to divest public funds for, that he 
doesn't sleep nights because it's the only time he has left in the day to 
write after extending himself to everyone he can, to where he spent nearly 
every cent he made (during the only month of the year that he's fully 
employed) investing in projects that will advance the cause...WHY?  because 
he's that committed and that strong and THAT, my friend, is why certain 
people need to step off their high-horse and see if there's something that 
can be learned from Amiri Baraka before they trip on their infantile and 
inflated sense of self-worth.  And if that offends you, then you're on the 
wrong side of history.  Later.
Matthew




> > Yeah, I'm with Chris.  Why in the world would we want to Amiri Baraka
> > to speak at this convention?  I mean, after all, just because we 
>followed

>talking

> > >Bright

> > >11:00 AM - 	Opening of the Convention by Chair,

> > >
> > >Introduction of the People's Campaign Platform
> > >
> > >11:10 AM - 	Amendments and debate on the People's
> > >Campaign Platform
> > >(One minute time limit to present or speak in favor of
> > >or against a proposed  amendment)
> > >
> > >12:10 PM - 	Vote on the People's Campaign Platform
> > >		(Entire platform will be voted on as a
> > >whole)
> > >
> > >12:20 PM - 	Final nominations for People's Campaign
> > >candidates for City Council
> > >
> > >12:30 PM - 	Lunch
> > >
> > >1:00 PM - 	Reconvening of People's Convention
> > >
> > >1:15 PM - 	Debate of People's Campaign candidates
> > >for City Council:
> > >
> > >		Speeches by prospective candidates (3
> > >minutes each)
> > >
> > >Endorsements of prospective candidates from the floor (3
> > >endorsements per candidate, 30 seconds each)
> > >
> > >2:15 PM - 	Vote on People's Campaign candidates for
> > >City Council
> > >		(New Brunswick residents only can  vote)
> > >
> > >2:40PM - 	Acceptance speeches by the three winning
> > >candidates (one minute each)
> > >
> > >2:45 PM - 	BREAK
> > >
> > >3:00 PM - 	Nominations and election of Campaign
> > >Manager
> > >		(Residents and non-resident campaign
> > >workers can vote)
> > >
> > >3:30 PM - 	Nominations and election of Coordinator
> > >for Elected Board Of Education
> > >Referendum
> > >		(Residents and non-resident campaign
> > >workers can vote)
> > >

> > >Committee

> > >workers can vote)

> > >Ward 4-5
> > >(residents only vote for leader(s) of the Ward they live

Sender:"Michael Long" <mikelong@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 02:03:05
Subject:Candidate flyer updated -- also, request for candidate quotes/bios
Message:

Hi all,

    Just wanted to let you know that the new flyer has been updated
to include the necessary legal tag line ('paid for by the People's Campaign'),
two more platform items (that's all that would fit) and the phone number
has been updated.

    Also, be warned that there are currently some DNS problems resolving
www.newbruns.org, (should be "resolved" by tomorrow)
so grab a copy at:

http://151.198.10.71/~mike/campaign_flyer_after_convention.doc

    Also, I know this has been circulating around via word of mouth, but just
a reminder that we NEED quotes and bios from the candidates!  Ideally,
we would like to two (one short, one longer) quotes and two bios for each 
candidate.  

Thanks,
- Mike

Post ID:291
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 08:42:11
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Media Committee Minutes 5/17/00
Message:

In addition to this media activities, I think the following should
be considered:

1--A free public service ad should be placed on cable channel
6. This might be a good spot to announce intership opportunities.

2--A public service announcement should be made for WRSU. As
in the above, it should stress interships and voter registration
help. The message needs to be nonpartisanly phrased. I suggest
Darryle Lamont Jenkin's skills be used here.

3--City council and school board meetings should be videotaped.
We have a git-darn right to do so and must use this option. The
video should then be edited and a Quick-Time movie should be
established on the Website.

4--I am in the process of writing letters on the Election Law
Enforcement Commission re Cahill and the Committee to Keep Politics
Out of Our Schools. I have been in contact with ELEC. Likewise,
I have significant information on the enviornmental contamination
of the Mile Run Brook beyond Rhodia. These letters will be developed
on behalf of others as tactically advised.

5--The issue of increased taxation regarding the fallow land
and the Lord Stirling School construction has been connected.
The amount in lost tax revenue is several hundred thousand dollars.
The connection is to be pronounced at the Lord Stirling School
groundbreaking ceremony in June. Candidates should perhaps take
the lead on this matter and in a controlled setting.
--- Original Message ---

Post ID:292
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 08:45:33
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Another canvassing experience. Thank you Cliff.
Message:

I agree with Jim's story, based on experience. What you say and
how you say it are VERY important.

--BV

--- Original Message ---
"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...> Wrote on 
Thu, 18 May 2000 16:20:20 -0000
 ------------------ 
I had a canvassing experience on Wednesday. It was different
from 
Jim's on Monday. 

Audrey and I were walking down Suydam St. and four guys and a
kid
were 
up on a porch. We stopped and I asked them if I could pitch them
about 
the campaign. 

Guys: "You guys hooked up with Cliff?"

Paul: "Yeah."

Guys: "Alright."

Paul: "Cool, we're trying to change how this city's run. First
we're 
gonna fire Craterface, then we're gonna send the good cops down
to 
fire the housing authority in NB Homes."

Guys: "Yea, these cops are outta hand. Things are all messed
up in 
this joint. We're gotta do something about this. Where do I sign?
I'm 
gonna vote this year. How do I register?"

Paul: "Yea, we can hook up all of that. Hey, what do you guys
think 
about Chinchilla and Marshall? That judge is looking to let them
off 
for sure."

Guys: "Yea, I saw the paper. Marshall busted EVERYBODY. He jumped

outta trees, hid in garbage cans. Everything ... That guy's a
murderer 
[Marshall] ... those two [cops] are kingpins ... they should
go to 
trial like a black drug dealer ... they should go to jail just
like 
everybody else!"

45 minutes later we bailed, everybody was wound up over our 
discussion. I had four pages of quotes from two guys. They said
"Put 
all of that in your paper!"  These guys never voted before and
now 
they're talking about seizing power.

I just want to thank Cliff. DOWN WITH ALL FORMS OF SECTARIANISM!

   In Unity and for the sake of the of the United Front--Paul



--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Jml " <jml@d...> wrote:
> An experience I had canvassing today:
> 
> Knocking on a door on Townsend Street, I was greeting by a

> man in his 50s.  I told him I was with the New Brunswick People's
> Campaign, and we were collecting signatures for petitions for
> an elected school board.  He immediately ushered me in.
> 
> I was not even across the doorway before he was probing me
> with questions: "What is your name?" "Who are you with?" 
> "Where is your office?"  
> 
> I met his wife in the kitchen.  Both were more than happy to
> put their signatures toward an elected school board.  But I
> was not in the house more than 15 seconds when the man turned
> to me, looked me right in the face, and said "Your flyers are
> completely overboard and ridiculous.  What are you doing?"
> 
> I asked him which flyers he had in mind.  He told me he meant
> the yellow ones.  "The ones with the name Block on Lock," he
said,
> explicitly remembering the name of the organization written
on
> those flyers.  "That's not how you go about running a campaign.
> I've lived in this town for 40 years.  This is *not* the kind
of
> message that appeals to people."
> 
> I assured the man that, as a representative of the People's
> Campaign, I stood as just that -- a representative of the 
> People, their platform, and the candidates they chose to run
> for City Council.  
> 
> He and his wife both seemed pleased with my attitude as they
both 
> enthusiastically signed the petition,
> emphasizing the need for democratic and progressive change
> in the city.
> 
> We shook hands, the gentleman wishing me and the Campaign
> much luck this year.  I assured him I would do everything in
> my power to properly represent the will of the people in my
> work.
> 
> Food for thought.
> 
> James Luceno

http://click.egroups.com/1/4054/0/_/357188/_/958666916/

Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>

Subject:Re: RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Another canvassing experience. Thank you Cliff.
Message:

I'm not trying to say I disagree with Jim's story. I trust Jim and 
I'm sure it's true. But I'm saying take the good and leave the bad.

>

> we're

> to 
> fire the housing authority in NB Homes."
>

> up in

Post ID:294
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 09:56:16
Subject:Re: RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Another canvassing experience. Thank you Cliff.
Message:

Paul, you can't take the good and leave  the bad.  If you ignore the "bad" 
experiences then you have nothing to grow from.  You need to learn from 
mistakes that are made and you need to stop and listen to what everyone is 
saying.  You have to watch what everyone is saying and doing especially 
from the internal side, you don't want half the people saying "We're 
running for 3 seats on city council" and then you have the rest going 
around yelling "Down with Cahill, Come Join the Anti-Cahill Revolution"

Contradictions will get the campaign nowhere...

At 01:50 PM 5/19/00 +0000, you wrote:

It's very disconcerting, especially if I've had a particularly witty retort 
that's lost it's teeth in cyber-limbo ;]  Just wondering.  MAtthew

Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Lag time
Message:

yes, the same is happening to me. i just checked my messages for the first 
time since monday, and i realized that i received many messages this week 
that were sent before monday that were not in my inbox on monday. i'm 
experiencing serious problems with my email (for example, dj darren has not 
received any of the messages i sent him re: our fundraising party, that i 
KNOW i sent him some time ago). i don't know if this is an issue with 
hotmail or with the egroups, or what, but it's kinda making me nervous...

anybody have any ideas?

Kristina

Post ID:298
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 13:18:07
Subject:Hi
Message:

Thats the thing.  Ive called up people on our contact list to follow up with them - and they told me that the person who canvassed them did not explain that this was a part of a political campaign to run 3 people against the current city council incumbents - one person told me that the canvasser didnt tell them much at all, and they were put on a list saying they would help out (perhaps bc they filled out a voter reg form) and then they get a call from me saying Im glad they are interested in helping out on the campaign and I have to apologize to them for being signed on to something without their knowledge.  Obviously not everyone is going to get all that we say, but I followed up with specific questions about the canvas dialogue, and they were able to be quite specific in response.



Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:299
Sender:"Michael Long" <mikelong@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-19 14:06:48
Subject:Re: [nbp] Hi -- request for information.
Message:

Friends,

    Some of the trouble comes from the fact that we lack the necessary
information when
we hit the streets.  I'd like to be so bold as to request an outline of what
we should try to
cover when canvassing.  In my opinion, everyone involved in the canvas needs
to be hitting
the same basic points: advertising the platform and the candidates.  It
should be easier now
that we have a platform flyer to refer to, however, there needs to be some
sort of
canvassing primer.  A very simple, single page primer that could be given to
anyone who
has just joined on the campaign, and with which he or she could then go out
and feel
comfortable canvasing.  *Obviously* we would not want to follow it verbatim,
simply
to provide a basis for new members.

For example:
* Hi I'm from the people's campaign
* ask his/her opinion of the current government in New Brunswick?
* Explain the people's campaign
        political campaign to run 3 people against the current city machine
for council.
* overview of platform points, explain the platform was voted on, result of
1000 surveys, etc
        hand them the flyer, ask questions, focus on things they are
interested in,
. . .

I think it would be incredibly useful.

In addition, I'd like to request information from Right to Know.  Lots of
it.  Chris has
offered to scan as much as possible and place it on the website.  All the
juicy dirt that's
been dug up needs to be kept together somewhere,  a nice big central
repository such
that when we are making flyers, papers, etc, we can just pull this
information out as needed.

Thoughts?

Thanks!
- Michael

> Thats the thing.  Ive called up people on our contact list to follow up
with them - and they told me that the person who canvassed them did not
explain that this was a part of a political campaign to run 3 people against
the current city council incumbents - one person told me that the canvasser
didnt tell them much at all, and they were put on a list saying they would
help out (perhaps bc they filled out a voter reg form) and then they get a
call from me saying Im glad they are interested in helping out on the
campaign and I have to apologize to them for being signed on to something
without their knowledge.  Obviously not everyone is going to get all that we
say, but I followed up with specific questions about the canvas dialogue,
and they were able to be quite specific in response.
>
>
>
> Zofia Nowakowski
> Fiscal Policy Institute
> 218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
> New York, NY 10018
> Tel: 212.278.0878
> Fax:212.730.1405

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:300
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-20 21:28:48
Subject:URGENT - from the Steering Committee
Message:

URGENT MESSAGE FROM THE STEERING COMMITTEE:

On Friday May 19, the Steering Committee made the 
unfortunate discovery that one of the People�s Campaign 
candidates, Danny Rosado, is not eligible to run for the 
New Brunswick City Council. Danny was under the 
incorrect impression that she only needed to be a U.S. 
citizen by the time of the November elections. She filed 
her naturalization papers with the INS five months ago 
and will obtain her citizenship within weeks. However, 
election law requires her to be a citizen and a 
registered voter by June 6 in order to get on the 
ballot. 
In light of this critical situation, the Steering 
Committee held an emergency meeting on Friday night. The 
meeting included all 10 members of the Steering 
Committee: Danny Rosado, Curtis Warren, Keith Joseph, 
Xavier Hansen, Joe Smith, Diego Morales, Frank Bright, 
Janice Payce, Audrey Allred and Jose Solano (Janice and 
Curtis were attending a dinner with Al Sharpton and 
communicated with the rest of the Steering Committee by 
phone). Considering time constraints (petitions are due 
by June 6, in two weeks), the Steering Committee, as the 
elected leadership of the People�s Campaign, decided to 
select a third candidate for the City Council in 
accordance with the democratic decisions made by the 
residents of New Brunswick at the People�s Convention of 
May 13.
 The fourth top vote-getter in the elections for City 
Council candidates at the People�s Convention was Glen 
Fleming (41 votes). However, Glen has cut off all 
contacts with the People�s Campaign since he lost the 
nomination at the People�s Convention. We found out this 
past week that  he signed his name to get petitions from 
the County Clerk�s office in order to run for a New 
Brunswick City Council seat on his own in the November 
elections, thereby competing against the People�s 
Campaign. This is a direct violation of the oath he 
signed at the People�s Convention (reiterated in his 
concession speech) to support the decisions of the 
People�s Campaign. This violation disqualifies him from 
becoming our third candidate for the City Council.
The fifth top vote-getter was Diego Morales (20 votes). 
Following a discussion by all members of the Steering 
Committee, we unanimously decided to place Diego Morales 
as the third New Brunswick City Council candidate on the 
People�s Campaign ticket, along with Curtis Warren and 
Keith Joseph. Diego has been a U.S. citizen for eight 
years and is registered to vote according to the 
official list of voters of Middlesex County. Danny 
Rosado gave him an enthusiastic endorsement. 
Danny was nominated as the new president of the Latino 
Committee and will remain on the Steering Committee. 
Everyone present told Danny we count on her to run as a 
People�s Campaign candidate in the next citywide 
elections two years from now. Danny promised to continue 
to promote the important issues she spoke of at the 
People�s Convention, specifically the struggles of 
working women in New Brunswick. Since we have 
regrettably lost our only woman candidate, everyone in 
the People�s Campaign should try to contribute to this 
task.
	The new People�s Campaign ticket continues to 
represent our most important strength: the multi-
national unity of the Latino, Afro-American and Euro-
American communities in the people�s struggle for 
democracy. Still, we must get a lot more serious about 
our work, down to the last detail, to avoid making any 
more dangerous mistakes of this kind in the months to 
come. We have an immediate challenge at hand: WE NEED 
EVERYONE TO COME OUT TO GET SIGNATURES FOR THE 
CANDIDATES� PETITIONS THAT ARE DUE IN TWO WEEKS!!! 
Canvass teams meet EVERY WEEK DAY AT 6PM at the PUBLIC 
LIBRARY (Livingston Ave.),  1PM ON SATURDAY and 12 NOON 
ON SUNDAY. Beep Samantha Prince at 898-9534 if you can 
only go at a different time of the day. We cannot let 
down the people of New Brunswick who have given their 
whole-hearted support to the People�s Campaign. We must 
show a lot of heart in the face of adversity if we want 
to defeat the City Machine in November. UNITE, ORGANIZE, 
SEIZE POWER!

CURTIS WARREN, KEITH JOSEPH AND DIEGO MORALES 
FOR THE NEW BRUNSWICK CITY COUNCIL IN NOVEMBER!

For the Steering Committee,

Xavier Hansen
Campaign Manager





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:301
Sender:"Michael Long" <mikelong@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-20 21:47:19
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] URGENT - from the Steering Committee
Message:

Xavier,

    I'd like to thank you, and everyone else on the Steering 
Committee for this *serious* overtime and high stress work.  

What happens to the petitions that have already been 
signed for the candidates?  
Do those signatures need to be re-obtained?

    I have already updated the candidate flyer on the web
page to reflect the change.

Thanks again!
- Michael

Post ID:304
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-21 00:42:09
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] URGENT - from the Steering Committee
Message:

Great work to everyone in the Steering Committee! It's highly unfortunate
that we must lose Danny as a candidate, but Diego is a wonderful new
candidate, and it's excellent that Danny will remain on the Steering
Committee as the Latino Committee's president and representative. You all
had to make hard decisions and deal with the situation presented to you,
and you did a wonderful job. I'm glad we elected all of you, and I think
this really proves the strength of this Campaign and of the
representatives elected by the people of New Brunswick. Thank you all.

--charlotte

On Sun, 21 May 2000 xavier.hansen@... wrote:

> URGENT MESSAGE FROM THE STEERING COMMITTEE:
> 
> On Friday May 19, the Steering Committee made the 
> unfortunate discovery that one of the Peoples Campaign 
> candidates, Danny Rosado, is not eligible to run for the 
> New Brunswick City Council. Danny was under the 
> incorrect impression that she only needed to be a U.S. 
> citizen by the time of the November elections. She filed 
> her naturalization papers with the INS five months ago 
> and will obtain her citizenship within weeks. However, 
> election law requires her to be a citizen and a 
> registered voter by June 6 in order to get on the 
> ballot. 
> In light of this critical situation, the Steering 
> Committee held an emergency meeting on Friday night. The 
> meeting included all 10 members of the Steering 
> Committee: Danny Rosado, Curtis Warren, Keith Joseph, 
> Xavier Hansen, Joe Smith, Diego Morales, Frank Bright, 
> Janice Payce, Audrey Allred and Jose Solano (Janice and 
> Curtis were attending a dinner with Al Sharpton and 
> communicated with the rest of the Steering Committee by 
> phone). Considering time constraints (petitions are due 
> by June 6, in two weeks), the Steering Committee, as the 
> elected leadership of the Peoples Campaign, decided to 
> select a third candidate for the City Council in 
> accordance with the democratic decisions made by the 
> residents of New Brunswick at the Peoples Convention of 
> May 13.
>  The fourth top vote-getter in the elections for City 
> Council candidates at the Peoples Convention was Glen 
> Fleming (41 votes). However, Glen has cut off all 
> contacts with the Peoples Campaign since he lost the 
> nomination at the Peoples Convention. We found out this 
> past week that  he signed his name to get petitions from 
> the County Clerks office in order to run for a New 
> Brunswick City Council seat on his own in the November 
> elections, thereby competing against the Peoples 
> Campaign. This is a direct violation of the oath he 
> signed at the Peoples Convention (reiterated in his 
> concession speech) to support the decisions of the 
> Peoples Campaign. This violation disqualifies him from 
> becoming our third candidate for the City Council.
> The fifth top vote-getter was Diego Morales (20 votes). 
> Following a discussion by all members of the Steering 
> Committee, we unanimously decided to place Diego Morales 
> as the third New Brunswick City Council candidate on the 
> Peoples Campaign ticket, along with Curtis Warren and 
> Keith Joseph. Diego has been a U.S. citizen for eight 
> years and is registered to vote according to the 
> official list of voters of Middlesex County. Danny 
> Rosado gave him an enthusiastic endorsement. 
> Danny was nominated as the new president of the Latino 
> Committee and will remain on the Steering Committee. 
> Everyone present told Danny we count on her to run as a 
> Peoples Campaign candidate in the next citywide 
> elections two years from now. Danny promised to continue 
> to promote the important issues she spoke of at the 
> Peoples Convention, specifically the struggles of 
> working women in New Brunswick. Since we have 
> regrettably lost our only woman candidate, everyone in 
> the Peoples Campaign should try to contribute to this 
> task.
> 	The new Peoples Campaign ticket continues to 
> represent our most important strength: the multi-
> national unity of the Latino, Afro-American and Euro-
> American communities in the peoples struggle for 
> democracy. Still, we must get a lot more serious about 
> our work, down to the last detail, to avoid making any 
> more dangerous mistakes of this kind in the months to 
> come. We have an immediate challenge at hand: WE NEED 
> EVERYONE TO COME OUT TO GET SIGNATURES FOR THE 
> CANDIDATES PETITIONS THAT ARE DUE IN TWO WEEKS!!! 
> Canvass teams meet EVERY WEEK DAY AT 6PM at the PUBLIC 
> LIBRARY (Livingston Ave.),  1PM ON SATURDAY and 12 NOON 
> ON SUNDAY. Beep Samantha Prince at 898-9534 if you can 
> only go at a different time of the day. We cannot let 
> down the people of New Brunswick who have given their 
> whole-hearted support to the Peoples Campaign. We must 
> show a lot of heart in the face of adversity if we want 
> to defeat the City Machine in November. UNITE, ORGANIZE, 
> SEIZE POWER!
> 
> CURTIS WARREN, KEITH JOSEPH AND DIEGO MORALES 
> FOR THE NEW BRUNSWICK CITY COUNCIL IN NOVEMBER!
> 
> For the Steering Committee,
> 
> Xavier Hansen
> Campaign Manager
> 
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Failed tests, classes skipped, forgotten locker combinations. 
> Remember the good 'ol days
> http://click.egroups.com/1/4053/0/_/357188/_/958872532/
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@...
> 
> To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@...
> 
>
