-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:366
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-20 21:08:38
Subject:Education, etc
Message:

Greetings --

I thought I would 'put down on paper' what I sought to express on 
Saturday, that is, my concerns over the "Higher Education" point of 
the platform as it is currently formulated, etc.. 

---

It is my understanding that the following was actually proposed and 
voted on as an integral component of the platform, at the convention:
             
             "College for all New Brunswick graduates"

Any further elaboration, in the form of specific policy 
recommendations and proposals, I understand need remain within the 
spirit of this (fairly general) point.  

Inside the current edition of the platform / candidates brochure, the 
following _specific_ policy recommendation appears, in attempted 
fulfillment of the above.  Verbatim --

"Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city 
assistance with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs 
in the city, to provide open admissions and free college education to 
all New Brunswick High School graduates."

I think the intentions here are quite good, and it isn't without 
merit to attempt to demand such an arrangement between Rutgers and 
the New Brunswick community. However, a number of problems arise.  At 
the same time, a number of considerations are omitted.   

1)  Rutgers is the 'State University of New Jersey'.  It is first and 
foremost accountable to the state legislature and the governor, 
alongside various corporate interests.  Secondly, only part of 
Rutgers College, Douglass College, and Mason Gross are actually in 
the City of New Brunswick.  The rest of it is in Piscataway, or in 
Newark or Camden.  

It would seem difficult for the City of New Brunswick to actually 
succeed in negotiating directly with the state university for such 
special consideration.  Would other cities and towns where Rutgers 
has campuses not demand the same arrangement?  This would have to 
become either a state policy, or no policy at all.  Of course, if the 
city council were to wish to put forward such a demand in a kind of 
activist role vis a vis the state or federal gov't -- there is 
nothing unusual about this -- it might be a good idea.  But the goal 
of the platform point seems to be something more concerete.

2)   It may be 'only fair' to extend open admissions selectively, to 
students from schools that perform so poorly that the state may well 
be obligated to give kids the benefit of the doubt, then compensate 
with remedial classes.  Rutgers is not that shy about lowering its 
admission standards for equality-of-opportunity considerations (as a 
state university).  What it fails at, like many large public 
universities undertaking this, is _retention_.  Open admissions won't 
guarantee that these NBHS graduates will go on to graduate from 
college.  This is perhaps more because of the "cultural capital" 
factor, knowing how to be a student, how to fake your way through 
certain things (like standardized tests), etc, than a lack of writing 
or math skills.  Or so I understand the consensus to be amongst many 
sociologists.

3)  The platform point above pays no attention to other state 
universities and colleges, vocational / technical / trade schools, 
and the county college.  Indeed, county colleges have a great deal of 
importance, if nothing else, in helping otherwise unprepared 
individuals to ultimately succeed in a four-year school.  (Also, MCC 
has a campus in New Brunswick)

So, what should be looked at more clearly is -- What opportunities 
_already_ exist, what community programs already exist, what are 
colleges in the state already doing, what scholarships exist, etc.. 
Furthermore, what sort of help are students recieving within the HS?  
Until these facts are known a little more clearly, it would probably 
be best to revise the platform to state something that includes more, 
but make less specific reccomendations.   

(Perhaps I am stating that the above proposal places the issue of 
higher education too much within the constellation of urban 
redevelopment issues rather than viewing it in terms of other 
educational and job-training/vocational issues)

This is all rudimentary, and issued with none but the most 
exploratory intent.  

Yours,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:367
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 09:35:10
Subject:City Council meeting tonite 7pm City Hall
Message:

The City council is expected to take final action tonight on a $49M budget that calls for a 9-cent property tax rate increase.  The municipal tax levy will increase by $2.2M to $17.2 million necessitating a tax hike from $1.03 per $100 of assessed value tro $1.12 per $100.  The increase is due to several expenditures including spending $600K to lease a new police headquarters next to city hall in Civic Square, which wil lbe leased for 20 yrs from the county.  The council will also bove on the proposed budget of the City Market special improvement distric that covers the downtown area - at $401,990, $1,500 more than last year.  It will be supplemented by corporate sponsor financing (whatever that means!) of $106,000.  The council will also conduct a public hearing on a proposed zoning ordinance that would set 2 1/2 stories as the maximum height of new one and 2 family homes in the city. (if this went through the planning board, I missed it - they spoke about the extra bedroom regulations which I spoke out against but this was not explained to me.)

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:368
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 09:52:45
Subject:Home News BOE article
Message:

Great work!


NEW BRUNSWICK: Trailer plan for pupils protested


Published in the Home News Tribune 6/21/00
By JAKE STUIVER
STAFF WRITER
Parents, teacher's union leaders and political hopefules turned out en masse 
for a New Brunswick board of education meeting last night where the 
administration was expected to present a plan to house more prekindergarten 
pupils.

Representatives from the People's Campaign, an independent political group 
that's running candidates for City Council, were at the high school 
auditorium front door throughout the evening handing out fliers promoting an 
elected school board. City activists recently revived the campaign to wrest 
control of school board appointments from Mayor Jim Cahill and have a board 
elected by the public.

The school board went into closed session, upon which People's Campaign 
council candidate Curtis L. Warren Sr. went to the microphone and rallied 
the large crowd against the proposal to place prekindergarten and child-care 
programs in 26 temporary trailers and have a private company assist in their 
education.

Warren claimed the board would privatize the operation and undermine 
teacher's unions. His speech was followed by several women from the audience 
who spoke against the plan. One woman backed the call for an elected board.

The board was still in closed session at press time last night.

Schools Superintendent Ronald Larkin planned to present a temporary solution 
last night to an anticipated influx of pupils resulting from the state 
Deparment of Education's requirement to provide free prekindergarten and 
child-care programs to all residents.

New Brunswick doesn't have any more room to build facilities for a large 
enrollment increase, Larkin said Monday.

There are currently about 750 3-year-olds, 800 4-year-olds and 850 
kindergartners in the city's program, he said. Some of them are in schools 
and others are spread throughout various daycare facilities in the city, he 
said.

Under the temporary plan, there would be 26 trailers spread among the high 
school and Lord Stirling, McKinley and Woodrow Wilson schools, officials 
said.

The trailers and longer-term placements would come at no extra cost to 
taxpayers because they come with fees the district already pays for its 
child-care programs, Larkin said.

Kate M. Smith, president of the New Brunswick Education Association 
teacher's union, had a statement prepared to respond to the board's 
discussion last night.

In the statement, she complained that Innovative Educational Programs, the 
company that runs the city's science and technology high school, is proposed 
for taking over some of the child-care programs.

"It is a corporation," she said. "What does a corporation know about 
education? A corporation's reason for being is money, profit, not children's 
education."

The teachers provided by IEP would lack the benefits of the union contract 
or rights guaranteed to board employees under state law and wouldn't be able 
to get tenure or contribute to the pension fund, Smith said.

"Who, then, would be willing to work under such demeaning conditions?" she 
asked.

Larkin, interviewed prior to the meeting, insisted IEP is a reputable 
child-care provider with which the district has had a successful 
relationship at the science and technology high school.



from the Home News Tribune

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:370
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 16:07:30
Subject:proposal to amend the platform
Message:

this is my proposal to amend our campaign platform. i want to replace the 
current description underneath the "JOBS" subsection, which i believe is 
disjointed and unclear, with the following:

Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all people 
in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will support/lead 
initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will actively support the 
right of all workers to organize for the purposes of collective bargaining; 
and we will give businesses that employ a majority city residents 
(especially those that are unionized) special preference in the procurement 
of city contracts. We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay equity 
policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages between workers of 
different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

thanks, Kristina
________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:371
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 16:07:41
Subject:proposal to amend the platform
Message:

this is my proposal to amend our campaign platform. i want to replace the 
current description underneath the "JOBS" subsection, which i believe is 
disjointed and unclear, with the following:

Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all people 
in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will support/lead 
initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will actively support the 
right of all workers to organize for the purposes of collective bargaining; 
and we will give businesses that employ a majority city residents 
(especially those that are unionized) special preference in the procurement 
of city contracts. We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay equity 
policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages between workers of 
different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

thanks, Kristina
________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:372
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-22 13:18:49
Subject:Paul McGee's Birthday Bash!
Message:

Hey, it's that time of year....

######################################################################

                  ...PAUL'S BIRTHDAY PARTY...

######################################################################

WITH A TWIST!  WHAT?  I'll get to that.   Just come to my party at 8pm on 
July 7th at 559 Hamilton, Franklin; just across from Krauszer's.

But don't give me ANYTHING! I know, I probably didn't give you a damn thing 
for your birthday. Hell, I probably didn't even remember your birthday!

But I do want you to give a donation to the People's Campaign, so that my 
birthday party isn't just another party. What you get out of it is a good 
time, great conversation, meeting new people, some really good beer, some 
good food if you get there on time, and an overall sense that you're doing 
something for and with the people of New Brunswick...So come and give $5 (at 
least) and we'll all have a good time....call me at 732 729 0873 if you're 
confused.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:374
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-22 15:21:04
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Education, etc
Message:

jeremy,

i think you bring up excellent points. overall, considering the revisions 
that have been offered in the past week on some of the platform points, I 
think we've reached a point in the campaign when we have to move beyond the 
"sound bite" stage. that means researching our policy points and formulating 
clear and informed proposals. my suggestion to you is to reword the 
Education proposal to include what you've written. that way we can vote on 
it and continue transforming our platform for the better.

additionally, i want to reintroduce Zofia's idea that we assign "point 
people" to each topic on the platform. Experts, so to speak. i don't mean 
this to sound intimidating, but i think it would be easier if one or two 
people concentrated on one specific topic and made sure to research it 
thoroughly. that way, when the time comes, we can be prepared to talk about 
everything.

what do people think about this? i'd like to discuss this at the next 
tactical meeting if all are willing.

Kristina


>From: timmy.o'toole@...
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Education, etc
>Date: Wed, 21 Jun 2000 01:08:38 -0000
>
>
>Greetings --
>
>I thought I would 'put down on paper' what I sought to express on
>Saturday, that is, my concerns over the "Higher Education" point of
>the platform as it is currently formulated, etc..
>
>---
>
>It is my understanding that the following was actually proposed and
>voted on as an integral component of the platform, at the convention:
>
>              "College for all New Brunswick graduates"
>
>Any further elaboration, in the form of specific policy
>recommendations and proposals, I understand need remain within the
>spirit of this (fairly general) point.
>
>Inside the current edition of the platform / candidates brochure, the
>following _specific_ policy recommendation appears, in attempted
>fulfillment of the above.  Verbatim --
>
>"Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city
>assistance with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs
>in the city, to provide open admissions and free college education to
>all New Brunswick High School graduates."
>
>I think the intentions here are quite good, and it isn't without
>merit to attempt to demand such an arrangement between Rutgers and
>the New Brunswick community. However, a number of problems arise.  At
>the same time, a number of considerations are omitted.
>
>1)  Rutgers is the 'State University of New Jersey'.  It is first and
>foremost accountable to the state legislature and the governor,
>alongside various corporate interests.  Secondly, only part of
>Rutgers College, Douglass College, and Mason Gross are actually in
>the City of New Brunswick.  The rest of it is in Piscataway, or in
>Newark or Camden.
>
>It would seem difficult for the City of New Brunswick to actually
>succeed in negotiating directly with the state university for such
>special consideration.  Would other cities and towns where Rutgers
>has campuses not demand the same arrangement?  This would have to
>become either a state policy, or no policy at all.  Of course, if the
>city council were to wish to put forward such a demand in a kind of
>activist role vis a vis the state or federal gov't -- there is
>nothing unusual about this -- it might be a good idea.  But the goal
>of the platform point seems to be something more concerete.
>
>2)   It may be 'only fair' to extend open admissions selectively, to
>students from schools that perform so poorly that the state may well
>be obligated to give kids the benefit of the doubt, then compensate
>with remedial classes.  Rutgers is not that shy about lowering its
>admission standards for equality-of-opportunity considerations (as a
>state university).  What it fails at, like many large public
>universities undertaking this, is _retention_.  Open admissions won't
>guarantee that these NBHS graduates will go on to graduate from
>college.  This is perhaps more because of the "cultural capital"
>factor, knowing how to be a student, how to fake your way through
>certain things (like standardized tests), etc, than a lack of writing
>or math skills.  Or so I understand the consensus to be amongst many
>sociologists.
>
>3)  The platform point above pays no attention to other state
>universities and colleges, vocational / technical / trade schools,
>and the county college.  Indeed, county colleges have a great deal of
>importance, if nothing else, in helping otherwise unprepared
>individuals to ultimately succeed in a four-year school.  (Also, MCC
>has a campus in New Brunswick)
>
>So, what should be looked at more clearly is -- What opportunities
>_already_ exist, what community programs already exist, what are
>colleges in the state already doing, what scholarships exist, etc..
>Furthermore, what sort of help are students recieving within the HS?
>Until these facts are known a little more clearly, it would probably
>be best to revise the platform to state something that includes more,
>but make less specific reccomendations.
>
>(Perhaps I am stating that the above proposal places the issue of
>higher education too much within the constellation of urban
>redevelopment issues rather than viewing it in terms of other
>educational and job-training/vocational issues)
>
>This is all rudimentary, and issued with none but the most
>exploratory intent.
>
>Yours,
>
>Jeremy
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:376
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-22 16:25:39
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Education, etc
Message:

Kris, I think you make good points. Let's get volunteers to contact outside 
experts, enlist them in the campaign's efforts (there have to be folks out 
there who would love to add some real policy juice to our work, get their 
names on the end product so to speak).  Point people shouldn't do all the 
work themselves. They should busy themselves getting NB residents to work 
with us. But point people would be responsible for gathering the info, 
cooking it down, and presenting it to either tactical or steering. They 
could also be the people who help prepare the candidates for the public, 
prep for debates, etc.

So far it seems they will up the class sizes, keep the 4-5 year olds kids in the classrooms in buildings.  They will likely subcontract out the 3 and 4 year olds.  However, the BOE is not giving out any info at this time and is in discussion with parents groups.

Mike and Moira are currently working on the newspaper.
They are expected to finish by Tuesday.

		Police Brutality Poster
		Rent Control Poster

Post ID:380
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-26 02:10:59
Subject:Campaign Web Site
Message:

www.peoplescampaign.net now works.  Check it out!

You can download all the latest flyers and posters from
there.  I'll be updating it periodically with Media's 
new work.  

Remember -- if you have criticisms of a piece, bring them
up within a week's time.  Otherwise they become old news
and our motivation to change them quickly will be ... well ...
less. :-)  

Once again, Media meets every Wednesday, 8pm, at 230 Sandford
Street, Flr 1.  All are welcome to attend.  But if you attend,
you will also be put to work, so no complaining. ;-)

Hope everyone is well.

Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:381
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-26 02:25:29
Subject:Newspaper
Message:

Folks, the newspaper is really looking sparse right now.  
It resembles a weak agitational pamphlet more than an
organ of Truth dissemination.  

I want everyone to look through the following two articles ...
and engage in Ruthless Criticism.  Remember -- this is the 
tool you will carry on the streets and give to anyone who is
interested in the Campaign.  It has to look sharp, it has to
represent the United Front, and it has to be true to our 
real intentions.

Nobody had a chance to criticize anything about the last
paper before it went to print.  I don't want that to happen
this time.  I want everybody's criticism.  Plus!  We need
everybody's contribution.  We are actually running short on
material for this paper.  So if anybody has information they
think should be in the paper, then please write an article
dealing with that specific issue.  (BOE, Redevelopment,
Police Brutality, Healthcare, children, etc.)The more specific 
information we can bring to the people, the better our chances of 
winning them over.

With that in mind, I want to push off the completion date of
this project from Tuesday to this weekend.  I'd rather have it a 
little later and better than sooner and shittier.  So let 'er rip.

Jim

Blurb on canvass: (Sam/Jim)

Volunteers for the People's Campaign collected 1000 surveys, in 
response to the question, "What do you believe is of greatest 
importance to the New Brunswick community?". This served as the basis 
for the following platform, openly debated and voted upon at the 
People's Convention this past May. These seventeen points form a 
spirited call for accountability and progressive reform. Since 
February members of the People's Campaign have canvassed the city, 
registering people to vote and getting signatures for an elected 
Board of Education.  We meet every day at the New Brunswick Public 
Library at 12 noon on Saturdays and Sundays and 6 PM during the 
week.  Come meet your neighbors and join the growing popular struggle 
for democracy!

Article on Convention: (Jim)

The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign held its history-making Convention 
on May 13th, 2000 at the Paul Robeson School, ratifying a platform 
and nominating three candidates for City Council.  Resulting from the 
many months of hard work by activists, residents, students, and 
community leaders, the Convention was a product of determination and 
dedication in the struggle for democracy.  
Uniting Democrats, Republicans, independents, revolutionaries, 
moderates, Blacks, Latinos, Whites, the young, and the old, it also 
represented the diverse array of groups in New Brunswick, coming 
together to take action against the corruption and gross injustices 
of the city machine.
The Convention was a product of the mass mobilization of the New 
Brunswick Peoples Campaign, which formed in January of this year.  
The months leading up to the Convention saw the expansion of the 
Peoples Campaign into a multi-national coalition comprised of 
residents and organizers who are fighting for democratic reform in 
New Brunswick.  Campaign organizers canvassed New Brunswick for four 
months, collecting over 1000 survey results to form a platform that 
is by the people and for the people.  The top five issues concerning 
New Brunswick's residents are rent control, police brutality, 
education, job availability and training, and youth activities.
Over 150 people attended the Convention, expressing their right to 
democracy and political decision-making.  They unanimously voted in 
favor of the Campaign platform, with their own amendments, proving 
the ability of the people to make political decisions in their own 
interests.
The Convention also chose three candidates to represent them in the 
November election for New Brunswick City Council.  The people chose 
Curtis Warren (New Brunswick Coalition Against Police Brutality), 
Keith Joseph (New Jersey Freedom Organization), and Diego Morales 
(Mexican-American labor organizer).  The three candidates took an 
oath to uphold the will of the people as expressed at the Convention, 
making them the undisputed servants of the people of New Brunswick in 
this year's election.
The multi-national composition of the Convention shows the 
willingness of the people to unite across cultural and ethic lines, 
fighting together for their common interests.  The Latino Committee 
formed at the Convention, composed of more than 30 individuals, and 
nominated candidates from their communities.  Joined by Blacks and 
Euro-Americans, the Convention reflected the cultural and racial 
composition of New Brunswick.
The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign is more than this year's election 
or the three individuals running for City Council, and this is 
evidenced by the enthusiasm and turnout at the Convention.  It is the 
beginning of a mass-based movement that will shake the wealthy 
controllers of New Brunswick from their lofty heights.  The seizure 
of City Council by the people will sound the trumpet of defeat for 
the rulers of New Jersey's cities.  People's Campaigns must spread 
like brush fire -- across the city, across New Jersey, and across the 
country.  Starting in New Brunswick we will light the fire that will 
blaze the path to the overthrow of our oppressors.

Campaign and National Politics: (Keith Joseph)

The first election in United States allowed only 4% of the population 
to vote. You had to own property, you had to be a man and you had to 
be white.  96% of the population did not qualify.  They were women, 
Afro-American, Native Americans, and white men without property. Even 
then America was hailed as a democracy yet the majority of people in 
the country were not allowed to vote. They were ruled by a class of 
property owning white men. 
Since then progress has been: made the civil rights movement, the 
women's suffrage movement extended the right to vote, but for the 
most part the majority of people are stilled ruled by that same tiny 
class. In New Brunswick this has become obvious to many.  Johnson and 
Johnson and other large corporations and banks control the city 
government through the "Democratic" Party machine, and non-
governmental organizations like New Brunswick Tomorrow and  DevCo. 
Across the United States cities are changing.  "Redevelopment" is 
the "politically correct" code word for the ethnic cleansing of our 
cities.  Cities in America used to be the homes of working people of 
all different nationalities.  Now the wealthiest few  want to turn 
the cities into their elite amusement parks, shopping, restaurants 
and theatre.  None of it is affordable or accessible to working 
people.  None of it will be owned by small business people who live 
in New Brunswick.  As "Redevelopment" rolls on more and more of New 
Brunswick's small business are being driven out to make room 
for "National Stores".  In New Brunswick, the politicians of Johnson 
and Johnson are planning the demolition of Memorial Homes.  Yet, they 
have no plans for the relocation of the people in New Brunswick. They 
want the people to leave town. They require a brutal police force 
that can terrorize people who do not follow along with their plans. 
They require a failing school system so that parents will want to 
leave town in search of a good public education for their children.  
We must organize a resistance and struggle to seize political power.  
The People's Campaign is a multi-national, multi-racial organization 
of working people, small business owners, students, and middle class 
people who have come together to work for a different redevelopment 
plan.  We want good schools and recreation and cultural activities 
for the youth. We want an end to police brutality. We want 
redevelopment that puts the people before the profits the of Johnson 
and Johnson. The People's Campaign is about our platform and getting 
it effect.  Our candidates and our organization are tools to win our 
program.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

>February members of the People's Campaign have canvassed the city,
>registering people to vote and getting signatures for an elected
>Board of Education.  We meet every day at the New Brunswick Public
>Library at 12 noon on Saturdays and Sundays and 6 PM during the
>week.  Come meet your neighbors and join the growing popular struggle
>for democracy!
>
>Article on Convention: (Jim)
>
>The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign held its history-making Convention
>on May 13th, 2000 at the Paul Robeson School, ratifying a platform
>and nominating three candidates for City Council.  Resulting from the
>many months of hard work by activists, residents, students, and
>community leaders, the Convention was a product of determination and
>dedication in the struggle for democracy.
>Uniting Democrats, Republicans, independents, revolutionaries,
>moderates, Blacks, Latinos, Whites, the young, and the old, it also
>represented the diverse array of groups in New Brunswick, coming
>together to take action against the corruption and gross injustices
>of the city machine.
>The Convention was a product of the mass mobilization of the New
>Brunswick Peoples Campaign, which formed in January of this year.
>The months leading up to the Convention saw the expansion of the
>Peoples Campaign into a multi-national coalition comprised of
>residents and organizers who are fighting for democratic reform in
>New Brunswick.  Campaign organizers canvassed New Brunswick for four
>months, collecting over 1000 survey results to form a platform that
>is by the people and for the people.  The top five issues concerning
>New Brunswick's residents are rent control, police brutality,
>education, job availability and training, and youth activities.
>Over 150 people attended the Convention, expressing their right to
>democracy and political decision-making.  They unanimously voted in
>favor of the Campaign platform, with their own amendments, proving
>the ability of the people to make political decisions in their own
>interests.
>The Convention also chose three candidates to represent them in the
>November election for New Brunswick City Council.  The people chose
>Curtis Warren (New Brunswick Coalition Against Police Brutality),
>Keith Joseph (New Jersey Freedom Organization), and Diego Morales
>(Mexican-American labor organizer).  The three candidates took an
>oath to uphold the will of the people as expressed at the Convention,
>making them the undisputed servants of the people of New Brunswick in
>this year's election.
>The multi-national composition of the Convention shows the
>willingness of the people to unite across cultural and ethic lines,
>fighting together for their common interests.  The Latino Committee
>formed at the Convention, composed of more than 30 individuals, and
>nominated candidates from their communities.  Joined by Blacks and
>Euro-Americans, the Convention reflected the cultural and racial
>composition of New Brunswick.
>The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign is more than this year's election
>or the three individuals running for City Council, and this is
>evidenced by the enthusiasm and turnout at the Convention.  It is the
>beginning of a mass-based movement that will shake the wealthy
>controllers of New Brunswick from their lofty heights.  The seizure
>of City Council by the people will sound the trumpet of defeat for
>the rulers of New Jersey's cities.  People's Campaigns must spread
>like brush fire -- across the city, across New Jersey, and across the
>country.  Starting in New Brunswick we will light the fire that will
>blaze the path to the overthrow of our oppressors.
>
>Campaign and National Politics: (Keith Joseph)
>
>The first election in United States allowed only 4% of the population
>to vote. You had to own property, you had to be a man and you had to
>be white.  96% of the population did not qualify.  They were women,
>Afro-American, Native Americans, and white men without property. Even
>then America was hailed as a democracy yet the majority of people in
>the country were not allowed to vote. They were ruled by a class of
>property owning white men.
>Since then progress has been: made the civil rights movement, the
>women's suffrage movement extended the right to vote, but for the
>most part the majority of people are stilled ruled by that same tiny
>class. In New Brunswick this has become obvious to many.  Johnson and
>Johnson and other large corporations and banks control the city
>government through the "Democratic" Party machine, and non-
>governmental organizations like New Brunswick Tomorrow and  DevCo.
>Across the United States cities are changing.  "Redevelopment" is
>the "politically correct" code word for the ethnic cleansing of our
>cities.  Cities in America used to be the homes of working people of
>all different nationalities.  Now the wealthiest few  want to turn
>the cities into their elite amusement parks, shopping, restaurants
>and theatre.  None of it is affordable or accessible to working
>people.  None of it will be owned by small business people who live
>in New Brunswick.  As "Redevelopment" rolls on more and more of New
>Brunswick's small business are being driven out to make room
>for "National Stores".  In New Brunswick, the politicians of Johnson
>and Johnson are planning the demolition of Memorial Homes.  Yet, they
>have no plans for the relocation of the people in New Brunswick. They
>want the people to leave town. They require a brutal police force
>that can terrorize people who do not follow along with their plans.
>They require a failing school system so that parents will want to
>leave town in search of a good public education for their children.
>We must organize a resistance and struggle to seize political power.
>The People's Campaign is a multi-national, multi-racial organization
>of working people, small business owners, students, and middle class
>people who have come together to work for a different redevelopment
>plan.  We want good schools and recreation and cultural activities
>for the youth. We want an end to police brutality. We want
>redevelopment that puts the people before the profits the of Johnson
>and Johnson. The People's Campaign is about our platform and getting
>it effect.  Our candidates and our organization are tools to win our
>program.
>
>
>
>

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

paper 
> demanding a town pool.

> >From: jmluceno@e...

> >To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
> >Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Newspaper
> >Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2000 06:25:29 -0000
> >
> >Folks, the newspaper is really looking sparse right now.
> >It resembles a weak agitational pamphlet more than an
> >organ of Truth dissemination.
> >
> >I want everyone to look through the following two articles ...
> >and engage in Ruthless Criticism.  Remember -- this is the
> >tool you will carry on the streets and give to anyone who is
> >interested in the Campaign.  It has to look sharp, it has to
> >represent the United Front, and it has to be true to our
> >real intentions.
> >
> >Nobody had a chance to criticize anything about the last
> >paper before it went to print.  I don't want that to happen
> >this time.  I want everybody's criticism.  Plus!  We need
> >everybody's contribution.  We are actually running short on
> >material for this paper.  So if anybody has information they
> >think should be in the paper, then please write an article
> >dealing with that specific issue.  (BOE, Redevelopment,
> >Police Brutality, Healthcare, children, etc.)The more specific
> >information we can bring to the people, the better our chances of
> >winning them over.
> >
> >With that in mind, I want to push off the completion date of
> >this project from Tuesday to this weekend.  I'd rather have it a
> >little later and better than sooner and shittier.  So let 'er rip.
> >

> >
> >Blurb on canvass: (Sam/Jim)

> >importance to the New Brunswick community?". This served as the
basis
> >for the following platform, openly debated and voted upon at the
> >People's Convention this past May. These seventeen points form a
> >spirited call for accountability and progressive reform. Since
> >February members of the People's Campaign have canvassed the city,
> >registering people to vote and getting signatures for an elected

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:384
Sender:ShearsToMe@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-27 01:50:28
Subject:Re: proposal to amend the platform
Message:

Hello.  I think your proposal is fairly well-conceived.  Let me offer 
some questions / problems.  

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...> 
wrote:

[quote]
 
Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all 
people in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will 
support/lead initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will 
actively support the right of all workers to organize for the 
purposes of collective bargaining;  and we will give businesses that 
employ a majority city residents (especially those that are 
unionized) special preference in the procurement of city contracts. 
We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

[unquote]

1)  The first sentence seems to be a statement of what the _core 
value_ is, what gives form and meaning to, the proposals that 
follow.  (This is a good way to write a point in a platform, I'd 
imagine).  Is "full and meaningful employment" the best statement of 
that core value -- especially in light of the concepts that follow?

1a)  Does it sound as though the campaign is _seriously_ 
promising "full employment" on the municipal level, as a realizable 
goal?  Will it be interpreted this way?  

1b)  "Meaningful employment" -- this phrase has all sorts of 
pitfalls.  There's is a sound of elitism to it.  I think professing 
the values of fairness and providing opportunities for advancement 
and free choice of vocation is sufficient.  

2)  The last sentence reads:  "We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities."  This is 
different from, but close to, merely stating sympathy for AA/EEO 
laws, regulations, hiring policies.  The point should probably be 
reconfigured to take this into account -- though I also wonder to 
what extent companies in New Brunswick, and state and federal laws, 
already mandate pay equity (and to what extent they don't).

2b) I will post a critique of the concept of "nationality", as it's 
sometimes used in the campaign, in a separate message.  For the 
moment -- I would suggest changing "genders and nationalities" to 
something like "backgrounds and genders", "gender, racial and ethnic 
backgrounds",  etc.  If nothing else, what is excluded is sexual 
orientation and religion.  

3)  This is a matter of research (Again, I would probably be inclined 
to help on on such tasks):  What leeway does a city government have 
in preferentially granting contracts?  I understand that officially 
prefering unionized firms and firms with more 'diversity' has been 
done before by municipalities (and states).  But can it be mandated 
that companies hire a certain percentage of the town's residents?
Furthermore, any given company, of course, has different echelons of 
employment.  

Some points that came to me.  Hope this is of use.  

Yours,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:385
Sender:ShearsToMe@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-27 01:51:30
Subject:Re: proposal to amend the platform
Message:

Hello.  I think your proposal is fairly well-conceived.  Let me offer 
some questions / problems.  

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...> 
wrote:

[quote]
 
Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all 
people in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will 
support/lead initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will 
actively support the right of all workers to organize for the 
purposes of collective bargaining;  and we will give businesses that 
employ a majority city residents (especially those that are 
unionized) special preference in the procurement of city contracts. 
We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

[unquote]

1)  The first sentence seems to be a statement of what the _core 
value_ is, what gives form and meaning to, the proposals that 
follow.  (This is a good way to write a point in a platform, I'd 
imagine).  Is "full and meaningful employment" the best statement of 
that core value -- especially in light of the concepts that follow?

1a)  Does it sound as though the campaign is _seriously_ 
promising "full employment" on the municipal level, as a realizable 
goal?  Will it be interpreted this way?  

1b)  "Meaningful employment" -- this phrase has all sorts of 
pitfalls.  There's is a sound of elitism to it.  I think professing 
the values of fairness and providing opportunities for advancement 
and free choice of vocation is sufficient.  

2)  The last sentence reads:  "We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities."  This is 
different from, but close to, merely stating sympathy for AA/EEO 
laws, regulations, hiring policies.  The point should probably be 
reconfigured to take this into account -- though I also wonder to 
what extent companies in New Brunswick, and state and federal laws, 
already mandate pay equity (and to what extent they don't).

2b) I will post a critique of the concept of "nationality", as it's 
sometimes used in the campaign, in a separate message.  For the 
moment -- I would suggest changing "genders and nationalities" to 
something like "backgrounds and genders", "gender, racial and ethnic 
backgrounds",  etc.  If nothing else, what is excluded is sexual 
orientation and religion.  

3)  This is a matter of research (Again, I would probably be inclined 
to help on on such tasks):  What leeway does a city government have 
in preferentially granting contracts?  I understand that officially 
prefering unionized firms and firms with more 'diversity' has been 
done before by municipalities (and states).  But can it be mandated 
that companies hire a certain percentage of the town's residents?
Furthermore, any given company, of course, has different echelons of 
employment.  

Some points that came to me.  Hope this is of use.  

Yours,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:386
Sender:ShearsToMe@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-27 02:15:27
Subject:Re: Education, etc
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...> 
wrote:
> jeremy,
> 
> i think you bring up excellent points. overall, considering the 
revisions 
> that have been offered in the past week on some of the platform 
points, I 
> think we've reached a point in the campaign when we have to move 
beyond the 
> "sound bite" stage. that means researching our policy points and 
formulating 
> clear and informed proposals. my suggestion to you is to reword the 
> Education proposal to include what you've written. that way we can 
vote on 
> it and continue transforming our platform for the better.

Thanks.  I'll try to put something together.  I think at this point, 
similarly, that it is vital that solid arguments with strong data 
exist behind every policy statement put forward.  The strongest claim 
that can be made is that the current administration is, 'bottom 
line', incompetent despite pretenses to the contrary.  What has to be 
shown is what, in the final analysis, a city council in New Brunswick 
could really be doing with the available resources.  At minimum.  
This is a minimum that can be proven quite concretely.  

> additionally, i want to reintroduce Zofia's idea that we 
assign "point 
> people" to each topic on the platform. Experts, so to speak. i 
don't mean 
> this to sound intimidating, but i think it would be easier if one 
or two 
> people concentrated on one specific topic and made sure to research 
it 
> thoroughly. that way, when the time comes, we can be prepared to 
talk about 
> everything.

I'll abstain for the moment from making arguments either way on this -
- I don't really know enough.  

I will, however, propose this:  If someone decides that a point on 
the platform should be changed, and if there's some determinable 
level of agreement as to this, the point should be revised to say 
something more general _until a sufficiently specific and well-
researched statement can be formulated_.  The process of agreeing to 
change it, and the process of providing an alternative, are thereby 
separated as to provide ample room for discussion.  

Yours,

Jeremy

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:389
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-28 17:44:57
Subject:Terminology
Message:

Hello.  I will try not to make this too extensive :

I would suggest that there is a good deal of rhetoric being utilized 
in the campaign that should be discussed as to its coherence, 
consistency, accuracy and appropriateness.  There are a number of 
highly anomalous phrases, words that are not commonly recognized by 
most residents of the United States, nonetheless being used as though 
they were to be taken for granted.  OR, they are not commonly used in 
the sense or context in which they're being used in the campaign.  

Rather than analyze in any depth these terms, I will simply list
them.  
I believe they all warrant conscious and open consideration:  this is 
what is required whenever any new word is introduced into a language 
in a democratic society.  

1)  Euro-American
2)  Ethnic Cleansing
3)  Nationality, Multi-National, Nation
4)  The Struggle For Democracy
5)  The People

(#4 and #5 are meant where used in certain particular ways)





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-29 15:30:15

ONE. YEAH. SO COME BY FRIDAY NIGHT FOR GOOD COMPANY AND A GOOD TIME. PLEASE 
BRING A DONATION FOR THE NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLE'S CAMPAIGN. ANY CHECKS YOU 
WERE GOING TO MAKE OUT TO FLAVIO OR PAUL, YOU CAN DIRECT THEM TOWARDS OUR 
BELOVED CITY COUNCIL CAMPAIGN. CALL 732 729 0873 FOR DIRECTIONS, ETC.

PAUL'S REALLY EXCITED BECAUSE THIS IS THE FIRST ELECTION HE'S GOING TO BE 
ALLOWED TO VOTE IN.

Post ID:391
Sender:"Jose Davila" <JDavila@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-28 14:42:40
Subject:Room for Rent
Message:

PEOPLE!

I am subletting a room for July and August, while I work and reside in NYC.  The room is a single for $300/month + utilities (cheap for the summer).  The room is available now through Labor Day.  It's located at 19 Louis Street b/w Somerset and French St.  It's a 3 bedroom currently occupied by 2 women (no gender preference).  The room includes use of a kitchen, livingroom, laundry facilities, storage space, backyard and is within walking distance of campus buses and public transportation.  The only catch is that there are no pets allowed.

If interested, call Jose Davila at (212) 730-6402 or (718) 861-1774 or email me.

******************************
Jos Davila
Research Assistant
Fiscal Policy Institute
232 West 40th Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY 10018
ph: 212/730-6402
fx: 212/730-1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:392
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-30 01:34:49
Subject:Board of Education article
Message:

Here's another anchor article for the paper.  Any comments?

Jim

No education without representation!
Zofia Nowakowski

This November 7th New Brunswick residents will vote whether or not to 
have an elected Board of Education.  Parents and the community could 
have real representation and control over decisions made about the 
schools.  For too long our schools have languished.  Change is 
stymied and frustrated by mayoral vetoes and deals for Superintendent 
Larkin's buddies.  The appointed school board's hands are
tied by 
mayoral relationships to organizations receiving contracts.

For too long New Brunswick schools have had poor quality education.  
Working parents decide to send their children to live with 
grandparents to get a decent education.  Parent activists throw up 
their hands in exasperation when they cannot succeed in reforming the 
schools, eventually sending their own children outside the district.

For too long the district schools have provided educational 
opportunities that depend on which school a child attends and who 
they are.  They have actively fostered inequality in the system, with 
our tax dollars, developing semi-private schools such as the charter 
school and Science and Technology High School.

For too long parents have actively engaged the schools for change and 
have seen their ideas ignored.  Recently a site-placed management 
plan hammered out by parents, teachers, and community members was 
vetoed by Mayor Cahill.  We must have recourse when these situations 
develop, and currently no board member is in an independent position 
to speak out against this injustice.

On June 20th the Board of Education met to discuss plans to privatize 
pre-K education.  The plan required moving 3 year-olds from local 
school areas to trailers at the high school.  A privately owned 
education "client company" with non-union teachers 
and "administrators" would direct the education of these
children.  
While the board met behind closed doors, deciding the fate of our 
children's education, the People's Campaign candidates, Keith
Joseph, 
Diego Morales, and Curtis Warren, took charge of the meeting, 
addressing a crowd of 500 parents, residents, and teachers.  The 
audience took over the meeting, expressing their concerns, and 
condemning the board for standing behind neither the children nor the 
teachers' unions.  Due to public outrage, the board cancelled
plans 
for the trailers, but they still intend to privatize the pre-K 
education.

Kate Smith, president of the New Brunswick Education Association, 
said she discussed the need for a contingency plan months before.  
Her suggestions were not addressed.  Contracting additional teachers 
with Innovative Educational Programs (I.E.P.) represented a direct 
attack on our own union teachers.  It favored a corporation that has 
a track record of high turnover in the last year in the Science and 
Technology High School.

New Brunswick, along with 29 other urban "Abbott v. Burke"
districts 
has waited far too long for funding from the state to address 
overcrowded and inadequate facilities, let alone the new mandated pre-
K programs.  Keith Joseph addressed the board on this point, 
demanding that the board act as "a sword for the people rather
than a 
shield for the state."  He called on them to assist residents in 
organizing a state-wide coalition and send residents to Trenton to 
lobby for the funds.

An elected Board of Education would require members to remain 
accountable and in touch with parents and the community.  The public 
would review the school budget, rather than a Board of School 
Estimates (the mayor, two council members, and two appointed board 
members).  Also, the board would increase from 7 to 9 members.
Only 20 of New Jersey's 550 municipalities have an appointed
school 
board.  It is time that New Brunswick win democratic representation 
on its school board so our schools can experience positive change in 
the near future.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:393
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-03 17:58:51
Subject:Platform Point
Message:

Hello.

I was advised to present a possible replacement for the 'college for 
all New Brunswick graduates' point on the platform.  For reference,
it 
currently reads: 

Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city assistance 
with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs in the city, 
to provide open admissions and free college education to all New 
Brunswick High School graduates.

I would suggest the following alternative, to be edited or modified 
however:

"Provide enhanced access to higher education and post-high school 
vocational training for all interested New Brunswick graduates.  
Ensure that high school students receive ample assistance with and 
information on scholarship funds and educational opportunities in the 
county, state and nationwide.  Work to guarantee that economic status 
not bar youth from pursuing their life goals."    

This is fairly general -- but it seems to be appropriate to the level 
of knowledge about "what's out there for NB students after
graduation" 
that we presently possess.

I present this as a temporary measure, until something more specific 
can be put together, discussed, and voted on at a general meeting.  I 
will make an argument about this specifically relating to the 
platform's forthcoming publication in the newspaper in a separate 
message.  

Yours,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:394
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-03 19:23:38
Subject:Important
Message:

The newspaper, I understand, is going to be published with a complete 
copy of the platform on one of its pages.  

I would argue that the changes I proposed for the 'college education' 
point be included in upcoming publication.  And I would submit this
to 
be feasible while still respecting democracy at all levels.

Why?

1)  The newspaper will be a definitive statement on the campaign and 
its activities, its foremost piece of literature, at least for a 
number of weeks.  The next general meeting, however, won't come until 
after the newspaper has been published.  Thus there's no way to vote 
on any changes in a general meeting beforehand.

2)  I would have proposed at the last General Meeting that the 
authorization to change the platform point to something less specific 
and more inclusive _as a temporary measure_ be voted upon, had I
known 
about the above (#1) problem.

3)  I think I successfully demonstrated that the platform point as it 
currently stands is either factually flawed, or has a great potential 
to prove difficult to defend under any kind of scrutiny.  Indeed, it 
seems that the problems I pointed out, with all due respect, simply 
weren't thought of when the platform's details were voted upon.  

If I were proposing a new addition to the platform, or a new policy 
proposal instead of the thing about Rutgers, that would be different. 
But I am merely proposing that, in the name of factual accuracy, the 
proposal be replaced with something more general -- a few sentences
of 
very generic rhetoric that is almost certainly implicit in the mere 
guarantee of "College for all New Brunswick Residents".  

4)  It should be noted, furthermore, that nobody spoke up to _oppose_ 
changing that point, nor in defense of that point as it was
originally 
formulated, either at the meeting or on this list.  

In fact, I thought that a tacit agreement to replace that point with
a 
more general, rhetorical placeholder had been reached -- provided
that 
it be eventually replaced with something more specific.  

I openly welcome any criticism of my arguments.  

Yours,

Jeremy

>King,

>years, if you do not carry on that tradition,  and that period of

>move

>power.

>murdering me

Post ID:396
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-03 23:18:29
Subject:Fwd: [soa] Gore, Interrupted- Urgent 6/29- Pass it On
Message:



>From: soa central command <soa1@...>
>To: soa@egroups.com
>CC: rites@..., blackpower@...
>Subject: [soa] Gore, Interrupted- Urgent 6/29- Pass it On
>Date: Sat, 1 Jul 2000 18:01:02 -0400 (EDT)
>
>------Original Message------
>From: "Claudia K White" <utahsports@...>
>Sent: July 1, 2000 9:38:21 PM GMT
>Subject: Gore, Interrupted- Urgent 6/29- Pass it On
>
>---
>STOP NATO: !NO PASARAN! - HTTP://WWW.STOPNATO.COM
>
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: Ramsey Kysia <mbakery@...>
>To: <iac-discussion@egroups.com>
>Sent: Friday, June 30, 2000 5:12 AM
>Subject: [iac-disc.] (Fwd) Gore, Interrupted- Urgent 6/29- Pass it On (fwd)
>
>
>---------- Forwarded message ----------
>Date: Thu, 29 Jun 2000 19:56:07 -0500
>From: Kathy Kelly <kkelly@...>
>To: kkelly@...
>Subject: Gore, Interrupted- Urgent 6/29- Pass it On
>
>In the midst of madness this morning, we received word here at the Voices
>office that Al Gore was visiting Chicago to talk about "energy policy
>incentives for cities."  Kathy was leaving today for Iraq to begin the
>Summer 2000 Voices in Basra sojourn, to live and witness the suffering
>caused by sanctions and to be in solidarity with the Iraqi people. Recent
>reports have suggested that the Clinton Administration is looking to pull
>out all the stops to bomb Iraq, possibly in the fall and help influence
>the election; with Gore down in the polls, Nader taking some votes, and
>Bush criticizing the current administration's stance on being "soft on
>Saddam," we are afraid this might not be so far from the truth.
>
>Kathy and I decided that we could not pass up this oppportunity, to at
>least be a presence near his speech, so I ditched her with all the mundane
>office tasks and last minute details and headed to Navy Pier.
>
>I entered Navy Pier, went to the Rooftop Terrace and showed my ID, which
>was all they asked for.  I later found out it was by invitation only,
>supposedly, but they were letting anyone walk in who showed an ID.  I
>passed through metal detection and made my way to the roof amidst a sea of
>ardent Gorettes and carefully placed Secret Service.
>
>The rooftop was filled with approximately 150 Gore supporters, Chicago's
>Mayor Daley, and every major media outlet.  As Gore stepped out to a
>standing ovation, with a stammering introduction from the Mayor, "These
>Are Days", a popular song written by the band 10, 000 Maniacs, blasted
>throughout the sound system. I had come not to hear the issues Gore was
>saying were important, but to ask him a question relating to an issue that
>is in the hearts and minds of 24 million people taken siege by sanctions.
>This question also weighs heavily on my heart and mind, since I recently
>returned from Iraq and witnessed the carnage so cavalierly bestowed upon
>the Iraqis by the US government.
>
>As Mr. Gore began to speak about how much "me and Tipper love the Windy
>City," I raised my voice and asked "Mr. Gore, why should anyone vote for
>an administration that kills five thousand innocent children a month
>through sanctions in Iraq?"
>
>He stopped.  And he laughed.  He actually laughed. He said he would
>discuss this later in the day. I responded by saying that every ten
>minutes a child dies in Iraq due to sanctions and we do not have the time
>to wait. I told him that we need to stop giving military aid to the Middle
>East, which works to divide and destabalize, and that the billions wasted
>on bombing missions and sanctions could benefit the American people. I was
>also able to spout off the names of Denis Halliday, Hans Von Sponeck, and
>Jutta Burghardt as UN officials who protest the sanctions before I was
>removed.
>
>Mr.  Gore did not answer my question directly, but many people expressed
>support, even the sticker wearing Gore fans.  The media taped the whole
>thing and at least one was going live (C-SPAN???)  If anybody sees any
>info, please contact us.
>
>I think of the song blaring while Gore walked to the podium as I think of
>what occurred this afternoon. I am more certain that at least one message
>from the afternoon is crystal clear.  That "These are Days."  These are
>days to stand up and demand an end to bombing and to sanctions.  These are
>days you'll remember.  These days are ours if we take them in the spirit
>of nonviolence and love that conquers even the strongest hate.
>
>Two weeks ago a doctor in Basra, after showing me infant corpses dead from
>both severe deformities, most likely from depleted uranium, and no blood
>bags, told me, with tears in his eyes from working an 18 hour day filled
>with hopelessness and despair, "Your government kills my people."  He is
>right, and the pressing question on my mind is "But can our people change
>our government?"
>
>This was a very easy action.  The SS wanted to know how I got in. I walked
>in the front door. I did not break the law.  I probably was somewhat rude,
>in the nature of the interruption, but I compare that to the millions of
>lives that have been interrupted or ended b/c of sanctions. Now is the
>time to push this issue and we need to use every avenue we can.  Gore and
>Bush need our vote - Not only should we NOT give it to them for the crimes
>that both are guilty of, but we SHOULD LET THEM KNOW WHY.  This is one
>way.  The people of Iraq are waiting...
>
>peace
>
>
>danny muller
>voices in the wilderness
>

Timmy, I await your argument. I like the broader approach of your 
suggestion, but you omitted another key aspect:  "Negotiate with Rutgers 
University, as a condition any city assistance with plans for expansion, new 
buildings, or new programs in the city...". This is how the people of New 
Brunswick will use their power to get what they need. I think we need to 
include the means and the ends. Paul

Post ID:399
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-05 18:13:25
Subject:Re: Platform Point
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@h...> 
wrote:
> Timmy, I await your argument. I like the broader approach of your 
> suggestion, but you omitted another key aspect:  "Negotiate with 
Rutgers 
> University, as a condition any city assistance with plans for 
expansion, new 
> buildings, or new programs in the city...". This is how the people 
of New 
> Brunswick will use their power to get what they need. I think we 
need to 
> include the means and the ends. Paul
 
Hey,

No, actually, my main point was that that part -- the part about 
Rutgers University -- should be, at least temporarily, taken out of 
the platform.  I wrote a message explaining this in detail a couple 
of weeks ago; if you can't find it, let me know.  I think I was full 
of coffee, and was feeling excessively logical -- every paragraph in 
it is numbered.  Ha.

It may simply be impossible for any municipal government, in short, 
to do the above.  Impossible in the way that the city of New 
Brunswick cannot, for example, ever aspire to send an army to annex 
Highland Park.  Not impossible in the sense of "not sufficiently 
pragmatic".

Yours,

Jeremy

councils, etc., to get what you want.'

of the sort.  Rutgers is a state university.  Not the 
university of "New Brunzwik". <snort>

Jim

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@h...>
wrote:
> I think what's important is that we state clearly that if the big
money 
> making institutions want to expand into our city, continue tax
abatements, 
> want to form partnerships with developers from outside, then
empower 
> education for the people of new brunzwik. I think it's okay to say
generally 
> 'the people have power, and now you have to go through the people's 
> councils, etc., to get what you want.'
>     Paul
> 
> 
>

http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:404
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-06 13:27:57
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Platform Point
Message:

You're not addressing how this suggestion is prohibited. Here's my case for 
including such general wording.

The city council has jurisdiction over some aspects of land use. The 
planning board has jurisdiction over other aspects. The corporations like 
Devco that masquerade as nonprofits do most of this development. They are in 
some ways tied to the wishes of the city government. We'll eventually have a 
full understanding of these relationships. And when we get in city council, 
we'll have some power to make legislation. Right now the city council has 
the power to do that, and they use it to the favor of corporate interests, 
etc. I think it's safe to say that the power of the council can be used to 
flip the script, so let's suggest that in our platform.

If a group wants to build in the city, they have to get city authorization 
in one way or another. That's negotiating power.

>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Platform Point
>Date: Thu, 06 Jul 2000 15:22:46 -0000
>
>But that is idealism.
>
>In reality, the City Council has no power to do anything
>of the sort.  Rutgers is a state university.  Not the
>university of "New Brunzwik". <snort>
>
>Jim

Post ID:405
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-06 14:08:05
Subject:Re: Platform Point
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@h...> 
wrote:
> You're not addressing how this suggestion is prohibited. Here's my 
case for 
> including such general wording.

Prohibiting what suggestion?  Can you show me how it 
is possible, with three City Council seats, to prohibit
Rutgers from building?
 
> The city council has jurisdiction over some aspects of land use.
The 

"some aspects of land use."  Which?

> planning board has jurisdiction over other aspects. The
corporations 

"other aspects"  Which?

like 
> Devco that masquerade as nonprofits do most of this development. 

"this development"  Which?

They are in 
> some ways tied to the wishes of the city government. We'll 

"in some ways tied to the wishes of the city government"  How?

eventually have a 
> full understanding of these relationships. And when we get in city 
council, 
> we'll have some power to make legislation. Right now the city 

"some power to make legislation"  What power?  What legislation?

council has 
> the power to do that, and they use it to the favor of corporate 
interests, 

Power to do what?

> etc. I think it's safe to say that the power of the council can be 
used to 
> flip the script, so let's suggest that in our platform.

How do you know that?

> 
> If a group wants to build in the city, they have to get city 
authorization 
> in one way or another. That's negotiating power.

Neither you nor anybody else has demonstrated to me that 
they know what this power is, who has it, and what control
City Council has over this.

I'm not just trying to be hard on you Paul.  This is
addressed to the entire campaign.

It seems that there is more rhetoric floating around these
parts than any specific, tactical plan for what happens
when we win.  We have a great platform, but it's very broad.
We will never win if we cannot demonstrate to people what 
exactly it is we want to do.  It's not enough to point out 
how they're wrong.  Lots of people know they're wrong.  But
they won't vote for People's Campaign by default.  We have
to give them a good reason.  This sort of rhetoric is not a 
good reason.

We are *not* going to win on slogans.  We are not going to
win with rhetoric.  We are not going to win with idealistic
notions of people's councils, people's struggle, people's that,
and people's the other thing.

We are going to get our asses *kicked* with that sort of
mentality.  If we pursue a policy of "Rutgers education for
all NB high school graduates," do you know what we look like?

Idiots.

Newsflash.  Rutgers is a state university.  They don't *have*
to build in New Brunswick.  They can build in Newark, Camden,
and even grand ol' Piscataway.  There's more open space in
Piscataway than there is between George Bush's ears.  Rutgers
won't give a flying fig what demands we make of them.  

C'mon already!  I hate to sound harsh, but people have got to
get serious about these things.  We're running a City Council
campaign.  We're not overthrowing the Czar.  We need facts,
not a whole lot of goddam impassioned revolutionary fluff.

Jim

Post ID:410
Sender:mike@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-06 21:39:05
Subject:Re: platform point - Louise, Paul - Why?
Message:

Louise, Paul,

Louise,
 I really have to ask, *why* don't you support the removal
of "anything"?  I must say, Jeremy has gone to the trouble to
post the details of his proposed amendments three times, once
in a message in excess of two pages.  You could have the courtesy
to respond with something other than "no."  I certainly agree with
the need for everyone to have a vote on the issue of changing
the platform, however lets not protect misinformation under the
guise of democracy.

Paul, 
 What factual information do you have that supports the 
assertion that presence of three city council members will 
be able to provide free Rutgers education to all New Brunswick
Graduates?  What in the world leads you to believe that Rutgers
would have any trouble "purchasing land" from the City of New
Brunswick regardless of who is on the city council ?  Considering
the revenue that is generated for the city of New Brunswick by the 
presence of Rutgers University, would it really be in the best 
interest of the City to thwart any attempted growth of the university?

What sort of information base do we have at our disposal to prove 
that the assertions made in the original draft of the platform can be 
achieved?  Do we know that this can be done?  What good is an
unattainable platform?  I would like to know that we have a clear plan
of attack in order to obtain these goals, otherwise we seem lofty
and foolish.

 I fear that we all suffer from a large lack of information.  I would
like to propose that 'Right To Know' release (at least) a single page
of information to the entire campaign on a weekly basis.  Some short 
informational primer that can be held at the office as well as 
available on-line.  I am pleased that there is a lot of emotional 
drive and passion about these issues, however passion alone will not 
win this.

Sincerely
- Michael

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:414
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 09:33:27
Subject:Announcement: one way to deal with the stress of running a campaign
Message:

I would like to invite all to a class in Reevaluation Counseling to be held at my house 218 Townsend this Wednesday July 12th at 7pm- 9:30pm.  This will be the first of several classes to be taught by a friend of mine, Lydia Simas.  Basically it is a form of peer counseling, based on a listening and cathartic process.  It can help people regain a sense of calmness and think better about themselves and others on the campaign.  It has been used by other political campaigns, and utilizing it in the campaign and in our lives can help improve our health, organization, and ultimately success.  The community of people that has developed largely voluntarily to spread this understanding of counseling also works actively toward the liberation of all humans from oppression through work on racism, sexism, agism, class oppression, religious oppression, etc etc etc. For a very watered down version, visit the website at www.rc.org.

Zofia

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:415
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 09:50:23
Subject:Why I think platform points are political stmts.
Message:

I think this whole big discussion boils down to two political lines: I'm 
saying that the platform and our calls as the campaign are designed to 
express the will of the people and to project their needs onto the political 
and economic systems in New Brunswick. Not every call can be realized right 
away. But there is an important purpose for those calls. We need to 
crystallize in people's minds what kind of future is possible, when people 
have more power. The call to cut a deal with local institutions is a 
political demand by the people. They know they're being exploited by 
powerful institutions and they respond by informing and endorsing our 
political calls.

The reality of current laws and power relationships may not allow for 
immediate imposition of our (the people's) demands. That's because the 
bourgeoisie and imperialist classes designed this system and continually 
contour it to their liking and needs. We know that their needs often run 
counter to the needs of the people. Class conscious folks that I've met on 
the street, etc., will acknowledge that the interests of J&J and other 
bourg-imperialist interests are not the interests of the people.

So, just as the ruling classes put out constant, hard driving lines which 
are often semi-legal or outright illegal: about how they want to privatize 
everything, tax you for everything, steal the public's money with corp. 
welfare, put all black and latino youth in prison, send the cops to take 
everyone's DNA, etc., etc. You get the idea-So do we need to put out our 
lines.

They shape the law and we have to deal with that assuming that we're bound 
to bourgeois notions of electoral politics, or we put out a political call 
for real power to the people and foreshadow future legal, political and 
legislative battles in the name of people's power.

I think we should scrutinize our platform points, but keep in mind that the 
campaign is about changing these relationships which are killing the people 
everyday. And I don't mean to say that we're going to accomplish them with 
three city council seats.


>From: mike@...
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com

Post ID:416

Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Re: Platform Point
Message:

Jim - First of all let the city explain to the people the limitations of the 
"democracy" we live in . We can and should make such demands. Secondly, 
according to the Right to Know, city council does have the ability to do 
such things.

Mike-, the reason I oppose the changes by Jeremy is not under the "guise of 
democracy." as you put it. Plain and simple, not everybody has access or 
utilizes this email. Therefore major changes to the platform cannot and 
should be made here, it is undemocratic. Jeremy is putting forth a position 
very different from what was voted upon at the convention and what he 
proposed at the last general meeting.
Louise

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:417
Sender:mike@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 12:10:22
Subject:Re: Why I think platform points are political stmts.
Message:

No way.  

This has nothing to do with differing "political lines."  I will 
agree, however that there is a difference in definition here; 
the definition of the platform.  I'm working from the assumption 
that the platform should be regarded as a list of things that we 
intend to do and provide for the people in New Brunswick - things 
we CAN and WILL do.  I do not see them as a list of "what kind of 
future is possible" -- at that rate we might as well be releasing 
fictional 
stories.  Our job is not that of a "teacher" to the 'enslaved masses 
of New Brunswick' that view point is not only out of line, it's 
insulting.

My concern is that in trying to realize some of these platform
points, we may find they are simply not possible. I hardly think we 
can win the people over with a platform that would be nice, "in 
theory."  
Shouldn't the platform contain what the candidates are
going to try to provide to the city, to their supporters, to the
people?  If we can't make good on our promises, we are lying.  If
we don't at least gauge the feasibility of these points, we are
opening ourselves up to let a lot of people down.

I'm working on this campaign because I see it as an effort to try
and improve the lives of people in New Brunswick.  A lot of people
have been screwed over and this does not have to happen.  I'm not
going to feel comfortable handing someone a list of promises that
we don't know if we can keep.  I would not feel comfortable taking
a person's vote under the same reasoning.  Most importantly, a person
will likely not cast their vote if they feel they will not get what
we are promising.

I am not out to bring social revolution to New Brunswick; I want to 
make life better for those who have been getting the short end 
of the stick.  I would like to see the "success" of  New Brunswick 
lead to better education for the children in New Brunswick, I'd like 
to see new businesses in New Brunswick equal new jobs for the 
resident's of New Brunswick.  I believe in the platform points, I 
believe they are good things.  I simply want to make sure 
we know what we can and can not do.

Am I out of line?
- Michael





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:418
Sender:mike@...

Message:

Louise,

  I did not intend to offend you, please excuse me if I did.
Again, I am asking the same question.  Perhaps I was unclear
before.

In what way do you feel that Jeremy's is "very different" than
the current platform point, or the point that he raised at the 
last general meeting?

I'm not trying to be nitpicky, but my intent was to get
your opinion on why this was a radical departure from what we
already have.

Thanks
- Michael
