-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:420
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 14:19:55
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Why I think platform points are political stmts.
Message:

Also,  

What is possible is defined by the political climate.  Provisions in the law suddenly surface in one circumstance that one might not have been aware of in another.  In NB we could easily within the realm of law call for a new Master Plan and Redevelopment Plan.  "Legal" precedents have been set in terms of community input/control opportunities for these, and we can search the country for such precedents.  Then we can create our own precedent for others to follow.  None of that is "illegal".  And if it were, we could lobby for new laws. Mount Laurel was a precedent set for states by NJ. Of course in the legislature it got mangled.  Lets just think of ourselves as the new precedent setters.

My experience for example with Heldrich is that I watching so carefully for the specific commonly travelled lines of reasoning and argument, writing a petition that demanded "concessions" I actually missed one boat that residents have called for - the line of not even destroying the hotel.  Two residents have expressed to me that based on historical grounds it should not be torn down, and many based on evictions.  So in fact other residents are more advanced than I and I am only holding back people in my concern for doing the reasonable or appropriate thing whatever that is.  I say lets focus on organizing, sharing info, supporting the creation of a sense of power in togetherness and developing fora where people can express their views and have an open debate - real democracy  - the new precedents and laws will come once people are mobilized.  It is actually helpful to set a direction that is not hampered by details that can quickly change depending on the circumstance.


Zofia  

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:421
Sender:Groove Meister <Groovemeister007@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 17:21:32
Subject:STAR LEDGER ARTICLE -- READ AND LEARN
Message:

Lifeless stream provokes a lawsuit 

07/07/00

By Alexander Lane
STAFF WRITER

Carlos Cortez knows he isn't supposed to play in the
stream near his New Brunswick home. But he does, along
with packs of other kids who live in the Hamilton
Gardens apartment complex, a collection of low
buildings just feet from the Mile Run Brook. 


When he comes home with muddy shoes, he gets a stern
lecture from his mother, who worries about the craggy
rocks and the tough older kids that hang out there. 


But according to recent tests, more sinister,
invisible dangers lurk in the stream: Lead. Arsenic.
Cadmium. Camphor. PCBs. 


''I've never seen any fish in there," Carlos, 11,
said. "Never." 


Rhodia Inc., a small chemical company upstream from
Carlos' neighborhood, has been polluting the brook for
decades, state environmental officials say. 


Fourteen years ago, a state judge ordered Rhodia to
stop the pollution and clean its land, with monitoring
by the state Department of Environmental Protection. 


On Wednesday, an environmental group sued both Rhodia
and the DEP, saying they allowed the pollution to
continue. 


With the lawsuit looming two weeks ago, the DEP sent a
20-page letter to Rhodia calling it "nonresponsive"
and "administratively deficient" in cleaning up. 


Mile Run Brook cuts through Rhodia's property, and the
stream bank comes right up against Building 11, where
a fragrance ingredient is made. 


A shiny black ooze seeps out from under Building 11
and into the stream, according to the DEP letter, and
groundwater infused with chemicals also bleeds into
the brook. 


The stream water has a bright sheen and the sweet
stench of the fragrance ingredient ethyl vanillin. The
bottom is black. The water cannot support life of any
kind -- not aquatic insect life, much less fish. 


''The contamination from this area has remained
relatively uncontrolled since the discharge was first
observed over 14 years prior," wrote Stephen Maybury,
chief of the DEP's Bureau of Environmental Evaluation,
in the June 22 letter. 


Maybury compared the texture of the seeping product to
molasses. 


''The material going into the stream should not be
going into the stream at this point," he said. 


Rhodia's 37 employees manufacture coumarin, an
ingredient that lends a pleasant scent to nearly every
detergent on the market. 


According to the DEP, the property has suffered
extensively under the French company. A state site
inspection report, written in 1991, documented a long
list of environmental mishaps at Rhodia. 


The report said the company illegally stored toxic
waste in basements in 1981. A few months later, a
worker complained of a rash after handling radioactive
vegetables and soil. A long list of sewer breaks,
shoddy storage, oily seeps, errant drums and other
violations continues past 1986. 


In 1989, 10 to 15 gallons of process water and ethyl
vanillin flowed into the Mile Run Brook after a sewer
line froze, according to the 1991 report. The potent
fragrance ingredient is detectable even in a mix of
one part per billion. 


Plant manager Michael Emery said the company has spent
more than $7 million on environmental improvements
since 1986. Rhodia also has begun removing a tanker of
tainted groundwater every six weeks at a cost of
$10,000 each time, Emery said. 


The DEP letter was in response to a thick document
Rhodia submitted to the state, the company's clean- up
plan. The "Remedial Action Workplan" was to be the
first step in the last stage of a long-term cleanup. 


But the state found shortcomings with the plan.
Officials said Rhodia failed to submit a study of the
brook's ecology and failed to stop the pollution from
Building 11, which is the 19-acre plant's only
operational building. 


Rhodia last had a state-certified lab test the soil
and groundwater on their property in July 1998. The
lab detected toluene, a compound that can cause
leukemia, at 2,400 parts per billion. The state's
limit is 1,000. Cumene was detected at 520 parts per
billion. The maximum limit is 300. 


Nitrobenzene, a cancer-causing chemical that is easily
absorbed into the skin and can cause nausea, headache,
irritability, dizziness, weakness, and drowsiness, was
detected at 2,300 parts per billion. The legal maximum
is 10 parts per billion. 


The chemical camphor was detected at 740,000 parts per
billion. The state has not set a maximum level for the
rare contaminant, but it is known to cause headache,
fainting, arrhythmia, convulsions and tumors. 


Some tests have shown that camphor is the main
ingredient in the black seep. Other tests point to
toluene. Rhodia has not had it tested it enough, the
state said, nor has the company adequately tested the
soil and water in the Mile Run thus far. 


Fed up with the pace of the clean-up, the Edison
Wetlands Association -- the group that sued the state
and Rhodia -- hired the Citizens Environmental
Laboratory of Cambridge, Mass., and South Mall
Analytical Labs of Plainview, N.Y. to test the brook.
They say they found levels of arsenic, cadmium, lead
and PCBs that exceed state maximums. 


The stream cuts through one of the few remaining
industrial areas of New Brunswick. Emery contends that
much of the contamination for which Rhodia is being
blamed comes from years past. 


The Rhodia property was once New Brunswick's municipal
landfill. Rhone Poulenc bought it in 1919. Du Pont
bought it in the 1930s, then sold it back to Rhone
Poulenc in 1955. 


Stopping the contaminated groundwater seepage and
black gunk from oozing out of Building 11 and into the
stream is compounded by the building's proximity to
the stream, Emery said. 


''It's very difficult when it comes to finding a
solution without cutting the heart out of the
company," he said. "My job is to make sure there's a
plant here when my people retire." 


Rhodia now has 30 days to adjust its cleanup plan and
resubmit it to the state. 


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached
at alane@... or at (732) 634-1236. 


--- Zofia Nowakowski <znowakowski@...>
wrote:
> Also,  
> 
> What is possible is defined by the political
> climate.  Provisions in the law suddenly surface in
> one circumstance that one might not have been aware
> of in another.  In NB we could easily within the
> realm of law call for a new Master Plan and
> Redevelopment Plan.  "Legal" precedents have been
> set in terms of community input/control
> opportunities for these, and we can search the
> country for such precedents.  Then we can create our
> own precedent for others to follow.  None of that is
> "illegal".  And if it were, we could lobby for new
> laws. Mount Laurel was a precedent set for states by
> NJ. Of course in the legislature it got mangled. 
> Lets just think of ourselves as the new precedent
> setters.
> 
> My experience for example with Heldrich is that I
> watching so carefully for the specific commonly
> travelled lines of reasoning and argument, writing a
> petition that demanded "concessions" I actually
> missed one boat that residents have called for - the
> line of not even destroying the hotel.  Two
> residents have expressed to me that based on
> historical grounds it should not be torn down, and
> many based on evictions.  So in fact other residents
> are more advanced than I and I am only holding back
> people in my concern for doing the reasonable or
> appropriate thing whatever that is.  I say lets
> focus on organizing, sharing info, supporting the
> creation of a sense of power in togetherness and
> developing fora where people can express their views
> and have an open debate - real democracy  - the new
> precedents and laws will come once people are
> mobilized.  It is actually helpful to set a
> direction that is not hampered by details that can
> quickly change depending on the circumstance.
> 
> 
> Zofia  
> 
> Zofia Nowakowski
> Fiscal Policy Institute
> 218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
> New York, NY 10018
> Tel: 212.278.0878
> Fax:212.730.1405
>

limitations of the 
> "democracy" we live in . We can and should make such demands. 

That's good.  Tell that to your consistuency.  Tell them
your plan to help them is to stamp your feet and scream that
we should live in a better world.

Really intelligent.

Secondly, 
> according to the Right to Know, city council does have the ability 
to do 
> such things.

"Such things?"  What?  The City Council is going to seize
land from Rutgers?  

Or even better, we'll force them to admit everybody from New
Brunswick that wants to go.  As if the academic standards 
at Rutgers haven't fallen enough. 

I'm sorry.  Not everybody in New Brunswick *deserves* to go to
Rutgers.  The demand that everybody who graduates New Brunswick
High School go to Rutgers is completely ridiculous.  

> 
> Mike-, the reason I oppose the changes by Jeremy is not under 
the "guise of 
> democracy." as you put it. Plain and simple, not everybody has 
access or 
> utilizes this email. Therefore major changes to the platform cannot 
and 
> should be made here, it is undemocratic. Jeremy is putting forth a 
position 
> very different from what was voted upon at the convention and what 
he 
> proposed at the last general meeting.

I agree.  People should vote for or against it at the next
General Meeting.

Jim

Post ID:423
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-07 18:39:39
Subject:Re: Why I think platform points are political stmts.
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Zofia Nowakowski" 
<znowakowski@u...> wrote:

Zofia, this is almost beside the point (although I support
defending the Monument Park Hotel).

Our platform calls for admission of all New Brunswick
High School graduates to Rutgers, in exchange for support
from the Council in all development.

Are you comfortable bringing this to people?  Are you 
comfortable showing this to Rutgers students, whose
classes are already overpopulated?  Are you comfortable
showing this to Rutgers professors, who are already sick
of the low academic standards to make room for football
players?  For that matter, are you comfortable making this
promise to people when we don't know if we can keep it?

I have to answer "nay" to all of the above.

I support Jeremy's more reasonable amendment.

Jim


> Also,  
> 
> What is possible is defined by the political climate.  Provisions 
in the law suddenly surface in one circumstance that one might not 
have been aware of in another.  In NB we could easily within the 
realm of law call for a new Master Plan and Redevelopment 
Plan.  "Legal" precedents have been set in terms of community 
input/control opportunities for these, and we can search the country 
for such precedents.  Then we can create our own precedent for others 
to follow.  None of that is "illegal".  And if it were, we could 
lobby for new laws. Mount Laurel was a precedent set for states by 
NJ. Of course in the legislature it got mangled.  Lets just think of 
ourselves as the new precedent setters.
> 
> My experience for example with Heldrich is that I watching so 
carefully for the specific commonly travelled lines of reasoning and 
argument, writing a petition that demanded "concessions" I actually 
missed one boat that residents have called for - the line of not even 
destroying the hotel.  Two residents have expressed to me that based 
on historical grounds it should not be torn down, and many based on 
evictions.  So in fact other residents are more advanced than I and I 
am only holding back people in my concern for doing the reasonable or 
appropriate thing whatever that is.  I say lets focus on organizing, 
sharing info, supporting the creation of a sense of power in 
togetherness and developing fora where people can express their views 
and have an open debate - real democracy  - the new precedents and 
laws will come once people are mobilized.  It is actually helpful to 
set a direction that is not hampered by details that can quickly 
change depending on the circumstance.
> 
> 
> Zofia  
> 
> Zofia Nowakowski
> Fiscal Policy Institute
> 218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
> New York, NY 10018
> Tel: 212.278.0878
> Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:424
Sender:citruswar@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-08 02:51:49
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] STAR LEDGER ARTICLE -- READ AND LEARN
Message:

Zofia, living next to a brook that has been carrying the run off of these 
contaminents has made me very aware. The water is undrinkable and there are 
times that I even question bathing in it let alone taking a shower. I put 
water in my fridge to drink( after boiling it thinking that would make it 
drinkable) but when I drank it, it had a very strong almost mettalic taste 
and smell. I buy my drinking water now, but I have been plagued by skin 
rashes since I've lived here, 5years. Paul and Tom turned me onto an 
organization that I can go to and possibly get my water tested to find out 
what I'm dealing with. I really appreciate your info.                         
                                                                              
                                                          Janice

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:426
Sender:Louise Ammentorp <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-09 16:25:37
Subject:Our Program
Message:

At the last General meeting Jeremy suggested that everyone graduateing from
NewBrunswick high school may not want to go to Rutgers.  Perhaps they would prefer a
vocational training or artistic training or county college or whatever.  Everyone
agreed that this was a good point and should be taken into consideration and raised
again.  What has come back is a complete departure from the original platform and from
what was stated at the last general meeting. The propoal is to make the platfrom
"reasonable", "realistic", "acceptable" etc.
Perhaps our platform should have stated more clearly we want "open admissons" at
Rutgers for a start, like they had at CUNY before Ghouliani gutted that with similar
arguements to the ones we are hearing against our current paltform point.  If we
remember the attacks on CUNY's "remedial" programs (which are also currently available
at Rurtgers, Yale, Harvard etc. in Fact Bush 2 and his Daddy's boy Quale spent much
time in these programs).  The question of a education at an IVY League school is not
one of  inttelctual  question but of  financial ability.  The point of admitting New
Brunswick high school graduates at Rutgers would address that fact head on.  I
strongly disagree that academic standars at Rutgers would decrease if poor people were
allowed to attended in fact quite the opposite a healthy dose of reality is just what
is needed at Rutgers.

Finally there is an emerging tendency in our campaign that believes it is more
important for us to know how everything works in the city before we can organize the
people.  That is policy is more important than organizing the people.  But the point
of our campaign is to empower the people.  (the people are students, workers,
proffesionals, small business people, small land lords as oppossed to the big monopoly
capitalists and their goons and stooges). Our slogan is not "Putting policy first".
Our program is not a laundry list of promises.  It is a fighting strategy, without the
mobilization and organization of the people of New Brunswick none of it is possible.
Our Campaign and our candiadtes must be  tools and weapons that the people must weild
to sieze power and enact policy that they themselves determine.  Our purpose as
camapign organizers is to mobilize, organize and guide the people towards the goal of
seizing power. Policy is important but it can not be determined by a small group in a
back room, or maybe it can be... but that is the method of the democatic party
machine.  Our platform is not unrealistic, it was determined by 1000 surveys and voted
on by a 150 people, that is its reality and reasonableness .  If current laws,
ideologies, institutions, and even the economic system stand in the way of enacting
the program than the people will determine how those obtacles need to be transformed
or eliminated. I think that our campaign stands for higher education for all; if there
is something in the way of that I think our campaign should help people to remove the
obstacle. Our campaign should definetly not play the role of explaining why their
aspiations are unrealistic.  We are not a shield for the status quo our campaign must
be the sword of the people.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:429
Sender:"Michael Long" <mike@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-10 02:47:24
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Our Program
Message:

Keith,

> At the last General meeting Jeremy suggested that everyone graduateing
from
> NewBrunswick high school may not want to go to Rutgers.  Perhaps they
would prefer a
> vocational training or artistic training or county college or whatever.
Everyone
> agreed that this was a good point and should be taken into consideration
and raised
> again.  What has come back is a complete departure from the original
platform and from
> what was stated at the last general meeting. The propoal is to make the
platfrom
> "reasonable", "realistic", "acceptable" etc.

	First and foremost you really should define how Jeremy's point is a
"complete departure" from the original drafting.  Until you define that, I
will disregard your comment as a baseless assertion.  Also, what is the
point in
having 'reasonable' 'realistic' and 'acceptable' in quotes?  I think its
fairly clear
that (as adjectives) the words themselves are in no way negative.  Do
you find these words to be negative or you are implying that there is a
secret conspiracy afoot which is using these words as some sort of a
disguise  ?
This post reads as though you are warning against some sort of lurking evil
 -- what gives?

> Perhaps our platform should have stated more clearly we want "open
admissons" at
> Rutgers for a start, like they had at CUNY before Ghouliani gutted that
with similar
> arguements to the ones we are hearing against our current paltform point.
If we
> remember the attacks on CUNY's "remedial" programs (which are also
currently available
> at Rurtgers, Yale, Harvard etc. in Fact Bush 2 and his Daddy's boy Quale
spent much
> time in these programs).  The question of a education at an IVY League
school is not
> one of  inttelctual  question but of  financial ability.  The point of
admitting New
> Brunswick high school graduates at Rutgers would address that fact head
on.  I
> strongly disagree that academic standars at Rutgers would decrease if poor
people were
> allowed to attended in fact quite the opposite a healthy dose of reality
is just what
> is needed at Rutgers.

Rutgers is not an Ivy league school, and I assure you MANY wealthy students
are
declined yearly.

If you open the doors to a university based on a factor other than a
measurement of
intellectual performance (ie: geographical location) you are guaranteed to
lower the
average of academic standards.  This is easily proven to anyone who attended
high school
(an educational facility in which the students are admitted by location).
What we find
in the average high school is usually several programs of varied difficulty,
for students
of varied "talent/achievement" levels (remedial, standard, honors, etc).
Saying you do not believe in this is preposterous and somewhat frightening.

> Finally there is an emerging tendency in our campaign that believes it is
more
> important for us to know how everything works in the city before we can
organize the
> people.  That is policy is more important than organizing the people.  But
the point
> of our campaign is to empower the people.  (the people are students,
workers,

Who said knowing "everything" -- I said knowing something about the promises
we are
making.   We should ensure that we can provide what we claim before we
organize, lest we
run the risk of organizing around something we may not be able to achieve.
Do you really
find this notion to be absurd?

How can you empower people if you are not clear on what you can do for them,
what can really be achieved?  What are we organizing around if we are not
armed
with this knowledge?  What power can we give to people without that?

> proffesionals, small business people, small land lords as oppossed to the
big monopoly
> capitalists and their goons and stooges). Our slogan is not "Putting
policy first".

Who the hell said anything about putting policy first?

> Our program is not a laundry list of promises.  It is a fighting strategy,
without the
> mobilization and organization of the people of New Brunswick none of it is
possible.

Keith, I regard a promise as a guarantee to do something.  I maintain that
the program is
a list of promises.  Yes people need to be organized, yes people need to be
mobilized, but
the program is in no way a strategy; a strategy is a guideline that leads to
an end.  The
platform as it is written today is simply the end, with the occasional vague
notion
of achieving some goal.

> Our Campaign and our candiadtes must be  tools and weapons that the people
must weild
> to sieze power and enact policy that they themselves determine.  Our
purpose as
> camapign organizers is to mobilize, organize and guide the people towards
the goal of
> seizing power.

More accurately, the campaign is the glue between the disconnected people of
New Brunswick,
it intends to provide the unity from which the power is derived.  In my
mind, as that glue,
we must not only encourage working together and "mobilization" however arm
people with
information.  Information not only about corruptions in the existing
government, but also
what they can do to change things, to overcome them.  It is very easy to
point a finger
and say something is not working.  It's hard to derive a solution.

Saying you are going to "mobilize" someone is about as meaningful as a
million other
buzzwords that exist in society today.  Mobilize them to do what?  To take
back their
rights?  What does that mean?  A lot of shallow words with very little
meaning.

> Policy is important but it can not be determined by a small group in a
> back room, or maybe it can be... but that is the method of the democatic
party
> machine.

What does this mean?

> Our platform is not unrealistic, it was determined by 1000 surveys and
voted
> on by a 150 people, that is its reality and reasonableness .

The platform points are good.  Also after speaking with Brian and Frank for
some
time the other night, I have a much stronger sense that many things on the
platform
can and will be achieved.   Determination by surveys or votes, however, does
not
guarantee 'reasonableness'.

> If current laws, ideologies, institutions, and even the economic system
stand in the
> way of enacting the program than the people will determine how those
obtacles need to
> be transformed or eliminated.

Again, I think it's OUR job to understand what changes/transformations need
to be made,
so we can give this information to the people.  I think many of the full
time activists
on-board have a much better shot at researching this information than
someone who works
2 jobs a day to put food on the table, don't you?

> I think that our campaign stands for higher education for all; if there
> is something in the way of that I think our campaign should help people to
remove the
> obstacle. Our campaign should definetly not play the role of explaining
why their
> aspiations are unrealistic.  We are not a shield for the status quo our
campaign must
> be the sword of the people.

For all the passion in this campaign, we need twice as much FACT.  I am glad
that people
believe in this, however our "mission" is not simply to rile people up, it's
to give them
information they could not have.  To really "arm" people, with their rights.
We should
not simply tell people things are bad, we must tell them how they can help
make it right.
Collecting adjectives such as "organization" or "mobilization" is not good
enough.  We need
to tell people (or at least know) what we will do once we have achieved
organization and
mobilization.

Very tired . . .
- Michael

wrote:
>

graduateing from
> NewBrunswick high school may not want to go to Rutgers.  Perhaps
they would prefer a

whatever.  Everyone
> agreed that this was a good point and should be taken into
consideration and raised
> again.  What has come back is a complete departure from the original
platform and from
> what was stated at the last general meeting. The propoal is to make
the platfrom
> "reasonable", "realistic", "acceptable" etc.

Let the record show that one of "the people's" candidates
is against proposals that are "reasonable," "realistic,"
and "acceptable."  Shall I mail this one to the Home News
or the Star Ledger first?

> Perhaps our platform should have stated more clearly we want "open
admissons" at

What do you mean by "open admissions?"

> Rutgers for a start, like they had at CUNY before Ghouliani gutted
that with similar
> arguements to the ones we are hearing against our current paltform
point.  If we
> remember the attacks on CUNY's "remedial" programs (which are also
currently available

Quale spent much

of admitting New

head on.  I
> strongly disagree that academic standars at Rutgers would decrease
if poor people were
> allowed to attended in fact quite the opposite a healthy dose of
reality is just what
> is needed at Rutgers.

Evidentally the only person who needs a healthy dose of
reality is you, Keith.

It stands to reason (by all the laws of logic) that if you admit
students based upon locality instead of merit that your standards
*must* decrease.  Unless you believe that people are necessarily
more intelligent by virtue of being poor.

Again, in the interests of gaining the support of Rutgers students,
Rutgers faculty, and, most importantly, the residents of the city
of New Brunswick, we should call for improved access to higher
education -- be it the University or technical training -- and
remove all bars to it based upon financial level.

> 
> Finally there is an emerging tendency in our campaign that believes
it is more
> important for us to know how everything works in the city before we
can organize the
> people.  That is policy is more important than organizing the
people.  But the point
> of our campaign is to empower the people.  (the people are students,
workers,
> proffesionals, small business people, small land lords as oppossed
to the big monopoly
> capitalists and their goons and stooges). Our slogan is not "Putting
policy first".

strategy, without the
> mobilization and organization of the people of New Brunswick none of
it is possible.

current laws,

I'll be so kind as to *not* embarrass you by responding to this
burst of emotional rhetoric with the cold impassiveness of reason
and reality.  Mike did a good enough job -- I agree with what he said.

Unfortunately, your opponents -- Cook, Recine, and Schrum --
will not do the same in a debate.  I'd suggest a change of
attitude between now and then.

Jim

Post ID:432
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-10 11:57:16
Subject:Residents wonder: Where can we go?
Message:


Residents wonder: Where can we go?

Published in the Home News Tribune 7/09/00

By JAKE STUIVER
STAFF WRITER

Once, it was a jewel of downtown New Brunswick.

Gov. Morgan F. Larson was its first guest in 1929, and the top-floor 
penthouse of the building originally known as The Woodrow Wilson Hotel held 
the city's most swinging parties and prestigious events.

Now, human corpses, stairwell feces, rotting food, 3-month-old beer empties, 
rats and mice are the main attractions at the Monument Park Hotel. That, and 
a group of residents teetering on homelessness.

After numerous highs and lows and changes in name and ownership over the 
past 70 years, the eight-story building at 10 Livingston Ave. is a few 
months away from becoming rubble.

Its new owner, the New Brunswick Development Corp., wants to make way for 
the 15-story Heldrich Plaza hotel and conference center that would cover the 
entire block.

The problem is, the hotel isn't exactly a hotel anymore. That is, its 
patrons usually don't check out the next day. Some of them haven't checked 
out for more than 10 years.

Many of the 50 or 60 residents and families still living at the hotel are 
there because of the relatively low living costs (usually about $800 a month 
and no utility expenses) and the fact that they were placed there by social 
services.

Add that to the 245-unit housing project down the street also slated for 
demolition by year's end for another redevelopment plan, and the city's 
poorest residents are all scrambling to find new places to live.

DevCo acquired the hotel for $2.7 million through bankruptcy court May 1 
after its prior owner, Donald Cresitello of Morristown-based Tello 
Enterprises, failed to restore the business to its early glory and ran into 
financial problems.

Within a week, a foul stench led the new owners to a dead body that had 
allegedly been sitting in one of the rooms since at least a few days prior 
to the property transfer. Another tenant's corpse turned up a few weeks 
later in a bizarre incident with a prostitute.

Though Cresitello denies it, representatives of DevCo and the firm hired to 
manage the site until demolition claim he pulled out all the phone wires, 
and they invested in restoring service to tenants.

While many residents are looking for new homes, they're grumbling that as 
long as they pay rent at the hotel, they're entitled to have somebody clean 
up the hallways and stairwells, which are full of trash and, in some places, 
human waste.

Until last week, when reporters began inquiring about the hotel's condition, 
the bar and basement were covered in food and glass empties from a party 
residents said the former managers had before they cleared out in May.

Some of the residents, including fifth-floor tenant Glenda Reaves, said they 
feel like the owners are trying to give them incentives to leave quickly.

"That is an absurd out-and-out lie," said Mitch Broder of One-Zero Hotel 
Management and Raritan Property Management, the firm DevCo hired to run the 
building. "To the contrary, we've bent over backward to be as accommodating 
as we can . . . to respond to any requests. We've turned on phones for 
people that we know are imminently moving, at huge expense for us. We have a 
full-time cleaning person cleaning the building. We have an exterminator. 
We've upgraded fire and electrical systems."

The messes in the halls and stairwells, Broder said, should have been 
brought to his attention instead of to the press.

New Jersey hotels face inspection, overseen by the state Department of 
Community Affairs, every five years. As long as the building is still 
standing and operational, it's subject to health and fire standards, DCA 
spokesman John Patella said.

The Monument Park Hotel's demolition is targeted for October. Its next 
inspection is due in September.


Moving the poor
Residents in the nearby New Brunswick Homes public housing are slowly 
getting out.

Some are finding affordable housing in the area. Others are hoping the city 
keeps promises for spots in the new low-income units planned for the site 
and other locations downtown.

Being public-housing tenants, however, can mean expedited Section 8 vouchers 
and other assistance that the hotel tenants won't get.

There's nothing Middlesex County can offer the tenants other than its 
standard homeless services such as rental assistance, said county Freeholder 
Jane Brady, chair of the Human Services Committee.

The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development focuses on family 
units, but there's also a need for what's known as single-room occupancy, 
she said.

"The problem is that there is just nothing out there for these people," she 
said. "They are looking for very low-income places to
live, and there just isn't any in this county. It is very disturbing that we 
are losing what was our last remaining single-room-occupancy unit."

The city plans to build low-income units at George Street and Remsen Avenue 
and in the soon-to-be-replaced Lord Stirling School, but those would go to 
Homes residents first, Mayor Jim Cahill said. Anything left after all the 
Homes residents are moved could go to former hotel residents if they 
qualify, he said.

Issues such as transportation, proximity to work and social services make it 
desirable for the residents to stay in the city, but most options would be 
better than living at the hotel, the mayor said.

"The hotel has not been well run, it has not been well managed," he said, 
adding many people have been moving out on their own. "As these numbers 
dwindle, it becomes easier to focus on the remaining residents."

Residents are organizing to learn and demand their rights.

A new group in the city called Advocates to Empower the Poor, headed by the 
formerly homeless Victor Luna, has been working to rally tenants and get 
them legal counseling.

A few hotel residents, such as Debra Key, have taken matters into their own 
hands by holding tenant meetings and consulting with Middlesex County Legal 
Services Corp.

Jose Abreu, a staff attorney with Legal Services' housing unit who's been 
working closely with tenants at the hotel, said he's encouraging them to 
challenge the notices to move out.

The notices were issued in May with July 31 deadlines, but that might not be 
adequate, Abreu said. He said he considers DevCo a private entity that must 
provide 18 months' notice.

Even if a judge deems DevCo a government agency, which needs to give only 
three months' notice, the letters contain no language about the type of 
mandatory relocation assistance the owner will provide, he said.

The residents don't have money to put down for moving costs and security 
deposits, and they're entitled to aid from the landlord
casting them out, he said.

The management should also offer help finding new homes, considering the 
low-rent housing market is so saturated with Homes and hotel residents 
pouring out simultaneously, he said.

Residents have been getting varying amounts of money as part of their 
agreements to leave.

"The only thing they've offered us is moving assistance," Key said. "Where 
are we going to move to? They're just trying to slide us up under the door. 
We're just asking for what's right, and they're trying to find every way 
around it."

Once a Palace
When the New Brunswick Hotel Corp. opened the Woodrow Wilson in 1929, one 
newspaper headline read "New Brunswick Crowns with Laurel its $850,000 
Hostelry."

The opening ceremony guest list included U.S. senators and congressmen, 
state officials and Rutgers University President John
M. Thomas.

Its suites, which include a bedroom, kitchenette and main area not much 
bigger than the bathroom, were once touted as the latest in comfort.

Its history is long and winding, but two things are clear: In 1940, it 
underwent the first of many name changes, to the Roger Smith Hotel; Sometime 
in the 1970s, the hotel began losing clientele, part of a citywide 
recession.

Cresitello said he bought the building in 1986 after it had been closed for 
several years, possibly because of problems with the city.

He said he invested about $7.5 million in renovations and reopened it as a 
Days Inn in 1988. He said there were problems with the Days Inn company, and 
in the early '90s he converted to a Howard Johnson's, soon to become the 
Monument Park Hotel.

"At that point, we took in whatever customers we could take," he said. "Some 
were long-term, some were welfare."

Much of the city's revitalization was supposed to happen 10 years ago, and 
the delay hurt the hotel industry, Cresitello said.

"We just figured the town wasn't ready for us," he said. "We got caught in 
the stall. We were never fully able to recover from it."

Now that redevelopment's day has come, the main redeveloper sees 
Cresitello's failure as DevCo's gold mine.

DevCo wants to raze the entire block between Livingston Avenue and New 
Street to build the Heldrich Center, which will also house a Rutgers 
work-force development school and a huge parking garage.

About 75 percent of the block is on the way to DevCo control, but most of it 
needs to go down before the hotel to make room for the collapse of the 
taller building, DevCo President Chris Paladino said.

"Getting the hotel was the cornerstone of the acquisition," Paladino said. 
"Without that, we would not have been able to move forward."

Paladino doesn't expect everybody to be out of the hotel until September, 
and he said DevCo is doing what it can to help find housing.

He noted, however, that it's still a hotel, not an apartment building, and 
that its rates aren't exactly poverty-level.

"At $800 a month, people are not homeless," he said. "$800 is not an 
insignificant amount of money."

He also noted Heldrich will create 500 jobs, plus another 3,000 during 
construction, and will provide training programs to employ people from the 
area.

Ultimately, DevCo is hoping to restore the block's luster.

On the inside
That doesn't mean much to the Lopez family, having lived on the hotel's 
fourth floor for the past eight years.

Ceasar Lopez, 26, drives to work at USA Detergents in North Brunswick but 
stays at the hotel because his 1-year-old son, Ceasar Jr., has Scimitas 
syndrome and has to see five doctors a month at city hospitals.

His wife, Anna Ramirez, 27, sits by Ceasar Jr. most of the time to make sure 
his ventilator unit, which takes up one-third of their tiny living room, 
stays operational.

The couple would love to have a bigger place but can't find one they can 
afford that's close enough to the hospitals.

When the notice to vacate arrived in May, Lopez was floored.

"It got everybody crazy," he said. "Nobody was expecting that."

Not everybody is as reluctant to leave as Lopez.

For Glenda Reaves, 47, of the fifth floor, the push out the door marks the 
end of a long, horrible nightmare at Monument Park.

A long-neglected ceiling leak has left her with mice, exposed asbestos and 
permanently mangled hands.

Condensation from the air conditioner upstairs ate through the ceiling 
panels right above the center of her main room, and for the  past two 
summers she's had her floor constantly covered in towels and bowls.

Once, while she was hanging towels out the bathroom window to dry, the loose 
frame slammed down on her hands and left her fingers twisted. She said she's 
suing the former owner.

Reaves said Advocates to Empower the Poor found her a real-estate company 
that got her into a Hampton Club residence subsidized by her social-services 
payments, and she's moving there next week, although the hotel's new 
management has been letting her use a seventh-floor room in the meantime.

Maybe at her new home, she hopes, she won't have to sleep on a cot mattress 
on the floor because there'll be room for both her and her 15-year-old 
daughter to have separate beds.

"I'm not a dirty person," she said, gesturing toward her makeshift bedroom 
by the towel pile. "But right now, living for the next day. It's all I can 
do. I don't want to live like this ever again."


from the Home News Tribune
Published: July 9, 2000
Copyright 1997-2000 IN Jersey.


________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:433
Sender:"Nicole Adler" <nicoleadler@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-10 14:34:53
Subject:Let's all be "reasonable" shall we?
Message:

Jeremy raises excellent points indeed.  He also did it in a way that was 
professional and with tact.  I think we could all learn a thing or two.  
First, Keith, people in New Brunswick who filled out the 1000 surveys (I 
don't have a copy of the survey--but I think I'm not mistaken) sited that 
education and the accessibilty of higher education was among one of the most 
important issues in NB, they didn't say that they wanted or thought that 
every high school graduate in NB should be accepted into Rutgers.  This 
platform point was the campaign's way of accomodating for what we regard as 
an important issue.  Also, if we are not to be policy wonks (in X's words) 
than we must be flexible in our platform.  Not to the extent that we will 
abandon our belief that the people of NB should have the power of running 
the city, but in the way in which we pursue the important issues that people 
have informed us about (education, police brutality etc.)  There are many 
angles that we have not looked at yet.

For example, not only is it unreasonable to say that a state university 
should accept students from only one of the towns that houses its many 
campauses, not only is it shortsighted to believe that all NB high school 
students even WANT to go to college, but let's be honest--is going to 
college the end all be all of having a better life and education?  Of course 
not.  I would be happier saying that the city should give heavy subsidies to 
students from NB to go to college--and for god's sake!  let's concentrate on 
giving these public high school students some resources while they're in 
high school still.  Let's concentrate on giving them a true education by 
treating our teachers fairly and giving them the resources to prepare these 
kids for life and if they so choose for the higher education of their 
choosing.  College nothing...  it'll only get you so far.

I think there has been a great deal of word and idea-bending in this debate. 
  It's senseless.  For example, I highly doubt that Mike and Jim believe 
that low income families will bring down the educational standards of 
Rutgers.  (Although, Mike and Jim--I think you could both relax a bit with 
the whole educational standards argument--money determines a school's 
rankings not the students).  In closing, I will repeat myself, not only do 
we need to organize and outreach to everyone we can--but we must continually 
develop ourselves and organize eachother within the campaign.  I think we 
should discuss this platform point at the next general meeting.

Yours,
Nikki "my dog's ain't with it" Adler ;-)
________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:434
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-10 15:14:24
Subject:Hello
Message:

One thought I had to reconcile some of the issues we are discussing is,

1. As a platform identify a general final goal - ex - jobs with a living wage for all NB residents - and then indicate specific concrete things that we would consider doing as an initial idea of a step toward that goal.  I think both sorts of goals are important.  Im not sure whether now is the time to make any actual promises regarding specific steps - we need more citizen participation before taking a particular course.

2. Also maybe we can set up an info library at the office with copies of all sorts of information and documents and make it available to residents to copy.  Any process steps to improve info distribution and eliminate hoarding of info/ info bottlenecks which I admit as RTK I have been reponsible for in part. 


Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:435
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-10 17:51:08
Subject:Our Program
Message:

[quote]
At the last General meeting Jeremy suggested that everyone 
graduateing from NewBrunswick high school may not want to go to 
Rutgers.  Perhaps they would prefer a vocational training or artistic 
training or county college or whatever.  Everyone agreed that this 
was a good point and should be taken into consideration and raised 
again.  What has come back is a complete departure from the original 
platform and from what was stated at the last general meeting. The 
propoal is to make the 
platfrom "reasonable", "realistic", "acceptable" etc. 
[unquote]

Well, first of all, let's just establish that no modifications of the 
platform are about to take place until voted upon at the next General 
Meeting.  So nobody is claiming that what I tried to express thereby 
gave legitimacy to a rewrite of that platform point without a binding 
vote.  Perhaps General Meetings are too infrequent?

Otherwise, I don't see on what basis you can sensibly protest -- your 
tone is certainly one of protest -- that "What has come back is a 
complete departure from the original platform".  For all that has 
taken place is informal discussion, and the submission (solely to the 
mailing list) of a very tentative replacement for the Higher Ed point.
Everyone is indeed welcome to discuss these things further, here or 
elsewhere, and they will certainly be submitted for very active 
consideration at the General Meeting.  (Hopefully, the means will 
soon exist in the office on Redmond for people who don't have 
computers to access this list.)    
 
I apologize if I was not terribly clear -- I was not -- at the last 
meeting, but I most certainly meant that the whole point, 
including "negotiating with Rutgers" should be called into question.

[quote]
... Perhaps our platform should have stated more clearly we 
want "open admissons" at Rutgers for a start, like they had at CUNY 
before Ghouliani gutted that with similar arguements to the ones we 
are hearing against our current paltform point.  If we remember the 
[..unquote]

This manner of arguing, though probably unintentional, comes across 
as a cheap demonizing tactic.  There are no Giuliani sympathizers, 
young Giulianis, or Giulianis-in-an-alternate-universe in this 
campaign, I am fairly certain.  

And more importantly, what is CUNY?  CUNY is the City University of 
New York.  Rutgers is the State University of New Jersey.  We're 
dealing with a qualitatively different kind of city government-local 
university relationship.

[quote]
attacks on CUNY's "remedial" programs (which are also currently 
available at Rurtgers, Yale, Harvard etc. in Fact Bush 2 and his 
Daddy's boy Quale spent much time in these programs).  The question 
of a education at an IVY League school is not one of  inttelctual  
question but of  financial ability.  The point of admitting New 
Brunswick high school graduates at Rutgers would address that fact 
head on.  I strongly disagree that academic standars at Rutgers would 
decrease if poor people were allowed to attended in fact quite the 
opposite a healthy dose of reality is just what is needed at Rutgers.
[unquote]

Yes, but in the final analysis, this can only be framed in terms of a 
statewide strategy.  A city council can be part of a statewide 
strategy of pushing for reform from below -- city councils can take 
activist roles to some extent at higher echelons of government.  But 
this activist role is clearly secondary.  (By "activist role", I'm 
not referring to 'Peoples' Councils' or whatever -- that's a 
completely different thing)

Oh, and let me repeat this :

Open admissions does not guarantee a high graduation rate at 
Rutgers.  Rutgers very frequently lowers its admissions standards for 
students from school districts like New Brunswick, Jersey City, 
Bridgeton, Camden, wherever.  But it only works so hard to guarantee 
that these students stay in Rutgers for four or five years and 
graduate successfully.  And, to be frank, Rutgers is a large and 
unsupportive environment no matter what you do to it.  Remedial 
programs can do alot for reading and math skills, for example, 
but 'cultural capital' is a bit more of a problem -- knowing how to 
be a student.  Indeed, that is one of the virtues of County Colleges 
as preparatory institutions for people who want to go on to a school 
like Rutgers.

[quote]
Finally there is an emerging tendency in our campaign that believes 
it is more important for us to know how everything works in the city 
before we can organize the people.  That is policy is more important 
than organizing the people.  But the point of our campaign is to 
empower the people.  (the people are students, workers, 
proffesionals, small business people, small land lords as oppossed to 
the big monopoly capitalists and their goons and stooges). Our slogan 
is not "Putting policy first". Our program is not a laundry list of 
promises.  It is a fighting strategy, without the mobilization and 
organization of the people of New Brunswick none of it is possible. 
Our Campaign and our candiadtes must be  tools and weapons that the 
people must weild to sieze power and enact policy that they 
themselves determine.  Our purpose as camapign organizers is to 
mobilize, organize and guide the people towards the goal of seizing 
power. Policy is important but it can not be determined by a small 
[unquote]

"Seizure of power" is still a fragment of imagery.  Nobody is 
literally "seizing power".  Power is asserted through the 
construction, organization and revitalization of institutions, not 
seized.  A literal seizure of power is violent, or usually implies 
violence.    

Let me provide this simple framework:  The ultimate assertion of 
power is all against one strongman;  the ultimate assertion of 
strength is one strongman over all.  Strength and power should not be 
conflated.  (This model can be found most definitively in Thomas 
Hobbes)  

There is, finally, a difference between analysis and rhetoric that 
should be recognized!  And, let's not forget, rhetoric can be 
analyzed, and analysis can shape rhetoric. 

[quote]
group in a back room, or maybe it can be... but that is the method of 
the democatic party machine.  Our platform is not unrealistic, it was 
determined by 1000 surveys and voted on by a 150 people, that is its 
reality and reasonableness .  If current laws, ideologies, 
institutions, and even the economic system stand in the way of 
enacting the program than the people will determine how those 
obtacles need to be transformed or eliminated. I think that our 
campaign stands for higher education for all; if there is something 
in the way of that I think our campaign should help people to remove 
the obstacle. Our campaign should definetly not play the role of 
explaining why their aspiations are unrealistic.  We are not a shield 
for the status quo our campaign must be the sword of the people. 
[unquote]

And we should recognize the limits of the General Will as a concept.  
Namely, the Will of the People is something that is always being 
interpreted and reinterpreted -- even the will of an individual comes 
about only through self-interpretation and criticism of oneself and 
one's environment.  The campaign doesn't know the Will of the People 
in some magical, unmediated way.   

There is room both for specialization and democracy.  Don't set up a 
false opposition between Policy and Democracy.  That is utterly 
absurd.  What, are thousands of people going to get together in 
Buccleuch Park every day to debate the minutae of traffic light 
regulations, or whether park benches should be made out of spruce or 
mahogany?  Democracy consists of accountability and trust, but trust 
implies distance.  The Peoples' Campaign seems to stand for there 
being the right degree and kind of distance between the represented 
and the representatives.  

Yours,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:436
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 01:38:56
Subject:Re: Hello
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Zofia Nowakowski" 
<znowakowski@u...> wrote:

> One thought I had to reconcile some of the issues we are discussing 
>is,
> 
> 1. As a platform identify a general final goal - ex - jobs with a 
>living wage for all NB residents - and then indicate specific 
>concrete things that we would consider doing as an initial idea of a 
>step toward that goal.  I think both sorts of goals are important.  
>Im not sure whether now is the time to make any actual promises 
>regarding specific steps - we need more citizen participation before 
>taking a particular course.
 
With respect to "citizen participation" let me just affirm
and expand upon what you appear to be saying:

A significant element in the campaign's work is researching, 
assessing, and making contacts with various organizations, activist 
efforts, religious institutions, etc, in New Brunswick and, in 
relevant cases, outside of New Brunswick.  Insofar as the work 
of 'policy wonks' relates to this realm of activity -- expanding the 
base of participating organizations/public-minded interests and, as a 
consequence, participating individuals -- it is quite democratic. 

Since the operative ideal here is citizen participation, and alot of 
citizen participation involves indirect participation through the 
institutions of "civil society", it has to be established 1) what the 
goal is and 2) how the institutions of civil society will be either 
worked with or fostered by the city council -- and, how public funds 
and resources at the county, state, or federal level will be 
utilized.  Since we're only at the point of attempting to get three 
city council members elected, this is particularly important.  The 
alternative to empowering the community through working with and 
fostering 'civil society' is, well, patronage, corruption and 
violence.  So, positing "goals" and how we will begin to pursue them 
consists in putting forward the very terms of that pursuit -- a 
statement of method.  

> 2. Also maybe we can set up an info library at the office with 
>copies of all sorts of information and documents and make it 
>available to residents to copy.  Any process steps to improve info 
>distribution and eliminate hoarding of info/ info bottlenecks whichI 
>admit as RTK I have been reponsible for in part. 

Sounds like a good idea.  

Yours,

Jeremy

Post ID:440
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 09:58:27
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Planning Board Meeting
Message:

Agenda tomorrow - 99 Bayard Street building is going to be included in the redevelopment plan.  

I havent been tracking planning since I moved over to education.  Heldrich Plaza is not up for approval this time either, although it might be wise to go to the meeting and ask why the City didnt apply for funds for relocation of residents (the answer Glen Patterson gave me is that the residents didnt qualify as permanent residents since they are technically living in a hotel).  It seems like there is a chance that Dev Co could be classified as a private agency - in that case, they should give residents 18 months before eviction (Legal Services opinion).  If they are classified as a govt entity - just 3 months are required I believe and they are operating under this - and in this case I believe that Dev Co is the designated redeveloper, although I wnated to confirm that with Mr. Clarke of the NB Housing Authority, the redevelopment authority of New Brunswick.  Designated redevelopers must apply to NBHA for approval. Anyway because of this hotel status the City (Or NBHA or DevCO, I am not certain which) applied for relocation funds from the state ONLY for the businesses and for the residents NOT living in the hotel.   If the residents had been classified otherwise (Im not certain how much leeway there is in interpreting this by the state and by the city) or if the City had chosen to think of the residents  otherwise we could have gotten state funds to assist the residents, and a law protecting them requiring that their relocated housing is at least comparable would have applied.  

I know Keith has been working with the residents.  It might be worth going to the pb mtg with the residents tomorrow to demand more information (acquiese that the 18 mth eviction rule applies) , relocation funds, etc..  Also someone might want to check with Jose Abreu at Legal Services to determine DevCos official status, the status of the legal battle at this point and see if theres any way people can go at this as a group rather than individually, legally.  



Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878

Post ID:441
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 10:44:13
Subject:re: Monument Hotel Article in Newspaper.

--- Original Message ---
"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...> Wrote on 
Mon, 10 Jul 2000 15:57:16 GMT
 ------------------ 


Residents wonder: Where can we go?

Published in the Home News Tribune 7/09/00

By JAKE STUIVER
STAFF WRITER

Once, it was a jewel of downtown New Brunswick.

Gov. Morgan F. Larson was its first guest in 1929, and the top-floor

penthouse of the building originally known as The Woodrow Wilson
Hotel held 
the city's most swinging parties and prestigious events.

Now, human corpses, stairwell feces, rotting food, 3-month-old
beer empties, 
rats and mice are the main attractions at the Monument Park Hotel.
That, and 
a group of residents teetering on homelessness.

After numerous highs and lows and changes in name and ownership
over the 
past 70 years, the eight-story building at 10 Livingston Ave.
is a few 
months away from becoming rubble.

Its new owner, the New Brunswick Development Corp., wants to
make way for 
the 15-story Heldrich Plaza hotel and conference center that
would cover the 
entire block.

The problem is, the hotel isn't exactly a hotel anymore. That
is, its 
patrons usually don't check out the next day. Some of them haven't
checked 
out for more than 10 years.

Many of the 50 or 60 residents and families still living at the
hotel are 
there because of the relatively low living costs (usually about
$800 a month 
and no utility expenses) and the fact that they were placed there
by social 
services.

Add that to the 245-unit housing project down the street also
slated for 
demolition by year's end for another redevelopment plan, and
the city's 
poorest residents are all scrambling to find new places to live.

DevCo acquired the hotel for $2.7 million through bankruptcy
court May 1 
after its prior owner, Donald Cresitello of Morristown-based
Tello 
Enterprises, failed to restore the business to its early glory
and ran into 
financial problems.

Within a week, a foul stench led the new owners to a dead body
that had 
allegedly been sitting in one of the rooms since at least a few
days prior 
to the property transfer. Another tenant's corpse turned up a
few weeks 
later in a bizarre incident with a prostitute.

Though Cresitello denies it, representatives of DevCo and the
firm hired to 
manage the site until demolition claim he pulled out all the
phone wires, 
and they invested in restoring service to tenants.

While many residents are looking for new homes, they're grumbling
that as 
long as they pay rent at the hotel, they're entitled to have
somebody clean 
up the hallways and stairwells, which are full of trash and,
in some places, 
human waste.

Until last week, when reporters began inquiring about the hotel's
condition, 
the bar and basement were covered in food and glass empties from
a party 
residents said the former managers had before they cleared out
in May.

Some of the residents, including fifth-floor tenant Glenda Reaves,
said they 
feel like the owners are trying to give them incentives to leave
quickly.

"That is an absurd out-and-out lie," said Mitch Broder of One-Zero
Hotel 
Management and Raritan Property Management, the firm DevCo hired
to run the 
building. "To the contrary, we've bent over backward to be as
accommodating 
as we can . . . to respond to any requests. We've turned on phones
for 
people that we know are imminently moving, at huge expense for
us. We have a 
full-time cleaning person cleaning the building. We have an exterminator.

We've upgraded fire and electrical systems."

The messes in the halls and stairwells, Broder said, should have
been 
brought to his attention instead of to the press.

New Jersey hotels face inspection, overseen by the state Department
of 
Community Affairs, every five years. As long as the building
is still 
standing and operational, it's subject to health and fire standards,
DCA 
spokesman John Patella said.

The Monument Park Hotel's demolition is targeted for October.
Its next 
inspection is due in September.


Moving the poor
Residents in the nearby New Brunswick Homes public housing are
slowly 
getting out.

Some are finding affordable housing in the area. Others are hoping
the city 
keeps promises for spots in the new low-income units planned
for the site 
and other locations downtown.

Being public-housing tenants, however, can mean expedited Section
8 vouchers 
and other assistance that the hotel tenants won't get.

There's nothing Middlesex County can offer the tenants other
than its 
standard homeless services such as rental assistance, said county
Freeholder 
Jane Brady, chair of the Human Services Committee.

The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development focuses
on family 
units, but there's also a need for what's known as single-room
occupancy, 
she said.

"The problem is that there is just nothing out there for these
people," she 
said. "They are looking for very low-income places to
live, and there just isn't any in this county. It is very disturbing
that we 
are losing what was our last remaining single-room-occupancy
unit."

The city plans to build low-income units at George Street and
Remsen Avenue 
and in the soon-to-be-replaced Lord Stirling School, but those
would go to 
Homes residents first, Mayor Jim Cahill said. Anything left after
all the 
Homes residents are moved could go to former hotel residents
if they 
qualify, he said.

Issues such as transportation, proximity to work and social services
make it 
desirable for the residents to stay in the city, but most options
would be 
better than living at the hotel, the mayor said.

"The hotel has not been well run, it has not been well managed,"
he said, 
adding many people have been moving out on their own. "As these
numbers 
dwindle, it becomes easier to focus on the remaining residents."

Residents are organizing to learn and demand their rights.

A new group in the city called Advocates to Empower the Poor,
headed by the 
formerly homeless Victor Luna, has been working to rally tenants
and get 
them legal counseling.

A few hotel residents, such as Debra Key, have taken matters
into their own 
hands by holding tenant meetings and consulting with Middlesex
County Legal 
Services Corp.

Jose Abreu, a staff attorney with Legal Services' housing unit
who's been 
working closely with tenants at the hotel, said he's encouraging
them to 
challenge the notices to move out.

The notices were issued in May with July 31 deadlines, but that
might not be 
adequate, Abreu said. He said he considers DevCo a private entity
that must 
provide 18 months' notice.

Even if a judge deems DevCo a government agency, which needs
to give only 
three months' notice, the letters contain no language about the
type of 
mandatory relocation assistance the owner will provide, he said.

The residents don't have money to put down for moving costs and
security 
deposits, and they're entitled to aid from the landlord
casting them out, he said.

The management should also offer help finding new homes, considering
the 
low-rent housing market is so saturated with Homes and hotel
residents 
pouring out simultaneously, he said.

Residents have been getting varying amounts of money as part
of their 
agreements to leave.

"The only thing they've offered us is moving assistance," Key
said. "Where 
are we going to move to? They're just trying to slide us up under
the door. 
We're just asking for what's right, and they're trying to find
every way 
around it."

Once a Palace
When the New Brunswick Hotel Corp. opened the Woodrow Wilson
in 1929, one 
newspaper headline read "New Brunswick Crowns with Laurel its
$850,000 
Hostelry."

The opening ceremony guest list included U.S. senators and congressmen,

state officials and Rutgers University President John
M. Thomas.

Its suites, which include a bedroom, kitchenette and main area
not much 
bigger than the bathroom, were once touted as the latest in comfort.

Its history is long and winding, but two things are clear: In
1940, it 
underwent the first of many name changes, to the Roger Smith
Hotel; Sometime 
in the 1970s, the hotel began losing clientele, part of a citywide

recession.

Cresitello said he bought the building in 1986 after it had been
closed for 
several years, possibly because of problems with the city.

He said he invested about $7.5 million in renovations and reopened
it as a 
Days Inn in 1988. He said there were problems with the Days Inn
company, and 
in the early '90s he converted to a Howard Johnson's, soon to
become the 
Monument Park Hotel.

"At that point, we took in whatever customers we could take,"
he said. "Some 
were long-term, some were welfare."

Much of the city's revitalization was supposed to happen 10 years
ago, and 
the delay hurt the hotel industry, Cresitello said.

"We just figured the town wasn't ready for us," he said. "We
got caught in 
the stall. We were never fully able to recover from it."

Now that redevelopment's day has come, the main redeveloper sees

Cresitello's failure as DevCo's gold mine.

DevCo wants to raze the entire block between Livingston Avenue
and New 
Street to build the Heldrich Center, which will also house a
Rutgers 
work-force development school and a huge parking garage.

About 75 percent of the block is on the way to DevCo control,
but most of it 
needs to go down before the hotel to make room for the collapse
of the 
taller building, DevCo President Chris Paladino said.

"Getting the hotel was the cornerstone of the acquisition," Paladino
said. 
"Without that, we would not have been able to move forward."

Paladino doesn't expect everybody to be out of the hotel until
September, 
and he said DevCo is doing what it can to help find housing.

He noted, however, that it's still a hotel, not an apartment
building, and 
that its rates aren't exactly poverty-level.

"At $800 a month, people are not homeless," he said. "$800 is
not an 
insignificant amount of money."

He also noted Heldrich will create 500 jobs, plus another 3,000
during 
construction, and will provide training programs to employ people
from the 
area.

Ultimately, DevCo is hoping to restore the block's luster.

On the inside
That doesn't mean much to the Lopez family, having lived on the
hotel's 
fourth floor for the past eight years.

Ceasar Lopez, 26, drives to work at USA Detergents in North Brunswick
but 
stays at the hotel because his 1-year-old son, Ceasar Jr., has
Scimitas 
syndrome and has to see five doctors a month at city hospitals.

His wife, Anna Ramirez, 27, sits by Ceasar Jr. most of the time
to make sure 
his ventilator unit, which takes up one-third of their tiny living
room, 
stays operational.

The couple would love to have a bigger place but can't find one
they can 
afford that's close enough to the hospitals.

When the notice to vacate arrived in May, Lopez was floored.

"It got everybody crazy," he said. "Nobody was expecting that."

Not everybody is as reluctant to leave as Lopez.

For Glenda Reaves, 47, of the fifth floor, the push out the door
marks the 
end of a long, horrible nightmare at Monument Park.

A long-neglected ceiling leak has left her with mice, exposed
asbestos and 
permanently mangled hands.

Condensation from the air conditioner upstairs ate through the
ceiling 
panels right above the center of her main room, and for the 
past two 
summers she's had her floor constantly covered in towels and
bowls.

Once, while she was hanging towels out the bathroom window to
dry, the loose 
frame slammed down on her hands and left her fingers twisted.
She said she's 
suing the former owner.

Reaves said Advocates to Empower the Poor found her a real-estate
company 
that got her into a Hampton Club residence subsidized by her
social-services 
payments, and she's moving there next week, although the hotel's
new 
management has been letting her use a seventh-floor room in the
meantime.

Maybe at her new home, she hopes, she won't have to sleep on
a cot mattress 
on the floor because there'll be room for both her and her 15-year-old

daughter to have separate beds.

"I'm not a dirty person," she said, gesturing toward her makeshift
bedroom 
by the towel pile. "But right now, living for the next day. It's
all I can 
do. I don't want to live like this ever again."


from the Home News Tribune
Published: July 9, 2000
Copyright 1997-2000 IN Jersey.

Post ID:442
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>

Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Our Program
Message:

Zofia.
whereas that may be the opinion of the one person you talked to and MCC is 
no Harvard, many people, (especially working class kids who can't afford or 
get into Rutgers) successfully use it as a stepping stone to four year 
colleges. It is supposed to be one of the better county colleges in the 
state. I don't understand the point of your email.
Louise

Post ID:445
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 11:16:26
Subject:Education
Message:

With the mention of community colleges I just wanted to share that discussion.  I was not promoting my own view but relating what someone else had said, since he is not on email.  I guess my point was that we need alot of input to promote policies on education, because together people have the best knowledge about what opportunities there are and could be.

Another idea that Luis had is to turn the library into a real resource for economic and employment development with more computers, and hired staff to teach people how to use them.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:446
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 12:40:10
Subject:Plng board mtg
Message:

Sorry if you got a copy of this. I havent seen it posted yet.

Agenda tomorrow - 99 Bayard Street building is going to be included in the redevelopment plan.  

I havent been tracking planning since I moved over to education.  Heldrich Plaza is not up for approval this time either, although it might be wise to go to the meeting and ask why the City didnt apply for funds for relocation of residents (the answer Glen Patterson gave me is that the residents didnt qualify as permanent residents since they are technically living in a hotel).  It seems like there is a chance that Dev Co could be classified as a private agency - in that case, they should give residents 18 months before eviction (Legal Services opinion).  If they are classified as a govt entity - just 3 months are required I believe and they are operating under this - and in this case I believe that Dev Co is the designated redeveloper, although I wnated to confirm that with Mr. Clarke of the NB Housing Authority, the redevelopment authority of New Brunswick.  Designated redevelopers must apply to NBHA for approval. Anyway because of this hotel status the City (Or NBHA or DevCO, I am not certain which) applied for relocation funds from the state ONLY for the businesses and for the residents NOT living in the hotel.   If the residents had been classified otherwise (Im not certain how much leeway there is in interpreting this by the state and by the city) or if the City had chosen to think of the residents  otherwise we could have gotten state funds to assist the residents, and a law protecting them requiring that their relocated housing is at least comparable would have applied.  

I know Keith has been working with the residents.  It might be worth going to the pb mtg with the residents tomorrow to demand more information (whether that the 18 mth eviction rule applies) , relocation funds, etc..  Also someone might want to check with Jose Abreu at Legal Services to determine DevCos official status, the status of the legal battle at this point and see if theres any way people can go at this as a group rather than individually, legally.  

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:449
Sender:"Chris Kozlowski" <razer@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-11 18:26:34
Subject:RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Our Program
Message:

Zofia,

Is that not precisely the point that was raised?  The ethic of a student is
something that needs to be cultivated right out of NBHS -- worst case, it
should be corrected at a county college.  It is hardly the responsibility of
a State university to countermand the shortcomings of public education at
the expense of those who have studied hard their entire lives.

Chris

sit around and play cards in class.

Post ID:452
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-12 11:37:00
Subject:Re: RE: [nbpeoplescampaign] Our Program
Message:

Im sorry,

I think my comment was misinterpreted.  The point Luis was making is that he felt the preparation offered at MCC was not enough to launch individuals into any real careers.  The reference to playing cards was to underline that students noted the lack of seriousness and intensiveness of the courses of instruction  available to them there.  Of course, one anecdote does not a policy make, but it sheds some light onto what students experience.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:455
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-13 09:58:12
Subject:On the agenda this SAT
Message:

1. This Saturday, July 15th, Curtis Warren is organizing a march from the People's Campaign office 149 Redmond Street starting at 12 pm to the tree where Sissy Adams was killed by a New Brunswick cop.  July 15th is her birthday, and he is naming the day Sisterhood Day in her memory.  There will be speeches and ice cream.  All are invited to join in the spirit of the day.

2.  At 2 pm back at the office there will be canvass training.  This is a great place to invite new people and become familiar with the campaign - the training is alot of fun with skits etc.

3.  If you know people who are not already involved in the campaign but would like to organize for an elected school board, please, send them my way:  (732) 729-1087.  I am canvassing this weekend and I would love to have people join the committee with me.  This should be a great opportunity to get to know the community and become involved in the most highly identified issue of concern in New Brunswick - community control over children's education.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:457
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-13 11:55:17
Subject:BOE sigs
Message:

Hi everybody, Zofia has indicated that she's planning to canvass separately 
for BOE sigs. I think we need to adopt more of a team approach for this 
important operation.

I don't know how this has been decided in tactical committee, but it seems 
to me we have the best chance to get the BOE question on the ballot is to 
incorporate intensive BOE drives into the canvass. We can do this by 
canvassing the verified registered voters, as with the petitions for 
candidacy. I think we should concentrate these votes in the middle class 
areas, and areas that we have recorded as coming out strong for elected BOE 
in past years.

Additionally:

Since the BOE signatories have to be registered voters, recorded by the 
county before the city clerk will approve their sigs, any voters registered 
less than a month before we hand in BOE sigs probably will not be counted as 
registered by the county, much less the city clerk!

Also:

I find that I spend most of my time with people convincing them to become 
supporter households, something I've been very successful with. In doing 
that, I'm concentrating on building political unity with them, convincing 
them to take on the campaign tasks as their own. So I often don't get in the 
BOE sig because there's so much to talk about.

I think that's cause to have some canvassing concentrated on getting these 
sigs. I'll definitely take part in planning the turfs and 
organizing/training on this issue. People, let me know what you think. Paul
