Post ID:505
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-26 10:10:03
Subject:From Good Jobs First on corporate relocation, economic development - 3 emails
Message:

From: 	"Sara Hinkley" <shinkley@...>
To:	"Greg LeRoy" <goodjobs@...>
Date: 	7/25/00 6:07PM
Subject: 	Corporate Mobility and Subsidies

As we said two weeks ago, GJF believes that with today's skilled-labor
shortage, there ought to be a  reallocation of development subsidies to
programs that produce more skilled labor --  GED, ESL, Adult Literacy, real
training for workers leaving welfare, and "carrots" for  employers to adopt
high-road practices such as lifelong learning and career ladders.

Now comes massive confirming evidence. Yesterday's New York Times had a long
Page 1 article showing that corporations are relocating *within the U.S.* at
more than twice the rate of just six years ago. It concludes that the
relocations are driven by the companies' quest for more (and cheaper) labor.
Yet despite the fact that the relocations are happening for hard market
reasons, public officials continue to subsidize the "new" facilities. Those
of us in the plant closing movement began decrying this practice 15 years
ago, saying that capital is already very mobile, so it makes no sense to
subsidize even more mobility.

It is one more example of how economic development in American has strayed
from its original intent.  Instead of leveraging investment that would not
occur otherwise, taxpayer dollars are often used to jump the parade of
market trends. Public officials, of course, love those
parade-marshal uniforms!

Greg LeRoy
Good Jobs First -- www.goodjobsfirst.org
-  - - - - - -

New York Times July 24, 2000

SHIFTING WORKPLACE
A special report.
A New Corporate Wanderlust Puts a Quiet Brake on Salaries
By LOUIS UCHITELLE

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- Not long after W. Lee Nutter took over last year as
chairman of Rayonier Inc., a big wood and pulp company with headquarters in
Stamford, Conn., he called in a top executive, Jack O'Grady, and asked, "Why
are we here?"

The reasons, in fact, had peeled away. Modern technology now allowed the
company to distance itself from New York's financial markets and still have
complete instant communications. More of Rayonier's timberland and mills
were in the Southeast, and Jacksonville beckoned with $2.7 million in public
subsidies. And, in a booming economy, managers and executives were
increasingly expensive. Moving to an office tower here this summer cut
executive labor costs.

Twenty-eight people transferred from Stamford, but others declined to
relocate and 44 men and women, mostly executives, are being hired locally at
salaries that are at least 10 percent lower, on average, than those paid in
Stamford. In relocating, Rayonier shrank the headquarters staff to 72 from
85. And the new executives expect less. "Salaries in the Southeast do rise
more slowly than in the Northeast," said Mr. O'Grady, who is senior vice
president for administration.

Companies have been migrating for decades, of course, moving operations both
within the United States and overseas for many reasons, including the search
for cheaper labor. But since 1996, corporate migration within the country
has soared, roughly doubling to more than 11,000 moves a year, according to
Site Selection Magazine of Atlanta, the only organization, public or
private, to track the phenomenon. At the same time, the emphasis has shifted
from factories, the traditional migrants, to every type of service
operation, and across a range of jobs, from Rayonier's six-figure executives
down to call center operators earning $7 an hour.

The increasing restlessness of American business is beginning to be noticed
by economists, government officials and industry groups. "Corporate
migration within the United States is definitely accelerating," said Allen
J. Scott, a geographer at the University of California at Los Angeles who
specializes in economic issues. "The booming economy is prodding companies
to relocate or expand in new places."

As labor shortages and competition for workers drives up wages in one city,
companies have shifted work or have expanded in another location, where the
same tasks can be done at lower pay. This movement helps to answer one of
the big questions about the recent economy: How has the United States
managed to achieve its lowest unemployment rate since the 1960's and yet not
experience as much upward pressure on wages as it has during past booms,
even when labor markets were not as tight as they are today?

Various explanations have been offered by economists for the failure of
labor shortages to give a bigger kick to wages in the record long expansion
that started in 1991: weaker unions, the greater use of temporary workers, a
minimum wage that has lost value, a flood of immigrant workers, layoffs and
job insecurity, global competition. Often overlooked, however, has been the
impact of the stepped-up rate of corporate migration, which adds another
critical element to the mix.

But if lower labor costs drive the process, technology greases the way.
High-speed telecommunications and fiber-optic lines, now available almost
everywhere in the country, allow a Rayonier to communicate as easily from
Jacksonville as from Stamford, and they also allow a great variety of
service companies to link operations in different cities, as if these
operations were all in one office.

In addition, the talent pool is more evenly spread across the country in the
1990's than in earlier generations, said Lawrence F. Katz, a Harvard
economist, meaning "you can find similar labor forces and similar amenities
in many more places in America."

While technology facilitates corporate migration, so does the growing use of
call centers to deal with the public. Many companies use centers to take
orders for merchandise, to service credit cards, to handle securities
transactions, to give investment advice, to help owners of computers solve
software problems, to collect debts, to sell insurance, to help people
navigate the Internet. No one has yet counted all the call center operators,
not even the Labor Department, but their importance is beginning to rival
that of assembly line workers 50 years ago. And call centers, generally
requiring only telephones and desk-top computers, are much more mobile than
factories.

Mid-sized cities in the Southeast and Southwest are prime targets of the
corporate migration, cities like Charlotte, Memphis, Phoenix and
Jacksonville. But companies have also been drawn in growing numbers to the
Midwestern states or to Maine or Pennsylvania or Kentucky -- to any place,
in fact, that offers lower wages and public subsidies. Maine has fewer than
6,000 people making shoes, less than half the number it had in 1985, but
out-of-state retailers, banks, pharmaceutical companies, even a newspaper
clipping service, have placed operations in the old shoe towns, re-employing
workers.

"Companies are searching for pockets of unemployment," said Steven H.
Levesque, commissioner of Maine's Department of Economic and Community
Development, "and Maine has these pockets."


Spreading the Jobs: Mobility Restrains Wage Momentum

he stepped-up corporate migration has spread jobs and living standards more
evenly across the country than in some earlier expansions. Rather than
expand several of its operations in New York or New Jersey, for example,
Merrill Lynch has gradually added 2,000 employees here in Jacksonville,
locating them in four imposing pink stone office buildings on a bucolic site
in a suburban office park.

For a migrating company, the money saved in labor costs often goes into
earnings, helping to explain the extraordinary profitability of American
business in recent years, economists say. And by lowering labor costs,
corporate migration serves to keep inflation under control. But it also
serves as a counterweight to the social benefit of a low unemployment rate.
The ability to move almost any kind of work easily gives employers a more
powerful response to the demands of their employees for greater pay.

"Not just the greater mobility, but the threat of it helps to hold down
wages," Mr. Katz said.

Even so, average hourly earnings have risen faster than inflation in the
boom years since 1996, the first time that has happened for so long a
stretch since the 1960's and early 70's. But compare the 1990's with those
earlier decades and a more complex story emerges. Wages moved up more
persistently in the 60's as the unemployment rate fell. In response, the
inflation rate also rose more in the 60's than it did in the 90's. Corporate
migration has helped, in effect, to hold down labor costs and prices.

Public attention has focused on manufacturers that shift factories abroad,
particularly to Mexico and the Far East. But corporate migration within the
United States, which dawdled along at fewer than 5,200 occurrences annually
from 1980 through 1994, jumped in the late 1990's to more than 11,400,
according to Site Selection's research.

The organization's totals cover not only corporate migrations but also the
initial investments of newly started companies. Because only the largest
start-ups are counted, however, they represent only 10 percent of each
year's total, says Jack Lynes, Site Selection's executive editor. The
totals, including the start-ups, reached 12,702 in 1999. Before 1995, the
high point was 5,686 in 1989, the last full year of the previous expansion.

Responding to a request for data on corporate migration, the American
Management Association polled 63 of its chief executives last month, asking
by e-mail whether they intended to relocate their headquarters. Forty-two
percent said they had either recently relocated or were actively considering
doing so.

"You have to conclude that relocating operations is very much on the agenda
of corporate America," said Eric Greenberg, the association's director of
surveys.

The continuing migration of millions of families to the Sun Belt and the
Mountain States serves as a magnet for many companies. The labor force has
grown more rapidly in these regions than in the Northeast or Midwest. In
Jacksonville, for example, the labor force has been growing at 3 percent a
year since 1990, or three times as fast as the national average.

As a result, skilled executives -- accountants, financial analysts,
personnel managers and computer specialists -- are finally as easy for
Rayonier to find here as they are in the Northeast, Mr. O'Grady says.

"These are people who have moved for the amenities of life," said Edward
Glaeser, a Harvard economist, "and in some long-run sense their wages are
going to be relatively low because they want to be there."

Rayonier is the 19th large company to move an operation to Jacksonville this
year, or expand one here, and the company is still unpacking. Paintings are
propped against a wall in the conference room, waiting to be hung. Potted
plants will also decorate the room, Mr. O'Grady promises, and out in the
lobby the black plastic counter encircling the receptionist's station will
soon be changed for a green marble one, matching the green in the new
carpet.

Rayonier's headquarters had been in Stamford for 20 years and in Manhattan
for 30 years before that. Its new executives in Jacksonville earn $85,000
and up, some as much as $175,000 a year. For that sort of money, Mr. O'Grady
said, the pickings are better and the turnover less.

"You have more people competing for our jobs at this pay range," he said.
And the quality is better. In the Northeast, you get a personnel executive,
for example, with experience only in workmen's compensation, Mr. O'Grady
explained. "Here, for the same pay, they also have experience in medical and
dental insurance and 401(k) plans. You get a broader experience base."

There are other advantages. Office space is cheaper, and because
headquarters is now "closer to the bulk of our operations," Mr. O'Grady
said, fewer executives are needed. The company likes to promote from within,
but getting promising employees to transfer to Stamford was harder and more
expensive than bringing them here is likely to be. Housing costs are less,
the climate milder, and the beaches spectacular. The championship Jaguar
football team also figures as a draw in the Rayonier calculation, Mr.
O'Grady said.

"I have a new condo here," said Mr. O'Grady, who transferred to Jacksonville
himself in the spring, "and I asked my neighbors, 'Where are you from?' and
I would bet 80 percent are from other places."


Have Jobs, Will Travel: More Places Seen as Viable Locales

ompanies that once put down deep roots are also showing up in Colorado,
Idaho, Texas, Nevada, Utah, Iowa, Nebraska, Ohio -- just about everywhere.

But the South is still a favorite. People have been migrating to the South
for more than a generation, and now their children, those raised and
educated in Jacksonville, for example, are everywhere at Merrill Lynch.
William A. Bridy, Merrill's senior director in Jacksonville, often recruits
graduates of the University of North Florida, whose campus, with 12,000
students, is only three miles away. Recent graduates are among the 25
"profilers" stationed at Merrill's suburban campus.

Merrill developed profiling at its Somerset, N.J., office, using the
profilers to build a database of biographical information on new clients for
use as a tool in selling more services. The expansion, seven months ago, was
in Jacksonville and Denver.

Here a profiler's starting wage of $26,000 is 10 to 20 percent less than in
New Jersey, Mr. Bridy said. "There is not the demand for New Jersey wages,"
he said, adding that if labor costs do rise, Jacksonville will become less
attractive. That is beginning to happen in Denver. "The problem you have
there is turnover, which is higher than Jacksonville," Mr. Bridy said.

Sometimes the corporate migration is only a few counties away. Pressed by
the Big Three automakers to hold down prices, some parts manufacturers are
shifting from the Detroit environs to Traverse City and other locations in
upstate Michigan, where wages are lower. Principal Financial Group, which
manages pension plans for thousands of companies, found that wages were
rising in Des Moines, its headquarters city, for the counselors who field
telephone calls from people seeking information about their plans or
shifting investments. So work has been moved, through computer links, to
offices in Waterloo and Ottumwa, Iowa, where wages for counselors with the
same skills are 5 to 10 percent lower than in Des Moines.

Burrelle's Information Services is a constant migrant. The company employs
nearly 2,000 people who cull newspaper, magazine, video and Internet
citations for corporate customers. As wages rose in Livingston, N.J., its
headquarters, and business grew, the company added an office in Salt Lake
City, then Presque Isle, Me., and most recently in Houlton, Me. -- all in a
successful effort to keep the hourly wage of most of the employees below
$10.

"The unemployment rate is a little higher in Houlton than in Presque Isle
because it does not have an airport and tends to be bypassed by other
companies," said Robert Waggoner, chief executive at Burrelle's. "You have
to be adventurous in finding new places."


Vying for Better Jobs: Towns Try to Draw the Better Wages

hile Maine, with an unemployment rate of 5 percent or more in many towns and
cities, vies to attract lower-wage jobs -- or any jobs -- Jacksonville is
taking a different tack. The unemployment rate here has fallen to 3.1
percent from 6.6 percent in 1992, and with the pressure reduced to bring in
jobs, whatever they pay, the Chamber of Commerce and the Economic
Development Commission are trying to attract companies with jobs that pay
more than $31,000.

Boeing, the aerospace giant, is one beneficiary. Servicing and overhauling
aircraft is a growing part of its business, but rather than expand repair
centers in Wichita, Seattle or St. Louis, where mechanics earn $20 an hour
and up, Boeing has opened a center in Jacksonville. So have Northrop Grumman
and Jet Turbine Services. Skilled mechanics, trained in the Navy and
mustering out here, sign on for $18 an hour or less.

"You go where the workers are," said Dee Burcham, manager of Boeing's
Jacksonville repair center.

The Navy has a big presence in Jacksonville, but part of its complex, Cecil
Field, an air station, was closed and turned over to the city last fall. Now
the city is leasing hangar space to Boeing and others for the give-away
price of $1.50 a square foot.

"We are pump priming," said Paul Krutko, a director of the Economic
Development Commission. "Later the rates will go up."

Mr. Beecham, the Boeing manager, whose 55 employees will rise to 120 by
January, acknowledges that Cecil Field's subsidized facilities were an
important lure. "All we had to do was organize a work force and we were up
and running," he said. But he gave equal billing to "the availability of
knowledgeable aviation mechanics and electricians" at $18 an hour or less.

They are people like Michael Zipp, 39, who trained in the Marines as an
aviation electrician. He joined Grumman in Bethpage, N.Y., in the early
1980's, long before its merger with Northrop. Earning $17.50 an hour, with a
wife and four children, he could not make ends meet on Long Island, he said.
So he quit in 1988, moved himself and his family to nearby St. Augustine,
where Grumman had an operation, and rejoined the company at $10 an hour.

Even at that lower wage, he says, he could finally afford to pay his bills
and, for the first time, purchase a home. Only now, more than a decade
later, has his wage risen back to its old level of $17.50 an hour. He is
aware that people with his skills earn more elsewhere in the country. The
starting wage in Wichita, for example, where Boeing also has operations, is
$25 an hour, he says.

Why not move? "I'm settled here," he said.


Son of Call Center: Jacksonville Chafes at Label, and Jobs

acksonville got its start in economic development as a mecca for call
centers, thanks to AT&T, which set up a center here in 1983, after the phone
company's breakup, to handle queries from shareholders whose stock was
split. Inexpensive land drew more call centers, and Florida's status as a
largely nonunion, right to work state.

Public subsidies also helped. They still do, although they are angled now
toward companies like Boeing and Rayonier, which is receiving from the city
a $1.8 billion cash grant for bringing its headquarters here and additional
"incentives," as Mr. O'Grady calls them, from the state government.

But for all the efforts of the city fathers to bring higher paying jobs to
Jacksonville, the call centers still play a dominant role. America Online,
Citibank, Bank of America, MediaOne all have a big presence here. "We have
gone from being a call center town to wanting to not be called a call center
town," said Faye Kullberg, director of human resources for MediaOne.

Few companies employ more people here than a descendant of the original AT&T
call center, now part of a company called Convergys, based in Cincinnati.
Convergys has 37 call centers nationwide, with 45,000 employees, including
4,500 here. The operators do not mention Convergys; they take on the
identity of the companies that purchase its services. A recent client is
AT&T Wireless, whose cell phone customers get a Convergys operator when they
call an 800 number for help.

But Convergys has not expanded recently in Jacksonville. The pay for call
center operators has risen by about $2 an hour in the last 18 months, to
between $10 and $12 an hour. Turnover is also rising, and Jacksonville is
losing its luster as a suitable site for low-wage call centers. So Convergys
opened its newest center in Brownsville, Tex.

"We pay the same in Brownsville as in Jacksonville," said Frank Kelly, a
Convergys executive, "but the unemployment rate there reached 14 percent,
and we were able to hire very good people. They consider our job to be a
white collar job."

From: 	"Greg LeRoy" <goodjobs@...>
To:	"Me" <goodjobs@...>
Date: 	7/25/00 6:42PM
Subject: 	An Enduring Movement

See the attached hot-linked article for your faithful correspondent's
historical perspective on the movement for subsidy accountability (a 22-year
pet peeve and counting...)

http://www.nfg.org/reports/72econdev.htm

Greg LeRoy
Good Jobs First -- www.goodjobsfirst.org

From: 	"Greg LeRoy" <goodjobs@...>
To:	"Me" <goodjobs@...>
Date: 	7/25/00 6:31PM
Subject: 	Subsidies: Eroding State Revenues?

A  recent report by the Congressional Research Service suggests that the
"economic war among the states" is causing state corporate income tax rates
to plummet. The report, attached here, documents the fact that the effective
rate of state and local taxes on corporate profits averaged 6.5% in the
1980s, but dropped to an average of 4.9% between 1990 and 1998, and stood at
just 3.8% in 1998 -- or a drop in the effective rate of more than 41%
comparing the 1980s to 1998.

Although the report does not explore the cause or causes of this sharp
decline, it concludes that "[p]erhaps the most obvious explanation is the
tax competition among states to attract businesses." As a major source of
the decline, it cites the increasingly common state practice of abandoning
the traditional three-factor formula for allocating profits for taxation
(equally weighting jobs, assets and sales in the state) and either
double-weighting sales or allocating taxes based entirely on sales. Such
changes are often demanded by large manufacturing companies which have large
asset bases and large workforces in a state, but sell
nationally/internationally. The net effect is to greatly reduce their state
corporate income taxes.

The CRS finding is consistent with other observers who have noted that after
many federal corporate income tax loopholes were closed in 1986, and after
federal rates were raised in 1993, many corporations turned their
tax-cutting energies to the states. There, they discovered that by packaging
corporate tax cuts as "economic development," they could play states against
each other and win cuts no longer available from Uncle Sam.

Corporate income taxes make up only about 7% of state tax revenues. Due to
robust growth in personal income, the erosion in corporate tax rates has
been masked in most states. But corporate income tax revenues are quite
volatile and are more sensitive to the business cycle than most other
sources. So the next recession may only further reduce the share of state
revenues coming from corporate profits.

Greg LeRoy
Good Jobs First -- www.goodjobsfirst.org






Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

>ARE NOT YET READY FOR PIRME TIME.......IN THE NAME OF
>ALLAH....ASILAMILAKIUM.......
>

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:508
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-27 09:58:05
Subject:Youth League
Message:

Hi everyone.

The first Sunday of Youth League went great! We played soccer and football, 
papermached balloons (thanks Alyssa!)and made posters with about 35 kids. It 
was a lot of fun, we had many kids involved with creative ideas of what they 
want to do in the league. Thank you to all our volunteers who came out.

I am emailing everyone to remind them that we are doing it every Sunday for 
six weeks. We meet at 2pm at 149 Redmond st (go around back) to discuss the 
previous week, what could be done better and to plan activities for the 
upcoming week, then we all go over to the field. If you canvass from 12-2 
(which is very much encouraged) you can meet up with us at 245 at the field, 
call me for directions.

Please call me or email me with any questions 732-890-0995. I hope to see 
you all there this week, we really need people since many will be out of 
town.

Also, we still need art supplies if you got them and does anyone know of a 
good place to get a wiffle ball and bat, walmart was a no go.

Thanks
Louise
________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

I think it begs the question that some of the recent posts belong
to city machine allies/political hacks. As for the credibility
issue, just look at the unsubstantiated, unjustified, LOUD and
empty rhetoric of recent commentators. And don't forget, those
spelling and grammatical errors. (Another reason for an elected
school board perhaps.)

That being said, has anyone noticed that "CHIMERANGA" sounds
at first, alot like "chimera?" The comments are certainly chimerical,
that's for sure.

Let's use our time to organize ourselves, the people, and the
campaign. Keep the eyes on the prize, not on the keyboard.

--BV

That is not possible under existing New Jersey law. 
Moreover, it would be silly at best to ask the voters
to approve a specified budget amount in November when
the beginning of the school fiscal year (Jul. 1) is 8
months away.

Groove

Post ID:523
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-28 16:36:05
Subject:Re: [nbpc] BOE Q
Message:

People I am speaking with are concerned that not enough people will go to vote in the spring.  Moving the date to November would make it easier for voters and would guarantee greater representation, and a coalition could be organized to move the day.  Of course, we should work towards election days being off for folks because so many have to work.
The point is to jointly with the BOE issue address any attacks on voters that make the election process more difficult., since the BOE will be a bigger win for true democracy that way. 

If the fiscal year makes it a challenge, others who have called for this must have thought of this and found a way to address it - I will have to look into it.


Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:524
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-28 17:37:05
Subject:Hello
Message:

I think so much of the history of New Brunswick has been about the struggle for representation because of harsh disenfranchisement of different groups, and the real necessity of clutching onto any and all wins made in this area.  What we are struggling with is the confusion of representation which has been able to grant some positive change, in the form of increased jobs going to a few members of those groups, possibly Section 8's, etc., some oversight of the most egregious errors, implementation of some new programs; the confusion of this with the gaining of real power to ensure that conditions in the town change systematically and substantively FOR ALL, not the lucky few recipients within each group, who get the new jobs or program - ie school administration and quality, redevelopment, youth activities, housing, etc. etc.  I think many people feel they have struggled so hard to get the representation that they do have at this point, and are afraid to rock the boat because the machine has tolerated this and in fact used it as political patronage, and they do not want any new factor that may shift the resource flows that have developed over time.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:525
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-07-27 11:43:25
Subject:Organizing
Message:

I agree that groups should organize themselves.  What you see in our general meetings is groups that have organized themselves formally or informally are able to put forward their proposals - so this step must happen in a sense first.  At the same time, I think that if the group has not yet been organized to perfection those people still need to jump in to the fray in order to influence it, otherwise the opportunity is missed.  And what I am learning in this campaign is also not to compromise ones ultimate goals in order to gain a measure of support.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

School Ethics Decisions re New Brunswick School Board:

Villa v. Gutierrez (Appeal to Superior Ct, App. Division)
http://www.state.nj.us/njded/legal/ethics/c1399.pdf

Villa v. Arocho
http://www.state.nj.us/njded/legal/ethics/c1699.pdf



New Jersey School Ethics Commission:
(The agency which administers the School Ethics Act)
http://www.state.nj.us/njded/legal/ethics/index



New Jersey Department of Education (Indexed Website):
http://www.state.nj.us/njded/legal/index

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:531
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-31 10:02:28
Subject:Interesting Article from The Nation
Message:

I think you'll like this.

Brian Villa thought this item from the The Nation Magazine would be of interest to you.

For more articles like the one you're about to read, visit The Nation website at http://www.thenation.com. Featuring editorials, essays, news and views as well as special subscription offers to The Nation, this site is the place to go for provocative, hard-hitting reporting you can't find anywhere else.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------


IN THE EIGHTH CIRCLE OF THIEVES



by E. L. DOCTOROW


Click here for our special election-season website.



Eased into governance
by years and years of conservative ideology, the corporations of America
today effectively oversee the Congress, the regulatory agencies and indeed
the presidency itself. There is no Article in the Constitution that recognizes
the supracitizenship of conglomerates; nothing is written that grants enlarged
and pre-emptive voting rights to business organizations and their trade
groups. But as Washington is run today, major issues of public policy are
bent and distorted by these multiheaded Brobdingnags who bribe Congress
with their money and coddle it with their lobbies, so that time and time
again socially desirable legislation in the public interest, whether having
to do with public health or safety, environmental protection, preservation
of our natural resources or any other issue of clear relevance to the entire
society, is defeated, sabotaged or transmuted by language into its perverse
opposite.

Yes, you say, tell me about it. But this is the recurrent truth
of Washington, so rhythmically repetitive as to be its heartbeat, the way
it pumps. Corporations that pit themselves against the manifest needs of
the American people according to the issues that arise take turns as enemies
of the people. Nothing else on Capitol Hill occurs so reliably and regularly.
It so prevails as a political fact of life that it is hardly news. It has
been a long, long time since it was news. It is now only and obviously the
way things are. Banking, oil, lumber, pharmaceuticals, weaponry, communications
and electronics, chemicals, meat and poultry--whatever the industry, you'll
find it striding with a proprietary mien through the corridors of power.
But in the name of what kind of Constitution?

Apologists will cite the
First Amendment, speak of the American or God-given right of people to function
in their own interest. That is just what democracy is, they say, a raucous
contention of interests that historically proves out as the genius of our
system; it is what we have always done in this country right from the start,
when frontiersmen in coonskin caps and leggings came to town, and later
the men in cutaways and top hats, everyone, always, grabbing their representatives
by the lapels and demanding to be represented.

But conglomerated organizations
of capital are not exactly people. They are compositions of human talents
formatted to their purposes. They are dedicated networks of artificial intelligence.
They think and feel in numerical abstractions. They will advertise their
employees as their human face, they will give themselves hearts and souls
in their television commercials, but as institutions they are dimensionally
beyond the humans who work for them or the shareholders who gamble in their
stock. They transform themselves, take on or divest themselves of companies,
move across national boundaries, restructure, wax and wane, merge with others
of their ilk in an institutionalized dynamic that leaves even their executives
irrelevant. They are profit manufactories that accumulate people or rid
themselves of people according to the transhuman logic of their balance
sheets. And for the loyalty they demand and receive, the quid pro quo is
to absolve those working for them who act inhumanely on their inhuman behalf.
* * *

In effect corporate entities that function in Washington to achieve
benefits for themselves--tax loopholes, contracts, entitlements, dismantling
of regulatory acts--regardless of the overall social effect, pre-empt the
idea of the larger community, the national ideal, the United States as the
ultimate communal reality. A just nation is not envisioned but a confederacy
whose people are meant to live at the expense of one another. Such social
Darwinism finds the presumptions of democracy naïve. The corporations
that will farm our lands, insure our lives and our health, finance our homes,
entertain us, power our cars, light our lamps... ask only one thing in return:
that we recognize two forms of citizenship, common and preferred.

How contemptuous
this all is, what an enormous humiliation to a society of free people. We
may ask those who speak of this corrupt and corrupting system as a kind
of speech that mustn't be tampered with, if to privilege the free speech
of corporations with vast treasuries on those grounds is not undeniably
to squelch the speech of others who don't have the same resources. Or if,
in fact, this huge application of money to the political process that so
depreciates the power of the individual voter is not a de facto poll tax,
with the expected minorities, Afro-American, Hispanic, joined in their disfranchisement
by the white citizenry.

To consider the elected politician in all this
is to mourn the days when amateurism was part of the political culture.
Somewhere along the line political officeholding became a profession. To
keep working, politicians have regularly to come like buskers into the street,
sing their song and dance their jig and hold out their hats. In the best
of them, this ritual has to induce a degree of self-hatred. Television is
the major reason campaigning is so monstrously expensive. The airwaves are
owned by the public, but that is irrelevant to the broadcast licensees,
who charge commercial rates for programming in the public interest... and
then contribute heavily to campaigns, so that no one who is elected will
get up in Congress and say what a swindle it is for the broadcasters to
charge the public for the use of airwaves the public owns.
* * *

The fundraising
dinners are affairs of the wealthy. If you are a politician, the fatter
the check that comes in, the greater your indebtedness. Your conscience
becomes an instrument of self-deception. Some politicians are entirely at
ease with this, either because they are themselves wealthy and are one with
their contributors, or so reliably conformed to the values of the plutocracy
that they rise up fully banked--as for example the Governor of Texas, noted
for his rigorous support for the death penalty and for the civil rights
of heavily polluting industries, who miraculously appeared in all the papers
two years before the primaries as a front-runner and who now floats atop
a campaign fund of $80 million.

What kind of political culture does the
politician cheerfully acknowledge, who can say, as Republican Senator Orrin
Hatch has said, that to back reform of the system of campaign money-raising
would be an idiotic thing for his party because it collects more money than
the opposition? What degree of public alienation can a politician like Senate
majority leader Trent Lott depend on, who has brazenly said in sponsoring
legislation written by corporate lobbyists... that after all they are the
specialists in their field, who know the issues better than anyone else?
These are the remarks of senators confident of a general population so numbed
and alienated that barely 50 percent of eligible adults bother to vote in
national elections. These are the flaunted values of politicians who know
of the conglomerate-owned press culture, that there will be no editorial
muckraking from the "in depth" journalists of the broadcast media, that
the rampant corruption in Washington, the vast, deep and dangerous mutant
character of the present state of things, will not be defined for what it
is, and that who speaks of the bewildering broad front of failure and mendacity
and carelessness of human life in so much of our public policy in tones
any louder than muted regret will be marginalized for this indecorous transgression
as a leftist, a bleeding-heart liberal or perhaps a raging populist, but
in any event someone so out of the "mainstream" as not to be taken seriously.
How many in Congress today have the integrity, the strength, to distinguish
the interests of their districts or their states from the interests of their
heavy donors? How many think there is a difference? How many can honestly
admit to themselves that the big money is their constituency? To hear the
points of view of some of these people, how they have become so much the
forces that have bought them, is to realize they are no longer guilty of
hypocrisy, having been transmogrified.

The instructive image here is from
Dante's Inferno, Canto XXV. We are in a pouch of the Eighth Circle, where
the thieves are kept. A monstrous lizardlike serpent leaps onto one of the
thieves, wraps its middle feet around his belly, pins his two arms with
its forelegs and, wrapping its rear feet around his knees, swings its tail
up between his legs and sinks its teeth into his face. And so intertwined,
monster and thief, they begin to melt into each other like hot wax, their
two heads joining, their substances merging, until a new third creature
is created, though somehow redolent of both of them. And it slowly slithers
away into the darkness.
* * *

Back in 1787, when the Constitutional Convention
had done its work and the drafted Constitution was sent out to the states
for ratification, the public's excitement was palpable. Extended and vigorous
statehouse debates echoed through the towns and villages, and as, one by
one, the states voted to ratify, church bells rang, cheers went up from
the public houses and in the major cities the people turned out to parade
with a fresh new sense of themselves as a nation.

Everyone marched--tradespeople,
workingmen, soldiers, women, clergy. They had floats in those days, too--most
often a wagon-sized ship of state, called the Union, rolling through the
streets with children waving from the scuppers. Philadelphia came up with
a float called the New Roof, a dome supported by thirteen pillars and ornamented
with stars. It was drawn by ten white horses, and at the top was a handsome
cupola surmounted by a figure of Plenty, bearing her cornucopia.

The ratification
parades were sacramental--symbolic venerations, acts of faith. From the
beginning people saw the Constitution as a kind of sacred text for a civil
society. Indeed, the voice of the Constitution is scriptural. It ordains.
It empowers itself to give law endlessly into the future. Like the Bible,
it requires interpretive commentaries that themselves have the authority
of law because its principles must be applied to a multitude of situations.
And where its prophecy has been false, as in the infamous Article IV, which
made a slave in one state a slave in all, the national calamity of a civil
war ensued before the text could be amended.

Today, the Constitution with
its Bill of Rights and further amendments rules us with a set of behavioral
prescriptions that, if we lived up to all of them, would make us a truly
free and righteous people. When the ancient Hebrews broke their covenant
they suffered a loss of identity and brought disaster upon themselves. Our
burden too is unmistakably covenantal. We may point to our 200-some years
of national survival as an open society, constitutionally sworn to a degree
of free imaginative expression that few cultures in the world can tolerate;
we may regard ourselves as an exceptional, historically self-correcting
nation whose democratic values locate us just as surely as our geography...
and yet we know at the same time that all through our history we have brutally
excluded vast numbers of us from the shelter of the New Roof, we have broken
our covenant again and again with a virtuosity verging on damnation and have
been saved only by the sacrificial efforts of Constitution-reverencing patriots
in government and out of government--Presidents, senators, Justices, abolitionists,
muckrakers, suffragists, striking workers, civil rights activists.
 What
is to be done now, when the Constitution is subjected to corporate-groomed politicians
who read it as no more than a postmodern self-deconstructing text? The present
wide-open, scandalous system of campaign financing is rationalized by a
rightist ideology that portrays the federal government as stiflingly bureaucratic,
intrusive and inimical to the natural rights of a free people. In the lifetimes
of many of us the federal government has been just the opposite, a means
of redress, redemptive justice and societal healing, as, for instance, when
it enacted the Depression measures of the thirties and the Great Society
legislation of the sixties. Today the corporate rightists in Congress mean
to privatize the Social Security system, vouch the public school system
out of existence and do whatever they can to limit if not decimate the regulatory
agencies established to control their worst business excesses. By the logic
of their thinking even the National Office of Weights and Measures could
be construed as an impediment to business practices.

It is not that members
of Congress--or indeed the media or the American public--are not aware of
the inequity of the present money-soaked system of political life in our
country. But to what extent that system is responsible for the grotesque
distortions of our present priorities--with the resultant poverty of so
many children; the way our jails proliferate for the incarceration of black
men, with more and more penal systems run privately for profit; the drift
into monopolization of our media and means of communication, with fewer
and fewer mega-corporations controlling more and more of what we read, see,
hear or understand as the news; or the cost of health insurance policies
that insure people until they get sick; the inequitable tax structure; the
international trade agreements that rescind our environmental laws; the
list is long--and how all of this is connected to the system of unrestricted
and flamboyant political donations may not be always appreciated by the
public or acknowledged consistently even by those members of Congress who
have voted to reform the laws of campaign finance.

In fact, campaign finance
reform as a phrase has been bruited about so long and to so little effect
and is so yawningly dull, dreary and unresounding, it makes one wonder if
it's not partly responsible for the conditions it has so far failed to address.
Perhaps there is a basement office somewhere in Washington where mischievous
lexicographers of a certain political orientation have the assigned task
of finding the words and phrases to defuse the issues that threaten the
interests of their employers. If so, campaign finance reform has done its
work well. Because what is hidden in that modest little phrase is the vision
of an honest, vigorously realized democratic republic.
* * *

To effect
a true and thoroughgoing reform would not change the innately raucous competition
of interests among us, but neither would it provide for the amplification
of some of those interests to a level that is deafening. It would amount
to a kind of revolution of our national political behavior; it would bring
people of talent and vision into political life who are not now available
to the nation; it would be breathtaking, predictive of a new authentic polyvocal
Union; and with the possibility, at last, of addressing our entrenched social
and economic inequities, the distortions of our priorities and what is grotesque
about our public institutions, we would begin to come out of the terrible
alienation that afflicts us and think again of the beauty of our national
promise. We would hope to fashion ourselves more recognizably to the ideal
of human rights implicit in our Constitution.

Perhaps, then, we should
not rely on Congress to find the votes to pass a true and thorough reform
bill that restores to us our dignity as citizens. A genuine ad hoc social
movement may be required, a state-by-state struggle by referendum, issue-specific
ratings at election time, an Internet-organized lobby to end all lobbies,
but in any event something--some great public outcry to flatten back the
ears of the distinguished colleagues in their paneled chambers.

To imagine
such glory is to invoke the idealism of Walt Whitman. Whitman did not buy
the elitist presumption of classic conservatism--that it was in the nature
of some to lead and most to follow--even as it claimed to recognize its
responsibility (as it does not now in its corporatized form) to look after,
to take care of, as one looks after or takes care of children or pets. He
saw it as a terrible depressant of human energies. He understood American
democracy's breakout potential to enlarge the dimensions of human life,
and thought that if the discourse was truly national, the communications
omni-directional, the minds of a populace living in neighborly freedom could
constellate into a universe that we hadn't yet dreamed of. That is why when
he walked the streets of nineteenth-century New York, Whitman embraced everything
he saw. He loved the multitudes, the industry of working people; he loved
the ships in the harbor, the traffic on Broadway. But he was not naïve.
He knew the newspaper business from which he made his living relied finally
for its success on the frail shoulders of itinerant boys and girls, street
urchins who lived on the few cents they made hawking the papers at every
corner. Thousands of vagrant children lived in the streets of the New York
Walt Whitman loved. Yet his exultant optimism and awe of human capacity
was not demeaned; he could carry it all, the whole society, and attend like
a nurse to its illnesses, but like a lover to its fair face.

And so must we.



----------------------------------------------------------------------------
E.L. Doctorow's latest novel is City of God (Random House).

Subject:Interesting Article from The Nation
Message:

I think you'll like this.

Brian Villa thought this item from the The Nation Magazine would be of interest to you.

For more articles like the one you're about to read, visit The Nation website at http://www.thenation.com. Featuring editorials, essays, news and views as well as special subscription offers to The Nation, this site is the place to go for provocative, hard-hitting reporting you can't find anywhere else.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------


IN THE EIGHTH CIRCLE OF THIEVES



by E. L. DOCTOROW


Click here for our special election-season website.



Eased into governance
by years and years of conservative ideology, the corporations of America
today effectively oversee the Congress, the regulatory agencies and indeed
the presidency itself. There is no Article in the Constitution that recognizes
the supracitizenship of conglomerates; nothing is written that grants enlarged
and pre-emptive voting rights to business organizations and their trade
groups. But as Washington is run today, major issues of public policy are
bent and distorted by these multiheaded Brobdingnags who bribe Congress
with their money and coddle it with their lobbies, so that time and time
again socially desirable legislation in the public interest, whether having
to do with public health or safety, environmental protection, preservation
of our natural resources or any other issue of clear relevance to the entire
society, is defeated, sabotaged or transmuted by language into its perverse
opposite.

Yes, you say, tell me about it. But this is the recurrent truth
of Washington, so rhythmically repetitive as to be its heartbeat, the way
it pumps. Corporations that pit themselves against the manifest needs of
the American people according to the issues that arise take turns as enemies
of the people. Nothing else on Capitol Hill occurs so reliably and regularly.
It so prevails as a political fact of life that it is hardly news. It has
been a long, long time since it was news. It is now only and obviously the
way things are. Banking, oil, lumber, pharmaceuticals, weaponry, communications
and electronics, chemicals, meat and poultry--whatever the industry, you'll
find it striding with a proprietary mien through the corridors of power.
But in the name of what kind of Constitution?

Apologists will cite the
First Amendment, speak of the American or God-given right of people to function
in their own interest. That is just what democracy is, they say, a raucous
contention of interests that historically proves out as the genius of our
system; it is what we have always done in this country right from the start,
when frontiersmen in coonskin caps and leggings came to town, and later
the men in cutaways and top hats, everyone, always, grabbing their representatives
by the lapels and demanding to be represented.

But conglomerated organizations
of capital are not exactly people. They are compositions of human talents
formatted to their purposes. They are dedicated networks of artificial intelligence.
They think and feel in numerical abstractions. They will advertise their
employees as their human face, they will give themselves hearts and souls
in their television commercials, but as institutions they are dimensionally
beyond the humans who work for them or the shareholders who gamble in their
stock. They transform themselves, take on or divest themselves of companies,
move across national boundaries, restructure, wax and wane, merge with others
of their ilk in an institutionalized dynamic that leaves even their executives
irrelevant. They are profit manufactories that accumulate people or rid
themselves of people according to the transhuman logic of their balance
sheets. And for the loyalty they demand and receive, the quid pro quo is
to absolve those working for them who act inhumanely on their inhuman behalf.
* * *

In effect corporate entities that function in Washington to achieve
benefits for themselves--tax loopholes, contracts, entitlements, dismantling
of regulatory acts--regardless of the overall social effect, pre-empt the
idea of the larger community, the national ideal, the United States as the
ultimate communal reality. A just nation is not envisioned but a confederacy
whose people are meant to live at the expense of one another. Such social
Darwinism finds the presumptions of democracy naïve. The corporations
that will farm our lands, insure our lives and our health, finance our homes,
entertain us, power our cars, light our lamps... ask only one thing in return:
that we recognize two forms of citizenship, common and preferred.

How contemptuous
this all is, what an enormous humiliation to a society of free people. We
may ask those who speak of this corrupt and corrupting system as a kind
of speech that mustn't be tampered with, if to privilege the free speech
of corporations with vast treasuries on those grounds is not undeniably
to squelch the speech of others who don't have the same resources. Or if,
in fact, this huge application of money to the political process that so
depreciates the power of the individual voter is not a de facto poll tax,
with the expected minorities, Afro-American, Hispanic, joined in their disfranchisement
by the white citizenry.

To consider the elected politician in all this
is to mourn the days when amateurism was part of the political culture.
Somewhere along the line political officeholding became a profession. To
keep working, politicians have regularly to come like buskers into the street,
sing their song and dance their jig and hold out their hats. In the best
of them, this ritual has to induce a degree of self-hatred. Television is
the major reason campaigning is so monstrously expensive. The airwaves are
owned by the public, but that is irrelevant to the broadcast licensees,
who charge commercial rates for programming in the public interest... and
then contribute heavily to campaigns, so that no one who is elected will
get up in Congress and say what a swindle it is for the broadcasters to
charge the public for the use of airwaves the public owns.
* * *

The fundraising
dinners are affairs of the wealthy. If you are a politician, the fatter
the check that comes in, the greater your indebtedness. Your conscience
becomes an instrument of self-deception. Some politicians are entirely at
ease with this, either because they are themselves wealthy and are one with
their contributors, or so reliably conformed to the values of the plutocracy
that they rise up fully banked--as for example the Governor of Texas, noted
for his rigorous support for the death penalty and for the civil rights
of heavily polluting industries, who miraculously appeared in all the papers
two years before the primaries as a front-runner and who now floats atop
a campaign fund of $80 million.

What kind of political culture does the
politician cheerfully acknowledge, who can say, as Republican Senator Orrin
Hatch has said, that to back reform of the system of campaign money-raising
would be an idiotic thing for his party because it collects more money than
the opposition? What degree of public alienation can a politician like Senate
majority leader Trent Lott depend on, who has brazenly said in sponsoring
legislation written by corporate lobbyists... that after all they are the
specialists in their field, who know the issues better than anyone else?
These are the remarks of senators confident of a general population so numbed
and alienated that barely 50 percent of eligible adults bother to vote in
national elections. These are the flaunted values of politicians who know
of the conglomerate-owned press culture, that there will be no editorial
muckraking from the "in depth" journalists of the broadcast media, that
the rampant corruption in Washington, the vast, deep and dangerous mutant
character of the present state of things, will not be defined for what it
is, and that who speaks of the bewildering broad front of failure and mendacity
and carelessness of human life in so much of our public policy in tones
any louder than muted regret will be marginalized for this indecorous transgression
as a leftist, a bleeding-heart liberal or perhaps a raging populist, but
in any event someone so out of the "mainstream" as not to be taken seriously.
How many in Congress today have the integrity, the strength, to distinguish
the interests of their districts or their states from the interests of their
heavy donors? How many think there is a difference? How many can honestly
admit to themselves that the big money is their constituency? To hear the
points of view of some of these people, how they have become so much the
forces that have bought them, is to realize they are no longer guilty of
hypocrisy, having been transmogrified.

The instructive image here is from
Dante's Inferno, Canto XXV. We are in a pouch of the Eighth Circle, where
the thieves are kept. A monstrous lizardlike serpent leaps onto one of the
thieves, wraps its middle feet around his belly, pins his two arms with
its forelegs and, wrapping its rear feet around his knees, swings its tail
up between his legs and sinks its teeth into his face. And so intertwined,
monster and thief, they begin to melt into each other like hot wax, their
two heads joining, their substances merging, until a new third creature
is created, though somehow redolent of both of them. And it slowly slithers
away into the darkness.
* * *

Back in 1787, when the Constitutional Convention
had done its work and the drafted Constitution was sent out to the states
for ratification, the public's excitement was palpable. Extended and vigorous
statehouse debates echoed through the towns and villages, and as, one by
one, the states voted to ratify, church bells rang, cheers went up from
the public houses and in the major cities the people turned out to parade
with a fresh new sense of themselves as a nation.

Everyone marched--tradespeople,
workingmen, soldiers, women, clergy. They had floats in those days, too--most
often a wagon-sized ship of state, called the Union, rolling through the
streets with children waving from the scuppers. Philadelphia came up with
a float called the New Roof, a dome supported by thirteen pillars and ornamented
with stars. It was drawn by ten white horses, and at the top was a handsome
cupola surmounted by a figure of Plenty, bearing her cornucopia.

The ratification
parades were sacramental--symbolic venerations, acts of faith. From the
beginning people saw the Constitution as a kind of sacred text for a civil
society. Indeed, the voice of the Constitution is scriptural. It ordains.
It empowers itself to give law endlessly into the future. Like the Bible,
it requires interpretive commentaries that themselves have the authority
of law because its principles must be applied to a multitude of situations.
And where its prophecy has been false, as in the infamous Article IV, which
made a slave in one state a slave in all, the national calamity of a civil
war ensued before the text could be amended.

Today, the Constitution with
its Bill of Rights and further amendments rules us with a set of behavioral
prescriptions that, if we lived up to all of them, would make us a truly
free and righteous people. When the ancient Hebrews broke their covenant
they suffered a loss of identity and brought disaster upon themselves. Our
burden too is unmistakably covenantal. We may point to our 200-some years
of national survival as an open society, constitutionally sworn to a degree
of free imaginative expression that few cultures in the world can tolerate;
we may regard ourselves as an exceptional, historically self-correcting
nation whose democratic values locate us just as surely as our geography...
and yet we know at the same time that all through our history we have brutally
excluded vast numbers of us from the shelter of the New Roof, we have broken
our covenant again and again with a virtuosity verging on damnation and have
been saved only by the sacrificial efforts of Constitution-reverencing patriots
in government and out of government--Presidents, senators, Justices, abolitionists,
muckrakers, suffragists, striking workers, civil rights activists.
 What
is to be done now, when the Constitution is subjected to corporate-groomed politicians
who read it as no more than a postmodern self-deconstructing text? The present
wide-open, scandalous system of campaign financing is rationalized by a
rightist ideology that portrays the federal government as stiflingly bureaucratic,
intrusive and inimical to the natural rights of a free people. In the lifetimes
of many of us the federal government has been just the opposite, a means
of redress, redemptive justice and societal healing, as, for instance, when
it enacted the Depression measures of the thirties and the Great Society
legislation of the sixties. Today the corporate rightists in Congress mean
to privatize the Social Security system, vouch the public school system
out of existence and do whatever they can to limit if not decimate the regulatory
agencies established to control their worst business excesses. By the logic
of their thinking even the National Office of Weights and Measures could
be construed as an impediment to business practices.

It is not that members
of Congress--or indeed the media or the American public--are not aware of
the inequity of the present money-soaked system of political life in our
country. But to what extent that system is responsible for the grotesque
distortions of our present priorities--with the resultant poverty of so
many children; the way our jails proliferate for the incarceration of black
men, with more and more penal systems run privately for profit; the drift
into monopolization of our media and means of communication, with fewer
and fewer mega-corporations controlling more and more of what we read, see,
hear or understand as the news; or the cost of health insurance policies
that insure people until they get sick; the inequitable tax structure; the
international trade agreements that rescind our environmental laws; the
list is long--and how all of this is connected to the system of unrestricted
and flamboyant political donations may not be always appreciated by the
public or acknowledged consistently even by those members of Congress who
have voted to reform the laws of campaign finance.

In fact, campaign finance
reform as a phrase has been bruited about so long and to so little effect
and is so yawningly dull, dreary and unresounding, it makes one wonder if
it's not partly responsible for the conditions it has so far failed to address.
Perhaps there is a basement office somewhere in Washington where mischievous
lexicographers of a certain political orientation have the assigned task
of finding the words and phrases to defuse the issues that threaten the
interests of their employers. If so, campaign finance reform has done its
work well. Because what is hidden in that modest little phrase is the vision
of an honest, vigorously realized democratic republic.
* * *

To effect
a true and thoroughgoing reform would not change the innately raucous competition
of interests among us, but neither would it provide for the amplification
of some of those interests to a level that is deafening. It would amount
to a kind of revolution of our national political behavior; it would bring
people of talent and vision into political life who are not now available
to the nation; it would be breathtaking, predictive of a new authentic polyvocal
Union; and with the possibility, at last, of addressing our entrenched social
and economic inequities, the distortions of our priorities and what is grotesque
about our public institutions, we would begin to come out of the terrible
alienation that afflicts us and think again of the beauty of our national
promise. We would hope to fashion ourselves more recognizably to the ideal
of human rights implicit in our Constitution.

Perhaps, then, we should
not rely on Congress to find the votes to pass a true and thorough reform
bill that restores to us our dignity as citizens. A genuine ad hoc social
movement may be required, a state-by-state struggle by referendum, issue-specific
ratings at election time, an Internet-organized lobby to end all lobbies,
but in any event something--some great public outcry to flatten back the
ears of the distinguished colleagues in their paneled chambers.

To imagine
such glory is to invoke the idealism of Walt Whitman. Whitman did not buy
the elitist presumption of classic conservatism--that it was in the nature
of some to lead and most to follow--even as it claimed to recognize its
responsibility (as it does not now in its corporatized form) to look after,
to take care of, as one looks after or takes care of children or pets. He
saw it as a terrible depressant of human energies. He understood American
democracy's breakout potential to enlarge the dimensions of human life,
and thought that if the discourse was truly national, the communications
omni-directional, the minds of a populace living in neighborly freedom could
constellate into a universe that we hadn't yet dreamed of. That is why when
he walked the streets of nineteenth-century New York, Whitman embraced everything
he saw. He loved the multitudes, the industry of working people; he loved
the ships in the harbor, the traffic on Broadway. But he was not naïve.
He knew the newspaper business from which he made his living relied finally
for its success on the frail shoulders of itinerant boys and girls, street
urchins who lived on the few cents they made hawking the papers at every
corner. Thousands of vagrant children lived in the streets of the New York
Walt Whitman loved. Yet his exultant optimism and awe of human capacity
was not demeaned; he could carry it all, the whole society, and attend like
a nurse to its illnesses, but like a lover to its fair face.

And so must we.



----------------------------------------------------------------------------
E.L. Doctorow's latest novel is City of God (Random House).
