IN THE EIGHTH CIRCLE OF THIEVES



by E. L. DOCTOROW


Click here for our special election-season website.



Eased into governance
by years and years of conservative ideology, the corporations of America
today effectively oversee the Congress, the regulatory agencies and indeed
the presidency itself. There is no Article in the Constitution that recognizes
the supracitizenship of conglomerates; nothing is written that grants enlarged
and pre-emptive voting rights to business organizations and their trade
groups. But as Washington is run today, major issues of public policy are
bent and distorted by these multiheaded Brobdingnags who bribe Congress
with their money and coddle it with their lobbies, so that time and time
again socially desirable legislation in the public interest, whether having
to do with public health or safety, environmental protection, preservation
of our natural resources or any other issue of clear relevance to the entire
society, is defeated, sabotaged or transmuted by language into its perverse
opposite.

Yes, you say, tell me about it. But this is the recurrent truth
of Washington, so rhythmically repetitive as to be its heartbeat, the way
it pumps. Corporations that pit themselves against the manifest needs of
the American people according to the issues that arise take turns as enemies
of the people. Nothing else on Capitol Hill occurs so reliably and regularly.
It so prevails as a political fact of life that it is hardly news. It has
been a long, long time since it was news. It is now only and obviously the
way things are. Banking, oil, lumber, pharmaceuticals, weaponry, communications
and electronics, chemicals, meat and poultry--whatever the industry, you'll
find it striding with a proprietary mien through the corridors of power.
But in the name of what kind of Constitution?

Apologists will cite the
First Amendment, speak of the American or God-given right of people to function
in their own interest. That is just what democracy is, they say, a raucous
contention of interests that historically proves out as the genius of our
system; it is what we have always done in this country right from the start,
when frontiersmen in coonskin caps and leggings came to town, and later
the men in cutaways and top hats, everyone, always, grabbing their representatives
by the lapels and demanding to be represented.

But conglomerated organizations
of capital are not exactly people. They are compositions of human talents
formatted to their purposes. They are dedicated networks of artificial intelligence.
They think and feel in numerical abstractions. They will advertise their
employees as their human face, they will give themselves hearts and souls
in their television commercials, but as institutions they are dimensionally
beyond the humans who work for them or the shareholders who gamble in their
stock. They transform themselves, take on or divest themselves of companies,
move across national boundaries, restructure, wax and wane, merge with others
of their ilk in an institutionalized dynamic that leaves even their executives
irrelevant. They are profit manufactories that accumulate people or rid
themselves of people according to the transhuman logic of their balance
sheets. And for the loyalty they demand and receive, the quid pro quo is
to absolve those working for them who act inhumanely on their inhuman behalf.
* * *

In effect corporate entities that function in Washington to achieve
benefits for themselves--tax loopholes, contracts, entitlements, dismantling
of regulatory acts--regardless of the overall social effect, pre-empt the
idea of the larger community, the national ideal, the United States as the
ultimate communal reality. A just nation is not envisioned but a confederacy
whose people are meant to live at the expense of one another. Such social
Darwinism finds the presumptions of democracy naïve. The corporations
that will farm our lands, insure our lives and our health, finance our homes,
entertain us, power our cars, light our lamps... ask only one thing in return:
that we recognize two forms of citizenship, common and preferred.

How contemptuous
this all is, what an enormous humiliation to a society of free people. We
may ask those who speak of this corrupt and corrupting system as a kind
of speech that mustn't be tampered with, if to privilege the free speech
of corporations with vast treasuries on those grounds is not undeniably
to squelch the speech of others who don't have the same resources. Or if,
in fact, this huge application of money to the political process that so
depreciates the power of the individual voter is not a de facto poll tax,
with the expected minorities, Afro-American, Hispanic, joined in their disfranchisement
by the white citizenry.

To consider the elected politician in all this
is to mourn the days when amateurism was part of the political culture.
Somewhere along the line political officeholding became a profession. To
keep working, politicians have regularly to come like buskers into the street,
sing their song and dance their jig and hold out their hats. In the best
of them, this ritual has to induce a degree of self-hatred. Television is
the major reason campaigning is so monstrously expensive. The airwaves are
owned by the public, but that is irrelevant to the broadcast licensees,
who charge commercial rates for programming in the public interest... and
then contribute heavily to campaigns, so that no one who is elected will
get up in Congress and say what a swindle it is for the broadcasters to
charge the public for the use of airwaves the public owns.
* * *

The fundraising
dinners are affairs of the wealthy. If you are a politician, the fatter
the check that comes in, the greater your indebtedness. Your conscience
becomes an instrument of self-deception. Some politicians are entirely at
ease with this, either because they are themselves wealthy and are one with
their contributors, or so reliably conformed to the values of the plutocracy
that they rise up fully banked--as for example the Governor of Texas, noted
for his rigorous support for the death penalty and for the civil rights
of heavily polluting industries, who miraculously appeared in all the papers
two years before the primaries as a front-runner and who now floats atop
a campaign fund of $80 million.

What kind of political culture does the
politician cheerfully acknowledge, who can say, as Republican Senator Orrin
Hatch has said, that to back reform of the system of campaign money-raising
would be an idiotic thing for his party because it collects more money than
the opposition? What degree of public alienation can a politician like Senate
majority leader Trent Lott depend on, who has brazenly said in sponsoring
legislation written by corporate lobbyists... that after all they are the
specialists in their field, who know the issues better than anyone else?
These are the remarks of senators confident of a general population so numbed
and alienated that barely 50 percent of eligible adults bother to vote in
national elections. These are the flaunted values of politicians who know
of the conglomerate-owned press culture, that there will be no editorial
muckraking from the "in depth" journalists of the broadcast media, that
the rampant corruption in Washington, the vast, deep and dangerous mutant
character of the present state of things, will not be defined for what it
is, and that who speaks of the bewildering broad front of failure and mendacity
and carelessness of human life in so much of our public policy in tones
any louder than muted regret will be marginalized for this indecorous transgression
as a leftist, a bleeding-heart liberal or perhaps a raging populist, but
in any event someone so out of the "mainstream" as not to be taken seriously.
How many in Congress today have the integrity, the strength, to distinguish
the interests of their districts or their states from the interests of their
heavy donors? How many think there is a difference? How many can honestly
admit to themselves that the big money is their constituency? To hear the
points of view of some of these people, how they have become so much the
forces that have bought them, is to realize they are no longer guilty of
hypocrisy, having been transmogrified.

The instructive image here is from
Dante's Inferno, Canto XXV. We are in a pouch of the Eighth Circle, where
the thieves are kept. A monstrous lizardlike serpent leaps onto one of the
thieves, wraps its middle feet around his belly, pins his two arms with
its forelegs and, wrapping its rear feet around his knees, swings its tail
up between his legs and sinks its teeth into his face. And so intertwined,
monster and thief, they begin to melt into each other like hot wax, their
two heads joining, their substances merging, until a new third creature
is created, though somehow redolent of both of them. And it slowly slithers
away into the darkness.
* * *

Back in 1787, when the Constitutional Convention
had done its work and the drafted Constitution was sent out to the states
for ratification, the public's excitement was palpable. Extended and vigorous
statehouse debates echoed through the towns and villages, and as, one by
one, the states voted to ratify, church bells rang, cheers went up from
the public houses and in the major cities the people turned out to parade
with a fresh new sense of themselves as a nation.

Everyone marched--tradespeople,
workingmen, soldiers, women, clergy. They had floats in those days, too--most
often a wagon-sized ship of state, called the Union, rolling through the
streets with children waving from the scuppers. Philadelphia came up with
a float called the New Roof, a dome supported by thirteen pillars and ornamented
with stars. It was drawn by ten white horses, and at the top was a handsome
cupola surmounted by a figure of Plenty, bearing her cornucopia.

The ratification
parades were sacramental--symbolic venerations, acts of faith. From the
beginning people saw the Constitution as a kind of sacred text for a civil
society. Indeed, the voice of the Constitution is scriptural. It ordains.
It empowers itself to give law endlessly into the future. Like the Bible,
it requires interpretive commentaries that themselves have the authority
of law because its principles must be applied to a multitude of situations.
And where its prophecy has been false, as in the infamous Article IV, which
made a slave in one state a slave in all, the national calamity of a civil
war ensued before the text could be amended.

Today, the Constitution with
its Bill of Rights and further amendments rules us with a set of behavioral
prescriptions that, if we lived up to all of them, would make us a truly
free and righteous people. When the ancient Hebrews broke their covenant
they suffered a loss of identity and brought disaster upon themselves. Our
burden too is unmistakably covenantal. We may point to our 200-some years
of national survival as an open society, constitutionally sworn to a degree
of free imaginative expression that few cultures in the world can tolerate;
we may regard ourselves as an exceptional, historically self-correcting
nation whose democratic values locate us just as surely as our geography...
and yet we know at the same time that all through our history we have brutally
excluded vast numbers of us from the shelter of the New Roof, we have broken
our covenant again and again with a virtuosity verging on damnation and have
been saved only by the sacrificial efforts of Constitution-reverencing patriots
in government and out of government--Presidents, senators, Justices, abolitionists,
muckrakers, suffragists, striking workers, civil rights activists.
 What
is to be done now, when the Constitution is subjected to corporate-groomed politicians
who read it as no more than a postmodern self-deconstructing text? The present
wide-open, scandalous system of campaign financing is rationalized by a
rightist ideology that portrays the federal government as stiflingly bureaucratic,
intrusive and inimical to the natural rights of a free people. In the lifetimes
of many of us the federal government has been just the opposite, a means
of redress, redemptive justice and societal healing, as, for instance, when
it enacted the Depression measures of the thirties and the Great Society
legislation of the sixties. Today the corporate rightists in Congress mean
to privatize the Social Security system, vouch the public school system
out of existence and do whatever they can to limit if not decimate the regulatory
agencies established to control their worst business excesses. By the logic
of their thinking even the National Office of Weights and Measures could
be construed as an impediment to business practices.

It is not that members
of Congress--or indeed the media or the American public--are not aware of
the inequity of the present money-soaked system of political life in our
country. But to what extent that system is responsible for the grotesque
distortions of our present priorities--with the resultant poverty of so
many children; the way our jails proliferate for the incarceration of black
men, with more and more penal systems run privately for profit; the drift
into monopolization of our media and means of communication, with fewer
and fewer mega-corporations controlling more and more of what we read, see,
hear or understand as the news; or the cost of health insurance policies
that insure people until they get sick; the inequitable tax structure; the
international trade agreements that rescind our environmental laws; the
list is long--and how all of this is connected to the system of unrestricted
and flamboyant political donations may not be always appreciated by the
public or acknowledged consistently even by those members of Congress who
have voted to reform the laws of campaign finance.

In fact, campaign finance
reform as a phrase has been bruited about so long and to so little effect
and is so yawningly dull, dreary and unresounding, it makes one wonder if
it's not partly responsible for the conditions it has so far failed to address.
Perhaps there is a basement office somewhere in Washington where mischievous
lexicographers of a certain political orientation have the assigned task
of finding the words and phrases to defuse the issues that threaten the
interests of their employers. If so, campaign finance reform has done its
work well. Because what is hidden in that modest little phrase is the vision
of an honest, vigorously realized democratic republic.
* * *

To effect
a true and thoroughgoing reform would not change the innately raucous competition
of interests among us, but neither would it provide for the amplification
of some of those interests to a level that is deafening. It would amount
to a kind of revolution of our national political behavior; it would bring
people of talent and vision into political life who are not now available
to the nation; it would be breathtaking, predictive of a new authentic polyvocal
Union; and with the possibility, at last, of addressing our entrenched social
and economic inequities, the distortions of our priorities and what is grotesque
about our public institutions, we would begin to come out of the terrible
alienation that afflicts us and think again of the beauty of our national
promise. We would hope to fashion ourselves more recognizably to the ideal
of human rights implicit in our Constitution.

Perhaps, then, we should
not rely on Congress to find the votes to pass a true and thorough reform
bill that restores to us our dignity as citizens. A genuine ad hoc social
movement may be required, a state-by-state struggle by referendum, issue-specific
ratings at election time, an Internet-organized lobby to end all lobbies,
but in any event something--some great public outcry to flatten back the
ears of the distinguished colleagues in their paneled chambers.

To imagine
such glory is to invoke the idealism of Walt Whitman. Whitman did not buy
the elitist presumption of classic conservatism--that it was in the nature
of some to lead and most to follow--even as it claimed to recognize its
responsibility (as it does not now in its corporatized form) to look after,
to take care of, as one looks after or takes care of children or pets. He
saw it as a terrible depressant of human energies. He understood American
democracy's breakout potential to enlarge the dimensions of human life,
and thought that if the discourse was truly national, the communications
omni-directional, the minds of a populace living in neighborly freedom could
constellate into a universe that we hadn't yet dreamed of. That is why when
he walked the streets of nineteenth-century New York, Whitman embraced everything
he saw. He loved the multitudes, the industry of working people; he loved
the ships in the harbor, the traffic on Broadway. But he was not naïve.
He knew the newspaper business from which he made his living relied finally
for its success on the frail shoulders of itinerant boys and girls, street
urchins who lived on the few cents they made hawking the papers at every
corner. Thousands of vagrant children lived in the streets of the New York
Walt Whitman loved. Yet his exultant optimism and awe of human capacity
was not demeaned; he could carry it all, the whole society, and attend like
a nurse to its illnesses, but like a lover to its fair face.

And so must we.



----------------------------------------------------------------------------
E.L. Doctorow's latest novel is City of God (Random House).

----------------------------------------------------------------------------


IN THE EIGHTH CIRCLE OF THIEVES



by E. L. DOCTOROW


Click here for our special election-season website.



Eased into governance
by years and years of conservative ideology, the corporations of America
today effectively oversee the Congress, the regulatory agencies and indeed
the presidency itself. There is no Article in the Constitution that recognizes
the supracitizenship of conglomerates; nothing is written that grants enlarged
and pre-emptive voting rights to business organizations and their trade
groups. But as Washington is run today, major issues of public policy are
bent and distorted by these multiheaded Brobdingnags who bribe Congress
with their money and coddle it with their lobbies, so that time and time
again socially desirable legislation in the public interest, whether having
to do with public health or safety, environmental protection, preservation
of our natural resources or any other issue of clear relevance to the entire
society, is defeated, sabotaged or transmuted by language into its perverse
opposite.

Yes, you say, tell me about it. But this is the recurrent truth
of Washington, so rhythmically repetitive as to be its heartbeat, the way
it pumps. Corporations that pit themselves against the manifest needs of
the American people according to the issues that arise take turns as enemies
of the people. Nothing else on Capitol Hill occurs so reliably and regularly.
It so prevails as a political fact of life that it is hardly news. It has
been a long, long time since it was news. It is now only and obviously the
way things are. Banking, oil, lumber, pharmaceuticals, weaponry, communications
and electronics, chemicals, meat and poultry--whatever the industry, you'll
find it striding with a proprietary mien through the corridors of power.
But in the name of what kind of Constitution?

Apologists will cite the
First Amendment, speak of the American or God-given right of people to function
in their own interest. That is just what democracy is, they say, a raucous
contention of interests that historically proves out as the genius of our
system; it is what we have always done in this country right from the start,
when frontiersmen in coonskin caps and leggings came to town, and later
the men in cutaways and top hats, everyone, always, grabbing their representatives
by the lapels and demanding to be represented.

But conglomerated organizations
of capital are not exactly people. They are compositions of human talents
formatted to their purposes. They are dedicated networks of artificial intelligence.
They think and feel in numerical abstractions. They will advertise their
employees as their human face, they will give themselves hearts and souls
in their television commercials, but as institutions they are dimensionally
beyond the humans who work for them or the shareholders who gamble in their
stock. They transform themselves, take on or divest themselves of companies,
move across national boundaries, restructure, wax and wane, merge with others
of their ilk in an institutionalized dynamic that leaves even their executives
irrelevant. They are profit manufactories that accumulate people or rid
themselves of people according to the transhuman logic of their balance
sheets. And for the loyalty they demand and receive, the quid pro quo is
to absolve those working for them who act inhumanely on their inhuman behalf.
* * *

In effect corporate entities that function in Washington to achieve
benefits for themselves--tax loopholes, contracts, entitlements, dismantling
of regulatory acts--regardless of the overall social effect, pre-empt the
idea of the larger community, the national ideal, the United States as the
ultimate communal reality. A just nation is not envisioned but a confederacy
whose people are meant to live at the expense of one another. Such social
Darwinism finds the presumptions of democracy naïve. The corporations
that will farm our lands, insure our lives and our health, finance our homes,
entertain us, power our cars, light our lamps... ask only one thing in return:
that we recognize two forms of citizenship, common and preferred.

How contemptuous
this all is, what an enormous humiliation to a society of free people. We
may ask those who speak of this corrupt and corrupting system as a kind
of speech that mustn't be tampered with, if to privilege the free speech
of corporations with vast treasuries on those grounds is not undeniably
to squelch the speech of others who don't have the same resources. Or if,
in fact, this huge application of money to the political process that so
depreciates the power of the individual voter is not a de facto poll tax,
with the expected minorities, Afro-American, Hispanic, joined in their disfranchisement
by the white citizenry.

To consider the elected politician in all this
is to mourn the days when amateurism was part of the political culture.
Somewhere along the line political officeholding became a profession. To
keep working, politicians have regularly to come like buskers into the street,
sing their song and dance their jig and hold out their hats. In the best
of them, this ritual has to induce a degree of self-hatred. Television is
the major reason campaigning is so monstrously expensive. The airwaves are
owned by the public, but that is irrelevant to the broadcast licensees,
who charge commercial rates for programming in the public interest... and
then contribute heavily to campaigns, so that no one who is elected will
get up in Congress and say what a swindle it is for the broadcasters to
charge the public for the use of airwaves the public owns.
* * *

The fundraising
dinners are affairs of the wealthy. If you are a politician, the fatter
the check that comes in, the greater your indebtedness. Your conscience
becomes an instrument of self-deception. Some politicians are entirely at
ease with this, either because they are themselves wealthy and are one with
their contributors, or so reliably conformed to the values of the plutocracy
that they rise up fully banked--as for example the Governor of Texas, noted
for his rigorous support for the death penalty and for the civil rights
of heavily polluting industries, who miraculously appeared in all the papers
two years before the primaries as a front-runner and who now floats atop
a campaign fund of $80 million.

What kind of political culture does the
politician cheerfully acknowledge, who can say, as Republican Senator Orrin
Hatch has said, that to back reform of the system of campaign money-raising
would be an idiotic thing for his party because it collects more money than
the opposition? What degree of public alienation can a politician like Senate
majority leader Trent Lott depend on, who has brazenly said in sponsoring
legislation written by corporate lobbyists... that after all they are the
specialists in their field, who know the issues better than anyone else?
These are the remarks of senators confident of a general population so numbed
and alienated that barely 50 percent of eligible adults bother to vote in
national elections. These are the flaunted values of politicians who know
of the conglomerate-owned press culture, that there will be no editorial
muckraking from the "in depth" journalists of the broadcast media, that
the rampant corruption in Washington, the vast, deep and dangerous mutant
character of the present state of things, will not be defined for what it
is, and that who speaks of the bewildering broad front of failure and mendacity
and carelessness of human life in so much of our public policy in tones
any louder than muted regret will be marginalized for this indecorous transgression
as a leftist, a bleeding-heart liberal or perhaps a raging populist, but
in any event someone so out of the "mainstream" as not to be taken seriously.
How many in Congress today have the integrity, the strength, to distinguish
the interests of their districts or their states from the interests of their
heavy donors? How many think there is a difference? How many can honestly
admit to themselves that the big money is their constituency? To hear the
points of view of some of these people, how they have become so much the
forces that have bought them, is to realize they are no longer guilty of
hypocrisy, having been transmogrified.

The instructive image here is from
Dante's Inferno, Canto XXV. We are in a pouch of the Eighth Circle, where
the thieves are kept. A monstrous lizardlike serpent leaps onto one of the
thieves, wraps its middle feet around his belly, pins his two arms with
its forelegs and, wrapping its rear feet around his knees, swings its tail
up between his legs and sinks its teeth into his face. And so intertwined,
monster and thief, they begin to melt into each other like hot wax, their
two heads joining, their substances merging, until a new third creature
is created, though somehow redolent of both of them. And it slowly slithers
away into the darkness.
* * *

Back in 1787, when the Constitutional Convention
had done its work and the drafted Constitution was sent out to the states
for ratification, the public's excitement was palpable. Extended and vigorous
statehouse debates echoed through the towns and villages, and as, one by
one, the states voted to ratify, church bells rang, cheers went up from
the public houses and in the major cities the people turned out to parade
with a fresh new sense of themselves as a nation.

Everyone marched--tradespeople,
workingmen, soldiers, women, clergy. They had floats in those days, too--most
often a wagon-sized ship of state, called the Union, rolling through the
streets with children waving from the scuppers. Philadelphia came up with
a float called the New Roof, a dome supported by thirteen pillars and ornamented
with stars. It was drawn by ten white horses, and at the top was a handsome
cupola surmounted by a figure of Plenty, bearing her cornucopia.

The ratification
parades were sacramental--symbolic venerations, acts of faith. From the
beginning people saw the Constitution as a kind of sacred text for a civil
society. Indeed, the voice of the Constitution is scriptural. It ordains.
It empowers itself to give law endlessly into the future. Like the Bible,
it requires interpretive commentaries that themselves have the authority
of law because its principles must be applied to a multitude of situations.
And where its prophecy has been false, as in the infamous Article IV, which
made a slave in one state a slave in all, the national calamity of a civil
war ensued before the text could be amended.

Today, the Constitution with
its Bill of Rights and further amendments rules us with a set of behavioral
prescriptions that, if we lived up to all of them, would make us a truly
free and righteous people. When the ancient Hebrews broke their covenant
they suffered a loss of identity and brought disaster upon themselves. Our
burden too is unmistakably covenantal. We may point to our 200-some years
of national survival as an open society, constitutionally sworn to a degree
of free imaginative expression that few cultures in the world can tolerate;
we may regard ourselves as an exceptional, historically self-correcting
nation whose democratic values locate us just as surely as our geography...
and yet we know at the same time that all through our history we have brutally
excluded vast numbers of us from the shelter of the New Roof, we have broken
our covenant again and again with a virtuosity verging on damnation and have
been saved only by the sacrificial efforts of Constitution-reverencing patriots
in government and out of government--Presidents, senators, Justices, abolitionists,
muckrakers, suffragists, striking workers, civil rights activists.
 What
is to be done now, when the Constitution is subjected to corporate-groomed politicians
who read it as no more than a postmodern self-deconstructing text? The present
wide-open, scandalous system of campaign financing is rationalized by a
rightist ideology that portrays the federal government as stiflingly bureaucratic,
intrusive and inimical to the natural rights of a free people. In the lifetimes
of many of us the federal government has been just the opposite, a means
of redress, redemptive justice and societal healing, as, for instance, when
it enacted the Depression measures of the thirties and the Great Society
legislation of the sixties. Today the corporate rightists in Congress mean
to privatize the Social Security system, vouch the public school system
out of existence and do whatever they can to limit if not decimate the regulatory
agencies established to control their worst business excesses. By the logic
of their thinking even the National Office of Weights and Measures could
be construed as an impediment to business practices.

It is not that members
of Congress--or indeed the media or the American public--are not aware of
the inequity of the present money-soaked system of political life in our
country. But to what extent that system is responsible for the grotesque
distortions of our present priorities--with the resultant poverty of so
many children; the way our jails proliferate for the incarceration of black
men, with more and more penal systems run privately for profit; the drift
into monopolization of our media and means of communication, with fewer
and fewer mega-corporations controlling more and more of what we read, see,
hear or understand as the news; or the cost of health insurance policies
that insure people until they get sick; the inequitable tax structure; the
international trade agreements that rescind our environmental laws; the
list is long--and how all of this is connected to the system of unrestricted
and flamboyant political donations may not be always appreciated by the
public or acknowledged consistently even by those members of Congress who
have voted to reform the laws of campaign finance.

In fact, campaign finance
reform as a phrase has been bruited about so long and to so little effect
and is so yawningly dull, dreary and unresounding, it makes one wonder if
it's not partly responsible for the conditions it has so far failed to address.
Perhaps there is a basement office somewhere in Washington where mischievous
lexicographers of a certain political orientation have the assigned task
of finding the words and phrases to defuse the issues that threaten the
interests of their employers. If so, campaign finance reform has done its
work well. Because what is hidden in that modest little phrase is the vision
of an honest, vigorously realized democratic republic.
* * *

To effect
a true and thoroughgoing reform would not change the innately raucous competition
of interests among us, but neither would it provide for the amplification
of some of those interests to a level that is deafening. It would amount
to a kind of revolution of our national political behavior; it would bring
people of talent and vision into political life who are not now available
to the nation; it would be breathtaking, predictive of a new authentic polyvocal
Union; and with the possibility, at last, of addressing our entrenched social
and economic inequities, the distortions of our priorities and what is grotesque
about our public institutions, we would begin to come out of the terrible
alienation that afflicts us and think again of the beauty of our national
promise. We would hope to fashion ourselves more recognizably to the ideal
of human rights implicit in our Constitution.

Perhaps, then, we should
not rely on Congress to find the votes to pass a true and thorough reform
bill that restores to us our dignity as citizens. A genuine ad hoc social
movement may be required, a state-by-state struggle by referendum, issue-specific
ratings at election time, an Internet-organized lobby to end all lobbies,
but in any event something--some great public outcry to flatten back the
ears of the distinguished colleagues in their paneled chambers.

To imagine
such glory is to invoke the idealism of Walt Whitman. Whitman did not buy
the elitist presumption of classic conservatism--that it was in the nature
of some to lead and most to follow--even as it claimed to recognize its
responsibility (as it does not now in its corporatized form) to look after,
to take care of, as one looks after or takes care of children or pets. He
saw it as a terrible depressant of human energies. He understood American
democracy's breakout potential to enlarge the dimensions of human life,
and thought that if the discourse was truly national, the communications
omni-directional, the minds of a populace living in neighborly freedom could
constellate into a universe that we hadn't yet dreamed of. That is why when
he walked the streets of nineteenth-century New York, Whitman embraced everything
he saw. He loved the multitudes, the industry of working people; he loved
the ships in the harbor, the traffic on Broadway. But he was not naïve.
He knew the newspaper business from which he made his living relied finally
for its success on the frail shoulders of itinerant boys and girls, street
urchins who lived on the few cents they made hawking the papers at every
corner. Thousands of vagrant children lived in the streets of the New York
Walt Whitman loved. Yet his exultant optimism and awe of human capacity
was not demeaned; he could carry it all, the whole society, and attend like
a nurse to its illnesses, but like a lover to its fair face.

And so must we.



----------------------------------------------------------------------------
E.L. Doctorow's latest novel is City of God (Random House).

redistribution is prohibited.

1-800-333-8536 or by following this link. The Nation encourages activists
and friends of the magazine to share our articles with others. However, it
is mandatory that academic institutions, publications and for-profit
institutions seeking to reprint material for redistribution contact us for
complete guidelines.

material from The Nation. For further information regarding reprinting and
syndication, please call The Nation at (212) 209-5426 or e-mail

Post ID:537
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-01 09:15:12
Subject:N.B. Liquor License/Live Music Article from HNT.
Message:



                                                            
                        

         August 1, 2000  
                                                            
      Story Search 







           



           Midnight closings at issue: City liquor-license revisions
tabled 

           Published in the Home News Tribune 8/01/00 

           By FRANCES CARROLL
           STAFF WRITER

           The City Council yesterday tabled an ordinance that
would have put out of business every establishment
           that serves alcohol in and around a residential zone
and forced all other liquor-license holders to close up
           shop at midnight.

           The ordinance, introduced quietly two weeks ago, was
drafted under the guise of a measure to cut down
           on the noise at businesses that offer live music and
dancing, but if adopted it could have forced the closure
           of restaurants like the renowned Frog & Peach.

           All other bars and restaurants that hold liquor licenses
would have had
           to close at midnight, regardless of where they were
located or if they
           featured music.

           The proposed ordinance would have created a new license
and rules for
           "cabarets," and in the first section makes reference
to businesses that sell
           alcohol and offer live music and dancing.

           However, in the second section the scope of the ordinance
becomes
           much broader.

           While Webster's New World Dictionary defines cabaret
as "a
           restaurant or cafe with dancing, singing, skits, etc.
as entertainment," the
           New Brunswick council defined the word cabaret for
the purposes of
           the ordinance as "a premises licensed for on premises
retail sale of
           alcohol beverages."

           That would include nearly every business in New Brunswick
that holds a liquor license, which number
           about 80, officials said. Only those operating with
a plenary retail consumption license would be required to
           apply for the new cabaret license, at $350 for the
first year and $200 for each year thereafter.

           Shortly after the council tabled the ordinance for
two weeks for "more discussion," City Attorney William
           Hamilton indicated the broad definition of cabaret
may have been an oversight and said he should be
           blamed because he drafted the document.

           But Council President Joseph Schrum said he knew exactly
what he was voting for when he voted to
           introduce the ordinance and that was no liquor licenses
in primarily residential neighborhoods and all
           businesses that serve alcohol to close at midnight,
two hours earlier than the current mandated 2 a.m.
           closing time.

           "We sure woke everybody up, didn't we," said Schrum,
who declined to comment further on that
           statement.

           Both he and Councilman Robert Recine said the ordinance
will not be adopted in its current form, and the
           council may opt to drop the issue all together in
the end. They said they ideally want to come up with a
           compromise that will answer residents who repeatedly
complain about noise, crowds and disturbances in
           and around taverns that feature live music but which
won't put tavern owners out of business.

           "We're trying to keep the quality of life in town,"
said Schrum. "They're trying to make money, which I
           respect, but we have people in these neighborhoods
who want to sleep at night."

           The ordinance as introduced said no cabaret could
operate in a residential zone or if 60 percent or more of
           properties within 250 feet of the premises are zoned
residential. It also said no business could be operated
           as a cabaret later than midnight, except for New Year's
Eve.

           Local bar and tavern owners found out about the proposed
ordinance slowly through word-of-mouth last
           week, and many yesterday were under the impression
it was solely a ban on live music after midnight. That
           ban alone could signal the end of New Brunswick's
growing reputation as a destination for up and coming
           musical talent not to mention kill the after-theater
business, they said.

           Club owners said their business was hurt when the
city rolled back weekend closing from 3 a.m. to 2 a.m.
           in 1995.

           Many tavern owners say they would lose so much business
by not offering music after midnight they could
           be forced to close.

           Many patrons don't show up until 11 p.m. or after,
and if there's no music customers are not "just going
           to sit down after midnight drinking and staring at
each other," said Steve Flaks, owner of the Melody Bar on
           French Street which features music seven nights a
week.

           If the ordinance is adopted as is, it would be a death
sentence for the Court Tavern, agreed Bobby Albert,
           owner of the Church Street club which has featured
live music for nearly 20 years in what is considered a
           commercial area.

           Albert said his tavern, which over the years has featured
bands which have gone on to national stardom
           such as the Smithereens and the Spin Doctors, has
never had a complaint about noise in 20 years.

           Stan Weinberg, owner of the Plum St. Pub on Hamilton
Street said "There's a lot of talent out there and
           by playing these bars it opened up a lot of doors
for them. Now they want to shut it down."

           Hamilton said it was noise complaints from residents
who live near the Plum St. Pub and D'Gala Cafe on
           Commercial Avenue that prompted the proposed ordinance.
Both of those bars had conditions placed on
           their liquor licenses in June limiting live music
to 11 p.m. or midnight and requiring an off-duty police officer
           to be on site on weekends, he said.

           Kermit Wade, manager of the Harvest Moon restaurant
and nightclub on George Street, said that
           restaurants in the city also would be adversely affected
by the restrictions.

           "Live music is a good way to unwind (after a meal),"
Wade said. "We have bands almost every night."

           The city would also suffer as it will become less
appealing as a destination for business travelers, Wade
           said.

           "The Hyatt (on Albany Street) has conferences and
(attendees) like to go out," Wade said. "What will
           there be to do at night?"

           The council placed a midnight cut-off on live jazz
and R&B music at Delta's Bar & Grill on Dennis Street
           when it opened seven months ago in the middle of the
RiverWatch development, said owner Josh Suggs.
           The restriction was placed on Delta's liquor license,
but Suggs hoped to have it lifted in the near future. 

           Staff writer Chris Jordan contributed to this report.

-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!

Post ID:539
Sender:mike@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-01 13:07:18
Subject:chimeranga == liberation struggle in Africa
Message:

FYI.

Hit your favorite search engine and search for chimeranga.
It (apparently) roughly translates to liberation struggle.

Also, 'Taji' was a factory in Iraq that was bombed.

What fun . . .
- Mike

Post ID:540
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-02 12:20:41
Subject:Announcement
Message:

To all interested parties:

The Media Committee meets Wednesday nights at 8pm, at Jim's house.  
Today is, of course, Wednesday!

It is strongly desired that people interested in becoming involved in 
the many activities of the committee -- article composition, layout 
and design, flyers, and to some extent working with the Press -- stop 
by.  

We are ESPECIALLY in need of someone to help out with layout for the 
newspaper, especially later on this month.  We have one person 
overburdened with this particular task.

Email me at timmy.o'toole@... or call (732) 565-0740 for 
directions, etc.

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:541
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-02 16:14:54
Subject:Correction
Message:

The invitation for all the join Media still stands.
We need all the help we can get.

It was decided at Tactical that our next newspaper
will come out in September -- not the end of August.
Production and planning of the next paper will start
at the end of August.

Jim

this is totally wild... read on...

>>one time it may concern you. Especially if you still have friend there or 
>>you are just a general believer in the right to play, listen or dance to 
>>music.
>>
>>
>>----Original Message Follows----
>>From: "Shah Motia" <s_motia@...>
>>To: s_motia@...
>>Subject: Fwd: This concerns all of us......8/1/00
>>Date: Tue, 01 Aug 2000 21:54:54 GMT
>>
>>I don't know if anyone else has received this, but please read it. I never 
>>send chain mails, but this affects us all.
>>
>>
>>>
>>>Friends, Family, Coworkers, Fellow Rockers...
>>>
>>>I was forwarded this letter by New Brunswick indie rocker/ local/ writer, 
>>>Rob
>>>Farrell. Rob is an active participant in the New Brunswick bar and club 
>>>and
>>>music scene. You may have seen his column on Tourdates.com or have been 
>>>lucky
>>>enough to catch him live with his band The Anderson Council.
>>>
>>>Basically, The New Brunswick City Council has planned a sneak attack on 
>>>New
>>>Brunswick Clubs, Bars and New Brunswick area bar / club patrons. This
>>>ordinance proposed to be passed by The New Brunswick City council could 
>>>be
>>>the end of life in the New Brunswick area as we know it. City Council 
>>>members
>>>would like to see all live entertainment end by 12am every night of the 
>>>week
>>>in New Brunswick. This is not just The Melody, The Court, Harvest Moon 
>>>and
>>>The Budapest... This will be Rutgers University, The State Theater, house
>>>parties, etc....
>>>
>>>Maybe you don't live in town anymore? Maybe you came to New Brunswick 
>>>once on
>>>tour? Maybe you were a student at Rutgers University? I think you all 
>>>know
>>>that if this ordinance is passed, it will mean the end of the New 
>>>Brunswick
>>>music scene.... No live shows past midnight, no all ages shows ( because 
>>>the
>>>venues will probably not be there )... no DJ's after midnight ( we know 
>>>that
>>>nobody goes out before 10pm ) ... How about house parties? Do you think
>>>you've been harassed in the past for kicking tunes with your friends on a
>>>Friday night? Think again, it is going to get a lot worse.....
>>>
>>>What I'm saying friends is... Don't sit on your ass on this one... Three
>>>years ago we lost the extra hour of party time on weekends when they 
>>>passed
>>>the 2 o'clock closing... We stand to lose a whole lot more if we don't do
>>>something about this...
>>>
>>>Below is a copy of the proposed ordinance...Check it out... Speak up, 
>>>take
>>>action....
>>>Make it happen... This is ours.
>>>                                                  - John K. ( indie 
>>>rocker/
>>>Club manager/ web designer/ club promoter/ New Brunswick area local )
>>>Please feel free to contact me, I'll tell ya what I know: 432-9602
>>>
>>>------------------------------------------------------------------------------
>>>---------------------------------------------
>>>The Melody Bar . 106 French St . New Brunswick, NJ . 08901
>>>732 . 249 . 3784 . www.Melodybar.com
>>>------------------------------------------------------------------------------
>>>---------------------------------------------
>>>
>>>The following is from Rob Farrell...
>>>
>>> > My dears,
>>> >
>>> > Wednesday (August 2, 2000) afternoon at 4 p.m., the City Council of
>>> >  the City of New Brunswick meets in the Council Chambers, City Hall,
>>> >  78 Bayard Street, 3rd Floor to discuss the following Ordinance.
>>> >
>>> > A few years ago, the Council surreptitiously changed bar closing time
>>> >  from 3 a.m. to 2 a.m. Bar owners, employees and patrons - which is
>>> >  to say us - had  virtually nothing to say about it. The following
>>> >  (which I transcribed from an official copy) includes some very
>>> >  questionable language. As you are reading the text, please keep in
>>> >  mind the Ordinance defines a cabaret as "a premises licensed for
>>> >  on  premises retail sale of alcohol beverages" and that "No licensed
>>> >  premises may be operated as a cabaret later than 12:00 midnight
>>> >  except on December 31-January 1 of each year." The Council is
>>> >  trying to close the bars in New Brunswick at midnight. Other
>>> >  interpretations exist, but this is how I read it.
>>> >
>>> > Whether you're a dancing fool or a wallflower, a grandparent or
>>> >  club kid, you know or you remember that nothing is over at midnight.
>>> >  Think about when you danced until you couldn't, and how happy you
>>> >  were, or when you saw a great band and wished the show would never
>>> >  end. You always had to option to leave, but you could stay, too,
>>> >  until closing time. You decided. The Council is trying, as a
>>> >  friend aptly put it, "to give the whole town a bedtime."
>>> >
>>> > The City Clerk's phone number is 732 745 5040 option 5. Please read
>>> >  the Ordinance before you call. If you can attend a 4 p.m. Wednesday
>>> >  meeting, please do it. If you know people who would be interested
>>> >  in this issue, please pass this email on as quickly as possible.
>>> >
>>> > Thank you for your help.
>>> >
>>> > -Rob
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > Note: the blanks in SECTION X exist on the as yet unsigned
>>> >  Ordinance. Joseph Schrum's signature is the only one the proposal.
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND THE REVISED GENERAL ORDINANCE OF
>>> >  THE CITY OF NEW BRUNSWICK, CHAPTER VIII, "ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE
>>> >  CONTROL", TO PROVIDE FOR THE LICENSURE AND REGULATION
>>> >  OF CABARETS AND TO PROVIDE PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS THEREOF
>>> >
>>> > BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of New
>>> >  Brunswick as follows:
>>> >
>>> > SECTION I
>>> >
>>> > FINDINGS:
>>> >
>>> > The City Council of the City of New Brunswick finds and
>>> >  determines as follows:
>>> >
>>> > A. Many premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic
>>> >  beverages also offer live music and dancing as a part of their
>>> >  business;
>>> >
>>> > B. Such businesses, when properly conducted, add to the
>>> >  style and variety of leisure time in the City;
>>> >
>>> > C. Some licensed premises which offer live music and
>>> >  dancing also have demonstrated the potential for causing noise,
>>> >  crowds and disturbances such as to adversely affect the lives of
>>> >  residents living in and near such licensed premises;
>>> >
>>> > D. The licensing of premises which offer live music and
>>> >  dancing as cabarets can help control the adverse aspects
>>> >  associated with some licensed premises while not adversely
>>> >  impacting properly run establishments; and
>>> >
>>> > E. The system of licensing adopted hereafter will promote
>>> >  the public health, safety and morals.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION II
>>> >
>>> > DEFINITIONS:
>>> >
>>> > As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall have the
>>> >  meanings indicated:
>>> >
>>> > "Cabaret" means a premises licensed for on premises
>>> >  retail sale of alcohol beverages.
>>> >
>>> > "Zoned Residential" means property located in any
>>> >  of the following districts as determined by the Zoning
>>> >  Ordinance and Zoning map as the same may be amended from
>>> >  time to time: R1A, R1B, R2 through R6.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION III
>>> >
>>> > LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
>>> >
>>> > The holder of any Plenary Retail Consumption License in the
>>> >  City of New Brunswick may apply for a cabaret license under this
>>> >  Ordinance. No holder of a Plenary Retail Consumption License
>>> >  shall operate or permit the operation of a cabaret without first
>>> >  applying for and being granted a license pursuant to this
>>> >  ordinance.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION IV
>>> >
>>> > APPLICATION REQUIRED:
>>> >
>>> > An applicant for cabaret license shall apply to the City
>>> >  Clerk for a license hereunder. The applicant shall furnish to the
>>> >  City Clerk a copy of the existing certificate of occupancy for the
>>> >  premises and a sketch drawn to scale that indicates dimensions of
>>> >  the rooms, location of bar and any cooking apparatus, rest rooms
>>> >  and all entrances and exists [sic] to the premises. The applicant
>>> >  also furnish a copy of the building capacity furnished by the Fire
>>> >  Safety Officer.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION V
>>> >
>>> > ANNUAL FEE:
>>> >
>>> > The fee required in connection with an initial cabaret
>>> >  license shall be $350.00 to be paid to the City Clerk at the time
>>> >  of application. In the event the application is denied, $150.00
>>> >  of the application fee shall be returned to the applicant.
>>> >
>>> > The fee for subsequent consecutive license years shall be
>>> >  $200.00
>>> >
>>> > SECTION VI
>>> >
>>> > REGULATIONS:
>>> >
>>> > A. As a part of the application process, the building shall
>>> >  be reinspected and a capacity assigned for use as a cabaret
>>> >  pursuant to the New Jersey Uniform Fire Code. In the event the
>>> >  capacity assigned as a result of this inspection is less then [sic]
>>> >  the existing capacity, the Fire Official will issue a certification
>>> >  showing both capacities. The premises will post both capacities.
>>> >  The lower capacity will be applicable at all times that the
>>> >  premises are being operated as a cabaret.
>>> >
>>> > B. The following regulations shall apply to all cabarets:
>>> >
>>> > (1) No cabaret license shall be approved for
>>> >   premises which are zoned residential or if sixty (60%)
>>> >   percent or more of the properties within 250' of the
>>> >   premises are zoned residential.
>>> >
>>> > (2) No licensed premises may be operated as a
>>> >   cabaret later than 12:00 midnight except on December 31-
>>> >   January 1 of each year.
>>> >
>>> > (3) The license granted to any cabaret may be
>>> >   revoked or suspended following hearing and conviction on
>>> >   written charges setting forth violations of this
>>> >   Ordinance or the filing of charges which set forth
>>> >   conduct in or about the licensed premises which evidence
>>> >   a clear disregard for the quality of life of residents
>>> >   living in the vicinity of the licensed premises.
>>> >
>>> > (4) Restrictions on the hours of operation set
>>> >   forth in subsection (2) above and/or other conditions on
>>> >   said license may be imposed following hearing and
>>> >   conviction on written charges setting forth violations
>>> >   of this Ordinance or the filing of charges which set
>>> >   forth conduct in or about the licensed premises which
>>> >   evidence a clear disregard for the quality of life of
>>> >   residents living in the vicinity of the licensed
>>> >   premises.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION VII
>>> >
>>> > ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
>>> >
>>> > Violations of this Ordinance shall be heard by the City Council
>>> >  provided that conduct which also constitutes a violation of other
>>> >  ordinances of the City shall be cognizable by the Municipal Court
>>> >  of the City or by Superior Court as may be appropriate to the
>>> >  nature of the offense.
>>> >
>>> > In addition to revocation or suspension of license and the
>>> >  imposition of conditions, violations of this Ordinance shall be
>>> >  punishable by a civil penalty of $500.00 for a first offense and
>>> >  $1,000.00 for a second or subsequent offense.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION VIII
>>> >
>>> > SEVERABILITY:
>>> >
>>> > If any subsection, paragraph or provision of this Ordinance
>>> >  is declared to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction
>>> >  such finding shall not affect the remaining provisions hereof
>>> >  which shall remain in full force and effect.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION IX
>>> >
>>> > REPEALER:
>>> >
>>> > All ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this
>>> >  Ordinance are repealed to the extent of such inconsistency.
>>> >
>>> > SECTION X
>>> >
>>> > EFFECTIVE DATE:
>>> >
>>> > This Ordinance shall become effective twenty (20) days
>>> >  following final adoption and shall be published as required by
>>> >  law.
>>> >
>>> > ADOPTED ON FIRST READING
>>> > DATED: , 2000 [SIGNATURE OF JOSEPH SCHRUM]
>>> > Joseph Schrum
>>> > Council President
>>> >
>>> > ADOPTED ON SECOND READING
>>> > DATED: , 2000 [SIGNATURE OF JOSEPH SCHRUM]
>>> > Joseph Schrum
>>> > Council President
>>> >
>>> > ATTEST:
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > __________________________
>>> > DANIEL TORRISI
>>> > City Clerk
>>> >
>>> > APPROVAL OF THE MAYOR ON THIS DAY OF , 2000.
>>> >
>>> >
>>> > _________________________
>>> > JAMES M. CAHILL, Mayor
>>
>>
>>
>

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:547
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-08 22:14:01
Subject:Fwd: FW: Save New Brunswick
Message:

this is the third email i've received regarding the bar closing. i think it 
would be appropriate, and a damn good idea, if someone composed a letter in 
response, and forwarded it out to these same people.

this is a perfect opportunity to bash the current council ( i have to say 
it: they are the biggest fools i've seen in trying to pass something like 
this right before an election!!!!) and PROMOTE the People's Campaign.

perhaps a candidate should draft up a letter? i think we should follow up on 
this soon, so as to not lose the momentum of all these events...

comments????

>From: Karen A <renren59@...>
>To: Adam <axe2370@...>, Andrew <alpineclowns@...>
>Subject: Fwd: FW: Save New Brunswick
>Date: Mon, 7 Aug 2000 22:40:54 -0700 (PDT)
>
>
>--- "Duszkiewicz, Anna" <aduszkiewicz@...> wrote:
> > From: "Duszkiewicz, Anna" <aduszkiewicz@...>
> > To: "'Gretchen'" <gezengel@...>,
> >         "'Jennifer Walters'"
> > 	 <jwalters@...>,
> >         "'Karen'" <renren59@...>, "'Marybeth'"
> > 	 <mohara@...>,
> >         "'Patrick Ferrante'" <pfat73@...>,
> >         "'Peter'"
> > 	 <pduszkiewicz@...>
> > Subject: FW: Save New Brunswick
> > Date: Mon, 7 Aug 2000 11:10:59 -0400
> >
> > why doesn't this shit surprise me??  read on....
> > __________________________________________
> >
> >
> >
> > Friends, Family, Coworkers, Fellow Rockers...
> >
> > I was forwarded this letter by New Brunswick indie
> > rocker/ local/ writer,
> > Rob Farrell. Rob is an active participant in the New
> > Brunswick bar and club
> > and music scene. You may have seen his column on
> > Tourdates.com or have been
> > lucky enough to catch him live with his band The
> > Anderson Council.
> >
> > Basically, The New Brunswick City Council has
> > planned a sneak attack on New
> > Brunswick Clubs, Bars and New Brunswick area bar /
> > club patrons. This
> > ordinance proposed to be passed by The New Brunswick
> > City council could be
> > the end of life in the New Brunswick area as we know
> > it. City Council
> > members would like to see all live entertainment end
> > by 12am every night of
> > the week in New Brunswick. This is not just The
> > Melody, The Court, Harvest
> > Moon and The Budapest... This will be Rutgers
> > University, The State Theater,
> > house parties, etc....
> >
> > Maybe you don't live in town anymore? Maybe you came
> > to New Brunswick once
> > on tour? Maybe you were a student at Rutgers
> > University? I think you all
> > know that if this ordinance is passed, it will mean
> > the end of the New
> > Brunswick music scene.... No live shows past
> > midnight, no all ages shows (
> > because the venues will probably not be there )...
> > no DJ's after midnight (
> > we know that nobody goes out before 10pm ) ... How
> > about house parties? Do
> > you think you've been harassed in the past for
> > kicking tunes with your
> > friends on a Friday night? Think again, it is going
> > to get a lot worse.....
> >
> > What I'm saying friends is... Don't sit on your ass
> > on this one... Three
> > years ago we lost the extra hour of party time on
> > weekends when they passed
> > the 2 o'clock closing... We stand to lose a whole
> > lot more if we don't do
> > something about this...
> >
> > Below is a copy of the proposed ordinance...Check it
> > out... Speak up, take
> > action....
> > Make it happen... This is ours.
> >
> > - John K. ( indie rocker/ Club manager/ web
> > designer/ club promoter/ New
> > Brunswick area local )
> >
> > Please feel free to contact me, I'll tell ya what I
> > know: 432-9602
> >
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------
> >
> > The Melody Bar . 106 French St . New Brunswick, NJ .
> > 08901
> > 732 . 249 . 3784 . www.Melodybar.com
> >
> >
>-------------------------------------------------------------------------
> > > The following is from Rob Farrell...
> >
> > My dears,
> >
> > Wednesday (August 2, 2000) afternoon at 4 p.m., the
> > City Council of the City
> > of New Brunswick meets in the Council Chambers, City
> > Hall, 78 Bayard Street,
> > 3rd Floor to discuss the following Ordinance.
> >
> > A few years ago, the Council surreptitiously changed
> > bar closing time from 3
> > a.m. to 2 a.m. Bar owners, employees and patrons -
> > which is to say us - had
> > virtually nothing to say about it. The following
> > (which I transcribed from
> > an official copy) includes some very questionable
> > language. As you are
> > reading the text, please keep in mind the Ordinance
> > defines a cabaret as "a
> > premises licensed for on  premises retail sale of
> > alcohol beverages" and
> > that "No licensed premises may be operated as a
> > cabaret later than 12:00
> > midnight except on December 31-January 1 of each
> > year." The Council is
> > trying to close the bars in New Brunswick at
> > midnight. Other interpretations
> > exist, but this is how I read it. Whether you're a
> > dancing fool or a
> > wallflower, a grandparent or club kid, you know or
> > you remember that nothing
> > is over at midnight. Think about when you danced
> > until you couldn't, and how
> > happy you were, or when you saw a great band and
> > wished the show would never
> > end. You always had to option to leave, but you
> > could stay, too, until
> > closing time. You decided. The Council is trying, as
> > a friend aptly put it,
> > "to give the whole town a bedtime."
> >
> > The City Clerk's phone number is 732 745 5040 option
> > 5. Please read the
> > Ordinance before you call. If you can attend a 4
> > p.m. Wednesday meeting,
> > please do it. If you know people who would be
> > interested in this issue,
> > please pass this email on as quickly as possible.
> >
> > Thank you for your help.
> >
> > -Rob
> >
> > Note: the blanks in SECTION X exist on the as yet
> > unsigned Ordinance. Joseph
> > Schrum's signature is the only one the proposal.
> >
> > AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND THE REVISED GENERAL ORDINANCE
> > OF THE CITY OF NEW
> > BRUNSWICK, CHAPTER VIII, "ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE
> > CONTROL", TO PROVIDE FOR THE
> > LICENSURE AND REGULATION OF CABARETS AND TO PROVIDE
> > PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS
> > THEREOF BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the
> > City of New Brunswick as
> > follows:
> >
> > SECTION I
> > FINDINGS:
> > The City Council of the City of New Brunswick finds
> > and determines as
> > follows:
> >
> > A. Many premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic
> > beverages also offer
> > live music and dancing as a part of their business;
> >
> > B. Such businesses, when properly conducted, add to
> > the style and variety of
> > leisure time in the City;
> >
> > C. Some licensed premises which offer live music and
> > dancing also have
> > demonstrated the potential for causing noise, crowds
> > and disturbances such
> > as to adversely affect the lives of residents living
> > in and near such
> > licensed premises;
> >
> > D. The licensing of premises which offer live music
> > and dancing as cabarets
> > can help control the adverse aspects associated with
> > some licensed premises
> > while not adversely impacting properly run
> > establishments; and
> >
> > E. The system of licensing adopted hereafter will
> > promote the public health,
> > safety and morals.
> >
> > SECTION II
> > DEFINITIONS:
> >
> > As used in this Ordinance, the following terms shall
> > have the meanings
> > indicated:
> >
> > "Cabaret" means a premises licensed for on premises
> > retail sale of alcohol
> > beverages.
> >
> > "Zoned Residential" means property located in any of
> > the following districts
> > as determined by the Zoning Ordinance and Zoning map
> > as the same may be
> > amended from time to time: R1A, R1B, R2 through R6.
> >
> > SECTION III
> > LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
> >
> > The holder of any Plenary Retail Consumption License
> > in the City of New
> > Brunswick may apply for a cabaret license under this
> > Ordinance. No holder of
> > a Plenary Retail Consumption License shall operate
> > or permit the operation
> > of a cabaret without first applying for and being
> > granted a license pursuant
> > to this ordinance.
> >
> > SECTION IV
> > APPLICATION REQUIRED:
> >
> > An applicant for cabaret license shall apply to the
> > City Clerk for a license
> > hereunder. The applicant shall furnish to the City
> > Clerk a copy of the
> > existing certificate of occupancy for the premises
> > and a sketch drawn to
> > scale that indicates dimensions of the rooms,
> > location of bar and any
> > cooking apparatus, rest rooms and all entrances and
> > exists [sic] to the
> > premises. The applicant also furnish a copy of the
> > building capacity
> > furnished by the Fire Safety Officer.
> >
> > SECTION V
> > ANNUAL FEE:
> >
> > The fee required in connection with an initial
> > cabaret license shall be
> > $350.00 to be paid to the City Clerk at the time of
> > application. In the
> > event the application is denied, $150.00 of the
> > application fee shall be
> > returned to the applicant. The fee for subsequent
> > consecutive license years
> > shall be $200.00
> >
> > SECTION VI
> > REGULATIONS:
> >
> > A. As a part of the application process, the
> > building shall be reinspected
> > and a capacity assigned for use as a cabaret
> > pursuant to the New Jersey
> > Uniform Fire Code. In the event the capacity
> > assigned as a result of this
> > inspection is less then [sic] the existing capacity,
> > the Fire Official will
> > issue a certification showing both capacities. The
> > premises will post both
> > capacities.  The lower capacity will be applicable
> > at all times that the
> > premises are being operated as a cabaret.
> >
> > B. The following regulations shall apply to all
> > cabarets:
> > 	(1) No cabaret license shall be approved for
> > premises which are
> > zoned  residential or if sixty (60%)percent or more
> > of the properties within
> > 250' of the premises are zoned residential.
> > 	(2) No licensed premises may be operated as a
> > cabaret later than
> > 12:00 midnight except on December 31-January 1 of
> > each year.
> > 	(3) The license granted to any cabaret may be
> > revoked or suspended
> > following hearing and conviction on written charges
> > setting forth violations
> > of this Ordinance or the filing of charges which set
> > forth conduct in or
> > about the licensed premises which evidence a clear
> > disregard for the quality
> > of life of residents living in the vicinity of the
> > licensed premises.
> > 	(4) Restrictions on the hours of operation set
> > forth in subsection
> > (2) above and/or other conditions on said license
> > may be imposed following
> > hearing and conviction on written charges setting
> > forth violations of this
> > Ordinance or the  filing of charges which set forth
> > conduct in or about the
> > licensed premises which evidence a clear disregard
> > for the quality of life
> > of residents living in the  vicinity of the licensed
> > premises.
> >
> > SECTION VII
> > ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
> >
> > Violations of this Ordinance shall be heard by the
> > City Council provided
> > that conduct which also constitutes a violation of
> > other ordinances of the
> > City shall be cognizable by the Municipal Court of
> > the City or by Superior
> > Court as may be  appropriate to the nature of the
> > offense.  In addition to
> > revocation or suspension of license and the
> > imposition of conditions,
> > violations of this Ordinance shall be punishable by
> > a civil penalty of
> > $500.00 for a first offense and $1,000.00 for a
> > second or subsequent
> > offense.
> >
> > SECTION VIII
> > SEVERABILITY:
> >
> > If any subsection, paragraph or provision of this
> > Ordinance is declared to
> > be valid by a court of competent jurisdiction such
> > finding shall not affect
> > the remaining provisions hereof which shall remain
> > in full force and effect.
> >
> > SECTION IX
> > REPEALER:
> > All ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of
> > this Ordinance are
> > repealed to the extent of such inconsistency.
> >
> > SECTION X
> > EFFECTIVE DATE:
> >
> > This Ordinance shall become effective twenty (20)
> > days following final
> > adoption and shall be published as required by law.
> >
> > ADOPTED ON FIRST READING DATED: , 2000 [SIGNATURE OF
> > JOSEPH SCHRUM]
> > Joseph Schrum
> > Council President
> >
> > ADOPTED ON SECOND READING DATED: , 2000 [SIGNATURE
> > OF JOSEPH SCHRUM]
> > Joseph Schrum
> > Council President
> > ATTEST:
> > DANIEL TORRISI
> > City Clerk
> >
> > APPROVAL OF THE MAYOR ON THIS DAY OF , 2000.
> > JAMES M. CAHILL, Mayor
>
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:548
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-09 08:12:57
Subject:FW: [Mike's Message] YEAH! No Chicks on the Tix! -- A Letter from Michael Moore
Message:


--- Original Message ---
"Mike's Message" <mikemail@...> Wrote on 
Tue, 08 Aug 2000 18:22:52 -0500
 ------------------ 
Tuesday, August 8, 2000

Dear friends, 

Women put up with a lot of crap, but
this year's Presidential farce has to
take the cake. 

We now have four men on the "two"
major party tickets running for the
White House. Neither candidate,
Democrat nor Republican, even
bothered to CONSIDER a woman for
Vice President, let alone appoint one.

Women: 53% of the population -- the
MAJORITY gender -- and once again,
there is ZERO representation. The
minority still rules, still calls the
shots, still holds the reins of power.
That's called "apartheid."

You know what amazes me? That
neither Gore nor Bush even tried to
PRETEND they were considering a
woman for Vice President! In the past,
the all-male Presidential candidates
have at least "floated" some names, or
said "so-and-so" was on "the short
list." They thought women might be
upset if it looked like they were being
ignored. So they played the game of
interviewing "Pat Schroeder" for the
job, or mentioning "Elizabeth Dole" as
a "possibility." 

No more. 

This year, in what appears to be a
political version of "battered women's
syndrome," guy politicians have
discovered that they don't have to do a
damn thing to placate women voters.
They are convinced women will just
take it -- in silence.

And just as Dick Cheney is the true
face of George W. Bush, Joe Lieberman
is the true face of Al Gore.
Lieberman's number one financial
backer in Connecticut is the insurance
industry -- and when they say "jump,"
he leaps. He even opposed Clinton's
watered-down health insurance bill. He
is an enemy of affirmative action. He
has voted for tax cuts for the rich,
voted for NAFTA, supports a form of
prayer ("the minute of silence") in the
public schools (and the granting of
vouchers to help fund religious
schools), and joined Al Gore as one of
only 10 Democrats in the Senate who
supported Bush the First in starting
the Gulf War. 

In short, a real guy's guy.

Of course, not to beat a dead Corvair,
there is a candidate who is now,
according to Tim Russert on "Meet the
Press" last Sunday, polling between
11% and 15% in some surveys, and
has chosen a woman as his running
mate. His name is Ralph Nader and HER
name is Winona LaDuke. She is a
Harvard graduate from Minnesota and
a Native American. She has a bunch of
wild ideas women usually come up
with, the kinds of things that probably
keep them off the other tickets -- like,
everybody should be guaranteed
insurance if they get sick, or working
moms and kids deserve day care, or
maybe we shoud build a few less
submarines in Connecticut and build a
few new schools in the Bronx. Stuff
like that. Chick stuff, ya know. Stuff
us guys ain't got time for.

Ralph and Winona have tripled their
standing in the polls since they
started. There is a momentum taking
place and maybe, just maybe, the
majority - women - will rise up and
say enough of this male apartheid.

Yours, 


Michael Moore
http://www.theawfultruth.com
http://www.michaelmoore.com
mmflint@... 

PS Tomorrow night (Wednesday,
August 9) is the final episode of "The
Awful Truth" for the season. More on
this in tomorrow's letter -- and my
thoughts about the Supreme Court in a
possible George the Second
Administration.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:552
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-11 11:26:59
Subject:President of New Brunswick Tomorrow Resigns
Message:

Who from the Media Committee (or whomever) contact the HNT reporter
and inquire if there will be a folow-up story? People's Campaign
comments should be part of any future article. The article follows.

--BV


           New Brunswick Tomorrow president resigns 

           Published in the Home News Tribune 8/11/00 

           By SHARON WATERS
           STAFF WRITER

           The president of New Brunswick Tomorrow, Stephen H.
O'Connor, has resigned effective Nov. 1 to
           pursue completion of a doctorate degree.

           The board of directors will meet next week to discuss
a replacement, O'Connor said. The organization
           hopes to fill the position before O'Connor leaves,
said NBT Chairman Chris Kjeldsen.

           O'Connor said his decision was based solely on the
need to complete his thesis and final requirements for a
           doctorate degree in urban planning and policy development
from the Edward J. Bloustein School at Rutgers
           University.

           It was a difficult decision because his nearly five
years at NBT were very gratifying, O'Connor said.

           "A large part of me is here and it's sometimes hard
to walk away," he said.

           The time requirements of managing a small nonprofit
extend to all hours of the day and night and also
           through the weekend and did not allow him to devote
enough time to his thesis and family, O'Connor said.

           He hopes to graduate next June when his son Ryan,
17, will graduate from high school. O'Connor also has
           a daughter, Katie, 15.

           NBT's board of directors appointed O'Connor as president
in December 1995. He previously worked as
           executive director of the New Jersey Housing Assistance
Corp.

           O'Connor's proudest accomplishments at NBT are expanding
the scope of programs and increasing the
           annual operating budget about 2 1/2 times during his
tenure, he said. The private nonprofit agency that
           addresses social-service issues in the city has about
3 million of programs now versus about $1 million five
           years ago, he said.

           NBT also oversees the social-services component of
the federal HOPE VI project that involves
           demolishing the public New Brunswick Homes high-rises
and replacing them with new mixed-income
           housing, as well as relocating residents and helping
them attain self-sufficiency.

           The resignation will have no effect on NBT's role
in the HOPE VI project, O'Connor said.

           "Everything is in the implementation stage and all
the key players are in place," he said.

           NBT created the program's design and oversees it,
but Catholic Charities actually provides services to the
           residents, O'Connor said. The people working in the
field are still in place, he added. 

           NBT provides oversight and advisory roles for the
HOPE VI project, said O'Connor. He also noted that
           NBT's vice president, Jeffrey M. Vega, manages almost
all the programmatic aspects of NBT.

           Sharon Waters: (732) 246-5500 Ext. 7270. E-mail swaters@...

           from the Home News Tribune 

           Published: August 11, 2000

-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:553
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-11 11:33:55
Subject:Reply Wanted: Housing Authority Letter to HNT
Message:

Housing agency has a good record

           As executive director of the New Brunswick Housing
Authority, I take great offense from your July 25
editorial, which made the unsubstantiated statement the authority
is not "the most trusted public agency in the city." This unprovoked
statement cannot go unanswered. 

           Here are just a few examples of the trust that has
been placed in us by our residents, the city and the federal
government.

           On Sept. 16 and 17, as Tropical Storm Floyd caused
the Raritan River to swell over its banks and began
taking over the land on which the New Brunswick Homes sit, our
residents trusted us as we provided them with food, transportation
and lodging; protected their belongings; and returned them to
their homes in a timely fashion. No major injuries occurred.

           City officials have trusted us to act as New Brunswick's
redevelopment authority. We have assisted in the
financing of over $400 million of revitalization over much of
the last 25 years.

           Through the federal Department of Housing and Urban
Development, the New Brunswick Housing Authority has been given
the opportunity to change the face of public housing in New Brunswick.
By entrusting us with a $7.4 million grant, HUD has shown they
believe we can not only provide more suitable public housing,
but more importantly integrate those on the lowest rungs of the
income ladder back into the community. This HOPE VI grant has
allowed us to leverage an additional $35 million that will be
used to
not only re-house our residents but also provide them with the
necessary social services to survive in the private housing market.

           Kevin Quince
           EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
           NEW BRUNSWICK HOUSING AND REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY


-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!
