Post ID:554
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-11 13:22:21
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Reply Wanted: Housing Authority Letter to HNT
Message:

On Sept. 16 and 17, as Tropical Storm Floyd caused
>the Raritan River to swell over its banks and began
>taking over the land on which the New Brunswick Homes sit, our
>residents trusted us as we provided them with food, transportation
>and lodging; protected their belongings; and returned them to
>their homes in a timely fashion.

Mr. Quince conveniently forgets that while the city was busy bailing out the 
well-to-do residents of the new-fandangled "Renaissance" condos, not to 
mention the police station, the NB Homes residents had to fend for 
themselves as the flood waters rose around their homes.  Also, it was on 
account of the extraordinary efforts of NJFO & Co. that forced the city to 
relocate the NB Homes residents into motels rather than sucking it up on the 
flea-bitten mattresses on the cramped & damp Lord Stirling gym floor. -MS

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:555
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-11 13:30:27
Subject:State's response to Protest Mode Organizing
Message:

National Guard Is Prepared to Deploy 3,000 Troops in
L.A.
By H.G. REZA, Times Staff Writer
http://www.latimes.com
The California National Guard is prepared to deploy as
many as 3,000 soldiers to help quell any civil disorder during the 
Democratic
National
Convention. In addition to supporting law enforcement, the troops will 
assist
firefighters in a plan that includes the use of the Los Alamitos-based 
Weapons
of Mass
Destruction team to combat acts of chemical, biological or nuclear 
terrorism.
Maj.
Gen. Paul D. Monroe Jr., the Guard's
adjutant general in Sacramento, said the preparations
are precautionary.
Soldiers and equipment can be deployed within 24 hours
after they are requested by local officials, he said. "The Los
Angeles Police Department is running the security program for the DNC. We 
were
not
included in the [local] planning," Monroe said. "It's felt that they have 
enough
law
enforcement personnel available to them to handle any problem. But we would
be negligent if we didn't plan for any eventuality."
In preparing for the Democratic convention, the LAPD will be supported by 
the
Los
Angeles County Sheriff's Department, California Highway Patrol and officers 
from
various
police departments in nearby counties. The security
teams will include federal agents assigned to protect Vice President Al Gore 
and
other
officials. State authorities are still smarting from the 1992 Los Angeles 
riots,
which
caught the Guard unprepared. Political indecision and lack of
coordination in Sacramento led to delays in mobilizing
the Guard, and some soldiers were sent to riot areas without ammunition.
This time, Guard officials began preparations in January. The plan took 
effect
last
Friday and will remain in place through Aug. 18. "For the past two years, 
there
have
been concerns from the electric utilities regarding a severe drain on
the power system in the summer months. Brownouts are a
very real possibility, as is a heat emergency in the Los Angeles
area," said the 31-page operational plan. The warning about possible power
shortages
is especially timely after the hot weather that has led to high electrical 
usage
and
taxed the state's power grid. "Nobody can predict what's going to
happen," Monroe said. "But we prepare for the eventuality in case we're 
called."
But
preparedness does not mean that soldiers
will be quartered in local armories during the convention. "We have not been
asked to
stage forces or to be prepared that way," Monroe said.
Instead, the Guard's plan
said that "on 24 hours notice [the Guard] .. will
deploy up to three 1,000-person response teams to the Los Angeles area in
support of
civilian authority." The troops probably will assemble at Camp San Luis 
Obispo
and the
Armed Forces Reserve Center in Los Alamitos and then convoy to Los
Angeles. In 1992, a large number of soldiers were sent
to the Los Angeles riots without locking plates in their M-16 assault 
rifles,
preventing the weapons from being fired fully automatic. This time 
commanders
were
ordered to have locking plates "installed and functional" by July 31.

Post ID:559
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-14 10:53:37
Subject:Letter to Ed(S.L.): Revitalization, not Gentrification!
Message:

LETTER TO THE EDITOR: Revitalization, not Gentrification!

Dear Editor:

(Regarding the Aug. 6, Star Leger expose on Newark development trends)

At a recent commemoration of the 1967 Newark Rebellion sponsored by the 
People�s Organization for Progress (P.O.P.), community artist and poet Halim 
Sulliman lamented that the current administration is turning �Brick City 
into Stick Town.�

This potent  metaphor describes the treacherous path of development being 
forced on the city by the likes of Newark�s deputy mayor, Al Faiella.  In 
his self-styled �reactive� manner, Faiella called community activist Nancy 
Zak �shortsighted� for criticizing the James administration�s policy of 
catering to profit-driven developers whose shoddy construction projects 
undermine the fabric of city neighborhoods.

Dean Urs Gauchat of the NJ School of Architecture correctly pointed out that 
these developers must rely on the Zoning Board�s support.  Only such a 
rubber stamp committee of political appointees would allow the destruction 
of sound historic brick buildings while constructing flimsy stick houses on 
poisoned soil, and variances encouraging developers to maximize their 
wallets while minimizing the integrity of their work.

But neither should we embrace City Councilperson Amadour�s desire to follow 
Hoboken�s lead in saving the historic buildings while yuppifying the poor, 
working-class communities with chic middle-class zombies who don�t know 
where they are.  The James Administration�s �dance with the devil�opers 
means that residents continue to get burned as the debate on how best to 
gentrify (ethnically cleanse) Newark rages on.  Indeed, asking the market 
frenzied land-snatchers and wealthy business elite to determine the future 
of Newark is like asking the fox to look after the chicken coup.

This city needs a democratically determined central plan for revitalization 
that preserves the integrity of Newark�s historic neighborhoods, focuses on 
the needs of its working-class residents, and concretely supports it�s local 
artists through grants and specific zoning for an indigenous arts district.

Matthew Smith, Newark

________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

Post ID:560
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-14 10:59:26
Subject:Get the Facts -- 8/10/00
Message:

GET THE FACTS 8/10/00
    Please Distribute

PUBLIC EDUCATION IMPROVEMENTS STALLED IN CONGRESS

    Since 1965, the Elementary Secondary Education Act (ESEA) has governed 
federal education programs for kindergarten through 12th grade. Congress is 
required to review ESEA every five years and make  changes to address issues 
facing students in our public schools. For the first time in 35 years, it is 
unlikely that Congress will complete ESEA.

At issue is whether federal dollars, which account for approximately 7% of 
funding for public education, should be targeted to improve student 
achievement and teacher quality.

Congress� failure to adequately address the following issues is stalling 
passage of ESEA:

* Repairing and modernizing schools. More than 14 million children in the 
United States attend schools that need extensive repairs. Students learn 
better in safe, modern schools with the latest technology, not in 
dilapidated, overcrowded classrooms.

* Reducing class size. Research shows that class size reduction in grades 
1-3, combined with a qualified teacher, leads to higher student achievement 
in reading and math. In the current school-year, approximately 1.7 million 
children are expected to benefit directly by being educated in smaller 
classes.

* Strengthening accountability. To ensure that in local school disctricts 
federal funds are targeted to raising academic standards, improving teacher 
quality, and improving student achievement, school  districts must be held 
accountable for student performance.

HERE�S WHAT YOU CAN DO!

* Help spread the word; work with friends and family to distribute this 
alert in your community.

* Call your members of Congress at 202/224-3121 and urge them to continue to 
target federal education funding to improving student achievement and 
raising academic standards.

WOMEN'S NETWORK FOR CHANGE ~ American Association of University Women ~ 
Advocates for Youth ~ American College of Nurse-Midwives ~American College 
of Obstetricians and Gynecologists ~ American Jewish Congress ~ American 
Medical Women's Association ~ Business and Professional Women/USA ~ Center 
for the Child Care Workforce ~ Center for Ethics in Action ~ Center for 
Policy Alternatives ~ Coalition of Labor Union Women ~ Federally Employed 
Women ~ Feminist Majority ~ Fifty plus One ~ Girls Incorporated ~ Gray 
Panthers ~ Hadassah ~ MANA, A National   Latina Organization ~ Ms. 
Foundation for Women ~ 9to5, National Association of Working Women ~ 
National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League ~ National Abortion 
Federation ~ National Association of Social Workers ~ National Council of 
Jewish Women ~ National Council of Negro Women ~ National Hook-Up of Black 
Women, Inc. ~ National Network of Abortion Funds ~ National Organization for 
Women ~ National Partnership for Women and Families ~ National Political 
Congress of Black Women, Inc. ~ National Women's Law Center ~ National 
Women's Political Caucus ~ New Girl Times ~OWL The Voice of Mid-Life and 
Older Women ~ Planned Parenthood Federation of America ~ ProChoice Resource 
Center ~ Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice ~ United States Student 
Association ~ Wider Opportunities for Women ~ Women Work! ~ Women's Campaign 
Fund ~ Women's Environment and Development Organization ~ Women�s 
International League for Peace and Freedom ~ YWCA of the U.S.A.

    FOR MORE INFORMATION ON THESE ALERTS, CALL 800/608-5286

            OF THE NIGHT. NO RAIN, WE'RE OUTSIDE. GOOD TIMES, YES

            ARTHOUSE, INDEPENDENT PROGRESSIVE SPACE FOR MUSIC, ART, 
DANCE 
AND WORDS 
            MEANS TO BUILD CULTURAL COMMUNITY AND BROAD ALLIANCES 
ACROSS 
ALL GROUPS OF 
            PEOPLE RIGHT HERE IN CENTRAL JERSEY AND BEYOND. 

            SO COME DOWN WITH FIVE BUCKS TO BENEFIT OUR 
CULTURE-BUILDING 
EFFORTS. TAKE HAMILTON STREET OUT OF NEW BRUNSWICK TOWARDS FRANKLIN. 
            THROUGH THE HIGHLAND AVE. LIGHT AND WE'RE RIGHT ACROSS
THE 
STREET FROM 
            KRAUSZER'S. CALL 732 729 0873 OR REPLY TO THIS EMAIL FOR 
MORE 
INFO.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:565
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-16 12:20:32
Subject:HNT: Board of Ed , Censure of Martin Arocho
Message:

As seen in today's Home News:

NEW BRUNSWICK: City's board of ed censures president 


Published in the Home News Tribune 8/16/00 
By SHARON WATERS
STAFF WRITER

City board of education President Martin Arocho was censured
at last night's board meeting for violating the School Ethics
Act with a 1998 vote in favor of awarding a $415,000 contract
to his employer, the Puerto Rican Action Board. 

The state School Ethics Commission, which operates under the
state Department of Education, determined Arocho had violated
a state statute and ordered the board of education to post and
read in public the resolution of censure.

"To me, they imposed the least of the penalties. I don't think
I did anything wrong by voting for the contract," said Arocho,
noting the contract had been voted for in the past by the board.
"I didn't think it was affecting me or PRAB." 

Possible sanctions are a reprimand, censure, suspension from
the school board or removal from the school board.

Arocho had asked the commission for a reprimand, which would
have been privately issued, but the commission reaffirmed a public
censure was appropriate.

"It's a reasonably appropriate penalty, but I think Arocho should
have been suspended. His action was contrary to well-established
law but suspensions are rare so I have go along with the decision,"
said New Brunswick activist Brian Villa.

Last year Villa filed a complaint against Arocho and board member
Edwin Gutierrez for voting on a July 1998 resolution awarding
a $415,583 contract to the nonprofit PRAB to provide preschool
for city 4-year-olds.

Villa says the two board members should have abstained from the
vote because they were both listed as members of PRAB in a board
flier and because Arocho worked for PRAB. He also challenged
Gutierrez's appointment to the board by Mayor Jim Cahill because
he is a city employee working in the Community Development Division.

The commission found that Arocho was not a member of PRAB at
the time of the vote, but he was an employee of the organization,
and therefore was in violation of a statute that prohibits school
officials from acting on any matter in which they or an immediate
family member has a direct financial involvement.

The commission dismissed the complaints against Gutierrez, finding
that Gutierrez's employment with the city did not constitute
a substantial conflict, and that Gutierrez was not a member of
PRAB at the time of the vote in 1998. Gutierrez was a founding
member of PRAB in 1971 and served on the group's board of trustees
until 1991.

Villa has appealed the commission's finding on Gutierrez.

Sharon Waters: (732) 246-5500 Ext. 7270. E-mail swaters@...


from the Home News Tribune 

Published: August 16, 2000


-----

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:569
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-16 17:58:04
Subject:Fwd: Exhibit @ Sumei Arts Center - Newark
Message:



>From: Khabirah Myers <kmyers@...>
>Subject: Exhibit @ Sumei Arts Center - Newark
>Date: Wed, 16 Aug 2000 13:57:11 -0400
>
>Brother Kalamu,
>
>please post.  Thank you again!
>- k.Sumei Multidisciplinary Arts Center
19 Liberty Street & Corner of Lafayette St.
Newark, NJ 07102
Cuba: The Illusive Island

September 9 to October 14

The Works of Afro-Cuban Realist Painter Raul Villarreal

Reception -Saturday September 9, 2000   4pm to 8pm

Raul Villarreal's realism is steeped in the symbology of Santeria,
romantic Cuban/Spanish mythology and nationalism.  Like many Cubans,
Villarreal yearns for his Cuban home, his culture, his people, his religion,
experienced as a child and a young man  in Cuba.  To Villarreal, the island 
is like an illusive woman, one he can see but cannot reach.  Using his 
traditional colors and those of the nature of the island, Villarreal, 
dresses his women in the colors of Orishas and surrounds them by the hungry 
Cuban landscape. He makes no bones about expressing the connectedness of 
Cuban life to its African religious roots.  At the same time Villarreal 
involves himself in a personal romance with the figure, his brush becoming 
the hand or fingers that smooth the flesh of his island women, as if to 
soothe them in their hunger to find again, the homeland.  A hunger, that has 
some silent lust, some longing, some pain and always behind it all the 
constant yearning desire.

A New Jersey painter, Raul Villarreal is a graduate of New Jersey City 
University, under the tutelage of Professor of Art and Artist of renown Ben 
Jones.  Villarreal is from the city of San Francisco De Paula, the town in 
which Hemingway lived.  His father was considered to be Hemingway's Cuban 
son and Villarreal grew up with the legend of Hemingway and the great 
artists that were part of La Finka as part of his youth's education.

He is the outgrowth of a tradition of Cuban realism, that other family 
members have practiced in generations past, and whose works still hang in 
the home of Earnest Hemingway.

Gallery Hours: During exhibits- Wednesdays 1pm to 6pm; Saturdays and
Sundays 11am to 6pm.  Other times by appointment.

Contact person: Yoland Skeete
Phone:973-643-7883  Fax:973-242-7914
Email: SunMeidia@...
www.sumei.org


________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:570
Sender:Groove Meister <Groovemeister007@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-16 18:24:09
Subject:Text of Bd. of Ed. Question
Message:

Following is the text of the proposed letter to be
sent to the County Clerk regarding the text of the
Board of Education question.  Please contact me with
any questions or comments upon same.

Groove Meister


NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLES� CAMPAIGN
149 REDMOND STREET
NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ 08901
732/545-5756
												


							August 19, 2000

Elaine Flynn
Middlesex County Clerk
1 JFK Square
New Brunswick, NJ 08901

		Re: 	New Brunswick Municipal Question
			November 2000 General Election

Dear Ms. Flynn:

	On behalf of the New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign, I
am writing to provide a suggestion as to the
appropriate language to appear on the November 2000
ballot in respect of the municipal question to be
voted on by the voters of New Brunswick regarding the
change of the board of education from an elected to an
appointed board.  We believe that pursuant to N.J.S.A.
19:14-1 et seq., you are the official responsible for
preparing the phrasing of this question.  In the event
you are not, we are also sending copies of this
letters to other officials who may be responsible for
this task, and by copy of this letter to them, we ask
them to adhere to the same suggestions.

	As you know, both statutory and case law impose a
number of requirements with respect to public
questions to voted upon by the electorate.  This case
law is fully applicable to public questions involving
boards of education.  N.J.S.A. 19:60-1(b); N.J.S.A.
19:3-6.

	In particular, this body of law emphasizes that
questions must be clearly written, easily understood
by all voters, and address the heart of the matter to
be voted upon, without technical or otherwise
confusing language.  In addition, certain questions
(including this one) must include an interpretive
statement which must likewise meet certain criteria of
clarity, informativeness, and fairness.  Thus, as to
the question itself, N.J.S.A. 19:3-6 provides:

Any public question voted upon at an election shall be
presented in simple language that can be easily
understood by the voter.  The printed phrasing of said
question on the ballots shall clearly set forth the
true purpose of the matter being voted upon.  
(emphasis added); see also Board of Ed. of Hackensack
v. City of Hackensack, 63 N.J. Super. 560 (App. Div.
1960).

In addition, the interpretive statement must be
drafted following similar principles.    Last year, in
Morris Bd. of Freeholders v. State, 159 N.J. 565, 582
(1999), the Supreme Court reaffirmed earlier precedent
mandating clarity of interpretive statements:

Questions put to the voters must be accompanied by an
interpretive statement that serves as an aid to
understanding the matter under consideration.  See
N.J.S.A. 19:3-6 (mandating "brief statement
interpreting the ... [question] and setting forth the
true purpose of the matter being voted upon");  see
also Gormley v. Lan, 88 N.J. 26, 37 (1981) (stating
interpretative statement is designed to "help the
voter understand more about the amendment than the
public question tells him, for the purpose of aiding
him in his decision").  The interpretative statement
should "get to the heart of the matter as understood
by those who are knowledgeable about it."  Gormley,
supra, 88 N.J. at 37.   Put another way, the
interpretive statement should always be informative
and fair.  Id. at 37-38;  Kimmelman v. Burgio, 204
N.J. Super. 44, 53 (App. Div. 1985).
(emphasis added).  In sum, the question and statement
must be informative, fair, and easily understood. 
This text on the ballot must be drafted in a manner to
state �clearly� what is being voted upon; to get to
the heart of it; and to aid in informing the voter of
his or her decision.

	The Peoples� Campaign believes that the language
actually chosen when this same question was placed on
the ballot in previous years (and which, presumably,
might provide a guide to choosing the text of the
question this year), does not comport with the
applicable legal requirements.  More particularly, the
1998 ballot question asked voters to decided whether
New Brunswick �which is governed by the provisions of
N.J.S.A. 18A:9-2 - Type I school districts, be
governed by the provisions of N.J.S.A. 18A:9-3 - Type
II school districts?�  This question sheds absolutely
no light on what is being asked of voters unless the
voter engaged in extensive statutory research on the
meaning and implications of each of those statutes. 
Thus, the question, by failing to disclose that its
objective is a change from an elected to an appointed
board, on its face, clearly violates the requirements
of N.J.S.A. 19:3-6, mandating that a question be posed
in �simple language that can be easily understood by
the voter� and �set[ting] forth the true purpose of
the matter being voted upon.�  A decision to use that
same text in the upcoming election would be a clear
violation of law.

	The interpretive statement chosen in 1998 is equally
out of compliance with the law.  Although the 1998
interpretive statement disclosed the general nature of
the change being presented to voters, it was done in a
confusing manner, including a superfluous statement
about appeals of budget decisions to the Commissioner
of Education, which would occur under both an elected
and an appointed board of education.  Morris Board of
Freeholders, supra, mandates that the statement must
�help the voter understand� the question for the
express purpose of �aiding him in his decision� and
must �get to the heart of the matter� without
superfluous or confusing language that fails to
identify both the current system and the effect of
approval of the question.  The interpretive statement
in 1998, contrary to Morris Board of Freeholders, was
neither �informative� nor �fair� and its use in the
upcoming election would also be a clear violation of
that mandate.  

	In that regard, we suggest the following question and
interpretive statement be placed on the ballot to
ensure compliance with the above-quoted statutes and
decisional law:

MUNICIPAL QUESTION

	Shall the school district of the City of New
Brunswick, which is now governed by the provisions of
N.J.S.A. 18A:9-2 (mayorally-appointed board of
education with budget ratified by Board of School
Estimate) be governed instead by the provisions of
N.J.S.A. 18A:9-3 (elected board of education with
budget ratified by voters)?

INTERPRETIVE STATEMENT
Approval of the question would result in New
Brunswick�s board of education being elected by the
voters of the school district, and the budget being
ratified by the voters of the school district. 
Currently, board members are appointed by the mayor
and the budget is ratified by the Board of School
Estimate.

	If you have further questions about this, please do
not hesitate to contact me.  I look forward to hearing
a response from you shortly so that any differences of
opinion about the text of the question may be resolved
in time for the printing of the ballot.


Respectfully submitted,

							NEW BRUNSWICK
							PEOPLES� CAMPAIGN


							By: 					
							       

cc:	DAG Sharon Young,
	  Attorney General�s Office
	Daniel Torrisi,
	  New Brunswick City Clerk

I know most people have seen this, but it is a good reminder of why we must 
Beat Bush!
Louise
>
The state of Texas, under the leadership of Governor George W. Bush, is
>ranked:
>
>              50th in spending for teachers' salaries
>              49th in spending on the environment
>              48th in per-capita funding for public health
>              47th in delivery of social services
>              42nd in child-support collections
>              41st in per-capita spending on public education
>
>       And ...
>
>             5th in percentage of population living in poverty
>             1st in air and water pollution
>             1st in percentage of poor working parents without insurance
>             1st in percentage of children without health insurance
>             1st in executions (average 1 every 2 weeks for Bush's 5 years 
>as Governor)
>
>Just think of what he could do for the country if he were president!
>

>
>             John R. Finnegan Jr., Ph.D.
>             Professor and Associate Dean For Academic Affairs
>             School of Public Health, University of Minnesota

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:577
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-17 12:05:29
Subject:re Star-Ledger School Ethics Complaint w/ Corrective Notes
Message:

A NOTE ON THE ARTICLE: The paper's article has some inconsistencies
and is incorrect in at least one place.  Clairifications and
corrective comments follow.

First, "the ethical line" is the law. 

Second, the (local school) board did not reprimand Arocho, but
was ordered to read the resolution at its next scheduled meeting.


Third, the censure is not the "lightest form of punishment";
that would be a reprimand. A censure is a significant punishment
--that's why the Resolution of Censure was read, and that's why
the Resolution of Censure has to be posted in public places for
thirty (30 ) days. 

Fourth, the complaint filed against Arocho (C16-99), did not
include Gutierrez (C16-99). 

Fifth, a "reprimand" is a lower form of punishment than a censure.
 The text of the School Ethics Commission decision can be found
on the State of New Jersey homepage under its own link, by visiting
the state department of education website.

I'm sorry there has been confusion in this matter. I anticipate
a future remedy. The Star-Ledger article follows below.

**********

School board censures president 

08/17/00

By Sue Epstein
STAFF WRITER


The New Brunswick Board of Education has publicly censured its
president for crossing an ethical line. 


The board reprimanded Martin Arocho for failing to abstain from
a 1998 board vote to award a $415,583 contract for preschool
services to the nonprofit Puerto Rican Action Board, for which
Arocho works. 


The state School Ethics Commission ordered Arocho's censure --
the lightest form of punishment he could receive -- and state
Education Commissioner David Hespe upheld the panel's decision.



Arocho could not be reached for comment yesterday. 


Brian Villa, the activist who filed the complaint against Arocho
with the ethics commission, yesterday called the board's action
his vindication. 


''It was gratifying to be found to have been ethically correct.
I was personally attacked for filing the complaint and it was
called frivolous. The state commissioner of education didn't
agree," said Villa. 


The complaint Villa filed also named Edwin Gutierrez, another
board member, who voted for the project, but the commission dismissed
Villa's complaint against him, saying there was no indication
Gutierrez was linked to the Puerto Rican Action Board. 


Gutierrez, who helped found the Puerto Rican Action Board in
1971, gave up his seat on its board of trustees in 1991. The
commission acknowledged that close connections can outlast direct
affiliation but said it "cannot conclude in the present case
that such a connection exists." 


Villa said yesterday he has filed an appeal of that dismissal
with the Appellate Division of Superior Court. 


Beyond censure, the commission could have reprimanded, suspended
or removed Arocho from the school board.

-----
Sent using MailStart.com ( http://MailStart.Com/welcome.html )
The FREE way to access your mailbox via any web browser, anywhere!

>From: Groove Meister <Groovemeister007@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpc] Text of Bd. of Ed. Question
>Date: Wed, 16 Aug 2000 15:24:09 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Following is the text of the proposed letter to be
>sent to the County Clerk regarding the text of the
>Board of Education question.  Please contact me with
>any questions or comments upon same.
>
>Groove Meister
>
>
>NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLES� CAMPAIGN
>149 REDMOND STREET
>NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ 08901
>732/545-5756
>
>
>
>							August 19, 2000
>
>Elaine Flynn
>Middlesex County Clerk
>1 JFK Square
>New Brunswick, NJ 08901
>
>		Re: 	New Brunswick Municipal Question
>			November 2000 General Election
>
>Dear Ms. Flynn:
>
>	On behalf of the New Brunswick Peoples� Campaign, I
>am writing to provide a suggestion as to the
>appropriate language to appear on the November 2000
>ballot in respect of the municipal question to be
>voted on by the voters of New Brunswick regarding the
>change of the board of education from an elected to an
>appointed board.  We believe that pursuant to N.J.S.A.
>19:14-1 et seq., you are the official responsible for
>preparing the phrasing of this question.  In the event
>you are not, we are also sending copies of this
>letters to other officials who may be responsible for
>this task, and by copy of this letter to them, we ask
>them to adhere to the same suggestions.
>
>	As you know, both statutory and case law impose a
>number of requirements with respect to public
>questions to voted upon by the electorate.  This case
>law is fully applicable to public questions involving
>boards of education.  N.J.S.A. 19:60-1(b); N.J.S.A.
>19:3-6.
>
>	In particular, this body of law emphasizes that
>questions must be clearly written, easily understood
>by all voters, and address the heart of the matter to
>be voted upon, without technical or otherwise
>confusing language.  In addition, certain questions
>(including this one) must include an interpretive
>statement which must likewise meet certain criteria of
>clarity, informativeness, and fairness.  Thus, as to
>the question itself, N.J.S.A. 19:3-6 provides:
>
>Any public question voted upon at an election shall be
>presented in simple language that can be easily
>understood by the voter.  The printed phrasing of said
>question on the ballots shall clearly set forth the
>true purpose of the matter being voted upon.
>(emphasis added); see also Board of Ed. of Hackensack
>v. City of Hackensack, 63 N.J. Super. 560 (App. Div.
>1960).
>
>In addition, the interpretive statement must be
>drafted following similar principles.    Last year, in
>Morris Bd. of Freeholders v. State, 159 N.J. 565, 582
>(1999), the Supreme Court reaffirmed earlier precedent
>mandating clarity of interpretive statements:
>
>Questions put to the voters must be accompanied by an
>interpretive statement that serves as an aid to
>understanding the matter under consideration.  See
>N.J.S.A. 19:3-6 (mandating "brief statement
>interpreting the ... [question] and setting forth the
>true purpose of the matter being voted upon");  see
>also Gormley v. Lan, 88 N.J. 26, 37 (1981) (stating
>interpretative statement is designed to "help the
>voter understand more about the amendment than the
>public question tells him, for the purpose of aiding
>him in his decision").  The interpretative statement
>should "get to the heart of the matter as understood
>by those who are knowledgeable about it."  Gormley,
>supra, 88 N.J. at 37.   Put another way, the
>interpretive statement should always be informative
>and fair.  Id. at 37-38;  Kimmelman v. Burgio, 204
>N.J. Super. 44, 53 (App. Div. 1985).
>(emphasis added).  In sum, the question and statement
>must be informative, fair, and easily understood.
>This text on the ballot must be drafted in a manner to
>state �clearly� what is being voted upon; to get to
>the heart of it; and to aid in informing the voter of
>his or her decision.
>
>	The Peoples� Campaign believes that the language
>actually chosen when this same question was placed on
>the ballot in previous years (and which, presumably,
>might provide a guide to choosing the text of the
>question this year), does not comport with the
>applicable legal requirements.  More particularly, the
>1998 ballot question asked voters to decided whether
>New Brunswick �which is governed by the provisions of
>N.J.S.A. 18A:9-2 - Type I school districts, be
>governed by the provisions of N.J.S.A. 18A:9-3 - Type
>II school districts?�  This question sheds absolutely
>no light on what is being asked of voters unless the
>voter engaged in extensive statutory research on the
>meaning and implications of each of those statutes.
>Thus, the question, by failing to disclose that its
>objective is a change from an elected to an appointed
>board, on its face, clearly violates the requirements
>of N.J.S.A. 19:3-6, mandating that a question be posed
>in �simple language that can be easily understood by
>the voter� and �set[ting] forth the true purpose of
>the matter being voted upon.�  A decision to use that
>same text in the upcoming election would be a clear
>violation of law.
>
>	The interpretive statement chosen in 1998 is equally
>out of compliance with the law.  Although the 1998
>interpretive statement disclosed the general nature of
>the change being presented to voters, it was done in a
>confusing manner, including a superfluous statement
>about appeals of budget decisions to the Commissioner
>of Education, which would occur under both an elected
>and an appointed board of education.  Morris Board of
>Freeholders, supra, mandates that the statement must
>�help the voter understand� the question for the
>express purpose of �aiding him in his decision� and
>must �get to the heart of the matter� without
>superfluous or confusing language that fails to
>identify both the current system and the effect of
>approval of the question.  The interpretive statement
>in 1998, contrary to Morris Board of Freeholders, was
>neither �informative� nor �fair� and its use in the
>upcoming election would also be a clear violation of
>that mandate.
>
>	In that regard, we suggest the following question and
>interpretive statement be placed on the ballot to
>ensure compliance with the above-quoted statutes and
>decisional law:
>
>MUNICIPAL QUESTION
>
>	Shall the school district of the City of New
>Brunswick, which is now governed by the provisions of
>N.J.S.A. 18A:9-2 (mayorally-appointed board of
>education with budget ratified by Board of School
>Estimate) be governed instead by the provisions of
>N.J.S.A. 18A:9-3 (elected board of education with
>budget ratified by voters)?
>
>INTERPRETIVE STATEMENT
>Approval of the question would result in New
>Brunswick�s board of education being elected by the
>voters of the school district, and the budget being
>ratified by the voters of the school district.
>Currently, board members are appointed by the mayor
>and the budget is ratified by the Board of School
>Estimate.
>
>	If you have further questions about this, please do
>not hesitate to contact me.  I look forward to hearing
>a response from you shortly so that any differences of
>opinion about the text of the question may be resolved
>in time for the printing of the ballot.
>
>
>Respectfully submitted,
>
>							NEW BRUNSWICK
>							PEOPLES� CAMPAIGN
>
>
>							By:
>
>
>cc:	DAG Sharon Young,
>	  Attorney General�s Office
>	Daniel Torrisi,
>	  New Brunswick City Clerk
>
>
>
>__________________________________________________
>Do You Yahoo!?
>Send instant messages & get email alerts with Yahoo! Messenger.
>http://im.yahoo.com/
>
>
>
>To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@...
>
>To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: 
>nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@...

Post ID:580
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-19 22:31:40
Subject:Non-New Brunswick Post About Toast
Message:

--- Original Message ---
Robert Weissman <rob@...> Wrote on 
Sat, 19 Aug 2000 21:48:53 -0400 (EDT)
 ------------------ 
Toast
By Russell Mokhiber and Robert Weissman

About six years ago, a friend gave us a toaster. It was a present.
The
friend bought the toaster from Williams-Sonoma, the San Francisco-based
kitchen store, with outlets in upscale malls throughout the United
States.
 
It was a modern toaster, which means first, that it was made
primarily out
of plastic instead of stainless steel, second, it had all kinds
of gizmos
on it, and third, if something goes wrong with it, in all likelihood,
because of the modern electronic devices embedded in it, you
won't be able
to fix it.
 
On these new modern toasters, you can calibrate the shade of
the toast --
you can set the toaster for lighter or darker toast.
 
Our first plastic toaster lasted about two years before it stopped
toasting.
 
Luckily, Williams-Sonoma will replace any item if you are "not
satisfied
with your purchase for any reason."
 
We took it back to the store here in Washington, D.C. and told
the sales
clerk that we received the toaster as a present purchased from
Williams-Sonoma and that the toaster wasn't working. The sales
clerk said
-- no problem, here's a new one.
 
And she handed over a brand new Kenwood Four Slice plastic toaster,
which
lasted a little longer than a year, before it stopped toasting.
So, we
took the Kenwood back and told the clerk at the store what happened
and
the clerk said -- no problem, and she handed over a new toaster
--
different make, this one was a Toastronic Ultra.
 
The following year, same problem. And same solution. We turned
in the
Toastronic Ultra and return it for a Kitchen Aid Toaster.
 
Last week, the Kitchen Aid Toaster stopped toasting on one side.
We took
it in to the Williams-Sonoma, and the clerk handed over a Cuisinart
plastic toaster.
 
The Cuisinart toaster has all kinds of features, including a
Bagel button,
a defrost button, a reheat button, the now traditional lighter
and darker
buttons, a cancel reset button, and most annoyingly, a "shade
control"
panel, which in bright red lights (just what you don't want to
see in the
morning) tells you where exactly on a scale of very light toast
to very
dark toast you have calibrated your new toaster for this morning.
 
We have a friend who is a super cautious person, but who believes
that
toasters should last a lifetime. (Forgive him -- he is from a
different
era.) So anyway, he gets one of these new plastic toasters, and
the
plastic lever falls off. Now everytime he wants toast, he throws
caution
to the wind and sticks a butter knife into the toaster's lever
slot to
hold down the lever until it clicks in.
 
Annoyed at this repeated failure of modern technology, we called
Williams-Sonoma's customer service line. The sales person answered
and we
told her our story about returning the plastic toasters periodically
to
her store. She said she didn't think she could do anything about
the
complaint. We asked -- why not just sell a toaster that lasts?
 
And she said -- we do. It's stainless steel Dualit Combi Toaster
and it
sells for $319.00. The plastic Cuisinart that we just received
sells for
$99.95.
 
"You can buy the Dualit and it will toast for you well into your
90s," she
said with a snicker.
 
In San Francisco, Williams-Sonoma spokesperson Tracy Brown told
us that
her store tries to sell the "newest and greatest" products. She
said she
checked with a buyer, and complaints about toasters breaking
down "are not
common."
 
Brown then called back to report that "we identified reliability
problems
with the Kitchen Aid and that's why we got rid of it."
 
"We really believe that the Cuisinart toaster will last," she
said.
 
Now, of course, we remember our parents' toasters -- the aluminum
Toastmasters that they toasted with -- toasters that lasted a
lifetime.
 
These classic toasters had no bagel button, no defrost button,
no reheat
button, and definitely no shade control panel.
 
You simply stuck the slices of bread into the slot, pushed down
the lever,
and waited for the toast to pop up.
 
So, with all the wonders of modern technology, why can't the
companies
make a reasonably priced toaster that lasts?
 
We put this question to Holly Smith-Berry, marketing director
at the
Columbia, Missouri based Toastmaster, the company that sold the
first pop
up toaster in 1926 (Model 1A-1) for $12.50.
 
"We get letters from our customers, wanting to send us their
old
Toastmaster toasters, telling us they love the triple loop design
on the
side of the toaster, and they are amazed at how long they have
lasted --
50 or 60 years, in some cases," Smith-Berry said. "But if you
took our
1940 steel toaster and costed it out for inflation, it would
cost $170
today."
 
She said that Toastmaster toasters today range from $10 to $30
and they
are tested to last for 12 or so years.
 
"We've seen toasters selling in Wal-Mart for $7.96," she said.
"So, if you
don't want to clean the crumbs out of your toaster, you can just
get rid
of it and buy a new one."
 
"Unfortunately, we live in a more disposable society," she says.
 
Toastmaster makes a heavy duty toaster, but it's built in Germany
by Bosch
Siemens, it's designed by Porsche, and it sells for $225.
 
The decline of the reliable, reasonably priced toaster is symbolic
of
what's gone wrong with modern society -- shoddy products, disposable
society, planned obsolescence, high-tech but no respect.
 
Shade control in, quality out.


Russell Mokhiber is editor of the Washington, D.C.-based Corporate
Crime
Reporter. Robert Weissman is editor of the Washington, D.C.-based
Multinational Monitor. They are co-authors of Corporate Predators:
The
Hunt for MegaProfits and the Attack on Democracy (Monroe, Maine:
Common
Courage Press, 1999).

(c) Russell Mokhiber and Robert Weissman



_______________________________________________

Focus on the Corporation is a weekly column written by Russell
Mokhiber
and Robert Weissman. Please feel free to forward the column to
friends or 
repost the column on other lists. If you would like to post the
column on 
a web site or publish it in print format, we ask that you first
contact us 
(russell@... or rob@...).

Focus on the Corporation is distributed to individuals on the
listserve 
corp-focus@.... To subscribe to corp-focus, send
an e-mail 
message to corp-focus-request@... with the text:
subscribe

Focus on the Corporation columns are posted at
<http://www.corporatepredators.org>.

Postings on corp-focus are limited to the columns. If you would
like to 
comment on the columns, send a message to russell@...
or 
rob@....

Post ID:581
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-20 12:29:06
Subject:HNT Article: Resident Tapes Council Meeting....
Message:

You too can do this. In lots of places. If you go to the city
meetings.... But do you??

--BV 


August 20, 2000  		
 
Piscataway resident videotapes council session for TV 


Published in the Home News Tribune 8/20/00 
By ROSA CIRIANNI
STAFF WRITER

Piscataway resident Larry Halper took matters into his own hands.


After being told by the Township Council that it does not want
its meetings televised on Piscataway Community Television Center,
Channel 71 on Cablevision, he videotaped a meeting.

Council members and Mayor Helen Merolla listed reasons why they
were against televising the meetings. They said it would be too
costly, no one would be interested in watching, it would cause
too much confusion, the meetings would drag out, and people such
as Halper would use the sessions as an opportunity to showcase
their gripes.

So Halper, one of the 16 owners of Cornell Dairy Farm fighting
a plan by Piscataway and Middlesex County to condemn the farm
for open space, brought a tripod and video camera to a council
meeting on Aug. 8. He said he wanted to have the tape aired on
PCTC. But he'll have to pay PCTC to transfer his tape onto the
TV station's tapes, which would cost roughly $30, said Peter
Namen, PCTC production facilitator.

Station manager Debbe Gist has the final say over what gets aired,
Namen said, adding that to his knowledge, no one from Piscataway
has ever asked PCTC to broadcast council meetings. Gist could
not be reached for comment.

PCTC, created in 1985 through a federal government grant, is
partially funded by the township and other sponsors, Namen said.
It serves Piscataway, Bridgewater, Raritan, South Bound Brook,
Bound Brook, Middlesex, Dunellen and Somerville. And it does
not charge the public to broadcast any tapes.

First Ward Councilman Mark Hardenburg asked Township Attorney
Howard Gran at an Aug. 8 council meeting about Piscataway's laws
and guidelines for video cameras at meetings. The council has
a list of 14 regulations for video-camera use that were adopted
two years ago after former Republican Township Council candidate
Ray Capone in 1997 did the same thing as Halper - set up a video
camera on a tripod. Officials claimed Capone's efforts were distracting
during the meetings.

The council's taping rules range from requiring that someone
wanting to tape the meeting contact the township clerk by 4 p.m.
on the Friday before the Tuesday meeting to setting a limit of
no more than one person with a video camera. The rules, however,
do not apply to swearing-in ceremonies or award presentations.

"If Piscataway taped all of its meetings, any nutcase in the
state who would get on free TV would get attracted to that,"
Hardenburg said.

Merolla said she doesn't have a problem with anyone videotaping
council meetings as long as they record the entire meeting and
do not use it for "grandstanding," as she said political candidates
often do. The majority of other officials agree: They don't want
their meetings to turn into a "circus" or have the public feel
uncomfortable about discussing issues at meetings because they
do not want to be on TV.

But according to Deborah Jacobs, executive director of the American
Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, the public has the right
to record with a video camera or tape recorder any public meeting,
for as long or as short a time they wish.

"When you are in a public place you should assume, 'I do not
have a right to privacy,' " Jacobs said. "The public has an obligation
to hold the government accountable and there could be many good
reasons for videotaping. How it is used is a totally separate
question."

Splicing a videotape and manipulating it for a public advertisement
would likely not be covered legally, she said. But that concern
on the part of some Piscataway officials, including 2nd Ward
Councilman Brian C. Wahler,e seems problematic to Jacobs.

"You could do doctoring of the tapes," Wahler said. "That was
a consistent concern of the council back when we did the regulations.
How do we know that it (the video) hasn't been edited. I mean
that's legitimate."

Clara Halper, Larry Halper's wife, said her family would like
to videotape council meetings and have PCTC broadcast them. But
she thinks the council should do it, and contends the money would
be well-spent. 

"Not many people get to see what goes on at town meetings because
people are so busy these days, working two jobs and with kids.
So maybe if they could turn it on at home, they would watch,"
Clara Halper said.

Attorney Arlene M. Turinchak of the McGimpsey & Cafferty law
firm in Somerset, which represents the New Jersey Press Association,
said there's nothing in the law that prohibits private citizens
from videotaping public meetings and they have a right to do
so under the state's Open Public Meetings Act of 1963.

The state Superior Court Appellate Division in 1984 upheld a
decision that entitles people to videotape public proceedings,
including criminal trials and school board meetings, as long
as the equipment is not distracting, obtrusive or disruptive.


Municipal officials, like judges in courts, can make rules limiting
the amount of video cameras, where they are positioned, their
lighting, the activity and location of the operator, and when
the cameras should be turned off. Jacobs gave the example of
a school board turning a video camera off when discussing a student
in public. 

Gran, the Piscataway township attorney, said there are no prohibitions
on videotaping council meetings, but the guidelines must be met.

GOP mayoral candidate Chris Lombard -- who is running in November
against Wahler, a Democrat, and Merolla, a Democrat vying as
an independent candidate -- has asked officials to have council
meetings aired on PCTC for years.

"If you're going to have a public-access channel, you should
be using it as a public service," Lombard said. "If you're not
afraid of anything, why not just televise the entire meeting?"

Rosa Cirianni (732) 246-5500 Ext. 7218. E-mail: rciriann@...


from the Home News Tribune 

Published: August 20, 2000

regarding the Housing Authority Chairwoman, also a city employee?

in the mass media.

Does this look like something --anyone  in the People's Campaign
can respond to?

Remember,  Silence=Death.

--BV


          

	
NEW BRUNSWICK: Public housing failing 


Published in the Home News Tribune 8/21/00 

Four sites fail U.S. inspection
By FRANCES CARROLL
STAFF WRITER

The New Brunswick Homes high rises received a rock-bottom score
on a recent "advisory" federal building inspection report, and
the New Brunswick Housing Authority's three other public housing
developments also came in well below the minimum passing score.

The 245-unit Homes, which were approximately 63 percent vacant
as of last week in anticipation of being demolished as part of
the federal Hope VI project to relocate tenants to low-density
housing, received a score of 1 on the federal Department of Housing
and Urban Development's Public Housing Assessment System.

The minimum passing score is 18 out of a possible 30 points.

The 59-unit senior Hoffman Pavilion building scored 4.6, the
200-unit Schwartz Homes scored 10.3 and the 59-unit Robeson Village
scored 14.1, according to HUD's recent management review of the
New Brunswick Housing Authority.

Robert Kaplan, a spokesman at HUD's Newark office, said this
is the first year local public housing authorities were rated
under a new assessment system so scores are "considered advisory
at this time. They are not final, they are subject to change."

Kaplan declined to discuss New Brunswick's particular scores.
NBHA Executive Director Kevin Quince declined to comment beyond
stating that all deficiencies cited by HUD have been or will
soon be addressed under the corrective action plan the authority
has submitted to HUD.

The physical inspection scores were included in a report on a
management review of the authority that HUD gave Board of Commissioners
Chairwoman Beatrice Harris in May. Conducted in February, the
"Limited Management Review" was designed to assess the authority's
overall performance and compliance with regulations.

The management review did not include details about building
violations and deficiencies, and the actual physical inspection
report was not immediately available.

But the review stated the authority had already certified it
corrected several "life-threatening findings" cited in an earlier
review. Those findings included a disconnected hot water vent
hood, inoperable/missing smoke detectors, exposed electrical
wires and blocked emergency exits/fire escapes. The review did
not state when or at which developments these findings were recorded.

HUD required the authority to address all the findings in the
physical inspection report, with the exception of those for the
Homes because they are scheduled for demolition.

"However, the NBHA is reminded that it must make all necessary
repairs to ensure the New Brunswick Homes site is maintained
in a safe, decent and sanitary condition . . . until all tenants
have been relocated," according to the review.

The authority filed a corrective action plan that applied only
to Schwartz Homes, Robeson Village and Hoffman Pavilion.

For the Schwartz-Robeson area, the plan stated the authority
will spend some $76,000 to repair paved areas, $31,000 to landscape,
and another $8,800 to remove old playground equipment and repair
fencing.

In Hoffman Pavilion, damaged ceilings and walls in the community
room are expected to be repaired as part of an overall $20,000
renovation scheduled this fall. Other common areas and the entrance
to Hoffman Pavilion are being renovated under a previously awarded
contract.

The action plan also addressed problems in other categories,
including aesthetic issues such as graffiti and litter, doors
and window screens, apartment interiors and building systems
such as heating, electrical and fire safety. 

Frances Carroll: (732) 246-5500 Ext. 7260


from the Home News Tribune 

Published: August 21, 2000

Subject:Youth League
Message:

Hi everyone.

Our last youth league is this Sunday August 27. We had a great summer with 
the kids and will return next year, with an even better program. Thanks 
again to all the volunteers.

We are having a party for the last day for parents and the kids, so I am 
putting out this message, if you know of any way to get cheap or free food 
(a friendly, sympathetic pizza place owner for example)or party favors, it 
would be greatly appreciated. Also if anyone can volunteer their time to 
take pitures and/or videotape our party that would be great.

We will meet again at the office at 149 Redmond at 2pm. Hope to see you 
there.

This will be your last message about youth league from me until next year. 
Please don't cry.

Louise

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:584
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-21 21:47:59
Subject:Fwd: Top 10 Lies About West Nile Virus and Anvil- R Lederman
Message:



>From: ARTISTpres@...
>To: undisclosed-recipients:;
>Subject: Top 10 Lies About West Nile Virus and Anvil- R Lederman
>Date: Fri, 18 Aug 2000 12:25:17 EDT
>
>[Please distribute widely]
>Top 10 Lies About West Nile Virus and Anvil
>by Robert Lederman
>
>1. THE ONLY SIDE-EFFECTS OF ANVIL EXPOSURE ARE
>COUGHING, STUFFY NOSE, ITCHING AND WATERY
>EYES
>Exactly like an allergic reaction to pollen, these responses to the
>toxic ingredients of Anvil are an attempt by a person's immune
>system to flush the substances from the body. Mucus nasal
>secretions, tears and coughing to expel the irritant from the lungs
>are not the harmful effects of exposure but are simply proof that
>the body recognizes Anvil as something it wants to get rid of
>immediately. The symptoms of a disease are not the effects of a
>disease. If you have emphysema from cigarette smoking you may
>feel tired and have difficulty breathing. In response, you might
>use an inhaler and temporarily breath better, but that would
>hardly mean you had recovered from the disease or from
>permanent damage to your lung tissue.
>
>The suspected and in many cases already proven long term
>effects of exposure to Pyrethrins like Anvil include immune
>system and liver damage, endocrine disruption, proliferation of
>breast cancer cells, lowered sperm count and cognitive
>difficulties. The latest science concerning this finds that at even
>the most minimal exposure serious health effects and endocrine
>disruption have been observed. The real damage from exposure to
>these chemicals won't be manifested until long after the itching,
>runny nose or coughing have stopped. By then, few people will
>remember or be able to prove the connection between exposure
>and their illness. Chemical companies, just like cigarette
>manufacturers, depend on this time lag between exposure and
>illness to prevent them from being found liable.
>
>2. WEST NILE VIRUS (WNV) IS A DEADLY DISEASE
>The Mayor and the media keep referring to WNV as a deadly
>disease transmitted by killer mosquitoes. Yet, they qualify these
>claims by saying that WNV is very hard to become infected by
>and that most people who do get infected recover without any
>treatment and without experiencing any symptoms. So which is
>it, a deadly infectious disease, or very mild and hard to become
>infected by? It can't be both.
>
>According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) the largest
>known WNV epidemic in history occurred in Romania in 1996.
>Approximately 100,000 people allegedly became infected. About
>400 of those people became ill with symptoms of encephalitis.
>Only 15 of those people, all of whom were over 65, died.
>Considering the level of health care in that country and the poor
>nutritional status and immune health of its senior citizens, these
>statistics indicate that the virus is much less dangerous than the
>common cold. See:  (www.naba.org/wnvirus.html). In NYC
>according to the Department of Health's own study, of the four
>NYC residents who they claim died last year from WNV, three
>were taking immunosuppresant cancer drugs and the fourth was
>HIV-positive...meaning that only people with severely
>compromised immune systems die from WNV and that even in
>those cases death is rare. [See: New York City Department of
>Health, West Nile Virus: A Briefing, City Health Information
>Vol. 19, No. 1 (May 2000)
>http://www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/doh/html/chi/chi.html]
>
>3. SEVEN PEOPLE DIED LAST YEAR FROM WNV
>Every Giuliani press release and every news report prominently
>mentions that seven people died in the general NYC area last
>year from WNV. Like the Mayor's crime statistics or the Federal
>government's claims that the economy has never been better these
>statements are unverifiable. No name, blood sample or tissue
>sample of any person who allegedly died from WNV has been
>made available to independent scientists for confirmation and
>testing. Every claim of an infected bird, mosquito or human is
>based on reports by the NYC Department of Health or scientists
>that work for the CDC or receive funding from them. These are
>also the same exact source of the spray policy, creating a perfect
>loop of "proof" justifying their own decision to spray. In science
>an outside independent source verifying the conclusions and
>reproducing experimental results is always necessary before any
>statement can be taken as a fact. The same is generally true in
>law, in journalism and in business. See the end of this report for
>an analysis of the reliability of the CDC in this matter.
>
>4. THE PESTICIDE BEING USED, ANVIL, IS NATURAL
>Anvil is a synthetic imitation of a naturally occurring substance
>found in Chrysanthemums. The natural version, which is
>considered much safer than the synthetic, is far more expensive
>and is not being used anywhere in NYC. This information is
>plainly stated in the Mayor's press releases yet he stands up at
>press conferences directly contradicting it-a good indication of
>his truthfulness on the entire WNV issue. Most of the numerous
>other ingredients in Anvil are synthetic derivatives of
>petroleum-based chemicals such as Benzene and Piperonyl
>Butoxide. Many of these ingredients are on the EPA's list of
>dangerous, toxic and cancer causing substances. They are about
>as far from natural as you can get.
>
>5. ANVIL IS SAFE AND NON-TOXIC
>It is illegal in NY State to describe any pesticide as safe. If you
>examine the actual texts of the Mayor's safety claims within his
>press releases you will find that each one is qualified by terms
>like "relatively safe", "less toxic than" and "safe when used
>according to directions". The EPA studies on which pesticide
>safety claims are based are done solely by the pesticide
>manufacturers themselves, who have an obvious conflict of
>interest in this regard. The term safe as used in these studies is
>very misleading, as a reading of the studies themselves makes
>clear. A determination of safe is reached by feeding rats the
>chemical or exposing them to its vapors. When only 50% of the
>rats die, the substance is classified as safe. Every study that
>concludes that products like Anvil are safe includes reports of
>tumors in rats, developmental problems in young rats,
>miscarriages and deformities to name just a few health effects. As
>long as less than 50% of the rats get these symptoms the product
>is considered safe. Since human testing of this kind is illegal
>there is no way to tell, short of massively spraying a population
>as is being done in NYC, what the effects will be on humans.
>[See: Cover Story, Kids At Risk 6/19/2000 US News and World
>Report
>http://www.usnews.com/usnews/issue/000619/poison.htm
>Also see: http://www.nih.gov/]
>
>6. ANVIL DISSIPATES BY THE NEXT MORNING
>Mayor Giuliani claims, and the media dutifully repeats, that
>these pesticides dissipate within two hours of being sprayed.
>These claims are deliberately deceptive. As chemical compounds
>are exposed to air and sunlight they undergo numerous changes.
>Malathion for example become Maloxon a very different
>substance which is more than 20 times as toxic. It is true to say
>the Malathion is gone-but what remains in its place is far worse.
>The claim of dissipation is based on ideal conditions-Anvil on a
>glass slide in direct sunlight-that have little if anything to do
>with the actual conditions in NYC. Much of the spraying was
>done on damp, even rainy days-in direct violation of the
>manufacturer's instructions. Much of the chemical is deposited in
>shady areas, on leaves, in cracks and crevices, in A/C filters, in
>heating vents and in countless other places where there is no
>direct sunlight. Much of it is tracked or drifts into people's
>homes where it can persist for weeks, months or years waiting to
>be inhaled, eaten or absorbed through the skin. The idea that
>people can enter a public park, jog, picnic and lay on grass that
>was massively sprayed just two hours before without receiving
>direct exposure is absurd. Children playing in that grass and then
>putting their hands in their mouths might just as well have been
>lined up and given a sample of Anvil to drink.
>
>7. ANVIL KILLS MOST OF THE MOSQUITOES
>The most ironic aspect of the spray policy is that, contrary to the
>Mayor's claims, it does not kill most of the mosquitoes. If it did,
>the earth, which has endured billions of tons of pesticide
>exposure, would already be mosquito-free. The opposite is true.
>Pesticide spraying, according to the NY State Department of
>Health and even the pesticide manufacturers, directly results in
>new generations of pesticide-resistant mosquitoes.
>
>For those like Mayor Giuliani who missed the past hundred years
>of science, this process is called natural selection. In insects,
>natural selection can occur in a period of days, weeks or months
>because each generation only lives a short time. Reproduction by
>even one genetically pesticide-resistant mosquito can result in
>hundreds of resistant offspring who then mate and create an
>entire population with that same genetic quality. Studies done in
>Florida where there is a much more severe mosquito problem,
>found a 1500% increase in mosquitoes after spraying, virtually
>all of whom were now pesticide-resistant. Even worse, many
>mosquito experts believe the immune suppression pesticides
>cause in all living things makes mosquitoes, birds and humans
>far more vulnerable to encephalitis infections. Apparently, only
>mosquitoes exposed to pesticides can get and transmit the
>infection due to damage to their stomach lining. Driving spray
>trucks past the fronts of rows of apartment houses to kill
>mosquitoes breeding in the backyards is about as effective as
>shooting a gun in the opposite direction of a target and hoping it
>will circumvent the entire earth to strike the target from behind. It
>is however, an excellent technique to guarantee an increase in
>mosquitoes, dead birds and encephalitis infections thereby
>justifying more and more spraying. See
>http://www.chem-tox.com/brevard/index.htm
>
>8. WE ARE SAVING LIVES BY SPRAYING-IF WE DIDN'T,
>MANY MORE PEOPLE WOULD GET SICK
>The CDC's own studies found that NYC's 1999 so-called WNV
>epidemic had peaked and was declining more than a month
>before spraying began. See
>http://www.cdc.gov/epo/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4841a3.ht
>m
>
>9. THE SPRAYING IS BEING DONE BY QUALIFIED
>PROFESSIONALS
>While the Clarke Mosquito Control Co. itself may have some
>qualified pesticide applicators the spraying in NYC is being
>done by temporary workers solicited through an ad in the NY
>Post. These untrained and unqualified workers are being paid
>$10 an hour to damage their own and everyone else's health-an
>excellent example of what Giuliani means by creating jobs. In
>direct violation of OSHA rules and the warnings on the product
>labels, none of the applicators are wearing protective clothing,
>respirators or gloves. Because of the heat, most drive the trucks
>with the windows wide open. The police escorts ordered to
>precede and follow the spray trucks are likewise totally
>unprotected and deliberately uninformed about the risks. This is
>not an oversight or an accident. If the applicators and the police
>escorts were wearing the type of protective gear required by law,
>no one would believe the Mayor's claims that the spray is safe.
>
>10. THE ONLY PEOPLE WHO OPPOSE THE SPRAYING
>ARE ENVIRONMENTALISTS WHO CARE MORE ABOUT
>BIRDS THAN PEOPLE AND ACTIVISTS WHO OPPOSE
>ANYTHING GIULIANI DOES
>While the loudest voices in opposition to the spraying may
>include many activists and environmentalists, there are
>thousands of medical professionals in the NYC area that oppose
>the spraying. [Contact Rivka Lieber (LieberR@...) for a
>copy of a petition signed by numerous doctors and scientists
>opposed to the spraying]. The media simply refuses to interview
>any of these people preferring to use sound bites from
>uninformed NYC residents or Giuliani supporters who believe
>anything the Mayor says no matter how absurd. Many scientists
>and health professionals are understandably fearful of losing
>their jobs, grants from chemical/pharmaceutical companies and
>their professional reputation if they speak out too loudly. Most
>medical professionals work for institutions that are dependent on
>receiving money from the government, from private institutions
>like Rockefeller University, from the CDC and from corporations
>that are actually behind the spray policy and the entire WNV
>panic. For them, publicly opposing this policy could destroy
>their careers. The same goes for reporters that would like to
>expose the facts but have been instructed not to.
>
>THE CDC SAYS WE MUST SPRAY-THE CONNECTION
>BETWEEN THE CDC, THE CIA AND THE WNV ISSUE
>The CDC bases much of its information concerning international
>health issues, epidemics and communicable diseases on reports
>by the CIA-a US governmental agency whose official role
>includes the dissemination of propaganda and disinformation
>throughout the world. The CIA oversees CDC operations in areas
>classified as a potential health threat to national security.
>
>The CDC has been implicated in numerous health disasters
>involving the distribution of vaccines both in the US and in the
>third world. Many scientists and researchers believe they are the
>source for a number of diseases that never previously existed. All
>of these diseases just happen to be associated with bio-warfare
>research labs working with or run by the CDC, the CIA and/or
>the U.S. Army.
>
>The CIA has a proven track record of misinforming not only
>foreign governments but other US governmental agencies, the
>Congress, the US military, the President of the United States and
>the American people on issues as diverse as the real condition of
>the Soviet Union during the Cold War, Sadamn Hussein's
>intentions in the Gulf, the state of affairs in Iran and where U.S.
>tax dollars are actually being spent on covert operations. Even
>some US Senators now believe the CIA is largely responsible for
>the crack epidemic in the U.S.
>
>As GW Bush and his likely appointee to be Attorney
>General-Rudy Giuliani-publicly admit, they get virtually all of
>their policy "ideas" directly from the Manhattan Institute, a think
>tank started by Ronald Reagan's CIA director William Casey.
>Immediately after WWII Casey played a major role in bringing
>thousands of top Nazi scientists and SS intelligence officials to
>the US. Many of them became employees of the newly formed,
>CIA.
>
>Most of the pesticides being used in NYC are derived from
>nerve gasses developed by Nazi scientists. The company that
>patented and manufactured them in Germany, IG Farben, was a
>full partner with Rockefeller/Standard Oil before, during and
>since WWII. After the war IG Farben was broken up into four
>companies that are now the world leaders in chemical and
>pharmaceutical manufacturing and research. Rockefeller/Chase
>Bank just happens to be the main funder of the Manhattan
>Institute. No less a high-level source than former Presidents
>Roosevelt and Truman considered the Rockefellers to be traitors
>to the U.S. who were actively aiding the Nazis throughout WWII
>[See The Secret War Against the Jews by Loftus and Aarons].
>
>Among the key issues promoted by the Manhattan Institute, is a
>campaign to discredit 50 years of science demonstrating that
>pesticides, petroleum-based chemical pollution and
>pharmaceuticals manufactured by contemporary spin-offs of
>Standard Oil/Exxon and IG Farben are dangerous to human
>health and the environment. All a coincidence? See Peter Huber's
>books featured on the Manhattan Institute's webpage
>http://www.manhattan-institute.org/ Also see
>http://www.fair.org/media-outlets/stossel.html for an analysis of
>John Stossel and his link to the Manhattan Institute.
>
>Robert Lederman, President of A.R.T.I.S.T.
>(Artists’ Response To Illegal State Tactics)
>ARTISTpres@...  (718) 743-3722
>http://www.openair.org/alerts/artist/nyc.html
>SEE:  http://Baltech.org/lederman/spray/
>for a detailed exposition on the West Nile issue and detailed
>references for many of the statements made in this article.
>
>Pay especial attention to those about Oravax, the company that
>has been developing a WNV vaccine invented by the U.S. Army.
>

Post ID:587
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-22 22:43:24
Subject:Damning Star-Ledger Article on NB Public Housing
Message:

Res ipsa loquitor.  Whacha gonna do about this?

**********

New Brunswick authority fails housing review �
�
08/22/00�
�
By Alexander Lane�
STAFF WRITER�
�
�
Shoddy maintenance, poor security and inadequate record keeping�
were among a long list of management problems federal officials�
have found in the New Brunswick Housing Authority, according�
to a recent management review. �
�
�
The review, based on interviews and inspections conducted by�
federal Department of Housing and Urban Development officials�
in February, was the source of the recent revelation that the�
authority does not have a resident on its board of commissioners.�
�
�
�
But that was just one of many problems federal officials unearthed.�
�
�
�
The officials reviewed annual inspection reports and found that�
each of the city's four public housing units was in dismal physical�
condition. �
�
�
Out of a maximum score of 30, with 18 as a passing grade, Robeson�
Village scored 14.1, the Schwarz Homes scored 10.3, Hoffman Pavilion�
scored 4.6 and the New Brunswick Memorial Homes scored 1.0. �
�
�
''The inspectors they send don't communicate with my staff,"�
complained Kevin Quince, director of the authority. �
�
�
''They say they went into the boiler room and found a fuse box�
was open. That's a deduction. You got a shingle missing on the�
roof, one of the drain spouts isn't pouring water out when it�
rains. Those are deductions. It's that kind of painstaking analysis."�
�
�
�
Quince said many other public housing directors have complained�
about the new Physical Housing Assessment System, which is performed�
by the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Real Estate�
Assessment Center. �
�
�
The New Brunswick Housing Authority manages about 500 apartments�
for lower income families. �
�
�
The review also found that too many rents were uncollected. Some�
20 percent of tenants, including the authority's public housing�
manager, had delinquent accounts as of the end of last year,�
according to the review. �
�
�
The authority has set up formal repayment agreements, but it�
has not been following up on them, the review found. �
�
�
Quince countered in his written response to the federal officials�
that "the authority's collection policy and procedure is standard�
and effective for the majority of our residents." �
�
�
Officials also criticized the authority for keeping two waiting�
lists -- one dating back to 1990 and one compiled after a housing�
lottery in 1997. �
�
�
The authority did not properly keep track of applications. In�
some cases, they housed residents on the more recent waiting�
list before applicants that had been waiting since 1990, the�
review found. �
�
�
Quince said the authority has since examined the 1990 list, housed�
any applicants still in need of housing and purged the old list.�
�
�
�
Drug dealing continues to infest the complexes, officials found.�
�
�
�
The Schwarz-Robeson complexes have become a "passageway to escape�
from drug enforcement agents," and drug dealers were working�
openly outside the Memorial Homes complex, officials said. �
�
�
Quince said the authority increased security patrols at the Memorial�
Homes -- but he acknowledged that the drug market continues to�
thrive on public housing property. He said he would schedule�
a meeting with federal officials to ask for advice on fighting�
drugs. �
�
�
New Brunswick officials could not be reached for comment yesterday.�
�
�
�
Andy Gury, the spokesman for Mayor James Cahill, said he did�
not know how to reach the mayor, who was taking a three-day weekend.�
�
�
�
Calls to Joseph Schrum, the city council president, and Jimmie�
Cook, the council's liaison to the housing authority, were not�
returned. �
�
�
Quince, who has been on the job for two years and earns $95,000�
a year, remained resolute yesterday in the face of the stream�
of criticism of his management. �
�
�
''I'll be damned if I'm going to let this take me down," Quince�
said. "I distributed this to department heads and said I'm not�
satisfied with how this came out. How can you be?" �
�
�
''I use these evaluations as a management tool, as an opportunity�
to evaluate our operations." �
�
�
Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at alane@...�
or at (732) 634-1236.�

The exclamation point is really included. It's so weird how it all comes 
together.

For the record, most chemical development comes from Germany because that was 
one of the emerging industries in the 19th century that required very few 
natural resources from colonial conquests. The American chemical industry 
really only started to kick butt when Caruthers from DuPont discovered ( in 
the '30's) a workakable polyester ( for example, Nylon). Before that Baklite 
was the only synthetic material.

This should be an exciting day.  Please invite all individuals you know, and forward this message to your friends and other listserves.
