Post ID:593
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-08-27 16:43:10
Subject:FW: GLOBAL CRITICAL MASS AGAINST GLOBAL WARMING!
Message:

--- Original Message ---
Santa Cruz Critical Mass <santacruzcriticalmass@...> Wrote
on 
Sat, 26 Aug 2000 23:12:43 -0700 (PDT)
 ------------------ 
GLOBAL CRITICAL MASS AGAINST GLOBAL WARMING!!!
  SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 19TH, 2000, 2PM(your time)

  This is during the international global warming
talks in The Hague, Netherlands.

  PLEASE FORWARD/SHARE THIS MESSAGE TO ALL    
BIKE/ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS/INDIVIDUALS AROUND THE  
WORLD!!!

  On Sunday, November 19th, 2000, cyclists from around
Europe will converge in The Hague, Netherlands for a
special Critical Mass Against Global Warming. Join
them in solidarity by organizing a Critical Mass  
Bike Ride in your community on that day.  Rally
support for the ratification of a strong Kyoto
Protocol, the international treaty that would be the
first step to stopping global warming!  The Kyoto
Protocol will be the main topic of discussion at this
November�s Global Warming Summit in The Hague,
Netherlands.  Join fellow cyclists from around the
world for a Global Critical Mass to protest global
warming and the fossil fuel companies that keep it
going, and promote two of the best solutions � a
strong Kyoto Protocol and the Bicycle!!! 

  This November 11-24, 180 countries will gather in
The Hague, Netherlands, for two weeks of talks on how
to deal with global warming.  This is the sixth such
meeting.  The Kyoto Protocol was named after Kyoto,
Japan, where the third meeting took place.  The Earth
Summit in Rio de Janeiro was the first. 

  In addition to celebrating the bicycle, and
promoting the Kyoto Protocol let's protest the big
oil/coal/car companies that are against
Kyoto.  In a similar Critical Mass this past Earth Day
in California we rode around a Chevron Gas Station for
half an hour, blocking the station and handing out
literature.  We got great media coverage, so
send out those press releases.  Good signs are
crucial!
Noisemakers/instruments are fun too.  

  Suggestions for signs: Ratify the Kyoto Treaty!,
Kyoto Now!,  Don't Weaken Kyoto!, Support Global
Warmin-Drive Y'r Car!, Nukes aren't the Answer!, Go
Solar! Stop Global Warming!, Stop Climate Change!,
Boycott Gasoline!, ExxonMobil Supports
Global Warming, Chevron Supports the GCC, Bikes are
Better!, etc. GCC stands for Global Climate Coalition.
(see Corporate Opposition below). It's easy to tape
signs (approx. 1 square meter size) to bike
racks, one on each side. Target politicians and fossil
fuel/car companies on your ride. Tell the press. Bring
cameras. Riding safely and respectfully will get the
message across better. Hope you join us! 
  Have fun!!


  Background Information:
   
  Global warming is one of the most serious
environmental threats facing the planet today. In
1995, 2,400 of the world�s leading scientists on
the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
reviewed the bulk of peer reviewed climate science and
concluded that: �the balance of evidence suggests a
discernible human influence on global climate.� The
IPCC estimated that if greenhouse gas emissions
continue to increase at current rates, the earth could
experience a temperature increase of 3-6 degrees over
the next 100 years. Some of the impacts of this
dramatic increase in temperature will be:
   
- Massive Forest and Species Die-Off 
- Increased Floods, Droughts, and Other Severe Weather
Events 
- Wetland and Coral Reef Destruction 
- The Spread of Tropical Diseases Such As Hantavirus,
Malaria and Dengue Fever 
-  Shifts of Agricultural and Ecosystem Belts 
-  Diminished Freshwater Supply 
-  Dramatic Sea Level Rise Causing Coastal Flooding
and Property Damage.

  Since then, tens of thousands of scientists, 2,500
economists including 7 Nobel Laureates, have made
strong statements about the need to take action to
stop global warming and that such action would
actually be good for the economy by making it more
healthy and efficient. 

  The Kyoto Protocol

  In response to the growing consensus about global
warming, over 140 nations joined together in Rio to
formulate what would later become the Kyoto Protocol �
an international treaty to cut global warming
pollution by 5% below 1990 levels. (U.S. emissions
have increased 13% since �90) After years of
negotiation, Kyoto was finally signed by the
United States and 170 other nations, however, it has
yet to be ratified by the U.S. Senate.  The Kyoto
Protocol is not the ultimate solution to global
warming but is a crucial first step.  If Kyoto were
enacted today the U.S. would have to reduce its CO2
emissions by 20%, which is significant.

  Corporate Opposition

  At the same time that the leaders of the world were
signing the Kyoto Protocol, an industry front group
called the Global Climate Coalition (GCC) was gearing
up a $13 million dollar ad campaign in the U.S. to
kill the Protocol, saying that there is not enough
scientific certainty about global warming to justify
action. Because of this the U.S. Senate has not
ratified the Kyoto Protocol, and without the world�s
biggest polluter ratifying this treaty it is unlikely
that other nations will either. The public relations
war has so far, unfortunately, been won by the
utility, fossil fuel, and auto industries which fund
the Global Climate Coalition�s efforts to undermine
the scientific consensus about global warming and to
stop every common sense solution to climate change. 
What is needed is a Nation/Earth-wide grassroots
movement to put pressure on the U.S. Senate for a
strong Kyoto Protocol and to expose the corporate
misinformation campaign. 

  Recently, the Kyoto Treaty has come under attack
from the nuclear and timber industries as well.  They
are seeking language in the treaty that will encourage
construction of a new wave of nuclear power plants
and the clear-cutting of old growth forests replanted
with allegedly more  "vigorous" new trees. A strong
Kyoto treaty is critical.  To send a fax to US
negotiators, visit http://www.cooltheplanet.org.
    
  So, tell all your friends, organize, and this
November 19th, �get your ass on down to the Global
Warming Critical Mass!!� 


  For more info on global warming: 
  http://www.cooltheplanet.org 
  http://www.kyotonow.org 
  http://www.ozone.org

  subscribe to: 
  climatecrisisaction-subscribe@onelist.com

*AND please e'mail back with your results from this
campaign and other related events with images.... 

SantaCruzCriticalMass@...

Post ID:594
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-31 15:27:33
Subject:DEVCO PUTS PEOPLE ON THE STREETS!
Message:




 >
 >***please forward widely***
 >
 >NEW BRUNSWICK DEVELOPMENT COMPANY
 >PUTS PEOPLE ON THE STREETS!
 >by A//E//F
 >
 >     Early this morning, Wednesday, August 30th, in New Brunswick, NJ, a
 >statement was made. A banner was hung from the New St. bridge, over Rt.18,
 >stating "DEVCO PUTS PEOPLE ON THE STREETS!". It was done by NJ Anarchists
 >who felt that a public statement needed to be made, and even moreso,
 >actions needed to be taken about the horrible treatment of poor people, 
and
 >even of homeless people in the city of New Brunswick. "DevCo" is the
 >shortened form of what some NB residents have often referred to as
 >DevilCo., and others know and experience it as the culprit in their own
 >gentrification as they scramble and search for places to live. The rich
 >folk, and the city "developers" do not see this problem, and do not see
 >their actions as the legal and sanctioned removal of the poorest people
 >within the city's borders as they prepare for situating a new influx of
 >corporate-backed stores and other chain businesses, which also will
 >"clean-up" the neighborhood to enhance its appeal to the theatre crowd.
 >This crowd is made up of much more privileged folk from out of town than
 >over half of the NB population. These "development" plans basically
 >eliminate the small business owner, cater to the more affluent, and line
 >big business investors' wallets with the cash of capital. Power has its
 >privileges. The poor need not apply.
 >     The Dozens of working class families who used to live in the New
 >Brunswick Memorial Homes low-income housing units, located just off of Rt.
 >18, have experienced the most shoddy living environments in their homes
 >within the buildings which were falling apart and left to decay because 
the
 >city obviously had more important plans. Same with the residents of the
 >Monument Park Hotel. The city officials had plans to kick 'em to the curb
 >if they couldn't find another place to live by a certain date. Now, most 
of
 >the families have already been removed. The Memorial Homes and the 
Monument
 >Park Hotel are both being replaced by middle-income housing, thus leaving
 >the ex-residents on the outside looking in. This is all in efforts by a
 >program called New Brunswick Tomorrow, and DevCo. (not a public group, but
 >a private one, by the way), employed by the city in long-term attempt at
 >what they like to label "revitalization", but the poorest NB residents 
know
 >is really called gentrification. These people are displaced without being
 >offered opportunity for equivalent housing situations. The city has no
 >obligation and no loyalty to their "revitalization" victims, but they
 >always seem to have an unfaltering commitment to the almighty dollar.
 >Corporate cohorts Robert Wood Johnson Hospital, Johnson & Johnson World
 >Headquarters, and Rutgers University are all responsible, and they
 >practically run the city. Something needs to change, and NJ Anarchists
 >realize this, the residents who are the pulse of the city realize this, as
 >well as several student groups. Something needs to change about the fact
 >that "DEVCO PUTS PEOPLE ON THE STREETS!" The corporate "revitalization"
 >needs to cease. It's time for Community Control of what belongs to them!
 >

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:595
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-08-31 16:50:17
Subject:Fwd: NB activist illegally evicted....needs help
Message:



>From: Anne Barron <barron58@...>
>To: Jim <DadWorld@...>, Laurel Kornfel <lkornfel@...>,  
>Liz Lipman-Stern <sept255@...>, Paul McGee <shorepaulie@...>,  
>Stephanie McIntyre <steffmc@...>, Joy Norsworthy 
><norsworthy@...>,  David O'Leary <doleary@...>,  Harriet 
>Pearlman <rpearlmn@...>,  Chris Rasmussen 
><jjones@...>,  Renee Rivera <rrivera@...>, 
>Manejeh Sabo <msabo@...>,  Paul Sauers 
><sauers@...>,  Joy Schulman <JoySchulma@...>
>Subject: NB activist illegally evicted....needs help
>Date: Thu, 31 Aug 2000 09:58:49 -0700 (PDT)
>
>HI, everyone
>
>I am appealing to you because of your interest in
>social justice issues and your activism.  Following is
>a letter Beverly Marshall wrote regarding the events
>leading to her eviction from NB Apartments on Oct.
>1...it is clear she is being evicted for her actions
>as head of the tenants ass'n.
>
>I didn't know Beverly personally until I read the
>article in the HNT but I had heard of her often while
>in NB...she has organized her neighborhood, held block
>parties, been active in school/PTO (and a strong
>helpful presence at the Lord Stirling elementary
>school in NB) and is raising her grandchildren.  She
>has been a strong advocate in her neighborhood- she
>lives over by the projects off rt. 18.
>
>She needs a good lawyer (any suggestions?  her present
>one is terrible).  She will be stratagizing as to what
>to do following her letter to the gov(??) and I'm
>trying to get a goodly amount of people who can either
>come to a rally or write letters to Community Reality
>or the gov., HUD, etc., to decry the
>unconstitutionality of it all.  (Because she is being
>evicted over 4 nice lawn chairs in her backyard, we
>thought a rally of lawn chairs could symbolize the
>attempt to silence her.)
>
>I spoke with her at length and urge  every activist in
>our area to take a moment to support her...if she
>falls, then we are that much more alone in our
>efforts.  Her plight is being followed by the
>HNT,which is excellent.
>Any thoughts?  Can you come to a rally or write a
>letter?  I can give you more info.  Her email
>addressis Bevmar_08901@...
>
>thanks for your time
>
>Anne
>
>33 Commercial Avenue # 7-H
>New Brunswick, New Jersey 08901August 27, 2000���
>
>The Honorable Governor Christine Todd Whitman Governor
>of New Jersey
>State House, CN 001Trenton, New Jersey 08625-0001��
>
>Dear Governor Whitman:�
>My name is Beverly A. Marshall, and I am writing this
>letter in need of your assistance. At present, I am
>the President of 33 Commercial Ave. Tenants
>Association, President of the Neighborhood Crime Watch
>and I served as President of Lord Stirling Parent
>Teacher Organization from 1997-2000. I also have
>custody of three of my eight grandchildren and am
>raising them at this address. (I�ve included an
>article from the Home News Tribune which explains
>thisin detail).�
>I am currently being evicted from my home in what can
>only be an attempt to silence my concerns as president
>of the Tenants Association (see enclosed flyer to
>tenants about illegal entry by management and letter
>dated August 11 about illegal drug activity). �
>I have always paid my rent; I am active in many civic
>and school groups. I am currently unemployed because I
>care full-time for a disabled grandson. �Why am I
>being evicted???
>I received a Notice from the manager of the New
>Brunswick Apartments on June 9, 2000, demanding that a
>yard Patio Set and Charcoal grill outside my back door
>be removed (see enclosed photo and letter). Despite my
>attempts to explain that this had never been a problem
>in the past 5 years, the landlord sent me notice Aug.
>22 Terminating my Lease as of October 1, 2000 from my
>Townhouse (See Home News Tribune article 2). Again,
>this has never been an issue for the last manager or
>even the present (Ms. Perez) until I questioned some
>actions on the part of Ms. Perez. For the past five
>years, at the end of June I have placed my patio set
>in the backyard. It is always removed after Labor Day.
>Our grill, as do other tenants� grills, stay outside
>against the wall away from the door covered in
>plasticover the winter.�
>There has never been a dispute before concerning patio
>set or residents using charcoal grills. My private
>belongings are not stored outside; the patio furniture
>does not obstruct the back door (as is misleadingly
>stated in the complaint). The only restrictions the
>complex had were not to use gas grills. Some of the
>residents has have resided here for twenty years and
>has used grills during the summer.�
>Let�s call this eviction what it is- an obvious
>harassment of a resident invoking her constitutional
>rights. To evict me from my apartment with three
>grandchildren, not because of non-payment of rent, or
>disorderly conduct, or selling drugs on the property
>or an unkempt apartment, but because of a patio set
>with a charcoal grill is unconstitutional. I am not
>taking away from the property- I am adding to it and
>to the sense of community here in New Brunswick.
>During the summer, family and neighborhood children
>come to my cookouts; I hold meetings and some mornings
>I even read my newspaper and drink a cup of coffee.
>Many subsidized housing complexes in my area are
>permitted outdoor furniture. Why not Community
>RealityManagement property?�
>To evict me is to say that, as a resident living in a
>subsidized apartment, I don�t have the freedom of
>speech, the freedom to assemble or the freedom of
>expression.
>This property is owned and operated by Community
>Realty Management. It is assisted under the Section
>236,221(d)(3) BMIR, Rent Supplement Program. I have
>also written to Secretary Andrew Cuomo of HUD and to
>the Director of HUD in Newark on July 27, 2000.�
>Governor Whitman, this isn�t just an apartment, it�s
>home for my three grandchildren and me. If you can
>assist me in anyway it would be greatly appreciated.
>Enclosed is a copy of the our House Rules, articles
>and documents.
>Thanking you in advance,����
>
>Sincerely,��Beverly A. Marshall�
>
>__________________________________________________
>Do You Yahoo!?
>Yahoo! Mail - Free email you can access from anywhere!
>http://mail.yahoo.com/

Subject:ladies!!!
Message:

Just a reminder to all the ladies out there...

We have a women's caucus meeting this Friday September 8 at 7pm at the 
office.

Followed by our infamous ladies night! We will be at 218 Townsend st. around 
900. I will try to avoid ending the night with a trip to the emergency room. 
So get those dancing shoes on! Yes Julie you can wear your toe shoes...

Please invite new friends and neighbors to both. I think to avoid 
unnecessary delay in our celebrations, everyone should bring food and/or 
drink.

love
Louise

hi all-
Here is the official information on the women's caucus meeting.

We are meeting on the third floor of the Douglass Student Center in the
computer lab at 7pm on friday. The meeting is going to be a working meeting
to research the platform- so bring books, pamphlets or whatever.

After that, for all interested women, it will be another exciting (fancy)
ladies night!!!!!
Remember how much fun we had last time? Bring your girlfriends...
love,
Audrey:)

Post ID:604
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-07 23:57:58
Subject:Celebrity Auction
Message:

For Immediate Release:

The Peoples' Council
      C/0 808 S.10th St.
      Newark, N.J.   07108

      On Thurs, Sept 14, 2000, THE PEOPLES' COUNCIL will present A CELEBRITY 
AUCTION, at the new and much talked about CLUB MILLENNIUM, 64 Clay St. 
Newark. Between the hours of  6pm to 12 pm.
	The CELEBRITY AUCTION will present a large variety of very valuable items 
from an impressive list of celebrities, some of whom will attend.  Unique, 
many one of kind articles will be offered from internationally known 
celebrities like MAYA ANGELOU, SHAQUIL O'NEAL, NINA SIMONE, MAX ROACH, 
QUINCY JONES, BILL COSBY, WARREN BEATTY, FELIPE LUCIANO, AMIRI BARAKA, DANNY 
GLOVER, WESLEY SNIPES, ALONZO MOURNING, RUSSELL SIMMONS, PUFFY COOMBS, 
SAVION GLOVER AND OTHERS.
.	The proceeds from the auction will be used to continue a campaign by The 
Peoples' Council  for  increased  Voter Registration and citizen awareness 
of the principal issues that affect the Newark community and to support the 
candidacy in Newark's 2002 municipal elections of Ras Baraka, for 
Councilman-at-Large.
             Ras Baraka, 30, born in Newark, the son of long time Newark 
Artist-Activists, Amina and Amiri Baraka , an eighth grade teacher at Warren 
Street Elementary School, and a dynamic young community activist will head 
this campaign as part of the Peoples' Democratic Council's public campaign 
to alert the people of Newark, and people everywhere, to the growing 
challenge to Democracy being made by the extreme right wing upsurge of 
groups like the Ku Klux Klan, Skin Heads, and other racist and white 
supremacist groups proliferating across the United States and the world.
	The deadly assault being made on the people by such forces has all but 
eliminated Affirmative Action, coopted commercialized and corrupted popular 
US culture, brought the deadly resurgence of Killer Cops, Police Brutality, 
such as the Earl Faison murder in Orange, outrages like NYC police execution 
  Diallo in a hail of forty one bullets, the lynching of     Byrd in Texas, 
the continued burning of Black churches in the south, recent growingly 
ubiquitous  marches by outspoken white supremacists in Morristown, the 
federal government's confirmation of New Jersey's infamous Racial Profiling, 
the elimination of Citizens' democratic rights such as the ban on Citizens 
speaking in Newark City Council,  the state's illegal and undemocratic take 
over of public schools  (now found in 24 states) which has resulted  in the 
disappearance of millions of dollars of public moneys but  not one trace of 
improvement to the education system.
              The frenzy of privatization of public institutions and 
services, with disastrous results such as the complete breakdown of the NJ 
Motor Vehicle Agency under the completely incompetent misadministration of 
private corporations at the expense of the state's people, allowing still 
more resources to be removed from the public treasury, like the huge give 
away tax cuts to the wealthy so that the state has to borrow money from the 
banks to pay for public services thereby further enriching corporate America 
while eliminating public democratic governance.
and dismantling the so-called citizen "safety net" of democratic services 
and institutions.
	Admission to the Celebrity Auction is $30 general admission, $60 VIP 
seating. For further information call  Peoples' Council     973-242-1346

>

Post ID:608
Sender:"Thomas DeGloma" <tdegloma@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-10 16:29:29
Subject:Seizing Power in New Brunswick
Message:


Attention all Cultural Activists:

The New Brunswick People�s Campaign is a coalition of student and community 
activists from New Brunswick who have formed an independent political party. 
  We are running three candidates for New Brunswick City Council in the 
November elections.

Our platform reflects the needs of students and the people of New Brunswick. 
  It was built with over 1,000 surveys conducted door-to-door, over 200 of 
which were filled out by students from Rutgers, Cook, and Douglass College.  
We will establish real rent control and promote music and culture throughout 
the city.  We will end all unfair ticketing (parking, trash, parties, etc.)  
We will build a women�s center.  We will establish an All-Elected Police 
Control Board with students and neighborhood representatives.  We will end 
the environmental devestation of New Brunswick�s waterways and 
neighborhoods.  We will build public pools and establish youth services, as 
well as tear down the walls that divide campus and community and make New 
Brunswick a safe and enjoyable place for all.  This is just a small part of 
a much a much larger revolutionary-democratic program that is the basis of 
our campaign - the needs and interests of the diverse people of our city.

Our candidates, Curtis Warren, Diego Morales, and Keith Joseph, were elected 
at a New Brunswick wide convention and have pledged to hold up the platform 
and the will of the people.

We need all the help we can get from student and community activists.  We 
need all organzaitions to register their members and contacts to vote in New 
Brunswick.  We need to turn out thousands of student to vote with the 
thousands of New Brunswick supporters on election day.  We are aiming to 
turn this city into a progressive stronghold and center for social justice.

We must unite - African-American, Latino, and Euro-American... men and 
women... students and community residents to ensure that the needs of all 
are met. That is what democracy is all about.  What we have now, at Rutgers 
and in New Brunswick, is the rule of the few over the many.  We have decided 
not to accept this. The city is going to change hands.

Please contact me by replying to this email or call me at home 732-729-0873 
for more information of to get involved.

In Unity,
Tom DeGloma


"Power concedes nothing without demand."
-Frederick Dougllass

"Speak loudly, even if your voice shakes."
-unknown

Thomas DeGloma
559 Hamilton Street
Somerset, NJ 08873
(h) 732-729-0873
(c) 732-687-2550
(o) 732-545-5756
Sociology Department 732-445-6893

Post ID:609
Sender:Anne Barron <barron58@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-11 07:08:03
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Fwd: NB activist illegally evicted....needs help
Message:

Hi, LEggles

Beverly Marshall is still in danger of eviction from
her NB Apartments (Oct. 1).

She did get a very short, unhelpful letter from Mr.
Soaries.  Commended her work as a grandmother and
suggested she contact the Kinship Navigator program
for advice.  ("The New Jersey Department of Human
Services createdthe Kinship Navigator Program to help
kinship caregivers navigate their way through the
various governmental systems to find local supports
and resources".)  And that was it.

HUD has sent her case to the HUD office in Trenton,
whatever that means.  They are suppose to contact her
but haven't yet.

thanks so much for your interest.  We may have to do a
rally in the next couple of weeks in her support. 
Beverly also wants to focus on the infringement of her
freedom of speech (over the sign on her door) and the
lower expectations of quality of life at her
complex(given the prohibition on lawn furniture).

other letters to the editor would help a lot (mine was
published Sat. in the HNT).  I will keep you posted.

Anne
--- LEggles867@... wrote:
> Does anybody know where this issue stands?  Did
> Beverly ever get a response 
> from Whitman? HUD?

Soaries.  Commended her work as a grandmother and

and resources".)  And that was it.

Post ID:611
Sender:Frank Bright <NBRC@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-11 22:06:25
Subject:Better than a Cup of Java
Message:

For those who keep posting leftist lines ... 



www.goreline.com

The Gore Line is a great resource for those attempting to follow Al
Gore's daily reinventions and frequent flip-flops on the issues.  

Last Sunday Governor Bush challenged Al Gore to join him for three
debates he had already agreed to - one sponsored by the Presidential
Debate Commission, one on a special edition of NBC's "Meet the Press,"
and one on a special edition of CNN's "Larry King Live."  True to form,
Al Gore ducked the Governor's challenge - and in doing so, revealed once
again that every word out of his mouth must be taken with large grains of
salt.

On Tuesday, in Pennsylvania, Governor Bush announced a detailed plan to
reform Medicare and provide prescription drug benefits to those seniors
in need.  Based as it is on a comprehensive reform of the Medicare system
- a system which is going broke - the Governor's plan sets up a clear
contrast with Gore's plan, which (like Hillary Clinton's failed 1993
gambit to nationalize the health care delivery system) relies on a Big
Government, bureaucrats-decide, one-size-fits-none prescription.

Wednesday, the Governor spoke to the American Legion - an audience
stiffed by Al Gore, much to the displeasure of the veterans in
attendance, who pointed out that it was the first time in history that a
presidential
candidate had failed to address them. 

New advertisement, entitled "Let's see/education," which challenges
Gore's credibility as a result of the 1996 Clinton/Gore fund-raising
scandal - a scandal that, when investigated, resulted in 22 indictments,
12 convictions, 70 people taking the Fifth Amendment, and 18 witnesses
fleeing the country.  After highlighting that sorry record, the ad pivots
to a discussion of Gore's promises to bring accountability to our
nation's schools - accountability that would be reached somehow (not
surprisingly, Gore doesn't say how) without testing.

________________________________________________________________
YOU'RE PAYING TOO MUCH FOR THE INTERNET!
Juno now offers FREE Internet Access!
Try it today - there's no risk!  For your FREE software, visit:
http://dl.www.juno.com/get/tagj.

Post ID:612
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-09-12 10:26:53
Subject:FYI
Message:

Hello,

For those of you who aren't on the Rutgers campuses frequently enough 
to pick up a copy of the Targum, Tom's recent mass email was printed 
today as a 'Guest Editorial'.  It appears to have been reprinted 
verbatim, but I might be wrong.  Also, there was an article a few
days 
ago -- on the 7th -- about a poll of NB residents by Eagleton that
may 
interest some people.  It is available in the "Archive" section of
the 
Targum's website, if you simply choose "News Articles" and "Sep. 7".  
I wrote a short letter in response to this.  Unfortunately, it got 
sort of screwed up by whomever edited it.

In any case, you can get the Targum online at www.dailytargum.com.   

Jeremy

Hello --

Yeah, what struck me about the article was that the person who wrote 
it didn't seem to really recognize the poll as being in any 
way 'political'.  It read like one of those 'Good News' articles that 
are used as filler in those local 'Community Shopper' advertisement-
newspapers.

I'm really curious to see how the survey was structured, what 
questions were asked and how, etc.  I'm sure someone will get back to 
you if they're writing something about the survey for whatever 
publication, newspaper, op-ed piece, etc.  I myself have been sort of 
out of the loop lately due to some academic commitments that should 
loosen a bit come next weekend, so I don't know what's up and what's 
down, in terms of the activities of the campaign.

Are you the person from RSU, btw?

TTYL,

Jeremy

Post ID:622
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-09-13 20:00:53
Subject:Re: Seizing Power in New Brunswick
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "Thomas DeGloma"
<tdegloma@h...> 
wrote:

Tom and anyone else,

You may wish to add "Asian" to the usual list of 'racial' groups to
be 
addressed by a document, poster, speech, whatever.  There isn't a 
substantial Asian community off-campus, but now that school is back
in 
session, there are many people of East or Southeast Asian descent 
living on or near campus.  To whatever extent it is felt to be good
or 
necessary to call out different groups rather than, say, just using 
some catchphrase of inclusiveness.   
  
As a matter of lesser importance -- I would tend to oppose wheeling 
out the term "revolutionary-democratic".  I would gladly explain if 
anyone really thinks it's necessary to call the campaign 
"revolutionary-democratic".  Again, I recognize that this is a very 
very minor issue.  

TTYL,

Jeremy

Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-15 13:11:29
Subject:Fwd: Apartment Available in Jersey City
Message:

>Hey folks,
>
>My Jersey city abode is available once again for sublet and i'm looking
>for potential occupants. Details of the apartment are down below, and i'm 
>looking for a someone to enter soon,
>like oct or november even. Someone is currently there and will move out on
>the arranged move-in date for the next occupant.
>
>Please email me Kevin Sztam at sztamke@...
>Please Call Kevin Sztam at 410.837.9020
>
>357 Fulton Avenue, Apt 1
>Jersey City, NJ 07305
>
>LOCATION:  Southern Jersey City, between Kennedy Blvd and West Side
>Avenue, both major conduits (and bus routes) through Hudson County.  12
>minutes to Canal and Sixth Ave by car, no traffic.  Major shopping (food,
>home depot, movies, etc) within 1 mile. Great italian food, and amazing
>bread bakeries (DiPalma's eggplant is the BOMB!).  7 minute drive to Grove
>St PATH and Liberty State Park.  8 minute drive to Route 280 or to "Indian
>Row." Ridiculous aloo gobi and kheer. The "brand-spanking-spanking new"
>Jersey City Light Rail (to PATH Stations and Hoboken) 6 blocks away. Great
>diners.  3 minute ride to Bayonne park (bayside).  15 minute drive to
>downtown Newark.  5 minutes to NJ Turnpike and Route 1.
>
>NEIGHBORHOOD:  mostly phillipino, with lots of families, few renters.
>Small close houses built around 1950. Cleaners, 2 italian restaurants,
>convenience stores, video store within one block.  Gym (JC State) four
>blocks away, walkable.
>
>APARTMENT: 1st Floor of house (that has upstairs and attic apartments
>curently rented). 2 Bedroom, Eat-In Kitchen with lots of light, Dining
>room and Living room, entrance closet, Pantry.  One bedroom with walk-in
>closet and ceiling fan.  Huge Porcelain Tub, Hardwood floors, great
>windows, especially in the front.  Off-street Parking: Sole use of Long
>DRIVEWAY. Sole use of WASHER and DRYER in basement.  Apartment common
>areas partly furnished.  No pets.
>
>COST:  $750 plus utilities.  Nice rent.
>
>WHEN:  Available officially November 1.  You can move your stuff in
>earlier if you like, and could even stay there by arrangement with the
>current tenant.
>
>THE DEAL:  I will be moving back to this apartment in Jersey City in
>either May, June or July of 2001 to continue medical school.  Ideally, i
>would love for one person to rent it until then, and if you desire, when i
>come back you can stay.  I have some stuff in the aprtment now in the
>common areas , and would prefer to keep it there, seeing as i've already
>moved my needed things to Baltimore.  I will be moving that stuff back
>when i return.  Someone is currently in the apartment and would be able to
>show it to you at a convenient time.  If you and a friend would like to
>rent it, that's cool so let me know and we can work it out.
>
>Any questions contact me ASAP.
>
>-Kevin
>

>"Vieques, Time to Decide" examines the history of the conflict between the
>islanders and the US Navy and the events that lead up to the current
>protests. The 33-minute documentary includes interviews with Carlos Zen�n
>and many other Viequenses, Governor Pedro Rossell�, Secretary of State
>Angel Morey and US Senator James Inhofe. The story was originally produced
>as a master�s project at Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism
>and is now aired by several PBS stations across the U.S.
>
>Producers: Ivan O'Mahoney, Thomas Loudon, Constanza Santa Maria
>Project Advisor: Scotti Williston

Post ID:637
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-24 03:34:20
Subject:Fwd: CIA Admits Nazi Connection by R Lederman
Message:



>From: ARTISTpres@...
>To: undisclosed-recipients:;
>Subject: CIA Admits Nazi Connection by R Lederman
>Date: Fri, 22 Sep 2000 19:04:22 EDT
>
>CIA Admits Nazi Connection
>by Robert Lederman
>
>Conspicuous by its silence the CIA owned and influenced media
>did virtually no coverage of what may be one of the decades
>biggest stories. Only UPI issued any statement on the CIA's
>admission that following WWII Hitler's top general in charge of
>espionage transferred his entire network of thousands of spies
>and double agents to what became the newly-formed CIA.
>
>What makes this much more than an interesting footnote to
>history is that the entire domestic and foreign history of the CIA
>has been molded by these former Nazis whose ideas on Eugenics,
>race, social control, biowarfare and propaganda dominate the
>policies of countless "think tanks" like the Rockefeller-funded
>Manhattan Institute and have influenced the U.S. government at
>its highest levels.
>
>During the past five decades numerous isolated revelations about
>Nazis imported to America by the Dulles brothers, William
>Casey and others have broken through the media blackout. These
>stories usually revolve around former concentration camp guards
>who hid their identity when emigrating. What makes this
>different is that General Ghelen was the #1 Nazi in this program.
>By acknowledging a CIA connection to Ghelen the entire can of
>worms can now be pried open.
>
>For excellent published works on the CIA/Nazi connection read:
>Trading With The Enemy by Charles Higham
>The Secret War Against the Jews by Loftus and Arrons
>Blowback by Christopher Simpson
>
>For my articles on the connection to Mayor Giuliani and the
>Bush family see:
>http://Baltech.org/lederman/spray/
>
>From:
>http://www.vny.com/cf/News/upidetail.cfm?QID=119975
>
>UPI 9/20/2000
>CIA says Nazi general was intelligence source
>Wednesday, 20 September 2000 20:28 (ET)
>
>CIA says Nazi general was intelligence source
>
>  COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- The Central
>Intelligence Agency has for the first time confirmed that a
>high-ranking Nazi general placed his anti-Soviet spy ring at the
>disposal of the United States during the early days of the Cold
>War.
>
>  The National Archives said in a release Wednesday that the CIA
>had filed an affidavit in U.S. District Court "acknowledging an
>intelligence relationship with German General Reinhard Gehlen
>that it has kept secret for 50 years."
>
>  "The CIA's announcement marks the first acknowledgement by
>that agency that it had any relationship with Gehlen and opens
>the way for
>declassification of records about the relationship," the National
>Archives said.
>
>  Gehlen was Hitler's senior intelligence officer on the Eastern
>Front during the war and transferred his expertise and contacts to
>the U.S. as World War II reached its climax. While Gehlen's
>relationship with U.S. intelligence during the 1940s and 1950s
>has been the topic of some five books over the years, the eventual
>release of CIA documents pertaining to the development of his
>European spy ring could shed new light on the origins of the
>Cold War and early U.S. espionage efforts against Moscow.
>
>  Gehlen's network of agents in Europe - including many with
>Nazi backgrounds who were bailed out of prisoner of war camps
>by U.S. intelligence officers - was known as the Gehlen
>Organization and received millions of dollars in funding from the
>U.S. until 1956.
>
>  The CIA's acknowledgement of its dealings with Gehlen came in
>a response to an appeal of a Freedom of Information Act request
>by researcher Carl Oglesby, the National Archives said. The
>agency pledged to release its records on the general in
>accordance with the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure
>Act.
>
>  The Act established the Nazi War Criminal Records Interagency
>Working Group (IWG), which for more than two years has been
>declassifying documents related to World War II war crimes and
>releasing them through the National Archives.
>
>  "This shows that the law is working," said former Rep. Elizabeth
>Holtzman, a member of the IWG. "We now must work closely
>with the Agency to follow through with the release of these
>records."
>
>Copyright 2000 by United Press International.
>All rights reserved.
>
>In accordance with Title 17 U.S.C. section 107, this material is
>distributed without profit or payment to those who have
>expressed a prior interest in receiving this information for
>non-profit research and educational purposes only.

>my home, my city, and my entire family with

>damages DNA and Anvil, a pyrethyroid nerve gas
>that reduces sperm count, causes cognitive
>difficulties and increases breast cancer tumors. I also
>want to thank you for killing off all those annoying
>little bees, birds, butterflies and fish that were taking
>up valuable space on which office towers and
>baseball stadiums could be built to glorify you as
>Mayor. You are absolutely right when you said that
>New Yorkers who don't understand that seeing a
>police car means they should run for their lives
>deserved the harmful spray effects they got. So many
>of my fellow citizens just can't appreciate that
>sometimes it's necessary to poison millions in order
>to theoretically save a few lives.

>has been so aggressive in spraying pesticides to kill
>mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus, Mayor
>Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, rejecting
>criticism from environmentalists who are suing the
>city to stop the spraying.. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday
>that the people who were sprayed with Anvil
>—which the city Health Department calls "relatively
>nontoxic to humans" — had only themselves to
>blame. "There is a very simple thing to do here. Get
>out of the way. Don't stay there and inhale the
>spray," the mayor said, noting that a police car
>accompanies the pesticide-spraying trucks to warn
>people."

Subject:CENSORSHIP AT NJIT!!!
Message:

Hey Matthew,
           I have a few concerns regarding your opinion. Though you do bring 
up
valid points in your opinion, there were parts of the column, where the 
message
of your opinion gets lost. If you could just reword your opinion so that you
state the message clearly at the top of your column, that would give people 
a
better sense of what to expect from your opinion. Also, even though you make 
a
valid point about architects, I believe that your column leans towards 
attacking
Eisenman, rather than making the point that he did not care about the 
community
in New Brunswick. Please reword it so that you can better get your point 
accross
to the readers. If you have any questions, feel free to e-mail the managing
editor at fjo8185@....
Thank you
Keerti Chivakula
Editor-in-chief






Dear Mr. Smith,
    Whether you feel that we are crticizing you is not the point. While your
opinions outline is good you spend most of it insulting a fellow human 
being.
The Vector is not an outlet for a persons gripe with someone else. If you
wish to write for the paper then I seriously recommend you change your tone.
Also, do not criticize the work of John Messenger [racist, right wing, 
columninst for Vector--MS]  for the only garbage that
I see here is that so called opinion of yours.

                                                            -Francisco Otero
                                                            -Managing Editor
p.s.- If that wasn't clear enough for you, we're not putting in your 
opinion!

Post ID:641
Sender:MEADHajduk@...
Post Date/Time:2000-09-25 12:47:42
Subject:gripe water brew
Message:

greetings matthew............here's a recipe for gripe water, though you may 
want to administer a stronger dose to those folks at the vector considering 
their discriminating taste.............althea

Herbal remedy for wind and indigestion, gripe water

Crush 15 grams (  oz ) of dill seeds, put them in a teacup and pour boiling 
water
over them. Stir and leave to draw for 10 minutes. Strain and allow to cool.

The dose for colicky babies is 1 teaspoon before meals, otherwise 1 teaspoon
as needed.

                                   For adults 1 tablespoon as needed.

Post ID:643
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-25 15:21:34
Subject:NJIT&CENSORSHIP/ARTICLE
Message:

CENSORSHIP AT NJIT/VECTOR!

	The Editor in Chief and Managing Editor of the only campus newspaper at 
NJIT has decided to censor an article of mine for the first issue of this 
semester.  This sets a disturbing tone, suggesting that Freedom of Speech is 
not guaranteed at NJIT.
	College campuses have long been hotbeds of intellectual debate and 
political dissension, playing a historic role for Social Change and claim a 
legacy of Civil Rights struggle in the United States.  More directly, this 
is Newark��The Brick City�--not some isolated country club on Ivy Hill.  
People have been struggling for social justice in Newark for longer than 
most of us here have been alive.  The Editors of the Vector need to get hip 
to this fact and cut with the sophomoric stunts.  The Vector office is not 
their private pizza den, though the paper�s embarrassing lack of substance 
in the past might suggest this.  The Managing Editor went as far as 
demanding that I not criticize John Messenger (see below), the Vector�s 
darling right-wing columnist last year, whose backwards, racist, Dixie-flag 
waving trash talk was vehemently defended in the name of Free Speech by the 
same paper that now wants to censor my thoughts and words.
	The great irony is that my article was titled �The Students Pen VS the 
Master�s Sword,� written on behalf of Architect Peter Eisenman, who, at a 
lecture appearance last spring, ordered his audience to put down their pens, 
threatening to embarrass any perpetrators with expulsion from the lecture 
hall!!!  This is my second year at NJIT, and I�m deeply concerned about 
casual attitude some folks seem to have regarding another�s right to form 
independent and progressive thought!  I call upon the students to email the 
Vector, or stop in on their office on the second floor of the Student 
Center, and demand that they stop the censorship & print my article, 
word-for-word.  Finally, it is my hope that once we get past the issue of 
censorship, we cen get down to a much needed and energetic debate as to the 
merits of Peter Eisanman's work, etc.
	IT�S TIME FOR FREE AND INDEPENDENT THOUGHT AT NJIT!
Send letters  to the.vector@...  (please CC to me, as well)

Matthew Smith
Architecture Student�3rd year
vivaohio@...


THIS ARTICLE HAS NOT REACHED SOME PEOPLE, BECAUSE OF ERRORS in the 
ATTACHMENT.


The Student�s Pen vs. the Master�s Sword


Let�s begin by taking care of some unresolved business.  Last year, the 
School of Architecture was graced with the presence of a Newark native and 
deconstructivist luminary, Peter Eisenman.  No need for introduction�accept 
to relay my first personal encounter with him:  He began his lecture in 
Weston Lecture Hall by telling me to put my pen down.  In fact he told us 
all to put our pens down, and if anyone didn�t comply he would embarrass 
them by ordering them to leave.  Nice.
	I imagine that most people complied because his talk went on uninterrupted, 
even when he mentioned that one of his clients is a Franco Spaniard (in 
German, that�s called a Nazi) My initial impulse, however, was to tighten my 
grip on my pen and hold on for dear life.  I can�t remember if it was 
initially an act of resistance or shock.  But regardless, as my indignation 
settled into clarity of purpose, my one thought was: the moment somebody 
orders you to put down the pen�the mightiest of weapons�you ask them, no 
matter who they are or think they are, politely�at first�where they would 
like you to stick it.  And then you start writing down his reaction so that 
everyone else knows how the story went.
	It was an unspoken test of wills.  Sitting in full view of our orator, 
front row, right-of-center, pen in hand, note book in full view, scratching 
thoughts down here and there, not to snatch his words out of the air and 
claim them as my own (which I guess was his concern)�frankly I don�t find 
much practical use for his ideas.   What I was jotting down was the question 
that I wanted to raise during the Q&A session.   I you�re wondering, he 
didn�t stop the lecture to single me out for exile.  What he did was much 
more insidious.  He refused to take my question.  And there�s no doubt that 
of all the waving hands, he accidentally missed just mine.
	O.K., Mr. Eisenman, now I will raise my question, this time with the luxury 
of preface.
You appeared New Brunswick, NJ, where I was living, a little over a year ago 
with a design concept commissioned by the City and sponsored by the Rutgers� 
arts school.   It was an inflated student center & 10,000 seat sports arena 
for Rutgers University.  The design was a predictably unpredictable sinewy 
curvilinear formless form.  Only, it was not set on Rutgers property, but 
directly on top of an entire struggling downtown community�sparing the 
church�which was already over-stressed by the �revitalization� that 
threatened to ethnically cleanse their block next, making way for the return 
of the �white-flighters.�  When the morning newspaper came out with a three 
page spread on your plan, folks were shocked, dismayed, and nearly up in 
arms.  The outrage only subsided when the city bosses distanced themselves 
from the concept by claiming that they never intended to build it.  It was 
merely a whimsical exploration of intellectual experiment. You seemed 
betrayed, and made the case that we, the people, are just not ready for such 
a vision.
So my question to you, Mr. Eisenman, is as it was last spring: What is the 
architect�s responsibility to the community in which his buildings are to 
exist?
I insist on having this addressed, because too often architecture neglects 
the very people whose lives are imposed upon by the invisible hand of the 
architect.  Mr. Eisenman, it�s not that the people of New Brunswick �didn�t 
get it�!  It�s because you apparently didn�t spend the time to get them.   I 
believe it is the job of the architect to go down to the community to find 
out its needs, its struggles, its desires.  The architect should be a public 
servant, not a lord.  There are real people whose real lives exist in that 
space between the architect�s imagination and his or her buildings.   Our 
work should reflect that.  Try it.

From my pen to you-
Matthew R. Smith, Student
NJ School of Architecture at NJIT



_________________________________________________________________________

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

"If anyone wishes their thoughts published without the burden of another 
man's opinion, creating a newspaper would be diligent."  Ben Franklin





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:646
Sender:Frank Bright <NBRC@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-26 17:02:30
Subject:The Return of The Somersaulting Al Gore
Message:



The old Al Gore resurfaced this week - no doubt to the consternation of
his campaign's spinmeisters tasked with the unenviable job of trying to
explain the vice president's, ah, er, shall we say,  propensity to
prevaricate. 

Monday's Boston Globe headlined a story about Gore shamelessly lying to
senior citizens to gain political advantage.  While on a Florida campaign
swing on August 28, the Globe revealed, Gore claimed that his
mother-in-law and his dog use the same arthritis drug, Lodine - but that
his mother-in-law has to pay three times as much as the pooch.  The Globe
discovered that, in fact, the prices cited by Gore came not from personal
experience, but from a bogus "study" prepared by Democrat congressional
staffers.  Then ensued four straight days of Gore's spin doctors hemming
and hawing over whether Gore's mother-in-law and/or canine companion
really do take the drug, how much they pay - or would pay if they did
take it - and so forth, none of which supported Gore's claims. 
Meanwhile, Gore's traveling press corps is becoming increasingly
perturbed over his unwillingness to directly answer any questions from
them.

Then, on Wednesday, Walter Shapiro of USA Today reported that two days
earlier, while in Nevada to accept the endorsement of the Teamsters, Gore
had said he fondly remembered the lullabies he'd been sung in the cradle,
and then launched into a slightly off-key rendition of "Look for the
Union Label," the advertising jingle of the International Ladies Garment
Workers Union.  Problem was, as Shapiro pointed out, the jingle was
written for an ad campaign that began in 1975 - when Gore was 27 years
old. Thursday - worried about how the highest oil prices in ten years
might affect his political fortunes- Gore called on Bill Clinton to
release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.  Yes, this is the very
same Al Gore who, as recently as last February, explained that releasing
oil from the Reserves would be a bad move, because it would be
immediately offset by equivalent OPEC production cutbacks.  And yes, this
is the same administration whose Treasury Secretary, Larry Summers,
warned just last week that doing so "would be a major and substantial
policy mistake." It would also be a campaign contribution from Clinton to
Gore using a public resource. And what was Governor Bush doing while Gore
was stewing in his own juices?

Unveiling his Blueprint for the Middle Class - a comprehensive theme that
wraps up his education, Social Security, Medicare/prescription drug and
tax cut plans into one cohesive package - and reaching more and more
voters by appearing on the popular television shows hosted by Oprah
Winfrey and Regis Philbin.




________________________________________________________________
YOU'RE PAYING TOO MUCH FOR THE INTERNET!
Juno now offers FREE Internet Access!
Try it today - there's no risk!  For your FREE software, visit:
http://dl.www.juno.com/get/tagj.

Please, we must focus on the task at hand.  United we stand, divided we fall.

> written for an ad campaign that began in 1975 - when Gore was 27 
years
> old. Thursday - worried about how the highest oil prices in ten 
years
> might affect his political fortunes- Gore called on Bill Clinton to
> release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.  Yes, this is the 
very
> same Al Gore who, as recently as last February, explained that 
releasing
> oil from the Reserves would be a bad move, because it would be
> immediately offset by equivalent OPEC production cutbacks.  And 
yes, this
> is the same administration whose Treasury Secretary, Larry Summers,
> warned just last week that doing so "would be a major and 
substantial
> policy mistake." It would also be a campaign contribution from 
Clinton to
> Gore using a public resource. And what was Governor Bush doing 
while Gore
> was stewing in his own juices?

I'm not so much concerned about Al Gore's character as an individual 
as much as I am concerned about the fact that he is really a 
Republican in Democrat's guise.

Whether or not he has a dog who takes arthritis medication may 
concern those middle managers and soccer moms nation-wide who look 
for nothing more in politicians than that they conform to the value 
system put forward by the sitcom Rosanne.  

As for me, well, I don't give a flying fig.  I'm more concerned about 
who, under the possible Gore administration, is going to get bombed.  
I'm curious to know which corporations are going to get the largest 
tax breaks at the expense of the majority of people.  And I'm of 
course very interested to know how many schools will go without books 
so that the United States military can have more toys.

> 
> Unveiling his Blueprint for the Middle Class - a comprehensive 
theme that
> wraps up his education, Social Security, Medicare/prescription drug 
and
> tax cut plans into one cohesive package - and reaching more and more
> voters by appearing on the popular television shows hosted by Oprah
> Winfrey and Regis Philbin.

Who is going to pay for it, Frank?

Oprah and Regis?  How about this.  Instead of having debates, we can 
just have the candidates do puppet shows, just like Tom Tomorrow 
recently suggested.  It will be a lot more fun fer down-ta-earth 
folks like you and me.  How 'bout it?

Isn't it also funny how Bush has to constantly revise his position, 
even his character, every week or so?  

GORE AND BUSH CAN BOTH KISS MY A**

VOTE NADER





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> >Monday's Boston Globe headlined a story about Gore shamelessly 
lying to
> >senior citizens to gain political advantage.  While on a Florida 
campaign
> >swing on August 28, the Globe revealed, Gore claimed that his
> >mother-in-law and his dog use the same arthritis drug, Lodine - 
but that
> >his mother-in-law has to pay three times as much as the pooch.  
The Globe
> >discovered that, in fact, the prices cited by Gore came not from 
personal
> >experience, but from a bogus "study" prepared by Democrat 
congressional
> >staffers.  Then ensued four straight days of Gore's spin doctors 
hemming
> >and hawing over whether Gore's mother-in-law and/or canine 
companion
> >really do take the drug, how much they pay - or would pay if they 
did
> >take it - and so forth, none of which supported Gore's claims.
> >Meanwhile, Gore's traveling press corps is becoming increasingly
> >perturbed over his unwillingness to directly answer any questions 
from
> >them.
> >

days
> >earlier, while in Nevada to accept the endorsement of the

> >had said he fondly remembered the lullabies he'd been sung in the 
cradle,
> >and then launched into a slightly off-key rendition of "Look for 
the

Post ID:658
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-09-27 21:58:17
Subject:Al Gore, etc, etc
Message:

I don't think it's necessarily terribly distracting to post messages 
not purely related to the campaign.  But -- Frank -- you would have 
to be demonstrating how a Bush administration would be concretely 
better in terms of the issues that the Campaign is dealing with.  
Certainly, you would have to demonstrate that there would exist more 
funding, more amenable court decisions, more programs, etc, to help 
sustain and foster local reform and activist efforts of all sorts 
(secular or church-based, for that matter) -- under a Bush 
administration.  

I would take the fairly strong stand that gossip about how 
inauthentic Al Gore is as a _character_ does not constitute political 
discussion.

Post ID:660
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-09-29 14:39:01
Subject:Call to Action...NB 2000!!!
Message:

***PLEASE SEND THIS MESSAGE OUT FAR AND WIDE***

To all friends and comrades in the Newark area-

    As most of you are aware, there is a groundswell of activity in New 
Brunwsick around the November 7 Elections.  To sum up:  The NB People's 
Campaign, a broad based, multi-national, multi-class, coalition united 
around the goal of upsetting the Democratic (read: "corporate") Machine in 
the upcoming City Council election.  We have advanced a 3 person, 
multi-national ticket and a revolutionary democratic platform arrived at 
through canvassing over 1000 people prior to a public Convention held last 
April, at which the platform points and candidates were proposed, debated, 
and voted on.
    Since then, the spectrum of forces in NB working on this campaign have 
grown deeper and wider, encompassing workers, students in the NB schools as 
well as on Rutger's campuses, artists, professionals, small business owners, 
the young and the old. The momentum is unprecented:  In ONE DAY last week, 
over 500 PEOPLE on Rutgers Campus were REGISTERED TO VOTE by our canvasers 
and supporters!
    Now, we are entering the home stretch.  With little over 1 month to go, 
and knowing that we need hundreds of people in the streets election day 
working the poles, getting out the voters, etc. we are now reaching out to 
those outside New Brunswick who understand the need for a real and radical 
transformation of the institutions that are running our lives.
    IN THE SPRING OF 1998, N.J.F.O. BROUGHT 50 PEOPLE FROM NEW BRUNWICK TO 
NEWARK TO WORK ON RAS BARAKA'S BID FOR CITY COUNCIL! (an election that he 
initially won, but had stripped of him through a dubious run-off election).  
THIS TIME, LET'S SHOW THAT NEWARK IS BEHIND NEW BRUNSWICK!!!  WE CAN MATCH 
THAT EFFORT AND THEN SOME IF YOU MARK YOUR CALENDARS NOW!  NOVEMBER 
7...ELECTION DAY: 2000, WE NEED YOU IN NEW BRUNSWICK TO HELP BREAK THE 
STRANGLED-HOLD THAT THE CORRUPTED AND ROTTEN NB CITY MACHINE HAS AROUND THE 
NECKS OF NEW BRUNSWICK RESIDENTS.  If and when we win in NB, it will send 
shock waves across the state, and indeed the nation, sending the message 
that it is possible for the people to organize to take control of their own 
lives.

     We are encouraging people to come down the night before, so that we can 
get organized and stike out early.  Please RSVP-ASAP and indicate if you can 
come Monday night (Lodging will be provided) or Tuesday morning.  Further 
information will be provided, such as rides, directions, sleeping 
arrangements, etc.

For the future,
Matthew Smith
(973) 372-7130 (# subject to change this month; please email.)
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:661
Sender:jfortun845@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-01 09:52:45
Subject:Re: NB peoples campaign and the Greens
Message:

Matthew and all:

Thank you for putting out this call. I'll spread the word and we'll try to 
get some Greens to help out in the final weeks. In my opinion, we can have 
our principled disagreement over the tactic of supporting Ralph Nader or not 
in the presidential election and still agree that the New Brunswick Peoples 
Campaign is a critically important expression of independent political action 
which must be supported. i will encourage Greens to get involved.

As far as Nader is concerned, I would argue that even if you hold to the "we 
must defeat Bush" line nationally, in New Jersey Gore is now 18 points ahead 
in the latest polls. Hence, in our electoral college system, a progressive 
who votes for gore would truly be wasting a progressive vote: it doesn't 
matter a tinker's damn whether Gore wins NJ by 18 % or 19 %.

In any case, keep up the good work and we'll try to respond in force to your 
call.

Joe Fortunato
(9730 744-5958

Post ID:664
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-02 10:55:57
Subject:today's targum
Message:

Daily Targum Oct 2, 2000

Ideal candidates?

Editorial

This November, the People�s Campaign, a multiracial coalition of city 
residents, Rutgers students and community organizers, hopes to defeat the 
three City Council incumbents. Although New Brunswick�s city government has 
dire need for a change, the People�s Campaign may unfortunately not be the 
answer.

Curtis Warren, Diego Morales and Keith Joseph are running on a 17-point 
platform derived from a 1,000-person survey canvass throughout the entire 
city. They hope to address the wants and needs of the people of New 
Brunswick and not the corporate interests that the current City Council 
seems to represent. The People�s Campaign�s goals concern government reform, 
resident support services and economic development, three lenses of reform 
that the City Council must begin to look through.

However, the candidates are too idealistic. They have limited access to 
information and haven�t been able to analyze the city�s current spending. 
The programs they wish to initiate � such as job placement and training for 
all city residents, public child care for infants through pre-kindergarten 
and free or low-cost health services for city residents as a condition of 
local hospital expansions � would cause massive increases in taxes.

It is important to have citizens with diverse interests on the council. It 
is important to break up the current administration, which has dominated New 
Brunswick for decades. The People�s Campaign is a worthy cause, but it 
cannot expect to break up the current system with lofty ideals. The 
candidates need to be politicians, not dreamers. Robert Recine, Joseph 
Schrum and Jimmy Cook � the incumbents � should remain in office, not 
because of their merits as council members, but because Warren, Morales and 
Joseph do not have realistic means to achieve their goals.
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:665
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-02 11:05:34
Subject:targum #2
Message:

Daily Targum
Oct 2, 2000

Ideal candidates?

By Joe Smith
Guest Commentary

In reference to the editorial �Appointed Democracy� (The Daily Targum, Sept. 
26), the editorial staff should do its homework and try to develop a correct 
analysis regarding the debate of an elected versus appointed board of 
education for the New Brunswick schools. Let us first look at the two 
biggest reforms dealing with public schools and see how they relate to the 
school system here in New Brunswick.

� Brown v. Topeka Board of Education, 1954 � The United States Supreme Court 
rules against the legal form of segregation in school districts across the 
nation.

� Abott v. Burke, 1974 � The New Jersey Supreme Court rules that the 
government must ensure equal funding and the same level of quality education 
across the board for all school districts throughout the state.

As the Campaign for the Elected Board of Education studies the New Brunswick 
schools, we can see that these rulings have not materialized, and Mayor Jim 
Cahill�s administration has not been fighting for these funds and resources 
that Gov. Christie Whitman�s administration so easily withholds. It is de 
facto segregation that is cemented in the New Brunswick school district from 
top to bottom. The editorial, while noting all the merits of the Cahill 
administration, did not ask the question, �Why does Cahill send his children 
to private schools?�

African-Americans and Latinos represent over 95 percent of the enrollment at 
New Brunswick High School. How many of these children are going to be 
sitting next to you in your classes at Rutgers? Let us be clear when we 
study the merits of the Cahill administration�s appointed school board. Its 
most notable merits this year � and we should understand that it is only 
late September � include two of the biggest attacks that can take place in 
any school system. Every school district in New Jersey was mandated to 
provide a high-quality, full-day education for three-, four- and 
five-year-old children by the school year 2000-01 (New Jersey State 
Department of Education, 1998).

So, instead of restructuring space available while planning to develop 
proper facilities, the appointed school board has taken over every child 
care system throughout New Brunswick. This is after it scrapped a plan, 
because of public opposition, to put these children in trailers. None of 
these teachers are certified, which leads to the fact that none of these 
teachers can be admitted into the New Brunswick Education Association 
teachers� union. What praise does Cahill�s administration deserve for union 
busting, and does the editorial staff feel these tactics are about the 
improvement of the education system for the city�s children?

Not only does New Brunswick High School maintain the lowest standardized 
test scores in central Jersey, but the Cahill administration is also 
responsible for a graduation rate of only 55 percent. These problems were 
not something Cahill walked into; rather, they are the problems he 
engineered.

How shall we deal with such an administration? This is the question for 
people serious about improving the educational system and the overall 
improvement of the life for the people of New Brunswick and Rutgers. Not 
improvement for Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, Rutgers, and 
Johnson and Johnson, but the improvement for the majority of people in this 
city who have nothing at all.

People in New Brunswick are fighting to establish Democratic community 
control over all the institutions that govern our lives. All public 
officials must be elected: police chiefs, judges, school board members, 
housing authority members. Our biggest opposition comes from the Democratic 
machine, which shows clearly whose interests it truly represents, and why we 
must run it out of town.

The Campaign for the Elected Board of Education will embrace all progressive 
forces in the spirit of unity and struggle. We endorse the People�s 
Campaign�s 17-point platform, as well as their three City Council candidates 
up for election. We are open about our intentions and clear about our 
reasons: win the elected board of education, overthrow Mayor Cahill and 
build the Revolutionary Democratic Workers Party.

Joe Smith, a University College first-year student, is campaign coordinator 
for the Campaign for the Elected Board of Education.
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:666
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-02 17:18:23
Subject:Letter to the editor re 10/2 editorial
Message:

October 2, 2000
To the Editor:

I'm writing regarding the editorial on 10/2/00, titled "Ideal Candidates?".  
In your piece, you said "New Brunswick's city government has a dire need for 
a change" and you also wrote that the People's Campaign "hope[s] to address 
the wants and needs of the people of New Brunswick and not the corporate 
interests that the current City Council seems to represent."  But you label 
our candidates "idealistic."

The People's Campaign has never claimed to know all the answers.  But we've 
undertaken a ten-month process to involve the entire town in its government. 
  Is it idealistic to ask people what they lack, and demand action from the 
city government?  That's what we in the local activist community have been 
doing for many years, without a word from the city council.  And now we 
propose to help the majority take its rightful position in city affairs and 
we're called "dreamers".

We challenge the Democrats for the same reasons that protestors attack the 
WTO, World Bank, and IMF.  Thousands of people in New Brunswick live in 
abject poverty, toiling day and night without hope of improving their lives. 
  None of these people get respect from anyone with power or money. They 
have to fight for their most basic needs.
The Democratic machine has organized the removal of thousands of local 
families from their housing, ignored police murders, intimidated voters and 
threatened political challengers. In short, the city council has presided 
over a city more like Soweto, South Africa than a wealthy center for 
business, technology and education.

I see two explanations for this editorial: either the Targum edit board 
doesn't leave the student center, or it seeks to serve the corporate-backed 
regime currently residing in City Hall.

Paul McGee, NB People's Campaign, Univ. College grad '97
732-729-0873

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

>                             415/643-4401
>
>                                         IPA LAUNCHES NEW FELLOWSHIP
>                                           FOR JOURNALISTS OF COLOR
>
>
>                             The Independent Press Association announces 
>the George Washington
>                             Williams Fellowship created to encourage 
>journalists of color to pursue
>                             important social issues in the public 
>interest. The fellowship funds stories
>                             written by journalists of color about issues 
>such as the environment, global
>                             trade policy, healthcare, race, and education. 
>Fellows receive access to
>                             research support, office facilities, 
>consultants, advanced professional
>                             training, and a large network of journalists 
>working in the public interest
>                             sector. In addition, program staff work 
>closely with fellows to publish their
>                             stories in major publications.
>
>                             Individuals may apply for financial and 
>institutional support to write a story,
>                             or they may seek a reporting fellowship of 
>three, six or twelve months to do
>                             more in-depth research on a specific social 
>issue. If accepted, the George
>                             Washington Williams Fellowship will pay 
>national commercial rates for
>                             individual stories or $1500 per month plus 
>expenses for reporting
>                             fellowships.
>
>                             Any journalist of color with at least three 
>years of solid reporting and writing
>                             experience may apply for the fellowship. 
>Individuals with backgrounds in
>                             investigative or enterprise reporting are 
>preferred, though not required.
>                             Previous reporting or other experience in the 
>chosen subject area is
>                             desirable.
>
>                             The George Washington Williams Fellowship is 
>named after the
>                             turn-of-the-century African American 
>journalist who wrote the first history
>                             of African Americans from their own point of 
>view. Williams was also the
>                             first reporter to document the upheaval in the 
>Belgian Congo at that time.
>
>                             For application information, please contact 
>Linda Jue at 415/643-4401
>                             x107.
>
>                             The Independent Press Association is a 
>nonprofit, national magazine trade
>                             association representing 230 independent and 
>public interest periodicals. In
>                             addition to the G.W. Williams Fellowship, the 
>IPA offers a variety of
>                             services to its members. These include a 
>revolving loan fund, a paper-buying
>                             cooperative, on-line publishing advice, 
>newsstand distribution services, and
>                             publishing conferences.
>

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:669
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-04 15:00:43
Subject:Yesterday's Letter
Message:

Paul,

Let me just offer a few comments about your letter to the Targum.  I 
mean no major disrespect; but I think certain claims ought not to be 
made.  This would go to anyone seeking to defend the Campaign or 
articulate its possible virtues.  

First, you cannot rightly compare Soweto to New Brunswick.  The 
problems with New Brunswick are deeply, qualitatively different.  I 
think it's fair to say that South Africa under Apartheid, especially 
prior to the 1980's, was a Totalitarian state.  There were countless 
different 'racial' categories officially, brutally enforced by the 
state.  Mobility, the right to work in a given area, the right to
live 
in a given area, was rigidly regulated according to one's official 
place in the white / coloured / Indian / Black hierarchy.    

I should also point out that any analysis of the city of New
Brunswick 
must note that 'race' must be considered somewhat less primary to the 
city's social and political ills than class.  It's really difficult
to 
fruitfully make the case that, on the national level, South African 
society was primarily being distorted by class inequities.  

The history of South Africa can only be relativized by comparison
with 
the city of New Brunswick in such a way, therefore.  And the unique 
problems of a small American city can only be rendered less clear and 
coherent by such a distorting comparison.  So I guess I'm suggesting
to 
be awfully careful before making dramatic comparisons that are only 
very superficially valid.  

Also, while I'm at it, accusing the Targum of conspiring with the 
Democratic Party might not be the best idea, even if it's really not 
meant literally.  If there is a kind of seige mentality on the part
of 
the editorial board, saying things to reinforce it will probably do
no 
particular good.  If there are two or three sympathetic individuals
out 
of five or six people on the board, those people will probably feel
far 
less justified in standing up for the campaign if they and their 
colleagues are accused of being someone else's pawns.  Convince me 
otherwise, of course, but I think there's a good deal of truth to
this.

TTYL,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:673
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-04 17:10:44
Subject:Voter reg forms
Message:

Does anyone have the time to go down to Trenton and pick up voter reg forms.  This is the last weekend to register to vote.  The County office is giving out photocopied forms, which cannot be mailed in, which means that fewer can be distributed since we have to wait to get them ourselves! Please, if there is someone who isn't already full to the brim let us know.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
275 Seventh Ave, 6th Floor
T: 212-414-9306
F: 212-414-9002

Matt,

Sorry, I guess I wrote too much.  I was taking a break from writing a 
paper for a few minutes.  Whatever.  

I should've simply stated that one ought not to relativize Apartheid.
That's all I was saying.  But I didn't mean that people shouldn't 
take risks or try to make creative rhetorical gestures.  Sorry if my 
rant seemed imposing.  

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:676
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-05 04:50:01
Subject:Possible Quip
Message:

While I'm sitting here in the computer lab ...

Tomorrow's (today's, actually) Targum, if the online edition is a 
proper reflect of what's going to appear in print (sometimes it 
isn't), has an article about how the city is promoting "National Walk 
to School Day"

http://www.dailytargum.com

Now, I remember hearing that NB high school students do not receive 
any kind of bus pass to ride local public transportation for free -- 
despite NBHS being all the way down Livingston Ave.  I remember 
hearing that students actually have to pay out of their own pockets
if 
they want to take public transportation.  If this is indeed true ... 
well, someone could really have fun with this one.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:677
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-05 09:10:05
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Possible Quip
Message:

Parents are currently clamoring for transport after school and b/w the  Health Sciences Tech HS and the HS (the Health Sciences HS has limited after-school opportunities).  The BOE claims a crisis in bus drivers is the problem, although in August they werent planning to transport students from the Health Sciences Tech HS to the HS.  Also, when it was suggested that they solve the bus driver situation by advertising to local residents via the schools, which would permit better access to better-paying jobs, Larkin stated (in the Sept BOE meeting) that he didnt want NB residents who currently are not aware of these opportunities as bus drivers of our children.

The school district has also been found not helpful in informing parents of their rights to Middlesex County transportation for disabled or injured students.

Not only that but the City administration is receiving state/federal funds for public transportation and they are planning to use it to fund buses for Rutgers students and for commuters, a targeted approach to using federal funds that could likely be the target of a class-action suit (in addition to all the others we could do if there were enough pro-bono lawyers to go around).

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
275 Seventh Ave, 6th Floor
T: 212-414-9306
F: 212-414-9002

>>> <jagross@...> 10/05 4:50 AM >>>

any kind of bus pass to ride local public transportation for free -- 
despite NBHS being all the way down Livingston Ave.  I remember 
hearing that students actually have to pay out of their own pockets
if 
they want to take public transportation.  If this is indeed true ... 
well, someone could really have fun with this one.
