-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:680
Sender:Kathleen Kuehn <kstar@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-05 10:24:37
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Yesterday's Letter
Message:

Hello.

I am unsubscribing myself to this listserve, and want everyone to know it
not because I think you'll miss me but because its your responsibility to
know.  Its you responsibility because your ridiculous and unprogressive
bickering has given me a tainted view of the People's Campaign that I
desparatly want to have faith in.  And I also know that I'm not the only
one who feels this way.  The Targum noted that you are all idealistic and
this makes you unfit to run a political position.  I disagree
wholeheartedly with that statement.  However, I'm beginning to think that
perhaps those BEHIND  the people running for the 3 positions are just not
mature enough to run part of the city government.  I'm not sure if you
realize that all this pettiness--which it often has come to be--is
disheartening because the PCC has put SO MUCH EFFORT into being taken
seriously by the people...and its THIS "forum" that is ruining the idea
for people like me.  I can look at your newsletter and feel like, "now
this is something I want to see happen, something I want to support."  But
having been on this listserve completely contradicts those feelings.  I am
sure you all still have my vote, but know that some people might be more
discouraged than myself and not take you seriously from all this petty
bickering and unecessary/unapplicable bullcrap contained in the 20
something waste of letters I get a day. (The amount which could greatly be
reduced if you would start replying to one another, instead of to the
entire list, over things that concern no one but the 2 parties involved.)

And I say all this to hopefully open your eyes to the perspective from a
student community memeber, not to bash you or the way you handle your
personal politics because you take care of that well enough on your own.

I would like to think I'm standing in solidarity with you (and now,
someone please take the time to ask me & the entire listserve if I know
what that means), and that you will take my perspective to heart.

Best of luck to you all, I know you intentions are good but I just can't
stand all of these unpertinent, discouraging  messages anymore.

Thanks,

Kathleen Kuehn

********************************
General Manager
88.7 WRSU-fm, New Brunswick
732.932.7800 ex.25

> organize the whole damn town. This is war, man. Paul

>

> >
> >Paul,
> >

> >mean no major disrespect; but I think certain claims ought not to be

> >prior to the 1980's, was a Totalitarian state.  There were countless
> >different 'racial' categories officially, brutally enforced by the
> >state.  Mobility, the right to work in a given area, the right to
> >live
> >in a given area, was rigidly regulated according to one's official
> >place in the white / coloured / Indian / Black hierarchy.
> >
> >I should also point out that any analysis of the city of New
> >Brunswick
> >must note that 'race' must be considered somewhat less primary to the
> >city's social and political ills than class.  It's really difficult
> >to
> >fruitfully make the case that, on the national level, South African
> >society was primarily being distorted by class inequities.
> >
> >The history of South Africa can only be relativized by comparison
> >with
> >the city of New Brunswick in such a way, therefore.  And the unique
> >problems of a small American city can only be rendered less clear and
> >coherent by such a distorting comparison.  So I guess I'm suggesting
> >to
> >be awfully careful before making dramatic comparisons that are only
> >very superficially valid.
> >
> >Also, while I'm at it, accusing the Targum of conspiring with the
> >Democratic Party might not be the best idea, even if it's really not
> >meant literally.  If there is a kind of seige mentality on the part
> >of
> >the editorial board, saying things to reinforce it will probably do
> >no
> >particular good.  If there are two or three sympathetic individuals
> >out
> >of five or six people on the board, those people will probably feel
> >far
> >less justified in standing up for the campaign if they and their
> >colleagues are accused of being someone else's pawns.  Convince me
> >otherwise, of course, but I think there's a good deal of truth to
> >this.
> >
> >TTYL,
> >
> >Jeremy
> >
> >
> 
> _________________________________________________________________________
> Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
> 
> Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
> http://profiles.msn.com.
> 
> 
> To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@...
> 
> To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@...
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:681
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-05 10:45:08
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Yesterday's Letter
Message:

Wow!  Kathleen, I hope that you're not turned off to independent politics in 
general. In response, I have to point out that several particulars exist on 
the egroup that don't represent the campaign as a whole.

First, most of the work of the campaign does not take place on it. The work 
takes place in face-to-face contact with people, winning them over to our 
move towards democracy.

Second, most people associated with the campaign don't check out the egroup. 
They either don't have access to the internet or they don't care.

Third, the egroups have long been a stomping ground for some people who 
don't do much work, some people who wish to advocate sloth as a political 
line, and yet other people whose online behavior differs drastically from 
their in-person behavior (they have internet muscles).

I hope you'll reconsider your doubt in the PC and please give me a call 
anytime @729-0873 and I would be glad to speak to you about any of these 
things.

Paul McGee, PC


>From: Kathleen Kuehn <kstar@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: Re: [nbpc] Yesterday's Letter
>Date: Thu, 5 Oct 2000 10:24:37 -0400 (EDT)
>
>Hello.
>
>I am unsubscribing myself to this listserve, and want everyone to know it
>not because I think you'll miss me but because its your responsibility to
>know.  Its you responsibility because your ridiculous and unprogressive
>bickering has given me a tainted view of the People's Campaign that I
>desparatly want to have faith in.  And I also know that I'm not the only
>one who feels this way.  The Targum noted that you are all idealistic and
>this makes you unfit to run a political position.  I disagree
>wholeheartedly with that statement.  However, I'm beginning to think that
>perhaps those BEHIND  the people running for the 3 positions are just not
>mature enough to run part of the city government.  I'm not sure if you
>realize that all this pettiness--which it often has come to be--is
>disheartening because the PCC has put SO MUCH EFFORT into being taken
>seriously by the people...and its THIS "forum" that is ruining the idea
>for people like me.  I can look at your newsletter and feel like, "now
>this is something I want to see happen, something I want to support."  But
>having been on this listserve completely contradicts those feelings.  I am
>sure you all still have my vote, but know that some people might be more
>discouraged than myself and not take you seriously from all this petty
>bickering and unecessary/unapplicable bullcrap contained in the 20
>something waste of letters I get a day. (The amount which could greatly be
>reduced if you would start replying to one another, instead of to the
>entire list, over things that concern no one but the 2 parties involved.)
>
>And I say all this to hopefully open your eyes to the perspective from a
>student community memeber, not to bash you or the way you handle your
>personal politics because you take care of that well enough on your own.
>
>I would like to think I'm standing in solidarity with you (and now,
>someone please take the time to ask me & the entire listserve if I know
>what that means), and that you will take my perspective to heart.
>
>Best of luck to you all, I know you intentions are good but I just can't
>stand all of these unpertinent, discouraging  messages anymore.
>
>Thanks,
>
>Kathleen Kuehn
>
>********************************
>General Manager
>88.7 WRSU-fm, New Brunswick
>732.932.7800 ex.25
>
>
>
>
>
>
>  On Wed, 4 Oct 2000, Paul McGee wrote:
>
> > I said "... more like Soweto, SA than a center of business ..." not 
>'exactly
> > like'.  And they printed it on top of the editorial page, so they must 
>have
> > liked it.  I think I was a little too easy on them. Feed off that while 
>we
> > organize the whole damn town. This is war, man. Paul
> >
> >
> > >From: jagross@...
> > >Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
> > >To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
> > >Subject: [nbpc] Yesterday's Letter
> > >Date: Wed, 04 Oct 2000 19:00:43 -0000
> > >
> > >
> > >Paul,
> > >
> > >Let me just offer a few comments about your letter to the Targum.  I
> > >mean no major disrespect; but I think certain claims ought not to be
> > >made.  This would go to anyone seeking to defend the Campaign or
> > >articulate its possible virtues.
> > >
> > >First, you cannot rightly compare Soweto to New Brunswick.  The
> > >problems with New Brunswick are deeply, qualitatively different.  I
> > >think it's fair to say that South Africa under Apartheid, especially
> > >prior to the 1980's, was a Totalitarian state.  There were countless
> > >different 'racial' categories officially, brutally enforced by the
> > >state.  Mobility, the right to work in a given area, the right to
> > >live
> > >in a given area, was rigidly regulated according to one's official
> > >place in the white / coloured / Indian / Black hierarchy.
> > >
> > >I should also point out that any analysis of the city of New
> > >Brunswick
> > >must note that 'race' must be considered somewhat less primary to the
> > >city's social and political ills than class.  It's really difficult
> > >to
> > >fruitfully make the case that, on the national level, South African
> > >society was primarily being distorted by class inequities.
> > >
> > >The history of South Africa can only be relativized by comparison
> > >with
> > >the city of New Brunswick in such a way, therefore.  And the unique
> > >problems of a small American city can only be rendered less clear and
> > >coherent by such a distorting comparison.  So I guess I'm suggesting
> > >to
> > >be awfully careful before making dramatic comparisons that are only
> > >very superficially valid.
> > >
> > >Also, while I'm at it, accusing the Targum of conspiring with the
> > >Democratic Party might not be the best idea, even if it's really not
> > >meant literally.  If there is a kind of seige mentality on the part
> > >of
> > >the editorial board, saying things to reinforce it will probably do
> > >no
> > >particular good.  If there are two or three sympathetic individuals
> > >out
> > >of five or six people on the board, those people will probably feel
> > >far
> > >less justified in standing up for the campaign if they and their
> > >colleagues are accused of being someone else's pawns.  Convince me
> > >otherwise, of course, but I think there's a good deal of truth to
> > >this.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:683
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-05 12:51:16
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Yesterday's Letter
Message:

Dear Kathleen,

I am sorry to hear that you are unsubscribing from the listserve. I can only 
emphasize the fact that this egroup does not by any stretch represent the 
heart of the campaign. As Paul pointed out, most people in the Campaign 
don't have access to a computer, never mind the internet. These electronic 
discussions tend to include only those dozen or so individuals who have 
unlimited access to the net while at work, school, etc.

However, an important aspect to consider is the fact that we are a united 
front campaign. While this phrase is tossed around often enough, it's true 
meaning, I think, is really hard for me, personally, and i'm sure for 
others, to truly grasp. We are a coalition of many people with many 
DIFFERENT ideas and ways of going about things (or not, for that matter). 
Disagreement and sometimes hostility is a natural byproduct of the often 
complicated process of united action.

I have chosen to disregard entirely those people whose only contribution to 
this Campaign has been to send out nasty, demoralizing, and less than subtle 
insults about the Campaign, the platform, the candidates, the organizers, 
participating organizations, etc. I agree, it gets tiring to read these 
tirades, especially when none of the main critics will be found at a general 
Campaign meeting on the last Saturday of the month.

However, for EVERYONE ELSE this listserve has been beneficial in that it is 
a wonderful opportunity to share ideas, commendation, stories, and even 
criticism. Criticism is a healthy thing, I believe, so long as it is 
conducted with respect and positivity.

And so, again, I'm sorry to have you go. However, please don't take this to 
heart. It's true that none of us have run City government before (!), but I 
am confident that the spirit and passion that drives this Campaign (as we 
fight against every obstacle imaginable) will be a guiding force in driving 
New Brunswick forward.

In Unity,
Kristina Bas, Treasurer

> > >society was primarily being distorted by class inequities.

> > >with

Post ID:686
Sender:Julie Poulos <juliepoulos@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-06 07:59:22
Subject:Ladies' night
Message:

Hey All Ladies,

Funky Ladies' Night was supposed to be at 218 townsend tonight.  But,
I'm very sorry, we cannot have it at 218.  If we'd like to reschedule
(which I personally would, since no one really knew about tonight, and
I have the LSAT's tomorrow;)  cool.  Otherwise, we must find another
venue.  Sorry about the last minute/inconvenience.  It's just we've had
craziness at our house every weekend for the last month and a half, and
when I talked with my roommates we all felt we needed a weekend off. 
I'll be happy to make calls or whatever is necessary when I get home
from work.  But someone needs to make a decision as to what is
happening. Again, I'm sorry, Gals.  

Julie

Post ID:689
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-06 19:12:59
Subject:Re: Eisenman Article
Message:

Dear Mr Hernandez, et al:   I fowarded the edited article and note to the 
legal staff, as I said, to avoid last minute surprises, not to ask it to be 
edited again by any other than the Vector staff.  I am frankly growing weary 
of this excercise.  I am struggling to discern genuine attempts to "make 
better journalists" and efforts to stifle my column.  This is now going into 
the third week of defending my writing, and it is extraordinarily 
disconcerting.  I have said it again and again:  the information is correct, 
etc.  I can't imagine any other article for the Vector that has gotten this 
sort of treatment.  I really don't want to take this any further.  I am 
asking once and for all that the article be printed next week, reflecting 
the careful edits that I have already made to comply with your requests.



>From: "Roger E. Hernandez" <rogereh@...>
>To: "Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>, "Vector Keerti" 
><kkc2216@...>,   "Vector Frank" <fjo8185@...>, 
><the.vector@...>
>Subject: Re: Eisenman Article
>Date: Fri, 6 Oct 2000 18:48:33 -0400
>
>Hello everybody, some comments:
>
>1)-I still think that the part about "Franco Spaniards" is gratuitous. If 
>you,
>Matthew, want to make a point about that association then make it explicit,
>don't beat around the bush. Even if you put in quotes you are still 
>insinuating
>something instead of coming right out with it.
>
>2)-In the second paragraph this says, "...deconstructivist luminary, Peter
>Eisenman.  No need for introduction..."  Well, I think there _is_ a need 
>for an
>introduction. I don't know who this guy is and will guarantee you that, 
>aside
>from architecture majors, few at NJIT will know him either. So....I advise 
>that
>you put in a sentence or two explaining that he is a well known, 
>controversial
>architect (if that is indeed the case,) or whatever he is. To merely say he 
>is a
>"deconstructivist luminary" just isn't enough info for your readers to
>understand who this person is & why you are writing these things about him. 
>They
>more context to make sense of what you are saying.
>
>3)- I made a few mechanical/grammatical/usage suggestions below. But PLEASE 
>do
>not think I have formally copy-edited the column. That's up to you guys.
>
>4)- Please be 100% sure that everything here is 100% accurate.
>
>5)-You need to further document what you say about people being "shocked,
>dismayed, and nearly up in arms."  What people? How did they show their 
>shock
>and dismay? Did they picket? Write letters to the editor? And when did this
>happen? Just a couple of sentences will do.
>
>6)- You say the architect "seemed betrayed, and made the case that we, the
>people, were just not ready for such a vision." How do you know this? In 
>what
>forum did he make this response?
>
>REH
>
>
>
>4)- I want to help you guys make good journalistic decisions and become 
>better
>writers and editors, but I don't think it is appropriate for writers to 
>send me
>stories before they are edited by a Vector staffer. I am making an 
>exception
>here, because I have already seen a previous version of the piece and 
>because
>it's already here in my mailbox. But think about it: For me to respond 
>directly
>to Matthew without going through Francisco or Keerti puts me in the 
>position of
>being the editor of the Vector rather than the advisor. And this is your
>newspaper, not mine.
>
>REH
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
>To: <the.vector@...>
>Cc: <rogereh@...>
>Sent: Friday, October 06, 2000 12:49 PM
>Subject: Eisenman Article
>


I wrote to Keerti & Prof. Hernandez, Vector legal adviser:
>
>Keerti- Here is the final draft.  I edited it for clarity, hopefully to 
>your
>satisfaction.  The beginning reflects the end, and I no longer address Mr.
>Eisenman directly .  All of the claims are factual, and I am able to back
>everything up with newspaper articles, the lecture video, and witnesses if
>necessary.  "Franco Spaniard" is in quotes, to stress that is not an
>'insinuation', rather Mr. Eisenman's own statement.  I am also fowarding
>this to Mr. Hernandez, so that there are no last minute surprises.  To be
>sure, there is no personal vendetta here.  Merely a desire to take a
>principled stand on an important issue.
>
>Thanks for your time, Matthew Smith
>
>
>The Student�s Pen vs. the Master�s Sword
>
>In the mysterious world of architecture, there are those individuals who,
>like rock stars, become blinded by the light of their own success.   
>Blinded
>to a fundamental principle that ought to guide every design: the needs of
>the people who must interact with that architect�s creation.
>
>This said, I would like to clear up some unresolved business:
>Last spring, the School of Architecture at NJIT was graced with the 
>presence
>of a Newark native and deconstructivist luminary, Peter Eisenman.  No need
>for introduction�accept YOU MEAN "EXCEPT'?? to relay my first personal 
>encounter
>with him:  He
>began his lecture in Weston Lecture Hall by ordering 350 of us to all put
>our pens down; further, that HE SAID THAT if anyone didn�t comply he would
>embarrass them
>by forcing them to leave.  Nice.
>
>I imagine that most people complied because his talk went on
>uninterrupted�even when he casually mentioned that one of his clients is a
>�Franco Spaniard� (in German, that�s called a Nazi), but I digress.  My
>initial impulse was to tighten my grip on my pen and hold on for dear life.
>I can�t remember if it was initially an act of resistance or shock.  But
>regardless, as my indignation settled into clarity of purpose, my one
>thought was: the moment somebody orders you to put down the pen�the
>mightiest of weapons�you politely ask where he would like you to stick it.
>And then you start writing down his reaction so that everyone else knows 
>how
>the story went.
>
>It was an unspoken test of wills.  Sitting in full view of our orator, 
>front
>row, right-of-center, pen in hand, note book in full view, scratching
>thoughts down here and there�not to snatch his words out of the air and
>claim them as my own, which I guess was his concern (frankly I don�t find
>much practical use for his ideas).   What I was jotting down was the
>question that I wanted to raise during the Q&A session.   If you�re
>wondering, Mr. Eisenman didn�t stop the lecture to single me out for exile.
>What he did was much more insidious.  He refused to take my question.  And
>there�s no doubt in my mind that of all the waving hands, he accidentally
>missed just mine.  Well, O.K.  Now I will raise my question, this time with
>the luxury of preface.
>
>Mr. Eisenman appeared New Brunswick, NJ, where I was living, a little over 
>a
>year ago with a design concept commissioned by the City and sponsored by 
>the
>Rutgers� arts school.   It was an inflated student center & 10,000 seat
>sports arena for Rutgers University.  The design was predictably
>unpredictable�a sinewy, curvilinear, formless form.  Only, it was not set 
>on THE
>Rutgers campus, but directly on top of an entire struggling downtown
>community�sparing the church�which was already over-stressed by the
>�revitalization� that still threatens to ethnically cleanse their block
>next, making way for the return of the well-to-do �white-flighters.�  When
>the morning newspaper came out with a three page spread on his plan, folks
>were shocked, dismayed, and nearly up in arms.  The outrage only subsided
>when the city bosses, who had commissioned this work, distanced themselves
>from the concept by claiming that they never intended to build it.  They
>claimed it was merely a whimsical exploration of intellectual experiment.
>Our architect seemed betrayed, and made the case that we, the people, were
>just not ready for such a vision.
>
>So my question is as it was last spring: What is the architect�s
>responsibility to the community in which his buildings are to exist?
>This needs to be addressed, because too often architecture neglects the 
>very
>people whose lives are imposed upon by the invisible hand of the architect.
>It�s not that the people of New Brunswick �didn�t get it,� as Eisenman
>insinuated.  It�s because he apparently didn�t spend the time to get them.
>I believe it is the job of the architect to go down to the community to 
>find
>out its needs, its struggles, its desires.  The architect should be a 
>public
>servant, not a lord.  There are real people whose real lives exist in that
>ethereal space between the architect�s vision and the bulldozers brought in
>to clear the way for its realization.
>
>From my pen to you-
>Matthew R. Smith, Student
>NJ School of Architecture at NJIT
>
>_________________________________________________________________________
>Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
>
>Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
>http://profiles.msn.com.
>
>

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:690
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-12 17:06:24
Subject:it's time to spread the word...
Message:

can anyone think of other publications or media outlets that I can forward 
this message to??? it's time to spread the word, folks, and get as much 
coverage as possible....


>From: "kristina bas" <krisbas@...>
>To: jnichols@...
>Subject: New Brunswick People's Campaign
>Date: Thu, 12 Oct 2000 20:43:50 GMT
>
>Hello Mr. Nichols,
>
>I have been keeping up with your series in The Nation, and I feel that it's 
>time to call your attention to an unprecedented grassroots campaign that is 
>taking place not too far from New York City.
>
>I refer to the city of New Brunswick, in Middlesex County, New Jersey. The 
>city is a unique mixture of college town (home of Rutgers University)and 
>corporate headquarters (Johnson & Johnson, Robert Wood Johnson, etc.), with 
>a signficant industrial, working-class base. The last ten years have seen 
>the systematic and often brutal transformation of the town, under the 
>guidance of the so-called "New Brunswick Tomorrow" development group, from 
>an urban, working-class enclave to a yuppie-centric, mini-Princeton.
>
>This city houses a large percentage of African-Americans (largely working 
>class and poor) and Latinos. These people, along with the white middle and 
>working class folks, have been victimized by what we believe is the ethnic 
>cleansing of this town: the widespread decimation of public housing, the 
>near collapse of the public school system, and the scandalous history of 
>police abuse/misconduct.
>
>It was in the midst of these conditions that we gave birth to the People's 
>Campaign. It consists of a multi-national united front of concerned 
>individuals: middle-class landlords, artists, students, trade unionists, 
>communists, greens, liberals, and even Republicans. We are united by our 
>desire to challenge the Democratic Party machine that has ruled the town 
>for decades and to begin to build a government controlled by the working 
>people.
>
>Three city council seats will be up for grabs in the upcoming general 
>election. The Campaign held a massive convention last May, during which 
>three candidates were elected: a Mexican-American, an African-American, and 
>a Euro-American. We voted on a seventeen point platform, calling for (among 
>other things) publicly funded child care, a civilian police control board, 
>and a public women's center.
>
>We have worked steadily on this campaign since last January, and have 
>gained tremendous momentum. Our campaign now consists of nearly one hundred 
>activists, youths, and local residents!
>
>We stand an excellent chance of winning these seats in November. History 
>will be made on that day, regardless of the outcome, because, to my 
>knowledge, this is the first time in many years that a united front, 
>grassroots effort, with no Party-backing or institutional support has posed 
>such a significant threat to an entrenched city machine.
>
>I would like to call your attention, Mr. Nichols, to the events now 
>transpiring in New Brunswick so that we can spotlight the campaign 
>nationally. We would like very much to outreach to other grassroots 
>movements, to learn from each other, and to form, ultimately, a national 
>movement to demand real democracy (people's democracy) in this country.
>
>I would love to talk with you further about the campaign and to share our 
>platform with you. This is an exciting and historic time that deserves 
>state-wide and national support.
>
>Thanks for your time, and I look forward to hearing from you.
>
>In Unity,
>Kristina Bas
>Treasurer & Fundraising Chair
>
>(732) 369-0759 home
>(732) 690-3368 cell
>

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:691
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-12 17:27:29
Subject:Re: [nbpc] it's time to spread the word...TELL YOUR FRIENDS
Message:

Please dont forget to highlight the elected school board in these endeavors.

THIS IS CRITICAL AND INTEGRAL TO THE MACHINES HOLD ON THIS TOWN.  I FIND OUT MORE EVERY DAY AND WE MUST FIGHT STRONGLY TO HAVE THE BALLOT Q PASSED.

The city is spreading lies that an elected board will raise taxes.  The district themselves and the NJ School Board Assn has confirmed with me that it cannot.  School tax rates are solely dependent upon the city assessment value, since the tax levy is fixed for an Abbott v Burke district.

The city says that an elected school board will bring patronage.  We already have it.  The mayor appoints people who already have jobs with the city, who wont speak up to the Mayor and who cover for administrators; Larkin and Latimer appoint their friends to administration positions; council people are allowed to override hiring processes internal to the district, and principals chosen by these false hiring processes can determine who sits on the school management teams that are now to control the schools.

And corruption?  I know of people who will get fired if they told of the moneys that have been absorbed by administrators.

The worst is that there is a gag on all those who know anything.  They know whats going on b/c they are involved, and if they tell they wont be able to be involved any more, or they will be fired. Kudos to the parents who have gotten involved despite all and are willing to speak up and be heard, and to those leaders and teachers who are supporting us in secret. We have had a long hard road to walk together.

The mayor is holding private meetings at private schools like St. Mary's with his executive staff present (including the planning director Glen Paterson) to promote the appointed board to possibly interested parrents and to actively oppose the initiative.  If you were to go to one of these meetings, having been invited by another parent, it is likely that after 2 minutes you would be asked to leave and escorted out the door with a threat by an individual who refused to identify himself, as happened to me. The  parents who support us cant even let us come speak at a PTA meeting.

Finally, those who work for the city and in the BOE must either keep mum and/or participate actively for the machine.  I have spoken to people who support us but cannot come out because of their jobs, even if they work in the kitchen.

Anyone who needs or wants details come speak to me in person.

AND

SPREAD THE WORD!!

Zofia

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
275 Seventh Ave, 6th Floor
T: 212-414-9306
F: 212-414-9002

>>> "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...> 10/12 5:06 PM >>>
can anyone think of other publications or media outlets that I can forward 
this message to??? it's time to spread the word, folks, and get as much 
coverage as possible....


>From: "kristina bas" <krisbas@hotmail.com>
>To: jnichols@... 
>Subject: New Brunswick People's Campaign
>Date: Thu, 12 Oct 2000 20:43:50 GMT
>
>Hello Mr. Nichols,
>
>I have been keeping up with your series in The Nation, and I feel that it's 
>time to call your attention to an unprecedented grassroots campaign that is 
>taking place not too far from New York City.
>
>I refer to the city of New Brunswick, in Middlesex County, New Jersey. The 
>city is a unique mixture of college town (home of Rutgers University)and 
>corporate headquarters (Johnson & Johnson, Robert Wood Johnson, etc.), with 
>a signficant industrial, working-class base. The last ten years have seen 
>the systematic and often brutal transformation of the town, under the 
>guidance of the so-called "New Brunswick Tomorrow" development group, from 
>an urban, working-class enclave to a yuppie-centric, mini-Princeton.
>
>This city houses a large percentage of African-Americans (largely working 
>class and poor) and Latinos. These people, along with the white middle and 
>working class folks, have been victimized by what we believe is the ethnic 
>cleansing of this town: the widespread decimation of public housing, the 
>near collapse of the public school system, and the scandalous history of 
>police abuse/misconduct.
>
>It was in the midst of these conditions that we gave birth to the People's 
>Campaign. It consists of a multi-national united front of concerned 
>individuals: middle-class landlords, artists, students, trade unionists, 
>communists, greens, liberals, and even Republicans. We are united by our 
>desire to challenge the Democratic Party machine that has ruled the town 
>for decades and to begin to build a government controlled by the working 
>people.
>
>Three city council seats will be up for grabs in the upcoming general 
>election. The Campaign held a massive convention last May, during which 
>three candidates were elected: a Mexican-American, an African-American, and 
>a Euro-American. We voted on a seventeen point platform, calling for (among 
>other things) publicly funded child care, a civilian police control board, 
>and a public women's center.
>
>We have worked steadily on this campaign since last January, and have 
>gained tremendous momentum. Our campaign now consists of nearly one hundred 
>activists, youths, and local residents!
>
>We stand an excellent chance of winning these seats in November. History 
>will be made on that day, regardless of the outcome, because, to my 
>knowledge, this is the first time in many years that a united front, 
>grassroots effort, with no Party-backing or institutional support has posed 
>such a significant threat to an entrenched city machine.
>
>I would like to call your attention, Mr. Nichols, to the events now 
>transpiring in New Brunswick so that we can spotlight the campaign 
>nationally. We would like very much to outreach to other grassroots 
>movements, to learn from each other, and to form, ultimately, a national 
>movement to demand real democracy (people's democracy) in this country.
>
>I would love to talk with you further about the campaign and to share our 
>platform with you. This is an exciting and historic time that deserves 
>state-wide and national support.
>
>Thanks for your time, and I look forward to hearing from you.
>
>In Unity,
>Kristina Bas
>Treasurer & Fundraising Chair
>
>(732) 369-0759 home
>(732) 690-3368 cell
>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:694
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-13 10:41:20
Subject:Legislation to get involved in
Message:

From: 	<jaydmedia@...>
To:	NYC7.GWIA("contingent-org@...","jaydmed...
Date: 	Fri, Oct 13, 2000  9:13 AM
Subject: 	[contingent-org] FYI: NJ Bill Targets Illegitimate Employment Agencies 

*************************************************
This message sent via the contingent-org listserv
*************************************************
The Star-Ledger 

                                     October 12, 2000, Thursday 
HEADLINE: New Jersey Bill Targets Illegitimate Employment Agencies 

BYLINE: By Steve Chambers 


    When the Puerto Rican Congress opened a nonprofit temp agency 18 months 
ago in Lakewood, it planned to offer a "living wage" for working-class 
clients and eventually get them into full-time jobs. 

But in recent months, the organization has run into competition from out of 
the state, as vanloads of Cambodian immigrants are ferried into Monmouth and 
Ocean counties from Philadelphia, where wages hover just around the legal 
minimum. 

"We lost a chance to place 15 workers recently because the employer told us 
to negotiate our prices lower," said Lydia Valencia, executive director of 
PRC Temps. "But we pay taxes, we provide workmen's compensation, the whole 
nine yards." 

Legitimate temp agencies and unions around the state have long complained 
that they face unfair competition from unscrupulous labor providers that pay 
exploitive wages and fail to withhold taxes. 

Legislation being introduced today in Trenton attempts to crack down on this 
shadowy underground that some experts say may keep 200,000 workers off the 
books. 

The legislation, sponsored by Assembly Labor Committee Chairman George Geist 
(R-Gloucester), would spread the responsibility for withholding payroll taxes 
to the companies contracting with temp agencies. It also would strengthen the 
licensing laws, making it difficult for temp agencies to work in New Jersey 
without seeking the proper approvals. 

Observers said they are pleased that the state has finally taken action 
against what they term an explosive underground economy, but some remain wary 
of the state's ability to back up legislation with strict enforcement. 

"This sounds like a good first step," said Lee Seglem of the State Commission 
of Investigation. "It's a tough and intractable problem, with social aspects 
and economic aspects but also fairness aspects. We are most concerned about 
how widespread this rip-off of tax money is that is being siphoned out of the 
public stream." 

An exhaustive study three years ago by the SCI found rampant violations of 
the withholdings laws in several southern New Jersey food processing plants. 
Investigators determined that temp agencies, mostly from Philadelphia, were 
ferrying in hundreds of employees in vans and pocketing millions of dollars. 

Barrie Peterson, associate director of Seton Hall University's Institute on 
Work, said the state has done little to police this burgeoning industry of 
largely immigrant workers, who he said are often exploited. At the same time, 
the rise of informal temp agencies has led to a huge increase in the number 
of commuter vans on the highways, vehicles that police say are often unsafe. 

"I'm encouraged that they are finally looking at this," Peterson said. 
"Hopefully it's a first step at righting some of the injustices out there and 
protecting the public interest." 

Geist acknowledged that the legislation may face opposition from employers 
who profit handsomely from the cheap labor and also are able to keep consumer 
prices low. 

"I recognize we are rocking the boat," he said. "Now that the legislation is 
being introduced, we shall see what we shall see." 

Responding to concerns by some southern New Jersey temp agencies that the 
legislation could amount to empty promises, Geist pledged to make sure the 
necessary enforcement dollars are sought and approved. 

The bill would require the state Division of Consumer Affairs to pursue cases 
against temp agencies that fail to win licenses and pull the licenses of 
companies that don't withhold proper taxes. 


Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
275 Seventh Ave, 6th Floor
T: 212-414-9306
F: 212-414-9002





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:695

office, little notes, emails, etc.  We in the field need to know any 
relevant stuff.   Paul


>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: Re: [nbpc] it's time to spread the word...TELL YOUR FRIENDS
>Date: Thu, 12 Oct 2000 17:27:29 -0400

>Please dont forget to highlight the elected school board in these 
>endeavors.

>THIS IS CRITICAL AND INTEGRAL TO THE MACHINES HOLD ON THIS TOWN.  I FIND 
>OUT MORE EVERY DAY AND WE MUST FIGHT STRONGLY TO HAVE THE BALLOT Q PASSED.

>The city is spreading lies that an elected board will raise taxes.  The 
>district themselves and the NJ School Board Assn has confirmed with me that 
>it cannot.  School tax rates are solely dependent upon the city assessment 
>value, since the tax levy is fixed for an Abbott v Burke district.
>
>The city says that an elected school board will bring patronage.  We 
>already have it.  The mayor appoints people who already have jobs with the 
>city, who wont speak up to the Mayor and who cover for administrators; 
>Larkin and Latimer appoint their friends to administration positions; 
>council people are allowed to override hiring processes internal to the 
>district, and principals chosen by these false hiring processes can 
>determine who sits on the school management teams that are now to control 
>the schools.

>And corruption?  I know of people who will get fired if they told of the 
>moneys that have been absorbed by administrators.
>
>The worst is that there is a gag on all those who know anything.  They know 
>whats going on b/c they are involved, and if they tell they wont be able to 
>be involved any more, or they will be fired. Kudos to the parents who have 
>gotten involved despite all and are willing to speak up and be heard, and 
>to those leaders and teachers who are supporting us in secret. We have had 
>a long hard road to walk together.
>
>The mayor is holding private meetings at private schools like St. Mary's 
>with his executive staff present (including the planning director Glen 
>Paterson) to promote the appointed board to possibly interested parrents 
>and to actively oppose the initiative.  If you were to go to one of these 
>meetings, having been invited by another parent, it is likely that after 2 
>minutes you would be asked to leave and escorted out the door with a threat 
>by an individual who refused to identify himself, as happened to me. The  
>parents who support us cant even let us come speak at a PTA meeting.
>
>Finally, those who work for the city and in the BOE must either keep mum 
>and/or participate actively for the machine.  I have spoken to people who 
>support us but cannot come out because of their jobs, even if they work in 
>the kitchen.
>
>Anyone who needs or wants details come speak to me in person.
>
>AND
>
>SPREAD THE WORD!!
>
>Zofia
>
>Zofia Nowakowski
>Fiscal Policy Institute
>275 Seventh Ave, 6th Floor
>T: 212-414-9306
>F: 212-414-9002
>
> >>> "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...> 10/12 5:06 PM >>>
>can anyone think of other publications or media outlets that I can forward
>this message to??? it's time to spread the word, folks, and get as much
>coverage as possible....
>
>
> >From: "kristina bas" <krisbas@...>
> >To: jnichols@...
> >Subject: New Brunswick People's Campaign
> >Date: Thu, 12 Oct 2000 20:43:50 GMT
> >
> >Hello Mr. Nichols,
> >
> >I have been keeping up with your series in The Nation, and I feel that 
>it's
> >time to call your attention to an unprecedented grassroots campaign that 
>is
> >taking place not too far from New York City.
> >
> >I refer to the city of New Brunswick, in Middlesex County, New Jersey. 
>The
> >city is a unique mixture of college town (home of Rutgers University)and
> >corporate headquarters (Johnson & Johnson, Robert Wood Johnson, etc.), 
>with
> >a signficant industrial, working-class base. The last ten years have seen
> >the systematic and often brutal transformation of the town, under the
> >guidance of the so-called "New Brunswick Tomorrow" development group, 
>from
> >an urban, working-class enclave to a yuppie-centric, mini-Princeton.
> >
> >This city houses a large percentage of African-Americans (largely working
> >class and poor) and Latinos. These people, along with the white middle 
>and
> >working class folks, have been victimized by what we believe is the 
>ethnic
> >cleansing of this town: the widespread decimation of public housing, the
> >near collapse of the public school system, and the scandalous history of
> >police abuse/misconduct.
> >
> >It was in the midst of these conditions that we gave birth to the 
>People's
> >Campaign. It consists of a multi-national united front of concerned
> >individuals: middle-class landlords, artists, students, trade unionists,
> >communists, greens, liberals, and even Republicans. We are united by our
> >desire to challenge the Democratic Party machine that has ruled the town
> >for decades and to begin to build a government controlled by the working
> >people.
> >
> >Three city council seats will be up for grabs in the upcoming general
> >election. The Campaign held a massive convention last May, during which
> >three candidates were elected: a Mexican-American, an African-American, 
>and
> >a Euro-American. We voted on a seventeen point platform, calling for 
>(among
> >other things) publicly funded child care, a civilian police control 
>board,
> >and a public women's center.
> >
> >We have worked steadily on this campaign since last January, and have
> >gained tremendous momentum. Our campaign now consists of nearly one 
>hundred
> >activists, youths, and local residents!
> >
> >We stand an excellent chance of winning these seats in November. History
> >will be made on that day, regardless of the outcome, because, to my
> >knowledge, this is the first time in many years that a united front,
> >grassroots effort, with no Party-backing or institutional support has 
>posed
> >such a significant threat to an entrenched city machine.
> >
> >I would like to call your attention, Mr. Nichols, to the events now
> >transpiring in New Brunswick so that we can spotlight the campaign
> >nationally. We would like very much to outreach to other grassroots
> >movements, to learn from each other, and to form, ultimately, a national
> >movement to demand real democracy (people's democracy) in this country.
> >
> >I would love to talk with you further about the campaign and to share our
> >platform with you. This is an exciting and historic time that deserves
> >state-wide and national support.
> >
> >Thanks for your time, and I look forward to hearing from you.
> >
> >In Unity,
> >Kristina Bas
> >Treasurer & Fundraising Chair
> >
> >(732) 369-0759 home
> >(732) 690-3368 cell
> >
>
>_________________________________________________________________________
>Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
>

>http://profiles.msn.com.

Subject:words of inspiration
Message:

hey everyone:

i found this quote on the front page of the New Jersey Election Law 
Enforcement Commission's web site. Despite the irony, it sure is applicable 
to our situation....

"And a people who mean to be their own governors, must arm themselves with 
the power that knowledge brings."

James Madison (1822)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:697
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-13 22:12:41
Subject:Re: it's time to spread the word...
Message:

Kris,

While I'm taking a little break here ... The following publications 
strike me as maybe appropriate:

There's In These Times and the Progressive, maybe Mother Jones.  All 
three are somewhat Nation-like, but a little more populist,
especially 
The Progressive.  Mother Jones is very into corporate expose type 
pieces.  And there's always Z Magazine, which is a little more 
centered on a few personalities (Edward Said and Noam Chomsky), but 
pretty activist-minded, as you might be aware.  There's also The 
Village Voice.  I'm uncertain what the deal is with UNITE, but I'll 
bet they have some sort of monthly newsletter or magazine, as do many 
unions.  There is also Salon magazine, which is perhaps a little too 
mainstream, but worth a quick solicitation.  Maybe the Green Party
has 
a newletter or magazine-sized publication of its own?  igc.net or 
igc.com or igc.org, one of those, is a good resource if you're
looking 
for publications to contact.   

This is just a suggestion, but you might want to add some ideas into 
the letter as to what broader, New Jersey-wide or nationally relevant 
issues or movements the Campaign is relevant to, or illustrative of.  
For example, someone writing a piece on school funding, school
reform, 
or public education in New Jersey (given our now fairly famous state 
supreme court decision on funding) could easily look to the push for 
an Elected School Board.  Or, it's not difficult to imagine someone 
writing an article on Johnson and Johnson, or perhaps discussing 
Johnson and Johnson from a 'corporate welfare' angle.  You get the 
idea.  And, of course, with the Nader campaign, there's lots of
people 
writing articles on anything that goes by the name of 'independent 
grassroots politics'.  (That's probably how the language in your 
letter about 'a movement for real democracy / people's democracy'
will 
be interpreted, in any case, by most people who read it)     

TTYL,

Jeremy

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:699
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-16 09:58:16
Subject:More
Message:

OK, Paul - 

The Oct 2000 City glossy newsletter has just been distributed promoting our school system.  This means City money is being used against the elected school board question.  The mayor is boasting about the groundbreaking at Lord Stirling (15 yrs in the making) and the high school test scores.  One teacher pointed out to me that getting decent grades on the high school tests is easy - by 11th grade, many kids have dropped out, gone into special ed programs, and gone off to vocational schools.  Looking at the 8th grade test scores may give us a better picture of how our school system is doing.  In fact, none of the 8th grade valedictorians or salutatorians got a passing grade on the 8th grade standardized reading tests!

Post ID:700
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-16 12:05:28
Subject:Matthew's new address, ph#, etc.
Message:

Friends & Comrades,  The time of moving is past.  Tracey and I have wearily, 
yet happily landed at our new apartment, in a historic district of restored 
brownstones behind the Newark Museum & Library.  Things seemed to be closing 
in on us the last morning of our 14 months on Clinton Ave, when we went to 
my car to pick up the U-Haul, and all that was left was a pile of window 
glass and a breeze!  Tough Luck, but a new start, and only a few blocks from 
NJIT!  Here goes:

73 Clinton Ave, 2nd flr, Newark, NJ 07102
(973) 824-2949

-Matthew Smith

Post ID:704
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-18 13:37:02
Subject:need help!
Message:

hello, this is a request for assistance from anyone who has a FAST 
computer...

on the web site, www.elec.state.nj.us you will find links that allow you to 
view single and joint candidate committee reports from the various elections 
throughout the state of new jersey. these are the campaign finance reports 
that list the where, who, and how much behind campaign contributions.

i have been trying to download the 28-day preelection reports for the 
Recine, Schrum, and Cook joint candidate committee for the upcoming general 
election. this report was filed last week. however, in order to view the 
reports, you must download a convoluted array of strange programs. I don't 
have a fast enough computer (dial-up, blah!) to download these programs (6K 
in size), so i haven't been able to access the reports.

If i order the reports via the ELEC office, it will cost money.

so, i'm putting out the call for anyone with a DSL or cable modem to try to 
get these reports for me. it shouldn't take too much time. Instructions for 
the download are located on www.elec.state.nj.us/download.htm

can anyone help?? getting this report would be very useful to us....

please let me know,

thanks much,
Kristina
(harried campaign treasurer)

NATIONAL DAY OF PROTEST - NYC MARCH TO STOP POLICE BRUTALITY, REPRESSION
AND THE CRIMINALIZATION OF A GENERATION, March organized against police
brutality by the October 22 Coalition.  Wear black in protest and solidarity
with the struggle against police brutality.
Sunday October 22, 1 p.m.
Look for the NOW-NYC banner and our delegation at the protest assembly at
1:00 p.m. at Union Square (14th St. & Broadway).  March ends at rallying
point in Times Square at 3:30 p.m.

Post ID:706
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-19 13:57:24
Subject:Quick note
Message:

Hi,

If you look at today's Targum, there's an article about the RCGA 
discussing whether to host a city council debate; there were some odd 
remarks about how having the People's Campaign participate would
raise 
security concerns about having a "rowdy audience".  Struck me as a 
very odd remark, not so subtle coded bias against _something_. I
think 
the article said, however, that it was ultimately resolved to host 
such a debate.  But it also said that the person on the RCGA who was 
worried about 'security issues' had spoken to the Democrats, and they 
had told him that they would never debate the People's Campaign.

I don't remember it with perfect clarity; it should prove an 
interesting read to anyone concerned:

www.dailytargum.com 
(Thursday issue)





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:707
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-20 09:56:57
Subject:election day update!
Message:

Enjoy!

-kristina


From Today's New Jersey Star-Ledger

New Brunswick incumbents reject debate

10/20/00

BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

The three New Brunswick Democratic councilmen up for re-election yesterday 
backed out of an Oct. 30 debate against three independents running as the 
People's Campaign.


The Rutgers College Governing Association, a nonpartisan group of Rutgers 
student leaders, organized the debate. But talks with the Democrats fell 
apart when they unilaterally declined the invitation, said Alex Goldmark of 
the association.


People's Campaign candidate Keith Joseph, who is running on a slate for city 
council with Curtis Warren and Diego Morales, criticized the Democrats' 
decision.


"It's really a stifling of the discussion," Joseph said. "A debate 
encourages discussion of different ideas in the city. Right now you have one 
voice in power, the Democrats."


Two of the incumbent Democratic candidates, Joseph Schrum and Robert Recine, 
have not returned phone calls to explain why they would not debate.


The third, Jimmie Cook, said he did not know the invitation had been turned 
down since their campaign manager, assistant city attorney T.K. Shamy, is 
handling such matters.


"I think that the candidates' records speak for themselves. I don't think 
there's any profit to a debate from the public's perspective," Shamy said.


With a major money advantage, the Democrats may have decided they do not 
need to debate. As of Oct. 10 they raised $25,900, mainly in contributions 
over $300. By contrast, the People's Campaign has raised just $8,959, mainly 
in contributions of less than $300.


Rhodia Inc., the French chemical company fending off a lawsuit for its 
alleged pollution of a Raritan River tributary, contributed $400 to the 
Democrats. The New Jersey Carpenters political committee gave them $1,000, 
as did David Samuel, an engineer with CME Associates, and Matrix Realty, a 
group planning an office complex on George Street. The Wilentz, Goldman & 
Spitzer law firm gave them $800.


People's Campaign organizers said they were fighting the financial 
disadvantage with legwork. For example, they deliver all of their literature 
by hand, not through the mail.


"When we raise money it's a heart and soul kind of thing," said Kristina 
Bas, the People's Campaign treasurer. "The truth of the matter is you can't 
buy popular support."


But the disadvantage is even more daunting than it appears. The New 
Brunswick Democratic Committee has $10,109 on hand with which it can help 
the candidates, according to the committee's most recent report. The annual 
Democratic dinner/dance takes place at the New Brunswick Hyatt Regency on 
Sunday, and another fund-raiser is scheduled at the Elks Lodge next 
Thursday.


And the People's Campaign is trying to wage two campaigns with their modest 
coffers -- they are fighting to switch the city board of education from a 
body appointed by the mayor to one elected by residents.


A Democrat-linked group -- the Committee to Keep Politics Out of Our Schools 
-- has raised $9,540 to keep a mayoral-appointed school board. All of that 
money has come in contributions under $300.


By law, contributions less than $300 do not have to be itemized, so small 
contributors can remain anonymous.


Joseph said that is a selling point for People's Campaign contributors -- 
such as local small businesses -- who do not wish to be on the record 
opposing the party in power.


"If they donate less than $300 they can remain anonymous and not face 
retaliation," Joseph said.


Glen Fleming, who is running as an independent and calling his campaign 
Reform Our City, did not report having raised any money on his most recent 
campaign-finance reports, but he said since those were filed he has raised 
up to $1,000.


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or (732) 634-1236.


_________________________________________________________________________

http://profiles.msn.com.

>>
>>"I think that the candidates' records speak for themselves. I don't think
>>there's any profit to a debate from the public's perspective," Shamy said.
>>
>>
>>With a major money advantage, the Democrats may have decided they do not
>>need to debate. As of Oct. 10 they raised $25,900, mainly in contributions
>>over $300. By contrast, the People's Campaign has raised just $8,959,
>>mainly in contributions of less than $300.
>>
>>
>>Rhodia Inc., the French chemical company fending off a lawsuit for its
>>alleged pollution of a Raritan River tributary, contributed $400 to the
>>Democrats. The New Jersey Carpenters political committee gave them $1,000,
>>as did David Samuel, an engineer with CME Associates, and Matrix Realty, a
>>group planning an office complex on George Street. The Wilentz, Goldman &
>>Spitzer law firm gave them $800.
>>
>>
>>People's Campaign organizers said they were fighting the financial
>>disadvantage with legwork. For example, they deliver all of their
>>literature by hand, not through the mail.
>>
>>
>>"When we raise money it's a heart and soul kind of thing," said Kristina
>>Bas, the People's Campaign treasurer. "The truth of the matter is you
>>can't buy popular support."
>>
>>
>>But the disadvantage is even more daunting than it appears. The New
>>Brunswick Democratic Committee has $10,109 on hand with which it can help
>>the candidates, according to the committee's most recent report. The
>>annual Democratic dinner/dance takes place at the New Brunswick Hyatt
>>Regency on Sunday, and another fund-raiser is scheduled at the Elks Lodge
>>next Thursday.
>>
>>
>>And the People's Campaign is trying to wage two campaigns with their
>>modest coffers -- they are fighting to switch the city board of education
>>from a body appointed by the mayor to one elected by residents.
>>
>>
>>A Democrat-linked group -- the Committee to Keep Politics Out of Our
>>Schools -- has raised $9,540 to keep a mayoral-appointed school board. All
>>of that money has come in contributions under $300.
>>
>>
>>By law, contributions less than $300 do not have to be itemized, so small
>>contributors can remain anonymous.
>>
>>
>>Joseph said that is a selling point for People's Campaign contributors --
>>such as local small businesses -- who do not wish to be on the record
>>opposing the party in power.
>>
>>
>>"If they donate less than $300 they can remain anonymous and not face
>>retaliation," Joseph said.
>>
>>
>>Glen Fleming, who is running as an independent and calling his campaign
>>Reform Our City, did not report having raised any money on his most recent
>>campaign-finance reports, but he said since those were filed he has raised
>>up to $1,000.
>>
>>
>>Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at
>>alane@... or (732) 634-1236.
>>
>>
>>_________________________________________________________________________
>>Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
>>
>>Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
>>http://profiles.msn.com.
>
>

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:712
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-23 09:37:54
Subject:BOK BOK, This time for real
Message:


           Dems accused of evading debate

           Published in the Home News Tribune 10/23/00

           By RON GEORGE
           STAFF WRITER

           NEW BRUNSWICK: Hoping to stir Democrats into meeting for a 
debate, members of the People's Campaign
           protested at last night's Democratic fund-raiser at the Hyatt 
Regency New Brunswick hotel with a man dressed in a
           chicken costume.

           People's Campaign candidates Curtis L. Warren and Keith Joseph, 
along with Frank Bright, the chairman of the New
           Brunswick Republican Party -- wearing an oversized chicken 
costume, making clucking noises and flapping his "wings"
           -- and about a dozen children paraded along the Neilson Street 
entrance carrying signs asking Democrats what they
           had to hide.

           Protesters were in full view of attendees of the event as they 
drove into the hotel's parking deck.

           Joseph, Warren and Diego Morales constitute the ticket of the 
grass-roots organization that will challenge Democrats
           Jimmie Cook, Jr., Robert Recine and Joseph Schrum in next month's 
elections. No Republican has entered the race.
           Glen J. Fleming is running for office under the Reform Our City 
party.

           "There is no debate in New Brunswick," said Joseph. "They are 
trying to escape democracy. They are trying to skirt
           the issues. The Democrats said they are running on their record 
and that it speaks for itself. Well, it doesn't speak for
           the majority of New Brunswick residents."

           Joseph said the Democrats, who control city government, are 
"chickening out" of debating the upstart organization.

           But Schrum said there was no formal agreement or ground rules 
set. He dismissed the oppositions claim the debates
           were not held because the People's camp was not a recognized 
party.

           Schrum said in the past, New Brunswick debates have included 
third and independent party candidates.

           The Rutgers College Governing Association, a nonpartisan group of 
Rutgers student leaders, had scheduled a debate
           for Oct. 30, but talks with the Democrats fell apart.

           Schrum reiterated the Democrats position of running on their 
records and would not comment on the protest that was
           being waged outside.

           He didn't acknowledge protesters who, using a bull-horn, shouted 
at him to engage in a debate as he walked into the
           hotel.

           "I'll tell you what they are afraid of," said Warren. "They don't 
want to answer what happened to the $3.5 million from
           the school budget, they don't want to answer about housing and 
jobs and the ethnic cleansing that is going on under the
           guise of redevelopment."

           The People's Campaign candidates don't have all the answers, but 
we are willing to stand before the people and
           answer questions," Warren added.

           A state Local Government Budget Review of the 1997 school budget 
revealed areas where the district could have
           $3.5 million in savings.

           The People's Party is also campaigning to switch the city board 
of education from a body appointed by the mayor to
           one elected by residents.

           Ron George: (732) 246-5500, Ext. 7347.

           from the Home News Tribune

           Published: October 23, 2000

           Go Back
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:713
Sender:"Paul McGee" <pmcgee@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-24 11:30:56
Subject:Fw: Crime Alert or 'profiling at RU'
Message:

This could be a thousand different people. This is irresponsible in the very
least and demonstrates the RUPD policy used to enforce segregation between
campus and city....


----- Original Message -----
From: "Anthony Murphy" <anmurphy@...>
To: <CRIME_ALERT@...>
Sent: Tuesday, October 24, 2000 9:10 AM
Subject: Crime Alert - Armed Robbery


> The Rutgers University Police and the New Brunswick Police are
> investigating an armed robbery that occurred at the corner of George and
> Seminary Sts at approximately 9:45Pm on 23 October 2000.  Three female
> Rutgers University students were walking along George St when a vehicle
> containing three males subjects stopped alongside them.  Two of the
> subjects exited the vehicle and engaged the victims in conversation.
> One of the subjects produced a handgun and demanded money from the
> victims.  The subjects grabbed a purse from one of the victims and fled
> from the scene in a small four-door  black vehicle believed to be either
> a Nissan or Hyundai.  The victims were not injured during this incident.
>
> The subjects involved in this robbery are believed to be responsible for
> three similar type robberies that have occurred in New Brunswick over
> the past two days.
>
> Suspect Description:
>
> Number of Suspects: 3
> Sex:  Male
> Race:  Black
> Age: 19 - 20 years of age
> Height:  6'0"
> Weight:  Unknown
> Clothing: Dark blue or black clothing
>
> Anyone with information regarding this robbery are encouraged to contact
> the Rutgers University Police at 732-932-7212.
>

Subject:E-Day Preparations - Forward to all lists

What we've all been waiting for -

a concrete thing we can do to make a difference.

Join the New Brunswick Peoples Campaign in our....

COUNT-DOWN TO E-DAY

ORGANIZING MEETING FOR ELECTION DAY
NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLES CAMPAIGN

SATURDAY, OCT 28, 2PM
NEW BRUNSWICK PUBLIC LIBRARY

Help take New Brunswick back
from the few corrupt, inbred powermongers.
Expand democratic expression -
elected school board, planning board,
civilian police review board....
Economic development for residents,
not the big corporations - RWJ, JJ, RU.
Stop the City from stopping the building of
affordable housing through zoning changes,
bureaucratic review...

Find out what role you and those you know can play
on this most critical day of the year.

This is it, folks! There is not much time left till Nov. 7th.

Any amount of your time is valuable - from flyering or talking to your 
neighbors, to canvassing, phone banking, and working with us for election 
day.

Contact us if you can't make the meeting but would like to help out:

(732) 545-5756
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
149 Redmond Street

VOTE WARREN JOSEPH MORALES FOR CITY COUNCIL

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:716
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-24 12:42:42
Subject:VOTER INFO - ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD Q - FORWARD TO ALL LISTS
Message:

Please pass this info on the elected school board question on to all 
possible lists.
It is based on a compilation of parents and teachers comments.

Why we should vote YES! for an Elected School Board
Commitee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign

Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and it 
has this year).  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million 
because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke).  
Therefore, the amount of taxes we must raise locally depends on our property 
assessments - something only City Hall can influence, yet under the current 
appointed system, the school board cannot comment on or critique City Hall's 
approach - because the board of education is elected.
Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or 
decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole responsibility 
of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board 
members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of 
Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.

Vote Yes and Stop Patronage
The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.  They 
have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search 
committees' recommendations and hired less than competent appointees.  This 
has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our education 
system.
Without fear of repercussions or public accountability, the superintendent 
has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  Not 
surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a computer 
based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a 
friend of the superintendent himself.

Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even 
absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, federal 
parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick 
parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and 
our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also 
estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went 
further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City 
purposes, not the school district!

Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That is 
why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly on 
mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include 
taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen have 
all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the 
district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of 
reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not publicly 
speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because they 
face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and denial 
of services to their children.

Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct 
control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 in 
which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how 
the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned residents.  
The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session 
that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of 
participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents, 
teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns 
are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open 
public debate.

Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional vehicle 
for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the integrity 
of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students graduate 
from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and in 
March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th grade 
reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the 
hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology High 
School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for its 
high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.

Points to ponder:

1. Dr Larkin addressing parents, June BOE mtg:  If you dont like the 
education system in New Brunswick, send your kids somewhere else!

2. Mayor Chahill has organized private, invitation-only meetings with  his 
top staff (city planner, fire chief) to oppose the measure, HOSTED by a 
PRIVATE SCHOOL, St Mary's!

3. The Mayors attorney has argued against clarifying the ballot question 
because it would be too clear, and people would not be forced to read the 
interpretive statement.

4. The elected school board is endorsed by the New Jersey Education 
Association and the Home News Tribune.

5. Parents and teachers who know of abuses within the system are afraid to 
go public, since it would place their jobs at stake, or they would be 
excluded from leadership positions in the schools, or they are afraid their 
children would receive poorer services (YES!)

For more info (and there is more),

contact: Zofia Nowakowski
Committee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
(732) 545-5756
znowakow@...

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:717
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-24 13:05:37
Subject:UPDATED VOTER INFO - ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD Q - FORWARD TO ALL LISTS
Message:

Please pass this voter info on the elected school board question in New Brunswick on to all 
possible lists.
It is based on a compilation of parents and teachers comments.

Why we should vote YES! for an Elected School Board
Committee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign

Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and it 
has this year).  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million 
because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke) and the state pays the rest.  
Therefore, the rate of taxation for the school district depends on our property 
assessments - something only City Hall can influence, yet under the current 
appointed system, the school board cannot comment on or critique City Hall's 
approach - because the board of education is appointed by the mayor.
Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or 
decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole responsibility 
of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board 
members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of 
Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.

Vote Yes and Stop Patronage
The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.  They 
have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search 
committees' recommendations and hired less than competent appointees.  This 
has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our education 
system.
Without fear of repercussions or public accountability, the superintendent 
has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  Not 
surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a computer 
based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a 
friend of the superintendent himself.

Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even 
absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, federal 
parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick 
parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and 
our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also 
estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went 
further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City 
purposes, not the school district!

Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That is 
why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly on 
mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include 
taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen have 
all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the 
district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of 
reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not publicly 
speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because they 
face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and denial 
of services to their children.

Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct 
control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 in 
which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how 
the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned residents.  
The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session 
that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of 
participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents, 
teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns 
are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open 
public debate.

Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional vehicle 
for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the integrity 
of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students graduate 
from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and in 
March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th grade 
reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the 
hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology High 
School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for its 
high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.

Points to ponder:

1. Dr Larkin addressing parents, June BOE mtg:  "If you dont like the 
education system in New Brunswick, send your kids somewhere else!"

2. Mayor Cahill has organized private, invitation-only meetings with  his 
top staff (city planner, fire chief) to oppose the measure, HOSTED by a 
PRIVATE SCHOOL, St Mary's!

3. The Mayors attorney has argued in court against clarifying the ballot question (which does not refer to elected or appointed, just NJSA statute numbers)
because it would be TOO CLEAR, and people would not be forced to read the 
interpretive statement.

4. The elected school board is endorsed by the New Jersey Education 
Association and the Home News Tribune.

5. Parents and teachers who know of abuses within the system are afraid to 
go public, since it would place their jobs at stake, or they would be 
excluded from leadership positions in the schools, or they are afraid their 
children would receive poorer services (YES!)

For more info (and there is more),

contact: Zofia Nowakowski
Committee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
(732) 545-5756
znowakow@...
