Post Date/Time:2000-10-24 16:04:07
Subject:[ru_ignite] Caellian deadline this Thursday! Election issue! (fwd)
Message:


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 15:57:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Charlotte L. Kates <ckates@...>
To: w_d_c@egroups.com, caellian@..., starc-rutgers@egroups.com,
     nbpc@egroups.com, ru_ignite@egroups.com
Subject: [ru_ignite] Caellian deadline this Thursday! Election issue! 

Hi, everyone! 

The Caellian's next issue, to be published on November 1, will focus on
elections, politics and voting. If you have something to say, if you want
to support a candidate, oppose a candidate, discuss the meaning of voting
or not voting, or otherwise comment on elections (or anything else, for
that matter), please submit! 

The deadline is this Thursday, October 26. Please submit articles to
ckates@.... Also, we meet Mondays at 9 PM on the third floor
of the Douglass College Center--get involved! 

Charlotte Kates 
(eic, the caellian)



Free Mumia!

Post ID:719
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-24 11:27:57
Subject:VOTER INFORMATION ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD - PLEASE FORWARD TO ALL LISTS
Message:

VOTER INFORMATION

Please transmit further to all possible email lists. People must be informed 
on this most critical ballot issue in New Brunswick.

Why we must vote YES! for an Elected Board of Education
in New Brunswick
Committee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign

Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and it 
has this year)!  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million 
because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke), and 
the state pays the difference.  Therefore, the amount of taxes we must raise 
locally depends on our property assessments � something only City Hall can 
influence, yet under the current appointed system, the school board cannot 
comment on or critique City Hall's approach � because the board of education 
is elected.
Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or 
decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole responsibility 
of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board 
members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of 
Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.

Vote Yes and Stop Patronage
The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.  They 
have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search 
committees' recommendations and hired less than competent appointees.  This 
has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our education 
system.
Without fear of repercussions or public accountability, the superintendent 
has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  Not 
surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a computer 
based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a 
friend of the superintendent himself.

Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even 
absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, federal 
parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick 
parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and 
our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also 
estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went 
further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City 
purposes, not the school district!

Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That is 
why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly on 
mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include 
taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen have 
all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the 
district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of 
reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not publicly 
speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because they 
face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and denial 
of services to their children.

Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct 
control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 in 
which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how 
the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned residents.  
The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session 
that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of 
participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents, 
teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns 
are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open 
public debate.

Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional vehicle 
for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the integrity 
of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students graduate 
from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and in 
March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th grade 
reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the 
hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology High 
School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for its 
high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.

Additional questions to ask yourself and food for thought:

1.  What does it mean when the Superintendent can say to concerned parents 
at a board of ed meeting:
"If you don't like the school system in New Brunswick, send your kids 
somewhere else!"

2.  What does it mean when the Mayor organizes private invitation including 
his top administrative staff such as the City Planner and Fire Chief, only 
meetings to promote the local school system HOSTED AT A PRIVATE SCHOOL, St. 
Mary's?

3.  What does it mean when the City's attorney argues in court against 
rewording the ballot question by saying it would make it so clear, readers 
would no longer be forced to look at the interpretive statement to 
understand the question?

4.  What does it mean when this info has been gathered from a network of 
anonymous parents and teacher leaders, who are afraid of the repercussions 
on their jobs and positions when the mayor-appointed administration finds 
out they support this initiative?

YES! for an elected board of education is endorsed by the New Jersey 
Education Association and the main local newspaper, the Home News Tribune.

For more info (and there is more), contact:
Zofia Nowakowski
Committee for an Elected School Board
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
znowakow@...
(732) 729-1087
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:720
Sender:JimmyFishHead@...
Post Date/Time:2000-10-25 08:39:38
Subject:Election day question.
Message:

Hey all,
    An acquaintance of mine in local government mentioned to me that most 
fraudulent voting is done via absentee ballot.  A recommendation was to have 
someone check the list of death certificates in New Brunswick over the last 4 
years to the absentee ballots to make sure this isn't happening.  Is someone 
already looking into this?  Thought I would pass the information along.
Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:721
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-25 14:16:58
Subject:Re: one point on the excellent Bd of Ed letter.
Message:

Zofia, This is great writing with new and important facts, but there is one 
small point that I think needs clarification for those not familiar with the 
issue.

In the third sentence, you say the board can't comment on the cause of tax 
increases because it's 'elected', instead of 'appointed'. I'm sending this 
to the list because I don't know how far and wide it's been spread. I think 
it's worth clarifying. Paul


>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpc] VOTER INFORMATION ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD - PLEASE FORWARD TO 
>ALL LISTS
>Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 11:27:57 EDT
>
>VOTER INFORMATION
>
>Please transmit further to all possible email lists. People must be 
>informed
>on this most critical ballot issue in New Brunswick.
>
>Why we must vote YES! for an Elected Board of Education
>in New Brunswick
>Committee for an Elected School Board
>New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
>
>Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
>Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and it
>has this year)!  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million
>because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke), and
>the state pays the difference.  Therefore, the amount of taxes we must 
>raise
>locally depends on our property assessments � something only City Hall can
>influence, yet under the current appointed system, the school board cannot
>comment on or critique City Hall's approach � because the board of 
>education
>is elected.
>Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or
>decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole responsibility
>of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board
>members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of
>Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.
>
>Vote Yes and Stop Patronage
>The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.  
>They
>have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search
>committees' recommendations and hired less than competent appointees.  This
>has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our education
>system.
>Without fear of repercussions or public accountability, the superintendent
>has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  Not
>surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a 
>computer
>based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a
>friend of the superintendent himself.
>
>Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
>Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even
>absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, federal
>parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick
>parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and
>our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also
>estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went
>further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City
>purposes, not the school district!
>
>Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
>New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That is
>why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly 
>on
>mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include
>taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
>Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen have
>all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the
>district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of
>reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not publicly
>speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because they
>face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and denial
>of services to their children.
>
>Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
>583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct
>control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 in
>which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how
>the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
>The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned residents.
>The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session
>that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of
>participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents,
>teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns
>are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open
>public debate.
>
>Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
>The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional vehicle
>for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the 
>integrity
>of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students graduate
>from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and 
>in
>March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th grade
>reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the
>hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology High
>School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for its
>high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.
>
>Additional questions to ask yourself and food for thought:
>
>1.  What does it mean when the Superintendent can say to concerned parents
>at a board of ed meeting:
>"If you don't like the school system in New Brunswick, send your kids
>somewhere else!"
>
>2.  What does it mean when the Mayor organizes private invitation including
>his top administrative staff such as the City Planner and Fire Chief, only
>meetings to promote the local school system HOSTED AT A PRIVATE SCHOOL, St.
>Mary's?
>
>3.  What does it mean when the City's attorney argues in court against
>rewording the ballot question by saying it would make it so clear, readers
>would no longer be forced to look at the interpretive statement to
>understand the question?
>
>4.  What does it mean when this info has been gathered from a network of
>anonymous parents and teacher leaders, who are afraid of the repercussions
>on their jobs and positions when the mayor-appointed administration finds
>out they support this initiative?
>
>YES! for an elected board of education is endorsed by the New Jersey
>Education Association and the main local newspaper, the Home News Tribune.
>
>For more info (and there is more), contact:
>Zofia Nowakowski
>Committee for an Elected School Board
>New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
>znowakow@...
>(732) 729-1087
>_________________________________________________________________________
>Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
>
>Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
>http://profiles.msn.com.
>
>
>
>To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@...
>
>To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: 
>nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@...
>

_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:722
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>

Subject:[nbpc] Re: one point on the excellent Bd of Ed letter.
Message:

Thanks.  Yes, Im sorry I should have been more clear.  The second email I sent "Update" contained that correction.

Zofia

>>> "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...> 10/25 2:16 PM >>>

increases because it's 'elected', instead of 'appointed'. I'm sending this 
to the list because I don't know how far and wide it's been spread. I think 
it's worth clarifying. Paul

>Subject: [nbpc] VOTER INFORMATION ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD - PLEASE FORWARD TO 
>ALL LISTS
>Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 11:27:57 EDT

>informed
>on this most critical ballot issue in New Brunswick.

>in New Brunswick
>Committee for an Elected School Board
>New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
>
>Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
>Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and it
>has this year)!  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million
>because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke), and
>the state pays the difference.  Therefore, the amount of taxes we must 
>raise
>locally depends on our property assessments  something only City Hall can
>influence, yet under the current appointed system, the school board cannot
>comment on or critique City Hall's approach  because the board of 
>education
>is elected.
>Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or
>decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole responsibility
>of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board
>members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of
>Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.

>The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.

>have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search

>has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our education
>system.

>has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  Not
>surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a 
>computer
>based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a
>friend of the superintendent himself.
>
>Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
>Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even
>absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, federal
>parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick
>parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and
>our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also
>estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went
>further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City
>purposes, not the school district!
>
>Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
>New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That is
>why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly 
>on
>mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include
>taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
>Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen have
>all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the
>district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of
>reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not publicly
>speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because they
>face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and denial
>of services to their children.

>Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
>583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct
>control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 in
>which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how
>the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
>The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned residents.
>The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session
>that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of
>participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents,
>teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns
>are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open
>public debate.
>
>Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
>The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional vehicle
>for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the 
>integrity
>of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students graduate
>from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and 
>in
>March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th grade
>reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the
>hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology High
>School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for its
>high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.

>

>at a board of ed meeting:
>"If you don't like the school system in New Brunswick, send your kids
>somewhere else!"

>his top administrative staff such as the City Planner and Fire Chief, only
>meetings to promote the local school system HOSTED AT A PRIVATE SCHOOL, St.
>Mary's?
>

>rewording the ballot question by saying it would make it so clear, readers
>would no longer be forced to look at the interpretive statement to
>understand the question?

>on their jobs and positions when the mayor-appointed administration finds

Post ID:723
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-25 14:40:11
Subject:TALK UP $25MM FACTS AND SHORT COUNCIL MEETINGS!!
Message:

FYI, I got the updated version but then received another copy of the first, 
this time with the subject in all caps.

EVERYBODY--THIS AGITATION WORKS! WE'RE GETTING STRONG RESPONSES FROM MILDLY 
INTERESTED PEOPLE OVER THE THREE AND SEVEN MINUTE CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS!!

Overall, though, really good info, I used the 25mm cap point at almost every 
door i knocked on last night and got a great response. I also would like 
more details on that-is there an original document put out by the city 
explaining that, or something. The other point that's been working really 
well with people is the debate rejection along with telling people how long 
(short) the last two city council meetings have been. I say '3 and 7 
minutes, respectively', and people get mad. It works.  Keep up the 
circulation of ideas and info.  CHARGE TO VICTORY!!!!!

ANYONE WHO CAN CANVASS FOR ONE,TWO,THREE HOURS ON ANY DAY B4 EDAY-CALL THE 
OFFICE. WE'RE GOING OUT EVERY DAY AND WE'RE KICKING ASS.

PEOPLE ARE BUGGING OUT IN ANTICIPATION THAT WE'RE GOING TO CHANGE THIS CITY. 
PEOPLE WANT MEETINGS IN THEIR NEIGHBORHOODS. THEY WANT ACTION THEY WANT 
CHANGE. WE'RE MAKING IT HAPPEN. SEE YOU ON THE STREET! PAUL

>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com

Post ID:724
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-25 14:55:30
Subject:Re: [nbpc] TALK UP $25MM FACTS AND SHORT COUNCIL MEETINGS!!
Message:

OK, the 2 sources on the cap info are - Mr. Jannerone (sp?) of NB Public Schools and Bob Albert of the NJ School Board Association (who knows a bunch re Abbott districts) confirmed this statement, and I questioned it 2 x with each of them, restating it over again.  Neither when asked whether and how the cap would change thought that it would, although this might be a q for someone who has the time to take it beyond these folks to Mr. Hespe at the State level.

Zofia

>>> "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...> 10/25 2:40 PM >>>

this time with the subject in all caps.

>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>

>Subject: [nbpc] Re: one point on the excellent Bd of Ed letter.

>sent "Update" contained that correction.

> >>> "Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...> 10/25 2:16 PM >>>
>Zofia, This is great writing with new and important facts, but there is one
>small point that I think needs clarification for those not familiar with 
>the
>issue.

>it's worth clarifying. Paul

>
> >From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@hotmail.com>
> >Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com 
> >To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com 
> >Subject: [nbpc] VOTER INFORMATION ELECTED SCHOOL BOARD - PLEASE FORWARD 
>TO
> >ALL LISTS
> >Date: Tue, 24 Oct 2000 11:27:57 EDT
> >

> >
> >Please transmit further to all possible email lists. People must be
> >informed
> >on this most critical ballot issue in New Brunswick.
> >
> >Why we must vote YES! for an Elected Board of Education
> >in New Brunswick
> >Committee for an Elected School Board
> >New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
> >
> >Vote Yes and Stop High Taxes
> >Only City Hall can currently raise taxes for the Board of Education (and 
>it
> >has this year)!  Our locally-paid school budget is fixed at $25 million
> >because New Brunswick is an Abbott School District (Abbott v. Burke), and
> >the state pays the difference.  Therefore, the amount of taxes we must
> >raise
> >locally depends on our property assessments v something only City Hall 
>can
> >influence, yet under the current appointed system, the school board 
>cannot
> >comment on or critique City Hall's approach v because the board of
> >education
> >is elected.
> >Under the current appointed board only the Board of Estimate increases or
> >decreases the budget.  Any budget increase has been the sole 
>responsibility
> >of the Mayor, 2 city council people, and 2 mayor-appointed school board
> >members (who make up the Board of Estimate).  With an elected Board of
> >Education there will be no budget increase without voter approval.
> >
> >Vote Yes and Stop Patronage
> >The hiring of principals is completely under the control of City Hall.
> >They
> >have been allowed to override the Board of Education's own search
> >committees' recommendations and hired less than competent appointees.  
>This
> >has caused 'teacher flight' and compromised the integrity of our 
>education
> >system.
> >Without fear of repercussions or public accountability, the 
>superintendent
> >has forced schools to pay for and implement his educational programs.  
>Not
> >surprisingly, these programs, like the Sequoyah Literacy Program (a
> >computer
> >based literacy program) have been rumored to sold to the district by a
> >friend of the superintendent himself.
> >
> >Vote Yes and Stop Corruption
> >Under the current system, school money has been poorly allocated or even
> >absorbed by administrators in areas including the theatrical arts, 
>federal
> >parent training programs, and technology labs.  Meanwhile, New Brunswick
> >parents are vastly underrepresented in national training conferences, and
> >our students receive fewer opportunities.  The state of New Jersey also
> >estimated that $3.5M was wasted in the local school budget.  They went
> >further to state City Hall wrongly used $1M of district money for City
> >purposes, not the school district!
> >
> >Vote Yes and Keep City Hall Politics out of our Schools
> >New Brunswick Board of Education is not independent of City Hall.  That 
>is
> >why the superintendent and the Board of Education cannot comment publicly
> >on
> >mayoral policies that affect the school district.  Such policies include
> >taxes, facilities development, transportation, and youth recreation.
> >Everyone's scared to talk.  Board of Education employees by the dozen 
>have
> >all voiced serious concerns about the Board's competency to run the
> >district.  However, no one is willing to go on record, stating fear of
> >reprisals by administrators.  Teachers were even instructed to not 
>publicly
> >speak about the issue in faculty meetings.  Parents won't talk because 
>they
> >face exclusion from leadership committees, and the stigmatizing and 
>denial
> >of services to their children.
> >
> >Vote Yes and Get Accountability and Respect
> >583 out of the 602 school districts in New Jersey are under the direct
> >control of the people of that district.  New Brunswick is one of the 19 
>in
> >which politicians control who is on the Board of Education, where and how
> >the money is spent, and how much taxes should be collected.
> >The Board of Education meetings are not accessible to concerned 
>residents.
> >The real decisions are made prior to the public meeting in closed session
> >that often runs well past the time working parents are capable of
> >participating.  Then they repeatedly disregard the input of parents,
> >teachers, and residents during the supposed public session.  Key concerns
> >are often resolved privately after the meeting, which discourages open
> >public debate.
> >
> >Vote Yes and Regain Control of the Quality of Public Education
> >The Mayor has used our school district continually as a promotional 
>vehicle
> >for the redevelopment of New Brunswick while he has undermined the
> >integrity
> >of our school system.  The plain truth is only 46% of our students 
>graduate
> >from High School, only 37% take the SAT's, there is no Middle School, and
> >in
> >March of 2000 no 8th grade valedictorians passed the Standardized 8th 
>grade
> >reading and language arts test (the G.E.P.A,).  The district supports the
> >hiring of private, non-union staff for the Health Sciences Technology 
>High
> >School and Early Childhood Program through a private company known for 
>its
> >high staff turnover rates in New Brunswick.
> >
> >Additional questions to ask yourself and food for thought:
> >
> >1.  What does it mean when the Superintendent can say to concerned 
>parents
> >at a board of ed meeting:
> >"If you don't like the school system in New Brunswick, send your kids
> >somewhere else!"
> >
> >2.  What does it mean when the Mayor organizes private invitation 
>including
> >his top administrative staff such as the City Planner and Fire Chief, 
>only
> >meetings to promote the local school system HOSTED AT A PRIVATE SCHOOL, 
>St.
> >Mary's?
> >
> >3.  What does it mean when the City's attorney argues in court against
> >rewording the ballot question by saying it would make it so clear, 
>readers
> >would no longer be forced to look at the interpretive statement to
> >understand the question?
> >
> >4.  What does it mean when this info has been gathered from a network of
> >anonymous parents and teacher leaders, who are afraid of the 
>repercussions
> >on their jobs and positions when the mayor-appointed administration finds
> >out they support this initiative?
> >
> >YES! for an elected board of education is endorsed by the New Jersey
> >Education Association and the main local newspaper, the Home News 
>Tribune.
> >
> >For more info (and there is more), contact:
> >Zofia Nowakowski
> >Committee for an Elected School Board
> >New Brunswick Peoples Campaign
> >znowakow@... 
> >(732) 729-1087
> >_________________________________________________________________________
> >Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
> >
> >Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
> >http://profiles.msn.com.
> >
> >
> >
> >To Post a message, send it to:   nbpeoplescampaign@... 
> >
> >To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to:
> >nbpeoplescampaign-unsubscribe@eGroups.com 
> >

People should call if they can and quickly plug the pc. call 212-209-2999,

>From: "kristina bas" <krisbas@...>
>Reply-To: njfo@egroups.com
>To: njfo@egroups.com
>Subject: [njfo] the left needs unity
>Date: Wed, 25 Oct 2000 14:47:45 GMT
>
>from today's new york times...
>
>October 25, 2000
>
>Democrats Hear Thunder on Left, and Try to Steal Some of Nader's
>By JAMES DAO
>
>
>The New York Times
>Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate, said he was glad for the "enhanced
>attention" brought to his campaign by Gore supporters.
>
>ASHINGTON, Oct. 24 � Concerned that Ralph Nader has become a major threat 
>to
>Vice President Al Gore's ability to win the presidency, the Democratic 
>Party
>and its allies in the labor, environmental and women's movements are
>mounting aggressive campaigns in swing states across the country to 
>dissuade
>liberal voters from supporting Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate.
>
>In the Pacific Northwest, the League of Conservation Voters is preparing to
>run radio advertisements asserting that voting for Mr. Nader would be
>tantamount to voting for Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican. In Ohio, the
>state Democratic Party has begun flooding college campuses with leaflets
>urging students not to waste their ballots on the Green Party. In 
>Wisconsin,
>the Service Employees International Union has dispatched hundreds of
>organizers to implore its 12,000 state members to vote Democratic, not
>Green.
>
>And the Democratic National Committee has organized an array of prominent
>liberals, including Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, the Rev. Jesse
>Jackson, Gloria Steinem and Robert Redford to stump for Mr. Gore in Nader
>strongholds like Eugene, Ore., Madison, Wis., and Seattle.
>
>Not wanting to offend Mr. Nader or his supporters, those surrogates have
>been paying homage to his long record of fighting for a cleaner 
>environment,
>consumer protection and labor rights. But they warn that a strong Nader
>showing can only help Mr. Bush � with potentially dire consequences for the
>very causes liberals hold most dear.
>
>"Mr. Nader is a good man, he's raised important issues," said Mark Fabiani,
>Mr. Gore's deputy campaign manager. "But he himself admits that he can't
>win. What could be lost in this election is a woman's right to choose, what
>could be lost are tough environmental protections."
>
>Told of the effort to squeeze the air out of his campaign, Mr. Nader said 
>in
>an interview tonight: "Their policy for six months has been to ignore me. 
>So
>obviously we welcome this enhanced attention."
>
>He added, "All these good people who have succumbed to the lesser-of-
>two-evils syndrome are setting themselves up for another cycle of political
>betrayal."
>
>Indeed, the sudden mobilization against Mr. Nader comes after Gore campaign
>officials had for months dismissed him as inconsequential. But Mr. Nader 
>has
>stubbornly continued to hover around 5 percent in polls taken in half a
>dozen tightly contested states where a shift of just a percentage point or
>two could determine the winner, including Oregon, Washington, Michigan,
>Wisconsin, Minnesota and New Mexico. A poll released today even shows Mr.
>Nader cutting into Mr. Gore's once- substantial lead in California.
>
>Now, with just two weeks left in one of the closest presidential campaigns
>in decades, Democrats say the last thing Mr. Gore needs is to be forced 
>into
>a two-front war against both Mr. Bush and Mr. Nader. And while Gore 
>campaign
>officials continue to express confidence in public that Mr. Nader's support
>will dwindle by Election Day, they are telling their surrogates in private
>that they are worried the Green Party candidate has become a real danger.
>
>"Bill Daley is well aware that it's extremely important to deal with Nader
>voters," Mr. Wellstone said, referring to Mr. Gore's campaign chairman. "He
>understands this could be the margin of defeat or victory in the
>battleground states."
>
>Mr. Gore himself has begun addressing Mr. Nader's challenge head on, 
>telling
>voters in Washington on Monday that his environmental record was as strong
>as Mr. Nader's.
>
>"I don't want to use the argument that a vote for him is a vote for Bush �
>that may be true," Mr. Gore told a reporter for KIRO-TV in Seattle. "I
>prefer to say, `Look, I want you to look at my record and my agenda and my
>passion for doing the right thing.' And I'll match that against anybody."
>
>But Democratic strategists say they want Mr. Gore to avoid mentioning Mr.
>Nader, arguing that doing so only elevates the insurgent's profile and 
>draws
>attention from their real target, Mr. Bush. For that reason, the Democrats
>are trying to shift the burden of wooing Nader voters to a stable of
>well-known liberal politicians and advocates.
>
>Ms. Steinem, for example, has been traveling by bus to campuses along the
>Pacific Coast, reading her list of "the top 10 reasons I'm not voting for
>Nader." On Sunday, she plans to join Elizabeth Birch, executive director of
>the Human Rights Campaign, the nation's largest gay and lesbian
>organization, Robert Cox, president of the Sierra Club, and the rock singer
>Melissa Etheridge for a concert and rally in Seattle.
>
>Their roadshow is scheduled to visit Oregon, Wisconsin and New Mexico next
>week. "Whatever value Nader brings to the public discourse," Ms. Birch said
>in an interview today, "it pales compared to handing the federal government
>and Supreme Court over to George Bush. We will do everything we can to peel
>votes away from Nader and give them back to Gore."
>
>Mr. Nader has tried to argue that he is not likely to hurt Mr. Gore,
>asserting that many of his supporters are non-Democrats who probably would
>not vote if he dropped out of the race. Democrats dispute that. He has also
>said in recent weeks that he would focus his final campaigning on states
>where either Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore holds a substantial lead. But his
>tentative schedule includes stops in closely contested states like
>Wisconsin, Minnesota and Michigan.
>
>The Democrats have asked Brent Blackwelder, president of Friends of the
>Earth, to campaign for Mr. Gore in the Pacific Northwest. And the Sierra
>Club will begin running television spots next week in five states where Mr.
>Nader is polling well that carry the message: "Think there's no difference
>between the candidates? Think again."
>
>Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Mr. Gore's rival in the
>Democratic primaries, is being dispatched later this week to campaign in
>Oregon and Washington, where Democratic strategists are counting on him to
>woo liberal white men for Mr. Gore. Mr. Jackson has been sent to colleges
>where Mr. Nader is considered popular, including the University of 
>Wisconsin
>at Madison.
>
>Because Mr. Nader could also win votes from union members who are angry 
>with
>Mr. Gore for supporting global trade, the Democrats have organized a list 
>of
>heavyweight labor leaders to help. Earlier this week, John J. Sweeney,
>president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., toured the Northwest with other labor
>officials urging labor activists to stick with Mr. Gore.
>
>Andrew L. Stern, head of the service employees union, said in an interview
>that he had been telling crowds in the Northwest: "If you can wake up the
>next morning and live with George Bush as the next president, then I guess
>you can vote for Nader. This is not a low-risk protest vote."
>
>The Democratic Party has also been asking Gore supporters to flood the 
>Nader
>campaign with e-mail messages urging him to drop out of the race. It has
>also been promoting a Web site created by a group of former colleagues of
>Mr. Nader's called nadersraidersforgore.com.
>
>Yet for all those efforts, some Democrats say they think the Gore campaign
>was slow to respond.
>
>Gary Sellers of Nader's Raiders for Gore, said of Mr. Gore's campaign: "I
>think they are not taking him as seriously as they should. The Nader people
>are true believers. It's going to take some time to convince them to vote
>against him."
>
>_________________________________________________________________________
>Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.
>
>Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at
>http://profiles.msn.com.
>

>To Post a message, send it to:   njfo@...
>To Unsubscribe, send a blank message to: njfo-unsubscribe@...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:727
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-26 10:58:17
Subject:School Board Taxes
Message:

OK, Paul, Thanks to your questions, I have more info for you from a third 
source, Joan Ponessa, Director of Research, Education Law Center, Newark, 
NJ.

This last year, our school district tax rate increased because the property 
tax values went down (NB School District source).  However, Joan states 
there are other factors that influence our school district tax rate - 
particularly, how much money the state gives us.  If when we apply to the 
state for supplemental funding, they dont give it to us, or if they don't 
give us enough Early Childhood Aid, our local levy can increase, too.

Joan states that research has shown whether a board is appointed or elected 
does not influence one way or another what the local tax rate is.  She 
stated that in her opinion the major thing that changes is the relationship 
between the school board and City Hall.  So the opposition is dead wrong 
with the first of their major slogans.

The opposition also points to the cost of running elections, citing a 
$10,000 cost of running them.  What is that compared to the dollars wasted 
currently in a $100M+ school budget?

They also state there is low voter turnout in such elections.  This is 
something our grassroots effort must ensure against.

The consensus of NJ SBA and Ms. Ponessa is that whether a board should be 
appointed or elected depends on each specific local case.



_________________________________________________________________________

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:728
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-26 14:48:15
Subject:People Campaign for City Council, New Brunswick, NJ
Message:

To the Courageous Staff at Democracy Now,

Please keep a close eye on the in New Brunswick, NJ.  This is a broad, 
multi-national united front of democratic classes focused on one goal: 
seizing political power from a hopelessly corrupted, though deeply 
entrenched, corporate City Machine represented by one party...in this case, 
the Democrats.  Through a months long process of canvassing over 1000 city 
residents last spring, the People's Campaign drew up a real democratic 
platform that was voted on at a Public Convention last April, where Amiri 
Baraka gave the opening address.  Now this campaign, which was initiated by 
the revolutionary democratic New Jersey Freedom Organization (NJFO), has 
picked up unprecidented momentum and, quite literally, has been turning New 
Brunswick upside-down.  At the convention, we also elected a ticket of three 
community members from a pool of eight nominations:  Diego Morales, a 
Mexican-Ameirican who once organized unions in Mexico; Curtis Warren, an 
African American bus driver who for years has fought for justice for victims 
of police brutality in New Brunswick, in particular, Sissy Adams who was 
murdered by former Officer James Consalvo back in Sept of 1996 (covered by 
WBAI's Wake Up Morning Show and Evening News); and Keith Joseph, a Rutgers 
graduate of Philosophy and a house painter, and a senior member of NJFO.  
For months, we have been blanketing the city and campus with our literature, 
informing people of the issues that matter most to them, continuing our door 
to door canvass, and generally making the City Machine feel the heat of the 
people taken to the street!  Most recently, the Machine's incumbent 
candidates have backed out of a debate that was being organized by the Home 
News & Tribune, as their track record of lies, corruption and scandals leave 
them with more to lose than to gain by such public exposure as a debate 
would bring. (Covered by the Star Ledger and the Home News & Tribune) Like 
the Imperialist candidates at the national level, they have shown that they 
are not interested in democracy, or in hearing the cries of the people...so 
like the national pawns of International Finance Capital, THEY GOT TO GO!!!

All Power to the People!

In Unity & Struggle, Matthew Smith

(LONG LIVE DEMOCRACY NOW...Down with the undemocratic Pacifica Board!)

*********************************************************************

From the Newark Star Ledger:

                Jury decides against policeman

                10/27/00

                STAFF WRITER

                A New Brunswick policeman gambled that he could beat charges 
that he and another officer ran a brothel in the city called the Pleasure 
Dome. Yesterday he lost the gamble, and now the two officers are facing 10 
years in prison.
                After six hours of deliberation, a jury in Middlesex County 
convicted Detective James Marshall and Sgt. Marco Chinchilla, along with 
three others, on charges of operating a bordello out of a seedy warehouse at 
121 Jersey Ave. in New Brunswick.
                In convicting the officers, the jury accepted the accounts 
of an admitted prostitute and her drug-addicted former boyfriend over those 
of two decorated cops, one of whom admitted he was at the warehouse but only 
to conduct a stakeout.
                The background of their two star witnesses had worried
prosecutors. Last weekend, as lawyers for both sides
prepared their closing arguments, prosecutors offered Marshall a highly 
unusual plea agreement, according to people involved in the case: In 
exchange for pleading guilty to lesser charges, Marshall would avoid prison. 
What's more, his four co-defendants would avoid prison, also.
              Convinced he would be acquitted, Marshall refused to
plead guilty. Yesterday he stood somberly in a New Brunswick courtroom as 
the jury convicted him, Chinchilla and the three others.
                "I think they made a mistake," Marshall later said of the 
jury. "The prosecutor is a liar. The witnesses lied. I still     insist I 
didn't do anything illegal and the truth will come out."
                Marshall, 44, and Chinchilla, 41, stared intently at the 
jurors as the verdict was announced. Chinchilla continued to stand for some 
minutes but bowed his head and sat down after his mother, seated in the 
first row of the gallery, started to sob.
                Marshall, Chinchilla and businessman Luis Posadas were
convicted of conspiracy, official misconduct and promoting prostitution. 
Posadas rented the third-floor warehouse space where the brothel was 
operated under the guise of a legitimate massage parlor, known as Club 121.
                Michelle Thibeault, 31, and Joyce Sweeney, 32,     masseuses 
at the brothel, were convicted of conspiracy.  Thibeault also was convicted 
of promoting prostitution, but  Sweeney was acquitted of that charge.
                Neither Chinchilla nor his family members would discuss the 
verdict. Middlesex County Prosecutor Glenn Berman said he was pleased with 
the verdict, but he added: "The conviction of two law-enforcement officers 
is not a cause for our office to celebrate. . . . I know this case has 
caused a divide with the New Brunswick Police Department. I have already 
talked to Director (Michael) Beltranena about this. We want to heal that 
rift."
                The jury of eight men and four women deliberated
Wednesday afternoon and a short time yesterday morning a brief ending to a 
trial that lasted five weeks.
                Superior Court Judge Barnett Hoffman said he will
sentence the defendants Dec. 18. They remained free on bail, although the 
judge ordered Posadas and Chinchilla, who have passports, to surrender them.
                The two police officers, both 16-year veterans, have been 
suspended without pay since they were indicted in December 1998. Beltranena 
said the suspensions would continue and additional action against the 
officers is pending. Upon sentencing, the officers face being barred from 
work in law enforcement.
                The case against Marshall and Chinchilla was closely
followed in the law-enforcement and legal communities --
not only because of the accusation against the two officers
but because of the backgrounds of the star witnesses, Katherine Saddler, 37, 
and Robert Rogers, 32.
                "Wow. I am surprised," former Bergen County Prosecutor John 
Fahy said after hearing about the verdict. "This was a
very risky case from the prosecutor's perspective. Who's going to believe a 
hooker or a junkie as compared with a police officer?"
                But Assistant Middlesex County Prosecutor Lawrence
Welle, who tried the case, said he never doubted the witnesses.  "People who 
violate the law do not do it with priests and rabbis and persons of the 
higher echelons of society,"
                Welle said. "For one reason or another, certain people tried 
to diminish how good a case it was. While the one woman was a prostitute and 
was not in the best period of her life, and they both were using drugs, the 
information they had was credible."
                Jurors were riveted, and sometimes amused, by the
testimony of Saddler and Rogers, who described a thriving house of 
prostitution that boasted a waiting room, massage tables, showers and a VIP 
room with a canopy bed.
                Prosecutors were aware that trying to convict two police 
officers, both personable and well-liked men, would be difficult. And the 
defense compounded the task by bringing in former and current employees of 
the prosecutor's office, including police and assistant prosecutors, as 
character witnesses.
                Marshall, who headed up vice investigations, testified he 
had been in the warehouse on more than a dozen occasions to stake out an 
auto theft ring operating in a backyard garage. He said he never saw any 
evidence of prostitution. On cross-examination, he acknowledged he had never 
filed any reports pertaining to his surveillance activity.
                Chinchilla, once named Officer of the Year for his
crime-fighting efforts, told the jury he never set foot in the
warehouse during the times the state's witnesses claimed
he was there.
                In the end, said juror George Levins, the panel believed 
Saddler, even as she faces criminal charges elsewhere, and Rogers. "We 
didn't believe everything she said, but she did have
some crucial evidence. So did Bobby Rogers," Levins said.
               "The prosecution did a good job and the defense did a
good job. We looked at the evidence and felt it backed up
our verdict."

                Staff writers Jim O'Neill and Tom Haydon contributed to this 
report.
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:730
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-27 15:02:06
Subject:To go after legal support....
Message:

From: 	Jeffrey Estep <jeff@...>
To:	"'nowakowski@...'" <nowakowski@fiscal...
Date: 	Fri, Oct 27, 2000  2:50 PM
Subject: 	FW: Nader in Newark tomorrow for "Inner Cities Green Day"

 

----- Original Message-----
From: NJ4Nader@...
To: undisclosed-recipients
Sent: 10/27/00 1:25 PM
Subject: Nader in Newark tomorrow for "Inner Cities Green Day"

We just got word that in conjunction with tomorrow's "Inner Cities Green

Day," Ralph Nader will make a campaign appearance in Newark!

Where: Rutgers Law School -- Atrium
      123 Washington St. (corner of Washington St. and New St.)
      Newark, NJ

When:  5:30 PM, Saturday, October 28th

Contact:  Joe Fortunato 973-744-5958 / JFortun845@...

Also: campaign supporters in South Jersey should spread the word that
Nader 
will be Philadelphia in the early afternoon:
Time: 1:15 - 2:45pm
Location: First Unitarian Church, 2125 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia
Doors open at 1:00          $10 minimum donation
Special Guests include Kenn Kweder, David Kairys, Terry Johnson, and
Aaron 
Kromash (Green Party of New Jersey congressional candidate, 3rd
District)
Press Conference: 3-3:30pm
Contact: Charles Sherrouse 215-743-8695

In Mercer County and the 4th Congressional District, Inner City Green
Day 
volunteers will gather at the Trenton Train Station at 12:30 PM.

Chaifetz (Chaifetz2000@...) 732-899-4202, Green Party candidate,
4th 
Congressional District.

Post ID:731
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-27 11:36:29
Subject:ONE VICTOY IN NB! ELECTION DAY TO GO!!!
Message:

Congradulations to all who have been struggling against police brutality and 
corruption in New Brunswick for years!  Sissy Adams will never be forgotten! 
  This is a victory for people's democracy!  DOWN WITH THE CITY MACHINE! 
ONWARD TO ELECTION DAY AND CITY COUNCIL!

Matthew Smith

*********************************************************************

From the Newark Star Ledger:

                Jury decides against policeman

                10/27/00

                STAFF WRITER

                A New Brunswick policeman gambled that he could beat charges 
that he and another officer ran a brothel in the city called the Pleasure 
Dome. Yesterday he lost the gamble, and now the two officers are facing 10 
years in prison.
                After six hours of deliberation, a jury in Middlesex County 
convicted Detective James Marshall and Sgt. Marco Chinchilla, along with 
three others, on charges of operating a bordello out of a seedy warehouse at 
121 Jersey Ave. in New Brunswick.
                In convicting the officers, the jury accepted the accounts 
of an admitted prostitute and her drug-addicted former boyfriend over those 
of two decorated cops, one of whom admitted he was at the warehouse but only 
to conduct a stakeout.
                The background of their two star witnesses had worried
prosecutors. Last weekend, as lawyers for both sides
prepared their closing arguments, prosecutors offered Marshall a highly 
unusual plea agreement, according to people involved in the case: In 
exchange for pleading guilty to lesser charges, Marshall would avoid prison. 
What's more, his four co-defendants would avoid prison, also.
              Convinced he would be acquitted, Marshall refused to
plead guilty. Yesterday he stood somberly in a New Brunswick courtroom as 
the jury convicted him, Chinchilla and the three others.
                "I think they made a mistake," Marshall later said of the 
jury. "The prosecutor is a liar. The witnesses lied. I still     insist I 
didn't do anything illegal and the truth will come out."
                Marshall, 44, and Chinchilla, 41, stared intently at the 
jurors as the verdict was announced. Chinchilla continued to stand for some 
minutes but bowed his head and sat down after his mother, seated in the 
first row of the gallery, started to sob.
                Marshall, Chinchilla and businessman Luis Posadas were
convicted of conspiracy, official misconduct and promoting prostitution. 
Posadas rented the third-floor warehouse space where the brothel was 
operated under the guise of a legitimate massage parlor, known as Club 121.
                Michelle Thibeault, 31, and Joyce Sweeney, 32,     masseuses 
at the brothel, were convicted of conspiracy.  Thibeault also was convicted 
of promoting prostitution, but  Sweeney was acquitted of that charge.
                Neither Chinchilla nor his family members would discuss the 
verdict. Middlesex County Prosecutor Glenn Berman said he was pleased with 
the verdict, but he added: "The conviction of two law-enforcement officers 
is not a cause for our office to celebrate. . . . I know this case has 
caused a divide with the New Brunswick Police Department. I have already 
talked to Director (Michael) Beltranena about this. We want to heal that 
rift."
                The jury of eight men and four women deliberated
Wednesday afternoon and a short time yesterday morning a brief ending to a 
trial that lasted five weeks.
                Superior Court Judge Barnett Hoffman said he will
sentence the defendants Dec. 18. They remained free on bail, although the 
judge ordered Posadas and Chinchilla, who have passports, to surrender them.
                The two police officers, both 16-year veterans, have been 
suspended without pay since they were indicted in December 1998. Beltranena 
said the suspensions would continue and additional action against the 
officers is pending. Upon sentencing, the officers face being barred from 
work in law enforcement.
                The case against Marshall and Chinchilla was closely
followed in the law-enforcement and legal communities --
not only because of the accusation against the two officers
but because of the backgrounds of the star witnesses, Katherine Saddler, 37, 
and Robert Rogers, 32.
                "Wow. I am surprised," former Bergen County Prosecutor John 
Fahy said after hearing about the verdict. "This was a
very risky case from the prosecutor's perspective. Who's going to believe a 
hooker or a junkie as compared with a police officer?"
                But Assistant Middlesex County Prosecutor Lawrence
Welle, who tried the case, said he never doubted the witnesses.  "People who 
violate the law do not do it with priests and rabbis and persons of the 
higher echelons of society,"
                Welle said. "For one reason or another, certain people tried 
to diminish how good a case it was. While the one woman was a prostitute and 
was not in the best period of her life, and they both were using drugs, the 
information they had was credible."
                Jurors were riveted, and sometimes amused, by the
testimony of Saddler and Rogers, who described a thriving house of 
prostitution that boasted a waiting room, massage tables, showers and a VIP 
room with a canopy bed.
                Prosecutors were aware that trying to convict two police 
officers, both personable and well-liked men, would be difficult. And the 
defense compounded the task by bringing in former and current employees of 
the prosecutor's office, including police and assistant prosecutors, as 
character witnesses.
                Marshall, who headed up vice investigations, testified he 
had been in the warehouse on more than a dozen occasions to stake out an 
auto theft ring operating in a backyard garage. He said he never saw any 
evidence of prostitution. On cross-examination, he acknowledged he had never 
filed any reports pertaining to his surveillance activity.
                Chinchilla, once named Officer of the Year for his
crime-fighting efforts, told the jury he never set foot in the
warehouse during the times the state's witnesses claimed
he was there.
                In the end, said juror George Levins, the panel believed 
Saddler, even as she faces criminal charges elsewhere, and Rogers. "We 
didn't believe everything she said, but she did have
some crucial evidence. So did Bobby Rogers," Levins said.
               "The prosecution did a good job and the defense did a
good job. We looked at the evidence and felt it backed up
our verdict."

                Staff writers Jim O'Neill and Tom Haydon contributed to this 
report.
_________________________________________________________________________

Post ID:734
Sender:jbates <jbates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-28 14:13:37
Subject:statistics?
Message:

yo folks,
    can anyone tell me where the stats on graduation rates etc for New
Brunswick came from? I need the info for a paper i'm writing.
        in struggle,
            jbates





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:735
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-30 10:52:34
Subject:Re: [nbpc] statistics?
Message:

1999 Legislative Data Book, NJ - basically, of those students entering NB high schools, how many end up graduating from there.

These stats include those students who drop out of school AND those who transfer out b/c of moving or going to a different (such as private) school system.  It is a tricky number.  The board of Ed has stated the dropout rate at 10% but upon questioning it is not clear exactly what this stands for (for ex. is it for the senior class)- you might want to try again. One teacher has said that noone knows what the real dropout rate is and this needs to be better measured. Re: transfering out of the system - It is true that we have a mobile population, but I know many people who work something out w/ nieghboring districts such as East Brunswick through a relative etc.


>>> jbates <jbates@email.eden.rutgers.edu> 10/28 2:13 PM >>>
yo folks,
    can anyone tell me where the stats on graduation rates etc for New
Brunswick came from? I need the info for a paper i'm writing.
        in struggle,
            jbates

Post ID:736
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-30 11:37:42
Subject:illegitimate academic should get the boot
Message:

Check out this Gillespie character and his faulty logic. I'm copying his bs 
editorial (from today's Targum) below, after my comments.

How can this guy claim positive results when 46% of entering students 
actually graduate NBHS? This guy must be EXPOSED! We can't tolerate 
pseudo-intellectuals. This professor is well-known and regarded in American 
Studies. We need to boot such folk to the intellectual gutter, where they 
belong. We need to utilize the public spotlight and SMASH fake claims and 
shoddy logic. We need debates on these issues, we need debates on democracy, 
elections, role of intellectuals and revolutionaries, the parties, history 
of voter disenfranchisement/jim crow/apartheid in the US.----elaboration on 
the 13th-15th amendments, voter rights act, economic position of oppressed 
nationalities (minorities) and their relationship to the broader economy.  
Let's start checking these out after the election and start exposing 
apologist frauds like Gillespie. These are some of the questions I think 
stand astride of the current education crisis in Abbott districts all over 
NJ, etc.

Here are the words of a chump:

Board member asks N.B. to vote �no�



                                           By Angus Kress Gillespie
                                           Guest Commentary


                                           Lately we�ve been hearing a lot 
about an important issue facing New Brunswick
                                           voters on the Nov. 7 ballot. For 
the fourth time in eight years, New Brunswick
                                           residents are being asked to 
consider switching to an elected school board. On
                                           each of the last three occasions 
this question was posed to New Brunswick
                                           voters, it was overwhelmingly 
rejected.

                                           As an educator and a long-time 
resident of the City of New Brunswick, I would
                                           like to take a moment to tell you 
just a few reasons why I believe you should vote
                                           �no� on the Board of Education 
question.

                                           I have seen the remarkable 
renaissance of this city that, unless you�ve been here
                                           for some time, is truly hard to 
appreciate fully. Among the many achievements this
                                           city has realized over the past 
few decades, perhaps most impressive are the
                                           accomplishments of the New 
Brunswick public schools. This is a subject matter
                                           of which I can speak from 
firsthand experience because I have the honor and
                                           privilege of serving as a member 
of the New Brunswick Board of Education.

                                           Our University�s involvement with 
the New Brunswick public schools has led to
                                           many successful partnerships, 
such as internship opportunities for Rutgers
                                           students, involvement of Rutgers 
students in after-school programming in all New
                                           Brunswick schools and the 
Professional Development School with the Rutgers
                                           Graduate School of Education.

                                           I�m extremely proud of the 
progress we�ve made to provide quality education to
                                           our 6,000 students and their 
parents, such as:

                                           � Student test scores soaring up 
to 95 percent on the New Jersey High School
                                           Proficiency Test, the largest 
gain in the state;

                                           � Now over 1,000 computers in our 
schools, with computer labs in each school,
                                           and an average of four computers 
with Internet access in every classroom;

                                           � A new Lord Stirling Community 
School for the Arts under construction, and
                                           recent McKinley and Woodrow 
Wilson School expansion and modernization
                                           projects complete;

                                           � Parents giving New Brunswick�s 
public schools their highest rating ever in the
                                           bi-annual Eagleton 
Institute/Rutgers University survey;

                                           � Creating the New Brunswick 
Health Science & Technology High School � the
                                           first in the state affiliated 
with a teaching hospital and a medical school;

                                           � Our award- and grant-winning 
after-school programs with Rutgers� student
                                           involvement in all of our 
schools;

                                           � The newly renovated Memorial 
Stadium, with the new Youth Sports Complex
                                           under construction;

                                           � Pre-school now available to all 
three- and four-year-olds citywide.

                                           As a member of the Board of 
Education, I am familiar with the process that I
                                           went through to be appointed to 
the board. There are no campaigns, no campaign
                                           contributions, no special 
interest influence and no self-promotion by elected
                                           school board members at the 
expense of our children.

                                           The board is made up of people 
just like me, whose only interest is to provide our
                                           children with the best possible 
education at a cost our residents can afford. So if
                                           you�re a New Brunswick resident 
and intend to vote on this ballot question, I
                                           hope you will join me in 
rejecting the efforts of political candidates attempting to
                                           undo all of the progress we have 
made with a board that puts our children ahead
                                           of politics. On Nov. 7, please 
say �No� to politics in our schools and vote no on
                                           the Board of Education question.

                                           Angus Kress Gillespie, Ph.D., is 
a professor of American studies and a member
                                           of the New Brunswick Board of 
Education.

Post ID:737
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-30 11:59:46
Subject:Bush for Pres.?
Message:

Dear Mr. Nader and Campaign Staff:

I write visceral and blunt urgings for your organization to reexamine your
role in the presidential election.

I submit the following as cause to back out of the race at this eleventh
hour:

1.  George Bush is a serial killer, a chronic privatizer, and an incoherent
babbler. Al Gore is not. The first two facts have most impact for minorities
who have never had the franchise in this country. Those minorities are not
voting Nader this year.

2.  Al Gore is inextricably tied to the Democratic Party, making him
accountable to local organizations around the country, not just finance
capital. That's what makes a party, independent local organizations. You
have to beat dems and reps in local elections to have a snowball's chance in
hell to win nationally.

3.  I think it's clear that your party will not win its five percent popular
vote to get federal funds, so why run anymore? There are no more gains to be
made for the national Green Party at this point.

4.  Lastly, I cite the example of Rudy "sans the little moustache" Ghouliani
in NYC. Rudy ran against Dinkins in '94. Many of the same "Left" groups who
support Nader for President ran massive publicity campaigns against Dinkins.
These groups mainly called Dinkins a sellout, sd he wasn't revolutionary
enough, called him a Tom, etc.  Dinkins was not a serial killer, a chronic
privatizer, an undying friend of the most reactionary sectors of finance
capital since Weimar Germany-- but Herr Giuliani is!!!  So these so-called
Left groups succeeded in knocking down Dinkins so much that fascist Giuliani
got elected.

Don't make the same mistake that these lefties made.  Make no mistake, Bush
likes fascism. Let's not confuse party-building with spoiler politics.

In Unity and Struggle for a vigorous independent political party,

Paul McGee, New Jersey Freedom Organization
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

the past 8 years in the White House.

GORE: I'm my own man. I may not be the most exciting politician, but I will
fight for the working families of America, in addition to turning the White
House into a lusty pit of marital love for Tipper and me.

BUSH: It's time to put aside the partisanship of the past by electing no one
but Republicans.

Erric Z.

Post ID:740
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>

At 02:25 PM 10/30/2000, you wrote:
>I cite the Giuliani example once again. Who gets lynched?
>
>
> >From: "Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
> >Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com

> >Date: Mon, 30 Oct 2000 12:09:38 -0500
> >
> >I know neither one of these (the original or the response) are about the
> >NBPC but...Um, Paul, are you on Crack?  Did you notice the Nader has 3-6%
> >in each area?  Gore may not be this "serial killer, et al" that you called
> >Bush, but he is a LIAR!  An outright, flaming, liar...he doesn't even know
> >what he did and did not do -- can I just site the Internet as just ONE
> >example out of many contradictions/outright lies he has told?  If the
> >Republicans win, this country will drop like a rock and maybe it'll be
> >easier to fight back from dead zero than to sit on the crap we have had for
> >the past 8 years in the White House.
> >
> >To quote a funny post I got somewhere else that's very fitting:
> >
> >LEHRER: It's time for closing statements.
> >
> >GORE: I'm my own man. I may not be the most exciting politician, but I will
> >fight for the working families of America, in addition to turning the White
> >House into a lusty pit of marital love for Tipper and me.
> >
> >BUSH: It's time to put aside the partisanship of the past by electing no
> >one
> >but Republicans.
> >
> >Erric Z.
> >
> >At 11:59 AM 10/30/2000, you wrote:
> > >Dear Mr. Nader and Campaign Staff:
> > >
> > >I write visceral and blunt urgings for your organization to reexamine
> >your
> > >role in the presidential election.
> > >
> > >I submit the following as cause to back out of the race at this eleventh
> > >hour:
> > >
> > >1.  George Bush is a serial killer, a chronic privatizer, and an
> >incoherent
> > >babbler. Al Gore is not. The first two facts have most impact for
> >minorities
> > >who have never had the franchise in this country. Those minorities are
> >not
> > >voting Nader this year.
> > >
> > >2.  Al Gore is inextricably tied to the Democratic Party, making him
> > >accountable to local organizations around the country, not just finance
> > >capital. That's what makes a party, independent local organizations. You
> > >have to beat dems and reps in local elections to have a snowball's chance
> >in
> > >hell to win nationally.
> > >
> > >3.  I think it's clear that your party will not win its five percent
> >popular
> > >vote to get federal funds, so why run anymore? There are no more gains to
> >be
> > >made for the national Green Party at this point.
> > >
> > >4.  Lastly, I cite the example of Rudy "sans the little moustache"
> >Ghouliani
> > >in NYC. Rudy ran against Dinkins in '94. Many of the same "Left" groups
> >who
> > >support Nader for President ran massive publicity campaigns against
> >Dinkins.
> > >These groups mainly called Dinkins a sellout, sd he wasn't revolutionary
> > >enough, called him a Tom, etc.  Dinkins was not a serial killer, a
> >chronic
> > >privatizer, an undying friend of the most reactionary sectors of finance
> > >capital since Weimar Germany-- but Herr Giuliani is!!!  So these
> >so-called
> > >Left groups succeeded in knocking down Dinkins so much that fascist
> >Giuliani
> > >got elected.
> > >
> > >Don't make the same mistake that these lefties made.  Make no mistake,
> >Bush
> > >likes fascism. Let's not confuse party-building with spoiler politics.
> > >
> > >In Unity and Struggle for a vigorous independent political party,
> > >
> > >Paul McGee, New Jersey Freedom Organization
> > >_________________________________________________________________________
> > >Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at
> > ><<http://www.hotmail.com.>http://www.hotmail.com.>http://www.hotmail.com.
