Post ID:770
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-01 11:07:01
Subject:Re: [nbpc] RE: THE NADER FACTOR
Message:

this is my question:

in 2001, when GW is president, will it have made one OUNCE of a difference 
that people voted for Nader? who will remember to the noble message that we 
would not vote for "evil". GW? Al Gore? the supreme court? congress? TVs? 
Radios? the police department? the American people?

when my right to choose is taken away; when affirmative action is crushed; 
when the Alaska wildlife preserve is decimated by oil companies; when social 
security is reduced to a windfall for Wall St.; when the government is 
privatized out to faith-based organizations; when public schools rot while 
charter schools bloom - boy, i sure will be happy that a select group of 
white, middle class liberals voted with their heart.



>From: "Mathew Levi" <ml@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: <nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com>
>Subject: Re: [nbpc] RE: THE NADER FACTOR
>Date: Tue, 31 Oct 2000 19:25:44 -0500
>
>An open invitation to debate.  Cool. :-)
>
>Well, I disagree with the idea that a 'leftist-minded' person should vote
>strategically for Gore, rather than vote on principle for Nader.  The
>principle is simple:  one should not vote for a candidate whom one thinks 
>is
>'evil,' no matter how much less an evil.  In terms of actual policy, it is
>true that a vote for Nader, which could potentially lead to a Bush victory,
>would do harm for this country.  I have several things to say about this.
>
>First of all, the actual damage this would do in terms of policy:  it's not
>so drastic as it seems.  Bush is not a fascist, he's an old-style
>conservative, old because he talks like a broken record and his policies 
>are
>pretty predictable.  But is Gore all that much different?  In truth, there
>are few areas of some difference.  One is the Supreme Court:  Bush would
>attempt to nominate conservative Christian-types, while Gore would
>supposedly nominate liberals.  There is truth to this, but let's not get
>carried away:  the Democrat-controlled Congress is to thank for Scalia,
>Thomas, and others whose nomination they endorsed.  Lieberman, who is no
>atheist himelf, has said on two occasions that he would have voted for
>Bork's nomination.  Bork is worse than anyone on the Court now.
>
>Another area of difference is gun control, and Clinton was able to get
>somewhere with this, although not far.  But I think any serious improvement
>is going to have to come through litigation, with the attack on the tobacco
>industry as the model.  I can't think of too many other differences.
>Abortion depends on the Court, but then again the Democratic Congress under
>Reagan/Bush is partially to blame.  Health care is nowhere, despite
>Clinton's best efforts;  the death penalty is wholly endorsed by Gore; the
>environment is hardly an issue anymore, especially to Gore who is awash in
>corporate sponsorship;  welfare policy was severely curtailed under 
>Clinton.
>The most important non-difference between the candidate is international
>policy, which is identical:  the Pentagon hardly has much to fear from 
>Gore.
>
>By voting strategically for Gore, we do more than keep Bush out.  We give
>him our consent:  he represents 'us.'  We all know this is a joke, that the
>two-party system plays on our fears.  Yet, what motivation does Gore have 
>to
>do anything except move further to the right, more toward the so-called
>'middle' of the political spectrum, the summit of the population pyramid?
>Under Clinton/Gore, many 'progressive causes' were lost: welfare was rolled
>back, we've bombed the hell out of a country illegally and immorally, and
>we've watched the wealth gap increase.  It's a trend - Gore will hardly
>'preserve' anything except his standing in his corporate sponsors' eyes.  
>On
>the other hand, if the Democrats lose they will have no choice but think
>'strategically' themselves, and at least move a bit more to the left.  If
>we're lucky, perhaps the Greens will grow and grow over the long-term, and
>one day the average person of this country will be able to live in a real
>social democracy, instead of a backwards laissez-faire system with
>institutionalized corruption and a government working hand-in-glove with 
>its
>corporate sponsors.
>
>Matt
>

Being that it is November 1st and the elections are only six days away, 
maybe some of you people who have worn out your keyboards on this list could 
actually do SOME WORK!!! If not why don't you send your silly negative 
emails to yourselves because we are busy. I have watched this stupidity 
(should I define) all along and it does nothing positive. If in your mind, 
Chris, Paul is a bit off that is fine but he is out working every night. I 
have only seen your emails as proof of your involvement. If you want to make 
a difference why don't you put down the keyboard and pick up a staple gun 
and actually WORK!!! That might seem foreign to you but that is how 
elections are won. Don't bother to respond because I am out putting up 
flyers and wouldn't have time to read it anyway.

Jim

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:775
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-01 14:23:05
Subject:UNITE, UNITE, UNITE
Message:

everyone:

i'm sorry that this debate has detracted from the main purpose of this 
egroup, which is the Campaign. For the record, I do not in the least bit 
equate voting for Nader the same as voting for the People's Campaign for 
city council. It's important to realize here that Nader has publically 
stated that he is not trying to win. big difference. we are trying to win, 
and actually gain some power. In Nader's own words:

"You miss the critical point: we seek long-term political reform
through a growing party that pushes the two parties toward reforms
that you have espoused over the years, thus far in vain."
NY Times editorial - Oct. 27, 2000

These are his words. I can not support voting for someone who believes the 
purpose of a political camaign is to shame/push the two main parties to " do 
the right thing".

Also, if the Green party was only trying to garner 5% of the vote for 
matching funds, they could easily target only those states where Gore is 
assured a victory and still get the 5%. It seems to me, however, that Nader 
is targeting specifically those states where Gore is weak so that Gore does 
not win. He does not want Gore to win. He wants Bush to win. I do not want 
Bush to win.

I hate the Democratic Party (witness my involvement in our campaign) but i 
can not support a man who is only trying to be a grand scale consumer 
advocate and whose political lines are actually pretty skewed.

I also think that real change, the kind that doesn't happen too often, can 
only come from a solid base of local grassroots organizing. I don't think 
voting for Gore will change anything. I do think working on the People's 
Campaign will.

Again, I'm sorry that this debate has shifted our attention from the 
important work at hand. Please let's unite around our upcoming victory on 
election day!!!

In Unity,
Kristina

http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:776
Sender:"Chris Kozlowski" <razer@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-01 18:52:14
Subject:RE: [nbpc] UNITE, UNITE, UNITE
Message:

Nader has not stated publicly that he is not trying to win.  He has stated
that it is not probable.  This simply means that he is not delusional.  He
has stated quite explicitly that they are indeed trying to win, as well as
gather as much support as possible.

The logic you are putting forth is precisely the sort of panicky drivel that
led to Clinton's election in 1992 and his re-election in 1996.  Everyone
bought into it and the Clintons, thus unchallenged, gave us a rollback of
democracy unseen in the Bush years. Put quite simply, they could pose as the
'lesser evil' and still do business as usual -- in effect, nothing different
than the Republicans.

It does no good to run around like Chicken Little and yell that the
Republicans are coming.  You will invite a dose of hysteria among the naive,
while those who contemplate the history of these arguments and wish to work
within the system to put an end to the existing monopoly and
unaccountability of power will just shake their heads at you.  The way to
move the Democrats to the left, in the near future, is to scare them with
third-party candidates and allow them to lose if necessary.

It is symptomatic of the Homo Sovieticus in some of you to play along with
the 'lesser evil' mentality.  Your arguments sound much like the ones used
to elicit the "98% support" for candidates back in the USSR.  "If you don't
vote for so-and-so, you are clearly supporting imperialism."

You cite passages to support a mind you have already made up, Kristina.  I
am not impressed with your train of thought.  Your suggestion that he is
merely a "consumer advocate" dismisses the platform of the Green Party,
which I will include below.  I suspect that you have dismissed it out of
hand, as you NJFO-derived folks have done dozens of times to any thought
that did not originate from the illustrious poet-revolutionary Amiri Baraka.
But yet, there is wisdom elsewhere in the world.  I encourage you to explore
it.

Grassroots Democracy
Every human being deserves a say in the decisions that affect their lives;
no one should be subject to the will of another. Therefore we will work to
increase public participation at every level of government and to ensure
that our public representatives are fully accountable to the people who
elect them. We will also work to create new types of political organizations
that expand the process of participatory democracy by directly including
citizens in the decision-making process.

Ecological Wisdom
Human societies must operate with the understanding that we are part of
nature, not separate from nature. We must maintain an ecological balance and
live within the ecological and resource limits of our communities and our
planet. We support a sustainable society that utilizes resources in such a
way that future generations will benefit and not suffer from the practices
of our generation. To this end we must have agricultural practices that
replenish the soil; move to an energy efficient economy; and live in ways
that respect the integrity of natural systems.


Social Justice and Equal Opportunity
All persons should have the rights and opportunity to benefit equally from
the resources afforded us by society and the environment. We must
consciously confront in ourselves, our organizations, and society at large,
barriers such as racism and class oppression, sexism and heterosexism,
ageism and disability, which act to deny fair treatment and equal justice
under the law.

Nonviolence
It is essential that we develop effective alternatives to our current
patterns of violence at all levels, from the family and the streets, to
nations and the world. We will work to demilitarize our society and
eliminate weapons of mass destruction, without being naive about the
intentions of other governments. We recognize the need for self-defense and
the defense of others who are in helpless situations. We promote nonviolent
methods to oppose practices and policies with which we disagree, and will
guide our actions toward lasting personal, community and global peace.

Decentralization
Centralization of wealth and power contributes to social and economic
injustice, environmental destruction, and militarization. Therefore, we
support a restructuring of social, political and economic institutions away
from a system that is controlled by and mostly benefits the powerful few, to
a democratic, less bureaucratic system. Decision-making should, as much as
possible, remain at the individual and local level, while assuring that
civil rights are protected for all citizens.

Community Based Economics
We recognize it is essential to create a vibrant and sustainable economic
system, one that can create jobs and provide a decent standard of living,
for all people, while maintaining a healthy ecological balance. A successful
economic system will offer meaningful work with dignity, while paying a
"living wage" which reflects the real value of a person's work. Local
communities must look to economic development that assures protection of the
environment and workers' rights, broad citizen participation in planning,
and enhancement of our "quality of life". We support independently owned and
operated companies which are socially responsible, as well as co-operatives
and public enterprises that spread out resources and control to more people
through democratic participation.

Feminism
We have inherited a social system based on male domination of politics and
economics. We call for the replacement of the cultural ethics of domination
and control, with more cooperative ways of interacting which respect
differences of opinion and gender. Human values such as equity between
the -sexes, interpersonal responsibility, and honesty must be developed with
moral conscience. We should remember that the process that determines our
decisions and actions is just as important as achieving the outcome we want.

Respect for Diversity
We believe it is important to value cultural, ethnic, racial, sexual,
religious and spiritual diversity, and to promote the development of
respectful relationships across these lines. We believe the many diverse
elements of society should be reflected in our organizations and
decision-making bodies, and we support the leadership of people who have
been traditionally closed out of leadership roles. We acknowledge and
encourage respect for other life forms and the preservation of biodiversity.

Personal and Global responsibility
We encourage individuals to act to improve their personal well being and, at
the same time, to enhance ecological balance and social harmony. We seek to
join with people and organizations around the world to foster peace,
economic justice, and the health of the planet.

Future Focus and Sustainability
Our actions and policies should be motivated by long-term goals. We seek to
protect valuable natural resources, safely disposing of or "unmaking" all
waste we create, while developing a sustainable economics that does not
depend on continual expansion for survival. We must counter-balance the
drive for short-term profits by assuring that economic development, new
technologies, and fiscal policies are responsible to future generations who
will inherit the results of our actions. Our overall goal is not merely to
survive, but to share lives that are truly worth living. We believe the
quality of our individual lives is enriched by the quality of all of our
lives. We encourage everyone to see the dignity and intrinsic worth in all
of life, and to take the time to understand and appreciate themselves, their
community and the magnificent beauty of this world.


-----Original Message-----
From: kristina bas [mailto:KRISBAS@...]
Sent: Wednesday, November 01, 2000 2:23 PM
To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
Subject: [nbpc] UNITE, UNITE, UNITE


everyone:

i'm sorry that this debate has detracted from the main purpose of this
egroup, which is the Campaign. For the record, I do not in the least bit
equate voting for Nader the same as voting for the People's Campaign for
city council. It's important to realize here that Nader has publically
stated that he is not trying to win. big difference. we are trying to win,
and actually gain some power. In Nader's own words:

"You miss the critical point: we seek long-term political reform
through a growing party that pushes the two parties toward reforms
that you have espoused over the years, thus far in vain."
NY Times editorial - Oct. 27, 2000

These are his words. I can not support voting for someone who believes the
purpose of a political camaign is to shame/push the two main parties to " do
the right thing".

Also, if the Green party was only trying to garner 5% of the vote for
matching funds, they could easily target only those states where Gore is
assured a victory and still get the 5%. It seems to me, however, that Nader
is targeting specifically those states where Gore is weak so that Gore does
not win. He does not want Gore to win. He wants Bush to win. I do not want
Bush to win.

I hate the Democratic Party (witness my involvement in our campaign) but i
can not support a man who is only trying to be a grand scale consumer
advocate and whose political lines are actually pretty skewed.

I also think that real change, the kind that doesn't happen too often, can
only come from a solid base of local grassroots organizing. I don't think
voting for Gore will change anything. I do think working on the People's
Campaign will.

Again, I'm sorry that this debate has shifted our attention from the
important work at hand. Please let's unite around our upcoming victory on
election day!!!

In Unity,
Kristina

Post ID:778

Post ID:779

Subject:RE: [nbpmgc] Paul McGee Groupies?
Message:

Yourself included?

<bemused smirk>

You are right though... We, the evil and underhanded forces of the 
disaffected bourgeois intellectuals, have had several meetings
of plotting and scheming.  Fortunately they were all done via
computer such that none of us would need to go outside.  The result 
of these middle-class bit blasts was the unanimous decision to take 
action and rally against our prime nemesis, Paul McGee.

Damn, we've been found out. . .
- Mike

PS: The above was intended to be humorous.  If you did not find
this amusing you probably need some time off.

Post ID:782
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 09:48:02
Subject:Re: [nbpc] RE: [nbpmgc] Paul McGee Groupies?
Message:

I agree with all of you, and further, to purge any remnants of sovietistics 
Left in Me Smithy of Me soul, I hereby prepare a microanalytical catharsis 
of deeds and identities I have performed and assumed, both good and bad, in 
the time-honored tradition of James Joyce, Kafka, Dostoyevsky, and that 
german guy.

Phase One:  Immediate flogging of my id

Phase Two:  Public renunciation of wine, women and song altogether

Third and Final Phaseology:  deconstruction and shredding of all sectarian, 
dogmatic, rigid, icky, yucky and distasteful points of view. They shall be 
inscribed upon a tablet and laid to rest in the graveyard that holds the 
word 'def'.

Peace be with me, and also with me. God help the comrades.

Post ID:783
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 09:56:36
Subject:The Good Word
Message:

Just to say,

The word around town is good.  As I was walking to work this morn a guy called out from across the street in encouragement.  I asked him about the weekend lockups and he said that the prostitution on Remsen has been known of for ages and nobody ever did anything about it until now, even though people in the neighborhood had tried.  He also hearkened to the oppression and 'black man hunt' that occurred in his neighborhood when the 2 cops shot eachother, what Keith has written about.

I was in Kinkos and the workers know of the campaign and think we will win.  We have whole families voting for us there.

Subject:Day Without Hate
Message:

Hi -- Just letting everyone know that the Week the Nov 13th, the day
without hate program will be taking place. we are still need of people to
help with programs, artists, and funding, if you are interested please
e-mail me back. we're trying to promote community in NEw BRunswick, RU and
throughout rest of the world. Personally, I'm tired of people trying to
kill each other because their different. . . and we're going to make
it known violence is not an answer.  If you have any desire
to help change the world for the better, please e-mail me asap  

peace
Ami Yares
Day Without Hate Chairperson 
247-9937





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:786
Sender:cuenzo@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 16:18:19
Subject:Re: [ru_ignite] misunderstood
Message:

Actually, there IS a protest being organized AGAINST rock the vote.  People 
are organizing Mock the Vote... for some of us, it is to protest the 
electoral process and our corrupt system of government, in which voting will 
do absolutely nothing -- corporations will still own and control America, and 
the rich (meaning the 2 major candidates that are running) will run the 
country.  For others, the Greens, this is a protest against the 2-party 
system and the exclusion of Ralph Nader and 3rd party candidates...  we are 
all working together because while are opinions do differ, we have enuf 
similarities that a joint effort is worthwhile.

Post ID:788
Sender:xadx <xadx@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 18:29:00
Subject:where's the communication?
Message:

does anybody else see a problem with this?  who is 'we...all' when the message
gets sent to the major student activist listserves at rutgers, and nobody has a
clue about what is going on (as in, i have seen absolutely no msg's regarding
actual plans for saturday - maybe i'm subscribed to the 'wrong' lists?)?  i look
at egroups and what, 180 people on the ignite list, 76 on the starc list, 21 on
sunb, and more than 40 from the campaign list... granted, many are on multiple
lists, there are so many people who are interested in getting stuff done on
campus, but there is just an utter lack of communication of what is going down on
campus... why are people planning shit and not letting everyone know? maybe if
there was a sense of collaboration that was instilled, something might actually
be achieved instead of random pockets of activity that seem to accomplish
nothing...

i know im not alone in harboring this sentiment as i even feel im echoing what
other people have said... do we need a campus-wide activist listserve, a website,
what are people's ideas?  what needs to happen...?

if it's just me, that's fine, in such a case you can regard this msg as drivel...

x...in.the.fight...x
     x.ad.x

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:789
Sender:Wildf10wer@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 18:39:57
Subject:synopsis of A Day Without Hate
Message:

Hello friends.  
I just wanted to follow up Ami's letter for those of you who may be 
interested in knowing more about what will be happening during this four day 
event.  
I agree with Ami. . .I, too, am tired of seeing senseless acts of hate.  This 
event has brought an amazing group of individuals together.  (Which, I feel, 
is a blessing in disguise.)  I feel empowered and motivated in creating a 
change that is reaching for a collective understanding of an interactive 
community built on kindness and successful communication. . .not ignorance, 
fear, and hate.  Can these four days make such a difference?  Yes. I already 
have learned so much and grown thanks to the many individuals involved with 
the organization of A Day Without Hate.  I feel confident that through the 
seminars, smiles, and outreach with music and art. . .we will be 
promoting/reminding our peers of the need for (and how to achieve) peace.    
I ask you to take a minute and read the synopsis that follows.  
Thank you.
With love,
Melissa Calabrese

A Day Without Hate
November 13-16

Imagine a day that stands up against the intolerance and negativity
present in the world.

Imagine a day that unites the Rutgers University and New Brunswick
Community. 

Imagine a week of kindness that culminates into a Day Without Hate.

Imagine that you and I could change the world. 

Help us make this a reality

We are looking for sponsors for funding as well as university student
group participation

Here is the synopsis for the weeks events. 

Monday, November 13:  For the Children
An assembly that will entertain and educate children at Lincoln School with 
interactive skits dealing with real life situations.  Our goal is to provide 
them with
conflict-resolution skills.  All students will receive literature to take
home and discuss with their parents.   We plan to set up a fair following the 
assembly that will allow the children to visit several stations concerning 
water issues
(provided by WaterWatch, an AmeriCorps program), communication skills, 
positive self-esteem, random acts of kindness, and art.  

Tuesday, November 14:  Diversity Day
With the recognition that there are several ways to communicate, we will
provide entertainment throughout College Ave, 
Douglass, Cook, Livingston and Busch campuses with music, theater,
artwork, and spirituality.  

Wednesday, November 15: Community and Self-awareness Day
This day, with the help of other organizations, we will focus on the
community and the self.  From clothing drives to blood donations, stress
management seminars to yoga workshops, we hope the individual will become
more aware of their personal actions.

Thursday, November 16: A Day Without Hate
This is a day of celebration and education.  First, a petition will be
circulated throughout the Rutgers community asking people to spend a day
without hatred.  Signers will receive a sticker to wear on November 16,
which will signify their participation in the program.  The pledge will be
placed as a display ad in the Daily Targum along with a list of the day's
events and an editorial explaining the motivation behind the establishment
of the day.  Again, all co-sponsors will be recognized.  

Second, throughout "A Day Without Hate", a series of seminars/events
discussing and focusing on hate, its causes, and solutions for dealing
with it will be held.  Each of these seminars will be run by a different
campus organization or department and will take place at a variety of
different locations throughout Rutgers.  "A Day Without Hate" will end
with a benefit concert and/or speaker.

If interested please e-mail contact phone number and we will reach you
asap

For questions only call: Ami Yares @ 247-9937 or Melissa Calabrese
@565-7969

MEETINGS WED NIGHT AT 9:15 at HILLEL 93 College Ave

Post ID:795
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 21:57:05
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Re: [ru_ignite] misunderstood
Message:

Actually you're wrong.
Voting does make a difference, especially on a local level.
Okay- There isn't much of a choice as far as the presidential race goes. I 
hate the two party system as much as I don't want Bush to become president.

You're not going to change the system from the top down anyway.

But you can change the corrupt system of government from the bottom up. You 
can vote and make a difference here in New Brunswick. In case you haven't 
heard the news yet- there are 3 candidates running for city council, who are 
backed by a 17 point platform, and have pledged to struggle against 
corporate corruption in New Brunswick.

You claim to be protesting the system by refusing to vote. Really you are 
just perpetuating the system and giving corporations the power to continue 
doing whatever the hell they want!

By voting you can protest corporate power (i.e. J&J) and change the system 
starting on a local level. You can't change the world in a day, it takes 
small steps, and seizing power on a local level is a step towards democracy, 
changing the corrupt system of government and taking power back from the 
corporate elite.

In Unity,
Audrey Allred


****************** On November 7th: ************************
Vote Line D for New Brunswick People's Campaign Candidates
Warren, Joseph and Morales

Vote YES for an Elected School Board!

*************************************************************

Post ID:798
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-03 10:15:45
Subject:Why Not to Mock the Vote
Message:

Hi folks,

I happen to think that you need to make the most out of situations, and to 
that end, many of us are working around the clock in the People's Campaign 
to win a city council election.

This campaign could break the back of a vicious machine which is responsible 
for terrorizing black and latino neighborhoods, throwing people out of their 
housing, denying an effective education and systematically stripping people 
of their money and dignity for over THIRTY YEARS!

We can win this election if people turn out. That means working people, 
especially oppressed people, have much to gain by voting. Locally. And 
students play a major role in this local election.

And now this show comes to town, with hip groups putting out decent 
messages. And a really big crowd is coming to see them. And much of that 
crowd may be thinking about how to vote. The People's Campaign will be 
engaging every possible person about their role this coming Tuesday because 
the future of New Brunswick depends on it.

Straight up, I think Mock the Vote is irresponsible towards local politics.

Further, these artists have worked years and years to perfect their art, and 
if you protest the event, you may as well protest their work.

If you're protesting the lack of progressive culture over the airwaves, I 
suggest you go out and sponsor some shows of your own that promote positive 
culture. What positive will come of this Saturday? Many of us in People's 
Campaign have worked for years to get where we are now and some folks think 
it's cool to fight the man by fighting every manifestation of corporate this 
and that. We can build relationships at this event and leave with 
substantive gains. Protest here will only promote the cynicism that keeps 
people away from the voting booth, which is what the corporations want. I 
say "Don't bite yourself in the ass"

Paul McGee, New Jersey Freedom Organization



_________________________________________________________________________

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:804
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-03 11:55:10
Subject:IMPERIALISM , CLASS WAR & THE NATIONAL ELECTIONS ,NOV 2000
Message:



>From: Amiri Baraka <ab11@...>
>
>Date: Thu, 2 Nov 2000 20:16:44 -0500
>
>IMPERIALISM , CLASS WAR & THE  NATIONAL ELECTIONS ,NOV 2000
>What is not ideologically distinctly defined, for all times, like the 
>"infinity" of idealism, lives in reality, as the practice of being, the 
>producer of ideas, politics, &c. So that Imperialism exists as a living 
>material dialectical paradigm. It is not simply the static book-"misread" 
>entity described by intellectually lazy Menshevik dogmatism, it is itself, 
>like everything else, developing, "rising", i.e. in a continuous motion, 
>its "ascending" -(like its concomitant "descending)_' aspect also the 
>process of clarifying, negating earlier characteristics, modifying, 
>changing, reaching a new stage of what it was having become what it is, as 
>is becomes again, was.
>	So that Imperialism which "rises" from competition, to monopoly, 
>reconfigures as here reaching elsewhere creating a larger here. The 
>monopoly aspect which competition become, rises further, always, and 
>becomes again competitive, even while never eliminating competitiveness 
>when it becomes in the main monopolist.
>	Now again the monopolist character, which remains, again is launched into 
>a competitiveness on a higher level, here, broader, more ubiquitously 
>itself> One nation monopoly which became the base of imperialism, itself is 
>victim to itself enlarged. Monopoly competes with monopoly to become more 
>expansive and its competitiveness becomes more expansive, likewise 
>expanded.
>        The era of Imperialism  "is that stage in which the domination of 
>monopolies and finance capital has established itself.....The (economic 
>partition of the world among the international cartels has begun. The 
>international cartels, which dominate the world market..."Lenin quoted from 
>"Imp The Highest Stage...in Politcal Economy p85 .It is the era also in 
>which "the export of capital has become extremely important". (That's what 
>the computer and Internet are really for!)
>        So Imperialism , through its continuous internal and 
>context-modifying motion, like cancer, cannot halt. It must be halted by 
>negation that completely transforms it into another character, albeit one 
>contained in its earlier phases. The socialization of labor which 
>capitalism began, intensifies in monopoly, expands in its international 
>imperialist aspect, socializes world labor, in its economic tendency and as 
>well, politically, through annexations, wars, coups, "alliances", 
>associations, organizations, and technological "advance", now begins to 
>crush the Hereness of itself altogether. Its Hereness becoming the 
>omnivorous internationalist Allness that includes Hereness and Thereness as 
>Everywhereness.
>                So that single nation monopoly can no longer exist 
>stablely. It becomes part of a larger monopoly through competitiveness, 
>which has never ceased. And even as Imperialism the world possessing 
>continues, so its origins the smallest competitive initiatives of commodity 
>production continue. As a fueling of the expansion, at the same time, part 
>of its "food"
>                 Imperialism's "globalization" (The New World Order) is the 
>stage at which national sovereignty is jerked and shoved and digested, by 
>law bribes, violence, so that it is diminished by the economics and 
>politics of its relationship to the imperialist engine and form. So 
>Imperialism will rule the world above the national form just as it rules 
>economically above any national economic or political form. In this sense 
>globalization is just an international form of Privatization.	Today, more 
>and more, Private entities WTO, NAFTA, IMF, &c run the economy of the 
>world, and merely pass it through the nations as parts of their grand 
>market.
>\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
>NADER-GREEN PARTY EMERGE AS A SUBURBAN CHAUVINIST  RIGHT WING LIBERAL 
>PETTY- BOURGEOISIE  & WAGE CLASS WARFARE AGAINST THE WORKING CLASS ,  
>OPPRESSED NATIONALITIES, WOMEN , WITH  "LEFT" PHRASE MONGERING  & 
>METAPHYSICAL  "BOYCOTTISM"
>               Gore and Bush conflict around the use of public moneys 
>because Gore represents bank and industrial capital and the superstructural 
>combination, that shapes US monopoly, but as a bulky associate of world 
>monopoly in its more "rational" as the present mode confirmed by 
>International Finance Capital) international mores and forms.  Gore would 
>not take money out of the public coffers at the same rate as Bush, because 
>Gores economic ideological base profits from the revenues in public 
>institutions. Banks, Insurance Companies. Trusts, Bureaucracy, Wall St, 
>Money Managers, Trade Revenues.
>	Bush is Oil, Cheney Oil. Annexationist, more reactionary since they ride 
>the oil juggernaut which still proposes an "independent" US power, as the 
>White Cowboy Savage of Free Western  (hemispheric and US factual mythology) 
>Post European Christendom. Like the mad general in Dr Strangelove, they 
>want to ride the big bomb of oil as the single back offense of an 
>invincible, sanctified ground game.
>             Bush would take more public funds because the privatization he 
>projects is into the interests, which bulk big oil. The international 
>politics, ironically, would use Israel as long as the oil is safe, like 
>Olivier in Marathon Man, "Is it Safe?" But if Arab political upsurge began 
>to dominate, Bushites would, like the British, after they gave permission 
>through Rothchild for the Zionists to take Palestine, switch their 
>allegiance without a blink. Do the American Jews realize this? The Zionists 
>are determined this will never happen, but by their action not their trust.
>	But the fact that Bush thinks the US is still in a position economically, 
>politically, militarily, to be the independent Tarzan of the world, 
>reflects a nostalgia
>Imperialism that is most vicious because it is outdated and the main 
>economic institutions think is dangers. Otherwise, why would the NY Times, 
>W Post, S Ledger, &c back Gore? Prosperity is here, don't mess with it, 
>don't fix what don't need, &c. Although they do admire the massive appetite 
>Bush projects, part of that belongs to the present associations and 
>alliances of international finance capital. And they understand they are 
>not Tarzan, anymore, even collectively, but more h's Supreme Court 
>appointments would overthrow Roe v Wade, making Abortions illegal, "You 
>cant really predict how Supreme Court justices will behave...." . He tops 
>this disgusting dismissal of practical politics by confirming that he has 
>no understanding of Democratic Struggle and is objectively in opposition to 
>the needs of Blacks, Latino's, Women, Gays, when he says of Roe v Wade, 
>that if Bush did overthrow it, "it would just revert to the states". 
>Apparently not understanding or not caring that one of the most consistent 
>of Democratic struggles of the Afro American People, Immigrants, Women, &c 
>is the fight against STATES RIGHTS Long used by Racists and Right Wing 
>Politicians to oppose democracy!
>	This fig leaf of opportunism masquerading as militancy is torn away by the 
>projected results of their dangerous vaudeville.  But also, most 
>graphically, by Nader, &c dismissal of the actuality of U.S. Imperialism, 
>and the needs of the working class and oppressed peoples, instead he 
>laughingly acknowledges that his "campaign" could elect Bush2  This is not 
>serious to him and them , because such National Liberal Chauvinists 
>actually have no real fundamental problems with Imperialism and National 
>Oppression, except it could be more efficient and they should be able to 
>get a big time job helping it to be that way, if those dumb guys only 
>understood!
>       Both Nader, a consumer advocate, a militant decorator of imperialism 
>desiring to paint its toe nails so it looks civilized, and The Greens, 
>petty bourgeois largely white suburban political drop-outs. No longer with 
>even the political relevance of the anti war movement, but those upgraded 
>"flower children" of the 60's communes who now can sell us tea or hip soap 
>or charming ice cream, or become respectable professionals, (stale Yippies 
>in suits) whose main gripe is WHAT? The Environment. Like the NJ Green 
>Senatorial Candidate, Bruce Afran, who says he "would be proud" to 
>contribute to rich Democrat Jon Corzine's defeat.
>(Even though Corzine's platform is more progressive and more relevant to 
>the working class and oppressed nationalities.) This Green Man's main 
>platform plank: "SAVE THE WETLANDS!"
>	This performance by Nader and The Greens shd effectively identify them as, 
>objectively, the right wing of the rural petty bourgeois. Those not 
>involved with saving Animals, rush to save the wetlands. While the plight 
>of the working class, entrenched now perilously in the cities, they 
>undermine and oppose, with ingenuous rhetoric and self-glorification as 
>"independent progressives". Both lies.
>	It is to be noted that this sector of the rightist liberal  petty 
>bourgeois suburban yuppies and buppies are the pioneer settler group the 
>Bigs are sending into the urban centers, like Newark, Harlem to reclaim 
>them for the Corpses as settlements and bed-room communities for their  
>young middle management hopefuls.
>	In fact, in the same NYTimes article quoted above, we find out that even 
>though Nader criticized Gore for having stock in the huge Occidental Oil 
>Corp, NADER TOO, HOLDS STOCK IN OCCIDENTAL. He sanitizes this by saying, 
>"The key is whether you fight the company you have money in".
>	Bush is even buying ads for Nader to defeat Gore. But where are the Black 
>issues or working class issues in detail in Nader's campaign? Aside from 
>the wooden Indian lady he says is his running mate (has anybody seen her?) 
>what aspects of Nader's campaign have addressed the issues of the working 
>class, farmers or oppressed nationalities?
>	Are the Maxine Waters, Donald Paynes, John Conyers, .....&c Congressional 
>Black Caucus (as undependable as they are) to be undermined, particularly 
>those holding or scheduled to become Chairpersons of major Congressional 
>committees to support an  aging Yippie?  Nader and The Greens must be held 
>responsible, along with the irresponsible, opportunists, or ignorant social 
>democrats, as well as the various sub rational Trots, Anarchist deviants, 
>and newly costume black supermilitants frenziedly pimping attention, if the 
>oil savage, Bush 2, get in.
>	IN EFFECT, THE NADER GREENS ARE WAGING CLASS WARFARE AGAINST THE WORKING 
>CLASS AND DEMOCRATIC MASSES. As such, they are allies of the far right! 
>Just as the Trots were when they undermined the Spanish Republic by 
>opposing the Popular Front with a traitorous rhetoric as "Anti-Stalinist" 
>leaders of an fantasy "Proletarian Revolution", dismissing the actual 
>political reality that the Spanish republic was facing fascism and must use 
>the Popular Front even to maintain the hollow democracy of a Bourgeois 
>Republic.
>	As backward as Clinton, &c are, the right lurch of the used to be liberal 
>democrats. They are Border States, Tennessee and Arkansas. Gore and 
>Lieberman, added to assure the Jews they are with them even though they 
>want to cool out the Middle East with some rosy settlement and redivision 
>of profits. (Its My Money, yells oily Bush)   ...Bush Cheney represent a 
>backward still more backward step, at this point just before another mass 
>upsurge can begin.
>	The fake Boycottism of the NaderGreens, in any real practical form, should 
>only be used when there is a mass political upsurge, the boycott meaning to 
>prevent the reintroduction of a past reform as alternative to the upsurge. 
>But at the low ebb of the movement, not to use what tools, such as 
>electoral politics to reverse the retreat, is criminally irresponsible, the 
>ignorance of a brainless mouth, or the evil self possessed immorality of a 
>"Bad Seed".
>	Between A SERIAL KILLER AND A PROSTITUTE is how the presidential election 
>can be shown in metaphor. So the genuine Left, because it has not yet 
>created a viable Anti-Imperialist United Front and the electorally 
>effective LEFT BLOC, Lenin spoke of ("March Separately, Strike Together!") 
>is bookended between the liquidationist Social Democrat based Nader Green 
>suburban, petty bourgeois, white gangster rap and the battery run juvenile 
>delinquent infantile leftism & political swindling of the 
>trot-anarchist-super-black minstrel militants. Just as it was after the 
>defeat of the 1905 revolution in Russia. Fleeing Intellectuals, Ex anti 
>imperialist petty bourgeoisie up-graded by bribes, disillusioned used to be 
>militants reconfigured as Preachers, newly moderate teachers, costumed 
>whores, traitors who are now negotiators for imperialism, various God 
>Builders and nostalgic husks explaining why they are on the other 
>side...now that they really understand how the doo doo.
>  Woiks.
>	Against all this we say, once more, REVOLUTIONARIES UNITE  WITH THE 
>WORKERS OF ALL NATIONALITIES, FARMERS, OPPRESSED PEOPLES AND DEMOCRATIC 
>MIDDLE FORCES, IN A UNITED FRONT AGAINST IMPERIALISM AND NATIONAL 
>OPPRESSION.
>
>	UNITE THE MANY TO DEFEAT THE FEW!! And for those of us still claiming 
>Marxism Leninism, Mao Tse Tsung Thought, Let us unite around the 
>revolutionary practice and theory of these great teachers and begin now 
>more earnestly and scientifically to LEAD THE REVOLUTIONARY COUNTER ATTACK! 
>TOWARD U.S. PEOPLES DEMOCRACY AND SOCIALISM!
>
>
>						AMIRI BARAKA 2NOV00

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:807
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-03 12:23:12
Subject:things heat up...
Message:

New Brunswick council race a sign that election can't come soon enough

Star-Ledger - 11/03/00
BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

Campaign sign disputes are nothing new in New Jersey, but yesterday the sign 
wars in New Brunswick took a turn for the weird.


A placard for three incumbent Democratic councilmen appeared on a fence 
outside the campaign headquarters of their archrivals, three independent 
candidates running as the People's Campaign.


And it's not going anywhere. Not legally, anyway.


The People's Campaign landlord is Peter Dalton, 32, owner of a property 
management company. Dalton gave a basement office to the populist upstarts 
for the last seven months, rent-free. Now he feels he has to give the town 
Democrats a plug, too, by letting them put a sign on his property.


If this nasty city council race were a tug-of-war, Dalton would be the rope.


Dalton, a personable sort, seems a little naive when it comes to dicey local 
politics. He graciously gave the People's Campaign free use of the basement 
office, thinking he was doing a favor for neighborhood chums.


Then the election drew closer, and heat came from all sides.


"The city doesn't like me now. They call me up and they tell me," said 
Dalton. "I got to work with the city, you know what I'm saying?"


His brothers, one of whom works as a school bus driver in New Brunswick, 
even chastised him for taking on City Hall. "They hate me because I got 
People's Campaign in my basement," Dalton said.


Arguments erupted between Dalton and his wife, who is convinced the city 
will take revenge on their business, he said.


"One time, she came in and wrecked the whole office," Dalton said. "The 
People's Campaign helped me clean it up."


One thing is for sure, Dalton said, the People's Campaign stays. He promised 
the group an office until Nov. 8, and he does not intend to kick them out.


"If I told somebody I'm going to do something I'm going do it," Dalton said. 
"I just got a good heart and I want to help people out. That's what I do. If 
the Democrats came to me first and said they wanted my basement, I would've 
helped them out first."


When the Democrats asked if they could put up signs on all six of the 
properties he owns in the city, including the office at 149 Redmond St., 
Dalton said yes. So as far as Dalton is concerned, the signs stay, too.


But People's Campaign candidate Keith Joseph, who is running with Curtis 
Warren and Diego Morales, said it's a little more complicated than that.


"This is a neighborhood I live in, and I don't think it's going to last very 
long," Joseph predicted, though he stopped short of saying just how it would 
disappear.


"It's a desperate move on their part to put their sign in front of our 
office," Joseph said. "They try to intimidate people into putting up their 
stuff, and I think it's because they have no support in the community."


Dalton said the city stopped short of intimidation. "They're not bullying 
me. But yet they're not doing any favors for me, either," Dalton said.


T.K. Shamy, the campaign manager for incumbent Democrats Joseph Schrum, 
Robert Recine and Jimmie Cook, said he has never been to the People's 
Campaign headquarters and did not set out to irk them with the political 
sign.


"Mr. Dalton is a supporter of ours. We asked him to put up some signs, he 
put up the sign." Shamy said. "His brother and I went to grammar school 
together. He's been a New Brunswick resident for years. It doesn't surprise 
me that they're supporters of the (Democratic) candidates."


But Dalton said he does not care to take sides.


"My back is up against the wall, really. I want to help both people," Dalton 
said. "I'm putting my neck out . . . I'm in a weird situation here."


It's bound to get weirder before Tuesday. The man who got himself in trouble 
by being too generous is trying to dig himself out with more generosity -- 
Dalton gave a $700 campaign contribution to the Democrats early this week.


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or at (732) 634-1236.


_________________________________________________________________________

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:813
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-08 13:03:19
Subject:Poll report W1 D 4,5
Message:

Perhaps each can report to the list from their site?

I was challenger in W 1, D4 and D5.

1. I counted the tickets that are taken at the polling machine for W1 D5 and 
they were 7 more than the votes that the machine registered - so 7 votes 
were lost.  The 2 poll clerks I worked there with let me count the tickets 
to be able to confirm this, and they confirmed my number. The machines are a 
pain because they dont seem to have a foolproof system.  There are 2 beeps - 
one before voting generated by the poll clerk to prepare for the voter and 
one after generated by the voter entering their vote.  If the voter forgets 
to press enter or the poll clerk spaces for a moment in high activity and 
doesnt clear the machine for the next voter (and we needed more poll 
clerks), then the votes seem to get swallowed. I was trying to keep track 
for the 2 beeps on each machine but things go so fast and once a beep does 
or doesnt happen you cant scroll back in time to check it again.  W1 D4 
didnt let me count their tickets at the end so I dont know about that. They 
told me that is not what I was challenger for, its just just for the 
individual voters, not checking the final tally.

Before I went to check the consistency between tickets and the machine I 
heard them discussing something about it.  I asked them is there a 
discrepancy.  They said no.  One challenger joked, your so worried about the 
big bad democratic machine.  So I went and checked it myself and it didnt 
work out.  Then they admitted there was indeed a discrepancy.

Once I was out of the room and came back and heard several beeps in a row.  
I asked them if they had heard it too.  The voter leaving the machine seemed 
confused about it.  They looked at me and said no, but it seemed hesitant 
and they didnt attack me for making that claim.

2. We had the bold "NO" self-made challenger badge situation, but it never 
got used at our site, it just lay on the table.  After the court decision on 
the day of the election that prevented them from using their own challenger 
badges within the polls (after it had been used already), one gentleman wore 
the approved NO badge in addition to his Democratic badge which was alot 
less obvious.

3.  There was a PTA bake sale going on within the 100-foot line of the 
polling site.  People were milling about. These folks were not openly 
electioneering.  Apparently they have done this several times in the past 
years.

4.  At one point there were 3 challengers for Recine.  They didnt seem to be 
aware of the rules.  Once I explained them they switched to become a 
challenger for Gore.

5.  The candidates Recine and Cook were audibly critical of our candidates 
to eachother within the polling site 3-4 meters from the polls. I dont think 
they realized this was wrong though.  They were just talking to the 
challengers.

6.  They had no idea what the terms of use of the provisional ballots were 
and at one point placed the ballot directly in the orange pouch with no 
envelope so that the poll clerk saw the votes.  I ended up going into the 
pouch to find the envelopes for them which I think was a violation.  There 
were also fuzzy rules around who could use the ballot.  I ended up using 
this test, "Did you register to vote in NB?"  Fuzziness was around if the 
person hadnt voted in years, also if they had moved to NB but their kids got 
new registration in NB and they hadnt and thought they had been transferred 
because their kids were via the high school registration, or if they tried 
to register after the 30 days and the MCBOE let them and gave them an ID 
number. In these cases we also gave them a ballot.

7. One woman didnt understand the school board ballot question and I 
explained what yes and no meant.  She wanted to file a complaint when I told 
here that was possible but the poll clerks said there were no complaint 
forms. Flavio was there at that time and we got them to search their forms.  
We found a complaint form but it was too late she had left.

8. Explanations of how to vote in the machine sometimes included pointing a 
bit of a  sweep down the Democratic line with a little here and there  so it 
was hard to pinpoint any obvious violation.  I had a hard time checking what 
they were doing when the poll clerks were explaining to people by pointing 
within the machine how to vote, since I couldnt see in well.

9. In general, with Flavios work we were able to establish some type of 
rationale at the site for orderly voting.

10.  Note on the walking lists which should have been organized by last 
name.

11. Since the day was such a family and friends affair, people were coming 
up and chatting with the challengers all the time.  I didnt challenge this 
because the challengers were already testy with me.
_________________________________________________________________________
Get Your Private, Free E-mail from MSN Hotmail at http://www.hotmail.com.

Share information about yourself, create your own public profile at 
http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:814
Sender:mikelong@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-08 15:23:06
Subject:Star Ledger Article - Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race
Message:

Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race 

11/08/00

BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

















It was politics New Brunswick- style, and it wasn't pretty. 


Three Democratic councilmen in the Hub City fended off a slate of independent People's Campaign candidates, winning by more than a 2-to-1 ratio. 


And the Democratic Party defeated a push to change the school board from a body appointed by the mayor to one elected by voters. 


In the process, the mayor's right-hand man allegedly punched a citizen activist in the face and frustrated Rutgers students who'd been turned away from the polls complained their votes were being suppressed. Democratic op
eratives were criticized for wearing illegal challenger badges into polling places. And city police officers worked overtime at the polls, prompting accusations they were there to intimidate potential voters. 


Perhaps the day's ugliest incident was in the morning outside the Lord Stirling School polling place, where Kevin Jones, an aide to Mayor James Cahill, argued with Joe Smith, an activist who advocated an elected board of 
education. 


Witnesses said Jones objected to Smith's standing too close to one of the Democrats' signs. The argument came to an abrupt end when Jones allegedly punched Smith in the face, drawing blood, police said. 


Police Director Michael Beltranena said Smith was at fault. "Smith assaulted Kevin Jones, Kevin Jones defended himself. They were both asked if they wanted to sign complaints; they declined to sign complaints," Beltranena
 said. 


Smith and witnesses friendly to him said Jones, who is considerably bigger than Smith, was the aggressor. 


Jones, who earns $40,000 a year for his city job, would not talk about the incident. "No comment. I'll see you after the election," he said. 


The incident was one of three run-ins with the New Brunswick police for Smith. Later, acting on an anonymous phone tip, they arrested him for failing to appear in North Brunswick Municipal Court for a speeding ticket Mond
ay. Before dawn he was arrested for allegedly throwing eggs at a group of men putting up Democratic election signs, a charge Smith denied. 


Meanwhile, at Lincoln School, near the Rutgers campus, many students trying to vote were rebuffed for a variety of reasons throughout the day. People's Campaign activists said there was a concerted effort by the city to s
uppress the unpredictable student vote. 


Michelle Shin, 21, a Rutgers senior, said poll workers sent her to four different polling places before she finally arrived back at Lincoln School, where she had gone originally, to vote. "It's like a trail of tears. I go
t out of class at 2:10, and it's 3:10 now," Shin said. 


Ron Gambone, 23, a Rutgers senior, said he registered five weeks ago, but he did not appear on the rolls at Lincoln, and he was forced to vote by paper ballot. 


"They should make sure registered voters get on that list," Gambone said. "Not voting on a machine makes me more wary, especially when they tell you your vote may not count (if your eligibility cannot be verified)." 


Robert Reck of the Middlesex County Elections Board acknowledged many students were encountering problems voting, but said they are often difficult to keep track of because they frequently change addresses. 


But People's Campaign activists did not believe the confusion at Lincoln School was unintentional. 


"We're investigating the filing of charges against the poll workers here. It's a pattern, it was a pattern when I was a student here 12 years ago," said attorney Flavio Komuves, who represents the People's Campaign. 


Democratic poll challengers at several sites wore badges advocating an appointed school board in the polling area until the county elections board forced them to remove the unofficial credentials after a hearing in the mo
rning. 


People's Campaign activists also complained that too many city police were stationed at polling sites. A 1985 federal consent decree -- prompted by charges that police were intimidating potential voters -- prohibits more 
than one officer per site, but up to six were at Lincoln and Lord Stirling at various times. 


Beltranena said he added officers to keep the peace after the 
confrontation between Jones and Smith. He said the consent 
decree allows him to increase the number of officers at stations if 
necessary. 


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or at (732) 634-1236.

Post ID:815

Subject:Re: [nbpc] Star Ledger Article - Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race

Sounds pretty gross. Thanks for your good work.

>>> <mikelong@...> 11/08 3:23 PM >>>
Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race 

11/08/00

BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

















It was politics New Brunswick- style, and it wasn't pretty. 


Three Democratic councilmen in the Hub City fended off a slate of independent People's Campaign candidates, winning by more than a 2-to-1 ratio. 


And the Democratic Party defeated a push to change the school board from a body appointed by the mayor to one elected by voters. 


In the process, the mayor's right-hand man allegedly punched a citizen activist in the face and frustrated Rutgers students who'd been turned away from the polls complained their votes were being suppressed. Democratic op
eratives were criticized for wearing illegal challenger badges into polling places. And city police officers worked overtime at the polls, prompting accusations they were there to intimidate potential voters. 


Perhaps the day's ugliest incident was in the morning outside the Lord Stirling School polling place, where Kevin Jones, an aide to Mayor James Cahill, argued with Joe Smith, an activist who advocated an elected board of 
education. 


Witnesses said Jones objected to Smith's standing too close to one of the Democrats' signs. The argument came to an abrupt end when Jones allegedly punched Smith in the face, drawing blood, police said. 


Police Director Michael Beltranena said Smith was at fault. "Smith assaulted Kevin Jones, Kevin Jones defended himself. They were both asked if they wanted to sign complaints; they declined to sign complaints," Beltranena
 said. 


Smith and witnesses friendly to him said Jones, who is considerably bigger than Smith, was the aggressor. 


Jones, who earns $40,000 a year for his city job, would not talk about the incident. "No comment. I'll see you after the election," he said. 


The incident was one of three run-ins with the New Brunswick police for Smith. Later, acting on an anonymous phone tip, they arrested him for failing to appear in North Brunswick Municipal Court for a speeding ticket Mond
ay. Before dawn he was arrested for allegedly throwing eggs at a group of men putting up Democratic election signs, a charge Smith denied. 


Meanwhile, at Lincoln School, near the Rutgers campus, many students trying to vote were rebuffed for a variety of reasons throughout the day. People's Campaign activists said there was a concerted effort by the city to s
uppress the unpredictable student vote. 


Michelle Shin, 21, a Rutgers senior, said poll workers sent her to four different polling places before she finally arrived back at Lincoln School, where she had gone originally, to vote. "It's like a trail of tears. I go
t out of class at 2:10, and it's 3:10 now," Shin said. 


Ron Gambone, 23, a Rutgers senior, said he registered five weeks ago, but he did not appear on the rolls at Lincoln, and he was forced to vote by paper ballot. 


"They should make sure registered voters get on that list," Gambone said. "Not voting on a machine makes me more wary, especially when they tell you your vote may not count (if your eligibility cannot be verified)." 


Robert Reck of the Middlesex County Elections Board acknowledged many students were encountering problems voting, but said they are often difficult to keep track of because they frequently change addresses. 


But People's Campaign activists did not believe the confusion at Lincoln School was unintentional. 


"We're investigating the filing of charges against the poll workers here. It's a pattern, it was a pattern when I was a student here 12 years ago," said attorney Flavio Komuves, who represents the People's Campaign. 


Democratic poll challengers at several sites wore badges advocating an appointed school board in the polling area until the county elections board forced them to remove the unofficial credentials after a hearing in the mo
rning. 


People's Campaign activists also complained that too many city police were stationed at polling sites. A 1985 federal consent decree -- prompted by charges that police were intimidating potential voters -- prohibits more 
than one officer per site, but up to six were at Lincoln and Lord Stirling at various times. 


Beltranena said he added officers to keep the peace after the 
confrontation between Jones and Smith. He said the consent 
decree allows him to increase the number of officers at stations if 
necessary. 


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or at (732) 634-1236.

Post ID:816
Sender:"Flavio Komuves" <komuvesfl@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-08 19:00:34
Subject:POLL REPORTS
Message:

*********************************************************************************
Confidential and Privileged.
Do not read if you are not the intended recipient.
Unauthorized use prohibited and taken at your own risk.
**********************************************************************************

I am pleased and impressed with the thoroughness of Zofia's report which will go a long way towards enforcing our promises to the community and the campus of zero tolerance for voter suppression.  

In that vein, I would like each of the thirteen poll captains to make similar reports for the express purpose of using them in litigation.  Make them soon while your memory is fresh!  I do NOT, however, want them posted on the group.  They should be sent to me and to Campaign Manager Xavier Hansen at Flavio.Komuves@... and xavier.hansen@..., respectively.  Others with knowledge of violations should also send reports of same to me and Hansen as stated above.  They should not be shared with anyone except other poll captains.

Please also give to me or Hansen all contemporaneous notes that you took that day, keeping a copy for yourself.

With that said, however, let me add some things:

1. When you refer to somebody, tell me their name, physical description and the capacity in which they were acting e.g. poll judge, democratic challenger, etc.  Since most poll workers were photographed or videotaped, tell me who did it and tell me the time they were photographed or videotaped.  (This is my sole criticism of Zofia's report and I will most definitely need such information).

2. When you refer to an event, tell me the time it occurred; if at a polling site, tell me what ward and district it occurred at.

3. Any repeated activity of electioneering by candidates, poll workers, or challengers inside should be reported.  I am not interested in a voter talking with a friend working the polls on an isolated basis; I want the repeat violators.

4. With respect to the provisionals, I need the list of the names and phone numbers or addresses of all persons who were given OR refused provisionals.  With respect to each, state: (1) why were they given a provisional, e.g. name not in the book, wrong address, etc.; (2) were they asked for ID?; (3) was ID presented, and if so, what was that ID; and (4) were they given a ballot or not?  Please also let me know the total number of provisionals for your ward and district.

5. With regard to white "no" ribbons (not the pieces of cardboard they were replaced with), give me the names or descriptions of all persons wearing or possessing them and the time when they took them off.

Thanks.

Flavio L. Komuves
General Counsel

Post ID:819
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-09 15:58:53
Subject:at least one elected board question passes...
Message:

This is interesting...


NY Times
November 9, 2000

Englewood Voters Approve Shift to Elected School Board
By MARIA NEWMAN

Voters in Englewood, N.J., decided on Tuesday that they wanted to elect the 
members of their school board, rather than continue to have the mayor 
appoint them.

The ballot measure was approved by a vote of 4,289 to 3,427 after a 
hard-fought campaign in which a group of homeowners, Concerned Residents of 
Englewood, told voters in frequent mailings and telephone calls that 
electing a board was the only way to improve the city's low- achieving 
schools.

"This is great tribute to democracy in Englewood," said Eugenia Vogel, a 
supporter of the ballot measure. "If you elect somebody to do the job and 
they don't do the job, then you vote him out of office."

But Mayor Paul T. Fader and another group, Englewood Citizens for Education, 
warned that changing the method of choosing board members would not 
guarantee better schools.

Englewood is the only school district in Bergen County with an appointed 
school board. Attempts to make the board an elected one failed here in 1975 
and 1980.

Mr. Fader said he was not surprised that the ballot measure was approved 
this time, especially because its supporters raised more than $28,000 for 
their efforts, according to election campaign records.

"It was clear to me it would pass," he said, "but it's also clear to me that 
it's not in the best interest of the city."

The mayor said he feared that only candidates with enough money to wage 
expensive campaigns would consider running for the board. He also said that 
voter turnout at school board elections was historically low in New Jersey, 
so a small and elite group of residents could end up deciding the board's 
membership.

But Mr. Fader said it was hard to compete with the pro-election campaign.

"It's very difficult to go out and tell the public they should vote against 
their right to vote," he said.

Englewood, which has a large wealthy community and high property taxes, has 
some of the poorest test scores in Bergen County, and almost half of its 
school-age children attend private schools.

The district has also been involved in a costly 15-year legal battle to keep 
a well-to-do neighboring community, Englewood Cliffs, from pulling its 
students � most of them white � out of Englewood High School, which is a 
disproportionate 97 percent nonwhite, and placing them in another public 
school.

Mr. Fader said the schools have improved since Dr. Joyce Baynes was named 
superintendent two years ago, and he said he thought those improvements 
would have continued under an appointed board.

"This group has not articulated any educational goals," Mr. Fader said. 
"They haven't talked about the need to reduce class sizes, which we've 
already done, or to create magnet schools, which we did. Now it's incumbent 
upon the people who have expressed an interest in education to articulate 
their vision for the schools.

"Some very wealthy people were willing to put a lot of money into this 
campaign for this measure," Mr. Fader said. "Was it their goal to improve 
education here, or just to cut the school budget? I guess we'll find out in 
the next two years."

Mrs. Vogel said the changes would not come immediately.

"Eventually they will get better," she said. "Not right away, but very soon, 
maybe in two years."

According to state law, the board will increase to nine members from its 
current seven. An election must be held in 60 days to elect the two new 
members. Elections will be held to replace the other members when their 
terms, which are staggered, are up. In about two years, the entire board 
will be elected.

Englewood was one of 19 school districts in the state that had an appointed 
school board, according to the New Jersey School Boards Association. On 
Tuesday, voters in New Brunswick rejected, for the fourth time in seven 
years, a measure to elect their board members. In Elizabeth, where voters 
have selected the school board since 1988, the City Council placed a measure 
on the ballot to return to an appointed board, but voters rejected the 
proposal by a 2-to-1 ratio.

Post ID:822
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-09 16:58:03
Subject:Targum letter today
Message:

In a letter to the Targum today, Rutgers College student Dana Caravela
discusses her difficulty voting, being turned away by poll clerks,
etc. She ascribes it to voter fraud and an attempt to keep students from
voting, and thanks Campaign people outside Lincoln School for telling her
about the provisional ballot, which she went back in and demanded. She
wants people who want to talk about voter suppression in NB to contact her
at caravela@eden. If someone already hasn't, Flavio, maybe you would want
to talk with her...

Charlotte

>> >   > Subject: Chicken crossing
>> >   >
>> >   >
>> >   > > Why did the chicken cross the road?
>> >   > >
>> >   > >   VICE PRESIDENT GORE: I fight for the chickens and I am fighting
>> >for
>> >   the
>> >   > >   chickens right now. I will not give up on the chickens crossing
>> >the
>> >   > road! I
>> >   > >   will fight for the chickens and I will not disappoint them.

>> >chickens
>> >   > across
>> >   > >   the road. I say give the road to the chickens and let them
>>decide.

>> >   > >   government needs to let go of strangling the chickens so they
>>can

>> >   > >   the road.

>>do

>> >   > >

>>question.
>> >   > >

>> >   > >   Did the chicken cross the road?

>> >   > >   Yes! The chicken crossed the road, but why it crossed,
>> >   > >   I've not been told!
>> >   > >
>> >   > >   ERNEST HEMINGWAY; To die. In the rain.
>> >   > >

>> >will be
>> >   > free
>> >   > >   to cross without having their motives called into question.

>> >road.

>> >   > >   told us that the chicken crossed the road, and that was good
>> >enough
>> >   for
>> >   > us.

>
