> >Date: Fri, 10 Nov 2000 10:33:15 -0800 (PST)
> >From: Ben Austin <sonofapalmbeachprecinctclerk@...>
> >Subject: My mother, Palm Beach County precinct clerk
> 
> the plot thickens...
> 
> >Dear friends,
> >
> >I don't normally send emails like this to a large block of people,
> certainly when it comes to my family, and certainly when the import
> of the
> issue makes it seem like the letter might travel far and wide. But so
> many
> people have asked about this story that it seems important to send it
> out.
> This is the true story of my mother, precinct clerk in Palm Beach
> county,
> Florida.
> >
> >My mother was a precinct clerk in Palm Beach county, Florida,
> election day
> of 2000. Mom's very good friend
> Leah was a precinct clerk as well. Both of them were incredibly upset
> during
> and after election day, before
> anyone knew the import of these specific voters. And my mother was
> convinced
> there were serious irregularities long before they gained national
> prominence, and she called me to say so.
> >
> >I note this because some Republicans are now asking if there were
> these
> irregularities, how come they were not raised until after the
> election? In
> fact, my mother and the other precinct clerks raised these issues
> from the
> moment that the polls opened in the morning; the problem is that the
> person
> they initially called on was Theresa LePore, elections supervisor of
> Palm
> Beach county. She was the source of the ballot confusion, and was
> uninterested in the issue.
> >
> >First, the paper ballot was extremely confusing to these voters.
> Although
> both major parties got a chance to review the card layout, it is not
> clear
> if any had a chance to put the actual ballot in an actual machine and
> punch
> the holes. The card is laid horizontally as you vote, and it is hard
> to see
> the holes as you punch them. And my mother, who supervised the
> precinct she
> was in (this is a paid position, and she reported directly to Ms.
> LePore)
> said the card did not even fit correctly in the ballot machine, so
> the holes
> in the card did not line up with the ballot.
> >
> >Anyone who thinks this was minor voter confusion has never dealt
> with
> retirees in a West Palm Beach retirement village in Florida, I
> promise you.
> >
> >My mother, following the rules, said the poll workers had been told
> not to
> help people with the cards, as it
> might bias the voters. My mother witnessed many, many people who
> voted
> incorrectly. Some stayed on a second
> line and had their cards re-done, some punched the second hole (and
> thus
> were probably thrown out), and some found out they voted for Buchanan
> after
> they had deposited their cards in the ballot box, and there was thus
> nothing
> they could do.
> >
> >Mom called me up to complain about this after the elction, and she
> called
> me up again on Thursday, very upset after reading a story in the New
> York
> Times (Nov. 9 2000, p. B6). The Times story states:
> >
> >After numerous complaints were received on Tuesday morning, Ms.
> LePore
> issued this directive to the county's 106 precincts: Attention all
> poll
> workers. Please remind all voters coming in that they are to vote
> only for
> one (1) presidential candidate and that they are to punch the hole
> next to
> the arrow next to the number next to the candidate they wish to vote
> for.
> >
> >Mom never received this directive, and she believes that if anyone
> knew
> they could have helped people vote
> their preference, the outcome would have been very different.
> Instead, my
> mother and the others were trying to do the right thing, and they
> felt that
> helping explain the ballot to these people would have been helping
> them to
> vote for Gore, something she didn't feel was proper. These women are
> honest
> to a fault.
> >
> >Leah did receive the directive, but not until 4pm on election day,
> and only
> by accident; someone was coming to visit from the main office and
> told her
> about it. In the mean time, my mother and Leah (and most of the
> precinct
> clerks) had been desperately trying to call the county office. They
> had been
> given a phone number by Ms. LePore and told that the phone line would
> be
> staffed throughout the day. They were told to call if there were any
> problems.
> >
> >Mom tried to call starting at 7:30am, calling straight through when
> polls
> closed, but she got a busy signal
> >the entire time.  But mom was at a polling station with only a pay
> phone,
> so she had to deposit coins each time, and with long lines waiting
> for her,
> she was becoming increasingly frustrated.
> >
> >Leah was precinct chief at the retirement village where they live,
> and ran
> a polling station at the clubhouse. Having a more modern facility,
> Leah
> tried on the phone as well, and when she couldn't get through, she
> called
> the operator to ask her why the phone was busy. Leah had the presence
> of
> mind to get the operator's number (history is made by people like
> Leah) when
> the operator told her the phone was off the hook, meaning nobody was
> on the
> line the entire day. Evidently, the supervisor's office just didn't
> want to
> hear the complaints.
> >
> >Leah then faxed the supervisor's office with her concerns at noon
> and again
> at 2pm. Nobody called Leah back until 5pm, when she heard from Ms.
> LePore,
> with the following words "don't bother me."
> >
> >So as this news starts to be spun and re-spun, let me tell you a few
> things
> I am certain to be true: -I can't argue intent either way, but the
> supervisor�' office in Palm Beach county is at the very least unable
> to
> carry out an election in which these people have their say
> >
> >-These people started trying to fix the problem from the moment
> polls
> opened, and were fought along the
> way. This is not about crying about the election once it is over.
> >
> >It pains me to see the issue being politicized by both sides. Gore
> has no
> place having his advisor Daley make
> statements that after a recount, Gore will emerge victorious; and
> Bush has
> no place saying that he is the
> victor, or setting up a transition team. In fact, the idea that Bush
> and his
> brother were together on election night, with Jeb Bush promising to
> "deliver
> Florida," draws a picture at least to me with the semblance of
> impropriety,
> especially now that we have seen the results so askew. I hope
> everyone will
> pay attention to the facts here, and let the people of South Florida
> have
> the same opportunity to vote that the rest of us had.
> >
> >You are free to send this to anyone you wish.
> >
> >Ben Austin
>

Post ID:853
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-15 12:14:39
Subject:Fwd: Bush family linked to Nazis-Sarasota Herald-Tribune 11/11/2000
Message:



>From: ARTISTpres@...
>To: undisclosed-recipients:;
>Subject: Bush family linked to Nazis-Sarasota Herald-Tribune 11/11/2000
>Date: Tue, 14 Nov 2000 17:56:27 EST
>
>Sarasota Herald-Tribune 11/11/2000
>http://www.newscoast.com/headlinesstory2.cfm?ID=35115
>  Author links Bush family to Nazis
>STAFF REPORT
>
>The president of the Florida Holocaust Museum said Saturday that George W.
>Bush's grandfather derived a portion of his personal fortune through his
>affiliation with a Nazi-controlled bank.
>
>John Loftus, a former prosecutor in the Justice Department's Nazi War 
>Crimes
>Unit, said his research found that Bush's grandfather, Prescott Bush, was a
>principal in the Union Banking Corp. in Manhattan in the late 1930s and the
>1940s.
>
>Leading Nazi industrialists secretly owned the bank at that time, Loftus
>said, and were moving money into it through a second bank in Holland even
>after the United States declared war on Germany. The bank was liquidated in
>1951, Loftus said, and Bush's grandfather and great-grandfather received 
>$1.5
>million from the bank as part of that dissolution.
>
>"That's where the Bush family fortune came from: It came from the Third
>Reich," Loftus said.
>
>Loftus made his remarks during a speech as part of the Sarasota Reading
>Festival. The author of "Unholy Trinity: The Vatican, The Nazis and the 
>Swiss
>Banks," Loftus documented the Swiss bank accounts that harbored funds
>confiscated from Holocaust victims and the participation of Italian priests
>in smuggling Nazi war criminals to safe haven in Canada, Central and South
>America and the United States after the war.
>
>Although he said he had a file of paperwork linking the bank and Prescott
>Bush to Nazi money, Loftus did not provide that documentation Saturday.
>
>Loftus pointed out that the Bush family would not be the only American
>political dynasty to have ties to the "wrong side of World War II." The
>Rockefellers had financial connections to Nazi Germany, he said.
>
>Loftus also reminded his audience that John F. Kennedy's father, an avowed
>isolationist and former ambassador to Great Britain, profited during the
>1930s and '40s from Nazi stocks that he owned.
>
>"No one today blames the Democrats because Jack Kennedy's father bought 
>Nazi
>stocks," Loftus said. Still, he said, it is important to understand these
>historical connections for what they tell us about politics today. The 
>World
>War II experience points out how easy it was then -- and remains today -- 
>to
>hide money in multinational funds.
>
>That money flows into American politics today, he said, from "a series of
>multinational corporations behaving like pirates. They don't care about
>ideology; they care about money."
>
>Loftus' speech left many in tears.
>
>"I am absolutely shocked," said Nancy Krauss of Punta Gorda. "I wish this
>would have come out before the election. My husband voted for Bush. I don't
>think he would have voted for him if he would have known."
>
>
>
>Sarasota Herald Tribune Newscoast newspaper florida bradenton Anna Maria
>siesta key St. Armands beaches myakka Charlotte North Port Venice Longboat
>Key Palmetto Tampa bay vacation resorts fun and surf

Post ID:854
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-15 12:25:42
Subject:Fwd: Bush May Appoint Giuliani AG By R Lederman
Message:



>From: ARTISTpres@...
>To: undisclosed-recipients:;
>Subject: Bush May Appoint Giuliani AG By R Lederman
>Date: Tue, 14 Nov 2000 16:52:12 EST
>
>Bush May Appoint Giuliani AG
>By Robert Lederman
>
>Want one more reason to strenuously resist GW Bush illegally
>becoming President?
>
>For the past two years I've been publicizing the idea that if
>elected Bush would appoint NYC Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as
>United States Attorney General. The latest confirmation of this
>comes from a 11/14/2000 Daily News article included below.
>My original source was a former close personal friend of the
>Mayor's who wants to remain unnamed.
>
>If Bush seizes power-it certainly won't be perceived that he was
>elected-he's going to need a tough Attorney General to fight off
>all the lawsuits, calls for impeachment and for a new election.
>He'll need someone who can trash the Constitution, crush
>protesters, blackmail political opponents and be willing to
>institute martial law with no justification.
>
>Giuliani was the #3 man in the cocaine-smuggling Reagan
>Justice Department and has long-standing ties to the very
>people the Bush family ultimately answer to at Rockefeller
>Center and the Manhattan Institute.
>
>On NY1 News former Mayor Ed Koch, commenting on the
>possibility of a Giuliani appointment, said Bush would not
>want a "tarantula" like Giuliani as AG. I disagree. It's exactly a
>tarantula he's going to need as his Consiglieri if he hopes to
>survive as President.
>
>For those who still believe Giuliani "cleaned up NYC",
>"crushed the Mafia" and made it, "the safest big city in
>America" you may soon have a rude awakening. Giuliani is the
>biggest criminal in New York and is the perfect complement to
>the Bush crime family. -RL
>--------------------------------------------------
>Daily News 11/14/2000
>  Giuliani Plays Coy In talk of Att'y Gen.
>
>By FRANK LOMBARDI
>Daily News Staff Writer
>
>Mayor Giuliani yesterday played down a report that he's on
>George W. Bush's short list for attorney general. But he
>stopped short of refusing to serve, if asked.
>
>"My desire is to fulfill my term as mayor of New York City,"
>Giuliani said of the report in yesterday's Daily News.
>
>Even without the suspense over who will become the next
>President, Giuliani said it would be premature for anyone to
>discuss presidential appointments.
>
>"You can assume that I'm going to be here as mayor of New
>York City" for the next 13 months, he told reporters when
>asked if he would accept a possible Bush appointment. "That's
>my desire. That's my intention."
>
>Giuliani's second term ends Dec. 21, 2001, and he is barred by
>city law from seeking a third consecutive term.
>
>When he dropped out of the Senate race in May, the mayor
>said, "I'm looking forward in my mayoralty. ...I want to
>improve it," — a position he has restated many times.
>
>He has often said he's not interested in working in a Bush
>White House. An appointment would be something of a
>surprise, because Giuliani has long had close ties to Bush rival
>John McCain. While Giuliani formally endorsed Bush, he
>never attempted to conceal his enthusiasm for the Arizona
>senator, who shares an independent streak with the mayor. In
>February — during the heat of the New York presidential
>primary campaign — Giuliani outraged Bush aides by refusing
>to allow his photograph or name to appear in an upstate Bush
>mailing that criticized McCain's record.
>
>It was not clear whether the factors that led the mayor to retire
>from the Senate race — his prostate cancer and his troubled
>personal life — would prevent him from seeking another
>office. He also has figured in speculation about the 2002
>governor's race.
>
>"I don't consider myself a candidate for anything," he said
>yesterday.
>
>Giuliani was the third-ranking official in the U.S. Justice
>Department under President Ronald Reagan and served as
>Manhattan U.S. attorney from 1983 to 1989.
>
>The mayor did have an opinion on the hand-counting of ballots
>going on in Florida. "I think that protracting this is dangerous,"
>he said.
>
>"I wish that George W. Bush is declared the winner," he added.
>"I voted for him. I supported him."
>
>In accordance with Title 17 U.S.C. section 107, the Daily News
>article above is distributed without profit or payment to those
>who have expressed a prior interest in receiving this
>information for non-profit research and educational purposes
>only.
>
>Robert Lederman, President of A.R.T.I.S.T.
>(Artists’ Response To Illegal State Tactics)
>ARTISTpres@...  (718) 743-3722
>

>http://Baltech.org/lederman/spray/

>http://www.openair.org/alerts/artist/nyc.html

Post ID:856
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 13:41:00
Subject:A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
Message:

A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . . 

Business and community leaders will meet to bring
accountable government back to Middlesex County 


Nov, 27, 2000 at 6:30 PM, East Brunswick Library


NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ -- Hardly a day goes by that some
credible individual or organization does not report on
the reckless disregard and wasteful spending of the
Middlesex County government. Having personal knowledge
of the corruption and collusion behind the Roosevelt
Care Center privatization fiasco, we are deeply
concerned that a band of incompetent and irresponsible
persons under the guise of government leadership can
operate arrogantly and defiantly -- not as proper
government representatives -- rather using the power
of government office in protection of their
self-interests. As an agent of the Federal government
once advised, Federal agents can not arrest County
officials for obvious stupidity. Perhaps not. However,
as taxpayers, we do have an absolute right to expect
responsible government accountable to its people. 

Everyone -- yes, its time to admit it, everyone -- in
the state of NJ is well aware of this County's
political stronghold. And it exercises improper and
undue influence on persons, media and businesses that
paralyzes constituents with fear, forever demanding
their loyalty, if they are to retain the County
government's favor, tax breaks, jobs, revenue or
contracts that the freeholders have selectively
awarded them. 

Enough. Middlesex County government is an atrocity and
begs to be brought down with accountability. It needs
to be investigated, its books audited, its conflicts
of interests exposed and a light of truth shined
behind its closed doors. We must undercover its
well-kept secrets that enriches its special interests
and impoverishes the rights and needs of every County
man, woman and child who has the audacity not to
contribute to the freeholders' Democratic Party
campaigns. 

We are asking -- indeed, we are expecting -- we are
believing -- that all companies and all persons who
have serious and valid concerns with the Middlesex
County Freeholders or Improvement Authority
commissioners will come together on November 27,
6:30PM at the East Brunswick Library and discuss
strategies on how we will legally hold these so-called
government leaders professionally and personally
accountable for their egregious acts. This "Call to
Arms" -- formidable representatives of business and
community interests -- will join hands and their
commitment to rid themselves of bad government. By
finally speaking out in protection of the common good,
we will symbolically empower people to stop sheepishly
dismissing what we have long known the County
government capable of doing. Bad government in
Middlesex County is no longer a laughing matter beyond
the taxpayers' ability to control. We can and will
restore good government to Middlesex County. 

All businesses or individuals committed to joining the
Middlesex County Call to Arms initiative, please
contact:
Patricia Nelson at Glendas House, An Affiliate of the
Association for Protection of the Elderly, Inc., PO
Box 7574, Princeton, NJ, 08543-7574
732-545-0304; Fax: 732-545-2519; e-Mail:
GlendasHouse@bigplanet.com.

Post ID:858
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 15:16:04
Subject:Model study: Contingent work as a cause of ethnoracial polarization of income in Toronto
Message:

From: 	Alice deWolff <alicedew@...>
To:	NYC7.GWIA("contingent-org@igc.topica.com","alicede...
Date: 	Thu, Nov 16, 2000  8:42 AM
Subject: 	[contingent-org] Toronto Study of Contingent Workers

*************************************************
This message sent via the contingent-org listserv
*************************************************

Toronto Organizing for Fair Employment (TOFFE) released this study yesterday. 
********

Breaking the Myths of Flexible Work 


A Study Conducted by the Contingent Workers Project 

Report Prepared by Alice de Wolff 



The realities facing Toronto workers in the "new global economy" are laid bare in this startling new study by the Contingent Workers Project. 

Breaking the Myths of Flexible Work provides a timely picture of the concerns of temporary, contract, part time and self employed workers across all occupations and industries. Approximately half the country*s workers are in non-permanent jobs. Sixty percent of the new "jobs" created in the last decade were contract self employment. In Toronto, many of the city*s newer immigrants are channeled into temporary work or low waged contracting, and this appears to be central to the ethno-racial polarization of income in the city. 

Breaking the Myths involved over 200 contingent workers. Flexible jobs are not meeting the needs of workers who participated in the study. A large proportion of contingent work is low waged, These workers have to carry more costs than people in permanent jobs. Most study participants did not receive sick leave, vacations, insurance, training or pensions from their employers. These workers, among the lowest income earners in the city, are taking the brunt of government and employer actions to "download" costs. Because they do not have full time jobs, many are not eligible for Employment Insurance and are not covered by Workers Safety Insurance. They are more likely to be hurt on the job; and the impact of irregular scheduling on workers* stress, health and caring responsibilities is significant. The study participants needed good information about their rights as workers, but more importantly, they wanted full time permanent work and collective action to promote fair working conditions.

For more information contact:


Deena Ladd, Toronto Organizing For Fair Employment (TOFFE), 416-531-0778

or 

Alice de Wolff, email alicedew@idirect.com

or

Download the Report from www.actew.web.net





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:859
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 15:16:02
Subject:News Flash - Important!
Message:

WASHINGTON, DC--Denouncing the American electoral process as "immoral and 
corrupt," President Clinton announced Tuesday that he will not step down on 
Jan. 20, 2001, declaring himself "President For Life."

Proclaiming Nov. 14 a new national holiday as "Day One of Americlintonian 
Year Zero," Clinton issued a directive of total martial law over "all 
territories formerly known as these United States, from now on to be called 
the Holy United Imperial Americlintonian Demopublic (HUIAD)." He added that 
all election results are "hereby invalidated under Demopublican provisional 
law."

"The American people have spoken," Clinton said. "By failing to generate a 
51 percent majority for either candidate, they have shown their inability 
to muster the drive to collective action. The time has come for a new 
America, a strong Americlintonian Empire, capable of providing the 
indecisive electorate with direction through one man's sheer force of will."

Dressed in full military regalia and flanked by members of his elite 
Demopublican Guard, Clinton told reporters, "Let all peoples of the land 
know this: The era of bipartisan inaction and paralysis has ended. The Age 
of the Great Cleansing Fire begins today."

A significant portion of the U.S. Armed Forces has sworn loyalty to the 
Imperial Demopublic Council of Generals, the new military wing of the 
Clinton regime. But despite such support, many political observers question 
the constitutionality of Clinton's actions, which include the burning of 
the Constitution, the dissolution of Congress, and the establishment of 
"re-education camps" in suburban D.C.

At a sparsely attended press conference, U.S. Attorney General Janet Reno 
raised the prospect of a Justice Department investigation of "possible 
illegal activities" on the part of Clinton. Most observers, however, 
believe that such a probe is unlikely: Less than an hour after Reno spoke, 
her battered and broken body was publicly fed to Clinton's dogs.

"Let them bring their pitiful reprisals to the impotent courts. Their 
lawyers and lawsuits shall face the wrath of a people united by the 
almighty fist," said Clinton, whose divinity as HUIAD's first Emperor-God 
was ratified late Tuesday night by the Americlintonic High Priest Council. 
"Let them recount their puny, paper ballots. They shall wither, as will the 
bankers, lawyers, and lobbyists all, before the Holy Cause of 
Americlintonia's glorious, righteous might."

Defiant in the face of objections from the Bush and Gore camps, Clinton has 
consolidated his power over the last several days, ordering armed takeovers 
of major federal buildings and the systematic collection and display of his 
enemies' heads on iron pikes.

In a test of the new regime's power outside the nation's capital, 
Senator-Elect Hillary Clinton, rechristened "Bride of The Lord Clinton On 
Earth," summarily ordered HUIAD troops to fire on Manhattan crowds, leaving 
more than 2,500 dead on Wall Street and quickly dispersing protesters loyal 
to defeated Republican challenger Rick Lazio.

Resistance movements are already forming. The new Legion Of Californians 
has sworn to defeat HUIAD in the west, and anti-Clinton groups have been 
reported across the U.S., including Naderist factions in Washington State 
and Maine.

Clinton has publicly dismissed such insurrections as "pathetic," confident 
that nothing will stem his authority over "the former U.S."

"The rebels are but mewling kittens who shall taste blood instead of milk," 
said Clinton, threatening to deploy HUAID-controlled nuclear weapons 
against members of resistance movements. "The holy power of the atom shall, 
if it must, cleanse this nation of all infidels."

Courtesy of:
http://www.theonion.com/onion3641/clinton_president_for_life.html





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:860
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 15:19:11
Subject:News Flash #2 - Important
Message:

BELGRADE--Serbian president Vojislav Kostunica deployed more than 30,000 
peacekeeping troops to the U.S. Monday, pledging full support to the 
troubled North American nation as it struggles to establish democracy.

"We must do all we can to support free elections in America and allow 
democracy to gain a foothold there," Kostunica said. "The U.S. is a major 
player in the Western Hemisphere and its continued stability is vital to 
Serbian interests in that region."

Kostunica urged Al Gore, the U.S. opposition-party leader who is refusing 
to recognize the nation's Nov. 7 election results, to "let the democratic 
process take its course."

"Mr. Gore needs to acknowledge the will of the people and concede that he 
has lost this election," Kostunica said. "Until America's political figures 
learn to respect the institutions that have been put in place, the nation 
will never be a true democracy."

Serbian forces have been stationed throughout the U.S., with an emphasis on 
certain trouble zones. Among them are Oregon, Florida, and eastern 
Tennessee, where Gore set up headquarters in Bush territory. An additional 
10,000 troops are expected to arrive in the capital city of Washington, 
D.C. by Friday.

Though Kostunica has pledged to work with U.S. leaders, he did not rule out 
the possibility of economic sanctions if the crisis is not resolved soon.

"For democracy to take root and flourish, it must be planted in the rich 
soil of liberty. And the cornerstone of liberty is elections free of 
tampering or corruption," Kostunica said. "Should America prove itself 
incapable of learning this lesson on its own, the international community 
may be forced to take stronger measures."

Courtesy of:
http://www.theonion.com/onion3641/serbia_deploys_forces.html

Subject:STOP THIEF! STOP BUSH!!!

>

STOP THIEF!  STOP BUSH!!! STOP THE RIGHT FROM STEALING THE COUNTRY!  
REMEMBER WATERGATE? NOW, FLORIDAGATE!

            The U.S. National Election has  provided a National Crisis. One 
of deeply serious consequences and  a profound demonstration of a new 
alignment of class forces. It is the principal task of revolutionaries now 
to Agitate and Communicate, in order to open further the gates of 
Revolutionary Struggle for Peoples Democracy (Majority Rule) as the next 
stage of struggle for Socialism.
The phrase -mongering of Nader-Green Nadirs exposes the objectively right 
wing stance of the Liberals. Objectively to the Right of  the Democratic 
party, the Congressional Black Caucus, the NAACP, Jesse Jackson, and even 
the Gore sector of the Bourgeoisie.
Jesse Jacksons candidacy, which these same Liberals, did not nearly so 
enthusiastically support was more advanced that the Nadirs,
because by running in the Democratic Primary, Jesse revealed both the 
strength of his constituency, and moved the electorate to the left. Dukakis 
just couldnt draw the voters he needed.

The Nadir-Greens,  by actually opposing the least reactionary sector of the 
bourgeoisie in the election , in the real world,  helped the most 
reactionary candidate and the rightist sector of the bourgeoisie to 
neutralize the peoples vote.  We must challenge the Nadir Green petty 
bourgeois Liberals to explain themselves and their intentions. Either they 
will join with the genuine anti-imperialist democratic movement to put 
together a mass electoral Left Bloc or they should be attacked, isolated 
so that their influence on the petty bourgeoisie and even the working class 
is gradual eliminated.

At this point these are some of the actions Revolutionary Democrats should 
pursue in opposing the Bush attempted Grand Larceny and Coup.

Letters, E-Mail, Faxes, Leaflets, Programs, Direct Communication to:
GORE and Democratic Party, Jesse Jackson, individual Congresspersons urging 
them to take the   election challenge to the hoop. To be unrelenting in 
their opposition to Bush Rip-Off!
To Reno, Justice Department,
Media , Media Personalities e.g.,., g Oprah, Gil Noble, Geraldo, Tavis 
Smiley Political and Academic stars   Glover, Black Newspapers, TV &Radio 
Programs,  Entertainer Stars Local and State politicians.  Other prominent 
Organizations COMMUNIST PARTY AND ALL ML AND SOCIALIST ORGANIZATIONS, 
Freedom Socialists, workers world,  Revolutionary Nationalists, other 
Oppressed Nationality Organizations RNA, APRP, APSO, NAACP, NATION OF ISLAM, 
AMERICAN MUSLIM MISSION,  BLACK UNITED FRONT, black radical congress, sclc, 
abc leo UNIONS, YOUR OWN AND OTHERS, COMMUNITY AND NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS, 
E.G., NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF NEGRO WOMEN,  BLACK JOURNALISTS, TEACHERS AND 
ARTISTS GROUPS,  to international contacts, u.n., oau, arab league, cubans, 
chinese, libyans, oas, student groups

Urging all to demand the uncovering of bush fraud and restoring of 
criminally removed votes and the election of gore based on popular vote, the 
elimination of electoral college, one person one vote, (including 
elimination of us house of lords, the senate and the creation of a 
unicameral (one congressional body) and the implementation of the 
parliamentary system where the smallest body of voters can be represented 
in the congress , (like most of the industrial democracies in the world) 
direct democracy, removal of all private monies from elections, automataic 
voter registration,
Initiate citizens suits and litigation against this election, the Electoral 
College, and for the removal of anti democratic aspects of US Political 
system.

+Make signs, leaflets, newsletters distribute and mail
+Hold programs
+Demonstrate at federal building
+Talk to people
+Revolutionaries take the lead. Revolutionary artists hit the community with 
graphics, poetry, plays, music, dances at all venues and in the street.

http://profiles.msn.com.

Post ID:862
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 19:42:39
Subject:Democracy for export, made in USA
Message:

From Cuba's Daily, Granma:


Democracy for export, made in USA

                   THE U.S. electoral crisis has produced unending amusement 
in Latin
                   America, where millions feel vindicated after many 
decades of U.S.
                   disdain for the so-called the "banana republics."

                   Except for a few exceptions, politicians south of the R�o 
Grande have
                   been hiding their sarcasm after the "technical draw" 
between Republican
                   George Bush and Democrat Al Gore, but the media has not 
ceased to
                   draw attention to the scandal which gives that democracy 
for export the
                   look of a banana republic.

                   A cable from the Spanish press agency EFE highlights some 
of the
                   commentaries from the Latin American press: in the 
Mexican daily
                   Reforma, the columnist Ren� Delgado pointed out that "if 
what had
                   happened in the United States were to happen in Panama, 
the Marines
                   would have already landed, ready to deal with the 
problem."

                   According to Gabriel Guerra Castellanos, another Mexican 
columnist,
                   "the entire world is laughing" at the United States and 
the crisis would be
                   funny if it wasn�t happening in the world�s most powerful 
country.

                   Neri da Silveira, president of the Brazilian electoral 
board, acting as an
                   observer at the U.S. elections, said that the U.S. 
electoral system is
                   "archaic and defective" and allows for fraud. "What 
struck me most was
                   the variety of voting and vote counting practices among 
the states. They
                   still use traditional ballot boxes and other obsolete 
equipment. Their
                   electronic ballot box is the size of a refrigerator."

                   Many have recalled the old refrain about "the only 
country on the
                   continent that has never had a military coup..." and now 
they are adding
                   the question: "Why doesn�t Washington have a U.S. 
embassy?"

                   There has been no lack of jokes about Latin American 
politicians with
                   questionable electoral ethics who have supposedly visited 
Miami to
                   advise its governor, Jeb Bush, brother of the Republican 
candidate.

                   "We Latin Americans would be delighted if an OAS 
delegation were to
                   arrive in the capital of Florida to supervise�naturally 
while trying to
                   keep straight faces�the revision of the U.S. electoral 
procedures,"
                   wrote Ra�l Gangotena in Quito�s El Comercio.

                   According to Panama�s El Universal, if what is currently 
happening in
                   the United States were to happen anywhere else in the 
world, "they
                   would have already set up a commission of observers 
making
                   declarations, sniffing out the vaguest shadow of possible 
fraud,
                   demanding precision, a recount of the votes and 
obligatory second
                   rounds."

                   Cr�tica Libre, another publication from that country, 
reminds us that when the
                   present candidate George Bush�s father was president he 
invaded Panama in
                   1989 to arrest General Manuel A. Noriega.

                   Many U.S. citizens could argue, as one U.S. correspondent 
for EFE did,
                   that the crisis is taking place in the most Hispanic of 
all the states,
                   Florida, with its millions of Latin American residents.

                   On other side of the world, the problem that has arisen 
in the "kingdom
                   of democracy" has not gone unnoticed. From Moscow ANSA 
reports
                   that a group of Russian delegates have offered to act as 
international
                   observers to oversee the U.S. elections.

                   The president of the Foreign Affairs Commission who 
proposed this
                   motion stated that, despite the fact that there is no 
chance of the
                   suggestion being approved by the majority of the Russian 
Duma, the
                   group, which calls itself In Defense of U.S. Democracy, 
have not lost
                   any occasion to ridicule the situation in Florida. After 
having received so
                   many lectures on democracy from Washington, they would be 
delighted
                   to return the favor.

                   While in the most technologically developed country in 
the world the
                   votes were being recounted by hand and the crisis is tied 
up in a legal
                   tangle for which the candidates are still continuing to 
amass revenues,
                   according to AFP one web surfer, frustrated by the 
lengthy process,
                   decided to advertise the presidency on the auction page 
of the website
                   E-bay which hurried to withdraw the advertisement 
entitled, "Become
                   president of the United States: presidency for sale."

                   The price of the presidency, after starting off at the 
value of a mere
                   cent, reached 100 million dollars. The requirements for 
participation in
                   the auction were that the bidder should be at least 35 
years of age, be a
                   U.S. citizen and not have a criminal record. But perhaps 
this is too much
                   to ask.

                                                                             
             � G.B.

Brooklyn Bridge


This is America.

Let*s make sure
every vote counts!

Sarah Ritchie

Post ID:866
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-17 16:54:04
Subject:Re: [nbpc] A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
Message:

should we send representatives? who else is involved?


>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpc] A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
>Date: Thu, 16 Nov 2000 13:41:00 -0500
>
>A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
>
>Business and community leaders will meet to bring
>accountable government back to Middlesex County
>
>
>Nov, 27, 2000 at 6:30 PM, East Brunswick Library
>
>
>NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ -- Hardly a day goes by that some
>credible individual or organization does not report on
>the reckless disregard and wasteful spending of the
>Middlesex County government. Having personal knowledge
>of the corruption and collusion behind the Roosevelt
>Care Center privatization fiasco, we are deeply
>concerned that a band of incompetent and irresponsible
>persons under the guise of government leadership can
>operate arrogantly and defiantly -- not as proper
>government representatives -- rather using the power
>of government office in protection of their
>self-interests. As an agent of the Federal government
>once advised, Federal agents can not arrest County
>officials for obvious stupidity. Perhaps not. However,
>as taxpayers, we do have an absolute right to expect
>responsible government accountable to its people.
>
>Everyone -- yes, it�s time to admit it, everyone -- in
>the state of NJ is well aware of this County's
>political stronghold. And it exercises improper and
>undue influence on persons, media and businesses that
>paralyzes constituents with fear, forever demanding
>their loyalty, if they are to retain the County
>government's favor, tax breaks, jobs, revenue or
>contracts that the freeholders have selectively
>awarded them.
>
>Enough. Middlesex County government is an atrocity and
>begs to be brought down with accountability. It needs
>to be investigated, its books audited, its conflicts
>of interests exposed and a light of truth shined
>behind its closed doors. We must undercover its
>well-kept secrets that enriches its special interests
>and impoverishes the rights and needs of every County
>man, woman and child who has the �audacity� not to
>contribute to the freeholders' Democratic Party
>campaigns.
>
>We are asking -- indeed, we are expecting -- we are
>believing -- that all companies and all persons who
>have serious and valid concerns with the Middlesex
>County Freeholders or Improvement Authority
>commissioners will come together on November 27,
>6:30PM at the East Brunswick Library and discuss
>strategies on how we will legally hold these so-called
>government leaders professionally and personally
>accountable for their egregious acts. This "Call to
>Arms" -- formidable representatives of business and
>community interests -- will join hands and their
>commitment to rid themselves of bad government. By
>finally speaking out in protection of the common good,
>we will symbolically empower people to stop sheepishly
>dismissing what we have long known the County
>government capable of doing. Bad government in
>Middlesex County is no longer a laughing matter beyond
>the taxpayers' ability to control. We can and will
>restore good government to Middlesex County.
>
>All businesses or individuals committed to joining the
>�Middlesex County Call to Arms� initiative, please
>contact:
>Patricia Nelson at Glenda�s House, An Affiliate of the
>Association for Protection of the Elderly, Inc., PO
>Box 7574, Princeton, NJ, 08543-7574
>732-545-0304; Fax: 732-545-2519; e-Mail:
>GlendasHouse@....

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:867
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-17 17:04:01
Subject:Re: [nbpc] A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
Message:

This is what Ive been able to get so far...
Glenda's
House
Please!!!
Copy this newsletter and pass
it along
to others.
Consumers fighting back
for the Roosevelt Care Center
        by Patricia Nelson	Contributor: Alex Wiener

Glenda's House is the NJ affiliate of the national non-profit advocacy organization, the Association for Protection of the Elderly, Inc., Lexington, South Carolina.  It speaks out in protection of elder and vulnerable adult rights and works tirelessly with legislators, judges, police, attorneys, interested companies and individuals to promote awareness, sensitivity and actions that stop the exploitation of elder and vulnerable adults.  In addition to its successful Elder Crime Offensive, Glenda's House takes particular interest in exposing criminal practices within the nursing home industry.




October 2000
Edison, New Jersey

 Why Roosevelt failed 	
	
The story behind Roosevelt Care Center continues in its promise to be as intriguing -- as it is bizarre.  And as we await the inevitable decisions that will formalize Roosevelt's long-term care (LTC) future, it is important to reflect on how this once- great healthcare facility was purposefully destroyed by what is now well-known political forces intent on its demise.
Every documented evidence has proven that the Middlesex County freeholders, their Improvement Authority commissioners (MCIA), and key players in Roosevelt's unions and administrative positions worked collusively and independently to bleed Roosevelt for their own purposes, exploiting it for their every need.
Roosevelt's current bleak standing is obvious proof that its intended operation was never about what was best for Roosevelt -- its residents -- or its extraordinary staff that for almost 60 years methodically built Roosevelt's reputation as a premiere NJ healthcare facility.  Rather, since 1994, Roosevelt has served as a political backdrop against which politicians and special interests have borrowed on their perceived credibility in order to promote false hope to County taxpayers that they would keep their LTC facility.  And, as they engaged their usual smoke screens, double-talk and misdirection to dissuade attention from who they were really serving while drafting Roosevelt's plans, these same self-serving people have personally collected on every advantage that Roosevelt would profit for them.
Purposefully bled dry, Roosevelt now offers no real advantages to benefit even the most greedy of special interests.  Except of course, for its land, which is the current prize almost within reach of the Democratic Party's campaign contributors * its commercial building contractors * who are now rabidly salivating for the land sales to come.

 How can we believe the Middlesex County freeholders or MCIA? 	
	
It is also clear that each egregious decision made over the past six years by the Middlesex County freeholders and MCIA commissioners reflected their desperate attempts to dump what they regarded as a dinosaur nursing home in a modern healthcare industry.  The freeholders and commissioners, particularly David Crabiel and Richard Pucci, enjoyed Roosevelt's earliest days, when it served the Democratic Party's purpose.  When Federal government monies were plentiful and fueled the County government's excesses with their overstaffing and poor management of Roosevelt, there was little need for accountability.  Money could be spent in a fiscally irresponsible fashion, allowing the County government to appoint staff and draft contracts for their cronies' services beyond Roosevelt's real needs.  Such appointments appeased the County freeholders' patronage mill, which hungrily demanded favors in return for the campaign contributions they provided. 
 However, as Federal monies dried up, the County increasingly had to subsidize lost insurance reimburse-ments from its own treasury.  And once Roosevelt's annual costs topped $21 million, a business consultant suggested privatizing (selling) Roosevelt for $40 million.  And it was with that financial advice the freeholders forgot their promise to their taxpayers to keep Roosevelt as a County-owned facility and thus they began their path to destroy the Roosevelt Care Center.
Before privatization could occur, Roosevelt had to be trimmed down from the excess financial fat the freeholders had built into it.  Needless jobs had to be eliminated and department services cut-back.  To accomplish these tasks, the freeholders needed a conduit, JFK Hartwyck (JFK), to serve as the slayers for the jobs.
The freeholders gave JFK the go-ahead and the necessary bloodbath ensued.  Although JFK seems to have followed sound business principles for bringing Roosevelt into financial feasibility, the relish with which JFK accomplished their tasks decimated the pride and morale within the facility.  Residents, staff and family members were left numb from JFKs kamikaze management style.  However, even with their success, JFK fell out of favor with the freeholders and once again, the County had to search for another nursing home management company.

Enter Solomon Healthcare

	Despite its well-known and dangerous practices for providing LTC services in Colorado (there was a 40- person class-action suit on record against Solomon for its egregious care when the freeholders were considering Solomon's services), the freeholders nonetheless hired Solomon Healthcare in their desperate attempt to rid themselves of a costly LTC facility. Solomon quickly took advantage of the freeholders' and commissioners' desperation * and their business naivete. They all entered into a 10-year management contract that would eventually be the County's undoing. Solomon soon arrived at Roosevelt, determined to enforce its holocaustic approach to LTC.  Staff, services and equipment were cut-back to bare minimums, exposing residents to potential crimes of abuse, neglect and wrongful deaths.  Havoc ensued * Roosevelt was in turmoil.  One such wrongful death occurred in November 1999 that led to the facility's admissions' closure.  Both residents and staff were under siege, yet the freeholders and MCIA did nothing to help.  Finally, Solomon would no longer tolerate Crabiel's reneging on contract 
payments and a multi-million dollar lawsuit was filed in US District Court.  Eventually, for $8.3 million dollars of Middlesex County taxpayers' money, the lawsuit finally settled * and conveniently for the freeholders * quietly went away.  
	
 The story about Royal 	
	
Coinciding with Solomon's depar-ture, the County government had to have another buyer for Roosevelt if it was to rid itself of its Solomon problem.  But a dilemma ensued, which caused the freeholders' serious concerns.  As it soon developed, no one was interested in buying Roosevelt.  Business leaders who considered the deal later explained that the freeholders' demands for Roosevelt's sale simply made no business sense.  (Ironically, the freeholders had already spent hundreds of thousands of dollars with *pay for players* Ernst & Young and the DeCotiis law firm to draft the sale's language * presumably for professional advice to achieve a successful result?  Not quite.)  However, these problems didn't faze the freeholders who were used to wasting taxpayer money to solve their personal problems (David Crabiel and Richard Pucci were both personally named on the Solomon lawsuit).  Calls were placed to the highest levels of the Democratic Party and a plan was quickly hatched.  If no one wanted to buy Roosevelt, then the County would pay someone to buy Roosevelt -- from them.
Like Solomon, Royal Healthcare also had a well-known and dangerous track record for LTC care.  Again, the freeholders were warned especially by this writer not to hire this substandard health-care provider.  In fact, Pucci, annoyed with this writer's public comments in opposition to Royal, shook his finger at her, praising himself for drafting a *superior deal.*  Subsequently, the freeholders --desperate to rid themselves of Roosevelt *nonetheless proceeded with the Royal fiasco.  
In the months that followed, the realities of Royal's true character and poor management practices became obvious.  Even its association with Michael Konig / Broadway Management, a known Medicaid defrauder who also had two of his other homes closed because of sexual assaults on residents, was not sufficient concern to dissuade the freeholders from turning Roosevelt over to these aberrant healthcare providers.  And despite all fanfare that Royal was Roosevelt's best answer, both the NJ Finance Board and the NJ Department of Health and Senior Services (NJDHSS), also declined to support the Royal deal.  The Board refused approval on the freeholders' needed bonds to finance Royal's services and the NJDHSS refused to license Royal's ownership.
Clearly, Pucci had not drafted the best deal for Roosevelt.  As the advocates proved, the deal was miserably flawed from the start.  Pucci therefore proved he had either no business acumen or he purposefully sold-out Roosevelt's best interests.  We believe Pucci sold Roosevelt out * at the freeholders' behest.  Their third management fiasco behind them, the Middlesex County freeholders now needed yet another management company to delay their decisions for Roosevelt until after November's elections.  After all, they had two boys up for freeholder re-election and they didn't want any Roosevelt decisions to offend anyone's vote.

 How can we believe JFK Hartwyck? 	
	
At a recent meeting of the Roosevelt Family Council, Thomas Lankey of JFK Hartwyck and John McGee of the Hartwyck's parent company, Solaris Health Systems, attempted to persuade Roosevelt's family members of JFKs *wait-and-see* approach for drafting Roosevelt's future.  Ostensibly, JFK has been hired for its short-term nursing home management expertise while it also gathers data to report on the feasibility of continuing Roosevelt as a LTC facility.  According to JFK, several issues are being considered.  Priority attention is on whether Roosevelt's current assets should operate as a facility licensed by the MCIA while managed by another company.  Or, in the alternative, should Roosevelt's existing buildings be demolished, building newer facilities elsewhere.  As this writer also pointed out, should the County simply discontinue operating Roosevelt completely?
John McGee, in a recent letter directed to the Home News, protested JFKs disparagement in the press and cited its exemplary record in its current LTC facilities.  Presently, JFK operates three LTC facilities in the Edison, NJ area.
Every nursing home management company, when faced with their track record for providing LTC services, are quick to point out the unfairness of citing 
what they characterize as *isolated* business and healthcare practices. When compared to providing for the daily needs of diverse * and often needy * populations, such criticism (they claim) is inappropriate.  Although there is merit in their arguments when evaluating minor violations, conditions that result in frequent personnel changes and resident abuse, neglect and wrongful death obviously point to serious quality of care issues and must be evaluated with due crisis.   Lack of standards require consumers to evaluate an LTC provider's professionalism and their ability to protect the civil and constitutional rights of nursing home residents in their care.
	Unfortunately, current law, much like domestic violence of 30 years ago, has not caught up to reality by recognizing that elders and vulnerable adults have the same rights of protection as any other non-institutionalized person. As a consequence, many LTC residents, when victimized by crime, have justice denied.  When LTC persons' rights are violated, nursing home owners, management companies, administrators and directors of nursing, who participate in purposefully providing egregious care conditions, should be arrested, jailed and prosecuted.  Current sanctions infrequently recognize that crimes are committed in homes.  And when they are recognized, crimes are more often dealt with as administrative routine than with the criminal justice they require.
Roosevelt's staff remembers JFKs conduct when it first managed Roosevelt in 1995 and the resulting chaos JFK orchestrated at the County freeholders' behest.  Recently, this writer reviewed JFKs three nursing home files available for public review at the NJDHSS.
It seems clear that if a nursing home management company represents itself to provide professional nursing home services, it should deliver.  I invite anyone considering JFK Hartwyck's LTC services to review these files in Trenton themselves.

 Towing the freeholders' lies 	
	
As one of the advocates who has successfully opposed the privatization of the Roosevelt Care Center, my files are littered with copies of documents that track the Middlesex County freeholders' past conduct and their probable final solution for Roosevelt.
It seems that when the freeholders' Royal Healthcare deal was exposed for all its flaws, the MCIA had finally had enough.  No longer willing to acquiesce to Crabiel's hair-brained schemes, they wanted an end to the Roosevelt fiasco.
The Royal Healthcare deal was a well-engineered scheme that required the unions' and administration's support if it was to succeed.  As we look back on how quickly the Royal deal was approved and vigorously defended by spokespersons from the unions * and even Ron Denti (Roosevelt's administrator) himself -- it was clear that everyone had to agree to the newest version of Roosevelt's privatization if the union was to keep its contract -- and if key administrative players were to keep their jobs.
The parade before the freeholder board's public meeting microphone was pathetic. Each union and administrative representative stood up on cue * at one point, they even desperately prevailed on Denti's secretary to speak * extolling the virtues of Royal Healthcare.  Was it not obvious to everyone they were expected * like circus acts * to perform on demand?
Both Denti and Frank Damiani, Roosevelt's then-operations manager, (never people to confuse concerns for quality healthcare in opposition to those who pay their $100,000 salaries) were clearly counted on to discredit any opposition to the Royal deal.  Denti had demonstrated his PR-on -demand abilities particularly during Solomon's tenure and even today * trying to sell the MCIAs religious revival of good faith management for Roosevelt. Damiani, Royal's then-spokesperson, despite months of publicly discrediting advocates who opposed Royal's obvious bad management, eventually acknowledged the advocates were right -- he left Royal's employ because of his admitted ethical concerns over their practices.  However, Damiani is now back again to manage Roosevelt under the guise of an MCIA employee.  Protests regarding his qualifications as being *best* for the job were typical of the freeholders' smokescreen tactics.  The freeholders just needed anyone available * preferably someone there before -- to keep Roosevelt steady until final solutions could be implemented for the dying facility now in the freeholders' way.

 The case for credibility 	
	
As the Middlesex County freeholders and MCIA commissioners cautiously await the November elections, they are also working silently behind closed doors to orchestrate Roosevelt's demise.  News of Roosevelt's future is hardly discussed in the press.   When the again publicly-humiliated freeholders asked Royal to leave (after only six-months into their MCIA-proudly negotiated contract), the freeholders required a new nursing home management company to help them quietly transition Roosevelt's short-term operations.  Why?  They needed to put Roosevelt in a holding pattern while they got their two cronies, Polos and Pulomena, re-elected to the freeholder board.  Once the elections were behind them, they would move to implement Roosevelt's final solution.  Yet even as all these things are occurring, you would think *for politically sensitive reasons * the commissioners would have demonstrated their lessons learned from their Solomon mistakes.  Unfortunately, they cared less.  For as the Middlesex County taxpayers eventually discovered, the MCIA * again * failed to actively monitor Royal's six-month management.  Each month, the MCIA turned over $2.3 million to Royal -- yet never demanded its accountability.  Royal secretly committed several egregious acts while it managed Roosevelt (Denti and Damiani, who witnessed Royal's unethical practices behind closed doors, said nothing).  And when Royal left in disgrace, it took with them almost $1 million in missed payroll and 90+ day overdue vendor bills.  Is it not obvious to all of us that neither the Middlesex County freeholders nor the MCIA commissioners are good stewards of their taxpayers' money?
And while all these things are going on, Denti is conducting his personal PR campaign to sell Roosevelt's residents, staff and families on the MCIAs newest decision to use JFK Hartwyck.  It doesn't seem to matter who tosses Ron a baton * with which to lead his present parade.  Today, in his newest metamorphosis as an MCIA employee, he is extolling Roosevelt's virtues based on the regulatory management of the NJ Department of Health and Senior Services, the same agency that presently (in October 2000) has Roosevelt closed to admissions because of problematic care.

 The NJ Department of Health and Senior Services (NJDHSS)  is broken 	
	
Denti would like consumers to believe that the NJDHSS is a highly reputable and reliable indicator for regulating NJs nursing homes.  In fact, he often cites the NJDHSS for its failure to substantiate advocates' concerns when they have filed numerous complaints against Roosevelt.  He would like consumers to conclude that since Roosevelt *mostly* passed its recent annual survey, and since most complaints filed against Roosevelt are recorded by the ombudsman and NJDHSS as *unsubstantiated,* there is clearly no reason for consumers to be *fooled*  by advocates whose only interest is *causing trouble* for Roosevelt.
Denti's comments are predictable in advocacy.  The first line of defense against advocates who annoyingly expose the truth * is to attack their credibility.  However, I feel it important to address Denti's smokescreen comments and his unflattering descriptions of the advocates who exposed the real debasement of the Solomon/Royal deals.  It would seem clear that any persons who could convince formidable agencies like the NJ Finance Board and the NJDHSS not to support a deeply entrenched Democratic Party County government's proposals * such advocates must have a respectable lobbying skill.  Add to this Wall Street's need to place Middlesex County's bonds on a negative rating watch because of their Royal financial fiasco * it would seem clear that the advocates are a credible adversary.
Unfortunately, considering the NJ ombudsman's and NJDHSSs qualifications and reliability for protecting the rights of institutionalized elders (well documented by Federal investigative agencies), the advocates are quick to assert that were it not for their advocacy, Royal Healthcare (despite its egregious LTC practices) would likely have been approved for Roosevelt's ownership.
Throughout the US, there is mounting concern for the quality of care found in 25% of our nation's nursing homes.  According to the US Government Accounting Office, the investigative arm of the Federal government, their March 1999 investigation of thousands of nursing homes over ten states conclusively proved that too many nursing homes have dangerous care standards. And their practices caused serious injury and needless death of residents.  (In NJ, this percentage would identify over 90 nursing homes housing 14,000 people daily.)
Coinciding with these reports (and numerous others done by the US Office of the Inspector General, the US Health Care Finance Administration, and the US Committee on Aging) Federal departments are also recognizing that each state's oversight agencies (in NJ, that includes the ombudsman and NJDHSS) are not meeting the standards of proper regulatory practices -- thus victimizing elders to egregious care practices.
As a researcher and writer, I often have opportunity to review nursing home files located at the NJDHSS in Trenton, NJ.  Having examined numerous files, tracking the dates a complaint is recorded, investigated and documented, I can attest that the quality of these files are problematic at best.  First, there is never consistency in the documents enclosed in each file.  Some files are missing important documents.  In nursing homes in which I know a complaint has been filed, I nonetheless find no information.  Documents signed for accuracy are missing important data.  Any researcher must therefore conclude from the condition of these files that many can not be considered accurate or complete.  
In examining complaints, the disparity in dates between the time a complaint is filed and when it is *investigated* is usually days, weeks * even months -- apart.  In cases when crimes of abuse or neglect are committed, clearly crime scenes thus have ample time to be cleaned, leaving the *investigator* with nothing to review * hence, yielding an *unsubstantiated* complaint.
These typical file conditions were just as compelling when I reviewed Roosevelt's files and the 38 complaints found in its folder.  Remarkably, of the 38 complaints filed, only two were substantiated.  (Outrageously, Roosevelt's media-circus exposure of Solomon's diaper debacle was a complaint also found *unsubstantiated* by the NJDHSS.  The reason?  Upon examination of the complaint, this writer determined that the investigator investigated * yes * the wrong zone.)  Both the outrageous quality and occurrence of these so-called  *investigations* can not help but conclude complaints as *unsubstantiated,* especially for Denti's and Damiani's alleged violation of the Code of Federal Regulations on June 19, 2000.
Roosevelt's Family Council held its first meeting on June 19.  Per its rights by Federal law, it declined to invite Roosevelt's administration, consisting of Denti and Damiani, then under Royal's watch.  Apparently, their then-boss, Surbhi Tarkas, was manic in her need to infiltrate the Family Council meeting.  Despite heated protests directed at both that they were violating CFR483.15 and were repeatedly asked to leave, both Denti and Damiani persisted in remaining.  Finally they left, but Denti proceeded to interrupt the meeting twice more.
Complaints were filed with the NJDHSS and its administrators' board for each man's alleged violations of Federal law.  After investigation, which solely consisted of the investigator asking Denti and Damiani if they were invited to the meeting (to which they obviously said *yes*) the investigation was concluded and the complaint found *unsubstantiated.*  What???
Outrageously, the NJDHSS failed to seek out over 30 family members  present at the meeting who witnessed Denti's and Damiani's bullying tactics and this writer's repeated advisement of their violations of Federal law.  Clearly, the NJDHSS failed in its mandated duty to properly, completely and credibly -- investigate this complaint.
If regular police investigations followed practices similar to the NJDHSSs complaints, crime scenes would never yield clues to convict accused criminals, there would be insufficient evidence for arrests, and few persons would ever be held accountable for their egregious acts.  I doubt that such conditions would ever be tolerated if corporate assets were involved.  Yet these insane investigatory practices are conducted daily in NJs nursing home complaint investigations (because elders do not have significant economic impact). Thus, any NJDHSS complaint investigation is problematic at best and likely can not be relied on for accuracy.  The most that present complaint documentation can serve is to point to the probability of bad care in homes * and in the rare instances that fines are assessed, consumers must wait years for fines to be collected, if at all.
Therefore, consumers can not be persuaded by Denti's positive assertions over the NJDHSSs findings.  We have seen the quality of care conditions that have existed in this facility when operated by egregious healthcare companies Solomon and Royal.  We have all witnessed the short-staffing.  We have sadly watched the forced departure of many faithful and long-time Roosevelt employees. We have wretched on the quality and choice of food served to Roosevelt's residents.  We have seen how depraved indifference * on the part of numerous *officials* surrounding Roosevelt -- has systematically destroyed a once-great healthcare facility.  Knowing Roosevelt's past as we do, we simply can not tolerate Denti's pathetic attempts to characterize Roosevelt's past or current operations as a testament to *management's* caring and supportive environment.  Roosevelt's residents, family members and staff are very intelligent people and they recognize that the County government and its administrator lackeys have persistently done a self-serving * and very bad job * in operating Roosevelt.

 The land for the two licenses 	
	
In a recent Home News article, the Middlesex County freeholders were given opportunity to grade their performance for managing the Roosevelt Care Center.  They gave themselves a *C.*  Considering the enormous pain and suffering the freeholders caused hundreds of lives (which was totally avoidable had they taken their responsibility to Roosevelt seriously) the opposing advocates would not even give them an *F.*  Actually, we would not even give them a gold star for coloring within the lines.
Considering that the freeholders had full knowledge of the dangerous backgrounds of the healthcare providers they recklessly hired, it is outrageous that they would reflect on their Roosevelt performance in such an infantile fashion.  During JFKs, Solomon's and Royal's tenure, chaotic and egregious care con-ditions contributed to the environments that led to the abuse, neglect and wrongful death of several residents and purposefully damaged the lives of many staff.
However, as always with the Middlesex County freeholders, Roosevelt was never about the quality of patient care or its promises to its staff.  It was about positioning Roosevelt's valuable property out of the hands of healthcare -- and into the hands of Democratic Party campaign contributors anxious to develop Roosevelt's land.
As we have already discussed in this newsletter, Roosevelt is presently in a holding pattern until after November's elections.  The Middlesex County freeholders felt (that for political reasons) a delay in Roosevelt's decisions was necessary before announcing Roosevelt's final solution.
Let's not pretend that JFK is presently evaluating the facility.  Their presence simply serves the freeholders' delay * providing *justification* and *due diligence* in pursuing Roosevelt's final solution.  We know that JFK did not enter its current agreement without purpose.  It, too, has its own agenda.  With news of Royal's departure, JFK wished to explore the ownership of  Roosevelt's licenses.  Coincidentally, JFK also wants to build LTC facilities.  However, since certificate of needs, necessary for building any LTC facility in NJ have not been issued for several years by the state, JFK had to locate existing licenses if it was to realize its plans to build new facilities.
The Middlesex County freeholders have publicly and repeatedly announced that they don't want to be in the LTC business.  And as their actions proved, they desperately tried to rid themselves of Roosevelt when they concocted their foolhardy Solomon and Royal deals. As plans to privatize Roosevelt eventually fell through when the freeholders' foolhardy schemes were exposed, the Democratic Party's plan to position Roosevelt's land began to take on more urgency.  In January 2000, the Middlesex County freeholders made a quiet change in Roosevelt's property deed.  When once it was stipulated by deed that Roosevelt forever remain a healthcare facility, the new changes made in the d

>>> "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...> 11/17 4:54 PM >>>
should we send representatives? who else is involved?


>From: "Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@uniteunion.org>
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com 
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com 
>Subject: [nbpc] A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
>Date: Thu, 16 Nov 2000 13:41:00 -0500
>
>A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . .
>
>Business and community leaders will meet to bring
>accountable government back to Middlesex County
>
>
>Nov, 27, 2000 at 6:30 PM, East Brunswick Library
>
>
>NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ -- Hardly a day goes by that some
>credible individual or organization does not report on
>the reckless disregard and wasteful spending of the
>Middlesex County government. Having personal knowledge
>of the corruption and collusion behind the Roosevelt
>Care Center privatization fiasco, we are deeply
>concerned that a band of incompetent and irresponsible
>persons under the guise of government leadership can
>operate arrogantly and defiantly -- not as proper
>government representatives -- rather using the power
>of government office in protection of their
>self-interests. As an agent of the Federal government
>once advised, Federal agents can not arrest County
>officials for obvious stupidity. Perhaps not. However,
>as taxpayers, we do have an absolute right to expect
>responsible government accountable to its people.
>
>Everyone -- yes, it s time to admit it, everyone -- in
>the state of NJ is well aware of this County's
>political stronghold. And it exercises improper and
>undue influence on persons, media and businesses that
>paralyzes constituents with fear, forever demanding
>their loyalty, if they are to retain the County
>government's favor, tax breaks, jobs, revenue or
>contracts that the freeholders have selectively
>awarded them.
>
>Enough. Middlesex County government is an atrocity and
>begs to be brought down with accountability. It needs
>to be investigated, its books audited, its conflicts
>of interests exposed and a light of truth shined
>behind its closed doors. We must undercover its
>well-kept secrets that enriches its special interests
>and impoverishes the rights and needs of every County
>man, woman and child who has the (audacity not to
>contribute to the freeholders' Democratic Party
>campaigns.
>
>We are asking -- indeed, we are expecting -- we are
>believing -- that all companies and all persons who
>have serious and valid concerns with the Middlesex
>County Freeholders or Improvement Authority
>commissioners will come together on November 27,
>6:30PM at the East Brunswick Library and discuss
>strategies on how we will legally hold these so-called
>government leaders professionally and personally
>accountable for their egregious acts. This "Call to
>Arms" -- formidable representatives of business and
>community interests -- will join hands and their
>commitment to rid themselves of bad government. By
>finally speaking out in protection of the common good,
>we will symbolically empower people to stop sheepishly
>dismissing what we have long known the County
>government capable of doing. Bad government in
>Middlesex County is no longer a laughing matter beyond
>the taxpayers' ability to control. We can and will
>restore good government to Middlesex County.
>
>All businesses or individuals committed to joining the
>(Middlesex County Call to Arms initiative, please
>contact:
>Patricia Nelson at Glenda s House, An Affiliate of the
>Association for Protection of the Elderly, Inc., PO
>Box 7574, Princeton, NJ, 08543-7574
>732-545-0304; Fax: 732-545-2519; e-Mail:
>GlendasHouse@....
>

Post ID:868
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-17 17:28:46
Subject:this is funny
Message:

"Politics Explained"

A little boy goes to his dad and asks, "What is politics?"

Dad says, "Well son, let me try to explain it this way: I'm the
breadwinner of the family, so let's call me capitalism. Your Mom,
she's the administrator of the money, so we'll call her the
Government. We're here to take care of your needs, so we'll call you
the people. The nanny, we'll consider her the Working Class. And your
baby brother, we'll call him the Future. Now, think about that and
see if that makes sense,"

So the little boy goes off to bed thinking about what dad had said.
Later that night, he hears his baby brother crying, so he gets up to
check on him. He finds that the baby has severely soiled his diaper.
So the little boy goes to his parents' room and finds his mother
sound asleep. Not wanting to wake her, he goes to the nanny's room.
Finding the door locked, he peeks in the keyhole and sees his father
in bed with the nanny. He gives up and goes back to bed. The next morning, 
the little boy says to his father, "Dad, I think I
Understand the concept of politics now." The father says, "Good son,
tell me in your own words what you think politics is all about." The
little boy replies, "Well, while Capitalism is screwing the Working
Class, the Government is sound asleep, the People are being ignored
and the Future is in deep shit."
_________________________________________________________________________

http://profiles.msn.com.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:869
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-17 21:59:48
Subject:Re: President
Message:

***
--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, Louise Ammentorp <lknesta@i...> 
wrote:
The arguement that Jeremy makes is somewhat common. My mom told me 
she heard Cokie Roberts (I don't know if that how to spell her name) 
make a similar arguement. I think that it needs to be addressed.  The 
only thing that I can say about it without doing more study is that 
usually the protection of the minority from tyranny of the majority 
has little to do with protecting national or ethinic minorities and 
more to do with protecting the property owning minority.
***

I don't think that (to protect minority groups) was the design of the 
Electoral College, as Federalist #68 makes clear (which I think Matt 
posted up on the NJFO list).  Judged by the reasons it was designed, 
it's a ridiculous antique.  

I think the only relevant question is a simple empirical question.  
Are the least powerful, and at the same time the least reactionary 
parts of the U.S., going to gain or lose influence if the Electoral 
College is eliminated?  

Since the Electoral College is almost historically _meaningless_, I 
don't think any values, any class issues, are substantially bound up 
with it.  It amounts to a tradition almost for tradition's sake.  It 
just is.  It only becomes an issue of value when the question is posed 
as to whether it should not be.  I think this is somewhat different 
from debates over the party system and Proportional Representation, 
where it can be argued that a two-party system is in the interests of 
stagnation and the maintenance of an economic elite.  

> NJFO is orgainizing a discussion/study group on the electorial 
> college.  On friday dec. 1.  The idea is to come together to look at 
> the history and the various lines on the electorial college.

What would you be looking at, specifically?

Post ID:870
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-20 09:25:14
Subject:Answering Kris' Q
Message:

rom:
        Patricia Nelson <glendashouse@...> Save Address - Block 
Sender

As for your question --

At this point, it is anyone's guess who is coming.  I have seen a lot of
interest from diverse people, backgrounds and organizations.  I can only
emphasize to all who are thinking of attending -- this is not a hidden,
subversive political plot -- no matter how Crabiel wishes to characterize
this effort.  It is my meeting -- and I guarantee that my intention is to
bring people from any background in one room to join together in strength
and commitment to bring accountability to this government -- period.  With
that said, there will be persons from political parties there -- but that
does not mean it impacts as a "political event."

Some folks that I know are coming are some advocacy groups from Highland
Park, the NJ Trust Guild, Republicans, Green Party folks, Roosevelt
advocates, Edison police reps.

I'm really looking forward to a lively meeting.

Patricia Nelson
GlendasHouse@...

Post ID:873
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-21 11:22:57
Subject:Re: Dollar a Dance?
Message:

THE PALM BEACH POKEY

You put your stylus in,
You put your stylus out,
You put your stylus in,
And you punch Buchanan out.
You do the Palm Beach Pokey
And you turn the count around,
That's what it's all about!

You put the Gore votes in,
You put the Bush votes out,
You put the Gore votes in,
And you do another count.
You do the Palm Beach Pokey
And you turn the count around,
That's what it's all about!

You bring your lawyers in,
You drag the whole thing out,
You bring your lawyers in,
And you put it all in doubt.
You do the Palm Beach Pokey
And you turn the count around,
That's what it's all about!

You let your doctors spin,
You let the pundits spout,
You let your retirees sue,
And your people whine and pout.
You do the Palm Beach Pokey
And you turn the count around,
That's what it's all about!

>From: Amnesty Campaign <prolibertad99@...>
