>Leonard Peltier is an Indigenous rights activist who
>has been unjustly imprisoned for over 24 years despite
>the total lack of evidence against him. He is
>considered by Amnesty International to be a political
>prisoner who should be "immediately and
>unconditionally released." Formerly withheld evidence
>casting serious doubt on Mr. Peltier's guilt forced
>the government to admit that they could not prove who
>was actually guilty of the crime he was convicted of
>and yet, he remains behind bars. Because he was
>unfairly targeted due to his key role in the American
>Indian Movement, Leonard Peltier is widely seen as a
>symbol of the US government's attempts to silence
>those seeking positive change for Native communities.
>Rigoberta Menchu, the National Congress of American
>Indians, the Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and the Dalai
>Lama are only a few of his respected supporters. Now
>Leonard Peltier is facing the most critical time ever
>in his campaign for freedom and indeed his life. His
>only chance for a near future release lies in the
>hands of President Clinton through a grant of
>Executive Clemency. Now is the time for us to send a
>positive and united message that Leonard Peltier
>should be free. December 10 will mark the anniversary
>of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Come
>join the Leonard Peltier Walk For Freedom and help
>begin the process of truth, reconciliation, and human
>rights for the Native Peoples of this land. Gather in
>Union Square at noon. Walk to Dag Hammarskjold Plaza
>at the United Nations where a program of speakers,
>cultural activities, and traditional music will be
>presented from 2pm-4pm. For updates call the NYC
>Hotline: 212-539-6027. Join us!
>TRUTH AND RECONCILIATION FOR INDIGENOUS PEOPLES BEGINS
>WITH:
>THE FREEDOM OF LEONARD PELTIER

Post ID:880
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-27 17:11:39
Subject:Re: FYI
Message:

 
Monday's letters to the Home News Tribune 


Published in the Home News Tribune 11/27/00
Appointed school boardis failing city students

The role of political patronage in New Brunswick's appointed Board of 
Education is appalling. A clear example is the landlord who felt pressured to 
evict an independent political group once it became public knowledge the 
group was granted free space from him. He said he had to evict them because 
he had to work with the incumbents or suffer the consequences.
If the Board of Education were doing a good job, members would welcome 
outside scrutiny. They could run for office and be elected on their merits. 
The taxpayers would have some say in administering the moneys that are 
available for education. Perhaps we would choose to bring back school bands, 
orchestras, field trips beyond the confines of New Brunswick and salaries 
comparable to those of neighboring districts. The citizens of New Brunswick 
are willing to pay for quality education. Now we get a "tax bargain" with 
bloated supervisory staff. I hope all the people who felt cheated at the 
polls will hold these "re-elected" individuals accountable. Let's demand 
genuine honesty, community control and democracy. 

Ruth Bickhardt
NEW BRUNSWICK

Post ID:881
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...

FYI,

Donna Best has a letter to the editor. She is printed as having great hopes 
for NB in the Home News Tribune Poor School Special that ran last year. 
Unfortunately, the City has rode roughshod over the community based 
management team at Woodrow Wilson, as reported in her letter to the editor, 
today ( and in the past by People's Campaign literature.). She sounds as if 
she is as determined as ever. As history has shown, the NB BOE has been able 
to discourage a vast majority of parents from getting involved.

I would print the letter but it doesn't appear on-line.

Frank





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:882
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-28 09:09:29
Subject:Re: NBPD Director Quits
Message:

New Brunswick police director decides it's 'time to move on' 

11/28/00

BY SUE EPSTEIN
STAFF WRITER





















New Brunswick Police Director Michael Beltranena announced his retirement 
yesterday after 27 years with the department, the last seven as the city's 
top cop. 


Beltranena, 49, the department's first Hispanic director, said his last day 
on the job will be Thursday. 


"It's time to move on," he said. "I've been preparing myself for this moment 
for the last several years. It's very difficult, but you know when it's 
time." 


Mayor James Cahill made the formal announcement yesterday from his office, 
flanked by Beltranena and the man who will replace him, Joseph Catanese, who 
has served as deputy director since earlier this year. 


Cahill said Beltranena "has served this city extremely well," citing several 
accomplishments during the director's time in office. 


"There has been a 34 percent drop in overall crime with a drop of nearly 57 
percent in juvenile arrests since 1993," when Beltranena became director, 
Cahill said. 


The department also grew from 122 members in 1993 to 140 officers, many of 
whom have been used in preventive programs in the city's schools, the mayor 
said. 


Cahill also credited Beltranena with establishing a good rapport with city 
residents through bicycle patrols and the creation of an office of police 
community relations. 


Beltranena said the recent conviction of two of his veteran officers for 
operating a brothel in the city played no role in his decision to retire. 


"My decision was actually made before the investigation . . . began," he 
said, referring to Detective James Marshall and Sgt. Marco Chinchilla. The 
two are facing 10-year prison terms when they are sentenced in January. 


Beltranena said he plans to remain in law enforcement in some capacity and is 
considering "several opportunities." He would not elaborate. 


"I want to spend a lot of time with my family and refocus my energies," the 
South Brunswick resident said. 


He said he is proud to have brought more diversity to the department by 
adding more African- American, Hispanic, Asian and female police officers. 


Beltranena joined the force in 1973 and was promoted to captain and chief of 
operations in January 1993. He was given the top job in July 1993 after the 
early retirement of the acting police director, who caused some friction in 
minority communities by deploying a police canine unit on a street-corner 
crowd. 


Catanese, 40, is an 18-year veteran of the department and a life- long New 
Brunswick resident. He holds a law degree from Seton Hall and a master's 
degree in public administration from the John Jay School of Criminal Justice. 


He said he wants to expand the programs Beltranena introduced, including the 
bicycle patrols and training for police officers. 


Sue Epstein is a reporter in the Middlesex County bureau. She can be reached 
at sepstein@... or (732) 634-4222.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:883
Sender:xadx <xadx@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-28 12:00:17
Subject:Re: [nbpc] NBPD Director Quits
Message:

here's the article from the targum which provides _some_ new details:

Police director retires after 27 years in service



                                                 By Sally Goldenberg
                                                 Senior Writer


                                                 New Brunswick has seen a 34 percent
drop in crime and nearly a 57 percent drop in
                                                 juvenile arrests since 1993. Since
1990, the city�s police department has diversified its
                                                 staff, increasing the number of Asian
officers from two to three, Black officers from 10
                                                 to 20, Hispanic officers from five to
10 and female officers from one to four. The
                                                 number of officers on the force has
also risen, from 113 in 1991 to 140 presently.

                                                 These changes, along with what many
city officials call an improved partnership
                                                 between the city and its residents,
were overseen by New Brunswick Police Director
                                                 Michael Beltranena, 49, who has
served on the force for the last 27 years. But
                                                 Beltranena has passed the torch to
40-year-old Deputy Director Joseph Catanese,
                                                 Mayor Jim Cahill announced in his
office in City Hall yesterday afternoon.

                                                 �It�s time to move on to the next
chapter in my life,� Beltranena said. �It�s a decision I
                                                 feel is good for New Brunswick, the
New Brunswick Police Department, my family
                                                 and myself.� He added that while the
decision to retire was a difficult one to make, he is
                                                 confident that Catanese will
adequately fulfill his new role.

                                                 �I am very confident that Director
Catanese will live up to the expectations that he has
                                                 set for himself,� Beltranena said.
�I�ve watched his career from the very beginning. He�s
                                                 an excellent police officer. ... I
feel very comfortable retiring and leaving the police
                                                 force in his hands.�

                                                 Beltranena spent his time with the
department in several capacities. He was appointed
                                                 as police sergeant in 1982, police
lieutenant in 1986, police captain in 1993 and director
                                                 of police in July of 1993.

                                                 �I am going to miss it,� he said.
�It�s like leaving home.� Based on New Jersey law as it
                                                 applies to police and fire officials,
Beltranena said a retiree can collect pension after 25
                                                 years of service with no minimum age
requirement, so he will begin collecting his
                                                 pension Dec. 1.

                                                 His future plans entail continuing
work in the field of criminal justice, he said,
                                                 emphasizing that his retirement will
allow him to spend more time with his family.

                                                 In continuing Beltranena�s
aforementioned accomplishments, Catanese said he plans to
                                                 expand on the developing partnership
between the community and the NBPD and the
                                                 Drug Abuse Resistance Education
program, to name a few of his goals.

                                                 �This opportunity means more to me
than anyone can imagine,� he said. �We are
                                                 committed to New Brunswick�s future.�

                                                 Cahill, who appointed Catanese, said
the 18-year veteran of the police department and
                                                 lifelong resident of New Brunswick
has an extensive background in the force. Catanese
                                                 joined the department in 1982, was
promoted to police sergeant in 1988, police
                                                 lieutenant in 1993 and police captain
in 1998. He became deputy director earlier this
                                                 year and will begin his new position
effective Friday.

                                                 Citing his educational
accomplishments, Cahill noted that Catanese is a 1989 University
                                                 alumnus and received a master�s
degree in public administration in 1995 from the John
                                                 Jay School of Criminal Justice and a
juris doctorate from Seton Hall School of Law in
                                                 1999, the same year he was admitted
to the New Jersey Bar Association.

                                                 He added that his retirement is not
related to the recent conviction of two New
                                                 Brunswick police officers, Sgt. Marco
Chinchilla and Detective James Marshall, who
                                                 were found guilty last month of
operating a brothel in the city.

                                                 �The trial played no part in my
decision,� he said. �My decision was made long before
                                                 the trial,� he added, noting that he
began planning for his retirement prior to the
                                                 investigation.

                                                 In response to some residents�
criticism of corruption in the police department � and the
                                                 recent conviction � Beltranena said
the department is far from corrupt. He added that
                                                 during the course of the
investigation for Marshall and Chinchilla, the Middlesex
                                                 County Prosecutor�s Office followed
all leads for the department and found no other
                                                 officers guilty of any charges.

                                                 �That trial would not have occurred
had it not been for the integrity of the New
                                                 Brunswick Police Department,� he
said, noting that it was NBPD officers who
                                                 essentially reported on the illegal
actions of the convicted officers.

Post ID:886
Sender:"No One Important" <dontlabelme89@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-30 06:44:39
Subject:1st Anniversary of Victory in Seattle Commerated By Local Anarchists
Message:

PRESS RELEASE 11/30/2000

In the early morning of November 30th, 2000 we, as anarchists, hung black
banners of negation across the city of New Brunswick, New Jersey.  We also
turned the American flags in front of the courthouse and city hall upside
down. These actions were done, first, as a signal of the distress and dismay
of many people at the brutality, illegal arrests, intimidation, and media
suppression of the large numbers of people who came to Seattle, Washington
on November 30, 1999.  These people were present to publicly demonstrate
their disagreement with the World Trade Organization (WTO), globalization of
economies, attacks against labor and health standards, and capitalism itself
at last year's meeting of the WTO ministry.  These activists succeeded in
shutting down their meeting.  The WTO is an undemocratic organization of
corporations that enforce "free trade" agreements globally.

These flags, which were hung in sympathy and outrage, are also symbols of
anarchist pride and optimism which commemorate the victory of our sisters
and brothers in Seattle.  With these actions a new movement was born - one
which showed the WTO that people will no longer tolerate their oppressive
actions.

Finally, we remember the court cases in Seattle that are still pending, as
well as those cases that have been resolved unjustly.  For these current
injustices we continue to offer our support and solidarity.

Anarchists are a non-violent, compassionate and dedicated group.   If it
were not for the systemic crisis of the emerging nations and the existence
of coercive governments worldwide, we would not have to exist. While we cry
for our own pain and losses sustained in actions which we freely
participated in in order to fight the systems which never fail to put
profits before people, we also perform all of these actions in memory of the
most direct victims of global capitalism.  These people do not choose their
oppression. These include all the people of the developing nations, who are
increasingly abused by sweatshop labor, relocation, destruction of their
environment, as well as all the victims who lost their lives to police
brutality were detained or tortured worldwide over the past year of 2000.

We, as anarchists, will continue to perform our actions boldly, with love
for all humankind and confidence in the righteousness of our beliefs.  So
long as our existence continues to be made necessary by the oppressive and
demeaning presence of capitalism and its violently coercive agents, we will
never cease in our actions.

_____________________________________________________________________________________
Get more from the Web.  FREE MSN Explorer download : http://explorer.msn.com

Subject:Film: "This is What Democracy Looks Like"
Message:

The Greens informed me re: the following showings of a film that is being shown independently around the country.  This film relates to the globalization of the economy.  Anyone seen it?

Saturday:  showing at 8PM "This is What Democracy Looks Like"
Where:  Charas Community Center, Manhattan, between B and C 
        avenues on 9th St.
The Greens are meeting at 5.30 
at the New Brunswick train station to go to this.

There is also a showing Friday night, 282 Broadway (Brooklyn) at La Familia
(JMZ lines?) that starts at 7.00, documentary at 8.00.

Subject:1st Anniversary of Victory in Seattle Commerated By Local Anarchists
Message:

PRESS RELEASE 11/30/2000

In the early morning of November 30th, 2000 we, as anarchists, hung black 
banners of negation across the city of New Brunswick, New Jersey.  We also 
turned the American flags in front of the courthouse and city hall upside 
down. These actions were done, first, as a signal of the distress and dismay 
of many people at the brutality, illegal arrests, intimidation, and media 
suppression of the large numbers of people who came to Seattle, Washington 
on November 30, 1999.  These people were present to publicly demonstrate 
their disagreement with the World Trade Organization (WTO), globalization of 
economies, attacks against labor and health standards, and capitalism itself 
at last year's meeting of the WTO ministry.  These activists succeeded in 
shutting down their meeting.  The WTO is an undemocratic organization of 
corporations that enforce "free trade" agreements globally.

These flags, which were hung in sympathy and outrage, are also symbols of 
anarchist pride and optimism which commemorate the victory of our sisters 
and brothers in Seattle.  With these actions a new movement was born - one 
which showed the WTO that people will no longer tolerate their oppressive 
actions.

Finally, we remember the court cases in Seattle that are still pending, as 
well as those cases that have been resolved unjustly.  For these current 
injustices we continue to offer our support and solidarity.

Anarchists are a non-violent, compassionate and dedicated group.   If it 
were not for the systemic crisis of the emerging nations and the existence 
of coercive governments worldwide, we would not have to exist. While we cry 
for our own pain and losses sustained in actions which we freely 
participated in in order to fight the systems which never fail to put 
profits before people, we also perform all of these actions in memory of the 
most direct victims of global capitalism.  These people do not choose their 
oppression. These include all the people of the developing nations, who are 
increasingly abused by sweatshop labor, relocation, destruction of their 
environment, as well as all the victims who lost their lives to police

We, as anarchists, will continue to perform our actions boldly, with love 
for all humankind and confidence in the righteousness of our beliefs.  So 
long as our existence continues to be made necessary by the oppressive and 
demeaning presence of capitalism and its violently coercive agents, we will 
never cease in our actions.

Hi, all

a public meeting tonight for all Middlesex residents
concerned about ongoing community justice problems.

Nov. 30- Thursday, 7PM, 
Victorian Manor 
2863 Woodbridge Ave in Edison.  
Community meeting hosted byAsst Prosecutor Cindy
Glaser... on community justice problems in the county.
 Ms. Glaser received a $38k grant to conduct 3 public
meetings to take public input & help develop 
some programs.

It looks like the meeting will be tightly
controlled...Buster Soaries will be speaker.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:891
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-30 14:05:25
Subject:Re: FYI
Message:

 
Judge transfers case of election-day clash 


Published in the Home News Tribune 11/28/00
By J.P. WHITE
STAFF WRITER
NEW BRUNSWICK: Election-day clashes between community activists and city 
workers will not be settled in New Brunswick Municipal Court.

Yesterday, Judge Gerald Gordon said he was transferring the case out of New 
Brunswick because city employees are involved. A new court date and location 
has not been set.

Mayor James M. Cahill's aide Kevin Jones faces charges of harassment and 
assault for punching Joseph Smith in the face on Nov. 7 outside the polling 
station at the Lord Stirling School.

Smith was the coordinator of the Campaign for an Elected School Board, the 
group behind a ballot referendum that could have changed the mayor-appointed 
school board to an elected body.

But Smith faces similar charges by Jones, who contends Smith brought on the 
attack.

Outside the court room yesterday, Smith claimed accusations against him are 
false -- "that I provoked him (Jones) into punching me in the head."

Smith said he confronted Jones outside the Lord Stirling School polling 
station after he saw Jones wearing an illegal ribbon that called for 
residents to vote "No" on the school-ballot question.

Jones refused to talk about the incident until it is resolved. Jones' 
attorney, Anthony Vignuolo of Borrus Golden and Foley in North Brunswick, 
also would not comment yesterday.

"I'm broke," said Smith, who is a full-time student at Rutgers and plans to 
raise money for his defense through a benefit party rather than use a public 
defender.

Smith also faces charges of assault and criminal mischief, pressed by William 
Pfeifer, who works for the city water department and is the union president 
of the Municipal Employees Association.

Pfeifer, who didn't return telephone calls yesterday, accuses Smith of 
throwing eggs at a pickup truck driven by campaign workers for the council 
incumbents.

Smith, who denies throwing anything, said the truck was used by campaign 
workers who were driving around the city tearing down opposition signs before 
the election.

On Nov. 7, New Brunswick voters defeated a public question for the fourth 
time that would have shifted the power of school-board selection from the 
mayor to the voters.

Smith said despite the voting results, the numbers -- 3,774 to 2,758 -- show 
the biggest number of "yes" votes since the question first made it to the 
ballot in 1993.

"But we were still defeated by a well-organized city machine," he said.

In support of a mayor-appointed school board, the Committee to Keep Politics 
Out of Schools raised upward of $25,000 with corporate funding -- far more 
than the amount members of the Campaign for an Elected School Board could 
contribute from their own paychecks, Smith said.

Smith's brother Cliff Smith has also found legal trouble as a political 
activist and will face assault charges tomorrow in New Brunswick Municipal 
Court.

High School Principal Pierre Embrey filed a complaint against Cliff Smith 
after the two engaged in an argument across the street from the high school 
Sept. 20, where Cliff Smith said he was distributing literature to students 
when Embrey told him to leave.

"He got pretty hot with me -- up in my face," said Smith, who thinks Embrey 
was even more upset over what appeared to be a bomb threat at the school.

Smith said he left the scene only to receive a court notice two weeks later 
charging him with verbally abusing, assaulting, and physically impeding 
Embrey's pathway.

"I think they (city and school officials) were trying to intimidate us and 
discredit our campaign on the eve of the election," he said.

For the three available council seats, independent challengers Keith Joseph, 
Diego Morales and Curtis L. Warren -- who were supported by Smith's 
organization -- were defeated by Democratic council incumbents Joseph Schrum, 
Jimmie L. Cook Jr. and Robert Recine.

In the wake of the election, the Smith brothers have formed a new activist 
group called the Student/Worker Organization for Revolutionary Democracy and 
will hold a benefit party for campaign legal defense at 6 p.m. Saturday at 
218 George St. 

J.P. White: (732) 246-5500, Ext. 7219. E-mail jpwhite@...


from the Home News Tribune 

Published: November 28, 2000

Post ID:893
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-01 00:03:00
Subject:Proposed Agenda for Meeting of 12-2-00
Message:

Following is the agenda proposed by the Steering 
Committee for the General Meeting of the People's 
Campaign scheduled for this coming Saturday December 2 
at 2PM at the New Brunswick Public Library (Livingston 
Avenue). 

Hope to see everyone there in the best spirit.

In unity,

Xavier Hansen
Campaign Manager

*******************************************************

NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLE�S CAMPAIGN

DRAFT AGENDA FOR GENERAL MEETING OF 12/2/00


1. INTRODUCTION � APPROVAL OF THE CHAIR

2. 2:30 PM: OPEN DISCUSSION � summing up the experience 
of the Campaign

3. 3:30 PM: LEADERSHIP PROPOSAL FROM THE STEERING 
COMMITTEE

a) We propose that the existing Steering Committee 
continue to lead the People�s Campaign until the next 
General Meeting of Saturday January 27, 2001 when the 
People�s Campaign will elect a new Interim Leadership of 
7 members.

b) We propose that the Interim Leadership elected in 
January 2001 be charged with preparing a People�s 
Campaign Congress for April 2001, inviting all people 
and organizations willing to unite in the struggle for 
people�s democracy in New Brunswick.

c) We propose that at the April Congress, the People�s 
Campaign vote on general principles and on an 
organizational structure to establish the People�s 
Campaign as a people�s democratic movement based in New 
Brunswick. We will then elect a new Steering Committee 
for a term of one year.

4. 4:00 PM: IMMEDIATE TASKS � Short presentations and 
sign-up sheets

a) Election Fraud Report � Gather & analyze election day 
information to prepare legal action and public exposure.
b) Fundraising � Organize a fundraising event to pay our 
few remaining outstanding bills and for our minimal 
basic operation costs.
c) After-school Program � Meet weekdays at 3:30PM to 
help city kids in the Campaign Youth Caucus with their 
homework � On Fridays, work on the Youth Caucus Magazine.
d) Spanish/English Classes & Exchange � Prepare teaching 
program for weekly lessons in both languages followed by 
one-on-one conversational exchanges.
e) Investigation Team � Follow up on our numerous leads 
on city machine corruption.
f) People�s Campaign Newspaper � Prepare the first post-
election issue of the People�s Campaign newspaper.

Post ID:894
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-05 17:05:21
Subject:Fwd: Impeach GW Bush! by R Lederman
Message:



>From: ARTISTpres@...
>To: undisclosed-recipients:;
>Subject: Impeach GW Bush! by R Lederman
>Date: Tue, 5 Dec 2000 11:34:45 EST
>
>Impeach GW Bush!
>by Robert Lederman
>
>Now that it seems all but certain a Bush coup has succeeded in
>seizing the US Presidency, I want to be the first to announce it:
>Impeach GW Bush!
>
>Unlike the fiasco of attempting to impeach President Clinton for
>lying about oral sex in the oval office, an attempt to impeach GW
>could be based on major felony crimes going back in a
>continuous lineage to his grandfather and continuing to the
>present day. These crimes involve his father, brothers, cousins
>and numerous business associates and include being traitors to
>America during WWII (grandfather Prescott Bush and
>great-grandfather, George Herbert Walker were Hitler's Wall
>Street bankers); immense savings and loan scandals that cost
>American taxpayers billions; drug running involving himself, his
>father and brothers and the stealing of the 2000 Presidential
>election, to name but a few highlights of their illustrious careers.
>
>Of course, it's highly unlikely that a massive Ken Starr-like
>investigation/persecution of the Bush crime family will ever be
>undertaken during a Bush regime. Once the Bush clique of white
>supremacists, drug manufacturers, oil interests, cocaine
>importers, military suppliers, media barons and eugenicists fully
>institute their power-grab agenda the U.S. government will no
>longer even exist as we've come to know it.
>
>Possibly the sole positive aspect of a Bush presidency is an
>anticipated relaxing of gun controls. The American people are
>going to need guns to defend themselves against the storm
>troopers of Bush's New World Order.
>
>Now I wouldn't want anyone to think I don't like GW Bush
>personally, despite the harsh comments above. If anything, I truly
>feel sorry for him. Most of the men who have been or who tried
>to become US president were driven by an all-consuming
>ambition to gain power and influence.
>
>In contrast GW Bush is about as incompetent, untalented and
>unambitious a man as ever existed in US politics. A GW Bush
>presidency will be nothing more than a ceremonial position, even
>more so than being the Queen of England-who Bush just
>happens to be a cousin of. No one in our own or any foreign
>government will ever imagine that GW Bush was responsible for
>any of the policies that America carries out in the next four years.
>
>When someone spends a major part of their lifetime trying to
>become president they make tremendous personal sacrifices in
>exchange for the opportunity to exert so much power. In contrast
>Bush-who apparently never had the least interest in becoming
>president-will never actually have any power. This is one of the
>few facts he seems clearly aware of.
>
>Watching Cheney and Bush at press opportunities is like
>watching a ventriloquist pretend it's his dummy who is talking. If
>anything, Bush is like a multiple-personality dummy channeling
>the voices of a whole gang of ventriloquists including Cheney,
>Bush senior, The Manhattan Institute and the most rabid leaders
>of the far right.
>
>I don't mean to suggest that if Gore had become President
>corporations would not have been running the show or that
>America would have been a paradise of equality and justice. At
>least Gore-unlike Bush-would have been able to understand what
>they were up to and on occasion would have modified the harm
>they intended. By contrast GW Bush seems unable to make a one
>sentence statement expressing his own opinion without the
>guiding hand of Cheney, Baker and his father's other top
>advisors.
>
>The Bush transition team is exactly that-a transition to a new
>high-tech form of governmental/corporate fascism that could
>make Nazi Germany pale by comparison. With the help of the
>mainstream media-who were co-conspirators with team Bush in
>stealing this election-we will see cruelty presented as
>compassion; racism presented as religion and war presented as a
>form of welfare.
>
>For close to 60 years the media-with occasional exceptions-has
>done its best to hide the crimes of the Bush family, beginning in
>1942 when it downplayed the Federal government seizing the
>Bush family's banking assets under the Trading With The Enemy
>Act. Media coverups on behalf of various Bush family members
>include hiding their involvement in the Kennedy assassination,
>the fake war on drugs, Iran Contra, the Savings and Loan
>scandals, cocaine smuggling and use, former President Bush
>having numerous Nazi advisors, the real story of the Gulf War
>and most recently fixing the US Presidential election.
>
>America is a wonderful country despite its many flaws. Our
>elected officials are not kings ruling by hereditary right nor are
>they dictators ruling by coup. If we want to have any hope to
>keep it that way we must rid ourselves of the Bush crime dynasty
>once and for all.
>
>The following are a very partial list of links to exposes on the
>Bush family. If only 25% of the information on them is true then
>the Bush family are among modern histories biggest criminals.
>
>[Note: as of this writing 12/5/2000 these were all good links]
>http://www.padrak.com/alt/BUSHBOOK_INDEX.html
>http://www.geocities.com/alanjpakula/triplecrown.html
>http://www.copvcia.com/witness_list.htm
>http://www.realchange.org/bushjr.htm
>http://www.gwbush.com/
>http://www.bushfiles.com/bushfiles/midland.html
>http://www.patrickcrusade.org/bush1.htm
>http://www.prorev.com/bush.htm
>http://afrocubaweb.com/bushes.htm
>http://www.davidicke.com/icke/articles/bush.html
>http://www.geocities.com/CapitolHill/3750/bush.htm
>http://www.kmf.org/williams/bushbook.html
>
>Robert Lederman, President of A.R.T.I.S.T.
>(Artists’ Response To Illegal State Tactics)
>ARTISTpres@...  (718) 743-3722
>
>West Nile Virus, Bush, Giuliani, Manhattan Institute, Eugenics
>info
>http://Baltech.org/lederman/spray/
>
>SprayNo archives
>http://www.egroups.com/group/sprayno
>
>Street artist info
>http://www.openair.org/alerts/artist/nyc.html
>
>

>cards for sale.  Twenty-two clients ordered 16,000 cards getting our
>new enterprise off to a wonderful start.  All proceeds
>support program operations and scholarships for our students!

>through our website at:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:900
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-07 12:37:31
Subject:RE: First Democratic Municipal Elections in Kosovo
Message:

 
Tuesday, November 28, 2000
Re:  First Democratic Municipal Elections in Kosovo
(This is 4-5 pages when printed out)

Hello Everyone,

Due to the constant "time constraints" that I seem to always live under
these 
days, I am sending this report out to all my friends at one time.  I 
apologize if it offends you to receive this somewhat generic letter - but 
please don't be offended!  You are one of my dear friends whom I felt would

like to hear about our latest mission - and this is the fastest means to 
report to all of you in a timely manner.

At the end of this report is information concerning our January Annual
World 
Citizen Diplomats Weekend Gathering planned for January 13th & 14th. 
Please 
be sure to respond as soon as possible if you plan to attend.

As you saw by the topic of my letter, I arrived home recently from my first

mission to Kosovo.  It was a remarkable and rewarding experience for me 
personally - and a very historic, successful and important mission for the 
citizens of this war-torn region!

This was my third opportunity to serve as an International Election 
Supervisor in the Balkins. Most of you probably remember when I went to
Nova 
Grad, a small suburb of Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, in Sept., 1997 to
help 
with the first democratic municipal elections following the war against the

ravages of the Serbian leader, Slobadon Milosovic.  I returned two months 
later to supervise the Parliament Elections, this time in Vogosca, another 
suburb of Sarajevo, where all the women and children survivors of the 
Srebrenica massacre now live.  Needless to say, I have seen the horror of
war 
in the eyes of the survivors and heard many terrifying stories of how 
horrible this war was!  As difficult as it is to see and hear from those
who 
have survived, it is so important to them to be able to tell their stories
to 
those of us who will listen - hoping the rest of the world will understand 
how much they have suffered.  Many of them responded in disbelief when we 
explained that all of us here in the United States watched our televisions
in 
horror and we cried for them when we saw what they were going through!  It 
really made a difference to them to know we were aware of their pain and we

were praying for their suffering to end.  They thought they were alone in 
their struggle against the aggressors of the war until they realized the 
whole world was crying with them, and we were all doing whatever we could
to 
help bring it to an end.  

On October 20th we left from Newark airport via Germany to Skopje,
Macedonia. 
 Barbara Wolf, the newest Board Member of World Citizen Diplomats who lives

in Rochester, New York, traveled with me.  Both of us were selected by the
US 
State Department to represent the American people as International Election

Supervisors.  When we arrived in Skopje we were met by the officials of the

OSCE (Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe).  This 
organization has been running elections in developing nations throughout 
Europe for the past decade.  We boarded the chartered buses waiting there
at 
the airport, and traveled south for four hours through the entire country
of 
Macedonia - to Lake Orhud on the southern boarder.  We were two of about
1000 
International Supervisors processed.  One Hundred and thirty of us were
from 
the USA.  There were 90 Germans, 90 Czechs, 100 from the UK and the rest 
represented another 20 countries.  We were all housed in two lovely resort 
hotels on the shore of Lake Orhud, overlooking this crystal clear lake and 
the mountains of Albania on the opposite shore! 

We remained here for four days receiving our training before embarking for 
Kosovo.  We were inundated with piles and piles of paperwork - hundreds
more 
sheets than we could possibly read in the entire eleven days we were
abroad!  
The training was intense and important - much too important to be crammed 
into just 3 days of actual training!  Our instructors had to move so
quickly 
to get all the information covered in time that we didn't even have time to

scribble notes as they talked!  This was the biggest complaint everyone
had.  
Thank goodness I had already participated in two previous elections.  But 
even with that knowledge I was a little worried that I wouldn't remember 
everything - because the OSCE has made many changes over the past three 
years.  I really felt sorry for those who were new to running elections 
abroad, and I knew there was no way they would ever be able to remember 
everything.  But at least we had everything with us in writing, and
hopefully 
we would be able to find the answers when needed!

Yes, we were under heavy guard, but because we were so far south in
Macedonia 
we felt very safe.  They had scores of undercover police all over inside
and 
outside our hotels - plus the military in uniform.  The last day we were 
there they allowed us to take taxis and travel around the area sightseeing.
 
Barbara and I took a taxi an hour south to the monastery where the Cyrillic

alphabet was first developed. 

At 5am on Oct. 25th we boarded the first of about 30 buses (6 left at a
time) 
and we headed north to tackle the Kosovo border crossing. Since the border 
guards were well aware that our international delegation was coming - the 
crossing went very smoothly.  However, we passed miles of buses and cars 
lined up to cross from both sides, and I bet it took more than a day for
them 
to cross over!  It was a real "eye opener" as we passed the "sand-bag"
types 
of battle stations along the way, and many war tanks and trucks.  We had a 
military escort from Skopje on - and after a day or so we became accustomed

to the constant military presence and escorts almost everywhere we went.

Barbara and I were sent to the Rahovec Region of Kosovo, located a little 
north west of Prizren and a little south east of Peje (Pec). About 100 of
us 
were sent to the Rahovec region - half Americans and half Czechs.  This is 
the German military sector, which is staffed with German KFOR (Kosovo
Forces) 
troops.  There was also a Russian contingent there.

Barbara was assigned to a polling station in Mlecane, a town in the
northern 
part of the municipality of Malisheve.  She worked with an international 
supervisor from the Czech Republic, who was given a polling station in the 
same school.  

I was assigned to the Mihail Grameno Primary School in the town of Rahovec,

where I was appointed the facilitator of this school.  I was in charge of 6

polling stations, all housed in 6 classrooms on the first floor of the 
school.  We had 4386 voters registered to vote at this center,
approximately 
700 for each station.  Each polling station was assigned one Int'l 
Supervisor.  Irene Ratner and I were the two American Supers - Eva 
Turacekova, Pavel Vavrina and Jan Trnka were the three Czech Supers - and 
Araceli Salto was our Supervisor from Spain.

Each of the 1000+ supervisors sent into Kozovo were assigned a translator, 
most of them young residents of the region we were assigned to.  Almost
every 
translator was between 18-25 years old.

We were also assigned a private driver and his car for three days - the day

before the election -- the day of the election - and the day after the 
election.  My translator was 22-year-old Ilir Kadiri.  My driver was 
47-year-old Wahid Spahia.  Wahid has six children, ages 13-22.  His wife, 
Nexhmije, is 45.  She is very ill, suffering from trauma, stress and fear 
from the war.  She is afraid to come out of her house, and she has many 
breathing problems that developed from being so scared.  She might not live

much longer.  In other words, she may be a victim who was literally "scared

to death!" It is so horrible!  Every family in Kosovo has experienced 
personal trauma from the war!  It seemed each story we heard was worse than

the one before!

The polling stations were scheduled to be open 12 hours, from 7am to 7pm. 
We 
got up at 3:30am, left our living quarters by 4:30 and picked up all the 
"sensitive materials" such as the ballots, etc, at the OSCE office.  We
were 
at our school by 5:30am.  The principal of the school arrived at 5:45 to
let 
us in.  We had already met our committee the day before, and already had
our 
polling stations set-up for the election.  From 6-7 we finished putting the

room in order to greet our first voters.  Each polling station had six 
committee members who were local citizens assigned to us.  We Int'l 
Supervisors explained to our committees that we were there only as helpers 
and observers, and we stressed we were not there to run the election.  We 
wanted them to know this was "their" election and we were only there to
help 
when needed. 

However, none of us had any idea what we were about to face!  At both 
previous elections in Bosnia I had a tiny station in a small town, and it
was 
a fairly easy assignment.  Nothing and No-one had prepared me for the next
24 
hours!

When we opened the school door at 7am there were already about a hundred 
people waiting outside.  We started lines outside each of the six
classrooms 
-  until there wasn't room in the hall for one more person.  By 8am we had
to 
close the outside door to the school and only allow people in after some
left 
the building.  This was the beginning of a very long day!

By noon we had 300-400 people outside the building - and every spot of the 
hall full inside.  Because they were overflowing into the street in front
of 
the school, we had to move everyone around back to the playground area.  We

had three types of police and military at our disposal.  The Kosovo local 
police and the U.N. civil police were the two forces who worked directly
with 
us all day.  Because of all the hundreds of people to control, I had about
12 
Kosovo and UN police helping me the entire day.

But by 4pm the crowd outside started to push harder and harder on the
school 
doors from the playground - which was wall to wall small panes of glass. 
We 
could see their faces being squeezed against the panes of glass, and
because 
the school was old I realized that the entire wall of doors could be pushed

in, which would cause many to be stampeeded and possibly crushed to death. 

We had a very dangerous situation and no matter how hard our twelve
policemen 
tried, they couldn't control the crowd or get them to back away from the 
glass doors.  

At 5:00 I finally had to resort to calling in the KFOR Troops.  We were 
instructed only to call the KFOR Troops in if we had a life-and-death 
situation - which we definitely had!

So in rolled two huge tanks with six-foot soldiers dressed in their
military 
camouflage uniforms carrying 3 to 4-foot-long automatic weapons in hand!  
Talk about a powerful presence!!  Within 15 minutes they had the hundreds
of 
people away from the building and lined up in a long, winding, "orderly" 
line.  Thank God!  We could have had a real tragedy on our hands.

The reason the people were so anxious to get inside was because they wanted

so much to vote. They knew the polling stations were to close at 7pm.  They

didn't understand that we were instructed to process every person standing
in 
the line - inside and outside the building - at 7pm. I explained this
several 
times to them, but they wanted to get inside so there wouldn't be any way 
they couldn't vote!  Most of the people stood in lines for 3 to 4 hours! 
Old 
people, many of them with visable wounds and amputees - pregnant women -
and 
women holding their infants!  It was really hard to see them waiting for so

long, but there just wasn't much we could do.  At least once every hour I 
would personally walk outside and pluck the oldest people out of the line
and 
escort them inside and put them into a chair until they were processed.

By 6:00 there were still hundreds of people outside the building.  Then Mr.

Kouchner, the OSCE head of the Kosovo Elections appeared on TV in Pristina,

which aired throughout Kosovo.  He told the people he was extending the 
polling hours until "every citizen voted"!  This was great for the citizens

of Kosovo, but a real dilemma for those of us running the stations.  We
still 
had to count every vote before we could go home!

It wouldn't have taken nearly as long as it did to process each voter if
the 
voter registration books had been done properly.  Unfortunately many of the

registration records had been lost in the mail - when OSCE sent the 
registration records to India to have them processed "cheaper"!  And the 
books weren't done in alphabetical order.  Instead they were put together
by 
registration number, but the numbers were about 12-14 digits long - adding
to 
the problem!  Consequently it took sometimes 10-20 minutes per person to 
process many of the voters.  It really was a terrible problem.

We finished processing the voters at 9:30pm that evening, and finally
closed 
our classroom doors so we could begin the closing procedures.  At 2:30 in
the 
morning, as we were counting the last of our ballots, I looked around our 
room and my committee looked absolutely exhausted.  I thought they would
pass 
out.  They were exhausted both mentally and physically!  We finished at
3:15 
am - 24 hours after our day began.  As we left the building we saw Pavel
and 
his committee still in their classroom counting!  He told me the next day 
that he finished at 4am.

After dropping all our materials off at the OSCE office, we headed back to 
our rooms.  This was honestly one of the hardest days of my entire life!

But after a long, hot shower and a few hours rest, I felt a whole lot
better. 
 Now that we look back on the election, we realize it was a remarkable 
success.  The moderate LDK party won by a large margin, which was a big 
statement for the Int'l community.  The Kosovo people are more interested
in 
rebuilding their country, improving living conditions, and developing new 
jobs for all the unemployed than they are in fighting with the local Serbs.
 
It is only the fanatical extremists who are still retaliating.  

Most of all - the Kosovo people want their Independence from Serbia.  And
who 
can blame them?  Every Kosovo Albanian family has witnessed unbelievable 
atrocities.  Since the election went so well, and the people voted so 
strongly for Ibrahim Rugova and the LDK party, the Int'l community is now 
forced to consider their desire for Independence.

Noon the following day we had our debriefing session, and we had an 
opportunity to share with the OSCE officials whom we worked directly with, 
all our concerns and suggestions for future elections - while everything
was 
still clear in our minds.  We witnessed many problems we hope the OSCE will

confront before the next elections.  But on the whole - the elections went 
excellent and the Kosovo citizens have a lot to be proud of from the
results 
of that very important "historic" day in the rebuilding of their lives.

There is absolutely no way for me to express the personal gratification you

receive from serving as a crucial part of such an historic event!  Every
one 
of you should try to serve as an Election Supervisor of a Democratic
Election 
in a developing nation.  It will most likely be one of the highlights of
your 
life!

I now realize that World Citizen Diplomats has chosen the correct direction

for our future.  Last summer we made the final decision following ten years

of traveling around the world dialoguing with all of you - that we see a 
definite need for a "Citizen Diplomacy Training Center".  We are now in the

process of applying for the funding we need to develop this training
center.  
We wish to offer a one week training to those of you who wish to apply to
the 
OSCE or the United Nations Volunteer Agencies who send people abroad to
serve 
as supervisors and observers of democratic elections. This one week of 
training will provide the attendee with an International
Supervisor/Observer 
Certification.  If you choose to attend a second week you will receive a
week 
of training in conflict resolution and mediation, certifying you as a 
"Citizen Diplomat Peacemaker".  

We plan to send these qualified peacemakers abroad into nations
experiencing 
the very first signs of a possible conflict brewing within.  These Citizen 
Diplomat Peacemakers will become part of an International delegation who
will 
go into hot spots around the world and help defuse internal problems before

they escalate into a war! They will live with the local families and 
eventually all the families will come together and begin dialogue regarding

the issues causing dissention. This is our idea of how humanity can
eliminate 
war before it starts.

Please drop us a note and let us know what you think about our plans.  

Two Fridays ago I received a telephone call from Hamburg, Germany.  It was 
Uli Fiddler.  Uli showed up at 7am at the door of our polling center the 
morning of the elections with his four-man filming crew and asked
permission 
to document the Kosovo elections.  He chose our town because we were part
of 
the German KFOR sector.  I was so thrilled that he called me because I had 
completely forgotten to get his name or telephone number until the next day
-  
and then it was too late to find him.  He and his filming crew documented
our 
entire day of elections.  Thank goodness he had taken my business card the 
day of the elections when he interviewed me.  He called to say that he
wanted 
to send a copy of the footage, and needed to know the kind of video we have

here.  I told him VHS, and he said he would send it right away.

Last Saturday I received the two video tapes, and I couldn't put them into 
the VCR fast enough - only to find out they are the wrong speed and format!
 
Yesterday I called a few video stores here on the shore and found two who
do 
foreign conversions.  But they cost quite a bit to convert (over $100), so
I 
will wait until the first of the year to have it done.  I intend to show
some 
of the footage at our January Annual WCD meeting on Saturday, Jan. 13th.  

I hope those of you who can afford to travel to Princeton that weekend will

come and spend the weekend with us.  We are planning a two-day gathering
the 
weekend of Jan. 13-14th, and everyone who attends will have an opportunity
to 
share with us what you have been doing the past two or three years. We will

find host families to accommodate you, if you can get here.  Barbara Wolf 
will report on her experiences in Kosovo, and her trip coming up soon to 
Japan.  Margaret Fikioris, Bruce Nichols and Barbara are attending the
Peace 
ceremonies in Hiroshima on Dec. 11-12, and all three will share their 
experience at our meeting.  Bruce just arrived home from his trip to The 
Univ. for Peace in Costa Rica where they had a celebration and dedication
of 
a statue of Peace Pilgrim.  Bruce will share this trip to Costa Rica, plus
he 
has some excellent slides of his trip he made with his father recently to 
Cuba.  I haven't had a chance to talk with Dietrich Fischer yet, but I am 
hoping he will be able to share some of his many experiences this past year

also.

I am trying to get the Kosovo coordinators from Quality Support, Inc. to 
attend and speak to all of us about the selection of International 
Supervisors and Observers.  I am also trying to get a representative of the

UN Volunteer Office to attend and share with us how we can become a UN 
volunteer abroad.

I am hoping we will be able to hold our meeting at the Woodrow Wilson
School 
at Princeton University, so we can open it up to the students who might be 
interested in attending.  I will send you all the details about the meeting

sometime in December.  

If you have any ideas of other things we should include that weekend,
please 
let me know so we can try to add it to our agenda.

I believe it is time for me to close for now, and I wish all of you a Happy

Holiday Season.  Please let me know if you can work it out to come to 
Princeton on Jan. 13th and 14th and participate in our Annual Meeting.

Warm Regards in Peace and Friendship,

Lois Nicolai




--------------------  End Forwarded Message --------------------





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:901
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-07 14:45:11
Subject:Re: Stranger?
Message:

Dear Matthew,

   It is just a pleasure to hear from you again after all this time.  
I'm sorry for the delay in my response, as Sylvia and I took our 
yearly constitution at the Swiss spa for the month of November, and I 
only received your package upon returning.

   How have you been old chap?  I'm sorry to hear about your sister 
Agnes's case of consumption.  It is terrible when God takes his 
children so soon.  

   You mentioned scarcely anything about those darling boys of yours!
How is Roger?  Has Nigel finally gotten over his bout of bedwetting?  
The boy still getting a bit of hazing for that at boarding school? 
Tell the young fellow not to worry.  It will clear up.  He's only 16 
after all.

   Well now, I am sorry to make this correspondence so short, but I 
must put Jules to bed now.  You should see his insect collection. 
My!  How it has grown.  To wit, he just found the most titilating 
specimen the other day while fetching biscuits from the larder.  

   But I'll derogate you no further.  Farewell ol' boy!

                      Your most humble and beloved servant
                      in God, Church, and Country,
                      James R. Westingshire, IV.

P.S. -- Prate not, and respond soon!  I will not be present next 
month, as I'll be on leave with Uncle Quillard attending to the
estate in New Zealand.

>From: "Mathew Levi" <ml@...>

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:904
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-08 10:46:07
Subject:Pastor Soaries as Governor
Message:

Developments in the upcoming governor battle.... this is going to be very 
interesting!

December 8, 2000 - NY Times
PUBLIC PROFILE
Firebrand Considers the Post-Whitman Era
By IVER PETERSON

BUSTER SOARIES knows very well that the things he's been saying in his 
sermons and speeches sound raw. Going on about black street gangs and drug 
dealers and wife beaters is a risky thing for someone who is both a Baptist 
minister and, as New Jersey's secretary of state, the highest-ranking black 
person in the administration of Gov. Christie Whitman.

But the Rev. DeForest B. Soaries Jr., or Buster to everyone in the State 
House, is convinced that the time is overdue for an attack on the faults in 
the black community while simultaneously holding the white majority's feet 
to the fires of justice. So there he was at Shiloh Baptist Church in Trenton 
recently, jolting about 600 black middle school boys with a dose of reality 
as he sees it:

"If being black means taking drugs and beating on your girlfriend, I don't 
want to be black," he roared as the boys watched, transfixed. "And if being 
white means paying your bills and using proper language and having a nice 
house, call me white!"

Back in his corner office in the State House, Mr. Soaries, 49, says he has 
been misunderstood and called a traitor for working for a white, Republican 
administration. But his habit of blunt speaking has not abated when it comes 
to minority concerns aboutthe racial-profiling scandal that is rocking the 
state. As state officials reluctantly disclosed recently that they had been 
aware of the practice in some form for years, Mr. Soaries stepped forward as 
the only member of the administration to condemn the state police and to 
demand change. Being a lightning rod is not a new experience to him, 
however.

When Mr. Soaries was 19, he was kidnapped and threatened with death by a 
gang of black drug dealers on the Rutgers University campus in New 
Brunswick, where he was a sophomore. The level of drug use among 
African-Americans dismayed him, and he and his growing network of friends 
and contacts had been putting pressure on the police and the university to 
crack down. The experience left him with one big thought.

"I think it cured me of ever falling into the trap that all blacks are good 
and all whites are bad," he said. "It was an inoculation, and it cured me 
from seeing the world in all racial terms."

Mr. Soaries ended his speech at Shiloh on another point, that racism is as 
real as the police officer who stops minority drivers � he himself has been 
pulled over � because of race.

For all the economic progress New Jersey has enjoyed in the seven years Mrs. 
Whitman has been governor, he said, members of minorities "live in a state 
where if you look in your rear-view mirror and it's the police, you're 
nervous if you're black." That problem will be solved, he said, only when 
New Jersey elects its first minority governor. Someone who would protect the 
progress minorities have made, who is not afraid to criticize ills within 
the minority community. Someone like him.

I WANT a minority governor," Mr. Soaries said as he ended his speech at 
Shiloh Baptist. "I want a governor who looks like me!"

The quest for justice has carried Mr. Soaries from a childhood in segregated 
Montclair to the Urban League, to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Operation PUSH 
and then to a doctorate in divinity and his own pulpit at the First Baptist 
Church of Lincoln Gardens, in Somerset. Along the way, he collected the 
names and contacts that help move public policy, and the policy he wants to 
move now is for a different kind of governor.

"My position is that I want a minority governor," he said at a news 
conference at the State House on Wednesday. "This state has a festering 
cancer of racism and sexism in a state agency that cannot be allowed to 
exist." Since none of the candidates he favored had offered to run, he would 
consider it himself.

Isn't making race the test for the next governor a kind of profiling in 
itself? Mr. Soaries, who recently switched from independent to Republican, 
was not biting. "Let's talk math, not race," he said. "If you sell hot dogs 
and you ignore one-third of your market, you're destined to fail."

What the state needs now, Mr. Soaries said, is a governor with better 
instincts on racial issues.

"My position is that it's going to take someone who has a high racial I.Q.," 
he said. "It's going to take someone whose background includes reaching 
people across racial lines, and it's going to take someone who lives in 
close proximity to people in the gap."

"The gap" is one of Mr. Soaries's favorite terms. He uses it to describe the 
space between the rich and the poor, the protected and the persecuted, the 
hopeful and the hopeless. The gap runs from Newark past his window in 
Trenton, on through Camden and into Vineland. Mr. Soaries patrols it every 
weekday from his State House office, every Sunday from his pulpit, and the 
rest of the time at home, where his wife, Donna, cares for their 11-year-old 
twins, Martin and Malcolm.

"The one show they like that creates a challenge to me is the W.W.F.," Mr. 
Soaries said, touching on the fake agony of Vince McMahon's World Wrestling 
Federation. "I've got to personally work on finding some redemptive value in 
the W.W.F., and I believe we may be able to develop a literacy program, 
based on W.W.F. images and personalities." A pause. "I'll have to call Vince 
McMahon about that."










_____________________________________________________________________________________

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:906
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-11 11:32:39
Subject:Re: Daily Targum
Message:

Follow the bouncing logic...

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

---------------------------------------

Complex solution



Editorial


------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--



To benefit the New Brunswick community, the New Brunswick Development 
Corporation, along with three developers, will transform the upper and lower 
plaza parking lots at New and Neilson streets into a $118 million complex. In 
the past, DevCo. has felt much community backlash for its re-development 
projects, since developments like Liberty Square and Kilmer Square ousted 
local retailers and residents. But this project will be revamping a parking 
lot, and for once, there can be no objection.

The complex — which will include about 750 apartments, 1,600 parking spaces 
and 32,000 square feet of retail stores — will be built in two phases to 
minimize parking disruptions within the city.

These disruptions, although they may handicap the city for a short period of 
time, will help the community economically in the long run. The retail space 
will include a food store, a dry cleaner and a video store, to revitalize the 
downtown area.

The construction is scheduled to begin next spring on a $43 million complex, 
surrounded by New, Neilson, Richmond and Burnet streets. Due the flooding of 
Hurricane Floyd in September 1999, the building will be designed as a 
three-story building erected above one level of enclosed parking. The 
building, when the project is completed, will have 417 residential units, 38 
three-bedroom apartments and 557 parking spaces. 

In addition to the new spaces, the authority may rent parking space at the 
old police station on Route 18 along with shuttle buses to transport workers 
during rush hour.

The building of the complex is ultimately not hurting any New Brunswick 
business and it is not putting anyone out of their homes. It is the most 
socially responsible thing the city has done in the past 20 years because 
they are rebuilding an area that needs rebuilding.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:907
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-11 12:15:36
Subject:Demand Democracy!!
Message:

Justice Scalia has taken it upon himself to remind us that our right to vote 
is not guaranteed... amazing how the system exposes itself...we should 
demand that this enemy be removed from the highest court of the country 
immediately!!!

from today's NY Daily News

Justice Scalia's Legal Vision
Is Blinded by His Ambition

Earlier this year, Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court justice who now is all 
but serving as the attorney for George W. Bush, let it be known that if 
Democrats won the presidency, he'd quit the court.

He would leave because under a Democratic administration, he would have no 
shot at being named chief justice by Al Gore, according to the March issue 
of the Washingtonian magazine.

Now, Scalia has taken charge of the election case for George W. Bush and 
will try to herd the conservatives this morning for the result he apparently 
wants: a Bush presidency, and, perhaps, the job of chief justice when 
William Rehnquist retires in a few years as is expected.

Normally, judges disqualify themselves from cases in which they have a 
personal interest; if the naked ambition to be the court's chief was 
accurately attributed to him, then he has no business deciding this fight.

Scalia, however, could not have been bolder in his advocacy for Bush's 
cause, and, by extension, his own.

During oral arguments two weeks ago, he took shots at the Florida courts, 
which had said the most fundamental right in a democracy is the vote.

No way, Scalia said.

"There is no right of suffrage under Article II," he declared.

In plain English, he said that the citizens have no constitutional right to 
vote for President. His reason is that the Constitution places that power in 
the hands of the state legislatures, although he did not mention that all 50 
state legislatures submit the question to a popular vote. (Some transcripts 
of the Supreme Court session attributed this remark to Rehnquist, but Scalia 
apparently was the actual speaker.)

Over the weekend, he took matters even further.

Scalia wrote that Bush would suffer "irreparable harm" if votes were counted 
"by casting a cloud upon what he claims to be the legitimacy of his 
election."

You have may seen that moment in "A Few Good Men" when Tom Cruise is 
defending a soldier at a military trial.

"I want the truth!" says Cruise, during cross-examination.

Jack Nicholson looks up at him with contempt.

"You can't handle the truth," snarls Nicholson.

The legality of the votes worries Scalia."Count first and rule upon legality 
afterward is not a recipe for producing election results that have the 
public acceptance democratic stability requires," Scalia wrote.

We've gotten by for two centuries on precisely that recipe. That is what is 
done on every Election Day in this country.

First we vote. Then come the challenges, if any, which end up in court, and 
are decided there. This is not new. To have disputed ballots decided by 
courts doesn't "change the rules of the game." Those are the rules of the 
game. To do otherwise changes the law, the customs and the practice in every 
single state.

No one can possibly argue that it is the best interests of Bush or Gore that 
the votes not be counted.

There was talk yesterday � unfortunately, it proved to be untrue � that the 
Florida courts were going to ship uncounted ballots up to Washington. Those 
ballots, for better and worse, are the only evidence about the results of 
this election.

To exclude them from this decision is like saying that a murder weapon 
seized from a suspect can't be shown to a jury because of a legal 
technicality.

But Scalia says that we � the nation � can't handle the truth of counting 
those ballots, that the results might damage a Bush presidency if they show 
that he really didn't win.

So we hide the facts for the good of the country.

Or is it really for the good of Antonin Scalia, the chief justice wanna-be?


Original Publication Date: 12/11/00

_____________________________________________________________________________________
Get more from the Web.  FREE MSN Explorer download : http://explorer.msn.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:908
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>

Subject:Re: [nbpc] Demand Democracy!!
Message:

It turns out that Scalia's son works in the law firm that is bringing Bush's case before the Supreme Court.

>>> "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...> 12/11 5:15 PM >>>
Justice Scalia has taken it upon himself to remind us that our right to vote 
is not guaranteed... amazing how the system exposes itself...we should 
demand that this enemy be removed from the highest court of the country 
immediately!!!

from today's NY Daily News

Justice Scalia's Legal Vision
Is Blinded by His Ambition

Earlier this year, Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court justice who now is all 
but serving as the attorney for George W. Bush, let it be known that if 
Democrats won the presidency, he'd quit the court.

He would leave because under a Democratic administration, he would have no

"There is no right of suffrage under Article II," he declared.

In plain English, he said that the citizens have no constitutional right to 
vote for President. His reason is that the Constitution places that power in 
the hands of the state legislatures, although he did not mention that all 50 
state legislatures submit the question to a popular vote. (Some transcripts 
of the Supreme Court session attributed this remark to Rehnquist, but Scalia 
apparently was the actual speaker.)

Scalia wrote that Bush would suffer "irreparable harm" if votes were counted 
"by casting a cloud upon what he claims to be the legitimacy of his 
election."

You have may seen that moment in "A Few Good Men" when Tom Cruise is 
defending a soldier at a military trial.

"I want the truth!" says Cruise, during cross-examination.

Jack Nicholson looks up at him with contempt.

"You can't handle the truth," snarls Nicholson.

The legality of the votes worries Scalia."Count first and rule upon legality 
afterward is not a recipe for producing election results that have the 
public acceptance democratic stability requires," Scalia wrote.

We've gotten by for two centuries on precisely that recipe. That is what is 
done on every Election Day in this country.

First we vote. Then come the challenges, if any, which end up in court, and 
are decided there. This is not new. To have disputed ballots decided by 
courts doesn't "change the rules of the game." Those are the rules of the 
game. To do otherwise changes the law, the customs and the practice in every 
single state.

No one can possibly argue that it is the best interests of Bush or Gore that 
the votes not be counted.

There was talk yesterday  unfortunately, it proved to be untrue  that the 
Florida courts were going to ship uncounted ballots up to Washington. Those 
ballots, for better and worse, are the only evidence about the results of 
this election.

To exclude them from this decision is like saying that a murder weapon 
seized from a suspect can't be shown to a jury because of a legal 
technicality.

But Scalia says that we  the nation  can't handle the truth of counting 
those ballots, that the results might damage a Bush presidency if they show 
that he really didn't win.

So we hide the facts for the good of the country.

Or is it really for the good of Antonin Scalia, the chief justice wanna-be?


Original Publication Date: 12/11/00
