-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:925
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-26 16:07:02
Subject:Fascism vs. Communism
Message:

Given the accusations by Frank Bright at last month's General Meeting
of the New Brunswick Peoples Campaign that certain members of the
coalition are "fascist," I thought now might be an appropriate time
to put forward this abstract on what the theoretical and historical
basis of fascism actually is, contrasted with the theoretical and
historical basis of communism.  Consider this merely an outline of a
broader theoretical work.  I give citations where appropriate.  This
is in no way a comprehensive work, as much more can be said and has
been said on this topic.

Socio-Cultural Manifestations

The most prominent socio-cultural feature of fascist society is the
lack of social or democratic institutions whereby the populace can
interface with the government.  While liberal democracy promises all
citizens equality before the law, the law being the impartial guide
to justice, justice under fascism is conceived in terms of the will
of the supreme leader.  One Nazi lawyer wrote in the Frankfurt
Zeitung in 1935, "Previously one spoke of justice and injustice, but
now a judge before reaching a decision must ask himself: What would
the Fuehrer say to this?"
Rather than the intervening institutions of the courts or civil
society or law, fascist society is characterized by a direct
connection between the national subject and the Supreme Leader.  In
this way an entire populace abandons its freedom, political and
otherwise, and looks toward the leader for all direction in action. 
In the ideal fascist society, one is free and all others are slaves. 
The relationship is the political analogue to a religious subject's
connection to a transcendent God, where all freedom is abandoned, all
action is predetermined, and every task is set upon with the idea of
increasing the glory of the leader.  Indeed, the fascist leader is
the incarnation of God on Earth.  One need only look at footage of
Nazi rallies to get a sense of the greater-than-life awe inspired by
Nazi aesthetics.
(For more on abandonment of freedom in the existential sense, look at
Erich Fromm, Escape From Freedom, where he treats the subject in more
depth.)

Ideological and Class Structures

Along with the emphasis on complete faith and devotion to the Supreme
Leader, there is inherent in fascism a romantic appeal to religion
and mythological heroism.  In this regard fascism is a direct
reaction to Enlightenment thought, as it stresses mythos over
rational thought.  Emphasis is on an emotional, purely subjective
connection to the fatherland and the leader. In fact, all capacity of
independent reasoning is given up and over to the whim of the leader.
 The turn toward a religious relationship with the leader is more
deep than a simple rebellion against Enlightenment thought; the
reaction is against the entire system of Enlightenment practice,
including the free market.  Fascist parties come to power in times of
economic crisis, promising a return to the glory of bygone days --
that is, before the cash nexus came to determine social relations,
and when a true sense of *belonging* to a fatherland and a king
pervaded social relations.  Granted, no such time ever existed, and a
good question to ask is
Why do people ever believe such a thing?  The answer to this question
can be found in the concrete historical circumstances leading up to
the rise of fascism, namely the crisis of liberal democracy and
capitalism, and its tendency to revert to anarchy and economic
collapse.  In times of economic crisis, if the working class is not
properly organized and prepared ideologically to present a true
challenge to the bourgeoisie, then the failure of the free market is
expressed by the proletariat in terms of the spontaneous uprisings
and destruction of property.  Such a state of affairs is entirely
unacceptable to the bourgeoisie, because law and order are
*necessary* in order to make profit. Law and order is the only way
the bourgeoisie can break strikes (with the police), conquer new
markets (with the army), keep the cost of raw materials low (with
tariffs), etc.  Overthrow of the state means the unequivocal
impotence of the bourgeoisie.  When liberal democracy goes into
crisis the industrialists will resort to
any means necessary to preserve their ability to make profit.  A
strong dictator becomes the answer to this.  A man (it is always a
man) who promises to return law and order.  The bourgeoisie would
rather *not* have dictatorship.  The ability to legislate through
parliament, congress is a strength for the industrialists.  But
accepting a dictator is the only way they can conserve *any* power. 
Dictatorship is *always* preferable to anarchy.  And when liberal
democracy goes into crisis, these are the two alternatives the
bourgeoisie are faced with (barring, of course, the organizing
uprising of the proletariat).  The fascist leader publically rides
into power on the backs of the two most reactionary classes --
peasantry and petite bourgeoisie -- because they are the classes that
have the most to lose under the free market.  That is, capitalism
ideally moves the peasants off the land into factories and phases out
the inferior production methods of the petite bourgeoisie.  It is
this fear of being removed from
land that that fascist appeals to when he invokes the glory of the
Fatherland.  Capitalism and Enlightenment destroy any existential
roots to the Earth and replace them with the cold rationality of
calculation.  Fascism appeals to this loss and invokes the
romanticism of religion, mythos, connection to the soil, etc.  But
make no mistake: while the fascist leader pays such lip service to
these classes, he is *actually* supported, the entire time, by the
most powerful industrialists.  The gran bourgeoisie, not the petite
bourgeoisie, are the ones who abandon liberal democracy and bring in
a Strongman to restore law and order against the proletariat.  (For
more on this aspect of fascism, see Karl Marx, 18th Brumaire of Louis
Bonaparte, or Barrington Moore, Social Origins of Dictatorship and
Democracy).

Why did Stalinist Russia look an awful lot like Fascist Germany?
It should be clear by now that fascism invariably results from the
direct alliance of the industrialists and the state where the two are
almost indifferentiable.  This was certainly the case in Prussia,
where industrialization from the end of the 19th century on was
carried out from the top-down.  This was also the case in Soviet
Russia with Stalin's Five-Year Plans.  While industrialization in
England took place in a gradual, bottom-up fashion, the same was not
true of industrialization in Germany and the Soviet Union.  England
experienced a gradual change in social relationships as capitalism
organically grew from the bottom up.  It was precisely the organic
nature of this evolution that made liberal democracy strong: if the
struggle for liberal democracy is intrinsically linked to the
economic *practice* of a class, then it is all the more likely to
hold.  This is not to say that this prevents the rise of fascism in
such countries.  It is only to say that a bottom-up industrialization
process seems to
have made liberal democracy stronger.  Top-down industrialization, on
the other hand, seems to be the economic basis for fascism. 
(Barrington Moore)  Up until Stalin, the revolution was fought in the
USSR from the bottom-up.  Stalin actually has to *abandon* the
principles of Communism, and hence the revolution, in order to carry
out his plan for industrialization.  Rather than allowing the
proletariat the power to determine production through an unalienated
relationship to production, it is the Party that decides what should
be produced, how it should be produced, how much of it should be
produced, etc.  To justify this move toward absolutism, Stalin
releases Economic Problems of Socialism in the USSR where he flatly
abandons the move from the Dictatorship of the Proletariat to
Communism, in favor of state capitalism.  State capitalism as the
impetus for industrialization, we have already seen, is one of the
material bases of fascism.

As I said, this is by no means a comprehensive analysis.  It is
merely an outline.  Moore's argument, for instance, is very involved
and complex.  I simply picked out a few things from his chapters on
England and France.  The point is that "fascist" is a term of
political theory and political economy.  It should not be used as one
would use the word "meany" or "ka-ka-head".  Unless of course you
want to sound like a desperate or insufferable twit.  Cheers, Jim.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:926
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-26 16:07:45
Subject:Fascism vs. Communism
Message:

Given the accusations by Frank Bright at last month's General Meeting
of the New Brunswick Peoples Campaign that certain members of the
coalition are "fascist," I thought now might be an appropriate time
to put forward this abstract on what the theoretical and historical
basis of fascism actually is, contrasted with the theoretical and
historical basis of communism.  Consider this merely an outline of a
broader theoretical work.  I give citations where appropriate.  This
is in no way a comprehensive work, as much more can be said and has
been said on this topic.

Socio-Cultural Manifestations

The most prominent socio-cultural feature of fascist society is the
lack of social or democratic institutions whereby the populace can
interface with the government.  While liberal democracy promises all
citizens equality before the law, the law being the impartial guide
to justice, justice under fascism is conceived in terms of the will
of the supreme leader.  One Nazi lawyer wrote in the Frankfurt
Zeitung in 1935, "Previously one spoke of justice and injustice, but
now a judge before reaching a decision must ask himself: What would
the Fuehrer say to this?"
Rather than the intervening institutions of the courts or civil
society or law, fascist society is characterized by a direct
connection between the national subject and the Supreme Leader.  In
this way an entire populace abandons its freedom, political and
otherwise, and looks toward the leader for all direction in action. 
In the ideal fascist society, one is free and all others are slaves. 
The relationship is the political analogue to a religious subject's
connection to a transcendent God, where all freedom is abandoned, all
action is predetermined, and every task is set upon with the idea of
increasing the glory of the leader.  Indeed, the fascist leader is
the incarnation of God on Earth.  One need only look at footage of
Nazi rallies to get a sense of the greater-than-life awe inspired by
Nazi aesthetics.
(For more on abandonment of freedom in the existential sense, look at
Erich Fromm, Escape From Freedom, where he treats the subject in more
depth.)

Ideological and Class Structures

Along with the emphasis on complete faith and devotion to the Supreme
Leader, there is inherent in fascism a romantic appeal to religion
and mythological heroism.  In this regard fascism is a direct
reaction to Enlightenment thought, as it stresses mythos over
rational thought.  Emphasis is on an emotional, purely subjective
connection to the fatherland and the leader. In fact, all capacity of
independent reasoning is given up and over to the whim of the leader.
 The turn toward a religious relationship with the leader is more
deep than a simple rebellion against Enlightenment thought; the
reaction is against the entire system of Enlightenment practice,
including the free market.  Fascist parties come to power in times of
economic crisis, promising a return to the glory of bygone days --
that is, before the cash nexus came to determine social relations,
and when a true sense of *belonging* to a fatherland and a king
pervaded social relations.  Granted, no such time ever existed, and a
good question to ask is
Why do people ever believe such a thing?  The answer to this question
can be found in the concrete historical circumstances leading up to
the rise of fascism, namely the crisis of liberal democracy and
capitalism, and its tendency to revert to anarchy and economic
collapse.  In times of economic crisis, if the working class is not
properly organized and prepared ideologically to present a true
challenge to the bourgeoisie, then the failure of the free market is
expressed by the proletariat in terms of the spontaneous uprisings
and destruction of property.  Such a state of affairs is entirely
unacceptable to the bourgeoisie, because law and order are
*necessary* in order to make profit. Law and order is the only way
the bourgeoisie can break strikes (with the police), conquer new
markets (with the army), keep the cost of raw materials low (with
tariffs), etc.  Overthrow of the state means the unequivocal
impotence of the bourgeoisie.  When liberal democracy goes into
crisis the industrialists will resort to
any means necessary to preserve their ability to make profit.  A
strong dictator becomes the answer to this.  A man (it is always a
man) who promises to return law and order.  The bourgeoisie would
rather *not* have dictatorship.  The ability to legislate through
parliament, congress is a strength for the industrialists.  But
accepting a dictator is the only way they can conserve *any* power. 
Dictatorship is *always* preferable to anarchy.  And when liberal
democracy goes into crisis, these are the two alternatives the
bourgeoisie are faced with (barring, of course, the organizing
uprising of the proletariat).  The fascist leader publically rides
into power on the backs of the two most reactionary classes --
peasantry and petite bourgeoisie -- because they are the classes that
have the most to lose under the free market.  That is, capitalism
ideally moves the peasants off the land into factories and phases out
the inferior production methods of the petite bourgeoisie.  It is
this fear of being removed from
land that that fascist appeals to when he invokes the glory of the
Fatherland.  Capitalism and Enlightenment destroy any existential
roots to the Earth and replace them with the cold rationality of
calculation.  Fascism appeals to this loss and invokes the
romanticism of religion, mythos, connection to the soil, etc.  But
make no mistake: while the fascist leader pays such lip service to
these classes, he is *actually* supported, the entire time, by the
most powerful industrialists.  The gran bourgeoisie, not the petite
bourgeoisie, are the ones who abandon liberal democracy and bring in
a Strongman to restore law and order against the proletariat.  (For
more on this aspect of fascism, see Karl Marx, 18th Brumaire of Louis
Bonaparte, or Barrington Moore, Social Origins of Dictatorship and
Democracy).

Why did Stalinist Russia look an awful lot like Fascist Germany?
It should be clear by now that fascism invariably results from the
direct alliance of the industrialists and the state where the two are
almost indifferentiable.  This was certainly the case in Prussia,
where industrialization from the end of the 19th century on was
carried out from the top-down.  This was also the case in Soviet
Russia with Stalin's Five-Year Plans.  While industrialization in
England took place in a gradual, bottom-up fashion, the same was not
true of industrialization in Germany and the Soviet Union.  England
experienced a gradual change in social relationships as capitalism
organically grew from the bottom up.  It was precisely the organic
nature of this evolution that made liberal democracy strong: if the
struggle for liberal democracy is intrinsically linked to the
economic *practice* of a class, then it is all the more likely to
hold.  This is not to say that this prevents the rise of fascism in
such countries.  It is only to say that a bottom-up industrialization
process seems to
have made liberal democracy stronger.  Top-down industrialization, on
the other hand, seems to be the economic basis for fascism. 
(Barrington Moore)  Up until Stalin, the revolution was fought in the
USSR from the bottom-up.  Stalin actually has to *abandon* the
principles of Communism, and hence the revolution, in order to carry
out his plan for industrialization.  Rather than allowing the
proletariat the power to determine production through an unalienated
relationship to production, it is the Party that decides what should
be produced, how it should be produced, how much of it should be
produced, etc.  To justify this move toward absolutism, Stalin
releases Economic Problems of Socialism in the USSR where he flatly
abandons the move from the Dictatorship of the Proletariat to
Communism, in favor of state capitalism.  State capitalism as the
impetus for industrialization, we have already seen, is one of the
material bases of fascism.

As I said, this is by no means a comprehensive analysis.  It is
merely an outline.  Moore's argument, for instance, is very involved
and complex.  I simply picked out a few things from his chapters on
England and France.  The point is that "fascist" is a term of
political theory and political economy.  It should not be used as one
would use the word "meany" or "ka-ka-head".  Unless of course you
want to sound like a desperate or insufferable twit.  Cheers, Jim.





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:927
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-26 16:10:05
Subject:Afterthot...
Message:

The relationship between Stalin and the Bolshevik Revolution is decidely more complex than I layed it out.  It is not so simple as Stalin taking power and changing the course of events.  If one analyzes this situation dialectically, it is impossible to avoid the fact that Stalin's rule grew out of Bolshevik rule and would have been impossible without the all-powerful vanguard party ruling in the place of the proletariat.  Tons has been written on this.  For example, look at Cyril Smith, "How the Marxists Buried Marx" for an historical and (mostly) philosophical exposition on this.

Jim





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:928
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-26 19:46:36
Subject:Re: [nbpc] Re: What's Hiding In GW's Cabinet? by R Lederman
Message:

First off, if there is anyone that got caught in this loop and prefers not 
to receive any more of these messages, please let us know and we'll take you 
off.  It started because I felt that there was information that had to get 
out as broadly as possible, and it has developed into a good and much needed 
debate.  That said:

*************************************************************************
Joe, thank you for your response.  I agree with you that our main task is to 
further the work of building an independent political movement and 
independent party.  How that movement is to be defined, however, will worked 
out through continued practice and theoretical discussion and debate.  It 
has been the position of the New Jersey Freedom Organization that the united 
front/coalition building is the best model to mobilize as broad a 
constituency as possible to combat the rightward surge locally and 
nationally, while simultaneously building a movement capable of more than 
protesting--that our ultimate task is the seizure of power.  As Kristina 
pointed out, we put this into practice by initiating the New Brunswick 
People's Campaign for City Council, which itself was a model for people's 
democracy (our first act was a public convention where everything from 
candidates to the campaign manager and our platform was voted on).  Although 
we didn't win the election, we mobilized the city like never before, shook 
up the entrenched power structure (who are corporate Democrats) and showed 
that they are actually most vulnerable around the question of democracy 
itself--something I think we agree that this system cannot ultimately 
deliver to the majority.

I reiterate all of this to draw a line of demarcation between types of 
independent movements, and that the reason Nader didn't win our support is 
that his campaign fell dangerously short in critical areas.  You said that 
"nobody in our movement ever said that there was 'no difference' between the 
Bush forces and the Goreistas."  This is simply not true.  It was repeated 
over and over as a mantra from the Green Party leadership to Nader's rank 
and file supporters.  If you were personally clear that there were 
contradictions, that message did not get out.  This gets back to our 
disagreement on the question of democratic revolution vs socialist 
revolution, as the present historic task.  It has been the position of NJFO, 
as put forward by Baraka, that the democratic revolution has never been 
completed--a historic fact that can be traced back to the last time the 
electoral college overturned the popular vote (Hayes-Tilden Compromise), 
which intentionally resulted in the undermining of Reconstruction in the 
south, and handing the south back to the deposed slavocracy and the Klan.

It is irresponsible for progressives and revolutionaries--especially for 
those of us who benefit from what this system does offer in terms of 
democratic rights & access to resources--to shrug and suggest that we've 
survived the right in power before, so we'll get through this.  It is the 
very same sectors of the population for which this country has never been a 
democracy that are most vulnerable to rightward swings, erosion of civil 
rights and lack of economic opportunities.

I agree that in eight years, Clinton/Gore abandoned the traditional 
Democratic constituency and raced to coopt the Republican social and 
economic agenda.  As Kris pointed out, we never once suggested that Clinton 
or Gore could be depended on as leaders of the people.  Clearly they are 
corporate whores for Imperialism; this "unprecedented" economy has had 
limited beneficiaries (certainly not those who have been downsized, 
profiled, or had their welfare de-formed) But the abandonment of the 
traditional left, and the centrist-ization of the Democrats has NOT meant 
that the Democrats and Republicans have melded into one indistinguishable 
corporate party, as HAS been asserted over and over by Greens, Naderites, 
WBAI hosts...  It means that right before our eyes, we are witnessing the 
rightward thrust of the entire political spectrum, and the Republicans are 
accelerating rapidly in that direction.  It means that the ultra-right has 
been empowered.  We need to look no farther than Ashcroft, Bush/Cheney's 
appointment to Attorney General, who is being touted as the most 
arch-conservative politician ever to hold the position.  We now have an 
honorary Bob Jones U. graduate as watchdog of the federal Civil Rights 
legislation!  This was an open concession by Bush/Cheney to their extreme 
right constituency.  Again, the ones who are going to feel the effects of 
this first and worst are the ones who already have the least access to 
democracy.

So Nader's campaign insisted that the Republi-crats are one corporate party, 
so vote for him or join the Greens, as this is the third party movement 
we've all been waiting for.  Yet, it was never a movement based on coalition 
building and united front work, with democratically elected candidates and 
leadership, not to mention platform. (Case in point was Nader's unforgivable 
positions on Roe v. Wade & states rights.) When I went to the Rutgers Law 
School in Newark to hear the Green candidates speak (Nader, Joe Fortunato, 
Bruce Afrin for NJ Senate) I didn't see anything that resembled a Newark 
based coalition movement.  The closest they came was with an endorsement 
from Larry Hamm of People's Organization for Progress, who endorsed him as 
an individual, not on behalf of an organization. The rest of the audience 
appeared to be older, white, middle-class lefties of various 
tendencies--pretty much representative of the Greens/Nader's 
constituency--but NOT in the least representative of the decades of 
roots-based revolutionary organizing that defines Newark itself. Or else 
Afrin would never have gotten away with his traitorous commentary that he 
would be proud to derail Corzine's campaign and cause "honest" Bob Franks to 
win the NJ Senate.
For the record, Nader didn't bother to distance himself from that position.

These things need to be resolved in order to move foward in a real way and 
turn this impending crisis into an opportunity.  All democratic classes must 
work tirelessly toward coalition building and a broad united front to keep 
this country from going over the precipice.  In doing so we will 
simultaneously be building the independant movement that will be capable of 
siezing political power.

On the national level, we can start with a broad call for the abolition of 
the Electoral College; Advance the call for the abolition of the Senate (the 
US version of the British House of Lords, and a leftover form of 
Constitutional Monarchy); Mobilize to end the existence of the 
anti-democratic Republican Party on the grounds that they trampled all over 
the Constitution with this election; and insist that Bush is an illegitimate 
President who was appointed by party operatives in the Supreme Court; 
Advocate against the WTO/IMF; etc.

It is on the local level, however, that we must seize power where we can put 
our hands on it--school boards, city councils, review boards, student 
governments, newspapers, and now, defending free speech on the radio by 
saving WBAI as an independant institution.  Only when we have the power to 
elect the dog-catcher can we move towards state and national level power 
struggle in a meaningful way.  But it has to come from the ground up, not 
the other way around.

In Unity & Struggle, Matthew Smith

>
>Matt:
>
>Nobody in our movement ever said that there was "no difference" between the 
>Bush forces and the Goreistas. What we were (and are) saying is that there 
>is not enough of a difference for us to forego our building towards an 
>independent political movement and party at this time.
>
>Sure, we recognize the grim reality that the Bush administration will mean 
>further and perhaps accelerated attacks on the people. But we also 
>recognize that the Clinton/Gore administration also brought about severe 
>attacks on the people in the guise of "welfare reform," Federal crime 
>bills, support for the death penalty, the embargo on Iraq (which the UN 
>says is killing 5,000 children a month), support for Star Wars and 
>increased military spending, etc., etc., ad naseum.
>
>Let's be clear about who ARE our friends and who are our enemies. The 
>Clinton/Gore administration did not succeed in stopping the right wing in 
>the eight years they held power. They barely tried. That's because their 
>lukewarm initiatives are designed to prop up this system of corporate 
>welfare and imperialist domination. Only an independent political force can 
>halt the advance of the right.
>
>Moreover, overestimating the danger of the right can only lead us to a 
>misplaced reliance on the more "liberal" sections of the bourgeoisie, 
>represented by Clinton/Gore and the entrenched labor aristocracy. The 
>situation in the US today is simply not the same as the situation in 
>pre-Hitler Germany. Although there certainly are some fascist types lurking 
>in the halls of power, most of our more conservatives in power are 
>Constitutional conservatives. To dogmatically insist that these folks are 
>fascist and that we must lineup behind the Clinton/Gore forces would be to 
>lead people into the arms of the "lesser of two evils" and would set our 
>movement back. When you support the lesser of two evils, you still get 
>evil. We have a good start towards a peoples party; let's build on it.
>
>Joe
>
>We lived through Nixon. We lived through Reagan. we lived through Bush, Sr. 
>We'll live through Junior. Many Iraqi children and Palestinian youth did 
>not live through Clinton/Gore.
>

Post ID:929
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-26 19:51:18
Subject:Fwd: [FAIR-L] ACTION ALERT: Lockout at WBAI: Pacifica management fires senior s taff, changes locks at New York station
Message:



>From: FAIR-L <FAIR-L@...>
>Reply-To: fair-l-request@...
>To: FAIR-L@...
>Subject: [FAIR-L] ACTION ALERT: Lockout at WBAI: Pacifica management fires  
>             senior s              taff, changes locks at New York station
>Date: Tue, 26 Dec 2000 15:41:13 -0500
>
>                                  FAIR-L
>                     Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting
>                Media analysis, critiques and news reports
>
>
>
>
>
>ACTION ALERT:
>LOCKOUT AT WBAI:
>Pacifica management fires senior staff, changes locks at New York station
>
>December 26, 2000
>
>The national management of Pacifica Radio has fired several long-time
>staffers at WBAI, the New York City community radio station that is home to
>the award-winning show "Democracy Now!": program director Bernard White,
>producer Sharan Harper, and station manager Valerie Van Isler (see 
>"Pacifica
>Management Move to Undermine WBAI's Independence,"
>http://www.fair.org/press-releases/van-isler.html ).
>
>Accompanied by security guards, Pacifica executive director Bessie Wash
>arrived at WBAI late at night on Friday, December 23, and changed the locks
>both to the station and to individual offices. WBAI staff-- including
>"Democracy Now!"'s Amy Goodman--  are now being admitted to the building
>only on a "controlled entry" basis until further notice. White and Harper
>have been threatened with arrest should they attempt to enter the building.
>
>Pacifica has appointed WBAI afternoon talk show host Utrice Leid as acting
>station manager. Last week, WBAI news director Jose Santiago turned down 
>the
>job, saying he had been falsely assured by management that Van Isler was
>resigning voluntarily. Since the lockout, Leid has asserted on air that the
>crisis is simply an internal personnel dispute. Given Pacifica management's
>recent embrace of arbitrary firings and other autocratic management
>techniques, this is at best hard to believe.
>
>The current crisis is reminiscent of last year's lockout at KPFA in
>Berkeley, which also came on the heels of a number of politically motivated
>firings. That lockout brought thousands of Berkeley listeners out into the
>streets to protest Pacifica management's actions and demand greater
>accountability to the community, in keeping with the progressive core 
>values
>laid out by Pacifica founder Lew Hill.
>
>Over the last year and a half, Pacifica's management has increasingly
>orchestrated censorship-- including of FAIR's own radio show, CounterSpin--
>retaliatory personnel moves and the disenfranchisement of listeners and
>local advisory boards in order to impose its often regressive decisions on
>the network. FAIR had feared that Pacifica's recent moves against 
>"Democracy
>Now!" (see http://www.fair.org/activism/democracy-now.html ) were an
>indication that the network was preparing an attempt to break the
>independence of WBAI, one of the cornerstones of the progressive community.
>The holiday firings and lockout have more than confirmed those fears.
>
>When FAIR asked for help in supporting "Democracy Now!" against harassment
>from Pacifica management this October, members of our email list responded
>passionately and swiftly, writing over 1,300 letters to Pacifica in just
>over four days, and organizing demonstrations across the country.
>
>Since then, listener meetings and demonstrations have been ongoing, and
>early signs are that listeners are responding to this latest crisis with
>just as much energy. Despite the organizing difficulties presented by the
>holiday season and below-freezing temperatures, listeners have already 
>begun
>to take action in New York City. Several dozen people held a vigil outside
>WBAI's Manhattan studios on the night of the lockout, and hundreds attended
>a demonstration outside the building on Saturday the 23rd. Daily protests
>are planned outside the station from four to six pm, beginning Tuesday,
>December 26.
>
>As a media watch group dedicated to strengthening democracy by defending a
>free press, FAIR decries the lockout and recent firings at WBAI. We urge
>Pacifica to immediately reinstate Van Isler, White and Harper, and to cease
>restricting employee access to the station. We stand in solidarity with the
>staff and listeners of WBAI who are fighting to win democratic, community
>control of their station.
>
>For more information about the ongoing crisis at Pacifica, see:
>http://www.fair.org/activism/pacifica-history.html
>
>ACTION:
>1. The group Concerned Friends of WBAI is urging New York City listeners to
>attend a community planning meeting this Wednesday, December 27, 6:30 pm at
>SEIU Local 32 B-J, 101 Sixth Avenue. For more information, see:
>http://www.wbai.net .
>
>Concerned listeners in other cities should check the Save Pacifica website
>for updates and for links to local listener groups that may be organizing 
>in
>their area: http://www.savepacifica.net .
>
>2. Please call or write to Pacifica and let them know that you support the
>locked out WBAI staffers. Urge the network to reinstate Valerie Van Isler,
>Bernard White and Sharan Harper, and to cease harassment of WBAI employees.

Post ID:932
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-29 11:50:43
Subject:recycle the old bastards!
Message:

time to get the seat belts out, folks, cuz we're heading backward in time 
and PRONTO!!!


December 29, 2000
Defense Secretary Chosen; Held Same Post Under Ford
By ERIC SCHMITT

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 � President-elect George W. Bush today selected Donald 
H. Rumsfeld, a veteran Washington insider and champion of missile defenses, 
to be secretary of defense, the same job Mr. Rumsfeld held in the Ford 
administration a quarter-century ago before entering the world of business.

Picking Mr. Rumsfeld, 68, a blunt- spoken former Navy fighter pilot and 
Illinois congressman, brings to the Pentagon's top job a man with the 
military experience and stature on Capitol Hill to press Mr. Bush's 
priorities to modernize the armed forces and build a missile shield against 
emerging threats.

"This is a man who has got great judgment," Mr. Bush told reporters here, 
introducing Mr. Rumsfeld. "He has got strong vision. And he's going to be a 
great secretary of defense � again."

Conservatives, already elated by Mr. Bush's selection of Senator John 
Ashcroft of Missouri, to be attorney general-designate, expressed jubilation 
today at the selection of Mr. Rumsfeld, a foreign policy hawk and social 
conservative who served as national chairman of Bob Dole's failed 
presidential campaign in 1996. Senators from both parties predicted a swift 
confirmation.

Mr. Bush made the surprise announcement here today with Vice President-elect 
Dick Cheney standing silently by his side.

Mr. Rumsfeld, who has long-term political ties to Mr. Cheney, was reported 
to be a front-runner as the next director of central intelligence, but his 
name came up for defense secretary after Mr. Bush expressed second thoughts 
about two leading candidates for that job. Those candidates were former 
Senator Daniel R. Coats of Indiana, who left Mr. Bush unconvinced after a 
meeting on Dec. 18 that the senator was the right man for the job, and Paul 
D. Wolfowitz, a former top Pentagon official who some in the Bush camp 
feared could be overwhelmed by the sprawling military bureaucracy. Mr. 
Cheney was then directed to broaden the search.

Mr. Cheney has played a major role in cabinet selections, but never more so 
than with Mr. Rumsfeld. It was Mr. Rumsfeld who brought Mr. Cheney into the 
Ford White House as a deputy chief of staff, and who has been the vice 
president-elect's prototype of a political executive ever since.

The two men share remarkably similar r�sum�s � congressman, White House 
chief of staff, secretary of defense and corporate chief executive � as well 
as a results-driven, no- nonsense management style. Mr. Cheney was the last 
Republican secretary of defense, serving under Mr. Bush's father, President 
George Bush, and had a very clear idea of the ideal candidate for the job: 
qualifications that Mr. Rumsfeld fit to a T.

The only trick was persuading Mr. Rumsfeld to serve again, a challenge that 
Mr. Cheney took on over the past several days, transition aides said.

"I tell you, this has all happened very rapidly," Mr. Rumsfeld, who has been 
working as an independent consultant, told reporters.

Mr. Rumsfeld, who served as secretary of defense for 14 months from 1975 to 
1977, after the withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam, is a skilled 
bureaucratic infighter who will serve as a complement and counterweight on 
Mr. Bush's national security team, especially to Gen. Colin L. Powell, the 
secretary of state-designate.

But he is perhaps best known recently for heading a bipartisan panel in 1998 
that concluded that nations like North Korea and Iran could threaten the 
United States with long- range missiles sooner than American intelligence 
analysts had predicted. This has led Mr. Rumsfeld to be a leading advocate 
for missile defenses against such threats.

The panel's report became one of the most influential in recent American 
military planning. Mr. Rumsfeld was among a group of Republican foreign 
policy luminaries, including Henry A. Kissinger and George P. Shultz, former 
secretaries of state, who flanked Mr. Bush at a news conference in May when 
the the Texas governor renewed his pledge to develop robust missile 
defenses.

With Mr. Rumsfeld's nomination, Mr. Bush has chosen eight members he expects 
to have in his cabinet. There are 14 statutory cabinet members, but every 
president can elevate any number of agencies to that level during his term. 
All of them must be confirmed by the Senate.

Aides said they expected Mr. Bush to make additional personnel announcements 
on Friday before returning to Texas to celebrate the New Year at his ranch.

Mr. Bush said he hoped to have his cabinet appointments finished by the end 
of the first week of January, adding with a laugh that he did not want to be 
held to that deadline.

"Let me just put it to you this way: On Inauguration Day, we will be ready 
to assume our respective offices," Mr. Bush said.

But the president-elect acknowledged that he was having trouble fulfilling 
his goal of recruiting a Democrat or two to serve in his cabinet.

"I've talked to some Democrats about whether or not there may be an interest 
of leaving their current positions," Mr. Bush said. "And most people want to 
stay in place."

Mr. Bush did make several senior White House staff appointments today. He 
named Joseph Hagin, a deputy campaign manager, to be deputy chief of staff 
for operations; and Joshua Bolten, the campaign policy director, to be 
deputy chief of staff for policy. Ari Fleischer, the campaign and transition 
spokesman, was named White House press secretary.

Mr. Cheney also announced that two former Pentagon aides would join his 
White House staff: I. Lewis Libby to be his chief of staff and David 
Addington to be his counsel.

Explaining why he chose Mr. Rumsfeld, Mr. Bush noted his experience in 
government and in the corporate world. But he underscored Mr. Rumsfeld's 
role on the missile-threat panel.

"`I felt he did an extraordinary job with a delicate assignment," Mr. Bush 
said. "He brought people together to understand the realities of the modern 
world."

Mr. Bush said he would rely on Mr. Rumsfeld to do "a selling job" on 
Congress to support not only the contentious missile defense proposal, which 
faces strong opposition from many Democrats as well as foreign allies, but 
also the costly task of revamping the military to deal with a new security 
threats, from terrorism to chemical-weapon attacks.

"One of Secretary Rumsfeld's first tasks will be to challenge the status quo 
inside the Pentagon, to develop a strategy necessary to have a force 
equipped for warfare of the 21st century," Mr. Bush said.

Mr. Rumsfeld kept his remarks brief and rather broad: "It is clearly not a 
time at the Pentagon for presiding or calibrating modestly. Rather, we are 
in a new national security environment. We do need to be arranged to deal 
with the new threats, not the old ones, with information warfare, missile 
defense, terrorism, defense of our space assets and the proliferation of 
weapons of mass destruction throughout the world."

One area that Mr. Rumsfeld said he would not revisit is the military's 
"don't ask, don't tell" policy on gays in the armed forces.

"That is not an issue that President-elect Bush has discussed in his 
pronouncements on defense," Mr. Rumsfeld said.

On Capitol Hill, Mr. Rumsfeld's announcement won praise from Democrats and 
Republicans.

"The nation is fortunate that this experienced, tested, tough-minded `old 
hand' joins the strong Bush corral for national security," said Senator John 
W. Warner, a Virginia Republican who heads the Armed Services Committee, 
which will hold confirmation hearings on Mr. Rumsfeld.

The committee's senior Democrat, Carl Levin of Michigan, called Mr. Rumsfeld 
"a strong choice."

At today's news conference, Mr. Bush offered insight into how he envisions 
his national security team to work and what his role will be. When asked how 
much influence Mr. Cheney and his close friend and ally, General Powell, a 
former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, would have at the Pentagon, 
Mr. Bush said, "I think little."

Then, warming to a subject that he has acknowledged having little expertise 
in, Mr. Bush continued, referring to Mr. Rumsfeld, "I picked a strong leader 
who is willing to listen to others but is a decisive leader. General 
Powell's a strong figure, and Dick Cheney's no shrinking violet. But neither 
is Don Rumsfeld."

"There's going to be disagreements," Mr. Bush said. "I hope there is 
disagreement, because I know the disagreement will be based upon solid 
thought. And what you need to know is that if there is disagreement, I'll be 
prepared to make the decision necessary for the good of the country."



_________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com

Post ID:933
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-12-28 12:34:30
Subject:money, money
Message:

this is interesting...

Campaign costs soar in towns

12/28/00

BY JOE DONOHUE
STAR-LEDGER STAFF

No one has to tell Helen Merolla that the cost of local political campaigns 
is soaring.


As an independent candidate in Piscataway this year, she lost by nearly a 
2-1 margin after Democratic mayoral candidate Brian Wahler outspent her 
$230,000 to $10,000.


"What they did was to produce glossies that arrived at the house every day 
for about 10 days. That's very difficult to overcome," she said.


"I'm extremely flattered by the amount of money that was spent. The 
Democratic organization normally spends about $50,000 on an election," she 
said.


The Piscataway election is a microcosm of what is happening throughout the 
state, according to a study released yesterday by the state Election Law 
Enforcement Commission.


Local campaigns are becoming increasingly sophisticated as more candidates 
use polls, consultants, cable television, the Internet and other modern 
campaign techniques.


But while more councilmen, mayors and freeholders are campaigning like 
legislators and members of Congress, they also are starting to have to shell 
out big bucks.


In 1995, candidates for mayor in Hamilton Township in Mercer County spent a 
combined $187,000. Last year, the campaign spending topped $415,000.


In Woodbridge, local campaigns cost $675,501 in 1999. Brick Township 
candidates sank $205,951 into their races. Cherry Hill candidates spent 
$167,078.


Combined, local and county candidates last year spent a record $17 million, 
according to a new study by ELEC. The average candidate spent $27,829, and 
total spending was up nearly 63 percent above the $11 million spent a decade 
earlier. That's comparable to the percentage increase in spending by state 
legislative candidates.


ELEC officials said local candidates have learned some of the same lessons 
as their big league counterparts. To win, you need every advantage. But 
winning can be expensive.


"There is significant financial activity at the local level, and that 
financial activity at this level is largely following trends at other levels 
of New Jersey politics," says the 53-page report.


Jeffrey Brindle, ELEC's deputy director and author of the study, said he 
examined spending by 50 randomly selected candidates to see where they got 
their money and how they spent it. More than 600 candidates ran in local 
races last year.


One finding was that 76 percent of all of local donations came from party 
organizations, mostly county and municipal. Another 10 percent came from 
business interests, 9 percent from individuals, and smaller amounts were 
from unions and political action committees.


The dominance of local parties, Brindle said, is due "in part to the fact 
that many local candidates are newly recruited to run for public office, and 
are dependent on local party organizations to undertake the everyday tasks 
of running a campaign."


By contrast, state legislators received just 17 percent of their donations 
from political parties. They can draw on contributors from a much larger 
area, and, unlike local candidates, tend to get financial help from 
colleagues in safe districts or leadership posts.


"In general, local candidates tap those individuals and businesses within 
the local area. Incumbent legislators, in particular, draw up Trenton 
lobbyists, legislative leadership committees and state party committees," 
the report says.


Brindle also found that 68 percent of the expenditures were for mass 
communication, primarily pamphlets mailed to the homes of voters.


"Of the dollars spent on mass communications, 80 percent was directed toward 
print advertising, with the majority of those expenditures committed to 
direct mail," he said.


William Dressel, executive director of the New Jersey League of 
Municipalities, said local officials regularly lament the surging cost of 
campaigns. But they also have asked the league to sponsor regular seminars 
for campaign advice, such as how to use Census data and e-mail to target 
voters.


"This isn't just door-knocking or working the crowd at the county fair 
anymore," he said. "These are really sophisticated campaign efforts that 
emulate state and federal campaigns, and one consequence is it is costing 
more."


Garabed "Chuck" Haytaian, chairman of the Republican State Committee, said 
he often is impressed by political novices these days because they seem 
better prepared than challengers a decade ago.


"They are much more informed, and I think a lot of that is because of the 
Internet," he said.


Star-Ledger staff writer Towanda Underdue contributed to this report.

_________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:934
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-12-30 22:35:32
Subject:Re: Fascism vs. Communism
Message:

I restrained myself from quoting the whole message.  Let me just 
respond to one point that I think is important ... 


> make no mistake: while the fascist leader pays such lip service to
> these classes, he is *actually* supported, the entire time, by the
> most powerful industrialists.  The gran bourgeoisie, not the petite
> bourgeoisie, are the ones who abandon liberal democracy and bring in
> a Strongman to restore law and order against the proletariat.  (For
> more on this aspect of fascism, see Karl Marx, 18th Brumaire of 
Louis
> Bonaparte, or Barrington Moore, Social Origins of Dictatorship and
> Democracy).

Okay, the problem here is differentiating between 1) The relationship 
between capitalism and fascism at the time of the _creation_ of a 
dictatorship ... versus 2) The relationship between capitalism and 
fascism after the dictatorship has been fully established.  In other 
words, do _capitalists_ intend a dictatorship (1) or do they (2) 
merely adapt opportunistically to the dictatorship once it is 
established?  

Historically, capitalism adapted comfortably and happily to Fascism.  
But fascism was never intended by the 'big bourgeoisie'.  Especially 
in Germany.  I'll briefly list the following articles of proof with 
respect to the Nazis:

1)  The power to appoint the Chancellor (in 1933) stood with a tiny 
clique of isolated individuals surrounding the aging President 
Hindenberg.  These included a few trusted old military figures and 
Hindenberg's son.  Hitler's ascension to power was indeed determined 
by very contingent political factors, by human choices.  A military 
dictatorship was all but fated; a Nazi dictatorship was not.  The 
last Chancellor before Hitler, Kurt von Schleicher, could have rather 
easily lead a military coup, and there might have never been a Nazi 
dictatorship.  In fact, he seriously considered doing so.    

2)  The 'big bourgeoisie' mostly opposed the Nazis, at worst 
supporting the more authoritarian of the basically liberal (if not 
fully democratic) parties.  THIS is an important point:  there may 
have been an element of elitism on the part of many industrialists.  
But this elitism, paradoxically, looked down upon the Antisemitism of 
the Fascists as vulgar, ugly and stupid.  It may have even been 
viewed as a phenomenon of 'mob rule'.  

3)  Many of the industrialists were at the head of industries that 
benefitted from free trade policies.  The Nazis were shrill in their 
condemnation of 'free trade'.  

4)  Exceedingly detailed research has been done on how the Nazi party 
was funded.  All records point to a mass-based funding model much 
like the Communists and Social Democrats, with greater reliance on 
money collected from party rallies (which were much more spectacular 
than those of the SPD or CP).  Industrialists contributed almost 
nothing; when they contributed at all, it was very late in the game, 
and only as a kind of desperate bribe.  Only one steel magnate, a man 
by the name of Fritz Thyssen, openly supported and contributed to the 
Nazis.  In 1934, he recanted and fled the country.  

There is only one argument that would seem at all logical.  It's a 
bit roundabout.  

Industrialists during the Weimar period did _not_ contribute to the 
Nazis, generally, nor support them.  They _did_, however, contribute 
to the liberal parties, the left-liberal DDP and the right-liberal 
DVP, in particular.  In the late 20's, they began to cut back their 
funding, because they found that they were entirely unable to 
influence the nation's economic policy through their support of, and 
contributions to, these parties.  This helped lead to the collapse of 
the centrist parties, and thereby the parties that frequently aligned 
with the SPD to neutralize the Nazis. It also led to the effective 
collapse of parliamentary rule.  But this hardly amounts to saying 
that the bourgeoisie wanted fascism.  

Otherwise, yes, the bourgeoisie adapted to Fascism just fine.  But 
Fascism is primarily political; it means the primacy of politics over 
economics, not the other way around.  

Bye,

Jeremy





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Post ID:4443
Sender:"Fred Kemp" <ccsq@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-01-14 11:43:27
Subject:adequately metaphorical
Message:

Let me descend for once into the dull abyss of facts. Here is no glorious birth for soul and spirit as that whichsprang from me in Reading Gaol.
This is a maxim which might be taken to heart by ourmodern business girls. Before we had started he asked mewhether it would make any difference if he closed his eyes. My spirit, which created beauty, was spirit; a passionate spirit cravingfor form and colour. This confusion may haveoccurred in connection with the next memory, referring to FatherPrideau-Fox. Echoes fromthat source might readily rise upwards.
It is interesting that the word toolshould be used of Mr.
To put it very mildly, themost favourable condition is suspension of consciousness. I felt it rather difficult and dangerous ground to ask about Wildesprison experience.
He seemed only half conscious, his eyes were closed. He seemed infact to have less power than the other members of my class.
Thesethings are of no real vital consequence.
V, had several sittings for ouijaboard work with me at the British College of Psychic Science.
Ruyssemberg said: We would liketo know your opinion of life beyond the grave. On the occasion, when a strong circle waspresent, Mr. I quote three passages from the ouijamessages relating to Wildes state on the other side. I dontknow where he lived in London, do you?
In rejecting it, the French didme great service therefore.
It is interesting that the word toolshould be used of Mr. This was rather moreencouraging, but it did not indicate that Mr.
I knew the Dublin address and no attempt was made togive it; I knew Lady Wildes nom de plume, Mr.
He wished to continue theautomatic writing.
To put it very mildly, themost favourable condition is suspension of consciousness. Satisfactory conditions chiefly consist in freedomfrom distraction of any kind whatever.
